title: Suicide Bomber Kills 8 at Iraqi Market
description: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber on Saturday attacked a group of Iraqi soldiers at an entrance of a large market in the northern city of Mosul, killing 5 soldiers and 3 other people and wounding 19, according to an Iraqi security official.

title: Sushi and Asian Fusion, Infinitely Varied
description: XAGA combines two restaurant trends that show no signs of slowing: sushi and Asian fusion. The full name of this six-month-old restaurant in Merrick is, in fact, Xaga Sushi Asian Fusion. It has an older sibling with the same name in Hewlett.

title: A Cheerful Brasserie, With Sweet Accents
description: THE BRASSERIE is a cheerful, attractive French restaurant within walking distance of the Fairfield train station. It has loads of character: exposed brick walls and a large blackboard listing handwritten specials. Tables are comfortably spaced, and the single-page menu offers a variety of appealing choices  French and not-so-French  like tapas, burgers, frogs legs, bouillabaisse and short ribs. But as I watched the restaurant fill almost to capacity on a recent Saturday evening, I wondered if the rest of the room knew something I didnt.

title: Levee Breach Moves One Step Closer
description: CAIRO, Ill.  Chugging north along the Mississippi River, twin barges laden with more than 250 tons of explosive material were ordered to dock at a final staging area on Saturday in an apparent sign that the Army Corps of Engineers was making further preparations to breach a nearby levee, inundating roughly 130,000 acres of Missouri farmland to relieve pressure on the groaning levee system upstream.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Only Missing Ingredient Is a Bit of Quiet
description: I HAVE one word of advice for Larry Fishman, owner of the Rail House 1449: textiles.

title: Baked Goods, Nothing Added
description: Susan OKeefe was looking for a commercial kitchen to expand her wholesale baking business when she came across a sunny retail space in Croton-on-Hudson that changed her perspective. Home to a series of pizza parlors, the storefront is now redolent with the smell of baking cookies, cakes and muffins.

title: Where the Diners Linger
description: Kathy West, co-owner of the Mockingbird Cafe, calls herself my own worst promoter. But the charming 40-seat cafe she and her husband, Tom, opened in August does a pretty good job of promoting itself.

title: Coming Together Amid the Wreckage
description: The tornadoes that ripped through the South last week have been the deadliest natural disaster on American soil since Hurricane Katrina.

title: A Bakery That Loves Butter
description: Dont judge La Brioche French Bakery by its dcor. The pine wainscoting, orange and red walls and linoleum floor all date to a previous era, when the building was occupied by the Boston Bakery. It is the delectable spread of breads and pastries that most clearly reflects the abilities of the current tenant, Colette Berube.

title: Thank You for Taking Our Teams Call. Now Please Hold.
description: They pipe music through Radio City Music Hall between picks at the N.F.L. draft. But the real background noise accompanying the three-day restocking for future seasons was provided by the legal maneuvering surrounding the lockout that threatens the start of the next one.

title: Police Look Into Complaint by Walcott After Traffic Stop
description: A New York police official said on Saturday that an internal departmental investigation had been initiated into the treatment of the citys schools chancellor, Dennis M. Walcott, by two plainclothes police officers during a traffic stop in Queens on Thursday night.

title: Blushing Newcomer
description: Rosato di Refosco hardly sounds like a wine from the East End. But it is the fourth and latest rosato  ros in Italian  at the innovative Channing Daughters Winery in Bridgehampton. This newcomer is a winner.

title: How Happy Are You? A Census Wants to Know
description: SOMERVILLE, Mass.  When they filled out the citys census forms this spring, the people of Somerville got a new question. On a scale of 1 to 10, they were asked, How happy do you feel right now?

title: A Couples Offerings of Film, Theater and Music
description: ARMONK, N.Y.

title: Celebrating a Few Fertile Years in the Hamptons
description: In 1953, Conrad Marca-Relli, an artist associated with the Abstract Expressionists, left Manhattan, with all its distractions, for a cottage in Springs, a quiet hamlet in the town of East Hampton. His new home  in terrible shape, as he wrote years later  was next to the property of the painters Jackson Pollock and his wife, Lee Krasner.

title: To Sell First Novel, Putting That Marketing Degree to Use
description: GREENLAWN, N.Y.

title: Central Florida to Review Recruiting
description: Central Florida is taking allegations of potential N.C.A.A. violations raised in a New York Times article very seriously, according to a statement released by the university. A highly rated recruit, Kevin Ware, said that Central Florida used an intermediary, Kenneth Caldwell, to help recruit him, even arranging three-way telephone calls with Coach Donnie Jones when coaches were prohibited from contact with recruits. Caldwell has an extensive criminal record and ties to a prominent sport agent, though Caldwell denies working for an agent.

title: The Joys and the Perils of Parenthood, Set to Music
description: RATED P, a new musical being staged May 5 to 8 at the South Orange Performing Arts Center, is about parenthood  the whole thing, from the time you find out youre pregnant all the way until the time you send them off to college, said the writer, Sandy Rustin, of Maplewood.

title: When Twin Towers Were a Dream
description: Matt Schatz, a versatile playwright-lyricist-composer, could have written a drama about a serious subject like the Iraq war or a frivolous musical with singing nuns or clueless Mormon missionaries. Those are the sorts of things that are big on Broadway this year. But Mr. Schatz chose to write a play about the relatively unpromising topic of the World Trade Centers structural design.

title: In Tornado Zone, Many Ask, How Can We Help?
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  So many contractors showed up at a high school gymnasium here on Saturday that they could not all fit. Even though the death count continued its grim climb upward in what is now the worst tornado disaster in the country since 1925, here at the epicenter people know that the rebuilding has to begin, and quickly.

title: Vows: Jill & Guy
description: Jill Kaufman, a New Yorker, and Guy Tallent of Tennessee were going through divorces when they first met. They have since integrated two families  three kids under eight  into a new one.

title: Gatlin Looking to Outrun Competition and Suspicions
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: After Disaster, Skater Brings a Little Smile to the People of Japan
description: MOSCOW  If all had gone according to plan, the dateline on this story from the world figure skating championships would have been Tokyo. But the national tragedy that began with a powerful earthquake in the Pacific Ocean changed all that for Japan, just as it has disrupted so many plans and lives since March 11.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Calendar, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Romney Catches Himself on Hang Metaphor
description: Mitt Romney, like many politicians, is no stranger to embarrassing statements: just a few months into his presidential run in 2008 he had already made so many gaffes that Time magazine put together a Top 10 list.

title: Curves of the City
description: The domes and arches built by the Guastavino Company are everywhere, but you have to look for them.

title: A Panoramic View of Guastavino
description: Some of the best work by Rafael Guastavino y Moreno and his son, Rafael Guastavino y Esposito, is out of the public eye.

title: In These Portraits, a Challenge to Labels of Sitter and Artist
description: The people have spoken, and the Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum listened. Research conducted by the museum found that community members would like to see more exhibitions linked together by a common theme. And while giving the people what they want is not always a successful strategy  either for increasing museum attendance, or for art in general  it works well in the first exhibitions under the new plan, a group of six solo projects by contemporary artists titled Portraiture at the Aldrich Contemporary Museum.

title: Evoking Jazz, Through Film
description: CAN one art form evoke another? The filmmakers Paul Bernays and Oren Jacoby think so. Working independently, some 15 years apart, each made a documentary about jazz that he hoped would mirror the music itself. The films will be shown at Jazz Sessions: The Greats on Camera 2011 at the Jacob Burns Film Center  in Pleasantville.

title: Lottery Numbers
description: April 30, 2011

title: For Want of a Draw, a Player Loses the U.S. Title
description: Yury Shulman forgot the old saying that a tie is better than a loss during his quest to win the United States Chess Championship last week. And that opened the door for Gata Kamsky to capture his second straight title.

title: Obama Zings Trump at White House Correspondents Dinner
description: Joe Biden. Michele Bachmann. Tim Pawlenty. Donald Trump.

title: At N.F.L. Draft, Jets Collect a Rogues Gallery of Talent
description: FLORHAM PARK, N.J.  In two seasons under Coach Rex Ryan, the Jets have operated as if no player is too risky, no background too questionable, no reputation too sullied. They have welcomed all types of questionable characters, as if starting an N.F.L. halfway house, and with consecutive trips to the A.F.C. title game, this strategy has worked, for the most part.

title: Lizas Back on Broadway
description: Photos of Liza Minnelli in Lizas at the Palace ...

title: Medieval Art at the Met
description: The Metropolitan Museum unveils its newly renovated medieval gallery and, in the adjacent sculpture hall, Choirs of Angels, a sumptuous little holiday show.

title: More Minnelli
description: Photos of some of Liza Minnellis performances on stage and screen.

title: Daily Replay: April 30
description: A highlight of the days sporting including gold medals, Rugby break-aways, and the Warrior Dash obstacle race.

title: Photos From the White House Correspondents Dinner
Paperback Business Best Sellers
Hardcover Business Best Sellers
Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Job Losses in November
description: The nations employers shed 533,000 jobs in November, the 11th consecutive monthly decline, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported Friday. Not since December 1974, toward the end of a severe recession, have so many jobs disappeared in a single month. The unemployment rate rose to 6.7 percent, up just two-tenths of a percentage point from October in part because it does not include all those too discouraged to look for work any longer or those working fewer hours than they would like. The number of part-time workers who want full-time work rose sharply, to 7.3 million, up 62.2 percent from November of last year.

title: New York Through a Looking Glass
description: At the Holiday Train Show at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx, electric trains run in loops around botanical versions of city landmarks.

title: The Faces of the Unemployed
description: A portfolio of images from across the country as the ranks of the unemployed grow.

title: Walking a Tightrope Between Nationalist and Populist
description: Ollanta Humala, the front-runner in Perus coming presidential election, has distanced himself from the far-left leanings of his 2006 bid in favor of a more populist approach, but transforming voters doubts into support is proving difficult.

title: Costly Afghanistan Road Project Is Marred by Unsavory Alliances
description: GARDEZ, Afghanistan  When construction crews faced attacks while working on a major American-financed highway here in southeastern Afghanistan, Western contractors turned to a powerful local figure named simply Arafat, who was suspected to have links to Afghanistans insurgents.

title: SACs Cohens Tells of Rough Six Months
description: Editors note: This post refers to an 2010 article in Vanity Fair. It was published in error.

title: Pragues Answer to Oktoberfest
description: The Czech Beer Festival is Pragues answer to Oktoberfest.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 1
description: With Congress gearing up for a debate over the debt ceiling, discussion of federal spending and the budget dominates the Sunday talk shows. But following President Obamas announcement of sanctions on Syrian officials and another week of Republican presidential posturing, the Middle East and the 2012 election are also on the agenda.

title: Giants Picks in 2011 N.F.L. Draft
description: The Giants continued to shore up defensive positions on the third day of the draft, grabbing a safety and two linebackers, including the all-American Greg Jones in the sixth round.

title: 7 Tips for Great Wedding Pictures
description: If the Royal Wedding hasnt yet made you aware of just how mundane wedding photos can be, June is coming soon with fresh opportunities for clichd group shots (Smile! Smile, everybody! Smile!)

title: Jets Picks in 2011 N.F.L. Draft
description: The Jets focused on defensive linemen in the early rounds of the draft, but turned their attention to offense Saturday, including trading up in the fifth round to get T.C.U. receiver Jeremy Kerley. Their last two picks, Greg McElroy and Scotty McKnight, have known Mark Sanchez for years.

title: ESPN, Mark Ingram and a Make-Him-Cry Moment
description: Not long after Alabama running back Mark Ingram was selected by the Saints with the 28th overall pick in the draft on Thursday, Suzy Kolber interviewed him for ESPN. After an initial question and response, Kolber read him an e-mail from Mark Ingram Sr., his father, who is in prison.

title: Stone House by the Sea
description: Behind the scenes at the home of Alexandre de Betak in Majorca.

title: John Paul II Beatified at Vatican Mass
description: VATICAN CITY  Lauding John Paul II as a giant of 20th-century history as well as a hero of the church, Pope Benedict XVI moved his towering predecessor one step closer to sainthood on Sunday in a celebratory Mass that drew more than a million people to Rome.

title: Defining, and Measuring, Happiness
description: I encourage you to read John Tierneys article, How Happy Are You? In a Boston Suburb, Its a Census Question. Heres the nut of the story, which speaks of an interesting effort in Somerville, Mass., to follow the lead of Bhutan and other countries testing new ways to gauge progress:

title: Israel Holds Palestinian Funds as Deal Nears
description: JERUSALEM  Israel said Sunday that it was delaying the transfer of almost $90 million in tax revenue owed to the Palestinian Authority in a move against the emerging reconciliation between Fatah, the party that dominates the authority, and its Islamic rival, Hamas.

title: One Fish, Two Fish, False-ish, True-ish
description: Two University of Washington scientists have just published a study in the journal Conservation Biology in collaboration with colleagues from Rutgers University and Dalhousie University arguing that the gloomiest predictions about the worlds fisheries are significantly exaggerated.

title: Fiscalization and Hellenization
description: Kevin ORourke leads us to a good complaint by Colm McCarthy about the ECBs handling of the eurozone crisis. McCarthy tells us that

title: Finding the Drama in What Life Has Left Behind
description: It is not often you see a couple of characters dashing around the Bronx dressed in Kiplingesque explorers outfits. But last summer, two actors named Joey Rizzolo and Christopher Borg pulled on their aviator goggles and straightened their bow ties and set off on an expedition.

title: Reaction to NATO Strike
description: Libyans react to the NATO airstrike late Saturday night that Libyan officials said killed Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's youngest son, Seif al-Arab Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Mixed TV Ratings for the Royal Wedding
description: The wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton on Friday was a snooze for most Americans, according to television audience estimates. Still, it amounted to a record ratings day for some television channels.

title: Mixed TV Ratings for the Royal Wedding
description: The wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton on Friday was a snooze for most Americans, according to television audience estimates. Still, it amounted to a record ratings day for some television channels.

title: The Beatification of John Paul II
description: Lauding John Paul II as a giant of 20th century history, Pope Benedict XVI moved his predecessor one step closer to sainthood in a celebratory Mass on Sunday.

title: Allies Defending Actions in Libya After Airstrike
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  NATO officials and Western leaders defended the increasingly aggressive airstrikes in Libya on Sunday after the Libyan government said one barrage had killed four members of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis family, raising criticism that the attacks exceeded the Security Council resolution authorizing the use of force.

title: Money Talks, Regulation Walks
description: The Times editorial page is outraged at the proposal to exempt foreign-exchange swaps from regulation  and rightly so. Have we learned nothing from the crisis?

title: Key Piece of Air France Data Recorder Is Found
description: PARIS  French accident investigators said Sunday that they had retrieved a key component from one of the flight recorders of an Air France jet that crashed in the mid-Atlantic almost two years ago, reviving hopes that it could help explain why the plane went down.

title: Grandersons New Swing Continues To Pay Off
description: Yankees center fielder Curtis Granderson hit another home run Sunday, his 22nd since last Aug. 14, or about the time Kevin Long, the teams hitting coach, helped Granderson simplify his swing. Granderson apparently hit the refresh button on his mental approach then, too.

title: A Canadian Party Gains Strength
description: OTTAWA  When Canadas government collapsed in March, setting in motion a federal election to be held Monday, the timing looked especially bleak for the New Democrats, the perennial third-place party.

title: Four Ensembles Unite for a Contemporary Composers Big Birthday
description: Steve Reich is in the enviable position, for a living composer, of not having to wait for milestone birthday celebrations to hear his music performed. Certain seminal works  Drumming (1971), Music for 18 Musicians (1976) and Different Trains (1988)  are heard at least once a season, and new scores are added immediately to his expansive Nonesuch discography. So when those birthdays do come  like Mr. Reichs 75th birthday, on Oct. 3  the stakes are raised: How do you make a concert of a composers works seem special when the music is heard all the time?

title: Sensual Spanish Accent Arrives by Way of Quebec
description: Lots of shows do their best to break down the fourth wall, but tango productions tend to rely on it. There the audience members are, seated demurely in their rows of chairs, while on stage the dancers and musicians, dressed to the glittery nines, evoke sultry encounters in romantic, far-flung locales. The whole point is to be transported to another place.

title: Roger Cohen Reports From Libya
description: From Ajdabiya, the Op-Ed columnist Roger Cohen urges NATO to keep up pressure on Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and his supporters.

title: An Underworld Rescue With Dancers and Chorus
description: A renewed sense of loss is inevitable when the Metropolitan Opera revives the Mark Morris production of Glucks Orfeo ed Euridice, which was originally conceived for the superb mezzo-soprano Lorraine Hunt Lieberson, who died in 2006, 10 months before it was first performed. That sense became even more acute when the production returned on Friday evening, just a week after the death of Hunt Liebersons husband, the composer Peter Lieberson, also from cancer.

title: A Viola and a Piano in Search of Common Ground
description: One may be the loneliest number, but two can be the most revealing. More than other ensembles, musical duos suggest narratives: rival siblings, say, or a blissful romance. But at a duet recital on Thursday evening at Carnegie Hall, the image that came to mind was of a couple out to dinner, each partner talking intently on his cellphone.

title: Stage Where the Blood Is Real and Freshly Drawn
description: On Friday night a recording of Ivo Dimchevs voice preceded his appearance in Som Faves with some words about the performance to follow: My body will lose energy; We are all going to lose time; and Somebody will even lose his own blood.

title: Tunes for the Swank Whod Rather Cha-Cha
description: The Copacabana, the Latin Quarter, El Morocco, the Stork Club, the Blue Angel and on and on: nowadays these fabled names tend to dissolve into a hazy, undifferentiated fantasy of glamour, cafe society and Manhattan nightlife before television arrived to change everything. And on Saturday evening the mists shrouding a world that is remembered largely by word of mouth and vintage live recordings were dissipated at the 92nd St. Ys new Lyrics & Lyricists show, The Crowds at El Morocco: The Heyday of the New York Nightclubs.

title: Songs of America, With Beauty and Gusto
description: Sarcasm is the prevailing mode in contemporary music about the American experience. Since many talented composers are dubious about the country and its history, their well-meaning attempts to grapple with them musically can easily slide into self-righteous critique. It may not be wrong, but its not interesting.

title: German Politics Faces Grass-Roots Threat
description: KLEINMACHNOW, GERMANY  They are called Wutbrger. And they have become the bane of every political party in Germany.

title: A Depression-Era Protest Ripped From the Headlines
description: Thats socialism! an angry character shouts in One-Third of a Nation, a play written during the Depression and now revived by the Metropolitan Playhouse. Its unconstitutional! yells another, the president of a mortgage company.

title: A Wry Eye on Problems of the Future
description: In his most recent film, Looking for Comedy in the Muslim World, Albert Brooks can be seen as a stand-up comic trying to entertain an audience in India. He tells a few jokes. Nobody laughs. He wonders why. Then he has the bright idea that maybe the crowd simply cant follow him. How many people in the auditorium understand English, he asks? Every person in the audience raises a hand.

title: Revisiting a Brash 2010 Slam
description: The Cavendish Invitational tournament starts on Wednesday in Henderson, Nev., on the outskirts of Las Vegas. The first two days feature the John Roberts Teams, won last year by Pierre Zimmermann, Franck Multon, Michel and Thomas Bessis (father and son), Geir Helgemo and Tor Helness.

title: Famine/Death 2012!
description: Johann Hari on Donald Trump and the GOP:

title: Maryland, My Maryland
description: April 27  May 4, 1861

title: Beethoven Devotee Makes Some Keyboard Time for Schubert
description: There is nothing flashy or even very charismatic about the shy-looking, bushy-haired English pianist Paul Lewis. Still Mr. Lewis, 38, has steadily gained a well-deserved reputation as an accomplished and exceptionally thoughtful artist. So a sizable audience turned out for his recital on Friday night at the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

title: New Series to Honor Duke Ellington
description: Duke Ellington, above, brought dance, music and variety shows to the Cotton Club in Harlem in the 1920s and 30s. This year City Centers Encores! series and Jazz at Lincoln Center will present Cotton Club Parade, a tribute to Ellingtons performances there, and the first in a new series of musical theater and jazz collaborations from the organizations. Cotton Club Parade will have six performances at City Center, Nov. 18 to 22, directed by Warren Carlyle (Finians Rainbow), with musical direction by Wynton Marsalis and featuring the Jazz at Lincoln Center Orchestra. The series will run every two years, with the next production scheduled at the Rose Theater at Jazz at Lincoln Center during its 2013-14 season. Tickets for Cotton Club Parade can be purchased through City Center beginning Aug. 15.

title: Footnotes
description: Mike Birbiglias My Girlfriends Boyfriend has extended its run at the Barrow Street Theater. The sad but humorous love life of Mr. Birbiglia, below, a This American Life and Moth favorite, will play through June 25. Mr. Birbiglias 2008 show, Sleepwalk With Me, ran for eight months at the Bleecker Street Theater, was turned into a book and CD, and is being made into a movie. ... Branden Jacobs-Jenkins has been named the winner of the Paula Vogel playwriting award, the Vineyard Theater said. Ms. Vogel will present the award, which includes a residency at the Vineyard as well as a prize of $3,000, to Mr. Jacobs-Jenkins at a luncheon on June 9. Mr. Jacobs-Jenkins is the author of Neighbors, which played at the Public Theater last spring, and The Octoroon: An Adaptation of The Octoroon Based on The Octoroon, which was produced at Performance Space 122 last summer.

title: Fast Five Vrooms to No. 1 at Box Office
description: The North American box office came roaring back to life over the weekend as Fast Five (Universal Pictures), with Vin Diesel and Dwayne Johnson, from left above, opened in first place to an estimated $83.6 million in ticket sales. An animated holdover, 20th Century Foxs Rio, was second with $14.4 million for a three-week total of $103.6 million, according to Hollywood.com, which compiles ticketing statistics. Tyler Perrys Madeas Big Happy Family (Lionsgate) was third with $10.5 million, for a two-week total of $41.1 million. Water for Elephants (Fox) was fourth, selling $9.1 million for a two-week total of $32.3 million. Prom, a low-budget comedy from Walt Disney Studios, failed to gain traction in its opening weekend, placing fifth with about $5 million.

title: Ferguson to Direct Film About WikiLeaks Founder
description: Charles Ferguson has taken on his first nondocumentary project with HBO Films, directing a movie about Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, according to The Hollywood Reporter. Mr. Ferguson won an Oscar this year for his documentary Inside Job, about the origins of the 2008 financial crisis, and received a nomination for his 2007 film No End In Sight, about the American occupation in Iraq. Mr. Assange has been embroiled in controversy since November, when WikiLeaks made public confidential diplomatic cables from the State Department. Shortly afterward, he was arrested in Britain on charges of sexual abuse in Sweden; he has appealed a decision allowing his extradition to Sweden. He is also under investigation by the United States Justice Department. Other films about Mr. Assange, below, and WikiLeaks are in the works, The Los Angeles Times reported. DreamWorks has optioned several memoirs about Mr. Assange and WikiLeaks; Universal has a documentary by Alex Gibney (Enron: The Smartest Guys in the Room) in production; and Annapurna Productions has said it is financing a film to be produced, and possibly written by, Mark Boal, whose Hurt Locker won him two Oscars in 2009, for original screenplay and best film.

title: On Not Reading Keynes
description: Ive been staying out of the truly stupid debate about whether Keynes advocated central planning; folks, this is not an issue to be settled by trawling his works for gotcha quotes. Keynes had a model, laid out at length in his General Theory; it was a model of how an otherwise workable market economy can suffer from inadequate demand, and how government can play a useful role by pumping up demand to achieve full employment. This model is, as Keynes himself said, moderately conservative in its implications.

title: Mixed Television Ratings for the Royal Wedding
description: The wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton on Friday was a snooze for most Americans, according to television audience estimates. The Nielsen Company said that an average of 22.7 million viewers at home in the United States watched the wedding live (between 6 a.m. and 7:15 a.m. Eastern daylight time). That figure, encompassing viewers of 11 channels, reaffirmed pre-wedding polls that found only lukewarm interest in the nuptials among most Americans. Still, millions did tune in, leading to a record ratings day for some television channels. Between 4 a.m. and 10 a.m., when the wedding coverage was at its peak, CNN had an average of 1.66 million viewers, its biggest audience since the day after the presidential election in 2008. Between 7 a.m. and 9 a.m. NBCs Today had an average of more than 9.6 million viewers, its biggest audience since the day after the presidential election in 2000. Good Morning America on ABC had an average of 8.65 million viewers, its biggest audience in at least 20 years. CBSs Early Show averaged 3.91 million viewers. The Nielsen ratings count only viewers at home, so it is unknown how many wedding aficionados gathered for viewing parties.

title: R.L. Stines Lastest Book to Be a Feature Film
description: The latest book from R. L. Stine, the author of the Goosebumps childrens books, will be turned into a family-adventure feature film. According to The Hollywood Reporter, Gotham Group, a management and production company, has optioned the rights to the book, Its the First Day of School ... Forever, about a 12-year-old boy whose first, horrible day of school keeps repeating itself. The book wont be released until July, and a writer and studio have not been determined for the film. Mr. Stines Goosebumps and Haunting Hour series have already been adapted for television; in an interview with moviefone.com Mr. Stine said that his adult novel The Sitter was also being developed as a feature film under the title The Au Pair, to be produced by Sam Raimis Ghost House Pictures.

title: Tribeca Audience Chooses Philippine Documentary
description: Moviegoers at the Tribeca Film Festival chose Give Up Tomorrow as the winner of the Heineken Audience Award for best feature film at a ceremony in New York on Saturday night. The films director, Michael Collins, an alumnus of the Tribeca Film Institutes All Access program, which supports filmmakers from underrepresented groups, will receive $25,000 as part of the prize. Give Up Tomorrow is a documentary that follows the case of Paco Larranaga, who was arrested in 1997 and accused of killing two teenage sisters on the island of Cebu in the Philippines, despite overwhelming evidence of his innocence.

title: Duerson Findings Could Shape Debate
description: The question of whether the former Chicago Bear Dave Duerson had football-related brain damage when he killed himself in February will be answered Monday morning, when Boston University researchers announce autopsy results.

title: From Southern Africa to American Tracks
description: Philadelphia

title: Monday: Mysterious Saucer
description: Administrivial Access Alert: The New York Times is aware that some people are having trouble accessing the PDF and still others are having trouble accessing the Across Lite version of the puzzle. While the problems are being resolved, here is a link to both versions. Sincere thanks to Jim Horne for his technical expertise, as well as for housing these links.

title: Beneath the Greasepaint, the Roar of Fam-i-ly!
description: When Violent J, the alter ego assumed by the husky Detroit native Joseph Bruce when he performs in the rap duo Insane Clown Posse, arrived at the Skyport Marina on East 23rd Street in Manhattan, it was just after midnight on Saturday morning, and he was still wearing the greasepaint that makes him look like a demented distant relative of Emmett Kelly.

title: From Starry-Eyed to Star
description: Arian Moayed is busy  like James Franco busy. Eight times a week he takes to the stage at the Richard Rodgers Theater, playing Musa, an Iraqi translator, with Robin Williams in Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo, Mr. Moayeds Broadway debut. In between shows he squeezes in time with his girlfriend, Krissy Shields, and their daughters, 2-year-old Olive Joon and 3-month-old Ivy Shireen. Sleep is not exactly a priority.

title: Behind the Smiles
description: Insane Clown Posse, the hip-hop do, performed at the Gramercy Theater.

title: Origins of the Deficit
description: Steve Benen gets exercised about the way Republicans place blame for our deficit on excessive spending, when that is very much not the story. Ive been thinking about ways to make that clear; heres one effort.

title: An Actor on Several Stages
description: A look at the actor Arian Moayeds first directing project, called Goodbar.

title: Wade Shines Brightest as Heat Holds Off Celtics
description: MIAMI  Stars collided Sunday, on the baseline and at the 3-point arc, going forearm to shoulder, elbow to rib and in one case, nose to cheek. title: The Ghost, and Cult, of Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip
description: Back in 2006, Studio 60 on the Sunset Strip made its debut on NBC, and the show was intriguing for several reasons. One, it was created by arguably TVs most revered auteur at the time, Aaron Sorkin, who was more-or-less fresh off The West Wing, a paragon of snappy-pattered, makes-you-feel-smart-just-for-watching television. Two, Studio 60 was about comedy: specifically, late-night comedy and, presumably, Saturday Night Live. (Studio 60 was the name of a fictional, live, late-night sketch-comedy show produced out of Los Angeles.) Third, in a weird coincidence, Studio 60 premiered the same year, on the same network, as the similarly numerically titled 30 Rock, which is also sort-of about Saturday Night Live and is written by the ex-S.N.L. head writer Tina Fey.

title: How Hot Will the Arab Summer Be?
description: There was a nice piece by Asef Bayat in Foreign Affairs last week on The Post-Islamist Revolutions. Bayat  born and raised in Iran, educated in Britain, professor at Leiden then the University of Illinois  makes the first convincing (rather than wishful) argument Ive seen that the Arab Spring is likely to usher in relatively liberal, though religiously inflected, societies. The article makes a nice pairing with another recent Foreign Affairs piece by Michael Scott Doran, which takes Iran and Syria seriously as a kind of anticolonialist bloc single-mindedly focused on undermining the United States. It is perhaps a slightly paranoid or excited piece, but it is paranoid about something that the United States, as a noncolonial and indeed anticolonial power, habitually underestimates in its foreign policy, namely the enduring political power of anticolonial feeling in a post-colonial world.

title: Case Study | Building a Better Mixer
description: When you entreat a conscientious bartender to make you a gimlet these days, he frequently does something that is at once resolutely incorrect and completely forgivable: he makes you a drink containing gin, simple syrup and fresh lime juice. Ive done it many times myself. Depending on whom you talk to, that might be a type of sour or it might be a type of fix, but it almost certainly is not a gimlet. A proper gimlet is made with lime cordial. And what most of the world knows as lime cordial is Roses, that dusty, fluorescent yellow-green bottle in the drinks section of your supermarket. I am willing to bet that at some point in its very long history Mr. Lauchlin Roses Cordial Mixer Lime Juice may have been a bracing product, redolent of the fruit that it promises. Sadly, its current incarnation is to limes as Spam is to steak. It tastes of the high-fructose corn syrup, stabilizers and various chemicals that give it its cesium-like shelf life, which is all fine for Cadbury, which has owned the brand since 1981, but is bitter gruel for someone trying to tap into the sublimity of a true gimlet. For that, as for many such rich rewards, youve got to make your own.

title: A Mix of Emotion Stored for a Decade

title: Linked In | Hoorsenbuhs

But soon the two men, who became fast friends on a Malibu beach 20 years ago and started Hoorsenbuhs in 2005, decided that an upgrade was in order. The new private showroom opened this week in a former bungalow on Santa Monicas Main Street, with fittings from the old space, like dark wood sliding doors, industrial lamps and jewelry cases offset with heavy maritime chains. (The Hoorsenbuhs name comes from a Dutch trading ship sailed by Keiths ancestors.). The new space is an airy, light-filled room that will soon open to an outdoor area with a fire pit.

title: Osamas Long Goodbye

I suppose it has to do with that very subtle business of distinguishing yourself from your enemies. So I felt some slight ambivalence when a force that was much stronger than my ambivalence took me into my daughters bedroom this morning to wake her and show her the local newspaper, then on the same errand into my sons room, waiting while he rubbed the sleep out of his eyes and focused on the Page 1 headline in great, black type: BIN LADEN DEAD. I exult in the death of my enemy.

description: The reasons are pretty clear why the San Jose Sharks have seized a 2-0 series lead over the Detroit Red Wings. The Sharks have been more purposefully physical and speedy, while the Wings have been plagued by prolonged moments of listlessness and taking bad penalties.

title: Street Eats in Bangkok
description: Small places often prove to be the best eating spots in many cities. But for historical reasons Bangkok may boast the finest street food on earth.

title: Back in Time on the San Blas Islands
description: While these cultural and tropical islands have flown under the tourism radar for years, it may not stay that way for long.

title: Weekend in Melbourne, Australia
description: Spend 36 hours getting to know this laid-back Australian city.

title: Cuisine of the Levant in Amman
description: In this politically, religiously and ethnically fraught corner of the world, the cuisine in Amman, Jordan, is a symbol of geography, war and identity.

title: Weekend in Hollywood
description: The city remains a place that only Los Angeles could produce.

title: The Elusive Affordable Family Ski Weekend
description: Following a few rules to a triumphant four days on the slopes.

title: Weekend in Breckenridge, Colo.
description: This former mining town has a new shine.

title: Climbing Kilimanjaro
description: Climbing to the roof of Africa before climate change erases its ice fields and the romance of its iconic image.

title: Love That Cheese, the Burger Declares
description: Remember the mock rant in Ghostbusters about dogs and cats living together? A new campaign for a dairy staple takes another look at the concept of unlikely amorous encounters.

title: Viennese Delights
description: The capital's new casual dining scene takes place in unexpected settings, from inside museums to cheese shops and even bookstores.

title: Readers Photos: Reactions to Bin Ladens Death
description: President Obama announced late Sunday that Osama bin Laden, the leader of Al Qaeda responsible for the Sept. 11 attacks, had been killed in a firefight during an operation he ordered Sunday inside Pakistan, ending a 10-year manhunt for the worlds most wanted terrorist. Readers submitted photos of their reactions.

title: On the Big Island and Kauai Without a Big Budget
description: While Hawaiis natural wonders may clear your mind of cares, its restaurants, hotels and attractions can also clear out your wallet.

title: Weekend in Cape Town, South Africa
description: Cape Town is South Africas Los Angeles to Johannesburgs New York  the glitzy, gorgeous, self-obsessed foil to its grittier, more serious and more powerful big sister.

title: Tune In for the Tony Nominations
description: Will Catch Me If You Can be nominated for the best musical Tony Award, after being left out of that category by the Drama Desk and Outer Critics Circle award nominators last week? Which of these five Broadway plays  Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo, Good People, Jerusalem, The  with the Hat, or War Horse  will not be in the running for best play when all of the Tony nominees are announced Tuesday morning? Will the two male stars of Catch Me and the two in The Book of Mormon take up four of the five nominations for best actor in a musical? And who will make the cut for the five spots in another competitive performance category this year, best actor in a play? Broadway veterans like Brian Bedford (The Importance of Being Earnest) and Joe Mantello (The Normal Heart); movies stars like James Earl Jones (Driving Miss Daisy), Al Pacino (The Merchant of Venice), and Robin Williams (Bengal Tiger); and widely admired actors Bobby Cannavale (Hat) and Mark Rylance (Jerusalem, La Bte) are all more-than-plausible as nominees. To that end, will Mr. Rylance be competing against himself at the Tonys ceremony? And which shows were blanked among the nominees? Who wuz robbed?

title: Weekend in Cairo
description: There are thousands of years of history in Cairo and that history can be seen in the people themselves.

title: A Year-Round Art Party in Miami
description: Miamis go-go art scene is no longer confined to the four-day December circus known as Art Basel Miami Beach.

title: The Rambling Trails of Marin County
description: Miles of well-maintained trails north of San Francisco offer something for anyone spry enough to walk a mile or two, on any budget.

title: Tavel, the Cradle of French Ros
description: A visit to this cherished French wine town is almost like a pilgrimage to Mecca.

title: Weekend in Napa Valley
description: Winter is a great time to explore the Napa Valley.

title: Half the World in Iran
description: Nearly three decades after the Islamic Revolution, Iran is undergoing a quieter transformation, this one in tourism.

title: Puerto Rico's Second City
description: Ponce, Puerto Rico, is a quieter option to San Juan.

title: Weekend in St. Barts
description: Despite a new wave of wine bars, chichi boutiques and designer restaurants, the islands main attraction remains its luscious white sand beaches.

description: Low cost and now chic, hostels are no longer just for backpackers.

title: Sliding Down a Live Volcano in Nicaragua
description: A new sport is drawing adventure-seekers to the steep slopes of a volcano.

title: Tensions Rise as Hamas Refuses to Take Sides in Syria
description: JERUSALEM  Relations between the Palestinian group Hamas, which is based in the Syrian capital, Damascus, and the Syrian authorities have been strained in recent weeks, mostly as a result of the antigovernment uprising there, with reports growing that Hamas is looking for another home.

title: Weekend in Tremblant, Quebec
description: For an East Coast ski resort, Mont Tremblant seems to have it all.

title: Jorge Amado's Salvador
description: A Brazilian novelist's visions of his city are found on every street of his hometown.

title: Summer in Sydney
description: Dine in Michelin-quality restaurants before taking a dip in Sydney's salty rock pools, where bathers can swim without fear of sharks.

title: A Weekend in Taipei
description: The vibrant capital of Taiwan offers great street food, crackling night life, arguably the worlds best collection of Chinese art, and hot springs and hiking trails.

title: The Lure of Acapulco
description: A scene more like South Beach than a Mexican resort with a midlife crisis.

title: In New York, the Art Outside
description: Art appears in the most unlikely, forgotten corners and is easy to walk right by if you dont have a sharp eye.

title: A New Round of Golf in Vietnam
description: Once considered a mark of imperialism, golf in Vietnam is staging a comeback.

title: Weekend in Puebla, Mexico
description: The Unesco World Heritage Site offers colonial treasures, cafe-lined squares and a vibrant arts-and-crafts culture.

description: Even if you're not religious, Semana Santa (Holy Week), this year March 16 to 23, is one of the best times to explore the city's religious architecture.

title: Weekend in Pasadena, California
description: Nestled in the San Gabriel Valley just 10 miles northeast of Los Angeles is the famed City of Roses.

title: Buenos Aires: Bohemians-in-Exile
description: Drawn by the city's cheap prices and Paris-like elegance, legions of foreigners are colonizing the city.

title: Regimens: Noise Canceling, Without Headphones
description: Studies have found that meditation helps prevent the recurrence of depression, perhaps by producing changes in parts of the brain associated with learning and anxiety. A new study suggests that meditation may modulate brain waves called alpha rhythms, which help regulate the transmission of sensory input from the surrounding environment.

title: Inside Rome
description: The citys wealthy nobles and artists have left behind a treasure trove of curious cubby holes for visitors to explore.

title: Weekend in New Delhi
description: The city-state of Delhi has been a seat of power for more than a thousand years, and remains a survivor of conquest and contrast.

title: Looking for a Superstar Horse? Hes in Europe
description: As we await this year`s Triple Crown, one that is wide open (which may be a euphemism for a less-than-stellar group), what is clear is that in Europe there is a superstar; his name is Frankel.

title: Turkey Latest to Close Its Embassy in Libya
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  Turkey closed its embassy in Tripoli, Libya, on Monday, apparently worried about the angry crowds that had attacked the missions of NATO countries after the airstrike that the Libyan government said killed a son of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi and three of his grandchildren.

title: Hidden San Francisco
description: San Francisco is riven with all manner of concrete crannies, quaint cobblestone back ways and remote waterfront hide-outs.

title: A Touch of France in Pondicherry
description: In the colonial city of Pondicherry, southern India meets the South of France.

title: Weekend in Berkeley
description: The spirit of 1969 hasnt completely gone away, but the California citys revamped sophisticated boutiques and shops offer a quirky mix of attractions.

title: Homemade Whole Grain Crackers
description: There are plenty of whole-grain crackers on store shelves, but none taste as good to me as those made at home. You can use a mix of grains and flours to make them, including gluten-free varieties like millet, buckwheat and rice flours, and top them with any number of seeds, herbs or spices. Theyre quick to mix together and very easy to roll out.

title: Beach Front in Miami
description: Explore the heart of the Art Deco District, an old-fashioned Cuban restaurant and the city's art scene.

title: Weekend in Dubai
description: You name it, Dubai has it. Or if it doesnt have it, its building it.

title: Saab Secures $44 Million and Plans Partnership With Hawtai Motor Group
description: While awaiting the financial package that would ensure its continued existence, Saab received an infusion of capital that put the Swedish automaker closer to restarting production, which has been idle for nearly four weeks.

title: Comfort Food in Montreal
description: From foie gras on cheese fries to buttery brioche toast, home cooking is the best cooking for local chefs.

title: Spain's Wine Country
description: One way to take a break from Barcelonas frenetic pace is to venture into Peneds region.

title: Romney Officially Out of Fox News Debate
description: More bad news for those hoping that a full slate of potential Republican candidates will show up at the Republican debate to be shown on Fox News Channel on Thursday: Mitt Romney is officially out.

title: Weekend in Chiang Mai, Thailand
description: Modern design and refined cuisine is seeping into the culture here, but there's still plenty of traditional Chiang Mai to see.

title: Shopper's Paradise in Mexico
description: Tonal, Mexico, is where the professionals shop.

title: Oxford, as Seen Over Pub Glasses
description: Filled with banter and the scent of yeast and hops, Oxford's pubs are a ready-made party, a home away from home, a club anyone can join.

title: Today's Munich
description: Quaint, grandfatherly, Munich  long considered about as cool as polka music on cassette  is Germanys hot spot of the moment.

title: Few Mental Health Professionals in Aging Communities
description: In case case you missed it, Jane Gross described in The Times on Sunday an effort to provide better mental health care to residents of nursing homes and assisted living facilities. Read the full article, and share your thoughts in the comments section.

title: Firewalkers in Spain
description: Firewalkers in Spain.

title: Game Systems Upgraded at a Cost-Conscious Pace
description: SAN FRANCISCO  So much technology seems to get upgraded at Internet speeds. Not video game consoles, at least not anymore.

title: How to Make a Better Gimlet
description: As Toby Cecchini points out on the Moment blog, a real gimlet is not made with lime juice. But you dont have to use the bottled stuff, as most bars do. His latest Case Study post includes a recipe for a homemade lime cordial.

title: Rome Illuminated
description: Night does not really darken Rome so much as make the parts that matter shine.

title: Bordeaux's New Culinary Stars
description: The region's potent food and atmosphere work an intoxicating spell.

title: Live Facebook Chat on Bin Laden
description: 4:38 p.m. | Updated Michael D. Shear, the chief blogger for The Caucus, answered questions at 3 p.m. on our Facebook page, http://www.facebook.com/nytimes, about the Osama bin Laden story and The Timess reporting surrounding it. Read a transcript of the chat.

title: Teaching Ideas: The Death of Osama bin Laden
description: Updated May 6

title: Nasdaq OMX and ICE Go Hostile in NYSE Bid
description: 7:24 p.m. | Updated The Nasdaq OMX Group and the IntercontinentalExchange announced on Monday that they would take their $11 billion takeover offer for NYSE Euronext directly to the companys shareholders.

title: Week Ahead: Debt Ceiling and Gas Prices Still Focus of Congress
description: The killing of Osama bin Laden will dominate Congressional conversations this week, but top aides said Monday that lawmakers still intended to pursue their planned agenda as members of the House and Senate return from spring break.

title: Obscura Cool
description: One pleasure of the sixth floor  right now I mean the offices, not the blog  is getting to walk past the prints of some of the photos weve published in the magazine over the years. Theyre big, and theyre full of fun or beauty or mystery or some mix of all these and other qualities. Im no art critic  I know, shocking, right?  but one in particular has struck me as subtler than the rest, harder to read at a glance, easier to pass by on a daily basis without fully seeing whats going on. Thats how it has been for me, anyway. The photo is a black-and-white camera obscura image of Times Square by Abelardo Morell. It ran in the magazine in 1997,and is reproduced above.

title: Obama Calls World Safer After Pakistan Raid
description: WASHINGTON  Calling it a good day for America, President Obama said on Monday that the death of Osama bin Laden had made the world a better place, as new details emerged about the overnight raid and firefight in Pakistan that killed him.

title: In Case of Eyewitness vs. Alibi, a Question of Lawyers Competence
description: WASHINGTON

title: Rajaratnam Away as Jurors Begin 2nd Week of Deliberation
description: 7:44 p.m. | Updated

title: Political Impact of Bin Laden's Death
description: Jeff Zeleny and Kate Zernike discuss the implications of Osama bin Laden's death on the 2012 presidential race.

title: Christie and Democrats Agree to Truce Over Court Seat
description: After a yearlong battle over an appointment to the New Jersey Supreme Court, Gov. Chris Christie and Democrats in the State Senate reached a truce of sorts on Monday, agreeing to have the governors nominee considered for a different vacancy.

title: Big Compound Stood Out, but Not Its Occupants, Neighbors Say
description: ABBOTTABAD, Pakistan  The sprawling compound where Osama bin Laden sheltered before his death stood out in its middle-class neighborhood on the edges of this scenic city, home to a large Pakistani military base and a military academy.

title: Bin Ladens Death and Obamas Approval Ratings
description: Presidents have traditionally seen sharp increases in their approval ratings at times of international crises, diplomatic events and military operations. Over the next few days, as public opinion polls are released, it will become evident how the death of Osama bin Laden has affected Americans views of President Obamas job performance.

title: A Thief That Robs the Brain of Language
description: Steve Riedner of Schaumburg, Ill., was a 55-year-old tool-and-die maker, a job that involves difficult mental calculations, and a frequent speaker at community meetings when he found himself increasingly at a loss for words and unable to remember numbers. He even began to have difficulty reading his own written comments.

title: Video: Political Impact of Bin Ladens Death
description: Read Jeff Zelenys related article, Presidents Vow Fulfilled.

title: Famous List of the Infamous, Now in Need of an Update
description: A red banner declaring Deceased was splashed across Osama bin Ladens photograph on the Federal Bureau of Investigations 10 Most Wanted list on Monday, ending his 10-year sojourn among Americas most sought-after public enemies.

title: Patterns: An Omega-3 Fatty Acid Shows a Risky Side
description: Omega-3 fatty acids have anti-inflammatory effects that may help protect against heart disease, studies have shown. But men with high blood levels of the omega-3 fat docosahexaenoic acid, or D.H.A., were at significantly greater risk for aggressive prostate cancer, a large study has found.

title: Journey and Legacy of Obamas Mother
description: Pieces of the story of Ann Dunham, the mother of Barack Obama, we know already. A white woman from Kansas, as he referred to her at the Democratic convention in 2008, who married an African intellectual and had a son with him. A strict mother who roused that son before dawn to study. An anthropologist who spent years studying in Indonesian villages, several of those years without her son. A 52-year-old woman whose last year before succumbing to cancer was spent in part trying to convince the Cigna insurance company that she should not be disqualified from benefits by virtue of a pre-existing condition. These are the parts of her life that resonate with our cultural anxieties about good mothering, access to health care and, of course, race.

title: Chief Photography Curator Retiring From MoMA
description: Peter Galassi, the chief curator of photography at the Museum of Modern Art, will retire in July, the museum announced. Mr. Galassi, 60, who first worked for the museum as a curatorial intern in 1974, will leave to devote time to other projects, including writing, according to a statement from the museum. He joined MoMAs photography department as a staff member in 1981 and was made chief curator 10 years later. Under his direction the museum expanded its exhibition style to include not just documentary but also post-modern works.

title: A Survey of Books About Osama bin Laden and Al Qaeda
description: Since 9/11, there has been an outpouring of books aboutOsama bin Laden, Al Qaeda, the Sept. 11 attacks and the war in Afghanistan. Below is an annotated list of some of the more useful ones.

title: Islamic Scholars Split Over Sea Burial for Bin Laden
description: White House officials decided before Mondays firefight in northern Pakistan that if American troops killed Osama bin Laden, they would bury him at sea in order to prevent his grave from becoming a shrine for his followers, a White House official said Monday. They planned to include all rites associated with Muslim burials, the official added.

title: After Liposuction, Fat Just Relocates
description: A troubling new study shows that when liposuction is used to remove fat from one part of the body, the fat comes back somewhere else. As Gina Kolata reports:

title: Reports on the Death of Osama bin Laden
description: New York Times correspondents report on the military raid in Pakistan that killed Osama bin Laden. Full Coverage

title: Dells Future Beyond the PC Business
description: Michael Dell built his company and his fortune in the personal computer business. But the companys future is increasingly going to rest on services and the bigger gear used in data centers  server computers, storage and networking equipment.

title: Lose the Tonsils, Put on Pounds?
description: In theory, losing a body part should result in a lower body weight. But some research suggests that having your tonsils removed is associated with weight gain, reports Anahad OConnor in todays Really? column.

title: Nightly News Anchors Flock to Ground Zero
description: Ground zero in New York City became a backdrop for television anchors on Monday as they prepared special editions of their nightly newscasts following the death of Osama Bin Laden.

title: Stand Up Straight!
description: Q. Can exercise correct kyphosis, the excessive forward curvature of the spine that is sometimes called widows hump?

title: A Poetic Job That Invites Conversation
description: I TRAVEL quite a bit, which raises the question, Why does a poet have to travel? Heres how it works. You write a poem and you make zero dollars. You write a book of poems, and you make slightly more than zero dollars. But if someone calls you to give a poetry reading, all of a sudden you actually make some money. I bet people didnt know poetry involved such high stakes.

title: Researchers Defend Study Finding Plankton Decline
description: A new study in Nature Climate Change,Revaluating ocean warming impacts on globalphytoplankton,has shown that the method used to calculate phytoplankton loss in the 2010 research greatly overstated plankton losses because of a missing vital factor. Read New Scientist for the details.

title: The Webster Sends T Packing
description: Laure Heriard Dubreuil and Frederic Dechnik, founders of the Webster Miami, have a penchant for sun, and lots of it. Its reflected in what they buy for their store but also in their personal itineraries, which have them jet-setting from Egypt and Greece to St. Tropez and Mallorca. Come June the duo will head to Venice (for the Art Biennale) and to Mexicos Costa Careyes for the wild beaches, Las Alamandas resort and the banana forest. With their astute knowledge of all climates  and immaculate taste  The Moment put Dubreul and Dechnik to work to send Ts editors packing. I guess its very French, but August is off, Dechnik says. I will never compromise. We can dream.

title: The Clout of Air Alliances
description: Global airline alliances used to be little more than marketing agreements among carriers, and travelers had only a dim awareness of them.

title: Monkeys Memories Can Stretch Beyond Whats in Front of Them
description: Monkeys can recognize an object they have seen before, but now scientists have shown that they are also capable of a much more sophisticated form of memory: They can hold in mind an object without actually seeing it.

title: The Droll, Buzzing Grandpas of Rap
description: BEASTIE BOYS

title: For Canadas New Democrats, a Cautionary Tale in Britain
description: As Canada conducts a snap general election on Monday with polls pointing to a significant realignment of support, there may be a cautionary tale in the most recent British election.

title: Honors for Off Broadway Productions
description: The Public Theater production of Bloody Bloody Andrew Jackson won the Lucille Lortel Award for outstanding musical on Sunday night, while Kristoffer Diazs The Elaborate Entrance of Chad Deity was named best play in the 26th annual competition recognizing Off Broadway work.

title: How Hummingbirds Drink
description: Video of a saw-billed hermit hummingbird drinking in slow motion.

title: Forget Straws: Hummingbirds Sip With Forks
description: Since the theory was first put forth in 1833, ornithologists have assumed that hummingbirds drink by capillary action: The bird curls its forked tongue into a straw shape, and the liquid is drawn up the tube by surface tension.

title: From the Front Lines
description: Three soldiers who recently returned from a year in Afghanistan reflect on Osama bin Ladens death.

title: TimesCast | May 2, 2011
description: Reactions from Pakistan, Afghanistan and the United States on the death of Osama bin Laden.

title: Pesticides: Ban on a Cousin of DDT Has Loopholes in India, Where Children Were Harmed
description: Endosulfan, a powerful 50-year-old insecticide sometimes called DDTs cousin, was officially banned last week at an international pesticides meeting in Geneva. Partial exemptions were created for India, however; the chemical may be used on some crops there for up to 10 years.

title: A Conversation With Warren Buffett
description: DealBook's Andrew Ross Sorkin talks to the chairman of Berkshire Hathaway about the lessons learned from the situation with David Sokol.

title: Warren Buffett on the Sokol Affair
description: DealBooks Andrew Ross Sorkin talks to the chairman of Berkshire Hathaway about the lessons learned from the situation with David Sokol, including what Mr. Buffett would have done differently.

title: Hearts Beat as One in a Daring Ritual
description: For as long as anyone in the tiny Spanish village of San Pedro Manrique can remember, people there have been walking on fire.

title: Extra Tax Revenue to Delay Debt Crisis
description: WASHINGTON  A greater-than-expected increase in tax revenue has extended by about a month, until early August, the federal governments ability to pay its bills without an increase in the debt ceiling, the Treasury Department said Monday.

title: Screening: An Autism Questionnaire at Checkup Time
description: A questionnaire that parents can fill out in five minutes while waiting for the pediatrician can detect autism and other delays in 1-year-olds, a new study has found. But the test has a high false-positive rate that may cause unnecessary alarm.

title: Second Thoughts About Obama and Bin Laden: Its Not Just the Economy, Stupid
description: When I first heard the news about the American military operation that killed Osama bin Laden, I was pretty certain that the popular press was going to overstate its impact on Barack Obamas re-election chances. I wrote an article to that effect last night.

title: Consumer Reports Offers New Comparison Tool
description: Consumer Reports has long offered rankings and comparisons of products as diverse as cars, vacuum cleaners and televisions. Now the magazines online counterpart, consumerreports.org, has teamed up with the bill comparison site Billshrink.com to help shoppers evaluate the services that go along with some of those products.

title: Facebook Transcript: Live Chat on Bin Laden Death
description: On Monday afternoon, Michael D. Shear, the chief correspondent for The Caucus, participated in a live chat on The Timess Facebook page, responding to comments and questions about Osama bin Ladens death and its political ramifications. The following is a transcript of the questions Mr. Shear addressed and the answers he posted on Facebook. Thanks to everyone who participated; we hope to bring you more Facebook chats like this in the future.

title: An Orphans Adventures, Ripe for the Telling
description: The Tragical Life of Cheeseboy, Finegan Kruckemeyers play presented by the New Victory Theater, begins with a bearded storyteller (Stephen Sheehan) in a top hat approaching some children sitting on the floor in the front row: Are you prepared to be saddened? he asks. Are you prepared to laugh? Are you prepared to be dazzled?

title: Prognosticate That!
description: Ahem:

title: Classical Music Finds Ways to Reach (Way) Out
description: Last fall, during his consultancy to the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, the celebrated cellist Yo-Yo Ma visited the Illinois Youth Center, a correctional institution in Warrenville. He accompanied the female inmates as they rehearsed a musical show based on their life experiences, as part of the C.S.O.s program to reach communities far from Symphony Center.

title: Tugging at Threads to Unspool Stories of Torture
description: AMMAN, Jordan  The first time the Iraqi Army arrested him, he said, soldiers burst into his shop in Baghdad, dragged him out in handcuffs and a blindfold, and took him to a filthy, overcrowded prison. Beatings, rape, hunger and disease were rampant, and he expected at any moment to be killed. He was held for four months, until December 2008.

title: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Washington, New York, Afghanistan and Pakistan.

title: Sony Declines to Testify at Congressional Hearing
description: 8:00 p.m. | Updated Added comment from Sony.

title: Jihadis Voice Grief and Determination at Death of Their Inspiration
description: WASHINGTON  Jihadis around the world reacted on Monday to the news of Osama bin Ladens death with a mix of sorrow, disbelief and determination that Al Qaeda and its affiliates would continue their struggle against the West and its allies.

title: Worldwide Travel Alert
description: In the wake of the killing of Osama bin Laden, the State Department has issued a worldwide travel alert, warning United States citizens of the enhanced potential for anti-American violence given recent counter-terrorism activity in Pakistan.

title: Whos Over-leveraged Now?
description: When I wrote the first edition of The Return of Depression Economics, I was reacting in large part to the Asian financial crisis, which I thought could presage similarly difficult crises here in America. Sadly, I was right.

title: Police Step Up Efforts on News of Bin Ladens Death
description: As New Yorkers made their way through the city on Monday, they were greeted with an increased police presence in the citys transit system, at the areas bridges and tunnels and at other key sites like Times Square and the financial district  part of a coordinated security plan put in place as soon as Osama bin Ladens death was reported by President Obama.

title: Drumbeat of Nuclear Fallout Fear Doesnt Resound With Experts
description: The nuclear disaster in Japan has sent waves of radiation and dread around the globe, prompting so many people to buy radiation detectors and potassium iodide to fend off thyroid cancer that supplies quickly sold out.

title: Adding Food and Subtracting Calories
description: To lose weight, eat less, right?

title: Staying in an Albergo Diffuso
description: The Sextantio is one of a number of new alberghi diffusi, or scattered hotels, which are transforming ancient villages.

title: They Still Sound Like Amateurs
description: In his first review of the Beastie Boys for The New York Times, Jon Pareles wrote that, the three Beastie Boys  King Ad-Rock (Adam Horovitz), Mike D (Michael Diamond) and the hoarse-voiced MCA (Adam Yauch)  are loudmouthed brats backed by loud guitars and a lean rhythm-box beat.

title: Bin Ladens Likely Heir Is Viewed as Organizer, Not as Inspiring Figure
description: Ayman al-Zawahri, long the second-in-command in Al Qaeda and Osama bin Ladens most likely successor, released five recordings between January and April trying to link the uprisings across the Arab world to the jihadist inspiration behind the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks.

title: What Will the N.R.C. Learn From Fukushima?
description: The trait that doomed the Fukushima reactors might not be so obvious, the chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission told a mostly skeptical audience at a forum organized by an anti-nuclear group on Monday.

title: Bluebird Coffees Owners Move on
description: Bluebird Coffee Shops owners have sold the store. I first set foot in the tiny coffee shop in the East Village early last year, when I was researching an article on where you could (finally) get a cappuccino or brewed-to-order coffee in New York on par with what you find in San Francisco or Portland, Ore. The coffee at Bluebird Coffee Shop was great, and when the head barista, Katie Duris, was on her game, it could be exquisite. I named it as one of the 10 most notable establishments in the city. For diehard coffee nuts, it was a place of pilgrimage. For the neighborhood, it was the next-door beauty who just happened to be a star.

title: Supplies Squeezed, Rare Earth Prices Surge
description: HONG KONG  Rare earth prices are reaching rarefied heights.

title: If Big-Brained Birds Can Make It Here...
description: A bird that wants to live in a big city may need a big brain to survive, Swedish researchers report in a new study.

title: Bin Laden News Gives CNN a Ratings Victory
description: The breaking news of the killing of Osama bin Laden pushed CNN to the top of the cable news ratings Sunday night, with almost 8 million viewers tuning in during the hour of President Obamas speech to the nation.

title: Live Blog: New York Reacts to Bin Ladens Death
description: Around New York, the wounds of Sept. 11 have been reopened yet again, this time for a piece of welcome news. Here are 19 dispatches from a galvanized city.

title: Pictures of the Day: Washington and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Washington, New York, Afghanistan and Pakistan.

title: Lara Logan Interview Leads Sunday Ratings
description: CBSs interview with its correspondent Lara Logan on 60 Minutes in which she recounted details of her sexual assault in Cairo topped the Nielsen ratings on Sunday. The program drew 10.6 million viewers during the 7 p.m. hour, lifting CBS to No. 1 for the night, according to preliminary estimates, which were somewhat imprecise because of interruptions in Western time zones for President Obamas announcement of the death of Osama bin Laden. Although CBS also appeared to lead the 8 p.m. time slot with The Amazing Race (9.7 million), at 9 and 10, CBSs Undercover Boss (8.8 million) and CSI: Miami (9 million) lagged slightly behind ABCs Desperate Housewives (10.1 million) and the second half of NBCs two-hour installment of Celebrity Apprentice (9.1 million). ABC ranked second for the night over all, garnering 9.6 million viewers in the 8 oclock hour for Extreme Makeover: Home Edition. NBC was third with Dateline at 7 (5.5 million) and Americas Next Great Restaurant at 8 (6 million). Fox finished in fourth place with mostly reruns.

title: Learning to Grieve in a Grown-Up World
description: Daniel Zimmermans set for Be a Good Little Widow is the perfect reflection of the lead character in Bekah Brunstetters funny-sad play about loss at Ars Nova.

title: In Syria, Reports of Arrests Proliferate
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian security forces have escalated an arrest campaign in the countrys most rebellious regions, detaining hundreds over the past few days in the besieged city of Daraa and towns on the outskirts of the capital, Damascus, activists said on Monday.

title: Congress Reacts to Bin Laden Death
description: Congressional officials on Monday hailed the killing of Osama Bin Laden as evidence of Americas determination to pursue justice and said the location of his hide-out in a Pakistani city raised new questions about that nations allegiances.

title: Wrath for Airlines as Airports Face Their Own Problems
description: TUCSON

title: The Magazine on Osama bin Laden
description: What did we say about Osama bin Laden? The magazine exhaustively covered 9/11 and the wars that followed  the wars, especially, with in-depth reports from Iraq and Afghanistan as well as coverage of policy debates in Washington and leading trends in South Asia and what the State Department calls MENA (Middle East/North Africa). But Bin Laden only occasionally wafted into view. In the first few months after 9/11, he was omnipresent  Andrew Sullivan, for example, filed an article late that month that talked about how it was a mistake to deny that the conflict we were in was about religion. His main evidence was the statements of Osama bin laden, which were then forthcoming in abundance.

title: The Morning Line: Slow, Slower, Slowest
description: Thanks for rejoining us at the Morning Line on The Rail where we try to summarize each days news coverage of the Triple Crown.

title: Media React: Al Jazeera on Bin Ladens Death
description: By midday the headline on Al Jazeeras English-language Web site read Osama bin Laden killed by US forces and all 10 of the most-viewed headlines on the Web site were about the killing of Bin Laden. The network live-streamed its broadcast on the Web site, including interviews with heads of state from around the world and a live press conference from the White House.

title: Dimming Optimism for Todays Youth
description: Maybe it has to do with sky-high levels of youth unemployment. Maybe its because student loan levels are climbing. Maybe its because todays younguns will someday be stuck supporting so many of their elders.

title: Nevada Official Rules Special Election Must be Open
description: A special election to replace Representative Dean Heller, a Nevada Republican about to be appointed to the United States Senate, should be open to all candidates and not just those selected by the two political parties, Nevadas Secretary of State ruled on Monday.

title: An Antarctic Buffet Where Whales Gather to Feast
description: Scientists doing observations in the Wilhelmina Bay in the western Antarctic have found an estimated two million tons of krill, and more than 300 humpback whales feeding on them. It is the densest population of these whales ever recorded, more than 15 per square mile.

title: Media React: Le Monde Notes Historys Timing
description: PARIS  Chance sometimes does things well, Le Monde, widely viewed as Frances newspaper of record, wrote in an editorial. The man who embodied international jihadism dies at the moment when the Arab spring has just given a blow to this totalitarian fantasy. As soon as Arab peoples revolted in the name of democracy and not Islamism or the return to the caliphate preached by Al Qaeda, Osama bin Laden was politically moribund.

title: Ensign Apologizes in Farewell Speech

title: Job Description Grows for Our Utility Hormone

You will get lost, and you will never get out of Westbeth.

title: Violinists Wander Into Bartok, and Well Off the Beaten Path

But in 1930 Bela Bartok was asked to make a contribution to an anthology for student violinists. Rather than arrange pre-existing works, the composer created his multifaceted 44 short Violin Duos.

title: Building on the Mastery of What Came Before
description: BOSTON  The stage, washed in white light, looks enormous when the curtain goes up on William Forsythes Second Detail, the opening piece on the Boston Ballet triple bill at the opera house here. Twelve dancers, dressed in the palest gray leotards and tights  some facing the audience, some with their backs to us  are arrayed in lines and diagonals, their bodies etched against the space with cut-glass clarity. Thom Willems electronic score offers a hesitant, knocking rhythm, and then a 13th dancer, a woman, walks on quietly and takes her place in a line.

It is not based on the new operating system the company just unveiled in the BlackBerry PlayBook, its first tablet computer.

He missed the Yankees series in Detroit last May with a strained groin muscle, and so he walked into the clubhouse unsure where to go. An attendant gladly pointed Granderson to his locker for the next four days.

title: Come Party! But Dont Talk to Celebrities
description: Heres the funny thing about inviting a nightlife columnist to write about your party: Shes there to write about your party. So when we received a special invitation from a publicist to cover Nur Khan and Harry Joshs private shindig at Hiro Ballroom in the meatpacking district on Saturday night, the e-mail splashed with the names of interesting guests, we eagerly R.S.V.P.d. We looked forward to spending a long night interviewing guests like Gisele Bndchen, Tom Brady, Helena Christensen and more.
