title: Blagojevichs Second Federal Corruption Trial Begins
description: CHICAGO  Rod R. Blagojevich, the former governor of Illinois who is charged with trying to sell the United States Senate seat once held by President Obama, talked and talked and talked. But he never really sealed a deal, criminal or otherwise.

title: In the Pacific Northwest, a Playoff Matchup Stings
description: To start with, a confession: I want to root for the Oklahoma City Thunder. I like the players. I like the team. I like the way it plays. The Thunder is easily one of the most likable teams in pro basketball. I get that.

title: Experts Say DNA Match Is Likely a Parent or Child
description: While federal officials said that analysis of DNA from several relatives helped confirm that it was Osama bin Laden who was killed in the military raid on Sunday, they have not yet disclosed the relationships of the family members whose DNA was used.

title: Obama Emphasizes Sense of Unity
description: President Obama told members of Congress on Monday that because of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden, America on Sunday experienced the same sense of unity that prevailed on 9/11.

title: Returned to Power, a Leader Celebrates a Checkered Past
description: PARAMARIBO, Suriname  Desi Bouterse has been a soldier, a coup plotter, the military ruler of this former Dutch colony, a convicted drug trafficker and, for more than a decade, a fugitive from Interpol. He remains on trial here for the killing of 15 top opponents by his military government in the 1980s.

title: Senator, a Guardsman, Seeks Afghanistan Stint
description: BOSTON  Senator Scott P. Brown of Massachusetts announced Monday that he had asked to conduct his annual training as a member of the states Army National Guard this summer in Afghanistan.

title: 4 Questions He Leaves Behind
description: To give the devil his awful due, Osama bin Laden was the greatest terrorist of the modern age. He took what had been disparate, disorganized terrorist groups and reshaped them into a disciplined and immensely ambitious organization, Al Qaeda, with the singular goal of waging jihad on the West in general and the United States in particular. Its terrorist prowess was never more evident than on that horrible day of Sept. 11, 2001.

title: Kings Staying Put for Now, but Arena Is Key to Future
description: Sacramento will hold onto the Kings for one more season, but its chances of keeping them long term rest solely on the citys ability to approve, finance and build a new arena  a goal the city has failed to meet many times in the last decade.

title: Ideas and Theory: The Political Difference
description: The last of the 200 comments to my previous column declaring the political impotence of the everything-is-socially-constructed thesis accuses me of assuming that ideas have no consequences. Nothing could be further from the truth. Women have long been marginalized and suppressed by a dominant male culture is an idea. Gays have been denied the rights that are theirs as citizens is an idea. Each of these ideas has been enormously consequential; and each has been the basis of concerted action that altered our political and cultural landscape.

title: U.S. to Join Suit Against For-Profit College Chain
description: The Justice Department plans to intervene in a whistle-blower lawsuit charging that one of the nations largest for-profit college companies, the Education Management Corporation, defrauded the government by illegally paying recruiters based on the number of students they enrolled, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing on Monday.

title: Grizzlies Make Room for Randolphs Rough Edges
description: To better understand the star-crossed basketball journey of Zach Randolph, consider that as a high school senior 11 years ago he was beaten out for Indianas prestigious Mr. Basketball honors by the one, the only, Jared Jeffries.

title: Buffett Lets the Facts Bury Sokol
description: OMAHA  In Warren E. Buffetts view, he was as ruthless as ever.

title: Rule Would Discourage States Cutting Medicaid Payments to Providers
description: WASHINGTON  In a new effort to increase access to health care for poor people, the Obama administration is proposing a rule that would make it much more difficult for states to cut Medicaid payments to doctors and hospitals.

title: Vatican: Bishop Who Broached New Rules for Priests Is Ousted
description: The Vatican ousted an Australian bishop on Monday who had called on the church to consider ordaining women and married men. In a statement, the Vatican said that it had removed from pastoral care Bishop William Morris, left, the bishop of Toowoomba, Australia. The statement was particularly strong; normally the Vatican urges bishops to resign and then announces that it has accepted their resignation. Australian media reported that Bishop Morris had recently published an open letter saying that he was being removed for having argued in 2006 that the church should consider ordaining women and married men in order to fight a shortage of priests, prompting Pope Benedict XVI to open an investigation into his diocese. In the letter, Bishop Morris said he that he refused to resign, but would take early retirement because the pope had decided that the diocese would be better served by the leadership of a new bishop.

title: In Deputys Arrest on Drug and Assault Charges, Another Crisis for Trenton Mayor
description: The second-ranking city official in Trenton was arrested on Monday and charged with heroin possession and assaulting two police officers, the latest blow to an administration that has lurched from crisis to crisis since taking office in July.

title: Bucking Trend, Connecticut Budget Deal Raises Taxes, Gasoline Excepted
description: Driving against traffic in an antitax era, Connecticut lawmakers appear poised to approve a two-year, $40.2 billion budget that includes $1.5 billion in increased taxes on income, corporations and an array of purchases and services, from yachts to yoga classes.

title: With Ejection, Pierce Revisits Impulsive Past
description: CORAL GABLES, Fla.  In another place and time, a younger, flightier Paul Pierce threw a forearm, was tossed from a game and nearly cost the Boston Celtics a playoff series.

title: Sense on the Stem Cell Front
description: The federal governments financing of embryonic stem cell research got a boost Friday when an appeals court panel ruled that the work could go on while a lower-court judge ponders its legality. More uncertainty awaits as opponents try to derail this promising field of research.

title: Property Lost in Holocaust Is Cataloged Online
description: JERUSALEM  As millions of Israelis paused in reflection on Monday at the sound of the siren marking Holocaust Remembrance Day, the Internet here was buzzing. The first online database of more than half a million pieces of property lost by Holocaust victims, many in Eastern Europe, had just been uploaded as a first step toward restitution.

title: What Drives History
description: Osama Bin Ladens mother was about 15 at the time of his birth. Nicknamed The Slave inside the family, she was soon discarded and sent off to be married to a middle manager in the Bin Laden construction firm.

title: So Many Memorable Races, Too Many Forgettable Picks
description: The other night I closed my eyes and remembered that steel gray colt named Monarchos steaming down the stretch at Churchill Downs on May 5, 2001, my heart racing right alongside him, on his way to an emphatic four-and-three-quarter-length victory in the 127th running of the Kentucky Derby.

title: Tales of Wagering Winners and Woes
description: 12:50 p.m. Wednesday | Updated tales from Times facebook readers and the lowdown on the Lightning-Pick Six saga.

title: Conservatives in Canada Expand Partys Hold
description: OTTAWA  The Conservative Party will again govern Canada, this time with a majority, following the countrys fourth election in seven years.

title: Doctor Rules Out Rare Disorder in Hughess Arm
description: DETROIT  The most encouraging element of the Yankees day Monday occurred not in Comerica Park, where they began a series against the Tigers, but at a doctors office 450 miles away in St. Louis. That was wherePhil Hughes learned that he does not have a rare neurovascular condition that could have sidelined him for the season.

title: Henry Cooper, Dramatic Loser to Ali, Dies at 76
description: Henry Cooper, a popular British heavyweight with a murderous left hook that, in his most famous fight, knocked a brash, future world champion then known as Cassius Clay on his backside, died Sunday in Oxted, Surrey, south of London. He was 76.

title: U.S. Business Has High Tax Rates but Pays Less
description: The United States may soon wind up with a distinction that makes business leaders cringe  the highest corporate tax rate in the world.

description: Jenrry Mejia, one of the Mets top pitching prospects, tore the medial collateral ligament in his right elbow and may need season-ending surgery.

title: Helping New Drugs Out of Researchs Valley of Death
description: Consider two numbers: 800,000 and 21.

title: Americans Favor Budget Cuts Over Raising Corporate Tax
description: While most Americans say corporations do not pay their fair share in taxes, they still prefer cuts in government spending to increasing taxes on corporations as a means of cutting the federal budget deficit, according to a recent New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: When Meeting a Congressman, Leave Nothing to Chance
description: SUN LAKES, Ariz.  It was no accident that Gina Gennaro found herself outnumbered at a town-hall-style meeting the other night and shushed when she tried to press her objections to Republican plans to remake Medicare.

title: Turning to Social Networks for News
description: When the White House abruptly announced an address to the nation by President Obama on Sunday night, CNN anchors spent the better part of an hour previewing the address without actually saying what it was about.

title: Norman Mailers Eclectic Life, as Seen Through His Last Home
description: Among the furnishings, photographs and knickknacks that fill Norman Mailers curious apartment in Brooklyn Heights, a visitor can get a sense of the writers voracious appetite for the patchwork of experiences life has to offer.

title: States Chief Judge Pledges More Aid for Poor in Courts
description: ALBANY  New Yorks chief judge, Jonathan Lippman, on Monday called the states routine failure to provide lawyers for poor criminal defendants being arraigned in local courts a problem that can no longer be tolerated, and pledged to remedy the situation within a year.

title: The End of the Jihadist Dream
description: TO the Qaeda members I interrogated at Guantnamo Bay and elsewhere in the aftermath of 9/11, Osama bin Laden was never just the founder and leader of the group, but also an idea. He embodied the belief that their version of Islam was correct, that terrorism was the right weapon, and that they would ultimately be victorious. Bin Ladens death did not kill that idea, but did deal it a mortal blow.

title: The Long-Awaited News
description: The news that Osama bin Laden had been tracked and killed by American forces filled us, and all Americans, with a great sense of relief. But our reaction was strongly tinged with sadness. Nearly a decade after the Sept. 11, 2001, attacks, the horror has not faded, nor has the knowledge of how profoundly our lives were changed.

title: Shots Heard Round the World
description: Three hearses, flag-draped and drawn by horses, rolled through the colonial streets of Boston on May 1. The men of the Sixth Massachusetts  the noble sons who have given their lifes blood in defense of the laws and maintenance of their countrys honor, in the words of the next mornings newspaper  had come home. The cortge, accompanied by Gov. John A. Andrew and by militia cadets marching with their muskets reversed, drew up at last before the staid 18th-century portico of Kings Chapel on Tremont Street. Slowly, the chapels great bell, cast long ago in bronze by Paul Revere himself, tolled a dirge.

title: The Full Poll on Spending and Taxation
description: A poll by The New York Times and CBS News on government spending, the federal budget and taxation.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted March 2 through 7 with 1,266 adults throughout the United States.

title: In Book, Ryan Is Ryan, Like It or Not
description: Rex Ryan has extended his general approach  open, blunt, direct and in some instances offensive  from the spoken word to the written one. In his book, Play Like You Mean It, Ryan produced an inside look of his first two years as the Jets coach and, perhaps fittingly, managed to spark the same reactions.

title: Lottery Numbers

description: A daily dose of a hormone gel reduced premature births by nearly half among women at particularly high risk, according to a recent study.

title: American Universities Group Votes to Expel Nebraska
description: For the first time in its 111-year history, an organization made up of the nations leading research universities has voted to oust one of its members, the University of Nebraska at Lincoln.

title: Behind the Hunt for Bin Laden
description: WASHINGTON  For years, the agonizing search for Osama bin Laden kept coming up empty. Then last July, Pakistanis working for the Central Intelligence Agency drove up behind a white Suzuki  navigating the bustling streets near Peshawar, Pakistan, and wrote down the cars license plate.

title: Funeral for Bus Crash Victim, After Wifes Long Wait for a Reunion
description: For the last three years of his life, until he died in the crash of a bus returning to New York from a casino in Connecticut, Wang Jianhua lived beneath the radar, an illegal immigrant eking out a livelihood in Manhattan as a restaurant deliveryman.

title: Bin Ladens Dead. Al Qaedas Not.
description: Washington

title: Catharsis Comes Once Again With Mets on the Field
description: As word of the death of Osama bin Laden spread through Citizens Bank Park in Philadelphia on Sunday night while the Mets played the Phillies, Bobby Valentine sat in the broadcast booth and reflected on everything that happened nearly 10 years earlier, when he was managing the Mets in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. He wasnt the only one looking back.

title: Enforcing Copyrights Online, for a Profit
description: DENVER  When Brian Hill, a 20-year-old blogger from North Carolina, posted on his Web site last December a photograph of an airport security officer conducting a pat-down, a legal battle was the last thing he imagined.

title: Cuomo Backs Higher Tuition at Top SUNY Campuses
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said Monday that he would support allowing the flagship campuses of the State University of New York to charge higher tuition than the rest of the system, a stance that could pit him against fellow Democrats who worry that lower-income students could be priced out of the top schools.

title: A Mood of Triumph and Sober Reflection
description: There were, of course, the joyous celebrations, the honking horns, cheering crowds and waving flags, as if war had been won and tyranny ended. But word that Osama bin Laden had at last been killed brought out other voices on Monday as well: sober, reflective, wounded still and vengeful, but also articulate in hope.

title: Even Before Al Qaeda Lost Its Founder, It May Have Lost Some of Its Allure
description: WASHINGTON  Al Qaeda and the movement it has spawned are unlikely to be immediately handicapped by the killing of Osama bin Laden, who by most accounts has long been removed from managing terrorist operations and whose popularity with Muslims worldwide has plummeted in recent years.

title: Tuesday: Its a Little Longer Than a Foot
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Its a bird! Its a plane! Its  Kevan Choset, back to put us through our puzzle paces.

title: Moshe Landau Dies at 99; Oversaw Eichmann Trial
description: Moshe Landau, the presiding judge in the war-crimes trial of Adolf Eichmann, died at his home in Jerusalem on Sunday, the eve of Israels Holocaust Remembrance Day. He was 99.

description: Archs High Bid Revives a Bubble

title: Mets Offer Free Tickets to Military Members
description: In a salute to the United States military, the Mets are planning to give away 4,000 tickets to Tuesday nights game against the San Francisco Giants to members of the armed services and their families.

title: Nevada: House Race Is Thrown Open to All
description: A special election to replace Representative Dean Heller, a Republican about to be appointed to the United States Senate, should be open to all candidates, not just those selected by the two major political parties, Nevadas secretary of state ruled on Monday. The decision improves the prospects of Sharron Angle, the Tea Party-backed Republican who ran for Senate last year and whom state Republicans had signaled that they did not want to run for this seat. The secretary of state, Ross J. Miller, a Democrat, ruled against an interpretation of the law that would limit the ballot to just candidates chosen by the major parties. Pleased to announce an open-ballot-access election, Mr. Miller posted on his Twitter account. Freedom for all to run; let the people decide rather than politically elite power brokers. Mr. Hellers Second Congressional District is, normally, solidly Republican; the decision appears to put the Sept. 13 election in flux. Mr. Heller would replace John Ensign, a Republican, whose resignation is effective today.

title: Media React: Haaretz Weighs In
description: The Web site for the Israeli publication Haaretz led its coverage with a map of the compound where Osamabin Laden was found, with the headline: U.S. Had No Choice but to Kill Bin Laden, Says U.S. Defense Official. Other content on the home page included a slide show of Americans celebrating the killing and an article featuring the results of a survey conducted by the Pew Research Center Global Attitudes Project. According to the article, the data found that support for Bin Laden had declined among Muslims worldwide. While the publications lead editorial focused on the commemoration of Holocaust Martyrs and Heroes Day, an editorial titled The Road to Bin Laden Ran Through Guantnamo Bay, by Yossi Melman, extolled the merits of the United States war on terror, including the cost to American taxpayers. It turned out that it was worth every cent.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Slogging on the Home Front
description: The bureaucratic logjam for veterans pursuing benefit claims has gotten so huge that judges  in Dickensian fashion  are having to work nights and weekends as they decide more than 600 cases each annually. The little-noticed court for appealing rejected claims is about to be even more overwhelmed by the caseloads from the Iraq and Afghanistan wars.

title: A Real, Unnecessary Crisis for Families
description: Ben Bernanke, the Federal Reserve chairman, made a strong argument for good early childhood care. In a speech in New York City, he argued that the value can be especially high for disadvantaged children with a strong payoff for the economy. These programs can increase high school graduation rates, and graduates earn more, pay more taxes, and rely less on state-provided health care.

title: For Hughes and Yankees, News Is All Good
description: DETROIT  The most encouraging element for the Yankees on Monday occurred not at Comerica Park, where they scored the winning runs in the ninth inning of their 5-3 victory against the Tigers, but at a doctors office 450 miles away in St. Louis. That was where Phil Hughes learned that he did not have a rare neurovascular condition that could have sidelined him for the season.

title: William Taylor II, Ex-Publisher of Boston Globe, Dies at 78
description: William O. Taylor II, a former publisher of The Boston Globe and the fourth member of his family to run that newspaper, died on Sunday at his home in Boston. Mr. Taylor, who oversaw the sale of The Globe to The New York Times Company in 1993, was 78.

title: Sony Finds More Cases of Hacking of Its Servers
description: Sony said Monday that it had discovered that more credit card information and customer profiles had been compromised during an attack on its servers last week.

title: In Neoprene and Kilts, Remembering a Risk Taker
description: Rihanna looked half naked in a black lace Stella McCartney gown with a sheer panel on one side. Beyonc wore a form-fitting Pucci the shape of a pepper mill. Rene Zellwegers gold lace dress, by Carolina Herrera, seemed demure by comparison, until she turned around to reveal the back, which plunged all the way into plumber territory.

Anna Wintour and Colin Firth  the actor who played King George VI  were standing at the top of the stairs, along with about 20 reporters and public relations people. I didnt see any reason to hang around there so I went into the exhibit, which is dedicated to Alexander McQueen.

The announcement of the success of the electric carriages created some surprise, as it has been thought lately that motors using some form of petroleum were best adapted for horseless carriage use, it reported.

title: An Art-Themed Block Party in Paris
description: Every spring art galleries in the Saint-Germain-des-Pres neighborhood, long famed as home to artists, writers and musicians, open their doors to the public, in a block party called Art Saint-Germain-des-Pres. With what might be the highest concentration of galleries in the world, its an ideal area to find a variety of art, from primitive to contemporary and sculpture and painting to photography, jewelry and antiques. This years event, from May 19 to 22, will include at least 60 galleries. As an example of the events breadth, La Galerie Artco-France will show works by the Surrealist Ren Magritte and La Galerie Frdric Got Fine Art photographs by Elliott Erwitt.

And how should outside powers deal with Pakistan, whose president denied Western accusations that his nuclear-armed nation lacked what he called vitality in combating terrorism?

title: Bin Ladens Death Expected to Have Little Impact on Al Qaeda in Iraq
description: BAGHDAD  Eight years ago Osama bin Laden called on his followers to head to Iraq to fight the United States. Within months, Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia took form, eventually allying itself with militants from the countrys Sunni minority. The group took a leading role in the insurgency that plunged Iraq into a bloody sectarian war.

title: Book of Mormon and Scottsboro Boys Lead Tony Nominations
description: The nominees for the 65th annual Tony Awards were announced this morning. Updates and analysis from the announcement, and developments as they unfolded, are below. A slide show of the nominees for best musical can be found here and a slide show for the nominees for best play can be found here. Make sure to fill out the interactive ballot here.

title: A Comedian Laughs All the Way to Dystopia
description: LOS ANGELES  For a guy who just wrote a whole book about the myriad catastrophes that could befall the United States in the next 20 years, Albert Brooks says hes not interested in end-of-the-world scenarios and, more to the point, hes too nervous to contemplate them.

title: Turkish Leader Says Qaddafi Must Step Down Immediately
description: ISTANBUL  In his harshest comments to date on the situation in Libya, Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, a regional power broker, told reporters here on Tuesday that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi had chosen blood, tears, oppression and that he must immediately step down.

title: Man Group Raises $1.5 Billion for Japan Fund
description: The Man Group said on Tuesday that it had raised $1.5 billion for a new hedge fund based in Japan.

title: Putting a Price on Sharks
description: Reef sharks, as I noted in an article on Monday about a new study, are worth more in the water than when sold for their fins and meat, at least in some cases.

title: Tuesday Reading: Bin Ladens Death Spurs Worldwide Travel Alert
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Updates on the Death of Bin Laden, May 3
description: On Tuesday, The Lede continues to follow the global reaction to the killing of Osama bin Laden during an American raid in Pakistan early on Monday.

title: Onex Sells Husky International for $2.1 Billion
description: Two private equity firms said on Tuesday that they had acquired Husky International, a maker of injection molding equipment for the plastics industry, for $2.1 billion from Onex, the largest Canadian private equity firm.

description: Tuesday will be partly cloudy and warmer than Monday, with highs reaching the mid-70s. Thunderstorms are possible in the evening.

title: Headline Inflation and Wages (Wonkish)
description: I suspect that this article by Heleen Mees will get a lot of attention from the inflationistas, who will see in it another reason to worry. So I guess Id better weigh in to say that the, um, core argument doesnt seem to make any sense.

title: On the Ground with a Gap Year
description: Ive periodically recommended that high school students take a gap year after graduation, by deferring college entrance for one year. Most colleges encourage students to take a gap year, partly because students then arrive a little more mature, a little more ready to study, a little more worldly. Its becoming a bit more common, and Princeton now pays for some kids to travel during their gap year, but most people are still wary of the idea. In fact, almost every kid Ive talked to who has taken a gap year raves about the idea, so I thought Id commission a guest column from my eldest son, Gregory, who is currently taking a gap year in China. He spent most of the year studying Chinese at Tsinghua University and then at a language school in Dalian, and soon hes going to finish up the year studying Spanish in Peru. On the side, he worked and volunteered. Heres his take:

title: Now Renting | Traveling Coffee Bar
description: The quest for the perfect cup of organic fair-trade Sumatran coffee can take you far afield (or at least off the island of Manhattan). But why travel when Melissa Knott of Grounded Coffee Catering will bring her coffee bar to you? Knott will journey anywhere in New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania where theres a dedicated electrical outlet and four clear feet of space for her folding table and portable Pasquini espresso machine. Along with filter coffee and espresso drinks  including a fantastic decaf  Knott offers loose-leaf black and herbal teas, hot chocolate (made with dairy, soy or coconut milk) and Italian sodas, all organic and fair-trade. She works with a local roaster to create custom blends and has them specially roasted for each event she caters. Since founding her business three and a half years ago, Knott has pulled shots and poured cups everywhere from suburban pool parties to the set of a slasher film on Governors Island. Her dedication to coffee  she wrote her thesis on it  is such that she even checks the water quality of an area before heading out. I actually prefer to bring my own, she says. If the waters too hard or too soft it really affects the taste of the coffee. For more on Grounded Coffee Catering, including information on the farmers markets where Knott sells her custom roasted beans, go to groundedcatering.com.

title: Five Men Arrested Near Plant In Britain
description: LONDON  Five men have been arrested near the Sellafield nuclear fuel reprocessing plant in the north of England under antiterrorism laws, the police said.

title: Rights Group Urges Prosecutions in Thai Violence
description: BANGKOK  A year after the bloody suppression of antigovernment protests in Bangkok, no government official has yet been charged with a crime related to the deaths of about 90 people, including medical workers and others who were apparently the deliberate targets of sniper fire, Human Rights Watch said in a report released Tuesday.

title: More Reasons to Say Eeh When You Learn About the ECB
description: Kevin ORourke directs us to a very good post that refers to evidence from the gold standard era on the advantages of a little inflation for a currency union  and the problems with tight money.

title: The Tony Nominations: Who Got Snubbed This Year?
description: Somewhere, Lord Voldemort is surely smiling while Harry Potter fans are heartbroken: Daniel Radcliffe leveraged his years as the star of that boy-wizard franchise to play J. Pierrepont Finch in the current Broadway revival of How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying, and spent months in vocal and dance training to get up to speed for the role. Yet he couldnt conjure up enough magic to secure a Tony nomination on Tuesday for a performance that excited many theatergoers and critics, making him one of the most glaring snubs of the morning. Did Tony nominators agree with Ben Brantley, who wrote in The New York Times that Mr. Radcliffe is clearly not to the musical manner born. Or was Mr. Radcliffe simply the victim of an evil spell cast by Severus Snape? We may never know.

title: The Caregivers Bookshelf: A Marriage Reshaped by Stroke
description: Another caregivers memoir?

description: Theres been a lot of commentary on this subject, but I thought Tyler Cowens instinctive reaction was particularly interesting:

title: During Egyptian Uprising, a Scene of Hope
description: Jacopo Quaranta, 27, an Italian native and a graduate of the International Center of Photography school, spent a week in Egypt during the uprising. He spoke with Kerri MacDonald last week in New York. Their conversation, part of the Turning Point series, has been edited and condensed.

title: River Level Drops After Blast at Levee
description: EAST PRAIRIE, Mo.  Last-ditch efforts to prevent a small Illinois town from flooding appeared to be working Tuesday morning, hours after the Army Corps of Engineers used explosives to tear open a protective levee.

title: No Fantasy in F.D.I.C. Lehman Paper

title: U.S. Sues Deutsche Bank Over Loan Practices
description: The United States government sued Deutsche Bank on Tuesday, accusing it of lying about the quality of home loans it handled under a government program and demanding that the bank repay hundreds of millions of dollars of losses on those loans.

title: Recipes to Curb Appetites
description: As I explain in todays Well column, Adding Food and Subtracting Calories,  researchers at Penn State University found that adding vegetable pure to various recipes didnt change the flavor much but did lead to big reductions in the amount of calories consumed. The result was that diners felt full after eating fewer calories, allowing the vegetable pure mixtures to act as natural appetite suppressants.

title: U.S. Sues Deutsche Bank Over Mortgages
description: Federal prosecutors on Tuesday filed a civil mortgage fraud lawsuit against Deutsche Bank and its MortgageIT unit, accusing the bank of reckless lending practices.

description: Tobys Corner, winner of the Wood Memorial and a leading contender for the Kentucky Derby, is lame in his left hind leg and will not run in Saturdays Derby.

John Legend (and the Roots) and Spike Lee. Duran Duran and David Lynch.

title: Uneven Prospects for the Arab World
description: The popular uprisings across the Arab world are defining a new order in the region. But as the transition continues, the areas economies are diverging sharply, posing added challenges to leaders as they seek to cultivate greater stability.

description: The top counterterrorism official in the United States pledged on Tuesday to get to the bottom of whether the Pakistani government provided help to Osama bin Laden in his decade-long efforts to avoid detection by those who were hunting him.

title: Richard Cornuelle, Libertarian Author, Dies at 84
description: Richard Cornuelle, a libertarian writer whose best-known book, Reclaiming the American Dream, championed volunteerism as a means of addressing social problems like poverty, unemployment, delinquency and urban blight, died on April 26 at his home in Manhattan. He was 84.

title: Pac-10 Secures Rich Deals With Fox and ESPN
description: The Pacific-10 Conference will start its own network on cable television in 2012, but will also sell most of its marquee football and basketball games to Fox and ESPN for about $3 billion over 12 years, more than quadrupling what the two companies have been paying.

title: In M.L.S., a Suspension Too Far?
description: Colorados Brian Mullan was suspended by M.L.S. for nearly a third of this seasons games after his tackle on Seattle Sounders striker Steve Zakuani broke Zakuanis leg.

title: The Red Carpet at the Met Gala
description: This years guest list was typically elite, and the fashion was daring in honor of the late Alexander McQueen.

title: Pelley Talks About New Job on Evening News
description: Scott Pelley, the 60 Minutes correspondent, will succeedKatie Couric as the anchor of the CBS Evening News next month  and he plans to stay almost full time at his current job.

title: Was Big D Wise to Pursue Small Customers?
description: Last week, we published a case study that explored whether Big D Custom Screen Printing could become profitable by specializing in small T-shirt orders. After a year in business, the company had sales of $325,000 on which it suffered a nominal loss. Big Ds co-founder, Darren Robbins, and his partner disagreed as to the best way to turn things around. His partner wanted to focus on large corporate accounts. Mr. Robbins believed Big D could thrive by targeting customers with small orders  as small as one T-shirt. The partners split (amicably) over the issue.

title: This Time, The Tonys Grow Up and Get It Right
description: Whats this? A full slate of real, original plays  and I mean plays, like mom and dad used to dress up for and would talk about over martinis afterward. Though the Tony nominations announced Tuesday morning didnt offer many surprises (the hearty, 12-nomination celebration of Scottsboro Boys was the only mild shocker), it did confirm some good news. Legitimate dramas are still being written, and theyre being written well.

title: Harold Garfinkel, a Common-Sense Sociologist, Dies at 93
description: Harold Garfinkel, an innovative sociologist who turned the study of common sense into a dense and arcane discipline, creating one of his fields most challenging and fruitful branches of inquiry, died April 21 at his home in Pacific Palisades, Calif. He was 93.

title: Demand for Small Cars Pushed April Sales Up 18%
description: DETROIT  Vehicle sales rose 18 percent in April, automakers said Tuesday, as consumers flocked to smaller cars in response to higher fuel prices and improved models from surging American companies.

title: The Making of a Cover
description: Our cover story on Sunday was about the American soldiers accused of murdering Afghan civilians. Some reports have depicted them as a rogue unit, but our story goes deeper into the psyche of the American soldier and questions whether the killings are symptoms of a much larger issue. Being a weekly, time was a factor, so we executed some staff-produced, alternate versions of the magazines cover, two days before it had to ship. We started with a graphic approach, experimenting with every font in our arsenal. We did more than can be featured in this blog post, but the following is a curated depiction of our process for developing a cover.

title: Nissan Is Named New York City Taxi of Tomorrow, Beating Out Ford and Karsan

title: Students Take Time to Reflect on Bin Laden
description: Matt Polazzo, a teacher at Stuyvesant High School in Lower Manhattan, put aside his planned lesson on Nigerian politics on Monday to ask what his students thought about the demise of Osama bin Laden, who was killed the day before by American soldiers in Pakistan.

title: Bright Passages
description: Notes from the newsroom on grammar, usage and style. (Some frequently asked questions are here.)
