title: Oscar de la Renta: Hey, Thats Me!
description: Well, that was embarrassing. A photograph that accompanied my article on the Met gala in Tuesday mornings paper was accompanied by an erroneous caption that identified the designer Oscar de la Renta as Giorgio Armani. (For what its worth, I dont write the captions.) Mr. Armani wasnt even at the party.

title: Court Denies Appeal of Spector Murder Conviction
description: A California appeals court has turned down an appeal by Phil Spector to have his murder conviction overturned and rejected the argument that other women who said he had threatened them with guns should not have been allowed to testify in the case, The Associated Press reported.

title: Ren Emilio Ponce, El Salvador General Linked to Priests Murders, Dies at 64
description: Ren Emilio Ponce, a Salvadoran military leader accused of ordering one of the most shocking atrocities of El Salvadors civil war, the killing of six Jesuit priests in 1989, died on Monday at a military hospital in San Salvador. He was 64.

title: Three Ways to Count Whales
description: Kate Stafford, an oceanographer at the Applied Physics Laboratory at the University of Washington, writes from Alaska, where she is participating in a visual census of bowhead whales.

title: The Morning Line: Hedging Bets at the Derby
description: Much like the public handicappers, the sports media Tuesday was unable to settle upon a favorite among the horses to cover in the Kentucky Derby. Instead the coverage was spread out among nearly all the horses likely to be entered in the Derby.

title: Three N.H.L. Teams in 2-0 Hole
description: You know that metaphoric panic button that everyone was hitting so earnestly in the first round of the N.B.A. and N.H.L. playoffs? Well, it has made an early reappearance in the second round. Of course, the Lakers really never put it away. They like having it around for dramatic effect. It sits next to their bench. It might even have a sponsor.

title: A Missouri Village at the Center of It All
description: If one were to divide the country into equal parts based on population, Plato, Mo., would fall square in the middle, according to the United States Census Bureau.

title: We Got Him
description: In early November 2004, I kissed my husband goodbye as he left for his first deployment to Afghanistan. I told him, my voice trembling as he walked toward the war, Go and kill Bin Laden.

title: Daring the Devil on Wheels
description: Martin Amis once described a certain kind of attention-getting book review  an unlikely person assigned by a mischievous editor to discuss an unlikely topic  with this excellent bit of shorthand: Evel-Knievel-on-Kierkegaard.

title: Resources, Inflation, and Monetary Policy
description: Ive been getting a number of requests that I say something about the implications of the widely publicized Jeremy Grantham piece arguing that weve entered a new era of resource scarcity.

title: Honda Expands Air-Bag Recall to 833,000 Additional Vehicles
description: In its fourth action to fix a problem with an air bag that deploys so forcefully it can injure or kill a driver, Honda announced late on Monday that it was recalling 833,000 more vehicles.

title: Save the Mothers
description: While you make your brunch plans, and search through racks of cards praising Mom, take a moment to remember that there are many places where it is dangerous to be a mother.

title: White House Weighs Whether to Release the Photo
description: To release or not to release?

title: City Ballet Reaches Accord With Dancers
description: Dancers with the New York City Ballet voted 63-1 on Tuesday to accept a contract after contentious negotiations over issues like overtime and salary. Im pretty excited, said Devin Alberda, a member of the companys corps de ballet who serves on the dancers six-member negotiating committee. I dont think we got everything we wanted, but we made a lot of progress in terms of our work conditions.

title: You Say Man Cave, I Say Good Taste
description: If Bravo is the network devoted to baroque expressions of coastal affluence, TLC exists as its spirit cousin and opposition: a cable channel committed to the ostensibly bizarre habits of non-elites. Producers take us from Pennsylvania to Arkansas to Utah and to other places that are neither West Hollywood nor East Hampton to uncover overbreeders (19 Kids and Counting, Kate Plus 8), polygamists (Sister Wives), addicts of household flotsam (Hoarding: Buried Alive) and the strange people who submit their young children to spray tans (Toddlers & Tiaras). Bravo ridicules the world of the well to do; TLC, instead, implicitly makes fun of the idea that those hoping to avoid encounters with creepiness or bad taste are safe beyond the realm of four-ply cashmere.

title: Q&A: Seeing the Sewers and Catacombs of Paris
description: Q.

title: Bird Week | Audubons Last Dear Home, on West 155th
The Nook Enters Tablet Territory
description: The new system upgrade for the Nook Color e-reader from Barnes & Noble does more than improve its usefulness as an electronic book  it adds new features that youd normally associate with a tablet. That includes the addition of apps, new e-mail capabilities and improved the social features.

title: How to Call Attention to a Great Wine
description: My column this week is on a tasting of nine vintages of Chteau Trotanoy, the excellent Pomerol that is sometimes overlooked with all the attention paid to its superstar stablemate, Chteau Ptrus.

title: Critics Picks Video: 12:08 East of Bucharest
description: This week, A. O. Scott looks at a film from Corneliu Porumboiu, one of the directors who has emerged out of the new wave of Romanian cinema. His film, 12:08 East of Bucharest, looks back at the Romanian revolution of 1989 and asks what the revolution meant to the country and how such a dynamic moment could quickly fade into history. In the film, three characters gather in a drab television studio to commemorate the revolution and to also question whether or not it really happened. Mr. Scott says that one of the elements that makes the film stand out is its sly, deadpan, understated wit. Have you seen 12:08 East of Bucharest or other films from the Romanian new wave? Please share your thoughts.

title: The Big Thirst': The Future of Water
description: Charles Fishman, a longtime writer for Fast Company magazine, is the author of The Big Thirst, a new book on water. He previously wrote The Wal-Mart Effect, which was an Economist book of the year in 2006 and a finalist in The Financial Timess awards for best business book. Our conversation follows.

title: U.N. Forecasts 10.1 Billion People by Centurys End
description: The population of the world, long expected to stabilize just above 9 billion in the middle of the century, will instead keep growing and may hit 10.1 billion by the year 2100, the United Nations projected in a report released Tuesday.

title: Roger Cohen in Libya
description: The Op-Ed columnist Roger Cohen reports from Darnah, Libya, on reaction to Osama bin Laden's death.

title: Cuban May Pursue Dodgers Next
description: The Dallas Mavericks owner Mark Cuban has said hes done chasing baseball teams he wants to purchase, without quite ruling out a run at the troubled Dodgers.

title: Peter Bergen to Write Book on Bin Laden Manhunt
description: Less than 48 hours after Osama bin Ladens death, the book deals have begun. Peter Bergen will write the definitive book on the hunt for Bin Laden, his publisher said on Tuesday. Crown Publishers, part of Random House, said it had acquired a new book by Mr. Bergen that it described as an immersive, definitive account of the operation that killed the worlds most wanted man.

title: Let Them Eat Choux
description: Popelini, the pastry shop Lauren Koumetz opened this month in Pariss Marais neighborhood, is devoted exclusively to choux  la crme, or cream puffs, the bite-size flavor shots that offer a sugar lover an alternative to Frances superstar macaron. On any given day, the choux are lined up in a half dozen flavors including dark chocolate, lemon praline, salted butter caramel, Madagascar vanilla and rose; some have an additional confit filling of passion fruit or raspberry. And then theres the choux du jour, dreamed up by the pastry chef Alice Barday, which might be strawberry-litchi, Earl Grey tea, pear, or tiramisu, inspired by the Italian dessert with whipped cream, almonds and crunchy chocolate sprinkles.

title: Troubled Employers and Your Company Charge Card
description: Buried near the end of a lengthy New York magazine profile of voluptuous financier Lynn Tilton was a nugget that caught our eye here at Bucks.

title: TimesCast | A Reclusive Neighbor
description: May 3, 2011 - Carlotta Gall visits Bin Laden's neighborhood and explains how what happened there is creating heightening tensions between the C.I.A. and the I.S.I.

title: Prevailing Poet Is Decreed in Meadowlands Ode Contest
description: On City Room did we last weekA poetry contest declareThe charge: to rewrite Kubla KhanMuch better known as XanaduIn light of recent news.

title: Russian Is Charged in Absentia With Betraying Spies in U.S.
description: MOSCOW  After a group of Russian sleeper agents were arrested in the United States last summer, an angry Vladimir V. Putin, Russias prime minister, promised to punish the person who betrayed them.

title: Canadian Leader Celebrates Victory Over Opposition
description: OTTAWA  It was a different Prime Minister Stephen Harper who appeared on Tuesday for his first news conference after his Conservative Partys resounding victory in Canadas federal election.

title: May Day
description: Now that Osama bin Laden is dead, I imagine many historians will be taking out their chisels and stones in an attempt to capture the moment within the historical record. Most military histories hyphenate years of conflict and inscribe them on a tombstone formed by parentheses. When we walk through historys graveyard, for example, we find: World War I (1914-1918) and World War II (1939-1945) among the many rows of markers annotating warfare.

title: The Up Side of Population (Projections)
description: Rumors of an impending human population crash are not borne out by the latest United Nations projections, offering further proof that human beings are the least certain factor in efforts to project the course of events on this planet in this century.

title: Mood Spending
description: Term used to describe emotional (and ill-considered) purchasing  illustrated by ticket applications for the 2012 London Olympics.

title: Colonie
description: THE lack of good restaurants in Brooklyn Heights has been a topic of discussion along the neighborhoods leafy sidewalks at least since the first white-shoe lawyers crossed the Brooklyn Bridge to settle there.

title: Reviewing Colonie
Teenager Questioned in Death of Baby
description: Updated, 9:35 p.m. | The police are questioning a 17-year-old in connection with the death of a baby who died on Tuesday while in his care, a law enforcement official said.

title: Inequality Rising Across the Developed World
description: America isnt the only rich country dealing with a rise in inequality. Most of the developed world is, too.

title: Icahn Gets Backing From I.S.S. on Mentor Graphics
description: Carl C. Icahns slate of candidates for the board of Mentor Graphics has received support from the influential proxy advisory firm Institutional Shareholder Services.

title: Obama to Observe 9/11 Anniversary in New York
description: President Obama will travel to New York City this September to observe the 10-year anniversary of 9/11 and the opening of a memorial at ground zero, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said on Tuesday.

title: Checking In | W Hotel, London
description: Centuries ago, Leicester Square was a genteel patch, but now it is brash and loud, bordered by an all-night Chinatown and ringed by West End theaters, carousels and street stalls. On weekend evenings, gaggles of young women soused on Magners or caffeinated tonic wine don dangerously short skirts (even in frigid temperatures) and stumble around the hucksters, buskers and neophyte tourists whove been sucked in, mothlike, by all that neon. There are good movie theaters here, great soup dumplings, and the square is convenient to just about everything in London. But it is not a traditionally desirable neighborhood for a hotel.

title: Congress Dedicates Statue of President Ford in Rotunda
description: Presidents Andrew Jackson and Ronald Reagan have new company: On Tuesday, a bronze statue of President Gerald R. Ford was dedicated in the Rotunda of the United States Capitol by Congressional leaders.

title: Six Tips on Taking Outside Investors
description: Having a great idea for a company is one thing. Getting the money to get it moving and growing is quite another  especially when youve got an unconventional product or business model that your average investor isnt likely to recognize as an obvious winner.

title: By the Numbers, an Uninspiring Derby Field
description: How fast are this years Kentucky Derby horses? Judging by the comments of Andrew Beyer, who developed Beyer Speed Figures, and Len Friedman of The Sheets, the field is anything but fast. John Scheinman at Kentucky Confidential talked to Beyer and Friedman:

title: Rick Riordans Favorite Childhood Books
description: Today marks the publication date of The Throne of Fire, the second in Rick Riordans latest mega-series, The Kane Chronicles, for which Disney has announced an initial print run of 1.5 million copies. Mr. Riordan is probably best known for his #1 best-selling Percy Jackson and the Olympians, also for middle grade readers, though he writes novels for adults as well.

title: Herms Is Selling Its Stake in Gaultiers Fashion House
description: Jean Paul Gaultier, the French designer whose fashion house has been in partnership with Herms since 1999, said Tuesday that the Puig Beauty and Fashion Group, a Spanish company whose primary focus is perfumes, was acquiring a controlling 60 percent share of the company.

title: How Should We Think of the Civil War?
description: Via Brad DeLong, Ta-Nehisi Coates argues that the Civil War wasnt tragic in the way its so often portrayed. The human losses were terrible  but the war marked the end of the far greater horror of slavery.

title: Obama to Give 60 Minutes Details on Bin Laden
description: President Obama will give his first extensive comments on the raid that killed Osama bin Laden in an interview with CBS Newss Steve Kroft that airs Sunday night on 60 Minutes.

title: Scene City: Inside the Met Gala
description: A glamorous and celebrity-studded crowd celebrated Alexander McQueen at the Metropolitan Museum of Arts annual Costume Institute gala.

title: Forstmann Is Said to Be Undergoing Treatment for Brain Cancer
description: Theodore J. Forstmann, one of Wall Streets original leveraged buyout barons, has received a diagnosis of a malignant brain tumor, according to a person close to him.

title: Teach for America Equalizes Health Costs for Domestic Partners
description: Teach for America is the latest organization to ensure that its employees with same-sex partners get the same treatment as opposite-sex married couples when it comes to health care costs.

title: White House Corrects Bin Laden Narrative
description: White House officials on Tuesday sought to correct the official account of the raid in Pakistan that ended in the killing of Osama bin Laden, saying that the Qaeda leader was not armed and that his wife was not killed. But they added that Bin Laden resisted when confronted during the raid.

title: Europe Leads in Pushing for Privacy of User Data
description: BRUSSELS  As pressure grows for technology companies like Apple and Google to adjust how their phones and devices gather data, Europe seems to be where the new rules are being determined.

title: Mother Knows Best | Tory Burch
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#897", 592, 380, true, chameleonData);

title: How Credit Card Data Is Stolen and Sold
description: Last week, after the Sony PlayStation Network was attacked by a group of unknown hackers, Sonys 77 million customers, along with security specialists and government officials, were surprised by the amount of information that might have been stolen from the company.

title: More Todd Haynes on My Morning Jacket Concert Film
description: Todd Haynes talked to Nate Chinen about making a film of My Morning Jacket concert. The first half of their conversation can be found here. The second half follows.

title: Manny in High School: A Slide Show That Tells a Sluggers Story
Double Take: There Are Recipes, Too
description: After reading Frank Brunis article on Torrisi Italian Specialties and the future of Italian-American food, I was curious  and hungry. Even more so after the two chefs agreed to let us post several of their recipes online. As a general rule, Im not into polyglot food. Curry on pasta? Even pineapple on Hawaiian pizza? Not for me. As Bruni points out, fusion has become a bit of a naughty word. But I was intrigued by the chefs Lower East Side mash-ups. So last night I resolved to cook their prosciutto fried rice for an unsuspecting friend.

title: In Bulgaria, a Tradition Meets New Realities
description: Every year, members of the Kalaidzhi, a group of seminomadic Roma, gather in a field outside the town of Stara Zagora to conduct the complex negotiations on a bride price that traditionally lead to marriage. However, support for marriage traditions is waning.

title: Kronos Quartet Honored with Two Awards
description: As the San Francisco-based Kronos Quartet prepared for a European tour, beginning on Thursday in Athens, its bags became a little heavier on Tuesday with two major awards. Kronos will receive the Avery Fisher Prize, awarded in New York to individuals or chamber ensembles for outstanding achievement and excellence in music, as well as the Polar Music Prize, awarded in Stockholm (not on the quartets current itinerary), also intended to recognize exceptional achievement in music.

title: Behind High Walls, Model Neighbors Were Harboring a Fugitive
description: ABBOTTABAD, Pakistan  In his last days, Osama bin Laden was not surrounded by a circle of heavily armed Arab bodyguards or mujahedeen who had fought with him in Afghanistan against the Soviet Union. Rather, he relied on two Pakistanis, one of whom, according to American officials, was his most trusted courier. Both men died with him in the American raid on their compound.

title: NYSE Euronext Chief Isnt Fazed by Hostile Nasdaq Bid
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  While the Nasdaq OMX Group and the IntercontinentalExchange finally said on Monday they intended to go directly to NYSE Euronext shareholders to win over the exchange operator, the Big Boards chief executive said he wasnt worried.

title: To Meet Demand for Chips, Samsung Bets Big on Austin
description: AUSTIN, Tex.  Samsung Electronics, one of the worlds biggest chip makers, is betting $3.6 billion that people will keep buying smartphones and tablet computers.

title: Cables Show U.S. Concern on Japans Disaster Readiness
description: TOKYO  In March 2008, the American ambassador in Tokyo sent a classified cable to Washington that contained a prophetic warning about the disaster preparedness of Japan, the United States most important ally in Asia.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, Libya, Missouri, and New Zealand.

title: Low-Salt Diet Ineffective, Study Finds. Disagreement Abounds.
description: A new study found that low-salt diets increase the risk of death from heart attacks and strokes and do not prevent high blood pressure, but the researchs limitations mean the debate over the effects of salt in the diet is far from over.

title: A Perfect Baby
description: When my older son was born, I quietly pitied other mothers of newborns. Mine was just so gorgeous, while theirs were, lets face it, somewhat misshapen and blobby.

title: Pakistan Pushes Back Against U.S. Criticism on Bin Laden
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Toughening its stand, the Pakistani government lashed out at the United States on Tuesday for the raid that killed Osama bin Laden, saying that the United States had made an unauthorized unilateral action that would be not be tolerated in the future.

title: Malcolm McKellar, Pioneer of the Pontiac Overhead-Cam Engine
description: Malcolm McKellar died on April 9, just a little more than a year after Pontiac  the brand he helped elevate to high-performance prominence  met its end. He was believed to be 90.

title: TimesCast | May 3, 2011
description: May 3, 2011 - New details on Bin Laden's life and surroundings, the uneasy relationship between the U.S. and Pakistani intelligence agencies, and Pakistan's culture of conspiracy theories.

title: Former Aide to Rangel Pleads Guilty in Tax Case
description: James Capel, who had been a top adviser to Representative Charles B. Rangel for more than a decade, pleaded guilty on Tuesday to failing to file tax returns, months after Mr. Rangel was censured on the House floor over his own tax problems.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, Libya, Missouri, and New Zealand.

title: The Hut Next Door
Florida Puts Overhaul of Courts to the Voters
description: MIAMI  The Florida Senate has decided to put major changes in the state court system before voters next year but only after rejecting the most contentious proposal, which would have split the Supreme Court in two.

title: In Tornado Zones, Seeking Shelter From the Storm
description: As communities across the storm-raked stretch of the South cope with the aftermath of the countrys second deadliest tornado outbreak, its worth reviewing the prime sources of vulnerability behind the terrible death counts: the substantial growth in southern populations in recent decades, a dearth of basements and the enduring popularity of mobile homes.

title: Virginia Woolfs Words, a Singers Voice
description: At intervals some emotion broke in. This astringent line, about Thomas Hardys funeral, is from the diary of Virginia Woolf, and also from Dominick Argentos classic 1974 song cycle, From the Diary of Virginia Woolf.

title: A Work Force for the World
description: China is increasingly known for shipping out cheap labor, and a backlash against it has grown across Africa and Asia, especially Vietnam.

title: Board Disciplines 3 Doctors
description: The Board of Medical Examiners in New Jersey, which is responsible for licensing doctors practicing in the state, said on Tuesday that it had disciplined three orthopedic surgeons because they did not disclose their personal financial interests in the success of an artificial spinal disk they were studying in clinical trials that were used by federal regulators to approve the disk.

title: USA Networks Twist on Upfront Puts Stars Up Front
description: 10:50 a.m. | Updated The executives at the USA Network cable channel decided to have some fun with the first large-scale presentation to advertisers, agencies and reporters of their coming season by sending out the stars of USA series to speak in their place.

title: Scandal-Scarred Formula One Men Return
description: After disappointing performances by the Williams Formula One car in the first three races, the team announced on Tuesday that its technical director, Sam Michael, and its chief aerodynamicist, Jon Tomlinson, had resigned, effective at the end of the season. The team also announced that Mike Coughlan, the race car designer behind a spying scandal four years ago, would join the team in June as chief engineer.

title: Scandal-Scarred Formula One Men Return
description: After disappointing performances by the Williams Formula One car in the first three races, the team announced on Tuesday that its technical director, Sam Michael, and its chief aerodynamicist, Jon Tomlinson, had resigned, effective at the end of the season. The team also announced that Mike Coughlan, the race car designer behind a spying scandal four years ago, would join the team in June as chief engineer.

title: Off the Beaten Path, History in Philadelphia
description: The No. 23 city bus running along the cobblestones is still known as the trolley,and you can take it to visit the house where a young Benjamin Franklin stopped for advice on books or to other homes where Revolutionary War battles left powder marks and bloodstains. George Washington slept here, a lot, and decades later so did runaway slaves at a well-preserved stop on the Underground Railroad. Theres also a homey lunch spot known for its veggie burger.

title: How to Yoke Oxen
description: A demonstration by the farmer Tim Huppe of how to yoke a pair of oxen for work in the field, from the 2003 how-to DVD "Training Oxen," a cult classic in the draft-power community.

title: Planetary iPad App Offers Visual Music Search
description: Video of Planetary from Bloom Studio.

title: Among Friends
description: Gays  and the heterosexuals who love them, including Chelsea Clinton  will gather tonight in New York for a fund-raiser for Friendfactor, a nonprofit organization that counts on the power of friendship to help gays and lesbians achieve equal rights.

title: Moving Students, Honoring Teachers
description: WASHINGTON  Michelle Obama surprised students at the Alice Deal Middle School in northwest Washington on Tuesday afternoon when she showed up to work out with them.

title: Tour dArt | Berlin Gallery Week
description: Where is Ai Weiwei? Its a good question, and one posed by the artist Rirkrit Tiravanija on a banner created to accompany Ais exhibition at Berlins Neugerriemschneider gallery, the opening of which Ai was regrettably unable to attend this past weekend because of a previous engagement with Chinese authorities. Despite his absence, his show was a big crowd pleaser during Berlins Gallery Weekend. The 44 participating galleries and numerous off-calendar spaces presented a thoughtful program that celebrated Berlins low-key ethos, and where the work, rather than celebrity-stocked private dinners and A-list parties, was the main attraction.

title: No Shades Needed in Not-So-Bright Future
description: Its the end of the world as we know it, or mighty close to it, in Laurel Hainess agreeably disjointed Future Anxiety, which opened on Thursday night at the Flea Theater. And while its many, many inhabitants may not exactly feel fine, theyre largely at peace with a world in which China imports American debtors as slave laborers, and the unemployment rate has dropped to a mere 65 percent.

title: Quiet Proxy Season Means Fewer Fights in the Boardroom
description: Proxy season is a bust.

title: A Good Night for ABC
description: ABC earned a solid victory in the ratings on Monday night as 20.9 million viewers tuned in to the networks reality competition Dancing With the Stars, according to Nielsens estimates. The two-hour installment dominated the ratings and boosted ABCs Castle (12.2 million) in the 10 p.m. hour ahead of CBSs Hawaii Five-0 (9.4 million) and NBCs Law & Order: Los Angeles (4.8 million). CBS placed second with sitcoms from 8 to 10 including How I Met Your Mother (6.7 million), Mad Love (5.8 million), Mike & Molly (8.1 million), as well as a repeat of Two and a Half Men at 9 (7.6 million). Fox was third with House (8.5 million) and The Chicago Code (5.5 million), while NBC placed fourth with Chuck at 8 (4.1 million) and The Event at 9 (4 million).

title: The Subway Gets a Dining Car
description: For one half-hour luncheon, a car on the L train was transformed into a traveling bistro, complete with tables, linens, silverware and a bow-tied matre dhtel.

title: Analyzing a Sea Change in Canada
description: Even for observers who were the most optimistic about the New Democratic Partys chances, the results of Mondays general election in Canada were nothing short of astounding.

title: India Sees New Reason to Distrust Pakistan
description: NEW DELHI  Prime Minister Manmohan Singhs often lonely efforts to improve relations with Pakistan are certain to become more complicated, and more difficult, after the disclosure that Osama bin Laden had been hiding in a military town in the heart of Pakistan.

title: Wall Street Journal Still First in Daily Circulation
description: Despite a new way to measure newspaper circulation, the top four daily papers are unchanged from six months ago, according to a report released Tuesday by the Audit Bureau of Circulations.

title: A Boon to Birds: Public Preserves
description: Publicly owned land, ocean and marshes provide habitats for at least half of the American populations of 300 bird species, the Department of Interior reports.

title: Now, Something for the Body Eccentric
description: PLEASE dont trip over the baby near the front of the new Henrik Vibskov store.

title: Huntsman Opens Committee to Raise Money
description: Three days after resigning as President Obamas ambassador to China, Jon M. Huntsman Jr. took the first steps on Tuesday toward joining the Republican presidential race by opening a political action committee allowing him to raise and spend money as he considers a candidacy.

title: Barring a Miracle, There Will Be No Baby Hawks
description: Violet the red-tailed hawk has been sitting on those eggs for a very long while. But sometimes, eggs dont hatch. This appears to be one of those times. Read more

title: H Plus X Plus Z, Formula for 3 Intersecting Lives
description: The independent Argentine film Extraordinary Stories interweaves the obscurely circuitous story lines of three cryptically named and decidedly unextraordinary characters: H (Agustn Mendilaharzu, the films cinematographer), a visibly bored civil engineer; X (Mariano Llins, the director), a frustrated architect slumming as a land surveyor; and Z (Walter Jakob), a midlevel bureaucrat in a provincial agricultural agency.

title: Funny or Die: Webby Awards Choose Funny
description: When Justin Bieber lost out on the Grammy Award for best new artist this year, all his fans could do was complain (and hack the Wikipedia page of the winner, Esperanza Spalding).

title: Portugal Agrees to a $116 Billion Bailout
description: Portugal agreed on Tuesday to accept an international aid plan of 78 billion euros ($116 billion) that the countrys caretaker prime minister, Jos Scrates, suggested would involve more lenient conditions than those imposed on Greece and Ireland in return for similar bailouts.

title: Aboard the L Train, Luncheon Is Served
description: IN the era of pop-up restaurants and speakeasies, flash mobs and social stunts, it was perhaps inevitable that a formal luncheon for a dozen people would be staged aboard the Brooklyn-bound L train. Inevitable, but still impressive.

title: James and Wade, Inseparable Even in the Interview Room
description: MIAMI  Dwyane Wade and LeBron James are close. Very close. Biceps to biceps close. So close that you could barely slide a deflated basketball between them. Or a tape recorder.

title: No Feather Left Unpreened
description: IN the category of Things People Were Talking About during Monday nights Costume Institute gala: Werent you just thrilled for Sarah Burton, the creative director of Alexander McQueen, for the timing of her royal wedding coup, three days before the big ball? Did you see Kate Hudsons baby bump? How about Christina Riccis tightly corseted waist? And, most pressingly, what was with the egg on Anna Dello Russos head?

title: Buvette
description: 42 Grove Street (Bleecker Street), West Village; (212) 255-3590; ilovebuvette.com.

title: After Bin Laden, Reliving the Iraq Mistake
description: Since hearing that U.S. forces killed Osama bin Laden, I have been thinking a great deal about what this means to me not only as an American, but also as a medically retired soldier. As someone who has led soldiers in combat in Iraq, I have held these wars close to me for some time.

title: Book of Mormon Tops Tony Nomination List
description: The Tony Award nominations on Tuesday snubbed a stretch limos worth of Hollywood stars who converged on Broadway during the 2010-11 season, bypassing actors who received critical praise (Robin Williams in Bengal Tiger at the Baghdad Zoo) and others who put their fame on the line by playing against type (a scheming Daniel Radcliffe, a mellow Chris Rock and a droopy Kiefer Sutherland, for starters).

title: Jones Wood Foundry
description: 401 East 76th Street, Upper East Side; (212) 249-2700; joneswoodfoundry.com

title: On Buvette and Jones Wood Foundry
Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: A Whiff of Camembert, From Upstate
description: Kinderhook Creek is the first Camembert-style soft-ripening cheese that the Old Chatham Sheepherding Company in the Hudson Valley has made entirely with sheeps milk, not a blend of sheeps and cows milk. Named for a stream on the property, its aged up to three weeks, and has a bloomy rind, a creamy ivory center and a border of satiny ripeness. The bouquet is fresh and lightly mushroomy, and it has a gently tangy herbal flavor, which will deepen even in the refrigerator, after another week. Wrap it in cheese paper; dont suffocate it in plastic.

title: New Tastes From Daniel Boulud, for Shoppers and Diners
description: At Daniel Bouluds first takeout shop, picerie Boulud, the array of finely crafted terrines and pts, cheeses and pastries may be unrivaled in the city. Like the charcuterie served next door at Bar Boulud, they are made under the direction of Gilles Verot of Paris. Some, like the breaded boned pork shank, or jambonneau (above), are not available at Bar Boulud. Many of the cheeses are aged by Saxelby Cheesemongers. Sandwiches, salads, breads and ice cream are also sold. A coffee and pastry bar will convert to an oyster and wine bar in the evenings.

title: Christina Tosi, a Border-Crossing Pastry Chef
description: PARENTS of picky eaters, take heart!

title: On Small Farms, Hoof Power Returns
description: SHEFFIELD, Mass.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Field Trip to Long Island

title: A New Cookbook Devoted to Herbs
description: No cookbook is easier to organize than one about herbs. Arrange it alphabetically, add some recipes that can be grouped in an index listing, and you are home free. Thats what Jekka McVicar, an English herb grower and expert, has done in this alluring volume, for Mothers Day perhaps. The book evokes spring from cover to cover, with illustrations by Ms. McVicars daughter, Hannah, that suggest William Morris patterns.

title: Overnight Polls Find Muted Improvement in Obamas Approval Rating
description: In the parlor game to predict the magnitude of improvement in President Obamas approval rating after the killing of Osama bin Laden, the weight of the evidence is with the skeptics so far.

title: A New First Stop for Homeless Families
description: The citys Department of Homeless Services on Tuesday opened a new intake center in the South Bronx, a $65.5 million building designed to greet families seeking shelter with much more of a smile than in the old days.

title: Inside The Libyan Rebels Hidden Weapons Shops
description: With much of the port city of Misurata reclaimed, part of the rebels success has roots in the network of hidden metal workshops, where the uprisings killing tools have been assembled and pushed out.

title: Teamwork
description: So, driven to a rustic frenzy by the Northeasts oxen craze, youve just bought a pair of brawny bovines and are ready to put them to work in your garden. But you have no idea how to do that. For $29.95 you can buy the DVD Training Oxen, made in 2003 by Drew Conroy, a professor at the University of New Hampshire who is known in draft-power circles as the ox guru. Or, to get started, you can take a look at this clip from the DVD with Tim Huppe of BerryBrook Ox Supply, in Farmington, N.H.

title: A Mysterious Marsupial That Ambushed Its Prey
description: It was known as the Tasmanian tiger, for its striped coat, or the Tasmanian wolf, for its doglike appearance. But new research indicates the bone structure and hunting habits of Thylacinus cynocephalus may make the tiger designation more apt.

title: Italys Birthday Specials
description: Italy is celebrating the 150th anniversary of the Risorgimento, the unification of the former patchwork of states up and down the peninsula.

title: U.S. and Romania Move on Missile Plan
description: WASHINGTON  The United States and Romania announced an agreement on Tuesday on the location for basing American antimissile interceptors in Romania as part of a program designed to link Washington and its NATO allies against an Iranian threat. The agreement immediately drew complaints from Russian officials.

title: Barcelona Proves to Be Master of Real Madrid
description: LONDON

title: Bay Goes on Paternity Leave List as Mets Face Giants
description: Mets left fielder Jason Bay was not in the lineup Tuesday night for the opener of a three-game series against the San Francisco Giants at Citi Field because he was put on the paternity leave list to be with his wife, Kristen, who was expecting their third child.

title: Obamas Sunday Address  Draws 56.5 Million Viewers
description: President Obamas announcement of Osama bin Ladens death was watched by 56.5 million people in the United States on Sunday night, the Nielsen Company said Tuesday.

title: The American West as Classroom, Art and Metaphor
description: LUBBOCK, Tex.  The native son Buddy Holly aside, this small city on the tableland of the southern Great Plains has never had a lot to recommend it, culturally or aesthetically. When Coronado passed through the area in the 16th century, he described an acute sense of European disorientation as his men struggled to plot a course across a place with no more landmarks than if we had been swallowed up by the sea.

title: Cerberus and Partner Acquire Innkeepers Hotels
description: Cerberus Capital Management and the Chatham Lodging Trust said on Tuesday that they had won a bankruptcy auction for 64 Innkeepers USA hotels. The winning bid was $1.1 billion, including debt.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,553 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: After the Raid: The Compound in Abbottabad
description: Shortly after Osama bin Laden was killed, the Pakistani military blocked access to the compound where he had been staying. This did not, however, stop journalists and curious residents from stopping by for a look.

title: Senator Presses Sony on Theft of Customer Data
description: Senator Richard Blumenthal, Democrat of Connecticut, sent a follow-up letter to Sony on Tuesday after the company said it had discovered that more company servers had been breached during a catastrophic hacking attack last month.

title: BP Is Fined $25 Million for 06 Spills at Pipelines
description: WASHINGTON  BP will pay $25 million in civil fines to settle charges arising from two spills from its network of pipelines in Alaska in 2006 and from a willful failure to comply with a government order to properly maintain the pipelines to prevent corrosion, federal officials announced on Tuesday.

title: A Once-Promising Field Gets Weaker
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  There will be 20 horses in the gate Saturday for the 137th running of the Kentucky Derby, but it is a stretch to say that they are the cream of this 3-year-old crop. The field lost another contender Tuesday when Tobys Corner, the winner of the Wood Memorial, came up lame in his left hind leg and was declared out of the race.

title: A National Security Strategy That Doesnt Focus on Threats
description: Heres a proposition: The death of Osama bin Laden brings a moment to talk about something other than threats  not because they dont exist, but because for the country to see and speak of nothing else is mortally dangerous.

title: Ronald D. Asmus, Official Who Favored Expanded NATO, Dies at 53
description: Ronald D. Asmus, an early proponent of expanding the Atlantic alliance to include Eastern European nations and a key figure in the Clinton administrations realization of that vision, died April 30 in Belgium. He was 53.

title: China: Database on Each Citizen Is Urged
description: Chinas top internal security official called for building a database containing information on each of Chinas 1.34 billion residents to improve social management, a term that encompasses the states efforts to manage public dissent and head off protests in the name of maintaining stability. The official, Zhou Yongkang, said the system should be based on the resident identity cards issued to every Chinese citizen, and should include such details as each persons tax record and history of education and employment, as well as what property and vehicles he or she owns. Writing in Qiushi, a Communist Party magazine, Mr. Zhou said that a comprehensive database would help neighborhood watchmen enforce stability.

title: Asthma Rate Rises Sharply in U.S., Government Says
description: Americans are suffering from asthma in record numbers, according to a study released Tuesday by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Nearly one in 10 children and almost one in 12 Americans of all ages now has asthma, government researchers said.

title: The Cue r1 Alarm Clock Is a Time Machine
description: Throwback is a word the Cue r1 clock radio brings to mind. For one thing, its a clock radio, by which it has an AM/FM radio built in and which is tied to the clocks alarm timer.

title: End in Sight for Darwin Letters Project Thanks to $8.2 Million in Grants
description: Teams of scholars have spent nearly 30 years tracking down, researching and editing the more than 15,000 letters written by or to Charles Darwin. Now, thanks to $8.2 million in grants from the Evolution Education Trust, the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation, the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, and the Isaac Newton Trust, the entire collection will be published in full by 2022. Texts of some 6,000 letters and information on 9,000 more are already available here.

title: Bruins Have a Lead, but Not Peace of Mind
description: BOSTON  Many hockey fans would be pleased if their team had taken a two-games-to-none lead in a playoff series, especially if those victories came on the road. But not Boston Bruins fans, judging from the radio call-in shows Tuesday morning, only hours after the Bruins had won Game 2 of their second-round series, 3-2, in overtime.

title: Sudan: Deadly Clashes in Disputed Border Territory
description: More than a dozen soldiers have been killed in clashes in Sudans contested Abyei area, Sudanese officials said on Tuesday. The fighting broke out Sunday afternoon when a convoy of northern Sudanese troops tried to enter the specially demarcated Abyei area, which straddles the border of northern and southern Sudan and is administered jointly. Southern Sudanese policemen traded fire with the northern troops; each side says the other one started it. Southern Sudan is preparing to split off from northern Sudan this summer, but Abyeis status is unresolved. Both sides have been beefing up their military forces in Abyei, raising fears of an all-out border war.

title: Renren Set to Go Public at $14 a Share
description: 9:20 a.m. | Updated

title: Land Arts of the American West
description: A program at Texas Tech takes artists and architects on a two-month road trip across the West.

title: TimesCast | A Culture of Conspiracies
description: The Times's Adam B. Ellick speaks with Pakistani journalist Rabia Mehmood on how Pakistani media is addressing Osama bin Laden's death.

title: Transgender Woman Settles Suit Against Two Organizations
description: Lana Lawless, the transgender woman who sued the L.P.G.A. and the Long Drivers of America last October challenging their rule that competitors be female at birth, has settled her case, her lawyer said. Lawless, 57, won the world long-drive title in 2008 but was later ruled ineligible after Long Drivers of America, which oversees the competition, changed its rules to bar transgender competitors. She was prevented from competing in the L.P.G.A. because of a similar rule.

title: William Campbell, Who Played Star Trek Klingon, Dies at 87
description: William Campbell, an actor who was widely familiar to film and television audiences and who was also known as the first husband of Judith Campbell Exner, a mistress of President John F. Kennedy, died on April 28 in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 87.

title: Rhode Island: Civil Unions Proposed
description: Leaders of the State House of Representatives introduced legislation Tuesday to allow civil unions for gay couples after conceding there was not enough support in the chamber for a same-sex marriage bill. Gay rights advocates criticized the move, saying civil unions were an insufficient compromise and protesting outside the State House. Same-sex marriage is legal in Connecticut, Iowa, Massachusetts, New Hampshire, Vermont and the District of Columbia. Lawmakers in Maryland also failed to muster enough votes to pass a same-sex marriage bill this year.

title: Huntsman Takes a Step Toward Race
description: Three days after resigning as ambassador to China, Jon M. Huntsman Jr. took the first steps on Tuesday toward joining the Republican presidential race by opening a political action committee allowing him to raise and spend money as he considers a candidacy. Mr. Huntsman, a former governor of Utah, has been ensconced in a Washington hotel for the last two days with advisers who are preparing him for the nominating contest. Politico first reported the opening of the committee.

title: Junk Food Guidelines Wont Help
description: Imagine your childs teacher was distributing twice daily snacks, before and after lunch  maybe Snickers and PopTarts in the morning, Mountain Dew and fries in the afternoon. Now lets pretend you complain to the principal, who tells the teacher, Could you please stop doing that? You have until  five years from Tuesday.

title: Court Agrees To Expedite N.F.L.s Appeal
description: A federal court said Tuesday that it would expedite the appeal that will probably determine which side in the labor dispute between N.F.L. owners and players will have the most leverage. The good news for fans is that the hearing on the N.F.L.s appeal of the injunction that stopped the leagues lockout was set for June 3. Although it is impossible to determine when a decision by a three-judge panel would come, it is logical to assume the decision will be expedited as well, said Michael Gans, the clerk of the Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit in St. Louis.

title: New U.S. Account Says Bin Laden Was Unarmed During Raid
description: WASHINGTON  Osama bin Laden was not carrying a weapon when he was killed by American troops in a fortified house in Pakistan, the White House said Tuesday, as it revised its initial account of the nighttime raid.

title: A Mission Not Yet Accomplished
description: Its obviously been a good week for the Obama administration. But it comes at a dangerous time, for both the administration and the economy. The excitement over tracking down Osama bin Laden could end up making the president and his advisers less panicked over the state of the economy. And they should be a little panicked.

title: TimesCast | Voicing Distrust on Pakistan
description: The Times's Mark Mazzetti discusses the uneasy relationship between the C.I.A. and Pakistan's intelligence agency.

title: As M.L.S. Grows, Concern for Charter Clubs
description: Major League Soccer is bodysurfing a wave of optimism.

title: The Night Bin Laden Was Hunted Down
description: To the Editor:

title: A Charge on Carbon Use
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctors Prescription Records
description: To the Editor:

title: Inquest Faults London Officer in 2009 Death During Protests
description: LONDON  At the time, the police said that Ian Tomlinson had died of a heart attack. But after a video handed to a British newspaper by an outraged bystander showed Mr. Tomlinson collapsing after being pushed and savagely struck by a police officer wielding a baton, his family demanded an inquiry.

title: Heaven, Hell and Love
description: To the Editor:

title: Class-Action Lawsuit Says Utah Immigration Law Violates Civil Rights
description: Two national civil rights law organizations sued the State of Utah on Tuesday, seeking to block a law that gives the police new powers to question people they stop about immigration status.

title: U.S. Regulators Face Budget Pinch as Mandates Widen
description: Government regulators on the Wall Street beat have long been outnumbered and outspent by the companies they are supposed to police. But even after receiving budget increases from Congress last month, regulators are still falling behind.

title: As Barriers to Lawyers Persist, Immigrant Advocates Ponder Solutions
description: More than two years ago, a federal judge in New York began a crusade to find lawyers for the many immigrants who are detained or deported because they lack representation. Powerful figures, including Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, heard the call and helped draw attention to the issue.

title: Mets Thank Troops in a Meaningful Setting
description: The fastest feet in the ballpark Tuesday night did not belong to Jose Reyes, who was on base all six times, but rather to Steve Castleton, a volunteer with the U.S.O., distributing tickets to service members.

title: Flooding Along the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers
description: Flooded areas in the Midwest and South

title: Google Takes to TV to Promote Browser
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google is once again taking up arms in the browser wars, in the belief that people who use its Chrome Web browser will be more likely to keep using Google search.

title: Reconnecting With a Spirit of the Sport
description: Last week I visited RiverRun Books in Portsmouth, N.H., to talk about Lord of Misrule, my racetrack novel that won the National Book Award last November. It drizzled all day in the harbor town, but a good crowd showed.

title: Tensions Rise as U.S. Officials Press Pakistan for Answers
description: WASHINGTON  Tensions between the American and Pakistani governments intensified sharply on Tuesday as senior Obama administration officials demanded answers to how Osama bin Laden managed to hide in Pakistan, and the Pakistani government issued a defiant statement calling the raid that killed the Al Qaeda leader an unauthorized unilateral action.

title: Good Feeling Gone, in Congress, Anyway
description: WASHINGTON  Whatever sense of unity the nation might have felt after the killing of Osama bin Laden, it did not extend to the pressing domestic policy issues that divide Congressional Republicans and Democrats, who returned to work in earnest Tuesday.

title: Under a Microscope, Jeter Has a Powerless Start
description: DETROIT  Derek Jeters 100th at-bat of the season came in the eighth inning Monday night against the Tigers, in a situation that over the years had all but defined his career with the Yankees. With two outs, the score tied and the go-ahead run on third base, Jeter strode to the plate, confident as ever.

title: Farewell to Geronimo
description: There is only one good thing about the fact that Osama bin Laden survived for nearly 10 years after the mass murder at the World Trade Center and the Pentagon that he organized. And that is that he lived long enough to see so many young Arabs repudiate his ideology. He lived long enough to see Arabs from Tunisia to Egypt to Yemen to Syria rise up peacefully to gain the dignity, justice and self-rule that Bin Laden claimed could be obtained only by murderous violence and a return to puritanical Islam.

title: 9/11 Inspires Student Patriotism and Celebration
description: Ashley Bright was 15 years old and on her way to school in Cottonwood, Ariz., when she stopped at a friends house and saw the news that two planes had hit the World Trade Center.

title: Central Park, Built for and With the Help of Horses, Will Again Offer Them a Home
description: Central Park is laced with bridle paths and dotted with pastures, and its plants were once fertilized with manure. But though carriage horses trot through it, police horses occasionally patrol it, and wooden steeds gallop around the carousel, horses have not called the park home for more than 100 years.

title: Prosecutors Are Expected to Seek Dismissal of Charges Against Bin Laden
description: It should happen with little or no fanfare, but it will still represent a moment that some thought might never occur: federal prosecutors in Manhattan are expected to file court papers this week that will formally ask a judge to dismiss all charges against Osama bin Laden.

title: Net Incomes Rise Solidly for CBS and Comcast
description: Both Comcast and the CBS Corporation reported strongly positive first-quarter earnings Tuesday, in one case reflecting largely the strength of its cable television holdings, in the other its strength in advertising sales for its broadcasting operations.

title: Bin Laden Raid Revives Debate on Value of Torture
description: WASHINGTON  Did brutal interrogations produce the crucial intelligence that led to the killing of Osama bin Laden?

title: Security on Higher Alert Across U.S.
description: There have been no known specific or credible threats received since American troops killed Osama bin Laden this week, but on Tuesday security at public spaces  including mosques, synagogues, train stations and basketball arenas  remained at elevated levels.

title: Lottery Numbers
David J. Sencer Dies at 86; Led Disease-Control Agency
description: David J. Sencer, who as a federal and New York City public health official confronted some of the most threatening infectious diseases of the past half century, finding controversy in both roles, died on Monday in Atlanta. He was 86.

title: Obamas TV Audience Was His Largest
description: President Obamas announcement of Osama bin Ladens death was watched by 56.5 million people in the United States on Sunday night, the Nielsen Company said Tuesday.

title: A Levee Breached, and New Worries Downstream
description: SIKESTON, MO.  With a rapid series of explosions late Monday that could be felt for miles through the Missouri soil, the Army Corps of Engineers successfully blew out some 11,000 feet of Mississippi River levee, taking dangerous pressure off the river above.

title: Farmers Concerned About Insurance
description: CHARLESTON, Mo.  Among the many mysteries swirling amid the floodwaters that rush across the breached Birds Point levee is whether those people who have lost their homes in the floodway will be able to collect on their insurance claims.

title: My Sister, My Grief
description: AFTER someone has been murdered, their family members often feel peace when the murderer has been executed, a friend called to tell me on Monday.Do you feel peace? Another friend asked, Are you going to dance in the streets now and celebrate?

title: Developers and Christie Detail a Plan for Xanadu
description: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J.  Much bigger and more expensive, but less gaudy: Gov. Chris Christie and developers laid out a new vision on Tuesday for completing and expanding the vast retail and entertainment complex formerly known as Xanadu in the Meadowlands.

title: Party Like Its 2013
description: Republicans on the House Financial Services Committee are having a campaign fund-raiser this week.

title: Judge Upholds Verdicts in Synagogue Bomb Plot
description: A federal judge on Tuesday upheld the verdicts of four men convicted of plotting to blow up synagogues in the Bronx and military airplanes, but chided the government for building a troubling case that relied on the work of an informer whose methods, she suggested, bordered on entrapment.

title: Is the Captain a Cause for Concern?
description: At 17-9, the Yankees have the second best record in the American League, yet much of the focus this season has been on the struggles of Derek Jeter. Through 100 plate appearances this season, Jeter is batting .250, some 60 points off his career average, and 20 points lower than his disturbingly unimpressive average of last season.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Ex-Adviser to Booker Is Expected to Lead Newarks Schools
description: The Christie administration has selected a New York City schools official who is an ally of Mayor Cory A. Booker of Newark to lead that citys school system, according to a person briefed on the appointment.

title: Hertz Uses Mascot in Effort to Make Rental Cars Cool
description: WHEN it comes to car rental, most people expect the basics  cleanliness and functionality. They do not expect cool.

title: Wednesday: Gallic Girlfriends
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Jeff Chen made his collaborative debut in The New York Times last July and today marks his first solo venture. He has taken more of a chance on this one, but thats only natural: this is a midweek puzzle.

title: Demolition of Levee Floods Missouri Farmland
description: Thousands of acres of Missouri farmland were flooded when the Army Corps of Engineers blew a hole in a levee at the confluence of the Mississippi and Ohio Rivers to help save the town of Cairo, Ill.

title: Citys Next Taxi: A Nissan Van Short on Looks, Perhaps, but Full of Comforts
description: The next New York City taxicab will have airplane-style reading lights, passenger air bags, and a so-called low-annoyance horn, engineered to stifle flagrant honkers. The back seat even has more leg room than the old couch-on-wheels Checker cab.

title: Ode to a Mall
description: On City Room did we last week

title: In Haiti, Class Comes With a Peek at Lush Life
description: LABADIE, Haiti  On a jungle-covered hill, about 25 Creole-speaking kindergartners chanted numbers inside a gleaming classroom, the ceiling laced with clotheslines of paper butterflies. Past noon, they spilled into the courtyard to dash across the gravel in a blur of blue and cream uniforms, each one embroidered with an anchor and the schools unusual name: cole Nouvelle Royal Caribbean, or the New Royal Caribbean School.

title: James Takes Command, and the Heat Pulls Ahead
description: MIAMI  It is 50 weeks too late for LeBron James to atone for what happened in Cleveland, in a postseason he would not or could not save for his former team. Personal retribution is another matter, and he nearly has it within his grasp.

title: Base-Running Blunders Sink Yankees
description: DETROIT  The Yankees did not pitch or hit as well as the Detroit Tigers on Tuesday night, and that, in the simplest of terms, is why they lost.

title: Life in No Mans Land
description: For the residents of Boise City, Okla., the current drought  the longest on record  is a reminder of just how parched and unyielding life can be along this wind-raked frontier, fittingly called No Mans Land,

title: Survivor of Dust Bowl Now Battles a Fiercer Drought
description: BOISE CITY, Okla.  While tornadoes and floods have ravaged the South and the Midwest, the remote western edge of the Oklahoma Panhandle is quietly enduring a weather calamity of its own: its longest drought on record, even worse than the Dust Bowl, when incessant winds scooped up the soil into billowing black clouds and rolled it through this town like bowling balls.

title: Glencore I.P.O. Mimics Blackstone and Draws Skeptics
description: Is Glencore the new Blackstone? It has become a theme from Wall Street to the City and beyond that the commodity traders planned $12 billion stock offering signals the top of its industrys cycle, just as Blackstones did for private equity. But investors should watch for other similarities when scrubbing Glencores prospectus, due out Wednesday.

title: Prebuilt Offices Now Draw Higher-End Tenants
description: Prebuilt office space  in which the landlord builds out the office before leasing it  has traditionally been seen as inferior to the custom-built variety.

title: Cool Hand Barack
description: WASHINGTON

title: The Myth of Mr. Obamas Weakness
description: President Obamas display of leadership in directing the killing of Osama bin Laden raises the prospect that American politics can move away from mindless debates over the presidents loyalties and fortitude. Perhaps the 2012 campaign might even shift to real issues, like the economy and the major parties competing visions of governments role.

title: Fit to Rule on Same-Sex Marriage
description: Given ample chance during a 13-day trial to offer an argument apart from prejudice, proponents of Proposition 8, the prohibition against same-sex marriage in California, found no evidence. Now they are trying to disqualify Vaughn Walker, the now-retired Federal District Court judge who ruled that the measure was unconstitutional.

title: Bush Declines Obamas Invitation to Ground Zero
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama invited former President George W. Bush to join him at ground zero in New York City on Thursday to mark the killing of Osama bin Laden, but Mr. Bush declined, a spokesman for the former president confirmed on Tuesday.

title: Past, Present, and the Quantity of the Year
description: How long is a year? Ask most people, and theyd say 365 days and not nearly long enough. The year, of course, is the time it takes the Earth to orbit around the Sun, a rate that is slowing fractionally each century. For many reasons, scientists need a more precise definition of the year than its length in days, yet the only unit of time defined in the International System of Units is the second, which is measured in oscillations of cesium atoms.

title: A Cruise Companys School for Haiti
description: Royal Caribbean Cruises has started a school in Haiti, after the company received harsh criticism for docking pleasure ships at a Haitian resort just six days after the 2010 earthquake.

title: The Mets, Short-Handed From the Start, Fall at the End
description: A new rule pushed the Mets into unfamiliar territory Tuesday night. They opened a three-game series against the San Francisco Giants without left fielder Jason Bay, who went on baseballs paternity leave list to be with his wife, Kristen, who was expecting their third child.

title: Bloggingheads: Bin Laden's Death
description: Heather Hurlburt, left, of the National Security Network and Eli Lake of The Washington Times debate celebrating the death of Bin Laden.

title: With a Start-Up Company, a Ride Is Just a Tap of an App Away
description: Here is yet another thing you can do with a smartphone: summon a car to pick you up with a tap on the screen.

title: The Battle for Libya | May 3
description: Colonel Qaddafis forces kept up their attack on the besieged city of Misurata, and a car bomb exploded in Benghazi.

title: Hidden Workshops Add to Libyan Rebels Arsenal
description: MISURATA, Libya  When the bloody siege of this isolated city began, the rebels who rose against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis conventional army had almost no firearms. Many of them relied on hands, knives and stones.

title: 44 Works Sell for $170 Million at Sothebys Auction
description: Chinese and Russian could be heard in the Sothebys salesroom on Tuesday night at the beginning of the big spring auction season. But in spite of the presence of Prada-clad international collectors, it was a tepid start, with a few strong prices and many works selling below expectations.

title: Morning T | Andrew Bolton on Alexander McQueen
description: In the latest installment of Morning T, Andrew Bolton, the British curator of the Metropolitan Museum of Arts Costume Institute, discusses the institutes current Alexander McQueen exhibition, Savage Beauty. The exhibition includes, among other extraordinarily rare pieces, some original designs from McQueens graduate student collection, which were lined with human hair. Read Suzy Menkess review of the exhibition here.

title: Morning T: Andrew Bolton
description: Horacio Silva discusses the new Alexander McQueen exhibit at the Metropolitan Museum of Art with its curator, Andrew Bolton.

title: Amazon Enters the Flash Sale Fray With Myhabit
description: Adrenaline-pumped online shopping, popularized by so-called flash sale sites like Gilt, has arrived at Amazon.com.

title: L'Amour Fou
description: Scenes from "L'Amour Fou," the new documentary about Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Berg.

title: How Sugar Affects the Body in Motion
description: Sugar is getting a bad reputation. A cover article in The New York Times Magazine several weeks ago persuasively reported that our national overindulgence in fructose and other sugars is driving the epidemics of obesity, diabetes and other illnesses. But that much-discussed article, by the writer Gary Taubes, focused on how sugars like fructose affect the body in general. It had little opportunity to examine the related issue of how sugar affects the body in motion. Do sweeteners like fructose  the sweetest of the simple sugars, found abundantly in fruits and honey  have the same effect on active people as on the slothful?

title: The Chapel of Sacred Mirrors
description: The Chelsea art space, a curious, over-the-top combination of gallery, New Age temple and Coney Island sideshow, will close at the end of the month.

title: FDRs First 100 Days, Revisited
description: As the teetering economy and Barack Obamas election spur plenty of allusions to F.D.R., two exhibitions revisit the early days of the Roosevelt Administration.

title: Pandora Internet Radio Service to Offer Large Archive of Comedy Clips
description: Since it began six years ago, the Internet radio service Pandora has changed the way millions of people listen to music online. Now the company wants to do the same for comedy.

title: As China Invests, U.S. Could Lose
description: SHANGHAI  For three decades, wealthy nations have invested hundreds of billions of dollars in China, helping drive one of the most remarkable economic booms in history.

title: Report on Chinese Investment
description: The full study from the Asia Society and the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars on Chinese foreign direct investment.

title: Word of the Day | adulterate
description: adulterate \-dl-t-rat\ verb

title: Finding on Dialects Casts New Light on the Origins of the Japanese People
description: Researchers studying the various dialects of Japanese have concluded that all are descended from a founding language taken to the Japanese islands about 2,200 years ago. The finding sheds new light on the origin of the Japanese people, suggesting that their language is descended from that of the rice-growing farmers who arrived in Japan from the Korean Peninsula, and not from the hunter-gatherers who first inhabited the islands some 30,000 years ago.

title: Iraq: Third Day of Blasts in Baghdad Neighborhood
description: Three explosions shook the neighborhood of Dora in south Baghdad on Tuesday, killing at least 10 and wounding 28, according to a local security official. It was the third straight day in which Dora had been attacked. Dora is predominantly Sunni, although the attack on Tuesday evening occurred in a Shiite area. Improvised explosive devices and magnetic bombs were detonated on Sunday and Monday, injuring 12 people, including four police officers and a government official. Members of Al Qaeda in Mesopotamia have said they would increase attacks after Osama bin Ladens death.

title: Some Troops Should Stay in Iraq, Speaker Says
description: WASHINGTON  After a high-level trip to Iraq, House Speaker John A. Boehner said on Tuesday that he would support keeping a contingent of troops in Iraq beyond the end of the year, when all American forces are scheduled to be withdrawn.

title: Report Implicates Kyrgyzstan Officials in Ethnic Violence Last Year
description: MOSCOW  Video taken during the ethnic violence that broke out in southern Kyrgyzstan last June show armored personnel carriers carousing wildly through devastated neighborhoods, with young men in civilian clothes hanging onto the turrets.

title: Photo Replay: May 3
description: A look at the day in sports from a rainy trot around Churchill Downs to a superstar performance in Miami.

title: Gaza: Barenboim Performs in Palestinian Territory
description: The Israeli musician Daniel Barenboim and 25 members of his orchestra performed in the Hamas-controlled Gaza Strip on Tuesday. Mr. Barenboim, who has honorary Palestinian citizenship, is a harsh critic of Israels occupation of Gaza and the West Bank and he co-founded a music education project in the Palestinian territories.

title: Voice Recorder From Air France Plane Crash Is Found
description: French investigators said on Tuesday that they had recovered the cockpit voice recorder from the Air France jet that crashed in the Atlantic almost two years ago en route to Paris from Rio de Janeiro. After three failed searches and expenditures nearing $30 million, both so-called black boxes are now in hand, giving investigators renewed hope of unraveling the mystery of what caused Flight 447 to go down in a heavy thunderstorm on June 1, 2009. All 228 passengers and crew members were killed. So far, the only information about what happened to the flight is from automated messages that indicated a malfunction of the planes airspeed sensors.

title: The Dry Season
description: A drought in the Oklahoma Panhandle is poised to do what the Dust Bowl couldn't  drive towns in this parched region out of existence.

title: News Quiz | May 4, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Gilded Home
description: Dr. Anthony Walter uses decorative art in his home to inspire others to devote themselves to their spouses and to God.

title: The Dining Room Where Buckley Reigned
description: The tables are still set at the Park Avenue home of William F. Buckley Jr.

title: North Korean Prison Camps Massive and Growing
description: SEOUL, South Korea  New satellite images and firsthand accounts from former political prisoners and former jailers in North Korea have confirmed the enormous scale and bleak conditions of the penal system in the secretive North, according to a report released Wednesday by the human rights group Amnesty International.

title: Test Yourself | Math, May 4, 2011
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article As Consumers Cut Spending, Green Products Lose Allure.

title: History, Caught on Camera
description: WHO is shown in this photograph?
