description: Todays word, in association with the flawless Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: Glencore Sets I.P.O. Range, Valuing It at $60 Billion
description: 7:12 p.m. | Updated

title: What Would You Do With a Gap Year?
description: The New York Times columnist Nicholas D. Kristofs son Gregory wrote a post on his fathers blog about his experience deferring his college entrance for a year to pursue personal interests. Would you like to take a gap year? If so, what would you do with that time, and why? If not, why not?

title: Applied Materials to Buy Varian
description: Applied Materials said on Wednesday that it would pay $4.9 billion in cash for Varian Semiconductor Equipment Associates, as it looks to capitalize on mobile and other high-growth technologies.

title: 2010 Seahawks: What the Film Revealed
description: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis. This week, we look at the N.F.C. West:

title: SiriusXM Tunes In a New Program Guide
description: The corporate merger of the satellite radio giants Sirius and XM formally took place in 2008. On Wednesday, a remapped channel lineup should make the two networks finally feel more cohesive for listeners.

title: New Keynesian Economics Misses the Point, for Now
description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: In Rome, Farmers Markets Are in Season
description: Nearly every neighborhood in Rome has a local market  a mercato rionale. Market hours  generally Monday to Saturday until around 1:30 p.m.  arent convenient for many consumers, who turn increasingly to supermarkets and their industrial products. Romes farmers markets are seeking to combat this by offering extended weekend hours and an opportunity to purchase local food directly from producers.

title: The Beatles Discuss Arizonas Immigration Bill
description: Last weekend, when I wasnt delivering meals to the homebound, I was researching Beatles bootlegs. And I discovered the so-called Commonwealth Song. Its not so much a song as it is an extended improvisation during the interminable Get Back studio sessions in 1969 (in fact, some theorize that The Commonwealth Song is a prototype for Get Back). Commonwealth name-checks Enoch Powell (the Tom Tancredo of his day, or Thilo Sarazin, if you prefer a German reference), who had delivered his anti-immigrant Rivers of Blood speech the previous year. Commonwealth was Paul McCartneys mocking response. All of which shows that the sun never sets on some issues. Its also nice to know that as late as 1969, Lennon and McCartney could still crack each other up, especially when John interjects his high-pitched Yes!

title: Angry Rhymes, Dirty Mouth, Goofy Kid
description: LOS ANGELES

title: The President's Approval Rating After Bin Laden
description: President Obamas approval rating is up, following Osama bin Ladens killing.

title: What Happens to Bin Ladenism Now?
description: The Op-Ed columnist Thomas L. Friedman on the Arab spring's rejection of the culture of violent extremism taught by Bin Laden and his followers.

title: Business Life After Death in Rwanda
description: In a previous post, I wrote about the Business Council for Peace, a nonprofit network of professionals who provide pro bono business services to mostly female entrepreneurs in countries affected by conflict, including Rwanda. Last month, three Rwandan owners, graduates of the three-year BPeace program, visited the United States during a trip that paired them with American businesses in their industries. The participants included Languida Nyirababeruka, who founded Pompe Funebre Twifatanye, a funeral home, after the 1994 genocide.

title: How the Poll Was Conducted
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News poll is based on telephone interviews conducted May 2 and 3 with 532 adults throughout the United States.

title: For Obama, Big Rise in Poll Numbers After Bin Laden Raid
description: Support for President Obama rose sharply after the killing of Osama bin Laden, with a majority now approving of his overall job performance, as well as his handling of foreign policy, the war in Afghanistan and the threat of terrorism, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: A Different Kind of Arab Spring
description: At The Daily Beasts The Dish, Andrew Sullivan links to an article on the Beast about the first Muslim playmate. Its hard to embrace this as a form of liberation, as Asra Q. Nomani reluctantly does. (Im not a fan of porn as a symbol of empowerment, but as a Muslim woman, hearing divinely sanctioned mandates all my life about what a good Muslim girl looks like, I can understand why Sahin has responded to our community sanctions about honor, shame and modesty by stripping  and why members of her family have ostracized her for it.) But it did make me flash back to a recent post on 3quarksdaily, showing a graffito of a burqa-clad woman having a Marilyn moment. We all know that hemlines rise during tough economic times. Do they also rise (or disappear altogether) during revolutionary ones?

title: Bush Aides Walk Delicate Line on Bin Laden
description: For the better part of a decade, those at the helm of George W. Bushs political and national security teams argued that their approach to terrorism was a necessary means to a desired end: the takedown of Al Qaeda and its leadership.

title: Dont Ticket Me. Im One of You.
description: There was something official-looking about the gleaming GMC Sierra pickup truck that sat one recent weekday morning in a no-parking zone on Washington Square South in Greenwich Village.

title: Z Fortune Awaits Life After Racing
description: Every week at New Vocations Racehorse Adoption Program we receive more than 15 requests from thoroughbred owners or trainers in need of retiring one or more of their horses. The correspondence is normally the same and consists of me asking questions about the retirees reason for retirement, race history and current situation.

title: Electronic Health Records: Green or Polluter?
description: This is the year that billions of dollars in government incentive payments are set to begin flowing to the nations doctors and hospitals to encourage them to adopt computerized patient records. The goal, of course, is to help improve the quality of care and curb costs.

title: ConAgra Bids $4.9 Billion for Ralcorp
description: 2:11 p.m. | Updated After getting rebuffed earlier, ConAgra Foods announced on Wednesday that it had upped its offer for Ralcorp Holdings to $4.9 billion, in a push to expand its presence in generic products.

title: White iPhone Versus White iPhone
description: For almost a year,the white iPhone has been as elusive as a double rainbow. Sure, we knew they existed, but few people had seen one. Now this sought-after device is available in stores. But their existence just provokes more questions.

title: K.K.R. Quarterly Profit Rises 10%
description: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts said on Wednesday that its first-quarter earnings rose 10 percent, as private equity firms continued to benefit from the economic recovery.

title: Wednesday Reading: Honda Widens Air-Bag Recall
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet .

title: Markets Losing Faith in Portugal
description: One day after agreeing to a $115.5 billion rescue package, Portugal was forced to offer higher interest rates on its debt, spurring fears that, as in Greece and Ireland after their aid deals, financing costs in the country will continue to escalate.

title: Bin Ladens Killing Helps Presidents Poll Numbers
description: Our colleagues James Dao and Dalia Sussman report that the operation in Pakistan that killed Osama bin Laden has given President Obama a sharp bump in his job performance approval rating among both Republican and Democratic voters, climbing to 57 percent from 46 percent in April. Many more Americans now approve of the job he is doing as president and of the way he is handling foreign policy, the war in Afghanistan and the threat of terrorism, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News poll.

title: Morning Buzz | Bin Laden Charges Likely to Be Dismissed
description: Expect rain, with temperatures reaching about 55 degrees. Things will clear up a bit in the evening.

title: Updates on the Killing of Bin Laden, May 4
description: On Wednesday, as new details continue to emerge about the killing of Osama bin Laden during an American raid in Pakistan this week, The Lede provides updates on breaking news and charts the global reaction.

title: Lackluster Earnings Daunt Investors
description: Stocks fell Wednesday, with commodity producers driving a third straight loss for the Standard & Poors 500-stock index, as lower-than-estimated reports on service industries and job growth damped optimism in the economy.

title: Dunkin Donuts Parent Files for an I.P.O.
description: Its time to make the I.P.O.

title: Mozart Leaps Perilous Hurdles to Reach an Audience in Gaza
description: GAZA  The program was perfectly normal: a pair of beloved Mozart chestnuts (A Little Night Music and the G minor Symphony), before a lunchtime crowd in a local cultural center.

title: Winning Isnt Everything: Lombardi to Close on Broadway
description: Lombardi, the play that tried to draw men to Broadway with a story about the legendary Green Bay Packers coach, will close on May 22 after a total of 30 preview performances and 244 regular performances, its producers said on Tuesday night.

title: Chinese Site Lists in U.S., and Its Shares Soar 29%
description: 8:21 p.m. | Updated

title: Why Casey Cant Read
description: Ive been asked for reactions to Casey Mulligans piece about the failure of New Keynesian economics.The short answer is, he should try reading a bit of Keynesian economics  old or new, it doesnt matter  before explaining whats wrong with it. For the doctrine hes attacking bears no resemblance to anything Keynesians are saying.

title: Graphic Content | Neshan
description: Irans stunning contemporary graphic design is virtually unknown in the West. But there is some light emerging. Over the past few years, books showcasing Iranian graphic design, posters, calligraphy and typography have been published in the West, opening a very rich vein of design that combines tradition and modernity. And one of the best places to view this work is Irans first and only graphic design magazine, Neshan. (Full disclosure: Im a contributor to the magazine.)

title: The Pain in Spain
description: Martin Wolf directs us to Paul de Grauwe (pdf) on the eurozone  a paper I wish I had written (there is no higher praise).

title: Time Warner Tops Forecast on Rebound in Ad Sales
description: Time Warner, the media company, on Wednesday reported a 6 percent gain in first-quarter revenue, to $6.7 billion, driven by gains at cable channels like TNT and HBO.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Wet Houses
description: Residential centres for chronic alcoholics for whom sobriety is not expected.Writing for The Times about St. Anthonys, a residence for chronic alcoholics in Minnesota, Benoit Denizet-Lewis spotlighted the term wet house:

title: From Mucho Macho Man to 3M
description: The name of the 3M Company originally stood for Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, but at least briefly on Saturday at Churchill Downs, it will stand for Mucho Macho Man.

title: One Juror Replaced, Galleon Jury Starts Over
description: 7:53 p.m. | Updated

title: Pakistan Sees Shared Intelligence Lapse
description: PARIS  As Pakistan faced a growing chorus of questions about its avowed ignorance of Osama bin Ladens presence on its soil, Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani sought to shift the focus of blame on Wednesday, saying the intelligence failure was made by the whole world, not Pakistan alone.

title: Palestinian Factions Sign Accord to End Rift
description: CAIRO  Rival Palestinian movements signed a historic reconciliation accord here on Wednesday vowing common cause against Israeli occupation, a product of shifting regional power relations and disillusionment with American peace efforts.

title: Not Quite a Revival, But Still a Sinful Hybrid
description: THE critics, this morning, are in something of a dilemma, Walter Terry wrote in the New York Herald Tribune on Dec. 5, 1958. City Ballet has produced an operetta, or perhaps, one should describe it as a music-drama with dancing.

title: A Blacksmiths Touch Makes Music Light
description: HEAVY metal usually means a lot of racket, but not here. Across the 30 or so rolling acres of his farm in southwestern Tuscany, the German sculptor and musician Paul Fuchs, 74, cultivates the Giardino dei Suoni, his Garden of Sounds. Weighing tons, his spindly abstractions of steel and bronze  The Long I, Cut Out, 0 + 1  inscribe the landscape like quick strokes and squiggles of some titans pen. Rising as high as 100 feet they catch movement in the air and give forth vibrations that verge on silence: the gentlest of music. One, Visit From the Extraterrestrial, tolls like a buoy on the churning sea.

title: How to Save on Group Travel
description: WITH summer on the way, many families and friends are starting to think about reunions and group vacations. But as anyone who has tried to organize a large group of travelers knows, the process can be daunting and can carry a big price tag. Luckily, there are ways to make group vacations more affordable and the planning process more streamlined, whether youre trying to arrange hotel stays, cruises or airline reservations. Here are a few tips.

title: Morgan Stanley Names New Risk Officer
description: Morgan Stanley has named a new chief risk officer.

title: Seinfeld on the Web, Portion Controlled
description: Over the course of a comedy career of 36 years and counting and 9 seasons of a singularly influential sitcom, Jerry Seinfeld has built a vast repository of stand-up material but was never truly master of his domain, in the online sense.

title: Jerry Seinfelds First Televised Jokes
description: Just how deeply did Jerry Seinfeld dig into the vault for his JerrySeinfeld.com Web site, which will make its debut on Friday and which he previews in this New York Times article?

title: Failing Grades on Civics Exam Called a Crisis
description: Fewer than half of American eighth graders knew the purpose of the Bill of Rights on the most recent national civics examination, and only one in 10 demonstrated acceptable knowledge of the checks and balances among the legislative, executive and judicial branches, according to test results released on Wednesday.

title: Bird Week | Ten Birds Worth the Wait
description: A ringing sweet-sweet-sweet and a flash of vibrant yellow: the prothonotary warbler has made its rare presence known to a lucky New York City bird-watcher.

title: Life in No Man's Land
description: Dryer than it was during the Dust Bowl era, Boise City, Okla., is shrinking fast.

title: Submit Questions for Red Bulls Tim Ream
description: Red Bulls defender Tim Ream, a contributor to this blog, will answer questions from Times readers on the Goal blog early next week.

title: Now Serving | Egg Cream at Eleven Madison Park
description: These days, fine dining isnt so much a three-act play of starter/main/dessert as a three-hour spectacular that starts with a couple of rounds of amuse-bouches and ends with the chocolates and dime-size cookies that appear some time after dessert and before the check. The headliners are still foie gras, langoustines and steak from an extremely expensive steer, but sometimes a meals brightest star is found between the big numbers.

title: China Creates New Agency for Patrolling the Internet
description: BEIJING  A powerful arm of Chinas government said Wednesday that it had created a new central agency to regulate every corner of the nations vast Internet community, a move that appeared to complement a continuing crackdown on political dissidents and other social critics.

title: What Happened to Air France Flight 447?
description: Late on the morning of April 3, the expedition ship Alucia rocked violently on the South Atlantic Ocean in the middle of a squall. On the aft deck, the crew huddled together in rain slickers and gazed across the heaving seas to a yellow blur on the horizon. This was an unmanned reconnaissance submarine carrying 15,000 photographs that they were nearly desperate to see. But it had buoyed to the surface just as the squall sprang up, and with 30-knot winds and four-foot swells that splashed over the stern, it was too dangerous to retrieve the sub. So they watched and waited.

title: Reid Dislocates Shoulder During Morning Run
description: Harry Reid, the United States Senate majority leader, took a spill on the rainy streets of Washington on Wednesday, leaving the Democrat from Nevada with a dislocated right shoulder and golf ball-sized bump above his left eye.

title: Why Moms Should Quit
description: A few weeks ago, in the middle of what I now refer to as my On the Couch period, I gave my younger son a list. I dont remember what exactly was on it, but I clearly recall his response. His expression said he was about to protest. He opened his mouth, closed it again, thought for a moment, then said: All this is the stuff you usually do around here but I dont notice, right?

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: In Afghanistan, No Time to Celebrate
description: Osama bin Laden is dead. The news was announced in tickers, as I entered my office at Bagram Airfield in Afghanistan on Monday morning. Everyone was gathered around the television, intently sitting on the edge of their black swivel chairs. All right, lets pack up now  its time to go home, one of the sergeants in the room said. I want to see a death certificate, our chiseled former infantry first sergeant said. We all know Donald Trump is going to demand to see one. The blond newscaster described how Bin Laden had been hiding in a luxurious compound 60 miles outside of Islamabad. She exclaimed, Who would have thought he would be hiding in Pakistan all along? One sergeant jumped up, muttering, I would have thought that. We all laughed.

title: Stage Is Set for First Republican Debate
description: The contrast with four years ago is likely to be striking.

title: Shunning Nasdaq, LinkedIn Prepares a Big Board I.P.O.
description: In a coup for the New York Stock Exchange, the business-oriented social networking site LinkedIn said in a filing on Wednesday that it would list its new shares on the Big Board.

title: Falling Dollar Phobia
description: I continue to be amazed by the way Very Serious People find ways to worry about everything except devastating unemployment. Theyve now spent two years warning about the bond vigilantes about to pull the rug out from under us any day now; as of right now, the 10-year interest rate has fallen to 3.21 percent on weak economic data.

title: Four Construction Executives Are Charged With Fraud
description: Four veteran construction executives were arraigned Wednesday on charges that they systemically stole tens of millions of dollars from investment firms, insurance companies and law firms as they built corporate offices in buildings across Manhattan.

title: 9/11 and the Silence of Shock
description: Our friends on the Lens blog are marking Bin Laden Week, which is what this seems to be turning into, with a remarkable series of Sept. 11 photos this morning. Theyre by Rikki Reich and were shot from the Jersey City waterfront over the course of the unfolding nightmare. As David Dunlap writes on Lens, Ms. Reichs pictures convey an awful tranquility, a suspension of everyday existence, the silence of shock. View the slide show on Lens.

title: Still Room for Freshmen at Many Colleges
description: Regular visitors to The Choice know that we try, whenever the opportunity presents itself, to remind readers that in sharp contrast to the competitive admissions landscape at some colleges, hundreds of other universities struggle every year to fill their freshman classes. For some of those institutions, the sluggish economy has only added to the challenge of completing the freshman class.

title: Its Still a No-Hitter in the Record Book
description: Its hard not to love no-hitters. They usually contain so much of what is charming about baseball: the mastery of a locked-in pitcher, superstitious teammates avoiding him in the dugout, dramatic defensive plays and nervous moments in the late innings, the emotional spillover when it is finally in the books. Francisco Lirianos no-hitter for the Twins on Tuesday night, however? Maybe only a mother could love that one.

title: Sheridans Suit Against Desperate Housewives Can Go to Trial, Judge Says
description: It was the producers of Desperate Housewives who decided to kill off Edie, the much-married Wisteria Lane resident whom Nicollette Sheridan had played on the prime-time ABC soap opera since its 2004 debut. But it is a California jury that will decide whether the characters death, in a car accident during the shows fifth season, was a fair exit for Ms. Sheridan, who has sued for damages for wrongful termination, among other matters.

title: The Godfather, Before He Was
description: How did the Don become the Don? A new prequel to The Godfather promises to explain the unknown history of how Vito Corleone rose to powerin Depression-era New York. Grand Central Publishing, part of the Hachette Book Group, announcedon Wednesday that it would publish The Family Corleone, a book based on a screenplay by Mario Puzo, in Juneof next year. Mr. Puzo died in 1999, but the book has the blessing of hisestate. The Family Corleone was written by Ed Falco, the author of three novels and the winner of a Pushcart Prize. The Godfather was first published in 1969 and has sold more than 21 million copies.

title: Complete Poll Results: Bin Laden's Death
description: Support for President Obama has risen sharply following the killing of Osama bin Laden by American military forces.

title: Wanted  Dead, Alive or Photoshopped
description: 2:15 p.m. | Updated

title: Live-blogging the Raid on Osama bin Ladens House
description: Uh oh, now Im the guy who liveblogged the Osama raid without knowing it.Mon May 02 04:41:46  via TweetDeckSohaib AtharReallyVirtual

title: Intel Increases Transistor Speed by Building Upward
description: HILLSBORO, Ore.  Intel announced on Wednesday that it had again found a way to make computer chips that could process information more quickly and with less power in less space.

title: Mother Knows Best | Carol Ross Joynt
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#246", 592, 420, true, chameleonData);

title: The Price of Oil, in Euros
Hague Court Seeks Warrants for Libyan Officials
description: The prosecutor of the International Criminal Court in The Hague said Wednesday that he would seek arrest warrants for three senior officials in Libya on charges of crimes against humanity, providing no names but saying that the three were the most responsible for the crimes committed.

title: A Better Way to Find Home Care Aides
description: Because a phrase like matching service registry can cause readers eyelids to droop, let me tell you instead about three women in Oregon.

title: Some Tickets Actually Get Cashed
description: When Joe Drape wrote this week about the trials and tribulations of a public handicapper, it inspired us to ask readers about some of their most memorable parimutuel experiences. Perhaps because of our own betting history, which often includes a blizzard of torn tickets, we at The Rail expected to get a series of agonizing bad beat stories, in which some unforeseen set of circumstances conspired to rob readers of thousands.

title: A Cuomo Against a Portrait, and Mothers Against Budget Cuts
description: ALBANY  With a stroke of his pen earlier this year, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo opened to the public his chambers on the Capitols second floor, a symbolic gesture toward transparent government that for the first time in over a decade allowed unfettered access to the vaulted and majestic Hall of Governors.

title: Sony Explains PlayStation Attack to Congress
description: Sony responded to lawmakers on Tuesday after the company was asked to answer a series of questions related to hackers breaching its network and gaining access to the personal data   including credit card numbers  of millions of its customers last month.

title: More on Hiring a Web Developer
description: My last post elicited some interesting responses. It was a straight-forward account of how I selected my new Web site developer, and some readers took issue with the process we used  in particular a reader named Rob.

title: Duersons Case Highlights the Limits of the N.F.L.s Disability Plan
description: BOSTON  As the football world absorbs Mondays news that Dave Duerson had the football-related brain damage he suspected before fatally shooting himself in February, an overlooked detail has emerged: had Duerson reached out for help via the N.F.L.s disability plan, which he helped administer, his neurological injuries would not have qualified for a high level of benefit, if any at all.

title: Account Tells of One-Sided Battle in Bin Laden Raid
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama decided Wednesday not to release graphic photographs of Osama bin Ladens corpse, as new details emerged about the raid on Bin Ladens fortified compound that differed from the administrations initial account of the nearly 40-minute operation.

title: Party Convoy in Turkey Is Fired on, Killing Officer
description: ISTANBUL  Unidentified attackers in northern Turkey opened fire Wednesday on a campaign convoy belonging to Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogans party, killing one police officer and wounding another, local officials said.

title: ConAgra Deals in the Show-Me State
description: Ralcorp is incorporated and based in Missouri, a fact that could make ConAgras takeover attempt tougher.

title: The Sustainable Prince
description: Less than a week after the wedding of his son William to Kate Middleton, Prince Charles was in Washington on Wednesday to, among other things, speak at a Georgetown University conference on the future of food and sustainable agriculture, a pet issue of his for nearly 30 years. The heir to the British throne gave an earnest and statistics-heavy address touching on such staples of the natural food movement as the virtues of composting and the need to maintain biodiversity.

title: Chemo Brain May Last 5 Years or More
description: Chemo brain, the foggy thinking and forgetfulness that cancer patients often complain about after treatment, may last for five years or more for a sizable percentage of patients, new research shows.

title: This Time, a Stuffed Alligator
description: Already an accomplished author of traditional picture books (though really, there is little that is traditional about them) and of early readers (also tweaking the traditional), Mo Willems, a three-time Caldecott Honor winner, creates something of a hybrid with his latest venture.

title: Bird Week | Mike Tyson Defends the Pigeon
Getting the Best Rate on a Car Loan
description: When it comes to buying a car, youre often far better off seeking a loan directly from a bank or credit union than going through the dealership, because dealers often add hidden finance charges.

title: The Morning Line: Another Defection, and Uncle Maybe
description: At least, for a day, there was real news about the Kentucky Derby to replace what had previously been 20 horses in search of a story line.

title: Installing Jaume Plensa's 'Echo'
description: A time-lapse video of Jaume Plensa's new site-specific work "Echo" being installed in Madison Square Park in Manhattan. (Video courtesy of Henry Jacobson/Madison Square Park Conservancy)

description: From our colleagues at the Bucks blog:

title: On Capitol Hill, Regulators Plead for More Money
description: Andrew Harrer/Bloomberg NewsMary L. Schapiro and Gary Gensler.

title: On Her Arm, a Symbol of Freedom
description: THOUGH she has rarely been described as a style icon, the suffragist Susan B. Anthony was readily identifiable on her travels by her red shawl and alligator handbag. To her, a bag was not a fashion statement but a symbol of independence at a time when women were not allowed to enter into a contract or even open a bank account.

title: ABCD
description: American Based Confused Desi  an updating of the term American Born Confused Desi, used to describe Indians in America debating whether to return to their homeland.

title: Who Will Run for President? Early Voting States May Hold a Clue
description: Were still in the Who Will Run? phase of the 2012 presidential race. Only a couple of major names  Tim Pawlenty and Mitt Romney  have registered with the Federal Election Commission to become 2012 candidates. And the words prospective candidate are bandied about before someones name almost as often as Mr. and Ms.

title: One Nurse, One Patient
description: As a nurse on the oncology floor, Im usually responsible for at least four patients each shift. But sometimes, one patient needs me more than most.

title: Campus Camo
description: Looks like the lax bros these days are laying down their lacrosse sticks in favor of something with a little more firepower. In college quads in the south, camouflage is replacing Kelly green as the prepsters color of choice. K. Cooper Ray, the Charleston, S.C.-based blogger of all things gentlemanly, saw local college kids polished and groomed and bow-tied and then they turn around and theyve got their camo on and shotguns over their shoulder, heading off to the marshes of the low country to go duck hunting. For his third Social Primer for Brooks Brothers accessory collection, Cooper tips his hunting cap to these rustic dandies who proudly refer to themselves as Prep-necks. Intrigued by these seemingly opposing ideas of masculinity, Cooper combined a green camouflage print with a Palm Beach pink repp stripe for his reversible bow tie, just one of a collection of ties, key fobs and pocket squares available at Brooks Brothers stores nationwide. Those poor ducks dont stand a chance against these dapper dudes.

title: In a Slow Week, Adele Tops Chart Again
description: Adele tops the Billboard album chart for a sixth time this week, easily taking the top slot in a down week for music sales.

title: He Puts the Maximus in the Circus
description: RANDY WEINER, the playwright and theater producer, is terrified of boring his audiences. So he was noticeably nervous before a new production of his play Caligula Maximus, a campy extravaganza that made its debut in early April at the House of Yes in Bushwick, Brooklyn.

title: The Feds Language Problem on Inflation
description: The Federal Reserve has made clear that its not worried about inflation right now, despite spikes in the price of oil, food and other commodities. It has had a harder time explaining why.

title: A Sliver of Hope Unites West Bank and Gaza
description: RAMALLAH, West Bank  Thousands of Palestinians, led by youth activists, have poured onto the streets of the West Bank and Gaza in recent months to demand national reconciliation.

title: Daniels Offers Few Clues on Potential 2012 Run
description: Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana paid a visit to Washington on Wednesday, but he dropped few clues to clarify the growing chatter among Republicans about whether he intends to jump into the partys presidential nominating contest.

title: Exhibition Trailer
description: The trailer for the new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art includes an excerpt from the artist's video "Tornado." (Video courtesy of MoMA)

title: Canucks Continue Playoff Escapes
description: If youre looking for excitement and drama in the N.H.L. playoffs, check out the No. 1 seed in the West, the Vancouver Canucks.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, Indonesia and West Bank.

title: Past Helps Righetti Nurture Staff
description: Hours before Francisco Liriano completed a 123-pitch no-hitter for the Twins against the White Sox in Chicago on Tuesday night, another left-hander from that storied fraternity of major league pitchers stood in front of the visitors dugout at Citi Field and recalled the fallout from his own unplanned appointment with fame.

title: Bin Laden Changes Afghan Debate
description: Michael D. Shear reports on the debate over pulling troops out of Afghanistan in the wake of the killing of Osama Bin Laden.

title: Coming to a Planet Near You: 3 Billion More Mouths to Feed
description: In an article in Wednesdays paper, we conveyed the highlights of a new report from the United Nations population division projecting that the global population will keep growing throughout this century and eventually pass 10 billion. And we mentioned that the population is expected to surpass seven billion this year.

title: More on Tornadoes, Floods, Climate and Risk
description: Heres a deeper discussion of efforts to clarify productive steps, both in science and policy, in the face of deadly tornado outbreaks, extraordinary midwestern flooding and climate change.

title: Afghanistan Uses News About Bin Laden to Intensify Its Criticism of Pakistan
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Afghan government escalated its criticism of Pakistan on Wednesday, publicly questioning for the first time how the Pakistanis could ensure the security of their nuclear arms if they did not even know that Osama bin Laden, the worlds most wanted terrorist, had been hiding in a compound in a Pakistani military town less than an hour from their capital.

title: A Stravinksy Program With Ancient Inspiration
description: A couple of years ago the Philadelphia Orchestra seemed adrift as it searched simultaneously for a chief executive, a board chairman and a music director. On top of that were rumblings of financial problems. It was hard to imagine how things could get worse for this great American ensemble.

title: Get Ready for 14 Hours of Derby TV Coverage
description: NBC has been home to the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness Stakes since 2001, but not since 2005 have all three Triple Crown races been shown on one network. Comcasts acquisition of NBC Universal has led to 14 hours of Kentucky Derby coverage, which is set to begin Wednesday. So pull up a seat or set your DVR.

title: Senate Thwarts Filibuster on Judge
description: Defying highly unusual opposition by business groups and the Senate minority leader, the Senate on Wednesday voted to proceed with a confirmation vote for a nominee for federal district court, thwarting a threatened filibuster and signaling an apparent unwillingness among many Republicans to hinder judicial appointments without extraordinary cause.

title: Video: Bin Laden and the Afghanistan Debate
Greater Power Over Wall Street, Left Unexamined
description: Doug Mills/The New York TimesBen Bernanke did not discuss regulation at his first news conference.

title: The Power in a Photo
description: David Brooks: Gail, I think it was Karl Marx who said that all great events happen twice, first as the event and then as the packaging. Were finished with the killing of Osama bin Laden, now we are having a debate about the presentation of the event.

title: With Supplies Dwindling, Some Honda Dealers Foresee Long, Dry Summer
description: As it works to restore production capacity lost after the earthquake in Japan, Honda announced delivery delays this week of some of its most popular and fuel-efficient models built in Japan, including the Insight, the Fit and the redesigned Civic Hybrid.

title: Share Six Words About Your Mother
At Galleon, Calm in the Face of Market Turmoil
description: As DealBook reported earlier on Wednesday, jury deliberations in the trial of Raj Rajaratnam, the founder of the Galleon Group, hit a snag after a juror dropped out for medical reasons.

title: Chance Encounter
description: Julia Leach doesnt strike you as the type of person who would leave anything to chance. A veteran of the ad agency Chiat/Day, Paper Magazine and Kate Spade, Leach is a prolific and meticulous storyboarder. Ideas seem to spill out of her head fully formed, including graphic sensibility, visual collateral and even potential plot twists. But when she struck out to start her own 360-degree lifestyle brand, she left ample room for serendipity. And as if to drive the concept home  or simply to remind herself that nothing ever really comes out exactly as you plan it  she named the venture Chance.

title: Chase Ends Test of $5 A.T.M. Fees
description: JPMorgan Chase quietly ended a test in which it was charging a hefty $4 or $5 fee for non-Chase customers in two states for access to its A.T.M.s.

title: Finding Long-Term Value in Renren
description: Many of Renrens investors profited handsomely from the companys initial public offering, when shares priced at $14 on Wednesday. But a venture capital firm, DCM, which owns 7.5 percent of the Chinese social networking site, is holding on to its stake.

title: Inside Twisters: Creating Scientific News Reports on Tornadoes
description: Updated: May 21, 2013

title: They Call Me 'Birdman'
description: James Cataldi, an Inwood resident, transformed a forgotten corner of Manhattan into a wildlife sanctuary, because, as he says, it was the right thing to do.

title: Raid Helps Obama With Independents
description: The raid that President Obama ordered on Osama bin Ladens bunker in Pakistan on Sunday has  at least for now  boosted his support among a key block of voters: independents.

title: Devastated Alabama Town Struggles to Account for Its Missing
description: HACKLEBURG, Ala.  Over the last week, this close-knit little town has had to grapple with a most unfamiliar feeling: not knowing where everyone is.

title: Ukraine Looks to Texas for an Energy Path
description: KIEV, Ukraine  This former Soviet state in Eastern Europe is betting that the path toward energy independence runs through Fort Worth.

title: Slushies Coming at You: Glee Goes 3-D in  Concert Movie
description: The Glee franchise isnt all about indulging the 1970s nostalgia of its creators and structuring entire episodes around The Rocky Horror Picture Show or Fleetwood Macs Rumours album; that hit Fox musical comedy has a few modern-day tricks up its sleeve, too. For instance: its Glee Live! In Concert! series will be filmed this summer for a 3-D movie that will feature 14 members of the television series and utilize whatever remaining exclamation points Fox possesses. On Wednesday, Twentieth Century Foxs film and television divisions said that the Glee Live! 3D! movie will be released in theaters on Aug. 12 and run for two weeks. The film, directed by Kevin Tancharoen (director of the 2009 remake of Fame, and the online series Mortal Kombat: Legacy) will feature Glee stars like Lea Michele, Chris Colfer, Heather Morris and Darren Criss performing numbers like Im a Slave 4 U, Raise Your Glass and Teenage Dream. (No word about the Glee star Matthew Morrison, whose cleft chin would seem tailor-made for the 3-D format.)

title: Two Students Plead Guilty in Bullying of Teenager
description: Two of the six students in South Hadley, Mass., who were charged with bullying a 15-year-old girl before her suicide last year pleaded guilty to misdemeanor harassment charges on Wednesday and received a years probation each, plus 100 hours of community service.

title: Apple Updates Software to Fix Problems With Collecting Location Data
description: Apple on Wednesday released its promised software update for its mobile devices to fix a problem that enabled the iPhone and iPad 3G to collect customers locations.

title: TimesCast | May 4, 2011
description: President Obama decides not to release photos of Osama bin Laden; Pakistanis question their militarys abilities; and Turkey plays an important role in the Arab spring.

title: Beauty Spots
description: VEGETABLE LOVE Yes To, a hair and skin care collection made from organic produce and minerals from the Dead Sea, has some new products. Tomato, rich in the antioxidant lycopene, is the featured ingredient in a new acne spot stick that also contains tea tree oil, and in a pore scrub with mango seeds (both $9.99.) And carrots  rich in beta-carotene, a natural form of vitamin A  appear in a new body lotion and hand cream whose other ingredients include soybeans and allantoin ($8.99 to $12.99). Available at Target, Walgreens, Duane Reade and yestocarrots.com.

title: New Stratagems in the Quest for Hair
description: RICHARD PADUDA, an athletic man with a dark, spiky coiffure, does not look like your typical user of Latisse, the prescription eyelash-enhancing solution that has been endorsed by Brooke Shields and Claire Danes. Thats because he has used it not on his eyelashes, which are fairly lush, but on his hairline, which he noticed last year was beginning to recede.

title: To Improve Your Swing: Bend Your Knees and Find a Good App
description: Every round of golf I play, Ill hit maybe three or four shots that go exactly where I want them to go. And every time it happens, its a mystery.

title: Goldman Brushes Off the Gadfly
description: William Thomas Cain/Getty ImagesEvelyn Y. Davis at the Ford Motor Companys annual meeting last year.

title: Stamps From Space, With Brooklyn Ties
description: Donato Giancola does not remember the day itself, which, if you happen to be checking the calendar, was 50 years ago on Thursday  May 5, 1961.

title: Bulls Korver Shadowed by Defensive Reputation
description: Over the course of his career, Chicago guard Kyle Korver has developed a reputation for being both one of the leagues top outside shooters and one of its lesser perimeter defenders. The former is unquestionably true: Korver is a career 41.1 percent 3-point marksman, and has connected on a whopping 61.9 percent of his attempts in these playoffs.

title: Quote Unquote | Small Wonder
description: Jean Shrimpton tells The Guardian why she likes Kate Moss. Of course the shrimp gets along with the waif.

title: Legislation Targets Drug Use in Horse Racing
description: Representative Edward Whitfield, Republican of Kentucky, and Senator Tom Udall, Democrat of New Mexico, introduced legislation Wednesday to regulate the use of performance-enhancing drugs in horse racing.

title: Adorable Anime Characters Go Speed Metal
description: The films of Hayao Miyazaki  Ponyo, Spirited Away, Princess Mononoke  are unlike anything else. The animation is amazing, but its the tone of the films that sets them apart. They are suffused with a mysterious sense of wonderment that is impossible to describe. And yet, the music: why?

title: New Apps to Post Videos With Ease
description: Most of the video shot in the world today is recorded on mobile phones. That annoying guy who walked around parties with a camcorder has been replaced with an army of annoying people who whip out their phones to capture the moment.

title: Aquifers Depletion Poses Sweeping Threat
description: The small town of Boise City, Okla., which I wrote about in Wednesdays Times, survived the environmental disaster of the Dust Bowl in the 1930s. But now it faces a confluence of dangers that could push it to the edge of extinction.

title: Jimmy
description: IN a space-deprived city, the rooftop pool is a symbol of thumb-in-your-eye luxury. Jimmy, which opened on the 18th floor of the James Hotel, joins the Standard, Trump SoHo and Gansevoort hotels as places where patrons can pretend theyre in Miami. It opened last fall, and interest has risen with the temperature.

description: Photographs from Pakistan, Indonesia and West Bank.

description: Owen Wilson and Rachel McAdams in a scene from Woody Allen's "Midnight in Paris."

title: UBS Settles Fraud Cases Over Munis
description: WASHINGTON  The Swiss bank UBS agreed to pay $160 million in fines and restitution because former employees conspired to rig bids in the municipal bond derivatives market, federal and state officials announced on Wednesday.

description: An 1886 Queen Anne in Bozeman, Mont.; a 1940 house in Miami; and a condo in a converted 1899 commercial building in downtown Los Angeles.

title: What You Get for ... $500,000
description: BOZEMAN, MONT.

title: 12 Heads Do the Talking for a Silenced Artist
description: The Chinese artist Ai Weiwei began his second month of detention this week, and still the Chinese government has given an increasingly outraged and anxious world no satisfactory answers to questions about his whereabouts, his condition or the charges against him.

title: Helping Veggie Islands Garden Grow
description: Veggie Island opened  for last years surf season, selling mainly local, mainly organic produce next to Rockaway Taco in Queens. This year, this quirky little stand is getting more serious, trying to raise $15,000 through Kickstarter to build a garden, greenhouse and composting facility at a nearby marina, and to fix up the store. So far its raised a little over $5,300 and has eight days to raise the rest.

title: Docking Your Laptop, Wirelessly
description: Mmmmmm. Wireless.

title: No, Osama Didnt Win
description: If youre looking for a counterpoint to my Bin Laden died a failure column from Monday, heres Radley Balko making that the case that the Al Qaeda founder actually died a great success:

title: The Gravity Probe B
description: The gravity probe B experiment used four gyroscopes to measure the warping of space and time around a gravitational body.

title: 52 Years and $750 Million Prove Einstein Was Right
description: In a tour de force of technology and just plain stubbornness spanning half a century and costing more than $750 million, a team of experimenters from Stanford University reported on Wednesday that a set of orbiting gyroscopes had detected a slight sag and an even slighter twist in space-time.

title: In Belize, a Beachfront Duplex
description: A five-bedroom beachfront duplex with pool and pier in Belize is on the market for $999,000.

title: Surprise! American Express Picks Your Destination for You
description: The biggest surprise that most travelers face is a flight delay. But American Express Travel is offering a new twist on trip planning that promises to inject some fun spontaneity into travel: it chooses destinations for you, and shares the details later.

title: Asked & Answered | Pierre Thoretton
description: In the past few years, there have been a number of documentaries about iconic fashion designers, from the critically acclaimed Valentino: The Last Emperor to the wayward Ultrasuede: In Search of Halston. But none seems as delicately composed and poignant as Pierre Thorettons LAmour Fou, which had its United States premiere at the Tribeca Film Festival last month and will be out in theaters on May 13. Thoretton hangs the film on the spectacular $480 million art collection that the French-Algerian couturier Yves Saint Laurent and his partner, Pierre Berg, amassed during their 50 years together and its symbolism for the love they had for one another. Still its hard not to wonder if it was Berg, as much as Thoretton, who called the shots in the film much as he did in Saint Laurents life and image. Here, the 43-year-old French director discusses the crazy love between the two men and the filmmaking techniques he chose to tell the story.

title: Beige Never Looked So Bright
description: DOLLY PARTON and Gloria Gaynor singing an impromptu duet. Britney Spears supposedly skipping out on her check. Jocelyne Wildenstein showing off her nip and tuck.

title: Forest Hills Stadium Loses Bid to Be a Landmark
description: Its courts were the site of the United States Open tennis championship for 62 years and they hosted the Beatles, Frank Sinatra and the Rolling Stones. But time may finally be running out for the now crumbling West Side Tennis Stadium in Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, one of the worlds most storied tennis arenas.

title: Moment of Falsehood
description: Well, remember how the Ryan budget was supposed to mark our national moment of truth, forcing us into a serious discussion of fiscal choices? Neither do I.

description: A look at the films Woody Allen has made outside of New York.

title: Six Gears Come to Brammo E.V. Bikes
description: Until Wednesday, one of the biggest selling points of electric cars and motorcycles has been their seamless, shift-free stream of power.

title: Into the Spotlight, Gently
description: UNTIL last Friday, Sarah Burton was an understudy in the chorus line of designers, a largely anonymous talent. As the creative director at Alexander McQueen  a role she reluctantly inherited after McQueens suicide in February 2010  she not only worked in his immense shadow, but also preferred the background to the spotlight.

title: Robbery Defendant, Uncuffed, Scuffles With Officers
description: A man facing robbery charges sent four Manhattan court officers to the hospital with minor injuries on Wednesday after he refused to go to his holding cell and scuffled with them, the authorities said.

description: President Obama decides not to release the photos of Osama bin Laden's corpse.
