description: America's successful mission to kill Osama Bin Laden has Pakistanis questioning the competence of their military.

title: TimesCast | Turkey's Role
description: May 4, 2011 - As Turkey turns its back on its ally in Libya, will it stay silent on its neighbor Syria?

title: Pakistani Military Investigates How Bin Laden Was Able to Hide in Plain View
description: ABBOTTABAD, Pakistan  The Pakistani military has taken charge of investigations into the circumstances that allowed Osama bin Laden to reside quietly in a three-story house on the edge of this town, officials here said. Military intelligence investigators returned to the house on Wednesday and spent most of the day working inside the compound, while the army and the police barred journalists and others from approaching the area.

title: House Votes to Block School Health Spending
description: House Republicans marched forward Wednesday with their efforts to dismantle the health care overhaul, one bill at a time.

title: Dialed In Is Early Derby Favorite at 4-1
description: Uncle Mo may or may not show up for the 137th running of the Kentucky Derby on Saturday, but if he does he will break from the No. 18 hole as the 9-2 morning-line second favorite.

title: Stripped Down to Black and White, Revealing Balanchine at His Core
description: The music starts. The curtain rises. There is no scenery, just a backdrop that implies the infinite sky. Yet the stage is far from empty: it features a central tableau of dancers, braced for action. When they start to move, they do so in sharply alive meters. Its as if they had been waiting for the music to ignite their motors. That little transition from standstill to motion always carries something of the drama of the moment when the sculptor Pygmalions statue Galatea comes to life.

title: Some Off-the-Edge Songs, Placed Front and Center
description: The enterprising New York Festival of Song has presented plenty of new music and even some pop at times (most notably, evenings of Beatles tunes and musical theater pieces). So it would not be entirely correct to suggest that its latest series, Nyfos Next, is an attempt to address a serious deficit in the festivals purview.

title: New York Attorney General Subpoenas Sony
description: 7:47 p.m. | Updated Added comment from Sony.

title: In Scotland, a Modern Farmhouse Rises From Ruins
description: A house on the tiny Isle of Coll was built on the remains of one abandoned 150 years earlier.

title: Voice Grows Stronger
description: The ratings for NBCs new singing competition The Voice grew 10 percent over its impressive debut a week ago, leading Tuesday nights ratings over all by a wide margin among viewers 18 to 49, and drawing 12.4 million over all. But in total viewers for the night NBC finished in third place, according to Nielsens estimates. CBS had the most viewers, garnering 17.3 million for NCIS at 8 p.m. and 14 million for NCIS: Los Angeles at 9. ABC ranked second over all, earning its best ratings at 9 for a Dancing With the Stars results episode (15.6 million), but at 10, its Body of Proof (10.4 million) trailed The Good Wife on CBS (12.3 million). Fox finished in fourth place for the night.

title: An Idol Judge Heeds Her Tips
description: Steven Tyler may operate on a bizarre frequency, and Jimmy Iovine may be the ruthless engine behind the scenes, but no one has kept American Idol afloat this year more than Jennifer Lopez.

title: Onetime S.E.C. Enforcement Lawyer Joins Weil Gotshal
description: Christian R. Bartholomew, a former senior enforcement lawyer at the Securities and Exchange Commission, has joined Weil, Gotshal & Manges as head of the law firms S.E.C. enforcement and litigation practice in Washington.

title: The Informant
Hired Killer, Forced Out of Retirement, Says Hello Again to an Old Adversary
description: Thomas Perry won the Mystery Writers of Americas Edgar Award for  The Butchers Boy, his 1982 debut novel about an extremely unflappable hired killer. He checks in on the character after long intervals, so the steel-nerved assassin showed up in the 1992 Sleeping Dogs. Now the Butchers Boy is back at full blast in The Informant, a book-length war of nerves that accentuates the best of Mr. Perrys gift for using pure logic and gamesmanship to generate breathless nonstop suspense.

title: Daniels Happy With Action on Indiana Schools
description: Just as he was noncommittal about entering the 2012 presidential race on Wednesday, Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana was characteristically low key in discussing his sweeping, even landmark changes for schools in his state.

title: Office Party? Lets Tweet It
description: ON a rainy Tuesday last month, in an all-white office space in Brooklyn, a blogger known as swissmiss traded productivity tips with some visiting creative strategists. Our own mini-TED, she said, half-joking, referring to the high-profile tech conference.

title: A New Book on Obama's Mother
description: Times reporter Janny Scott talks about her book on the life of Barack Obama's mother, Stanley Ann Dunham.

title: Its Official: Wasserman Schultz Is New Democratic Chief
description: Representative Debbie Wasserman Schultz of Florida officially became the chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee on Wednesday.

title: Liberal Groups Video Assails Koch Brothers
description: The liberal guerrilla video group Brave New Foundation on Wednesday began what it says will be a prolonged political attack against the industrialist Koch family, which has become synonymous with the anti-Obama conservative movement.

title: Designer as Dramatist, and the Tales He Left Behind
description: A hairstylist friend of mine used to place leather bondage gear in her downtown shop window to scare off what she called the wrong element, meaning anyone wanting a nice wash and trim. She wanted to be sure that if you sat in her chair, you were ready to accept whatever look she decided on for you, because it would change the way you saw yourself in the world. That was the deal.

title: Warm Respect for a Scottish Ruin
description: ISLE OF COLL, Scotland

title: Bird Week | Birdman of Inwood
description: As he rounds the corner of West 208th Street and Ninth Avenue with two green fishing nets over his shoulder, James Cataldi says: You go first. Theyll flock toward me if they see me.

title: Bargain Planes Priceless Heritage
description: MARYSVILLE, Calif.  Matthew and Tina Quy did not look quite ready to part with their vintage Stearman biplane as they showed it off here last weekend at an air show at Beale Air Force Base here: its two open cockpits, its repaired fuselage and the wings they rebuilt from scratch working weekends in their one-car garage.

title: As Ethier Pursues DiMaggio, Rollins Believes Streak Can Be Broken
description: PHILADELPHIA  Jimmy Rollins will face Jason Marquis of the Washington Nationals on Wednesday, as he has many times before, most memorably on April 6, 2006. That was when Marquis held Rollins hitless three times to help stop the longest hitting streak of the last 24 years.

title: Citigroup Hires UBS Banker
description: Kevin Cox, formerly head of Americas investment banking at UBS, is joining Citigroup as co-chairman of global industrials banking.

title: Shopping Snapshots for May 5
description: A chat with Pamela Love; cat-eye sunglasses have been gathering steam with modified styles; Loomstate hosts a party-performance, and store openings, sales and events are scheduled in New York.

title: Artware Editions Moves to the Bowery
description: After five years in the West Village, Artware Editions has moved to a 2,300-square-foot space on the Bowery  one large enough to display the range of products offered by the gallery, which specializes in functional designs by visual artists. The space allows us to show pieces in the context of each other, said Rebecca Kong, a founder of the company. We can show the Klein table with a couch, so you can see its something you can live with.

title: Ottomans and Tray Tables Merged With Flowerpots
description: The Oasis collection from the Swedish furniture company Offecct offers a new way to add plant life to interiors, by merging furniture with flowerpots. Plants and flowers enhance the quality of the air, said David Lerdell, a spokesman for the company, but some people dont like the look of ordinary plant containers. With Oasis, he said, you can have vegetation and the feeling of the interior that you want.

title: The Look and Feel of Handmade Furniture
description: Those who have tired of the high-gloss, metal-heavy aesthetic that has dominated the kitchen and bath world in recent years might be interested in Bornholm Kitchen, a new company on Long Island that makes kitchen and bath pieces with a fine-furniture aesthetic.

title: Five Gadgets for the Backyard
description: Several high-tech gadgets that promise to solve some horticultural hassles.

title: Shopping for Toys With David Weeks
description: The lighting designer shopped for good-looking toys that would appeal to adults as well as children.

title: Sales at Moroso, Housing Works and Elsewhere
description: The  Housing Works Design on a Dime event opens Thursday night with a preview party, with merchandise 50 to 70 percent off (a Bunny Williams turquoise lamp, originally $800, will be $350; a Jonathan Adler Lampert sofa, regularly $3,200, will be $1,600); tickets are $250 at the door, at (347) 473-7457 or at housingworks.org. Design on a Dime continues Friday and Saturday at the Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street (Sixth Avenue).

title: At the MoMA Store, Designs From the Streets of Istanbul
description: Destination: Istanbul, the latest in a series of product collections developed in other countries for the Museum of Modern Art, has its debut next week at the museums stores in Midtown and SoHo (and is online now).

title: In Brimfield, Mass., Running the Antiques Show That Dad Founded
description: From Tuesday to May 15, the town of Brimfield, Mass., population 3,600 or so, will swell to many times its size, straining to contain a flood of antiques dealers and the buyers who will rush the gates in search of treasure: a vintage shoe rack, a copper weather vane, a Staffordshire dog, an old postcard from Minnesota.

title: How to Choose the Best Vines for Your Yard
description: MICHAEL DORFS backyard vineyard started a decade ago with 10 grapevines, enough to make four cases of wine if everything went well.

title: Sales of Home Safes Surge, Driven by the Recession and Recent Disasters
description: THE engineer in Danbury, Conn., is feeling more secure now that he has an 875-pound safe bolted to the floor of his den. The 52-year-old, who is a skeet shooter, wanted the 19.2-cubic-foot safe to lock up his seven shotguns, some of which are family heirlooms. But he also stores his wifes jewelry in there, as well as a stash of emergency cash and a backup hard drive for his computer.

title: Tools for the Wired Gardener
description: LAST spring my wife and I moved to the suburbs, and although there were many reasons for our relocation (a new job, an imminent baby), what we yearned for most was a backyard.

title: A Wine to Call Our Own
description: AMONG the great wineries of the 20th century, my grandfathers basement in the Bronx never got much respect. The best thing you could say about the red wine he made each fall was that there was a lot of it.

title: Designer Toys
description: AS a designer of light fixtures that are sculptural and modern, David Weeks has long been a favorite of interior designers and architects. But when he recently began designing toys, many of his clients werent sure what to think.

title: Jackie Cooper, Film and Television Actor, Dies at 88
description: Jackie Cooper, the pug-nosed kid who became Americas Boy in tear-jerker films of the Great Depression, then survived Hollywoods notorious graveyard of child stardom and flourished as an adult in television and modern pictures, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 88.

title: The Tupperware Party Moves to Social Media
description: LOOKED at a certain way, the venerable Tupperware party could be deemed an early form of social networking or word-of-mouth marketing. Now, the Tupperware parent is making a big bet on the contemporary, digital equivalents.

title: A Return to Spending and the Front Rows
description: BUSINESS travelers are back, and the airlines are eager to court them again.

title: Abbeys Restoration Is First Stitch to Heal a Gash in Central Italys Landscape
description: CASTIGLIONE A CASAURIA, Italy  A little more than two years after an earthquake destroyed broad stretches of Italys central Abruzzo region, this normally low-buzz community of some 900 souls was a beehive of activity.

title: A Bin Laden Hunter on Four Legs
description: The identities of all 80 members of the American commando team who thundered into Abbottabad, Pakistan, and killed Osama bin Laden are the subject of intense speculation, but perhaps none more so than the only member with four legs.

title: Spirit of Tuskegee
description: A Stearman biplane, purchased on eBay in 2005, has been revealed to be one of the few surviving planes that were used to train the Tuskegee Airmen.

title: The Battle for Libya | May 4
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis forces made an artillery strike on the port area of Misurata, killing four people.

title: Mets Look for an Answer for Tholes Struggles
description: The Mets young catcher Josh Thole has had several bad games behind the plate recently, which warranted his being benched Wednesday night. But what seemed to bother Manager Terry Collins most was how Thole discussed his defensive play after Tuesdays game.

title: Stripped Down to a Bigger Sound
description: Mikel Jollett of the Airborne Toxic Event had just started a song at the Mercury Lounge on Tuesday night, unaccompanied except for those in the room singing along, when he stopped abruptly, as if distracted by something. I forgot how small this place was, he said, chuckling. (There was a colorful modifier in that sentence.) He paused, encouraging some rowdy cheers, and then it was on with the song, and the show.

title: In Sweeping Action, G.M. Recalls 154,000 Chevrolet Cruze Models
description: General Motors is recalling all of its 2011 Chevrolet Cruze compact sedans to check for a steering problem as well as a condition in which an automatic transmission that appears to be in Park may still be in gear, increasing the chance of a roll-away accident.

title: Seal Hits the Beach in Upper Manhattan
description: Update, 10:04 a.m. Thursday | The seal was still on the beach as of 10 a.m. Thursday, the city parks department said, and still appears healthy and normal. We have some rangers out there monitoring it but nothings really changed, a parks spokeswoman said.

title: Gadgets to Ease Travails of Travel
description: IN many ways, travel has gotten worse: security concerns, overcapacity, rising rates  it is a now-familiar list of inconveniences and humiliations.

title: Some Adventures in Scoring in Advance of the Cavendish
description: The Cavendish Invitational Pairs, which begins in Henderson, Nev., on Friday, features a two-tier system. The entry fee of $2,800 per pair is redistributed in session and overall prizes. There is also an auction, for which the minimum bid is $12,500. That money is returned to the buyers of the Top 10 pairs.

title: Portable Technology for Travelers
description: Todays travelers, for business or leisure, can carry far less electronic gear than they used to, thanks to combinations and innovations.

title: In Arizona, Tea Party License Plate Draws Opposition From Its Honorees
description: SURPRISE, Ariz.  When conservative Republicans pushed a bill through the Arizona Legislature creating a Dont Tread on Me license plate design that would be used to raise money for Tea Party groups in the state, opposition was expected from Democrats, liberals and other assorted antagonists.

title: Unrest Around the Arab World Endangers Turkeys Newfound Influence
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Turkey faces a growing challenge from the tumult sweeping the Arab world to its booming economic stake in the region, newfound political influence and longstanding policy of permitting no problems to fester along its borders.

title: Mobile Booking Apps Are Only Just Starting to Deliver
description: ITS happened to all of us: after a mad rush to the airport, you arrive to discover that your flight has been canceled. You run to the ticket counter to book a new one, only to wait alongside other travelers competing to get on the next plane out.

title: At Sculpture Unveiling, Appeals for Artists Release
description: They rose from the majesty of one of New Yorks great fountains: 12 bronze statues, each depicting an animal of the Chinese zodiac, staring fiercely at passers-by at the edge of Central Park. The mayor, the curator and artists from around the world were there for the exhibits opening on Wednesday. The creator was not.

title: Tough Rule Eliminates Most Tarmac Strandings
description: WHEN they get together, business travelers complain about the hassles of air transportation, but one big issue has abruptly dropped off the gripe list.

title: Lacking Blockbuster, News Corp. Falls Short
description: Not every fiscal quarter can have an Avatar.

title: After Bin Laden: The Torture Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Importance of Class Size
description: To the Editor:

title: Britain: 5 Freed Without Charges
description: The police have released five men who were arrested this week near the Sellafield nuclear processing facility in northwest England. They were freed without charges, the Greater Manchester Police said Wednesday. The men, all in their 20s and from London, were questioned by antiterrorism police officers before being released. Activities at the Sellafield facility include recycling fuel and processing nuclear waste.

title: A Right to Counsel
description: To the Editor:

title: Declining Scores on Advanced Placement Exams
description: To the Editor:

title: In Land of Wild Horses, One Gentle Creature Stands Apart From the Herd
description: HERRIMAN, Utah  The horse in corral No. 2 was alone, eating alfalfa from a tractor tire turned trough, isolated from the wild horses clustered in a corral up the hill. She does not really have a name, said Tami Howell, a wrangler in boots and jeans standing by the fence. Or rather, Ms. Howell added, a few names were tried over the years but none stuck.

title: For Many Carriers, Business Class Is the Premium Choice
description: TO the question, what does a person get when spending upward of $16,000 for a first-class international airline ticket, the answer is: more than ever. Private lounges with hot food and drink, spalike bathrooms and concierge services. Courteous guards to help passengers through a separate security checkpoint and a private car to whisk them to the plane.

title: Best of the Best Are Back in the Final
description: The Champions League final at Wembley on May 28 will be a rematch of Rome two years ago, when Barcelona beat Manchester United, 2-0, with, of all things, a flying header from the diminutive Lionel Messi.

title: Canada: Bishop Pleads Guilty in Child Pornography Case
description: A Roman Catholic bishop pleaded guilty in Ottawa on Wednesday to possession of child pornography for importation. Bishop Raymond Lahey, left, who once led the Diocese of Antigonish, Nova Scotia, was charged after customs agents examined his laptop computer as he returned to Canada from an overseas trip in 2009. They found 588 graphic images of children, 33 videos and the texts of stories featuring the enslavement of children. Customs officials estimated that some boys in the photographs were only 8 years old.

title: Marian Mercer, Actress With Zany Streak, Is Dead at 75
description: Marian Mercer, a willowy actress with a comedic flair who won a Tony Award in 1969 for her performance in the hit musical Promises, Promises, died on April 27 in Newbury Park, Calif. She was 75 and lived in Agoura Hills, Calif.

title: The Voice Brings NBC a Ratings Surge
description: NBCs new singing competition, The Voice, cemented its position as the breakout hit of the network television season Tuesday night by becoming the first new show on any network this season to post ratings growth in its second edition.

title: Florida Struggles With Arizonas Immigration Plan
description: MIAMI  With no debate, the Florida Senate on Wednesday approved a watered-down bill to curb illegal immigration, an issue that has divided Republicans in the state, pitting pro-business and Hispanic lawmakers against the partys more populist wing.

title: LeBron Jamess Decision Is Looking Better
description: MIAMI

title: Ground-Level Tastings of the Best Food in the Sky
description: AIRLINES are bringing their best food offerings to street level, with roving trucks and pop-up lounges that offer passers-by a taste of whats being served in the air.

title: Constructing a Story, With 2,982 Names
description: How do you find a name?

title: Drop Jeter Down? Girardi Isnt Even Thinking About It
description: DETROIT  It was a difficult conversation for Joe Girardi when he spoke over the winter with Jorge Posada about ceding his starting catching job to be the Yankees full-time designated hitter. Girardi said he had not even begun thinking about what would be an equally awkward discussion, informing Derek Jeter that he had been dropped in the lineup.

title: Raise Taxes, but Not Tax Rates
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Audit Finds Long Waits for Breast Exams
description: Women have had to wait dangerously long times for mammograms at several of New Yorks public hospitals, a city audit released on Wednesday found.

title: Plan to Build Up Chelsea Market Has Some Up in Arms
description: Chelsea Market, the old Nabisco bakery complex that was transformed into a hip food arcade and office building in the 1990s, has served as a neighborhood anchor as the surrounding area turned from a faded industrial wasteland to a haven for galleries, fashion houses, technology firms and flashy apartment houses.

title: A Manager Turns Misfortune Into a Lesson
description: WILMINGTON, Del.

title: Q&A: Upgrading on the Up-and-Up
description: Q.

title: Q. and A. With Director of Thoroughbred
description: Thoroughbred, produced and directed by the Academy Award winner Paul Wagner, sets out to capture the beauty of the breed and the passion of the people whose lives revolve around the majestic creatures. From the breeding shed, to the auction ring, to the winners circle at Churchill Downs, this film takes you along for the joyful and sometimes heartbreaking journey through the world of horse racing. Wagner shared his thoughts about making the film, which includes footage of the road to the 2009 Derby. Thoroughbred premieres in the New York area at 10 p.m. Wednesday on WNET/Thirteen and nationally on PBS on Thursday at 9 p.m. Eastern.

title: Pakistani Army, Shaken by Raid, Faces New Scrutiny
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The reputation of the army, the most powerful and privileged force in Pakistan, has been severely undermined by the American raid that killed Osama bin Laden, raising profound questions about its credibility from people at home and from benefactors abroad, including the United States.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Sugary Web Sites
description: On this weeks Bits: Tech Talk show, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Matt Richtel, a Times technology reporter, about proposed federal guidelines that could affect how food companies promote their products to children online. The children who visit the companies Web sites that feature games, quizzes and other entertainment often cant distinguish the advertising component, Mr. Richtel says.

title: Dodgers Say Selig Caused Shortfall
description: Frank McCourt, the Los Angeles Dodgers owner, appeared to move closer to a legal confrontation with Major League Baseball on Wednesday by sending two letters accusing Commissioner Bud Selig of causing the teams financial distress by not approving a pending local television deal with Fox.

title: Madoff Trustee Readies First Payout for Investors
description: The trustee liquidating Bernard L. Madoffs firm said on Wednesday that he would allocate $2.6 billion to a fund for investors who lost money in Mr. Madoffs Ponzi scheme and pay an initial $272 million to those with approved claims.

title: Beyond Flowers for Mom
description: HARGEISA, Somaliland

title: ConAgra May Have to Go Hostile After Ralcorp Rejects Offer
description: ConAgra Foods proposal to buy Ralcorp Holdings for $4.9 billion may be called a bear hug, but the deal is far from warm and fuzzy.

title: Navigating With Social Media
description: WHEN Mark Rosch and his wife, Carole Levitt, were traveling to Kansas City, Mo., on a recent trip for their legal education and research business, they did not want to miss an opportunity to dine across the state line at  Oklahoma Joes Barbecue in Kansas City, Kan. But after arriving by taxi at the award-winning restaurant, located in a former gas station in a residential area, they worried about finding a taxi to take them back to their hotel after dinner.

title: Doctor, Patient and Politician
description: Let us stop for a minute to consider Mitch Daniels, the governor of Indiana.

title: As Baghdad Violence Evolves, Officials Grapple With New Scourge: Assassinations
description: BAGHDAD  Under pressure to respond to a public unnerved by a wave of assassinations, one of the top security officials in Baghdad held an unusual news conference on Wednesday to play video confessions from three suspects from what he said was a cell of Al Qaeda.

title: Using History to Mold Ideas on the Right
description: ALEDO, Tex.  In an unmarked office building in this ranching town, among thousands of Revolution-era documents and two muskets with bayonets, David Barton might seem like a quirky history buff. But the true ambition of this slender man in cowboy boots is to use Americas past to remake its future, and he has the ear of several would-be presidents.

title: Derby Field Lacks Speed of Horses in the Past
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  They drew the field for the 137th running of the Kentucky Derby on Wednesday, but it did little to clear up the intrigue over whether Uncle Mo, last years 2-year-old champion, will actually show up for the race Saturday. Nor did it solve the mystery of why this group of 3-year-old horses is so slow.

title: The Torture Apologists
description: The killing of Osama bin Laden provoked a host of reactions from Americans: celebration, triumph, relief, closure and renewed grief. One reaction, however, was both cynical and disturbing: crowing by the apologists and practitioners of torture that Bin Ladens death vindicated their immoral and illegal behavior after the Sept. 11 attacks.

title: Debt Ceiling Has Some Give, Until Roof Falls In
description: WASHINGTON  The federal government will not run short of money to pay its bills on May 16, when the federal debt reaches the legal maximum of $14.3 trillion.

title: From Floor Plans to Dcor, a Focus on Design
description: Avery Leigh Cox, 24, has been a junior designer for the past year at Amanda Nisbet Design and helped install the frisky bedroom the firm designed for the Kips Bay Decorator Show House, on display through May 26. Ms. Cox graduated with a B.F.A. in interior design from the Lamar Dodd School of Art at the University of Georgia and moved to New York from Dallas, her hometown, in 2009. She scraped along through a couple of unpaid internships before joining Nisbet and lives in Greenwich Village, where she customized her apartment by painting its brick fireplace hot pink.

title: Connecticuts Budget Is Done, but Governors Work Is Not
description: HARTFORD  Moving from Gorilla A to Gorilla B, Gov. Dannel P. Malloy on Wednesday signed into law a $40.1 billion budget that includes the largest tax increase in Connecticut history, then headed toward a Friday target for extracting $1 billion in annual wage and benefit concessions and program cuts from more than 45,000 state employees.

title: 17-Year-Old Is Charged in Babys Death
description: A Brooklyn teenager was charged on Wednesday with the murder of a 9-month-old boy who had been left in his care, the police said.

title: In Bin Ladens Compound, Seals All-Star Team
description: WASHINGTON  There were 79 people on the assault team that killed Osama bin Laden, but in the end, the success of the mission turned on some two dozen men who landed inside the Qaeda leaders compound, made their way to his bedroom and shot him at close range  all while knowing that the president of the United States was keeping watch from Washington.

title: Tour Officials Labor to Make Golf Work
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  They wear starched white shirts and crisply knotted neckties, carry walkie-talkies and buzz their carts around tournaments with an air of authority. But golfs version of umpires and referees is all but invisible.

title: Jury Verdict for Hospital in Suicide Case Is Set Aside
description: A jury verdict that cleared a psychiatric hospital in Connecticut of liability in a patients suicide has been overturned by an appeals court that said the judge should have tried to determine if jurors were prejudiced by a newspaper article published just before the trial began.

title: Lawmakers Challenge: A Plan to Lower the Deficit, and Make It Stick
description: WASHINGTON  As bipartisan negotiations were to begin over how to limit the spread of federal red ink, Senator Max Baucus, chairman of the Finance Committee, said Wednesday that he was open to imposing a trigger that would force spending cuts if the government exceeded prescribed deficit levels.

title: Renren May Skew Facebooks Value
description: Goldman Sachs got a steal of a deal on its Facebook stake. Thats if Renren is anything to go by. Shares in Renren, Chinas answer to the social networking giant, surged more than 25 percent on their first day of trading on Wednesday. That meant it was valued at nearly 100 times last years revenue. On that basis, Facebook is worth about $200 billion. Goldman bought in at just a quarter of that. With some bubbly assumptions, the higher figure can almost be supported.

title: Washing Away the Fields of Iowa
description: To an untrained eye, the fields of Iowa have a reassuring solidity. You cannot tell that the state has lost half its topsoil in the past century. According to a new report from the Environmental Working Group, Iowas soil is washing away at rates far higher than anyone realized.

title: Goodbye to All That
description: My first New York apartment was a 9-by-5-foot room on 20th Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues. It was an all-female boarding house, or S.R.O. (single room occupancy) as they were called before my time. The eight women on my floor all lived in cell-like rooms, and shared the two tiny bathrooms in the hallway, one with nothing but a toilet, the other with a moldy shower.

title: A Chance to Rebuild SUNY
description: Even before the fiscal crisis, the New York State Legislature was doing a terrible job of managing the State University of New York System. Lawmakers who voted to cut financing to the 64-campus system also starved it by forbidding reasonable tuition increases and then hijacked tuition revenue for use in the general state budget. In recent years, administrators have had to cut class offerings, limit enrollment and rely far too much on part-time faculty.

title: Claiming Fraud in A.I.G. Bailout, Whistle-Blower Lawsuit Names 3 Companies
description: The first known whistle-blower lawsuit to assert that the taxpayers were defrauded when the federal government bailed out the American International Group was unsealed on Friday, joining a number of suits seeking to settle the score on losses related to the financial crisis of 2008.

title: At an Art Party, Baring All While Remaining Dressed
description: We saw relatively little of Marina Abramovic at the Museum of Modern Art on Tuesday night because, unlike in some of her shows elsewhere, she wasnt naked.

title: Big Brother Goes to West Egg
description: Kings Point, N.Y., on Long Islands gilded North Shore, wants to do criminal checks on every car that enters its placid realm. It has the technology  license-plate cameras hooked up to police computers  and is borrowing the money to install 44 of them. For about a million dollars, it will get what village trustees say is the snuggest security blanket money can buy.

title: For Next Chief of Newark Schools, Hard Choices
description: As the new superintendent of the Newark schools, Cami Anderson faces the monumental task of rescuing an urban school system that has long been mired in low achievement, high turnover and a culture of failure, despite decades of state intervention.

title: Recuse Me
description: However the courts eventually resolve the challenge to Californias ban on same-sex marriage, the record of the case will contain an ugly footnote: the last-ditch effort to retrospectively disqualify the federal judge who ruled that the ban is unconstitutional. It turns out that  horrors!  the judge, Vaughn R. Walker, is gay. Perhaps, his critics suggest, Judge Walker secretly intends to marry his partner of 10 years and has thus improperly placed himself in a position to reap personal benefit from his own ruling.

title: Hotels Add Extras to Cushion Higher Prices
description: Suzanne Dissette wont pad her expense account with minibar charges or in-room movie fees. She comparison-shops for airfares and drives to the airport, rather than take a taxi, to save money. She walks a line between spending what she needs to do her job and watching her outlays. That is why the free bottle of water at the Doubletree Hotel in Dana Point, Calif., felt like a gift  both personal and spontaneous.

title: Lottery Numbers
Warner Music Nears a Sale to Access
description: 11:15 p.m. | Updated

title: A Cottage, So Preppy, Pops Up for Hilfiger
description: The M11 bus rumbled through the rain on the cobblestone streets of the meatpacking district on Wednesday, splashing past a cottage with gray cedar shingles and blue-and-white-striped awnings plunked down incongruously onto what, only last week, was an empty public plaza.

title: Mummified Body Found in Former Actresss Home
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.  Yvette Vickerss first appearance on a big screen was a fleeting part in Sunset Boulevard, the 1950 classic about a former Hollywood star turned recluse living in a crumbling mansion with her butler.

title: Jackie Coopers Career
description: Jackie Cooper, a child star who flourished as an adult in television and modern pictures, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 88.

title: Thursday: City Known as the Big Guava
description: Administrivial NOTEPAD Alert!: There is a notepad in todays Across Lite version of the puzzle that says: Some of the black squares in this puzzles grid provide a hint to the four longest Down answers. Now that you have the hint, proceed in an orderly fashion through the puzzle and upon finishing, please wait until this post has come to a full and complete stop to exit the blog.

title: A Suspects Surrender, Eased by a Clergy Program to Curtail Black-on-Black Violence
description: The suspect, Trevin T. Smith, was waiting in the rain with his sister on a Brooklyn street corner on Wednesday morning. The clergyman, Bishop Gerald G. Seabrooks, pulled up alone, as agreed, in his brown four-door car. Then the three set out on a 15-minute ride to Rehoboth Cathedral to meet the police.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: A Brief Victory Lap Before Budget Fight Strains Unity Call
description: WASHINGTON  On Monday night President Obama welcomed dozens of Congressional leaders to dinner at the White House and expressed hope that they can harness some of the unity forged by the death of Osama bin Laden to confront the many challenges that we still face. On Thursday comes the biggest test of that, and few see much prospect of a dawn of bipartisanship.

title: Hurting Moderates, Helping Militants
description: THE rival Palestinian groups Hamas and Fatah officially agreed this week to reconcile and form a unity government. In response, Israel has decided to punish the Palestinian Authority by withholding two-thirds of its annual revenues. Its a tactic Israel tried after Hamas won parliamentary elections in 2006  and it will probably have as little success now as it did then.

title: Bloggingheads: The Osama Stimulus?
description: Matthew Yglesias, left, of the Center for American Progress and Karl Smith of the University of North Carolina debate whether Bin Laden's death could help the economy.

title: CUNY Blocks Honor for Tony Kushner
description: In a rare move, the trustees of the City University of New York have voted to shelve an honorary degree that one of its campuses, John Jay College, planned to award to Tony Kushner, the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright of Angels in America. The vote on Monday evening came after a CUNY trustee said that Mr. Kushner had disparaged the State of Israel in past comments, a characterization that the writer attacked on Wednesday.

title: Yankees Rocky Day Continues Into Night
description: DETROIT  A bumpy day Wednesday for the Yankees began with the disclosure that Phil Hughes would miss at least another six to eight weeks, and it continued with Manager Joe Girardi finding himself in an awkward situation, confronted with questions about Derek Jeters security atop the lineup.

title: Suit Accuses U.S. Government of Failing to Protect Earth for Generations Unborn
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Advocates of stringent curbs on greenhouse gas emissions sued the federal government on Wednesday, arguing that key agencies had failed in their duty to protect the earths atmosphere as a public trust to be guarded for future generations.

title: The Amenity Travelers Want Most: Power for Their Gadgets
description: In the lavish days before the recession, there was an amenities arms race in the hospitality industry, as hotel chains replaced dated bedspreads with down comforters and duvet covers, mounted flat-screen TVs in all their rooms and competed to offer fancy toiletries and must-have accessories like iPod docking stations.

title: As Goaltending Falters, Flyers Find Themselves in a Familiar Hole
description: BOSTON  The Flyers playoff goaltending has been a mess.

title: Lincecum Is Latest to Baffle the Mets
description: The cumulative frustration of facing three of baseballs elite pitches in four games was expressed in the tense, clipped words of Manager Terry Collins after the final game in the sequence. After seeing the Mets split their games against the Phillies Roy Halladay and Cliff Lee last weekend, Collins watched helplessly as the Giants Tim Lincecum, a two-time Cy Young Award winner, put the finishing touches on the challenging progression.

title: Calisthenics Come Back as the Anywhere Workout
description: Pierre Rougier, a publicist in Manhattan, is known as one of the fashions industrys most powerful behind-the-scenes players.

title: A Workout to Go
description: Rob Morea, an owner at Great Jones Fitness in Manhattan, demonstrates exercises that can be done in a hotel room.

title: Knicks Castoff, and Now Hes Guarding Bryant
description: LOS ANGELES  The Boston Celtics quickly excused the Knicks from the playoffs. But some of Knicks recent alumni have moved into the second round.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,554 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: A Potential Candidate in No Rush for a Race
description: WASHINGTON  Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana called the leisurely pace of the 2012 presidential campaign a blessing for voters. Whether he plans to take advantage of it is another question, which he did not answer as he paid a visit here Wednesday.

title: Illinois: State Leaves Immigration Program
description: Gov. Pat Quinn has withdrawn the state from a federal program that runs immigration checks on fingerprints of everyone arrested by the state and local police. In a letter to Immigration and Customs Enforcement, Mr. Quinn, a Democrat, said he was canceling Illinois participation in the program, known as Secure Communities, because of a conflict between its stated purpose and its results. Although officials had said the program would deport immigrants who were convicted criminals, Mr. Quinn wrote, fewer than 20 percent of immigrants deported under the program had serious convictions.

title: Vlaminck and Monet Tie for Top Sale at Christies
description: An early sighting of Leonardo DiCaprio trying to hide under a navy-blue baseball cap and sitting next to his actor pal Lukas Haas added a bit of Hollywood flavor to a generally lively sale of Impressionist and modern art at Christies on Wednesday night. Although neither man could be seen raising his hand, others certainly did, though in a controlled, price-conscious fashion. Blue-chip names including Monet, Matisse and Picasso brought solid prices  even if the works were far from their best  a day after auction season got off to a bumpy start at Sothebys.

title: House Votes to Limit Access to Abortion
description: House Republicans continued Wednesday with their efforts to dismantle the health care law. On a 251-to-175 vote, the House approved a bill prohibiting federal money to be used for insurance plans that cover abortions. The bill goes beyond current federal law, which prohibits the use of federal funds for abortions. It would also wipe out tax breaks for private employers who provide coverage if their plans offer abortion services and would eliminate the ability to pay for an abortion with pretax dollars from a flexible spending plan. Voting 235 to 191, the House blocked money for construction of school-based health centers that had been earmarked in the health care act.

title: Shaping Human Path to 15, or 6, Billion by 2100
description: Following up on the latest United Nations projections for population growth through 2100, Room for Debate, drawing on some familiar Dot Earth voices, has elicited five fascinating takes on alternative human futures:

title: When the Fur Doesnt Fly
description: Spacious rooms, plush bedding, spa treatments, a large swimming pool and a lively social scene. It sounds like a dream vacation. But these amenities are not for humans; they are for pets left behind when their owners take plane trips.

title: Resort Living for Pets
description: While their owners are out of town, some pets live the good life at boarding facilities that are more spa than kennel. And theyre convenient to the airport.

title: How to Beat High Airfares
description: Air travel remains a necessity, even as it gets ever more expensive. First, the cost of flights, which fell throughout most of the 2000s relative to inflation, is climbing once again thanks to higher fuel prices. And then there are the added fees for everything from checked baggage to those vile croissanwiches.

title: Jerry Brown, the Contender
description: California and Brown have changed in the 28 years since he left the governors office, and now they are relearning each other.

title: Jerry Browns Last Stand
description: The 39th, and 34th, governor of California was making his first trip to Los Angeles since being sworn in, for an evening speech in February to the citys Chamber of Commerce, and a swarm of reporters was waiting at Terminal A of the Bob Hope Airport in Burbank. Edmund G. Brown Jr.  he has always preferred Jerry  arrived from Sacramento not on a state aircraft (and certainly not a private jet, as was the preference of his predecessor, Arnold Schwarzenegger) but aboard Flight 896 on Southwest Airlines. As Brown walked off the plane and into the terminal, he was essentially alone, save for a few police guards who hung off to the side. There were no press aides, no advance staff, no speechwriters, no policy mavens; in short, nothing like the bustling entourage of self-importance that typically buffers a chief executive.

title: Sports Replay: May 4
description: A look back at the day in sports, from the Champions League to hockey fights and sweeps.

description: The creator of Google Voice left Google last fall to work on a new start-up, and now hes ready to talk about what hes doing.

title: Americans Abroad: Should These 5 Guys Come Home to M.L.S?
description: The early returns are in on the transfer of Benny Feilhaber from AGF Aarhus to Major League Soccers New England Revolution: It was a shrewd move.

title: Bank of America to Triple Number of Mortgage Help Centers
description: Bank of America plans to triple the number of local centers across the country that provide assistance to mortgage customers facing foreclosure, lifting the total to 40 from 12 by early summer.

title: A Better Medical School Admissions Test
description: Recently the college-age daughter of a friend talked to me about her dream of becoming a doctor. She was doing well as a psychology major and in her pre-medical courses, was working as a research assistant for a pediatrician at a nearby medical school and volunteered on the cancer ward at a childrens hospital.

title: Obama Honors Victims of Bin Laden at Ground Zero
description: President Obama laid a wreath of red, white and blue flowers at ground zero on Thursday, honoring the nearly 3,000 people killed in the September 2001 terrorist attacks and marking the death of the perpetrator, Osama bin Laden.

title: Mavericks Prevail and Send Lakers Into Panic Mode
description: LOS ANGELES  The Lakers celebrated last June on the Staples Center court in gold glitter when Kobe Bryant persevered, Pau Gasol dominated and Ron Artest chipped in. They had outlasted the Boston Celtics and cemented another championship.

title: Qaeda Affiliate Is Blamed in Iraq Suicide Bombing
description: BAGHDAD  A suicide bomber attacked a police training center on Thursday in the predominantly Shiite city of Hilla, south of Baghdad, killing 25 people and wounding at least 75 in the second major bombing in Iraq this week.

title: Accord Brings New Sense of Urgency to Israeli-Palestinian Conflict
description: CAIRO  A day after Palestinian leaders signed what many called a landmark reconciliation accord, the antagonists in the protracted Israeli-Palestinian conflict and their international mediators in Europe staked out positions in a rapidly shifting political and diplomatic landscape on Thursday.

title: The Inner Lives of Wartime Photographers
description: This has been a grievous season for the tight-knit tribe of combat photographers. For The Times, the sorrow began last October, when a land mine exploded under Joao Silva while he was shooting pictures of an American patrol near Kandahar, Afghanistan, destroying both of his legs and shredding his intestinal tract. This spring, three other photographers working for The Times  Jehad Nga, Tyler Hicks and Lynsey Addario  were among the numerous journalists who disappeared into the custody of Libyan state thugs, where they were beaten and terrorized before we could negotiate their release. The darkness deepened by several hues last month when two admired lensmen  Tim Hetherington and Chris Hondros  were killed while embedded with Libyas hapless rebel militia.

title: Should Obama Have Released the Photos of Bin Ladens Body?
description: After intense debate within his administration, the president has decided not to release photographs taken of Osama bin Laden after he was killed by the United States military. Do you agree or disagree with that decision, and why?

title: Workers Enter Japans Crippled Reactor Building
description: TOKYO  Workers entered a damaged reactor building at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant on Thursday for the first time since explosions crippled the Japanese power plant two months ago.

title: In London, a Slice of Downtown New York, Circa 1970s
description: The Barbican Art Gallery is offering a glimpse of life in downtown Manhattan in the early 1970s  at least through the eyes of a particular group of artists. The Pioneers of the Downtown Scene, New York 1970s exhibition, at the gallery through May 22 (Barbican Centre, Silk Street; 44-207-638-4141; www.barbican.org.uk/artgallery/), features sculptures, drawings, photographs, documentation of performances, and mixed-media works.

title: The Early Word: No Bin Laden Photos, but Thousands of Words
description: In Todays Times: In deciding not to release photographs of Osama bin Ladens corpse, President Obama concluded that the images could incite violence against Americans and would do little to persuade skeptics that Al Qaedas founder had been killed in the raid on his Pakistan compound, Mark Landler and Mark Mazzetti write. There is still a risk that a photo will be leaked, they say, noting that fakes are already circulating on the Internet. Today, Mr. Obama is scheduled to take part in a wreath-laying ceremony at the Sept. 11 memorial in lower Manhattan before meeting with relatives of the victims. On Friday, he will travel to Fort Campbell, Ky., to speak to troops returning from combat duty in Afghanistan.

title: 2010 St. Louis Rams: What the Film Revealed
description: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis. This week, we look at the N.F.C. West:

title: Pakistani Army Chief Warns U.S. on Another Raid
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The head of Pakistans army, Gen. Ashfaq Parvez Kayani, said Thursday that he would not tolerate a repeat of the American covert operation that killed Osama bin Laden, warning that any similar action would lead to a reconsideration of the relationship with the United States.

title: Syria Arrests Scores in House-to-House Roundup
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Syrian security forces raided a restive Damascus suburb on Thursday, going house to house and arresting scores of men in a broad campaign that activists and American officials say represents a new chapter in the crackdown on the countrys uprising against four decades of authoritarian rule.

title: In General, Dont Generalize About Breeding
description: Bruno De Julio has been a workout analyst and thoroughbred owner for the past 20 years. He is the author of Bruno on Workouts: Exposing the Mystery and can be found daily at Racing With Bruno and Grade One Racing.

title: 100 Restaurant Rules Reconsidered
description: Southfork Kitchen has been open for almost six months. Sussing out a summer season that looms large, I thought it might be instructive to a look at my 100 rules to see which ones were pie-in-the-sky and which ones still hold water, which ones were idealistic foam and which ones have stood up to the reality of Saturday nights.

title: European Central Banks Stand Pat on Rates
description: FRANKFURT  The European Central Bank left its benchmark interest rate unchanged Thursday, and signaled that it would probably wait until July before it made another move.

title: Obama Blocks Release of Graphic Photos for Second Time
description: Twice since assuming office, President Obama has been confronted with the question of whether to release grisly photographs depicting the results of American actions overseas.

title: Linda Ronstadt, First Lady of California
description: In this weekends magazine, the New York Times reporter Adam Nagourney writes about Gov. Jerry Brown as he wrestles with Californias budget. Linda Ronstadt makes a cameo appearance as Browns former girlfriend. But for me, Ronstadt is always the main event. Seeing her perform in her Cub Scouts uniform at Pine Knob outside Detroit in the late 1970s (or early 80s; its a bit hazy) was a formative experience. With a few not-inconceivable twists of fate, its possible (at least to me) to imagine Brown as president and Ronstadt as first lady. That this didnt happen might have marked the moment when things started to go wrong. Or maybe that was when Johnny Carson retired. Anyway, this clip of My Boyfriends Back (date uncertain but probably filmed sometime during the campaign for the 1980 Democratic nomination) gives a hint of what we missed.

title: Gap Dismisses Design Chief as Brands Slow Sales Persist
description: Gap announced on Thursday that it had dismissed its star designer, Patrick Robinson, in an acknowledgement that its problems run deeper than the company had previously indicated.

title: G.M. Reports Earnings Tripled in First Quarter, as Revenue Jumped 15%
description: DETROIT  It wasnt long ago that a first-quarter profit of $3.2 billion would have been cause for a major celebration at General Motors.

title: Morning Buzz | Help in Finding One Name in 2,982
description: Thursday will be partly cloudy and warmer than Wednesday, with highs reaching the upper 60s.

title: This Germ of an Idea Calls for an Antibiotic
description: THE preview at MoMA calculated to ignite euphoric Oscar buzz over the studios new $60 million comedy ended and the lights came up, revealing an audience of 400, stiff, with eyes shut, bringing to mind what it must have been like when outsiders first stumbled upon Jonestown. As the local opinion makers revived and shuffled through the exits, I bumped into Philo Cubbage, a schmendrick I knew from the periphery of show business who surfaced intermittently over the years with some fresh scheme for achieving bankruptcy. After the customary exchange of insincere remarks about how neither of us had aged, we agreed to masticate a pair of sirloins and repaired to Upchucks, where we could dine and disembowel the film wed seen at leisure.

title: Thursday Reading: G.M. Recalls Chevy Cruze
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

description: ROME  The United States announced Thursday that it would try to release some of the more than $30 billion in assets seized from Libyas leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, as international officials said they would create a fund to give money directly to the Libyan rebels.

title: Notes From the Underground | Cansei de Ser Sexy
description: The Brazilian pop band Cansei de Ser Sexy (CSS) kicked off its current American tour with a star turn at Coachella, then stepped off the stage and went straight to Pomona, Calif., and an all-ages show at the Glass House the following night. Fans mobbed the barricades to get a closer look at the lead singer, Lovefoxxx (pictured here). Dressed in a sequined bolero ensemble and Doc Martens boots, she turned cartwheels and surfed the crowd. The audience read like a throng of exultant misfits, gathered to hail their beloved leaders. Lovefoxxx gave a shout-out to someone watching that night, who had written the band an e-mail explaining how they had inspired him to come out and be honest about who he was with his family and friends, and later she brought several teenage girls to the stage to dance alongside her. CSS will perform three nights in New York City in May.

description: On Thursday, as new details about the killing of Osama Bin Laden continue to emerge, and the debate about the legality and ethics of the operation intensifies, The Lede provides updates.

title: Asked & Answered | Flavin Judd
description: When Donald Judd died in 1994, he had a couple thousand dollars in the bank but was millions of dollars in debt. The task of sorting out his estate was left to his two children, Rainer and Flavin, who persevered against what many considered insurmountable odds, resulting in the creation of the now seemingly solid Judd Foundation. Judds daughter, Rainer, is the president of the board of the foundation and the more public of the two while his son, Flavin, is vice president (but referred to himself as the curatorial consultant). Despite being very involved in the day-to-day running of the foundation, he remains relatively out of the public eye. T recently caught up with Flavin Judd, who was in town to oversee the installation of a major exhibit of his fathers work at David Zwirner gallery. Donald Judd, which opens on Friday, features nine aluminum boxes originally shown in a 1989 exhibition at Staatliche Kunsthalle Baden-Baden. It is the first time since that such a large number pieces from that show have been installed in one place.

title: Poetry Pairing | May 5, 2011
description: In our weekly Poetry Pairing series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poems themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

title: Have Golden Locks, Seeking Hammer
description: As I stumbled out of the Imax multiplex all-media advance screening of Thor, depositing my 3-D glasses in the appropriate bin, I thought of seeking shelter: in a nearby bar; under a passing bus; in the velvet shadows of an art house playing the longest, slowest, most obscure movie imaginable. But when something like Thor comes to town, there is really no refuge to be found in drink, death or subtitles, and so I tried to reason myself out of the leaden gloom that lay upon my soul as heavy as Mjolnir. (Thats Thors magic hammer, for those not versed in Marvelized Norse mythology.)

description: Retailers expected a good April, and they got it.

title: Thousands of Afghans Rally in Kabul to Reject Any Peace With Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  More than 10,000 people gathered Thursday in Kabul to oppose reconciliation with the Taliban and the involvement of Pakistan in any peace deal, warning that it would be a betrayal of the Afghan peoples long fight against extremism.

Built for the 1950 World Cup and at the time the largest stadium in the world, it became an instant national landmark, a symbol of Brazils soccer-centric culture.

title: Another Capitals Exit
description: Even if you are not a Washington Capitals fan, please feel free to boo them. It may seem unfair  and a little weird if youre nowhere near Washington and, say, in a business meeting  but go ahead anyway. The Capitals are more than a No. 1 seed bounced from the Stanley Cup playoffs in a gruesome second-round sweep, they are a four-year story of promise gone haywire. They boast a handful of the games most exhilarating players  Alex Ovechkin, Alexander Semin, Nicklas Backstrom and Mike Green  who treat the big stage of the playoffs like children being forced to eat overcooked cabbage.

title: My First Afghan Burqa
description: Alissa J. Rubin is the bureau chief of The New York Times in Kabul.

title: House Tour: Westport, Conn.
On Birds, Twitter and Teaching
description: Now that Im spending more time in classrooms than the newsroom, I often face students displaying a peculiar kind of bifocal gaze divided between the front of the room and the laptop screen. So I know about the frustrations of teachers in trying to engage students in the real world even as theyre buffeted with digital information.

title: Use at Own Risk: a Derby-Winning Breeder Handicaps the Derby
description: Like most veteran horse racing handicappers privileged to inside information, I have been loath to disclose the secrets of my selection process, honed over 20 years of betting on the Kentucky Derby, and that could prove highly valuable to anyone planning to bet this coming Saturday.

title: Cuisine Art | Subodh Gupta at Hauser & Wirth
description: Every morning, the the gallery staff at Hauser & Wirth on the Upper East Side must top off a glass of water that sits on a bare wooden table under a glass display box. A Glass of Water, as the work is appropriately titled, is by the artist Subodh Gupta, whose show, by the same name, opens today. If guests drinks a glass of water offered at another persons home, it means theyve taken the reception, said Gupta, explaining its significance in his native India. And yet, there is something inhospitable here. The found stainless steel vessel is filled to that delicate point where the liquid threatens to spill over on to the table. Gupta  who has been called the Damien Hirst of India  is thrilled by its dynamics: the beauty in that delicate curvature of the water and the precipice of something almost, but not quite, being pushed over the edge.

title: Password Service Warns of Possible Hacking Attack
description: 5:28 p.m. | Updated  Adding more background and information from interview with the companys chief executive.

title: American Idol Top 5: Competition Triumph or Career Success?
description: Scotty McCreery > Lauren Alaina > Haley Reinhart > Jacob Lusk > James Durbin

title: Thinking Through Assassination
description: Amid the jubilation surrounding Osama bin Ladens death on Monday, which followed closely on the heels of an apparent attempt to take out Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in an air strike, its difficult to remember a time when assassination was a dirty word in this country. But it was, and not so long ago. Before the practice becomes a bad habit, we might want to heed the counsel of the past.

title: Panic Comes to Hockeytown
description: Its time for panic in Hockeytown, as the Detroit Red Wings have been pushed to the brink of elimination, possibly culminating in a sweep Friday, at the hands of the potent San Jose Sharks.

title: Dissecting This Weeks Oil Price Tumble
description: Theres a saying in the oil business: The best cure for high oil prices is high oil prices. In other words, when prices are high, consumers are supposed to buy less at the pump and oil companies are supposed to produce more because it is more profitable to do so.

title: Once Feared Egypt Official Gets 12 Years and Fine
description: CAIRO  An Egyptian court sentenced the once feared former interior minister, Habib el-Adly, to 12 years in prison on Thursday and fined him about $4 million, setting a template for a series of high-profile corruption trials of senior figures in the government of the ousted president, Hosni Mubarak, that could include Mr. Mubarak himself.

title: Hamas Leader Calls for Two-State Solution, but Refuses to Renounce Violence
description: CAIRO  One day after celebrating a landmark reconciliation accord for Palestinian unity, Khaled Meshal, the Hamas leader, said on Thursday that he was fully committed to working for a two-state solution but declined to swear off violence or agree that a Palestinian state would produce an end to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

title: Warner Music Suitors Record of Deal-Making
description: Len Blavatnik, the Russian-born billionaire who is nearing an acquisition of the Warner Music Group, is well known for his investing prowess.

title: Jason Bay Returns to Mets After Birth of Third Child
description: After missing two games on paternity leave the Mets outfielder Jason Bay returned to the team for Thursdays afternoon game against the Giants sounding a bit fatigued.

title: The Ultimate Kentucky Derby
description: What if Big Brown, Smarty Jones, Barbaro and Monarchos all ran in the same Kentucky Derby? While were at it, what if every Derby winner from the past 20 years were put in the same starting gate?

title: Judith McGrath, Chief of MTV, Resigns
description: MTV Networks announced Thursday that its chairman and chief executive, Judy McGrath, was resigning. The surprising change at the top comes at a time when MTV is riding a surge in both ratings for its programs and profits for its parent company, Viacom.

title: Random House Buys Digital Agency
description: Random House has acquired Smashing Ideas, a digital media agency, in an effort to strengthen its digital publishing side, the publisher said on Thursday.

description: The Times's Adam Nagourney talks about covering Jerry Brown.

title: Recollections of 9/11 and Lehman
description: Guy Kulman is the president and founder of Bay Island Capital. From 2001 to 2008, Mr. Kulman worked at Lehman Brothers, most recently as a vice president for the firms chief legal officer and vice chairman.

title: Naked for 72 Years, a Bugatti Gets Fitted for a Suit
description: In 1939, shortly before his death in a track accident, Jean Bugatti, the son of Ettore Bugatti, who founded the car-manufacturing company that bears his name, designed and built a chassis for the Type 64, which was intended to succeed the legendary Type 57. But World War II and a fathers grief intervened.

title: Republican Debate Notable for No-Shows
description: Tim Pawlenty, the former governor of Minnesota, took a swipe at his potential rivals for the Republican presidential nomination on Thursday, calling them out for skipping the first debate of the 2012 campaign.

title: Op-Eds About Osama bin Laden
description: A sampling of Op-Eds about Osama bin Laden shows how perceptions of the man evolved as he transformed from an obscure fundamentalist to the embodiment of global terrorism and hatred for the United States.

title: Why She Went
description: Janny Scotts article (The Young Mother Abroad) about Ann Dunham resonated with me as an American parent who years ago took a small child to live in Southeast Asia. It resonated even more with me as a high-school principal. I have observed that parents who teach their children compassion often forget to teach them resilience, and those who teach their children to stop being wimpy often do so with an admonition that the world is a mean place in which they will have to be tough to compete. Ann Dunhams insistence on both idealism and strength is a model for creating useful adults and perhaps even presidents.EMILY H. JONESPutney, Vt., e-mail

title: Thelma and Louise vs. Pretty Woman
description: Where do these two movies, the subject of Carina Chocanos Riff column, put men? Either our value is reduced to how much is in our bank accounts, so that we can buy love and a beautiful woman, or we are threatened by a woman who thinks for herself and has her own opinions and desires. What about a guy that doesnt make a lot of money and loves strong, independent women and is loved back? Where is our cultural trope?

description: Representative Mike Pence announced Thursday that he would run for governor of Indiana in 2012.

description: If New York City subway lines were students, the cleanliness report card issued Thursday by the Straphangers Campaigns annual schmutz survey, which tracks subway car cleanliness, would get one quarter of the citys subway lines into serious trouble with their parents.

Republican hopefuls like Newt Gingrich, Mike Huckabee and Michele Bachmann are seeking Barton out for advice. Barton also figured in a 2010 magazine cover story in which Russell Shorto examined the movement of conservative Christian activists trying to influence how history is taught in Texas public schools.Shorto wrote this about Bartons role at the time:

title: Executive Director of American Folk Art Museum to Step Down
description: The executive director of the financially struggling American Folk Art Museum in Manhattan is stepping down in July, Bloomberg reported. In a statement on the museums Web site, the director, Maria Ann Conelli, said that she was leaving the museum after six years to take a job in academia. A spokesman for the museum, Fred Schroeder, said he was not at liberty to name her future employer.

description: People pitch me on new apps all the time, but Al Gore doesnt do it that often. In fact, only once  last week.

description: Will you be spending Mothers Day with your mother? If not, will you be giving her a call?

title: Fox, With Idol, Leads the Pack
description: The last five finalists faced off on American Idol on Wednesday night as 20.6 million viewers tuned in to the 90-minute episode of the Fox reality show, according to Nielsens estimates. Fox led the night over all by a wide margin even as its 9:30 p.m. sitcom, Breaking In, drew a much more modest audience of 7.3 million viewers.

title: Caribbean Summer Deals, Better Than Ever
description: The Caribbean is a staple winter destination for travelers looking for a warm weather getaway, but through the summer and fall, the threat of rain and hurricanes can mean fewer visitors and dramatically lower prices at many upscale properties. This year, however, some luxury hotels are offering even better deals than the 2010 low season. Here are four where an off-peak stay costs less than it did last year.

title: Calling the Derby: My Dream, My Challenge
description: Larry Collmus, the announcer at Monmouth Park, will call his first Kentucky Derby for NBC on Saturday.

title: Its All About My Mother
description: Whenever I see my mother (which I do as little as possible), we fall into a terrible rut. She asks me a question. I get out a few words of reply. Then she interrupts me and starts talking about herself. This makes me feel much worse than you would think. I havent brought it up with her because she doesnt take criticism well, and I dont feel like defending myself. I know I should see her on Mothers Day, but I really dont want to. Any advice?

In this lesson, students participate in a Socratic seminar to consider questions of truth and fiction in memoir raised by allegations about the veracity of Greg Mortensons Three Cups of Tea. They also write their own six-word memoirs.

description: JERUSALEM  Most flights out of Israels international airport were grounded Thursday as a safety precaution after the airports fuel supply was found to be tainted, Israeli officials said.

title: Theater Talkback: Tony Kushner and the Art of Empathy

But I was deeply saddened to read of the City University of New Yorks initial decision, now being reconsidered, to rescind an honorary degree for Mr. Kushner, after a trustee at CUNY said the playwright had made disparaging remarks about the State of Israel, particularly in regard to Israels policy toward Palestinians.

description: At Artopolis Cafe in Astoria, Queens, a whiff of cinnamon, a basket of Greek pastries and a passion for cookies.

title: The Pastries and Aromas of Greece
description: IT all started with a sweet, cinnamon-tinted whiff. The subway roaring above, I crossed the street and followed my curiosity to the Greek bakery tucked in the corner of a shopping complex in Astoria, Queens. That afternoon, the first of my many visits to Artopolis Bakery, on 31st Street and 23rd Avenue, there were bohemians, families pushing strollers, and old men in black suits lined up against the counter or crowded at the few wrought-iron tables, dunking cookies in the darkest coffee Id ever seen.

title: Flashing Yellow
description: A few readers have asked what I make of recent economic indicators. The answer is, nothing good.

title: No Plans to Split CVS Caremark, Chief Says
description: The new chief executive of CVS Caremark said on Thursday that there are no plans to split up the company.

title: Whats the Holdup in the Stanford Case?
description: As the $7 billion fraud case against the jailed Texas financier R. Allen Stanford drags on, a whistle-blower says he is concerned about the possibility of a cover-up by the government. In this video interview, CNBC speaks to a former Stanford employee, Charlie Rawl, about the case and the information that he has.

title: Body in Jet Wreckage Is Retrieved From Sea Bottom
description: PARIS  An underwater salvage team on Thursday began the grisly task of recovering the remains of the victims of an Air France jet that crashed in the Atlantic two years ago, retrieving the first of possibly dozens of bodies from the wreckage as experts gather evidence that they hope will shed more light on what happened in the flights final moments.

title: Now Recalling | Imagined Nostalgia
description: I wanted to create objects from a childhood that I never experienced firsthand, Lucien Smith says, explaining the background of Imagined Nostalgia, which opens May 6 at 41 Cooper Gallery. The show is a collaboration between Smith, 22, and Jack Siegel, 24, who shared studio space at Cooper Union (where Smith is enrolled and set to graduate this month). The work is based on how our imaginations create false memories of what actually happened in the past  how we remember something from the past and embellish it to make it seem worse or better, larger than life, different. Highlights include yearbook-style photographs from familiar New York faces like the filmmaker Austin Peters and the artist Brenden Lynch.

title: Scratch Uncle Mo
description: It is only three days before the Kentucky Derby and Uncle Mo, the 2-year-old champion who had his only defeat as the 1-10 favorite in the Wood Memorial, is only 50-50 to start in the Kentucky Derby.

title: Just After Spider-Man Reopens, Taymor To Deliver Theater Conference Keynote
description: Julie Taymor, the ousted director of Broadways Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, will deliver a keynote speech at a major theater conference in Los Angeles on June 18, four days after the $70 million musical is scheduled to have its long-delayed opening night in New York. Ms. Taymor will also speak that Saturday at a panel session, titled A Directors Life, during the annual conference of Theater Communications Group, a national organization of nearly 700 nonprofit theaters and affiliated groups.

description: May 5, 2011 - President Obama honors 9/11 victims; the Times photographer Doug Mills recalls being at ground zero in 2001; and social scientists explain the celebratory reaction to Bin Laden's death.

title: Yes, This Is Made of Celery
description: You might think it bizarre: celery sorbet with a little dressed celery salad; goat-cheese-mousse balls coated with olive-oil-sauted bread crumbs; macerated figs with balsamic vinegar. And those things go together on a plate.

title: Emotional Video Fights Distracted Driving
description: The latest public service announcement warning against distracted driving has an interesting twist: it presupposes that people know about the dangers of multitasking behind the wheel. Instead, it illustrates the emotional toll for those who are affected by an accident caused by a person texting or talking on a phone.

title: Commission Asks Congress to Support a Smithsonian American Latino Museum
description: A presidential commission called on Congress to establish a Smithsonian American Latino Museum at the Capitol on Thursday morning during a news conference attended by proponents of the project. In a report submitted this week to President Obama and Congress, the commission said that it would cost $600 million to build and open the museum, adding that half of the money could be raised privately. In deference to current budget conditions, the commission said that no federal financing would be needed for six years. Congress established the panel, the National Museum of the American Latino Commission, in 2008.

description: The gray seal on the beach in upper Manhattan is a she.

title: Global Warming Reduces Expected Yields of Harvests in Some Countries, Study Says
description: Global warming is already cutting substantially into potential crop yields in some countries  to such an extent that it may be a factor in the food price increases that have caused worldwide stress in recent years, researchers suggest in a new study.

title: Bill Clinton Urges Albany to Legalize Gay Marriage
description: ALBANY  Bill Clinton, who as president signed legislation prohibiting federal recognition of same-sex marriages but has in recent years become a supporter of them, called on Thursday for New York State lawmakers to pass a measure allowing gay couples to wed.

description: DETROIT  The second time Alex Rodriguez came to Eduardo Nunezs aid Thursday afternoon came in a hushed clubhouse, after spotting a crowd of reporters waiting at his locker. Rodriguez asked if Nunez preferred speaking through a translator, and Nunez said in Spanish that he did.

title: House Passes a Bill to Expand Offshore Oil Drilling
description: WASHINGTON  With rising gasoline prices and skyrocketing oil company profits as a backdrop, the House approved a bill on Thursday to force the Obama administration to accelerate oil lease sales in the Gulf of Mexico and off the coast of Virginia.

title: 36 Hours in Detroit
description: DESPITE recent news stories of a population exodus from Detroit, there are many reasons to make a pilgrimage to this struggling city right now  and not just because Eminems slick Super Bowl commercial showcased the inner strength of the Motor City. No video can portray the passion one finds on the streets of Detroit these days, where everyone from the doorman to the D.J. will tell you they believe in this citys future. While certain areas are indeed eerily empty, other neighborhoods  including midtown, downtown and Corktown  are bustling with new businesses that range from creperies and barbecue joints catering to the young artists and entrepreneurs migrating to Motown, to a just-opened hostel that invites tourists to explore Detroit with the aid of local volunteer guides. In the historic Brush Park district, architecture buffs will find some lovely refurbished houses, and along Woodward Avenue, restored film palaces are a wonderful reminder that this citys storied past includes not just automobiles, but also the entertainment industry. No urban enthusiast will want to miss the recovery that Detroit is now attempting.

description: The Leopold Museum in Vienna is selling one painting by Egon Schiele to pay for another.

title: Pentagon Breaks Silence on Pakistani Role
description: WASHINGTON  A top Pentagon official said Thursday that Obama administration officials do not have any definitive evidence at this point that Pakistan knew that Osama bin Laden was living in a compound in a garrison city only 35 miles from Islamabad, but she said that Pakistan would have to work hard to rebuild relations with the United States Congress.

description: The chef Dan Silverman integrates Spanish, French and Italian ideas at the restaurant that has opened beneath the High Line at the Standard Hotel.
