description: 11:27 a.m. | Updated If you are confused about todays jobs report  job growth was up in April, but so was the unemployment rate  the chart below may help.

title: Lost in the School Choice Maze
description: ON the last day in March, when most eighth graders in New York City learned where they would be going to high school in the fall, Radcliffe Saddler watched the majority of his classmates rip open thin envelopes and celebrate.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Fervor Roils Markets as Companies Beat a Path to Go Public | Companies are lining up to go public. Market conditions are favorable. Investor appetite is strong.

title: A More Normal Job Market?
description: On the surface, the jobs report today was as confused as ever. The household survey looked bad (the unemployment rate went up) and the employer survey looked good (the economy added 268,000 private sector jobs in April). More private-sector jobs  760,000  have been gained over the last three months than over any comparable period in five years.

title: Romanian Cinema Rising
description: A. O. Scott on the new wave of Romanian cinema.

title: A Midwestern Familys Withered Roots
description: About a third of the way into The Year We Left Home, Jean Thompsons 10th book of fiction, the Erickson family of Grenada, Iowa, attends  along with much of the town  the funeral of a beloved great aunt. Torrie, the Ericksons 17-year-old daughter, arrives late to the church, an offense she knows will strain her already volatile relations with her mother; by the time she gets there, the only empty seats are up in the choir loft. From that height, as the pastor delivers the eulogy, she can see her family in the pews below, angry and worried over her seeming absence, but they cannot see her:

title: Fracture on Fracking
description: Secretary of Energy Steven Chu has appointed a panel of seven scientific and environmental worthies to study the rapidly growing method of natural gas extraction known as hydraulic fracturing and to make recommendations about how it can be done more cleanly and more safely.

title: May 2011
description: The latest images after Western intervention in Libya.

title: Lessons From a Sleeping Baby
description: My older son slept through the night at three weeks. I thought I was a remarkable mother. My younger son, we joke, still hasnt slept a normal night. Hes 17. So much for sleep as a measure of my parenting skills.

title: A Little Less Suburban, Please
description: ALDONA DAUKANTAS grew up in the 1960s as one of five siblings in an apartment beneath the elevated J line near the Woodhaven Boulevard Station in Queens. She was a subway student at City College, where she studied art.

title: Laurie Zucker
description: Ms. Zucker, 55, is the vice chairwoman of the Zucker Organization, a development company, which with its management firm, Manhattan Skyline, owns and operates about 3,000 apartments in the New York area. The latest developments include Love Lane Mews in Brooklyn Heights and the Story House in the Flatiron district. The company was started by Ms. Zuckers father, Donald.

title: Paris, With Hot Sauce
description: In a city dominated by coq au vin and rillettes, authentic Mexican food  let alone a good margarita  has been hard to come by. Now there is Candelaria, Pariss first real taqueria, which recently opened in the Marais. The galley-size kitchen, helmed by the Mexican chef Luis Rendon, is buffered by a five-seat counter and a communal table. The seasonal menu, listed on a jagged blackboard, currently includes dishes like rajas con queso (tacos with sauted green peppers, onions and melted cheese), totopos (chips) with zesty guacamole and longaniza (spicy pork) or pollo pibil (stewed chicken) tostados dressed with shredded red cabbage. The crisp tortillas are made in-house with meseca imported from Spain. Spicy sauces are on hand  and thankfully so are Mexican beers, bubbly fluorescent Jarritos sodas and hibiscus juice. Theres no wine or coffee  positively heresy in Paris  but here nothing has been compromised for a French palate, insists Carina Soto Velasquez, who founded the restaurant with Adam Tsou and Joshua Fontaine. And about those margaritas? Hidden behind a mural-covered door in the back is a cocktail bar whose alcoholic arsenal includes well-aged tequilas, organic mezcal, rare rums and a curated drink selection with contributions from international bartender aficionados. (One is from the provenance of the East Villages Death & Co.) Assorted young artists helped supply the dcor, including Adrian Rubi-Dentzel, who repurposed the spaces original floor into the bar, and Confetti System, whose shimmering pendant adds a nice flourish.

title: Nurse, I Think I Have Derby Fever
5 Answers from the Jobs Report
description: Yesterday, I posed five questions about this mornings jobs report. Here are some answers:

title: Japan Asks Another Nuclear Plant to Shut Down Its Reactors
description: TOKYO  Prime Minister Naoto Kan said Friday that he had asked the Hamaoka nuclear power plant in central Japan to close until it could build stronger defenses against earthquakes and tsunamis. Nuclear safety activists have long warned that the aging plant, built along the coast in an area laced with known fault lines, should be closed.

title: Friedrich A. Hayek, Big-Government Skeptic
description: The publication of the definitive edition of Friedrich A. Hayeks Constitution of Liberty coincides with the unexpected best-seller status of his earlier book The Road to Serfdom as a result of its promotion by the conservative talk-show host Glenn Beck. In an age when many on the right are worried that the Obama administrations reform of health care is leading us toward socialism, Hayeks warnings from the mid-20th century about societys slide toward despotism, and his principled defense of a minimal state, have found strong political resonance.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Death and Afterlife on the Slopes
description: I am a first and last paragrapher. I never read a book until Ive taken some time to examine the beginning and the end. Allowing the frame to orient my gaze to the painting  thats how I think of it. Granted, the technique has its disadvantages: now and then I have bought books that decorated their borders with more artistry than their interiors, and occasionally the final lines of a story will contain some ruinous premature revelation. But knowing how a book arranges itself answers a few essential questions: What are its rhythms? What is its emotional tenor? Can I feel comfortable relinquishing myself to its authority? How will it go about removing me from and then reintroducing me to the trajectory of my life?

title: Dealing With Higher Costs of F.H.A. Loans
description: THE increased cost of F.H.A. mortgages has shifted the math a bit for would-be borrowers.

title: The Founding Fathers and Their Gardens
description: In 1961, when John F. Kennedy asked Rachel Lambert Mellon to design the Rose Garden at the White House, the commission established a strong link with Americas botanical past. And so, much more recently, has Michelle Obamas organic vegetable garden, elsewhere on the grounds. As Andrea Wulf reminds us in her illuminating and engrossing new book, Founding Gardeners, the first four presidents were passionate botanists whose country seats became laboratories for their grander vision of an independent agrarian republic in the New World.

title: Lukes Lobster Expands, With a Food Truck
description: The ever-expanding Lukes Lobster is taking to the streets, joining the army of food trucks with a vehicle of their own. Theyre having their debut on Sunday at the Hells Kitchen Flea Market Gourmet Food Truck Bazaar and will be serving the lunch crowds starting Monday.

title: Mohamed ElBaradei, the Inspector
description: The Nobel laureate Mohamed ElBaradei has stated his intention to nominate myself to be president of Egypt, but this memoir will not improve his election prospects. In personal terms, its hard to imagine anything less thrilling to Egypts street revolutionaries than ElBaradeis accounts of his meals (The food was very basic, with few choices: noodles, meat and kimchi; no fruit or salad) and accommodations (a worn, drab-colored suite consisting of a bedroom and a salon) in places like North Korea. Nor will his fellow Egyptians be much intrigued by the details of his battles against nuclear proliferators. At the moment, the protestors have other priorities.

title: In Jersey Shore Subset, Top-Heavy With Pricey Homes
description: WHEN a newly built house beside the beach in Sea Girt went into contract for $3.6 million last month, it was sort of a good news-bad news occurrence, in the eyes of real estate brokers and agents.

title: Hope at the High End of the Market
description: CONNECTICUTS housing market went into hibernation during the first quarter of 2011 as sales took a dive and prices continued to deteriorate.

title: French Chteau Will be Sold at Auction
description: Upper Brookville

title: A Stop the Presses Moment: More on the Death of Bin Laden
description: The New York Times does not literally stop the presses often, but on Sunday night, after President Obama announced the death of Osama bin Laden, it did.

title: Q & A
description: Casting a Vote by Cellphone

title: With Pops of Color
description: When not chasing down her 3-, 5- and 7-year-olds, Patricia Lansing, at 37 the youngest of the designer Carolina Herreras four daughters, works as a creative consultant for her mothers line and for the Go Project, a charity serving low-income students. BEE-SHYUAN CHANG

title: Worries About Convenience Casinos in Florida
description: APOPKA, Fla.  A drab strip mall in this city north of Orlando includes the usual fixtures: a pharmacy and a payday loans store, as well as an Internet cafe with a sign on the door that reads Copy-Fax-Print, Surf the Web.

title: Dumbo's Next Chapter
description: In recent years, debates about the neighborhoods future have led to the designation of a city historic district and a rezoning of the eastern end designed in part to encourage residential growth.

title: The Jury Is Still Out
description: In the last week Ive been in the South of France for the Hyres Fashion Festival and in San Francisco to meet students at the Academy of Art University, with a stop in New York for the opening of the Alexander McQueen exhibition. What links these places is not just fashion, but the design process itself and how the ideas of designers evolve over time. That evolution is one of the pleasures of Andrew Boltons selections for the McQueen show, especially in the tailoring choices. It was inspiring to see how his cutting methods changed over his career, yet how certain assumptions remained fixed. One of the most rewarding and maddening of these assumptions is that design is a learning process. And McQueen always wanted to learn.

title: The Gangster Gets Rehabilitated
description: THERE is no questioning the sales success of the Chrysler 300 that swaggered into the full-size sedan market in 2004 like a mob underboss; some 650,000 were sold in the 2005-10 model years. The 300 was instrumental in keeping Chrysler in business through its dark days of drift, bankruptcy and reorganization.

title: Before the Roses, the Lilies for the Fillies
description: Todd Schrupp is an American television personality who works for TVG Network.

title: Bringing Up Dumbo
description: THE freight train tracks that snake along Jay Street on the Brooklyn waterfront were laid down in 1904, to carry coffee beans and other cargo from docks to warehouses. Freight service shut down in 1959, decades before anyone dreamed of calling the area Dumbo. It was the end of an era in a neighborhood where eras come and go with increasing speed.

title: Jaguar C-X75: Belle of the Paris Auto Show to Enter Production
description: At a press conference on Friday morning in London, Jaguar answered the question vexing hand-raisers for the Porsche 918 Spyder plug-in hybrid: is $845,000 too dear a price for a next-generation supercar?

title: A Psychoanalyst Runs Amok
description: In this uncertain world, of one thing we can be sure. It is never a good idea for a psychoanalyst to have sex with his patients.

title: May 7-8: This Weekends Top Global Matchups
description: The outstanding matchups in Europe and South America this weekend:

title: Comparing Recoveries: Job Changes
description: Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics. Chart by Amanda Cox. Horizontal axis shows months. Vertical axis shows the ratio of that months nonfarm payrolls to the nonfarm payrolls at the start of recession. Note: Because employment is a lagging indicator, the dates for these employment trends are not exactly synchronized with National Bureau of Economic Researchs official business cycle dates.

title: Appointment in Abbottabad
description: Reflecting on her own reactions to Osama Bin Ladens death, Megan McArdle excerpts a long quote from George Orwell, on the hollowness of revenge. The scene is post-war Germany, and Orwell is watching a German Jew abuse an imprisoned S.S. man:

title: Up Front: Michael Cunningham
description: In this issue, Michael Cunningham reviews Rikki Ducornets novel Netsuke, about a psychotherapist who compulsively has sex with his clients.

title: A Midsummer Nights Dream, Retold in San Francisco
description: Nature does not stop to grieve, an observation that since time began has either appalled or inspired the human beings who have made it. Poppies sprout in bloody battlefields, and birds sing outside death-room windows. On one hand, the big thing that just happened to you is insignificant to the rest of creation, and on the other, you are still part of a creation thats so much bigger than your loss.

title: Selling Books by Day, Writing Them by Night
description: Like all good independent bookstores, BookCourt in Brooklyn has a robust section of staff recommendations. There, nestled in with titles by Jennifer Egan, Haruki Murakami and David Foster Wallace, is Other People We Married, a collection of short stories by Emma Straub. A handwritten note taped to the wall below reads: I wrote this book. Please buy it. I love you.

title: The Departed
description: Maybe youve heard of him. Named after the foster father (Eddie the Butcher) who taught him his trade, and introduced almost 30 years ago by Thomas Perry in The Butchers Boy, this cold-blooded professional killer is one of the immortals of the genre. Michael Schaeffer, to give this antihero his current alias, seemed a bit mechanical when he briefly came out of retirement two decades ago in Sleeping Dogs, but he makes a great comeback in THE INFORMANT (Otto Penzler/Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $27)  older, wiser and deadlier.

title: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: Frequent Flier
description: Stuart Woods has had 10 books on the hardcover fiction list over the past three years. His Bel-Air Dead debuts at No. 3 this week.

title: Inside the List
description: BERNIE MADOFF, BOOK REVIEWER: The Wizard of Lies: Bernie Madoff and the Death of Trust, by the New York Times financial reporter Diana B. Henriques, enters the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 10 this week. Liaquat Ahamed, who reviews the book in our May 15 issue, calls it riveting reading, a vivid portrait of a sad, hapless man who, lacking the character to tell the truth at the critical moment, stumbled foolishly and blindly into one of the crimes of the century.

title: Editors Choice
description: THE TRAGEDY OF ARTHUR,  by Arthur Phillips (Random House, $26.) Phillipss splendidly devious novel consists of a Shakespearean play of his own virtuosic creation and an introduction that devastatingly reveals the psychological life of its author.

title: Paperback Row
description: OUR KIND OF TRAITOR,  by John le Carr (Penguin, $15.) Though set in the present, le Carrs latest thriller is steeped in cold war nostalgia. During a Caribbean vacation, an English couple find themselves caught up in a high-stakes espionage game with a Russian money-launderer looking to strike a deal with British intelligence in exchange for safe harbor.

title: Fie on Badness! Jeremy Irons to Play King Arthur for One Night
description: His sinister voice and unnerving gaze have guaranteed Jeremy Irons a career playing nefarious characters, but does he dream of playing a hero  even a once-great medieval king who is ditched by his wife for a newer and better model of knight? If so, Mr. Irons, a star of the Showtime series The Borgias (not to mention films like Reversal of Fortune and The Lion King) will get to fulfill that goal in a one-night concert production of Camelot for the Irish Repertory Theater, in which he will play King Arthur. Press representatives for the production, which will be presented on June 6 at the Shubert Theater, said on Friday that Mr. Irons will play Arthur, the Excalibur-wielding monarch, in the Lerner and Loewe musical. James Barbour and Melissa Errico will play Lancelot and Guenevere, reprising the roles they played in a 2005 production at the Hollywood Bowl. The Irish Rep concert production, which will be directed by Charlotte Moore, with musical direction by Mark Hartman, will be presented as a benefit for the theater, so be prepared to dig up a little more coin of the realm for tickets. Prices for individual seats are $100 to $300.

title: Bird Week | Whats Good for the Goose: Collies?
description: Dogs of every breed come to Prospect Park and bother the geese, but only Cleo, a black and white Border collie, is paid to do it. Her job is to save the geese by tormenting them.

title: Going Crackers for Homemade Crackers
description: In this weeks Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman explains why even the simple cracker can be improved in the home kitchen.

title: Canucks Green Men Playfully Invade Playoffs
description: It appears you cant keep good Green Men down, even with edicts in place from the N.H.L.s powers-that-be.

title: What Do You Mean We, White Man? Deficit Edition
description: Whenever I read pieces like David Brookss column this morning  pieces that attribute our budget deficits to the publics irresponsibility and lack of realism  I find myself wondering how so much recent history went down the memory hole.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Starting Friday and open daily through June 9 from 11 a.m. to 9 p.m. is Mad. Sq. Eats at Worth Square in Madison Square Park, near Fifth Avenue and 24th Street. The list of eateries participating include Goat Town, Asia Dog, Momofuku Milk Bar, Hong Kong Street Cart, Robertas Pizza, the P&H Soda Company, Cookie Panache and Eataly.

title: Fisher Behavior
description: A camera trap video of fishers interacting with a plastic flamingo doused with orange scent. The difference in the behavior of different fishers may reflect bold or shy personalities of individuals.

title: The Land of the $800 Stroller
description: ON Sept. 11, 2001, TriBeCa, the Lower Manhattan loft district two blocks north of the World Trade Center, shook. Much of the neighborhood saw one if not both hijacked airliners fly into the twin towers. Residents watched aghast as bodies and then the buildings themselves crashed to earth. Clouds of ash descended on the streets as if in some macabre snowstorm.

title: Dispatch | The Hyres Festival of Fashion and Photography
description: While most style watchers spent last weekend glued to the nearest television awaiting Kate Middletons wedding dress, a crowd of fashion devotees gathered in the South of France for a different sort of unveiling: the winners of the 26th Hyres Festival of Fashion and Photography.

title: Jobs Report: The Age of Diminished Expectations
description: Better than most people, myself included, expected. So good news, definitely.

title: The Scientific Revolt Against Death
description: The British philosopher and freewheeling intellectual John Gray is in serious danger of making philosophy exciting and fun to read. The Immortalization Commission opens with an 1874 sance attended by Charles Darwin, Francis Galton and George Eliot; a few pages later we are introduced to the Society for Psychical Research, which counted William James, Henri Bergson, John Ruskin, Alfred, Lord Tennyson and W. E. Gladstone among its members. The central concern driving the many supernatural investigations of these luminaries was the not inconsequential question of whether life exists after death.

title: Requesting the Royal Treatment
description: SUDDENLY trees are sprouting  and not only as proof that spring has finally arrived. Credit the recent royal wedding and the couples decision to line the aisle in Westminster Abbey with English field maples and hornbeams.

title: Palantir Valued at $2.5 Billion or More
description: Palantir doesnt attract the same attention as its social media peers in Silicon Valley.

title: Tesla Prepares for a Gap as Roadster Winds Down
description: SAN FRANCISCO

title: Paul Allen: Microsoft and Me
description: Pity Paul Allen. All those billions, but Microsofts other founder doesnt receive the credit or respect he feels he deserves. Sure, those vast storehouses of cash Allen earned while he was still in his 20s have allowed him to buy a pair of big-name professional sports teams, the Seattle Seahawks and the Portland Trail Blazers. (He is also co-owner of a soccer team.) He can soothe his resentments riding the seas on a 414-foot yacht, tended to by a full-time crew of more than 50. The yacht holds a basketball court, a movie theater and a fully equipped recording studio, complete with killer ocean views, that has allowed him to rub shoulders with the fabulous  Mick Jagger, Bono, Paul McCartney and a long list of Page Six names that populate this memoir. One of the greatest creative minds in the world of technology, writes Pete Carroll, the coach of the Seahawks and therefore an Allen employee, in a blurb gracing the books back cover. Tellingly, no one remotely connected to the technology world echoes that sentiment.

title: The Kentucky Puzzle
description: For the casual sort of racing fan, and we mean those who have no idea that O.T.B. closed its doors, the Friday before the Kentucky Derby is the day to a) remember that theyre running the Kentucky Derby Saturday and b) figure out who on earth is in it.

title: Notes From a Young American in Congo: The Stigma of Rape
description: My father sent me the story about the CBS reporter Lara Logan, who survived a brutal sexual assault by a mob in Cairos Tahir Square in February. What hit me was not just the brutality of the attacks, but the redoubtable strength she showed by speaking out about potentially the most stigmatizing and painful experience a person can endure. Its no secret that survivors of sexual assault such as Ms. Logan often choose not to come forward, and its not difficult to see why.

title: What Shostakovich Was Really Expressing
description: First, before we turn our attention to Stalin, to Soviet-era dissidence and to debates about Dmitri Shostakovichs memoirs, listen. Try the Second String Quartet, from 1944, in which music can veer from somber melancholy to raucous jeers in just a few pages; or trace the coded allusions in the Eighth String Quartet, from 1960, in which the composer uses letters of his name to create a musical motif and invokes phrases from his earlier works that can drift like wisps of smoke; or stay focused through the otherworldly fugal opening of the last quartet, the 15th. Play it so that flies drop dead in midair, and the audience starts leaving the hall from sheer boredom, the composer told the players preparing its premiere in 1974.

title: And You Used to Think Hairballs Were Bad
description: What is the shortest measurable amount of time? Youd think the answer would involve advanced physics, something to do with some invisible force and nanoseconds. But no. Scientists now agree that the shortest measurable amount of time is the micro-instant between when a person first acquires a cat and when that person feels the need to use the phrase bad kitty.

title: Stories of Biracial America
description: Barack Obama makes two appearances in Danzy Sennas first story collection, You Are Free: in a photograph on an administrators desk at an exclusive preschool, and on the bumper sticker of a BMW. Seeing that BMW, the narrator of the story Replacement Theory observes, The election had come and gone, the blackish man was in charge, and the slogan on the bumper  Yes We Can  already had the feeling of some dusty, long-gone revolution.

title: Ron Paul Sees Fund-Raising Windfall on Debate Day
description: Representative Ron Paul of Texas has none of the typical attributes of a successful presidential candidate, except one: he can raise money.

title: A Memoir of Living Off the Grid
description: Melissa Colemans father, Eliot, once suggested that evidence points to the return to the land as a cyclical urge in history. Some families work the land out of necessity, while others seek the good life through labor and simplicity. In the 1840s, Thoreau took to the woods to live deliberately. During the Great Depression, self-sufficiency was raised to new importance, and well-educated men like the writer and editor Elliott Merrick and the economist Ralph Borsodi found homesteading a rational and intellectual pursuit. The political climate of the late 1960s (and later the energy crisis of the 70s) provoked back-to-the-land desires in many, including Eliot Coleman, who, inspired by Helen and Scott Nearings book Living the Good Life, moved in 1968 with his pregnant wife, Sue, to a remote 60-acre wood in coastal Maine. There, they developed sustainable, small-scale farming techniques that would help catalyze the organic movement.

title: Desk Guilt
description: ZABUL PROVINCE, Afghanistan  I deployed last June with the Second Stryker Cavalry Regiment from Vilseck, Germany, to an isolated combat outpost in a remote district of Afghanistans Zabul Province.

title: Weekend Competition: Define Wit
description: This weekend, Schotts Vocab is soliciting definitions of wit.

title: Getting a Taste of Oaks Day
description: 6:35 p.m. | Update  Plum Pretty, trained by Bob Baffert, held off St. Johns River to win the $1 million Kentucky Oaks. Her Smile finished 11th.

title: The First Debate of the 2012 Race
description: The Times's Jim Rutenberg and Megan Liberman discuss the first Republican presidential debate of 2012. Also, Adam Nagourney on Gov. Jerry Brown of California.

title: Fledgling Filmmaker Casts Against Type
description: DAN RUSH was at a restaurant in SoHo the other day, describing Will Ferrells face. Its a face from a different era, Mr. Rush said. Hes got strong features. Theres kind of a ruddiness. Theres man in it, you know?

title: A Star Turn for a Lady-in-Waiting
description: LONDON

title: Christina Norman Dismissed as Chief of OWN
description: 9:17 p.m. | Updated |  Dissatisfied by the first ratings report cards for OWN, Oprah Winfrey and her business partner, Discovery Communications, said on Friday that they had dismissed the four-month-old channels chief executive, Christina Norman.

title: After Bust in Ireland, Ordinary People Make Do With Less
description: DROGHEDA, Ireland  Brian and Rosie Condra grew up poor. But as prosperity washed over Ireland in the first decade of the 21st century, they managed to buy a modest house, start saving for their childrens future and, for once, do more than simply make ends meet.

title: Survey Suggests Employment Prospects for Arts Graduates Are About the Same as for Others
description: Prospective students who are wondering whether to major in business or art in this harsh economic climate might want to take a look at a survey of arts graduates. The Strategic National Arts Alumni Project based at Indiana University, which tracks the lives and careers of arts graduates, has recently released one. The results of the 2010 online survey include responses from more than 13,500 students who were in fine arts, theater, dance, music, creative writing, media arts, film, design and architecture programs and graduated in the past 15 or so years from 154 arts high schools, undergraduate and graduate institutions.

title: Eres, in the Swim of Things
description: From St. Tropez to Porto Cervo, Capri to Cannes, few brands are as at home in the worlds most glamorous settings as Eres  and come this weekend, the luxury swimwear house is setting up shop in Americas playground of the rich and fabulous, the Hamptons. In America, having stores in resort locations is a must, explains Eress swim and lingerie designer, Valerie Delafoss. But unlike the Eres boutiques in Palm Beach and Los Angeles, this latest venture, at 55 Main Street in East Hampton, will feature more beachy attire  ocean-blue maillots with a flirty tassel belts, color-blocked boy-short bikinis and cotton jersey wide-leg cover-up pants  than delicate lingerie. Our opinion? Either way, its a good excuse to go to the Hamptons!

title: The Perched, the Frothy, the Fascinator
description: NEVER has a hat stirred such a squall. Moments after the royal wedding, images of Princess Beatrices spiraling Band-Aid-hued headpiece had gone viral.

title: N.E.A. Advances Endorsement for Obama in 2012
description: The National Education Association took a major step on Friday toward becoming the first labor union to formally endorse President Obamas re-election bid, announcing that its political action committee approved a recommendation for the union to back Mr. Obama and for its 3.2 million members to vote for him.

title: Can a Water Plan Work Without an Environmental Goal?
description: We dont go anywhere. Going somewhere is for squares. We just go. Marlon Brando, The Wild One

title: A Never-Ending Lawsuit Turns 40
description: When he filed the lawsuit 40 years ago this month, Jethro M. Eisenstein could not have imagined it would have still been going on. Just around three years out of law school, he certainly did not envision that there would be a case that would span his entire legal career.

title: Hartenstein Takes Over at Tribune
description: After a six-month process the Tribune Company has announced the appointment of a new president and chief executive.

title: A Recovery Less Robust Than in the 70s
description: TO judge by the stock market, the recovery from the Great Recession is much stronger than the one after the early 1970s recession, which followed the first oil price shock.

title: How Well Did Warner Musics Investors Do?
description: The sale of the Warner Music Group is music to the ears of its controlling investors.

title: Our Derby Picks, From the Sideline
description: The Rails contributors welcome this years Kentucky Derby guest picker, the Louisville mens basketball coach, Rick Pitino. He knows a thing or two about sports in Kentucky, having led the rival Wildcats to the national championship in 1996. He has also owned two horses who have run in the Derby.

title: Jaguar Supercar Is Coming, but Where Is the BMW 3 Series Fighter?
description: Jaguars announcement that it would build the C-X75 hybrid supercar in an edition of 250, each priced in excess of $1 million, overshadows a more pressing matter facing the company.

title: Drive for Palestinian Unity Exposes Fractured Society
description: HEBRON, West Bank  Louai Faisal, 27, a Palestinian resident of this West Bank city long considered a Hamas stronghold, has spent three periods in Israeli prisons, starting in 2003 when he was sentenced to two and a half years as a would-be suicide bomber for Hamas.

title: Metropolitan Preview | Trapped in the Admissions Maze
description: High school in New York City is a time of intense competition, confusion and stress  and that is only the admissions process for eighth graders.

title: Delta Starts Tracking Bags
description: Delta Airlines has begun a system that allows its passengers to track their bags after theyve been checked in, the carrier announced recently.

title: With Levine Leaving, Boston Symphony Announces Plans for Next Season
description: Lacking a music director because of James Levines announcement in March that he is resigning as of Sept. 1, the Boston Symphony Orchestra announced its cobbled-together plans for next season, including Mr. Levines replacements for concerts at Carnegie Hall and a California tour in December. Kurt Masur, Christoph Eschenbach and Stphane Denve will lead the orchestra for the March 6-9 Carnegie stand and Ludovic Morlot  a former assistant conductor in Boston and the incoming music director of the Seattle Symphony  will take over the California trip.

title: BP Offers Plan to Salvage Its Swap Deal With Rosneft
description: LONDON  The oil giant BP made a crucial concession on Friday in an attempt to salvage a share-swap agreement with Rosneft, the Russian state-controlled oil company.

title: Boehner Picks Jesuit Priest to Be House Chaplain
description: House Speaker John A. Boehner will nominate the Rev. Patrick J. Conroy, a Jesuit priest and former Georgetown University chaplain, to become the 60th House chaplain.

title: Goblin': the Early (and Illegal) Reviews
description: Goblin, the hotly anticipated album by Tyler, the Creator, leader of the Odd Future Wolf Gang Kill Them All hip-hop collective, is no longer hotly anticipated by many Odd Future fans.

title: Schools Chief Plays Peacemaker
description: When a fight broke out between two reporters in the rotunda of City Hall on Friday, nobody seemed quite sure what to do. Enter Dennis M. Walcott, schools chancellor, peacemaker and former kindergarten teacher.

title: Video of Syrias Friday of Defiance
description: As my colleague Anthony Shadid reports from Beirut, Lebanon, Thousands of protesters gathered after noon prayers in dozens of towns and cities across Syria in what activists declared a Friday of Defiance, despite the governments deployment of security and military forces in the most restive regions, activists and human rights groups said.

title: Big Deal | Hudson St. Penthouse Back on the Market
description: New York City can seem like a mighty unpleasant place if youre trying to get into or out of the Holland Tunnel.

title: In Rape Trial Of 2 Officers, A Defendant Denies Guilt
description: A New York police officer charged with rape took the stand in his own defense on Friday and for the first time publicly offered his account of what happened the night he and his partner assisted a drunken woman into her East Village apartment.

title: Mother Knows Best | Charlotte Dellal
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#888", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: Video: The Official Start of the 2012 Campaign
Price of Crude Oil Falls Again, but Analysts Warn It Will Remain at Lofty Levels
Amanda Pekoe and Christopher Lueck
description: EVEN before she knew him, Amanda Pekoe liked Christopher Lueck for his look, and liked him even more when he changed it. She first encountered him in 1999 when they were both acting students at Brooklyn College and his long brown hair reached the collar of his motorcycle jacket. A perfect guitarist for her band, she thought  until he said he didnt play and brushed me off.

title: Tallying the Votes at Goldman
description: The results are in.

title: A Scattering of Protests Honoring Bin Laden
description: CAIRO  About 200 demonstrators gathered outside the United States Embassy here on Friday to protest the killing and burial at sea of Osama bin Laden as manifestations of what they called American hostility to Muslims.

title: She-Hulk Issues Warning to Potential Fans
description: Entering our paperback graphic books list this week, at No. 4, is Vol. 1 of Sensational She-Hulk, by the writer and artist John Byrne. The green giant, the cousin of the Incredible Hulk, had a series of adventures involving Spider-Man (no surprise), Santa Claus (it happens) and a conflict with Dr. Bong (now were getting a little more funky). The biggest twist of the series was that She-Hulk broke the fourth wall, often addressing her fans.

title: Washington Square, 11:55 A.M.
description: Heres Violet the red-tailed hawk and the first one out of her eggs. Go to Updates From the Nest for live Hawk Cam video, a Q. and A. on what to expect in the days to come, and the latest developments, or to post a comment.

title: For Young Navy Veteran, Next Tour Is the Nationwide
description: ATHENS, Ga. - Billy Hurley III probably was going to get into this weeks Nationwide Tour event here before Osama bin Laden was fatally shot on the other side of the world. His handwritten letter asking for an exemption caught the eye of Jud Doherty, the president of Stadion Money Management, the events sponsor.

title: Narrowing the Export Gap in Indies
description: THE director Lixin Fan had already shown Last Train Home, his acclaimed documentary about Chinese migrant workers, around the world when, a few weeks ago, he finally got to screen it for Wuhan, his hometown. And, more important, for his mother.

title: How Many Jobs Should We Be Adding Each Month?
description: How many more jobs does the country need to get back to full employment? The short answer: as many as possible. The longer answer: It depends on how quickly you think Baby Boomers are retiring.

description: Becky Frances Coviello, a daughter of Joanne Blaser Seim of Brooklyn and Anthony J. Coviello of Leesburg, Va., was married Friday evening to Staff Sgt. Chris Lee Price, a son of Tammy Saunders of Inwood, W.Va., and the late Michael Price. The Rev. Hope McNew, a nondenominational minister affiliated with the National Spiritual Science Center in Washington, officiated at Herrington on the Bay in Rose Haven, Md.

title: Marli Porth, John Fanciullo
description: Marli Belle Porth and John Alexander Fanciullo were married Saturday evening in Washington. Britt Snider, a friend of the couple who became a Universal Life minister for the occasion, officiated at the Hay-Adams hotel.

title: CBS Drops Hallmark Hall of Fame
description: The Hallmark Hall of Fame franchise of made-for-television movies no longer has a home on network television. CBS has chosen not to extend its three-movie-a-year deal with Hallmark, so the franchise is now being shopped to others, Variety reported on Friday.

title: A More Refined 300
description: The redesign of Chryslers flagship sedan is less visually striking than its predecessor, but more refined.

title: International Center of Photography Seeking a New, Bigger Home
description: The International Center of Photography in Manhattan is looking for a new home that can accommodate both its museum and its school, its director, Willis E. Hartshorn, said on Friday. The school and museum are across the street from each other on the Avenue of the Americas near 43rd Street. Mr. Hartshorn said the center was in the early phases of evaluating various sites below 26th Street, including buildings in Lower Manhattan and Chelsea.

title: Security Freezes: How Theyve Worked Out for You
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I write about security freezes, also known as credit freezes, in the wake of the big customer data breach at Sony.

title: Handicapping the Battle Over NYSE Euronext
description: The endgame in the Nasdaqs bid for NYSE Euronext has begun.

title: ID Theft Tool That Sony Isnt Using
description: On Thursday, Sonys chairman and chief executive, Howard Stringer, finally got around to apologizing for the security breach that left the personal data of 77 million customers vulnerable to hackers.

title: Edible Selby | Danny Bowien of Mission Chinese
description: The hole-in-the-wall at 2234 Mission Street in San Francisco looks more like a greasy spoon where General Tsos chicken is ordered by number than a cult outpost offering quirky, responsibly sourced Chinese food. Inside, its both. Danny Bowien and Anthony Myint, who ran the pop-up Mission Street Food out of Lung Shan restaurant, are now cooking here permanently with Mission Chinese Food. Alongside Lung Shans menu, you can now indulge in what Mr. Bowien calls whimsical Chinese  sizzling cumin lamb, ma po tofu, barbecued brisket braised with a Mexican/Coca-Cola gastrique. Its not fusion, he said. Its not fine dining. Its not authentic. Its not from one region. Were just trying to do everything backwards. Go to interactive feature >>

title: Designing Successful Sequel Is Exercise in Restraint
description: WHEN clandestine photos of the redesigned 2012 Volkswagen Beetle turned up on the Internet last fall, two words appeared repeatedly in online critiques: squashed and squished.

title: After Disaster Hit Japan, Electric Cars Stepped Up
description: TOKYO

title: Twitter in the Classroom  The Sequel
description: Two educators have followed up on my piece on the use of Twitter by students chronicling bird behavior with their experiences teaching in 140-character bursts. Their thoughts are below, but first  speaking of twittering  heres the latest from The New York Times Hawk Cam, which captured the hatching of a red-tailed hawk eyass Friday morning.:

title: Obama Calls for End of Oil Subsidies
description: With gasoline prices still hovering above $4 a gallon, President Obama renewed his call on Friday to close tax loopholes for large oil companies, declaring, If youre already paying them at the gas pump, we dont need to pay them through the tax code.

title: Anatomy of Two Fake Quotations
description: Anatomy of a Fake Quotation, The Atlantics look this week at how a comment written and posted by a Facebook user concerning Osama bin Ladens demise came to be attributed to the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. brought to mind another quote mistakenly attributed to another civil rights leader, Nelson Mandela.

title: TimesCast | May 6, 2011
description: May 6, 2011 - Protests across Syria on Friday, as the government's crackdown continues; remembering the 1982 massacre in Hama, Syria; and the op-ed columnist Thomas L. Friedman.

title: Actors Take Lead Roles in New Video Game
description: L.A. Noire forgoes typical animation, instead using video of real actors  some 400 of them.

title: Who Makes Our Magazine?
description: The New York Times daily newspaper is printed at multiple locations across the globe to ensure timely delivery. The entire run of The New York Times Magazine, however, is printed every week at RR Donnelly, a press in Lancaster, Pa. They have been printing our magazine for almost 30 years. We here in New York deliver the last of the files every Friday to them, and they print over 1.5 million copies of the publication for delivery nine days later.

title: Video Game to Play in Vintage Gumshoes
description: LOS ANGELES

title: How to Photograph the Cover
description: For this weeks article on the crash of Air France Flight 447, we considered several photographic treatments for the cover. First we considered having a photographer charter a plane and fly over the recovery ship, the Alucia, while it was still near the spot where its crew located the plane in early April. We decided that option was too costly, so next we tried to take a satellite picture of the Alucia. But on the chosen day, a combination of vague coordinates  French authorities refused to provide the precise location of the ship  and cloud cover prevented us from getting any usable image.

title: Bakeries Spring Up in the Twin Cities
description: ON a recent Saturday morning there was a line out the door at Patisserie 46 in Minneapoliss emerging Kingfield neighborhood, as folks waited to get their daily baked goods. The bakery (4552 Grand Avenue South; 612-354-3257; patisserie46.com) hasnt yet been open a year and already has achieved cultlike status for its French-style offerings: the croissants are crisp and light as air, the macarons evaporate in the mouth.

title: A New Way to See Sicily
description: ON a thick summer afternoon in the Sicilian town of Corleone, beneath palm trees in the small central piazza, the old men in their rimmed caps watched us. They rolled their eyes over our touristy selves (cameras and sunhats), and my husband and I scarfed our gelato a little faster.

title: Restaurant Report: 41 in Barcelona
description: Technically, the buzzy new dining spot 41 in Barcelona, Spain, isnt a restaurant  its a cocktail bar with snacks. But when the surname of the two lead proprietors is Adri  as in Ferran and Albert, of the famed three-Michelin-starred restaurant El Bulli  such distinctions take a back seat.

title: Hotel Review: Chicago JW Marriott
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Off the Roman Coast, Bobbing for Views
description: ARRIVING by ferry or hydrofoil at Ponza, an island in the Tyrrhenian Sea, the boat trims the islands eastern coast, a vista of sheer tuff cliffs bleached white by the sun and eroded by water and wind.

title: Atlanta Serves Sophisticated Southern
description: WHEN I moved to Atlanta from New York late last year, I made a few rookie food mistakes. I would corner the dry cleaner, the preschool teacher, every food friend I knew. So where can I find great barbecue? I asked.

title: Lost in Java
description: IN 15 years of traveling to Asia, I have seen and done a number of strange things. I have eaten writhing octopus tentacles in Seoul, and Ive been shepherded into a Phnom Penh nightclub by a Cambodian dwarf in a tuxedo. At this point, little surprises me. But when I arrived in the city of Malang, in the cool hills of inland East Java, I discovered something I never imagined existed.

title: Letters: Charge It, Please?
description: To the Editor: The article Picking the Best Credit Card (April 24) was helpful but did not address the common problem that credit cards issued in the United States have a magnetic strip, not the chip found in European cards. This is an inconvenience, as United States cards are rejected at some kiosks all over Europe, and even for some counter purchases.

title: Letters: Florida, Here We Come
description: To the Editor: Re A Post-Spring Break Jaunt to Floridas Beaches (April 19): The area around Jacksonville is great. You can camp at Kathryn Abbey Hanna Park. Jax Beach, Neptune Beach and Atlantic Beach are great to visit. Just south of town, on your way to St. Augustine on Route A1A, is Micklers Landing and Beach. Its a great beach, with lots of friendly locals, surfers and families, plus lots of free parking. My favorite place is Cocoa Beach. Its a relatively small town, with small-town prices. The beach is great, and theres an even better one south of town at Patrick Air Force Base (lots of free parking). The stretch from Jacksonville to Cocoa Beach is a great part of Florida. Youre guaranteed to enjoy your time there.

title: A Twist on the B&B in Wales
description: THERE are a few constants on the Pen-y-Wyrlod farm in southeast Wales: the sheep, the rain, the mud, the Black Mountains. And at the top of a small hill, beyond an unmarked gate, across from a medieval church, a Gypsy caravan barely large enough to hold a bed, a wood-burning stove and a paying guest  me.

title: Offbeat Bargains in Berlin
description: Known primarily for its dreadlocked denizens and enormous warehouse nightclubs, Berlins Friedrichshain district has lately developed a reputation as a retail destination.

title: Demography and Jobs (Wonkish)
description: Catherine Rampell raises the question of how many jobs we need to keep up with population growth, given the aging of the population. Id been thinking about it a different way. We know that the employment-population ratio has been flat since late 2009; would things look better if we looked at the employment ratio for prime-age workers?

title: The Morning Line: Scratching of Uncle Mo Is No Surprise
description: The Uncle Mo melodrama has ended for the Derby with the decision this morning that Mo is a no-go. Owner Mike Repole told reporters the colt hasnt recovered well enough from his stomach ailment to handle the 1 1/4-mile distance, according to USA Today. Jay Privman for the Daily Racing Form said that the news was expected, and Joe Drape  similarly found that the scratch was not surprising since Uncle Mo has not looked like himself in the morning here and his owner, Mike Repole, has said all week that it was a 50-50 chance that Uncle Mo would run in Americas greatest race.

title: The Reluctant Transgender Role Model
description: AT the Sundance Film Festival earlier this year, I wheedled a ticket to Becoming Chaz, a documentary about the sex change of Chastity Bono. Having long admired the Fenton Bailey and Randy Barbato World of Wonder productions  slyly edu-taining films like The Eyes of Tammy Faye and oodles of just-louche-enough-for-reality-TV shows like RuPauls Drag Race  I anticipated their usual mix of human interest, alternative lifestyle and salacious tabloid.

title: Stylelikeu | Mother and Daughter Sartorialists
description: Target is offering matching dresses for moms and babies from its new Calypso collaboration. Lucky magazine recently introduced a back-page feature called My Mom, the Style Icon. But for most of us, there was a period, in between teetering in Moms high heels and aching to steal her vintage blouses, during which wed balk at anything anything  she liked. Not so for Lily Mandelbaum, a student at N.Y.U. who has collaborated with her mother, the fashion editor and stylist Elisa Goodkind, on the style blog Stylelikeu since 2008. The popular site features closet tours, style mantras and video interviews with their fashion muses, both known (the fashion designer LaQuan Smith) and unknown (Virginie Sommet, who makes art out of Indian candy and fennel). Now, just in time for Mothers Day, theyve released a book of the same name, full of beautiful images of sartorial inspiration, including collages of hands garnished with jaw-dropping gems, club kids posing in their bedrooms and little old ladies who refuse to hang up the toreador pants. As Tziporah Salamon,one such senior, happily explained: Every single day you get a chance to invent yourself. How fun is that? Happy Mothers Day!

title: Suburbia: What a Concept
description: There is no more iconic suburb than Levittown, the postwar planned community built by the developer William Levitt in the late 1940s, so it is understandable that in launching Open House, a collaborative project to imagine a future suburbia, the Dutch design collective Droog in collaboration with Diller Scofidio + Renfro architects would make it the focus of their inquiry.

description: If you edit a magazine, unsolicited criticism comes with the job. When youre in a decent mood and its phrased humanely, it can be helpful and fortifying. When youre not in a good mood or if the word idiot is used freely, then you tend not to take it so well.

In recent programs he has focused on chamber music, performing a concert with the Tetzlaff Quartet (of which he is first violinist) and a duo recital with the violinist Antje Weithaas.

title: A Celebration With a Clock Ticking
description: On May 5, 1891, Carnegie Hall was inaugurated with a gala concert at which Tchaikovsky was the distinguished guest. On Thursday night Carnegie Hall celebrated its 120th anniversary with a gala program performed by the New York Philharmonic, with Alan Gilbert conducting, and a roster of starry solo artists. Television cameras recorded the concert for broadcast in PBSs Great Performances series, and many in the audience were formally dressed and ready to party.

description: The rate of prescription pain medication misuse by New York City residents who are 12 or older has increased by 40 percent from 2002 to 2009, according to a report released Friday by the citys Health Department.

title: Lots of Drama, but No Fall, During Spider-Man Rehearsal
description: Rehearsal for Broadways Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark on Friday was no normal slice of scene work for Christopher Tierney, the actor who fell 30 feet from a platform and nearly died during a performance on Dec. 20. Mr. Tierney, who plays the masked super-hero in stunt sequences, flew Thursday for the first time since rejoining the cast last week; Fridays work call had him back at the moment in the musical when his accident occurred.

title: Bird Week| The Lure and Danger of the High Line
description: Bright lights, big city: That combination draws birds to the same kinds of places the characters in a Jay McInerney novel would go if all that 80s dissipation did not do them in first. There is, for example, the High Line elevated park. Except that at least one spot along the High Line is not for the birds  for them, it can be deadly.

title: Master of Hounds 101
description: Master of Hounds hardly looked like a Derby contender when he failed to fire in the Breeders Cup Juvenile Turf last fall. But a bit of a break over the winter apparently agreed with him, because a bigger, stronger version of the colt took to the track in Dubai on World Cup night.

title: For These Designers, Mom Knew Best
description: IN The Importance of Being Earnest, Oscar Wilde wrote: All women become like their mothers. That is their tragedy. No man does. Thats his. Fashion designers get around this problem by incorporating their mothers way of dressing into their work. On the occasion of Mothers Day, several shared their primal style memories.

title: Primal Style Memories
description: PETER SOM, 40

title: Designers and Their Mothers
description: Images of designers like Carolina Herrera and Jason Wu, with their mothers.

title: Hawk Cam | Send Us Name Suggestions for the Baby Hawk(s)
description: Update, May 17, 4:08 p.m. | Thanks for all your suggestions. Read about the baby hawks newly bestowed name.

title: A Matter of Degrees
description: In 1940, a Brooklyn woman named Jean Kay filed a suit with the State Supreme Court against the her citys Board of Higher Education claiming that the renowned mathematician and philosopher Bertrand Russell was morally unfit to teach at the City College of New York, where he had been offered a professorship. Kay, supported by a host of others in the public scrum, including Bishop William Manning of the Episcopal Church, argued that Russell, who advocated sex before marriage and other heretical lifestyle choices, posed a threat to the virtue of her daughter  even though the impressionable youth was not actually a student at the college. A judge ruled in Kays favor. Russell, who was not allowed to speak in his own defense, was denied his appointment at the college, which was, and is, part of the publicly financed City University of New York system. Today, the now-notorious incident is chronicled in an exhibition on City Colleges Web site, called The Struggle for Free Speech at CCNY, 1931-1942, as is a recounting of the subsequent firings, spurred by the McCarthy era Rapp-Coudert Committee, of faculty members accused of being Communist Party members.

title: Sloan Group Is Lab Partner to the Arts
description: Anna Zieglers play Photograph 51 focuses the spotlight on Rosalind Franklin, the least heralded of the four scientists who discovered the structure of DNA in 1953. Although Franklins death from cancer at 37 precluded her sharing the Nobel Prize that this breakthrough brought, her X-ray photography provided the critical evidence of the molecules famed double helix.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 7
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Bloggingheads: Better Off Dead?
description: Glenn Greenwald, left, of Salon.com and David Frum of FrumForum debate the killing of Osama bin Laden.

title: The Week in Pictures for May 6
description: Photographs from the past week in New York City and the region, including a Sikh Day festival, a stable in Central Park and President Obamas visit to ground zero.

title: Recalling and Quoting Her Mother
description: In 1999 the choreographer Muna Tseng paid homage to her brother, the photographer Tseng Kwong Chi, who had died of AIDS. That work, SlutForArt, was created in collaboration with the theater artist Ping Chong. Now, in Stella, Ms. Tseng tries to get under the skin of her mother, a stylish woman who had a sharp tongue. Stella cared about clothes  included in the show is an exhibition of her luxurious couture dresses  and said memorable things like, The biggest waste in life is time.

title: New Jazz That Keeps an Ear Trained on the Past
description: By the late 1990s, jazz outside the straight-ahead mainstream was looking around itself and worrying. Outlasting a flicker of interest from major-record labels, anticipating audience decline as the downtown jazz scene grew diffuse and undefinable, it went in search of its parents and looked backward and Eastward: to Ornette Coleman, Lennie Tristano, Jimmy Giuffre, early fusion and progressive rock, the Art Ensemble of Chicago and Balkan and cantorial music. A whole field of bands gravitated toward intense polyphony, liturgical melodies and the clank: drummers playing roughed-up rhythm, rushing time and forestalling your pleasure, vexing you on purpose.

title: Youth, Balanchine and Fans Are Served
description: In the Stravinsky-Balanchine Apollo, the world itself is young. The boy god Apollo, the first musician, discovers art by creating it in the open air. On Thursday night at New York City Ballet, the title role was danced by Chase Finlay, who had not even graduated from the School of American Ballet when this piece was last performed, in 2008. Afterward the audience would not release the performers until Mr. Finlay had taken a solo bow in front of the curtain.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 7
description: More Photographs

title: The Battle for Libya | May 6
description: Protests, Friday Prayers and the appearance of land mines as the struggle in Libya continued.

title: A Womans Persecution, and a Daughters Deliverance
description: HOUSTON  On a blustery night the week before Mothers Day, a woman and her daughter sat together on the sofa at a hair salon here. Nica Sabet had come to the beauty parlor after school, because it was where her mother, Nahid Sabet, worked. By this time, past 8 oclock, the doors were locked and the customers gone, and Mrs. Sabet could tell the story that Nica had never heard in its entirety.

title: A Country Star in Search of Her Voice
description: How many people must hurt so that Shania Twain may heal?

title: Matching Eighth Graders With a High School
description: A look at how many New York City students get placed in their top choice of high schools.

title: NBCs Office Takes a Hit
description: In the first episode of The Office without its star Steve Carell, ratings for the NBC sitcom were down two million viewers and some 15 percent in the demographic of viewers 18 to 49 compared with a week ago. According to Nielsens estimates, 6.8 million people tuned in to the episode at 9 p.m., down from 8.4 million previously. For the night, NBC ranked a distant fourth, earning its second- and third-highest ratings at 9:30 and 10 for Parks and Recreation (5.1 million) and 30 Rock (4.2 million). Fox dominated prime time as usual thanks to an elimination episode of American Idol at 8 (20.8 million) in which Jacob Lusk failed to make the cut for the Top 4. CBS was second with CSI at 9 (10.5 million) and The Mentalist at 10 (13.6 million). ABC finished in third place, attracting its best ratings at 9 for Greys Anatomy (9.9 million).

title: Podcast: Jobs, Economics and a Retail Makeover
description: After the economic slowdown that showed up in the data for first-quarter G.D.P., Fridays Labor Department report on jobs and unemployment was nervously awaited.

title: Publishers Make a Plan: A One Stop Book Site
description: Publishers have spent a lot of time and money building their own company Web sites with fresh information on their books and authors. The trouble is, very few book buyers visit them.

title: In Mississippi Delta, All Eyes on a Swelling River
description: CLEVELAND, Miss.  For 76 years, the bankers, catfish farmers, and corn and soybean growers who make up the Delta Council have gathered to talk crops and politics, and listen to speeches by governors, senators and, on one occasion, William Faulkner.

title: The Week in Pictures for May 6
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include New Yorkers watching the Royal wedding, the Sikh Day Parade and reaction to the death of Osama bin Laden.

title: Closed Out of One High School After Another
description: About 10 percent of the citys eighth graders did not get into any of the public high schools they wanted, leaving them  and their worried, frustrated parents  to consider what was next.

title: Ministers Meet to Study Fixes on Greek Debt
description: New moves to prevent the huge burden of Greek debt from overwhelming the countrys economy were discussed Friday during an unannounced meeting of a small group of European finance ministers, including those from Germany, France and Greece.

title: Struggling Folk Art Museum Hands Off Antique Show
description: As part of an effort to stabilize its finances, the struggling American Folk Art Museum is turning over the ownership and management of the annual American Antiques Show, a fundraising fair that it has run for a decade, to the Art Fair Company, which organizes the Sculpture Objects and Functional Art fairs and the Art and Antique Dealers League of America Spring Show, Mark Lyman, the president of the company, said in an interview on Friday.

title: Not Far From the Pharmacy, a Different Sort of Drug Deal
description: The universal, not-so-secret password of the drug deal: What you got, man?

title: Farm Subsidies Become Target Amid Spending Cuts
description: WASHINGTON  When it comes to spending cuts, members of Congress like to say that everything is on the table. Except, generally, food. But now federal farm subsidies, long decried by policy makers as wasteful and antiquated but protected by powerful political interests, appear to be in serious danger.

title: Block by Block
description: Sights and sounds from West 14th to West 23rd Street including the Buddakan nightclub, the grounds of the General Theological Seminary, Le Grainne Cafe and Moonstruck diner.

title: With Dallas Leading, Outspoken Owner Lowers the Volume
description: DALLAS  Mark Cuban is not an owner who merely watches his Dallas Mavericks. He seems to internalize the action while outwardly cheering and complaining. When his emotions are released  and they frequently are  the result is often a fine leveled at Cuban by the N.B.A.

title: Russia: Lawyers Killer Gets Life Term
description: A young nationalist was sentenced to life in prison, Russias most stringent punishment, on Friday for fatally shooting a human rights lawyer and a young journalist two years ago on a busy street near the Kremlin. His common-law wife, who prosecutors said acted as a lookout, was sentenced to 18 years as an accomplice. The sentence brings to a close a case that deeply shook Russian human rights circles, which have been dogged by a series of high-profile killings. Last week, the couple, Nikita Tikhonov, 30, and Yevgenia Khasis, 26, were found guilty. Defense lawyers appealed the sentence on Friday, saying the judge had sided with prosecutors. This can be qualified in whatever way you like, a costume ball, a farce, a reprisal, but not a trial, Aleksandr Vasilyev, Mr. Tikhonovs lawyer, told the Interfax news service.

title: Sort of Cool, Not Yet Hot
description: POOR Ninth Avenue. You could dismiss the stretch from West 14th to West 23rd Street as the northern hinterlands of the greater meatpacking district. Or you could pity it, there in the shadow of 10th, the glamorous sister avenue whose profile has been transformed by famous art galleries, starred restaurants and the coursing aorta that is the High Line. But no need to disparage in any way: These blocks in West Chelsea form a self-contained little quarter, with a thriving life all their own.

title: The Week That Was
description: This is not the column I was going to write, but because of the recent days of relentless saturation  and I dont mean by or about the Mississippi River  whatever I try to type, my fingers, unbidden, produce the letters Osama bin  etc.

title: A Major Fight, and Its Not on HBO? Times Are Changing for Big Promoters
description: LAS VEGAS  On Saturday, the MGM Grand will serve as both the site of a welterweight title fight and a network experiment.

title: Judge Gives Immigrant in Same-Sex Marriage a Reprieve From Deportation
description: An immigration judge in Newark on Friday suspended the deportation of a Venezuelan man who is married to an American man, responding to an unusual signal this week from the Obama administration that it is exploring legal avenues for recognizing same-sex marriages in immigration cases.

title: George Jetson, Your Room Is Ready
description: Weve all had this dream for so long that some of us have probably forgotten about it. Its the dream that someday well be able to navigate New York without ever being at the mercy of a rude cabdriver, an indifferent waiter or a butterfingered bellhop.

title: Energy Dept. Panel to Revise Standards for Gas Extraction
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration, seeing increased domestic natural gas production as a linchpin in its long-term energy strategy, has named a panel of experts to find ways to make hydraulic fracturing, a fast-growing method of extracting natural gas, safer and cleaner.

title: A Titan Under a Microscope
description: Steven A. Cohen, the once-secretive billionaire hedge fund manager, is suddenly everywhere.

title: William Craig, Politician in Northern Ireland, Is Dead at 86
description: William Craig, a Protestant politician in Northern Ireland whose banning of a civil rights march by Roman Catholics in 1968 helped set off 30 years of sectarian violence, which he fueled with incendiary pronouncements, died April 25 in Bangor, Northern Ireland. He was 86.

title: The Man Likes What He Sees in the Mirror
description: Michael R. Bloomberg, long one of the nations most-admired big-city mayors, is not accustomed to seeing his popularity used as comic fodder. But there he was, at the black-tie White House Correspondents Association dinner, when Seth Meyers, of Saturday Night Live fame, strode to the rostrum and, in front of much of the nations political, media and entertainment elite, let loose with a joke about a Bloomberg-sponsored after-party.

title: Florida Legislators Pass H.M.O. Plan for Medicaid
description: MIAMI  In a sweeping overhaul of its $21 billion Medicaid program, the Florida Legislature approved a bill Friday to shift nearly three million Medicaid recipients into managed-care programs in the hope of saving money and improving services.

title: CUNY and Tony Kushner: A Firestorm
description: To the Editor:

title: The Nissan Taxi Is Rolling In, to a Bronx Cheer
description: To the Editor:

title: On a Gas Line in 1979
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Warns Schools Against Checking Immigration Status
description: Federal officials issued a memorandum to the nations school districts on Friday saying it was against the law for education officials to seek information that might reveal the immigration status of children applying for enrollment.

title: Dissecting the Twin Tales of Teams in Distress
description: On Thursday, after the Mets defeated the San Francisco Giants, 5-2, Fred Wilpon stood off to the side in a wide corridor near the Mets clubhouse at Citi Field and interacted with friends and their families. Wilpon, the Mets owner, casually greeted players, kissed their newborn babies and congratulated expectant mothers.

title: Warner Music Is Sold, Ending a Long Auction
description: Kevin Mazur/Hope for Haiti Now, via European Pressphoto AgencyMadonna is among Warner Musics artists.

title: Sainthood for John Paul
description: To the Editor:

title: New Jersey Rock History: More Than Big Hair and the Boss
description: IN Jersey Rocks: A History of Rock & Roll in the Garden State, a new exhibition at the Morris Museum in Morristown that will run through Sept. 5, the background music may be as interesting for some visitors as the 400 or so objects on display. Stacys Mom, the 2003 hit by the pop band Fountains of Wayne, whose front man, Adam Schlesinger, grew up in Montclair, was followed recently by Walk on By, the 1960s classic made famous by Dionne Warwick, who was raised in Newark and now lives in South Orange.

title: Knocking Them Dead Backstage
description: The leading lady is hopeless. Shes a bosomy redhead who cant remember her lines, and, rather than act, she just poses. The shows final number, Wide Open Spaces, is pedestrian, and the choreography is longer on energy than style. The Boston reviews are dreadful.

title: Presidential Spotlight Shines on the Commandos Who Work in the Shadows
description: FORT CAMPBELL, Ky.  They are the shadowy warriors of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden: two dozen members of the Navy Seals who stormed the fortified compound in Pakistan where Bin Laden was hiding. Their identities will probably never be known; their faces will most likely never appear in photographs at the White House, on magazine covers or on television talk shows.

title: How We Reacted to the Killing of Bin Laden
description: To the Editor:

title: Strangers on a Train, Destination Unknown
description: Night Train, a new play by John Biguenet at the New Jersey Repertory Company in Long Branch, takes viewers on a quick journey into darkening deception as a traveler becomes intrigued  unfortunately, for him  by two of his fellow passengers.

title: A Wedding in the Winners Circle
description: In a bucket-list moment, Julie June Stewart woke up at 4 a.m. and bought a ticket to the 2008 Belmont. She hasnt stopped going to the races since. That is when she isnt isnt taking on a wildfire, hurricane, volcano or oil spill as the nations leading expert in disaster airspace coordination.

title: Top Mets Suitor Would Likely Draw Scrutiny
description: With a net worth of $8 billion, Steven A. Cohen, who is in the bidding to purchase a minority stake in the Mets, unquestionably has the money to buy a sizable chunk of the franchise.

title: Diplomatic Service
description: To the Editor:

title: A Brief History of Primary Polling, Part III
description: About a month ago, I published a pair of articles (see Part I and Part II) that focused on the predictive value of polls conducted in the early stage of the presidential primary process. Specifically, it looked at national polls conducted in January through June of the year before the primaries  for example, polls taken in January through June 1987 for the 1988 nomination races.

title: Golfers Reflect as Ballesteross Condition Deteriorates
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  An ocean apart, at a PGA Tour event in North Carolina and a PGA European Tour event in Madrid, professional golfers had Seve Ballesteros on their minds Friday. Word of his rapidly worsening health had swept across the golf courses, and its impact was felt by many of the players who had competed against him.

title: A Hideaway for Wine
description: THE dimly lighted storefront gives Bouchon Wine Bar Caf a speakeasy feel, like an exciting hideaway, although it is located only a block from the homey Pleasantville train station. But theres more to Bouchon than its narrow facade implies: its long, deep space has been divided smartly into cozy areas fitted with couches, a few high and low tables and a full bar.

title: A Complex Interplay in Latin Cuisine
description: THE chupe at Cienega, a saffron-infused yellow, is lovely just to look at. But sample a spoonful of this Peruvian chowder and the pleasure really begins. Filled with firm shrimp, sweet corn kernels, bits of green and red peppers  even a poached quail egg  the soup is somehow both strong and subtle, rich and light: an interplay of flavors and textures. It is a fitting introduction to Cienegas complex Latin cuisine and a metaphor for the overall dining experience there.

title: Facing Criticism, U.S. Official Quits
description: Peter Vidmar, a two-time Olympic gold medalist in gymnastics, stepped down Friday as the chief of mission for the 2012 United States Olympic team after a controversy about his public opposition to same-sex marriage.

title: U.S. Demands More From Pakistan in Bin Laden Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  Pakistani officials say the Obama administration has demanded the identities of some of their top intelligence operatives as the United States tries to determine whether any of them had contact with Osama bin Laden or his agents in the years before the raid that led to his death early Monday morning in Pakistan.

title: A Talented Jockey Is No Longer a Secret
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.  The girl was on horses before she could walk and grew up following her mother around barns in her native New Jersey. She quickly grew out of pony racing and into thoroughbreds, first galloping horses in the mornings on Maryland racetracks. She got a jockeys license when she was 17 and earned her first victory with her first mount, Ringofdiamonds, on June 9, 2005.

title: The Spring Quiz
description: I. Match that quote:

title: The Bin Laden Bounce
description: Osama goes down. Obama ticks up. Thats the narrative of the killing of Osama bin Laden and the lift in the polls for President Obama in its aftermath. In fact, a New York Times/CBS News poll conducted after Bin Laden was killed  found an 11-point jump in the presidents approval rating.

title: Lincoln, Douglass and the Double-Tongued Document
description: The two months following Lincolns inauguration found Frederick Douglass struggling to understand and bitterly demoralized by the presidents policies, but also exhilarated by the outbreak of war at Fort Sumter. He had no interest in the new presidents oratorical olive branches to the seceded South, his poetry about the mystic chords of memory or the better angels of our nature. Indeed, Douglass despised the olive branches, calling the speech little better than our worst fears, and a double-tongued document, capable of two constructions, concealing rather than declaring a definite policy.

title: An Iranian Filmmaker Tiptoes Around the Censors to Explore Risky Subjects
description: TEHRAN This is not something I should be doing, Mehrdad Oskouei says, shuffling through thick stacks of sepia-tinged postcards of long-bearded Qajar noblemen, mustachioed revolutionaries, veiled women and wandering dervishes. Mr. Oskouei, perhaps Irans most prominent documentary filmmaker, has spent a considerable amount of time and money assembling the collection, a venture that many of his friends and relatives see as a quixotic cultural crusade.

title: Baby Hawk Deaths Greatly Exaggerated, Video Feed Shows
description: Nature, fortunately, does not listen to the experts.

title: You Call That Tough?
description: The only thing missing from Preet Bhararas press conference was the blaring of trumpets.

title: Trying to Game Google on Mothers Day Flowers
description: Mothers Day flowers.

title: After Reversal, Honor Is Likely for Kushner
description: Under mounting pressure, the City University of New York board of trustees moved on Friday to reverse its decision earlier this week to withhold an honorary degree from the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Tony Kushner because of one trustees concerns about Mr. Kushners views regarding Israel.

title: A Philosopher in Love
description: Houston

title: The Return of Drill, Baby, Drill
description: With the country again facing $4-a-gallon gasoline, the time would seem ripe for a grown-up conversation on energy. What we are getting instead is a mindless rerun of the drill-baby-drill operatics of the 2008 campaign, when gas was also at $4 a gallon. Then, as now, opportunistic politicians insisted that vastly expanded oil drilling would bring relief at the pump and reduced dependence on foreign oil. Then, as now, these arguments were bogus.

title: One Hand Clapping
description: Jobs data can be hard to read. When an economy is emerging from recession, a rising jobless rate can be a good sign if it reflects an increase in the people actively looking for work. Sadly, that was not the case with the April employment numbers reported on Friday. The jobless rate rose because the people who lost or left their jobs outnumbered those who found new work.

title: Legal Fight Continues for N.F.L.
description: With silence from a federal appeals court, the N.F.L. headed into another weekend in limbo, with business shut down and players wondering when  or if  they will go back to work.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Lottery Numbers
In Search of a Republican Presidential Field
description: Even John Boehner, the speaker of the House and Republican chieftain, didnt bother to watch his partys presidential debate on Thursday, and its hard to blame him. Only five candidates showed up, none with impressive followings. And what they said demonstrated why Republicans are having such a hard time delivering a coherent and appealing message ahead of the 2012 campaign.

title: CUNY Shamed Itself
description: The trustees of the City University of New York got it exactly backward this week. They supported the political agenda of an intolerant board member and shunned one of Americas most important playwrights. They should have embraced the artist and tossed out the board member.

title: In Praise of Brew Masters
description: After the Blue Point Brewing Company opened in Patchogue 13 years ago, said Pete Cotter, 48, the brewerys co-founder, we were the only game in town for a while.

title: An American Newcomer With an Italian Accent
description: CAF RED, in Kings Park, is the newest member of the family of restaurants owned by Nino Antuzzi and Kelley Danek. The others, all in Huntington, are Red, Osteria da Nino and Sapsuckers, a casual, publike spot.

title: Lanny Friedlander, Founder of Reason Magazine, Dies at 63
description: Lanny Friedlander, who with little more than a typewriter and a stack of paper founded the libertarian magazine Reason in his college dorm room in 1968 and ran it briefly before dropping out of sight for the next 40 years, died on March 19 in Lowell, Mass. He was 63.

title: Mattingly Looks Past Dodgers Financial Fray
description: Shortly after Commissioner Bud Selig appointed Tom Schieffer to run the Los Angeles Dodgers against the will of the teams ownership last month, Schieffer held a meeting with the players in the clubhouse at Dodger Stadium.

title: In Fallout of Suicide by Student, a Plea Deal
description: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J.  One of two former Rutgers University students accused of spying on another student with a webcam just days before he committed suicide will be allowed to avoid a conviction if she continues to provide information about her co-defendant, prosecutors said Friday.

title: Power Struggle in Iran Enters the Mosque
description: The unprecedented power struggle between the two most powerful leaders in Iran deepened Friday, spilling out into Tehrans public prayers where the mullah leading the service indirectly criticized President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad while the crowd chanted Death to opponents of the supreme leader!

title: Saturday: Unlike the Opera Wozzeck
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  How long have you been doing late week puzzles?
