description: John A. Boehner, the House speaker, plans to visit upstate New York on Monday to support the struggling campaign of a Republican candidate who is running for a vacant seat in Congress.

title: Mental Health in Old Age
description: To the Editor:

title: Slow Recovery in Tornado Territory
description: The South makes a slow recovery from record tornadoes that swept the region this spring.

title: Lawyers for Immigrants
description: To the Editor:

title: New Top 10s Wont Include Any Americans
description: Monday is a historic day for United States tennis, one that will generate no rejoicing in the American tennis community. In the nearly 40 years since the inception of computer rankings, it will be the first time that no man or woman from the United States is ranked in the top 10 in the world in singles. Christopher Clarey looks at what has gone wrong. Read the article, and come back to this post to comment.

title: Gay Marriage in New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Sectarian Violence in Cairo
description: Violence between Coptic Christians and Muslims in Cairo on Saturday night left at least 12 people dead and two churches in flames.

title: A Public Health Pioneer
description: To the Editor:

title: Tilapia, the Starter Fish
description: To the Editor:

title: Animal Kingdoms Win Is Victory for the Sport
description: LOUISVILLE, Ky.

title: Broad Taliban Attack Paralyzes Kandahar
description: KANDAHAR, Afghanistan  For more than 30 hours over the weekend, the Taliban immobilized the southern city of Kandahar, unleashing multiple attacks with small arms and suicide bombers near the citys downtown, pinning down people in their homes, forcing shops to close and halting most traffic.

title: Suit Opens a Window Into Google
description: A stack of internal e-mail messages from Google, which a Massachusetts state court made public last week, provide a glimpse into the competitive tactics and decision-making inside a business that is crucial to the companys growth  its Android software for smartphones.

title: Mexico Takes Aim at a Titan in Telecom
description: MEXICO CITY  In the two decades that Carlos Slim Hel has turned a crumbling Mexican phone monopoly into a continental telecom giant, he has successfully fought off competitors and challenged authorities who wanted to limit his companies control.

title: After a Ho-Hum Victory, Pacquiao Is Running Out of Challengers
description: LAS VEGAS  Late Saturday, at his postfight news conference, Manny Pacquiao looked less like a combatant in a welterweight prize fight and more like a congressman emerging from a bargaining session. He appeared tired, but wore neither bandages nor bruises; his face was unmarked, his body unharmed, except, perhaps, for a touch of wounded pride.

title: Beijing Blames Foreigners for Its Fears of Unrest
description: BEIJING  Chinese and American officials are polishing off scripts for a ritual that is set to unfold in Washington on Monday and Tuesday. During a meeting known as the Strategic and Economic Dialogue, they will smile across conference tables and talk about cooperating on a range of issues: trade, currency, North Korea.

title: Mildred Leet, 88, Who Helped Empower the Poor, Dies
description: Mildred Robbins Leet, a philanthropist who was a co-founder of Trickle Up, one of the first nonprofits to provide microgrants, typically of $100, to help poor people start their own businesses, died on Tuesday in Manhattan. She was 88.

title: In Cable Niches, Less Reality and More Original Shows
description: Stacy Littlejohn worked her way up in network television like so many other writers and producers  she was a writers assistant on a Fox show, a joke writer on a CW show, a writer-producer on ahalf-hour ABC show.

title: Hitting the Bottle
description: SUDDENLY, theres a baby boom going on around me. Im making weekly shopping trips to stock friends nurseries, and Im struck by how many signs on the shelves advertise BPA-free bottles, BPA-free sippy cups. It breaks my heart. Manufacturers might be removing BPA, a chemical used to harden certain plastics, from their products, but they are substituting chemicals that may be just as dangerous, if not more so.

title: The Unwisdom of Elites
description: The past three years have been a disaster for most Western economies. The United States has mass long-term unemployment for the first time since the 1930s. Meanwhile, Europes single currency is coming apart at the seams. How did it all go so wrong?

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Russia Kills 8 Militants in South
description: MOSCOW  The Russian authorities announced Sunday that eight insurgents were killed in a large counterterrorism operation in the southern region of Dagestan.

title: Looking Ahead to Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include import prices for April and wholesale trade inventories for March (Tuesday); the trade deficit for March (Wednesday); the Producer Price Index for April, retail sales for April, weekly jobless claims and business inventories for March (Thursday); and the Consumer Price Index for April and the Thomson Reuters/University of Michigan consumer sentiment index for May (Friday).

title: The Debt Limit Negotiations
description: Republican leaders and White House officials will meet on Tuesday to continue talks on the federal debt limit. They need to tread very carefully here.

title: Can You Explain the War Powers Act?
description: The Department of Educations latest assessment of what young Americans know about civics shows that the light of democracy burns steadily in schools, if too dimly.

title: Boarding? Denied. Lock and Loading? Sure.
description: Here is a chilling and potentially lethal fact of life: A person on the F.B.I.s terrorist watch list is barred from boarding an airplane yet is quite free to buy high-power firearms and ammunition at any American gun shop.

title: In Buffalo, Visions, Perhaps Illusions, of a University-Fueled Revitalization
description: BUFFALO  This city has lost more than one-tenth of its residents in the last decade, and it shows.

title: Culture of Calm Is Threatened by Budget Cuts
description: As students funneled through the doors of Roberto Clemente High School on a recent Friday, Cristina Pacione-Zayas, the schools Culture of Calm coordinator, could barely finish a conversation before her walkie-talkie summoned her to the next one.

title: 50 Years After Trial, Eichmann Secrets Live On
description: BERLIN  Germany is famous for confronting its Nazi past. But confronting the years after the war is another matter. The latest proof comes as the countrys foreign intelligence agency, the BND, refuses to declassify several thousand secret files detailing what Adolf Eichmann, the high-ranking Nazi who helped orchestrate the Holocaust, was doing between 1945 and his capture by Mossad agents in Buenos Aires in 1960. More than a few Germans have been speculating that the refusal has as much to do with tarnishing a cherished era as with betraying potential sources.

title: After a Tornado, Solace on the Ball Field
description: RINGGOLD, Ga.  Around sunset 12 days ago, Slade Dale, a Ringgold High School ninth grader, took shelter in the bathroom with his sister and father as a tornado bore down on their rental home.

title: A Bleak Life, Cut Short at 4, Harrowing From the Start
description: She died in September by the ugliest means, weighing an unthinkable 18 pounds, half what a 4-year-old ought to. She withered in poverty in a home in Brooklyn where the authorities said she had been drugged and often bound to a toddler bed by her mother, having realized a bare thimbles worth of living.

title: Seeking Business, States Loosen Insurance Rules
description: Companies looking to do business in secret once had to travel to places like the Cayman Islands or Bermuda.

title: A Fatah-Hamas Deal
description: Ultimately, a successful Palestinian state will need to have all its people, from both the West Bank and Gaza, working together to build a stable and prosperous future. The recent agreement between the two main factions  Fatah, which leads the Palestinian Authority and has committed to peace with Israel, and Hamas, which has committed to Israels destruction  is not the answer.

title: Japans Nuclear Sites Raised U.S. Concerns, Cables Show
description: TOKYO  American officials repeatedly raised concerns about the security of Japanese nuclear plants from terrorist attacks but in at least one case were rebuffed by local officials, according to classified State Department cables made available by WikiLeaks.

title: Hawk and Hatchling Have Wide Audience, and a New Threat in an ID Tag
description: After braving weeks of harsh weather and the risk of accidentally eating a poisoned rat, a red-tailed hawk named Violet became a mother on Friday morning when an eyas, or baby hawk, hatched from one of her eggs. But over the weekend a new threat to Violet emerged  a metal wildlife band constricting blood flow to her leg and making it swell to at least twice its usual size.

title: With Legs Churning, Reyes Makes the Case to Stay
description: The five letters on the billboard in the deepest part of Citi Field read G-E-I-C-O, but they ought to read R-E-Y-E-S. The Mets ballpark is a monument to garish advertising, but also a playpen for Jose Reyes, their most exciting player.

title: When Wearing Golf Shoes Off the Course Means Breaking News
description: Im happy President Obama is a golfer; its great for the game. But he is setting some golfing benchmarks I did not expect.

title: The Kushner Flap: Much Ado About Nothing
description: On May 5, the historian Ellen Schrecker of Yeshiva University gave back an honorary degree she had received from John Jay College because the playwright Tony Kushner had been denied the same honor by the CUNY Board of Trustees. At the urging of a trustee who objected to Kushners views on Israel, the nomination, which had been forwarded by the faculty and administration of John Jay, was tabled. (Kushner had been informed of the impending honor.)

title: Family Feuds
description: The narrative of the Civil War revolves around the metaphor of neighbor against neighbor, brother against brother. But in the mountains of the Upper South, this was no metaphor: counties, towns and even families split between the two sides, and then set upon each other with gruesome fury in one of the bloodiest  and least understood  theaters of the war.

title: Tour Bus Driver Charged in Pedestrian Death on West Side
description: The driver of a tour bus was charged with drunken driving and vehicular manslaughter after being involved in an accident that killed a pedestrian on a West Side street, the police said Sunday.

title: Stories From the City
description: DEAR DIARY:

title: Whose Foreign Policy Is It?
description: For those with eyes to see, the daylight between the foreign policies of George W. Bush and Barack Obama has been shrinking ever since the current president took the oath of office. But last week made it official: When the story of Americas post-9/11 wars is written, historians will be obliged to assess the two administrations together, and pass judgment on the Bush-Obama era.

title: Beating Friend in Playoff, Glover Ends Drought
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  When he won last, Lucas Glover was one of golfs up-and-comers, a smooth-faced 20-something from the Deep South with a homespun wit and one tour victory. A long hitter who came into the 2009 United States Open at the Black Course at Long Islands Bethpage State Park as an unknown, he won over the locals and left town with his first major championship.

title: In Kansas Courtroom, Echoes of Rwanda Genocide
description: WICHITA, Kan.  The faces in the jury box are a cross-section of southern Kansas. The judge has a white beard, wears a bow tie and speaks in the straightforward language of the Great Plains. One defense lawyer favors cowboy boots and sometimes dons bolo ties.

title: Celtics Face Quandary in Injury to Rondo
description: WALTHAM, Mass.  In basketball, the elbow is a multipurpose tool. It is used for dribbling, shooting, passing and, occasionally, to send messages (as in, when they are thrown). It is useful to have two, and vital to have at least one in working order.

title: Three Hearts Butt Heads in One Marriage
description: Small stirrings of the heart and mind evoke delicate musical responses in A Ministers Wife, the lovingly composed chamber musical that opened on Sunday night at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater at Lincoln Center. Based on Candida, George Bernard Shaws comedy about the mysteries of marital love, the musical moves with a gentle step, keeping an intimate focus on its central characters as they circle one another in a cozy London study that becomes the site of a well-mannered moral and intellectual boxing match.

title: The Battle for Libya | May 8
description: Rebels and government forces clashed in Misurata on Sunday as the nation continued to wait out the struggle for power.

title: Brooklyn Teachers Joined at the Hip, and, to Some Pupils, by a Hyphen
description: In 1999, when Our Lady of Perpetual Help High School closed, Margaret Doria and Anita Dente feared it would be the end of them. For 33 years, Ms. Dente, the schools Italian teacher, and Ms. Doria, an English teacher, had worked together, car-pooled together to the school in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, finished each others sentences.

title: Privacy Disappears at a Trial About Rape
description: Possible rape victims have long been afforded an extra layer of protection from public scrutiny. The news media typically withhold their names, and law enforcement authorities are careful not to release information like tape recordings or public documents that may reveal their identities.

title: Corrections
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

title: Stars Gain Control of Online Images
description: When Tom Hanks posts a message to Twitter leading his 1.8 million followers to view a photo, perhaps of him in a candid moment on a movie set, they are sent to a special kind of site, one that gives him and other celebrities new control over their presence on social media.

title: Lottery Numbers
China to Improve Nuclear Safety
description: HONG KONG  China plans to improve its emergency procedures in response to potential problems that became apparent after Japans nuclear accident in March, the official newspaper, China Daily, reported Monday.

title: Battle Over Health Care Law Shifts to Federal Appellate Courts
description: A five-week flurry of federal appellate hearings on the constitutionality of the Obama health care law kicks off Tuesday in Richmond, Va., beginning the second round of a race to the Supreme Court among a multitude of litigants eager to strike down the presidents signature domestic achievement.

title: Democrats See Strategy to End Big Oil Tax Breaks
description: WASHINGTON  Linking two of the politically volatile issues of the moment, Senate Democrats say they will move forward this week with a plan that would eliminate tax breaks for big oil companies and divert the savings to offset the deficit.

title: Turning Golf Tradition on Its Head
description: In bright daylight, for all to see, Pat Gallagher handed a foursome a can of cooking spray to carry around on the golf course. It was as if he had given a batter a corked bat to take up to the plate.

title: Obama Elaborates on Bin Laden Raid
description: President Obama said in an interview broadcast Sunday that his advisers were conflicted over sending Navy Seal commandos after Osama bin Laden inside Pakistan, and that their intelligence suggested only a slightly better-than-even chance that Bin Laden was inside the walled compound where they found and killed him May 2.

title: Photo Replay: May 8
description: Images from the day in sports, from a marathon in Prague to hockey in Europe.

title: Obama Cant Depend On New Poll Numbers
description: Politically speaking, President Obama walks taller now that American commandos, on his order, found and killed Osama bin Laden.

title: Study in Korea Puts Autisms Prevalence at 2.6%, Surprising Experts
description: An ambitious six-year effort to gauge the rate of childhood autism in a middle-class South Korean city has yielded a figure that stunned experts and is likely to influence the way the disorders prevalence is measured around the world, scientists reported on Monday.

description: Lisa Houlgrave and her her husband, Simon Rogers, needed an apartment to match and antique mahogany table and a circa 1790 Hepplewhite serpentine-front sideboard.

description: shoddy \sh-de\ adjective

title: Volunteering in Tuscaloosa
description: The Red Cross, the Salvation Army, and the Southern Baptist Convention have made their presence known in Tuscaloosa, Ala., where they have been aiding in relief efforts following a series of tornadoes that struck the area.

title: For Some, Helping With Disaster Relief Is Not Just Aid, Its a Calling
description: RAINSVILLE, Ala.  Some couples spend retirement playing the nations best golf courses or hopping cruise ships. Not Marteen and Wiley Blankenship. They collect disasters the way other retirees collect passport stamps.

title: Smugglers Guide Illegal Immigrants With Cues via Cellphone
description: NOGALES, Ariz.  A group of migrants was hustling north through the southern Arizona desert the other night when one of their cellphones vibrated with a text message. Watch out, it warned. Things are hot up ahead. Take cover in the bushes.

title: Japan Reaffirms Nuclear Energy Use
description: TOKYO  Japan remains committed to nuclear power despite the crisis at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station, Prime Minister Naoto Kan indicated Sunday, as workers moved closer to repairing the crippled plant by opening the doors of a damaged reactor building.

description: Todays Times

title: Unemployed Mothers Day
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst.

title: In Madrid, Disparate Art Collections Collide
description: It can be a bit of a buzz kill to walk into one of those cozy little time-capsule museums that feature the private collection of an enlightened prince or recreate life in that particular place during an earlier century, only to discover that the museum has brought in contemporary art to dialogue with their historical holdings. Such presentations can easily break the spell of time travel that so-called house museums typically offer, without helping the visitor appreciate or understand the art of either epoch.

title: Q&A: Troubleshooting the BlackBerrys Battery
description: Q.

title: Ten Ideas for Two and a Half Men
description: Im imagining the Two and a Half Men writers these days thusly: four days without sleep, living off Ho Hos and Coke (thats the cake and the drink, people), clumps of hair strewn on the ground. As Bill Carter reported in The Times in late April, the writers have been given less than three weeks to come up with a newish version of their hit comedy. They are no doubt under just a teensy bit of pressure to produce something with the same award-winning, ratings-generating, money-raking-in qualities as the original, while also having to abruptly write out a major character, Charlie Harper, the jingle-writing cad brother played by Charlie Sheen until he was fired by Warner Brothers in March.

title: One on One: Ayesha Khanna, Futurist
description: Ayesha Khanna is the director of the Hybrid Reality Institute, a think tank that explores the practical implications of what she refers to as human-technology co-evolution in the Hybrid Age. The following is an edited transcript of an interview with Ms. Khanna.

title: Could This Be Alex Fergusons Finest Hour?
description: The only downside to coaching 12 league-title-winning teams, as Alex Ferguson is poised to do with Manchester United, is that there are people who sit back and compare them.

title: Chinese Crackdown on Domestic Critics Extends to Writer Barred From Traveling
description: HONG KONG  In the latest sign of Chinas continuing crackdown on domestic critics, a prominent Chinese writer has been barred from leaving China to attend a literary festival next week in Australia, the writer and festival officials said Monday.

title: Wheres the App to Help You Read the Menu?
description: Earlier this week, I was at Delfina, a really nice San Francisco restaurant. Everything on the menu looked either delicious or unintelligible. Did I want the salad with prosecco-black pepper zabaglione or the one with pancetta and Parmigiano frico? Was I in the mood for a main dish with sepia and ceci inzimino, or was I more in a gremolata mood?

title: This Week in Small Business: Profiting From Osama, Dealing With the Dollar
description: Whats affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners this week.

title: Do Fraternities Promote Misogyny?
description: Some studies show that fraternity members drink more and behave more lewdly toward women. What should colleges do about it?, asks the Room for Debate blog. Six experts give their opinions. Read the full discussion, then tell us what you think. Do fraternities promote misogyny (that is, a hatred, dislike or mistrust of women)?

title: Hertz Makes $2.24 Billion Bid for Dollar Thrifty
description: Hertz Global Holdings said on Monday that it had made a new bid for Dollar Thrifty Automotive Group, offering $2.24 billion.

title: Aside From the Vampires, Lincoln Film Seeks Accuracy
description: EDGARD, La.  Mary Todd Lincoln, in shimmering evening wear, calls to her husband. They are late. A gaunt, black-clad president strides to join her in a horse-drawn carriage bound for Fords Theater.

title: Libyan Woman Who Claimed Rape Flees to Tunisia
description: Eman al-Obeidy, the Libyan women who burst into a Tripoli hotel filled with journalists in late March and described a brutal rape by forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, fled to Tunisia on Thursday, CNN reports.

title: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Readers Respond to the Kushner Storm
description: Last weeks decision by the City University of New York board of trustees to withhold an honorary degree from the Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Tony Kushner because of one trustees concerns about Mr. Kushners views about Israel prompted many comments on NYTimes.com and letters to the editor. Readers on the ArtsBeat and City Room blogs called the situation shameful, sad, unfortunate and very Talibanish. Ben Brantley, the chief theater critic of The New York Times, wrote a Theater Talkback essay in support of Mr. Kushner, calling him one of our most high-reaching dramatists.

title: Private Equity Has a Horse in the Race
description: It turns out that DealBook has jurisdiction over Animal Kingdom, the winner of the Kentucky Derby.

title: LinkedIn On Track to Raise $274 Million
description: LinkedIn is on track to raise as much as $274.4 million in an initial public offering, according to a filing  on Monday.

title: Freescale Could Raise $944 Million in I.P.O.
description: Freescale Semiconductor Holdings, the chip maker acquired in 2006 in one of the largest technology buyouts ever, disclosed on Monday that it could raise $944 million in its initial public offering.

title: The Price Tag of a Safety School Enhances Its Allure
description: Spring is finally here in Colorado. The sun is back and with it, the flowers and songbirds. Its an auspicious feeling as I make my final choices that will guide the beginning of the rest of my life. Senior year is almost over, A.P. exams are close at hand, and all of my classes are winding down into review.

title: Monday Reading: Beating High Airfares with Hidden-City Ticketing
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: New Creative Director at Chlo
description: After months of half-hearted denials, Chlo announced Monday morning  on Twitter  that Hannah MacGibbon, its creative director, is leaving the company. Ms. MacGibbon, you may recall, was rumored to be on her last legs at Chlo even before her last runway show in March. She has worked with the company for 10 years, and was named its creative director in 2008.

description: Putin says were hooligans; Brazil accuses us of currency wars; and the Chinese are, well, being their usual charming selves. But whats going on in the international currency scene?

title: Among Thousands of Film Festivals, One About G.I.s
description: It began with a conversation six years ago between Brandon L. Millett, a public relations consultant, and his wife, a West Point graduate and Army reservist. Both were dismayed at how Hollywood was treating the Iraq and Afghanistan wars. So they came up with a plan: They would hold their own festival featuring films they thought portrayed troops in a more accurate, and positive, light.

title: Charges Are Resolved in Bieber 2009 Mall Stampede Case
description: From the department of long national nightmares that are now over: criminal charges against two key members of Justin Biebers team, stemming from a 2009 mall appearance that turned unruly, have been resolved, The Associated Press reported.
