title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: The Talented Player and the Ticking Clock
description: The arc of Derek Jeters career with the Yankees raises the eternal question for great athletes on the decline: When do you know when its time to go?

title: Nuance Shares Spike on Talk of Apple Deal
description: Shares of Nuance Communications surged by nearly 9 percent on Monday on speculation it was in deal talks with Apple.

title: Lag in Closing Plant Highlights Problems in Japan
description: TOKYO  Last week, Prime Minister Naoto Kan surprised many here when he suddenly moved to suspend the Hamaoka nuclear plant, long criticized as one of the most vulnerable and potentially dangerous nuclear power stations in Japan.

title: Unpeople
description: Via Digby, heres how an ultra-orthodox newspaper that never shows images of women dealt with the now-famous Situation Room picture:

title: Chinas Growing Overseas Portfolio
description: SHANGHAI  A study released last week by the Asia Society in New York forecast that over the coming decade China could invest as much as $2 trillion in overseas companies and projects, with a big share of that money heading to the United States.

title: Investigation Upgraded to 60,000 Mini Coopers for Power-Steering Loss
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said it had found enough reason to upgrade its investigation of a power-steering problem on nearly 60,000 Mini Coopers.

title: Huntsman Says No Self-Financing if He Runs
description: COLUMBIA, S.C.  If Jon M. Huntsman Jr. decides to join the field of Republican presidential candidates, he would be among the wealthiest contenders. But he vowed in an interview here that he would not use his familys fortune to pay for a campaign.

title: The New York Times Polling Practices: An Introduction
description: The New York Times and CBS News began the first newspaper-television polling partnership between two major national news organizations in 1975. A "CBS Evening News" report on American attitudes toward President Ford's response to the possible default of New York City was introduced by Walter Cronkite on Nov. 4, 1975. The next morning, readers of The Times saw a front-page article by Robert Reinhold titled, "Poll Finds Public Thinks Ford Minimizes City Peril."

title: Exonerated Inmates Fight Lawyers Lobbying Fees
description: DALLAS  If you are a wrongly convicted inmate in Texas and are exonerated, you stand to receive a very rewarding apology from the state.

title: Clarity Has A Well-Known Liberal Bias
description: As Jonathan Chait and Jamelle Bouie note, today was another VSP day at the Washington Post, with both the editorial page and the fact-checker tut-tutting at Democrats who insist on describing the Republican plan to dismantle Medicare as a plan to dismantle Medicare.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Tenet Rejects Community Healths Revised Bid
description: 6:08 p.m. | Updated

title: Gilt Groupe Valued at Roughly $1 Billion
description: In a bid to expand its e-commerce empire, the Gilt Groupe has raised $138 million in its latest financing round.

title: Video: Lunchtime for Baby Hawk
description: A Hawk Cam viewer, Jeff Folmsbee, grabbed this amazing video of Violet the red-tailed hawk feeding her 3-day-old baby a dead rat about 12:30 p.m. on Sunday. It is rather graphic.

title: Life and the Cosmos, Word by Painstaking Word
description: TEMPE, Ariz.  Like Einstein, he is as famous for his story as for his science.

title: Leak of C.I.A. Officer Name Is Sign of Rift With Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  For the second time in five months, the Pakistani authorities have angered the Central Intelligence Agency by tipping the Pakistani news media to the identity of the C.I.A. station chief in Islamabad, a deliberate effort to complicate the work of the American spy agency in the aftermath of the raid that killed Osama bin Laden, American officials said.

title: Ruth Bourdain Wins Humor Award, Invisibly
description: The big question in food-media circles last week was: Will he or she, or wont he or she?

title: Feudin and Fussin Over a Beverly Hillbillies Barbie Doll
description: Yall get a good intellectual property lawyer now, you hear? Come and listen to our story about a woman named Donna Douglas, an actress who for nine seasons kept herself fed by playing Elly May Clampett, the comely daughter of mountaineer Jed Clampett on The Beverly Hillbillies. But then one day, some 40 years after that hit comedy series went off the air, Ms. Douglas took notice of a Barbie doll designed to look like the Elly May character and filed suit against Barbie manufacturer Mattel, saying the toy uses her likeness without her permission, Reuters reported.

title: Gingrich to Announce Candidacy Online on Wednesday
description: Trying to tap into the spontaneity of Twitter and Facebook, Newt Gingrich, the former speaker of the House, will announce his campaign for the Republican nomination for president on Wednesday by way of the two popular social networking sites, his spokesman, Rick Tyler, said in a Twitter post on Monday.

title: Syria Proclaims It Now Has Upper Hand Over Uprising
description: DAMASCUS, Syria  The Syrian government has gained the upper hand over a seven-week uprising against the rule of President Bashar al-Assad, a senior official declared Monday, in the clearest sign yet that the leadership believes its crackdown will crush protests that have begun to falter in the face of hundreds of deaths and mass arrests.

title: YouTube Founders Acquire Web Analytics Firm
description: Chad Hurley and Steve Chen, the co-founders of YouTube, are on a shopping spree.

title: U.N. Urges Ships to Help Migrants in Mediterranean
description: PARIS  The United Nations refugee agency has urged the crews of ships in the Mediterranean to keep watch for unseaworthy vessels carrying migrants from war-torn Libya after a report that a ship with 600 people on board broke up just off the port of Tripoli on Friday.

title: Shirtless Schock on Cover of Mens Health
description: Representative Aaron Schock of Illinois, who already had the distinction of being the youngest member of the House, has a new feather in his cap (or maybe, his gym bag): he is the first member of Congress to appear shirtless on the cover of Mens Health magazine.

title: On Our Radar: Tigers Found in Indonesian Logging Concession
description: A video and photographs captured by the World Wide Fund for Nature show a dozen highly endangered tigers living within an Indonesian logging concession that could be cleared if a forest protection deal is not finalized, the group said in a statement. The Indonesian government has tentatively agreed to a two-year moratorium on new logging permits under a $1 billion deal with Norway to reduce the carbon emissions associated with deforestation, but the plan has yet to be signed into law. [Reuters]

title: Baptist Relief Effort
description: The Southern Baptist Convention volunteers are playing a central role in relief efforts for victims of tornadoes that struck Alabama.

title: Lieutenant Governor, Not Cuomo, Attends Gay Rights Rally
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo was conspicuously absent on Monday as more than 1,000 New Yorkers gathered at the State Capitol for the annual lobby day in support of gay rights.

title: Battle Hymn of the Small-Business Tiger Mother
description: As usual on this Mothers Day, I found myself not only being waited on by my husband and two sons but also reflecting on my own experiences of motherhood and how Im measuring up. As a mother and small- business owner, I often find myself squeezed by the double whammy of guilt: time spent in my business is time spent away from my kids, while time with my kids is time away from my business. They all need me, and the struggle to be there is ongoing.

title: The Best Investment Advice: Stop Losing Money
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: At DeMatha, Sports and Music Play Well Together
description: HYATTSVILLE, Md.  The new gym at DeMatha Catholic High is named for a Hall of Fame basketball coach and his wife, and its foyer is lined with championship banners for all the sports the school offers and usually dominates. On a recent afternoon, football players ran sprints under the gaze of coaches from Stanford, Virginia, West Virginia and Duke.

title: Reporters Notebook: Here They Stood, Until They Ran
description: MISURATA, Libya  The family photo albums, abandoned on the sand, lay open and fluttering in the desert wind. Around them were the personal items with which they had been packed: heaps of clothing, sandals, DVDs, combs, bottles of perfume, cooking utensils, razors, toothbrushes, several teapots, bundled blankets and a few biscuits, broken and dry. Every several yards a dropped suitcase rested on the dirt, looted bare.

title: Nine Is Enough
description: Melissa Fay Greene, who wrote the Lives essay in yesterdays magazine, was well qualified to fill the Mothers Day slot. She and her husband have six sons and three daughters. Or four children by birth and five from foreign orphanages. Divide it however you want; its nine kids. This column isnt about motherhood, exactly, but it shows the way a mother sees and, in Greenes case, how much she loves seeing her athletically gifted son Fisseha run like the wind. (Her children could field their own baseball team, but Fissehas sport of choice is soccer.)

title: Mississippi River Crowds Memphis
description: MEMPHIS  The Mississippi River was approaching levels it has not reached in over 70 years as it rolled through here on Monday, attracting a festive crowd of spectators to its banks but also sending residents from their homes in some parts of the city as the river shoved its tributaries aside to make way.

title: Donnelly to Run for Senate in Indiana
description: Representative Joe Donnelly, Democrat of Indiana, announced Monday that he would run for the Senate, declaring, I want to take the fight for American jobs and opportunity to the United States Senate.

title: Gender Neutral Parenting
description: Are gender differences nature or nurture?

title: A Jockeys View of the Derby
description: With the help of Trakus, which uses global positioning technology to keep track of every horse in a race, viewers can simulate what it was like for John Velazquez as he rode Animal Kingdom to victory in the Kentucky Derby on Saturday.

title: Should I Be a Jerk or a Human Being on Facebook?
description: I want to talk about Facebook as it pertains to identity and public image, but in order to do that, I have to tell a story first.

title: When Demented Patients Receive Feeding Tubes
description: I wrote a few months back about one of the toughest decisions families face as their elders falter: whether to allow insertion of a feeding tube. Somehow, this question seems to stir up even more doubt and anxiety than other medical interventions intended to prolong or improve life.When a senior nears death and cannot speak for herself, we may find it easier to say no to cardiopulmonary resuscitation or a ventilator than to say no to nutrition.

title: How We Could Lose in Libya
description: From a Kenneth Pollack essay making the case for Western escalation:

title: More on the Change at Chlo
description: In a phone interview, Geoffroy de la Bourdonnaye, chief executive at Chlo, shed a bit more light on Mondays news. First, he praised Hannah MacGibbon, saying: I think shes been extremely good for the house. She put the house back on track, no question about it. Ms. MacGibbon, who was promoted to creative director in 2008, helped restore attention to the feminine brand, which had briefly faltered under its previous designer.

title: Eating Local Honey Cures Allergies
description: THE FACTS

title: Lakers Go Out With a Thud
description: It is not generally fair to compare teams fates across sports. They are different games and circumstances, ruled by entirely different committees of the sporting gods. That said, well do it anyway because the Lakers and the Red Wings responded so remarkably differently this weekend when faced with the epitaph being written on their dynasties.

title: Disease of Kings Trickles Down to the Rest
description: A 55-year-old neighbor of mine was awakened in the wee hours of the morning recently with an excruciating pain in his right big toe that rendered him unable to walk. As happens in a classic attack of gout, the onset was sudden and the affected joint red and swollen.

title: Belgian Cyclist Dies After Crashing in Giro dItalia
description: Before flying to Italy for the Giro dItalia, one of cyclings three Grand Tours, Wouter Weylandt of Belgium made sure he was ready for the grueling three-week race.

title: One Door Closes, Another Opens
description: Our intrepid blogger was not named to the United States roster, which was announced Monday, for this summers Womens World Cup in Germany. She nevertheless filed this assessment.

title: A Band Program Apart
description: A high school where there are no band geeks? At DeMatha Catholic High School, many athletes also play music in the school's many competitive ensembles.

title: High Hopes for Porgy and Bess on Broadway
description: The American Repertory Theaters reconceived production of The Gershwins Porgy and Bess looks well-positioned for Broadway in the 2011-12 season, if Sundays three-hour developmental performance in Manhattan for potential investors and others was any indication.

title: Manhattan Theater Club Announces Its New Season
description: A Broadway production of a new work by David Auburn, a new play by Zoe Kazan and a new comedy featuring David Hyde Pierce will be presented during the 2011-2012 season of Manhattan Theater Club, the theater company said on Monday.

title: Why Success Starts With Failure
description: Tim Harford is a columnist for The Financial Times and the author of The Undercover Economist. Hes part of the growing cadre of journalists who try to write about economics in plain English. His new book, Adapt: Why Success Always Starts With Failure, will be published this week. Our conversation follows.

title: Cameras Capture Endangered Tigers in Sumatra Forest
description: If there is one thing that the Internet loves, it is video footage of cats.

title: Monday Motorsports: Vettel Returns to Winning Form at Turkish GP
description: Sebastian Vettel has secured pole position and won all but one race on the 2011 Formula One calendar. Judging from his performance this last weekend, Vettel intends to spare himself any further blemishes.

title: Caring for an Ill Spouse, and for Other Caregivers
description: Monday morning can be a downer, but for the dozen women and men in our support group, its a highlight of our week. Thats when we gather to speak candidly of what is unspeakable in polite society or even among closest friends and family.

title: The Obama Presidency, Post Bin Laden
description: The Times's John Harwood and Peter Baker discuss President Obama's position as he turns, somewhat strengthened, back to other issues.

title: Uncle Mo Sent to Farm; Archarcharch Is Retired
description: Uncle Mo, last years juvenile champion, was sent to WinStar Farm in Versailles, Ky., on Monday to convalesce as he tries to recover from a gastrointestinal infection. While his return to the races this year is possible, another leading 3-year-old, Archarcharch, has been retired after surgery on his injured left foreleg discovered cartilage damage.

title: Q. & A. With Stuart Elliott
description: Q: (Reader)

title: A Developer in Debt, and a Reeling Condo
description: Five years ago, when Mayra Kirkendall-Rodriguez decided to buy a two-and-a-half bedroom apartment at the Walden on East 130th Street in Harlem, she says she was happy to find a place that offered the promise of space, light and air, a lovely property on a quiet, residential block in an up-and-coming neighborhood. With a 400-square-foot terrace, easy access to transit and, perhaps more important, 24-hour security, it seemed like a good value for the money. Single at the time, she was often out late, she said, so knowing there would be a doorman on duty whenever she got home was a big, big plus.

title: New York Lottery Commercial
description: A commercial that is part of a new campaign for instant games sold by the New York Lottery.

title: It Only Takes an Instant, Lottery Ads Declare
description: The lottery that contributed Hey, you never know to the lengthy list of memorable advertising catch phrases vernacular is hoping to do it again, with a new slogan for its scratch-off games.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Beam Global Spirits and Wine, Deerfield, Ill., expanded its relationship with the Chicago office of Euro RSCG Worldwide by naming it to handle the creative duties for the introduction of Pucker, a flavored vodka. Spending has not been determined. Euro RSCG Chicago already creates campaigns for Beam Global brands like Effen vodka and Sauza tequila. Beam Global is part of Fortune Brands and Euro RSCG Worldwide is part of the Havas Worldwide unit of Havas.

title: Hertz Gets Back Into the Drivers Seat
description: Its not quite the action in the movie Fast Five, but the rental car wars just got interesting again.

title: Thai Premier to Dissolve Parliament; Elections Set for July 3
description: BANGKOK  The prime minister of Thailand said Monday that he had received the kings approval to dissolve Parliament seven months early. He set elections for July 3.

title: Marketing Junk to Kids  Or Not
description: New York City Department of Health and Mental Hygiene Mayor Michael R. Bloombergs attempt to fight fat.

title: Red Bulls Coach Says M.L.S. Roughness Is Overstated
description: LITTLE FALLS, N.J.  The word has gone out around the world that Major League Soccer is a physically demanding place to play. Whether it is because of a lack of technical ability or something peculiar to the game in North America  whatever  Red Bulls Coach Hans Backe is simply not buying the conventional wisdom.

title: The Obvious Rarefied
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists have generously proposed definitions of wit.

title: S.E.C. Documents Shed Light on Warner Deal
description: The Warner Music Group, home to Green Day, the Red Hot Chili Peppers and Led Zeppelin, reached a deal on Friday to sell itself to Access Industries for $3.3 billion. More details of the deal came to light on Monday in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Obama Fills a Gap in the Seals Tool Kit
description: Even the most serious of subjects  like the killing of a hunted terrorist leader  apparently needs its light moments.

title: A Clip From 'A.N.T. Farm'
description: China McClain performs in a clip from the Disney Channel series "A.N.T. Farm."

title: Another Early Show Producer Is Ousted
description: For the fifth time in less than four years, The Early Show on CBS is getting a new boss.

title: Video: President Obamas Political Capital
description: Read John Harwoods related column Obama Cant Depend On New Poll Numbers in Mondays New York Times.

title: Sundhage Names U.S. Roster for Womens World Cup
description: Coach Pia Sundhage on Monday named the 21 players who will represent the United States in the 2011 FIFA Womens World Cup. This will be the first World Cup for 12 squad members, while the 9 others will be returning to the tournament. The two-time world champions will be aiming to win their first Womens World Cup since hosting the event in 1999.

title: As Special House Race Intensifies, Washington Sends Backup
description: DEPEW, N.Y.  This village of strip malls, car dealerships and working-class neighborhoods is an unlikely stage for a battle between the two major parties in Washington.

title: Like Mother, Like Daughter: Bristol Palin Has a Reality TV Show
description: Following in her mothers footsteps, Bristol Palin is going to star in her own reality television show.

title: Changing Like Winds, With Gusto
description: The Miller Theaters Composer Portraits series covered a lot of ground this year, as it moved from Pierre Boulezs elaborate serialist explorations to Julia Wolfes post-Minimalist string works and Chaya Czernowins arcane experiments, with other stylistic detours along the way. The series ended on Thursday evening with chamber music by Joan Tower, a composer whose directness and eclecticism make her music instantly accessible, and whose imaginative sense of development  often by way of insistent but evolving rhythms and surprising juxtapositions  gives it an original, distinctive personality.

title: Jury in Galleon Case Hears Taped Calls Again
description: 8:50 p.m. | Updated

title: Democrats Press Boehner on Debt Ceiling
description: With Speaker John A. Boehner preparing to deliver a major economic speech in New York on Monday night, Democrats raced to get out in front of the talk by pressing Mr. Boehner to assure members of the financial community that Republicans would raise the federal debt ceiling this summer.

title: Risks: Busy Business Traveler? Carry a Pharmacy
description: A new study confirms what many corporate road warriors already know: Frequent business travel takes a toll on ones health.

title: House Financial Services Committee Goes Digital
description: The financial crisis prompted Congress to offer a $700 billion banking bailout, a sweeping overhaul of financial regulations  and now a blog.

title: Numberplay: Mission Shortest Path
description: In the above problem, you had to determine the shortest distance, which, assuming that the speed of the vehicle was constant over the terrain, would also result in the shortest travel time. In the next mission, you have to specifically determine the path that takes the least time.

title: YouTube Expands Video Rental Service
description: Updated 5:48 p.m.: Adding details about the new movie rentals and correcting the spelling of Salar Kamangar, the head of YouTubes, last name.

title: Screening: New Threat Rises Between Mammograms
description: Some breast cancers detected between regular screenings were simply missed on the patients last mammogram. But a majority found during the interim periods cant be found on previous scans at all.

title: Recent Poll Shows Gingrich Has Work to Do
description: As a former speaker of the House and contributor to Fox News, Newt Gingrich will enter the presidential race this week as one of the better-known Republicans on the list of possible contenders. But a New York Times/CBS News poll conducted last month found that that may not necessarily be to his advantage.

title: Sothebys to Offer a Founding Fathers Illicit Notebooks
description: In the annals of injudicious disappearances from Manhattans mean streets, before there was Judge Crater there was Judge Lansing. And, before Judge John Lansing Jr. vanished in 1829, not so far from where Judge Joseph Force Crater went missing 99 years later, Judge Lansing was already famous  as a Founding Father and New York delegate to the Constitutional Convention in 1787.

title: Video Game Level Replicates Bin Laden Compound
description: Reading the news coverage of Osama bin Ladens death last week sometimes sounded like the narrative of a new video game. There were the secret radar-evading government helicopters, the highly trained war dog and the fearless members of Seal Team 6, the best of the best Navy Seal units, whichstormed Bin Ladens compound.

title: Fixated by Screens, but Seemingly Nothing Else
description: The mother had brought in a note from her sons elementary school teacher: Dear doctor, I think this child needs to be tested for attention deficit disorder.

title: Hazy Recall as a Signal Foretelling Depression
description: OXFORD, England  The task given to participants in an Oxford University depression study sounds straightforward. After investigators read them a cue word, they have 30 seconds to recount a single specific memory, meaning an event that lasted less than one day.

title: Identifying Another Victim, Officials Raise Possibility of a 2nd L.I. Killer
description: Long Island residents, already grappling with the notion that a serial killer has been dumping bodies in their midst, got more disturbing news on Monday: a second serial killer may have been at work.

title: Quebec to Spend Billions to Develop Resources in Northern Regions
description: OTTAWA  Quebec province, anticipating renewed interest in its natural resources, rolled out on Monday an ambitious 25-year plan to develop its vast but largely untouched northern and Arctic regions.

title: Dean Heller Sworn In to Senate
description: The Senate welcomed its newest member on Monday with the swearing in of Dean Heller, who on Friday was a Republican congressman from Nevada. Mr. Heller was appointed by Gov. Brian Sandoval of Nevada to replace John Ensign, who resigned from the Senate last month under an ethics cloud before finishing his term.

title: Reader Idea | From 19th-Century Factories to 21st-Century Sweatshops
description: Here is another in our Great Ideas From Readers series.

title: The Goth-Pop Revival
description: For those of us who remember this sound from the first time around, its both eerie and nostalgically pleasurable to listen to Austra and Zola Jesus channeling Siouxsie Sioux. Austras new album comes out next week; Zola Jesus, whom I sadly missed in New York, is currently on tour.

title: Henzab
description: Name given by Libyan rebels to homemade caltrops (anti-personnel weapons designed to puncture boots and tyres).

title: Meryl Streep to Participate in Alan Aldas Marie Curie Play
description: Opening night of the World Science Festival in New York is going to feature a more glittering lineup of stars than most Broadway shows. Meryl Streep, Amy Adams, Allison Janney, Liev Schreiber, David Morse and Bill Camp are among the actors coming together on June 1 at Alice Tully Hall to participate in a reading of a new play written by Alan Alda about the scientist Marie Curie.

title: F.D.I.C. Chairwoman to Leave in July
description: Sheila C. Bair, one of the banking industrys most influential regulators and outspoken critics during the financial crisis, said on Monday that she planned to step down as chairwoman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation on July 8.

title: Regimens: Looking Twice at Supplements for Infants
description: Nearly one in 10 babies are given supplements or plant-based teas to soothe colic or help with teething during the first year of life, even though the products are unproven and may contain contaminants or spur allergies, a new study says.

title: Who Made That Campbells Soup Label?
description: In 1962, Andy Warhol produced Campbells Soup Cans: 32 paintings, each representing a flavor of Campbells condensed soup. With these works, Warhol took on the tradition of still-life painting, declaring a familiar household brand of packaged food a legitimate subject in the age of Post-War economic recovery, according to Christies. Warhol appropriated the famous soup can and reinvented it as a work of art. He can be credited with converging the world of high art and supermarket branding, propelling the pop-art movement forward and possibly even boosting the sales of canned soup, but the label that he rode to stardom was not his design at all.

title: Stay-at-Home Moms and the Need for Credit
description: If you are a stay-at-home mom (or dad) and want a credit card, you should consider applying for one, pronto. A pending change in the way card companies must evaluate applications will probably make it much harder for people who dont have their own, independent income to get one.

title: Inside the Groupon-Live Nation Deal
description: The daily-deals site Groupon is pairing with Live Nation Entertainment, an online ticket seller, to create GrouponLive, a discount ticket seller. In an interview with CNBC, Groupons chief executive, Andrew Mason, and Live Nations chief executive, Michael Rapino, discuss the rationale behind the deal and their strategy to grow the pie of online event marketing.

title: Attention Problems, Except for Screens
description: Why is it that children with attention deficit problems at school can be held in rapt attention by a video game or television program?

title: Hot Type
description: The latest entry in the movement to free Ai Weiwei, the Chinese dissident artist who has been detained since April, is this T-shirt, the heavy black bars of which speak volumes about free speech. Its the creation of Playtype, a self-described online type foundry that was established by e-Types, a Copenhagen design agency, to showcase over 20 years of type design, including commissioned works for fonts created out of pure passion and typographical heartache. E-Types collaborated on the project with the architecture office Bjarke Ingels Group and V1 Gallery in Copenhagen. Late last year, Playtype opened a concept store  which will operate for one year only, until Dec. 1  in Copenhagens trendy Vesterbro neighborhood, a former red-light district. The stores wares, which include the aforementioned T-shirt and type-adorned notebooks, wine labels and ceramic mugs, are not sold online, alas, but inquiries are invited at info@playtype.com. You can also download the T-shirt graphic here.

title: Infant Deaths Drop After Midwives Undergo Inexpensive Training
description: Giving midwives simple training has already been shown to save newborns lives, and a new study in Zambia has found that it can be remarkably cost-effective as well.

title: An Insider Views China, Past and Future
description: Its been four decades since President Richard M. Nixon sent Henry A. Kissinger to Beijing to re-establish contact with China, an ancient civilization with which the United States, at that point, had had no high-level diplomatic contact for more than two decades. Since then the cold war has ended; the Soviet Union (a threat to both China and the United States and a spur to Sino-American cooperation) has come unwound; and economic reform in China has transformed a poverty-ridden, poorly educated nation into a great power that is playing an increasingly pivotal role in the globalized world.

title: Woman Who Accused Militiamen of Rape Has Fled Libya
description: CAIRO  A Libyan woman who became a symbol of her countrys repression after security forces tried to silence her accusations that Qaddafi militiamen had raped her said on Monday that she had escaped to neighboring Tunisia.

title: TimesCast | May 9, 2011
description: The rift between the U.S. and Pakistan escalates, as American officials blame Pakistan for releasing the name of the CIA station chief in Islamabad to Pakistani news media.

title: The iPad in Your Hand: As Fast as a Supercomputer of Yore
description: Its common wisdom that the computer you can hold in the palm of your hand today is as powerful as a computer from years ago that filled an entire room.

title: Live Nation Teams Up With Groupon Amid Worries About Concert Season
description: Live Nation Entertainment, the worlds biggest concert promoter, is teaming with the popular coupon site Groupon to sell discounted tickets.

title: Floridas Rejected Rail Funds Head North
description: If there had been a piata in Pennsylvania Station on Monday, it would have borne a resemblance to Floridas governor, Rick Scott.

title: A Parade of Astronauts and Corvettes
description: A group of current and former NASA astronauts gathered in Cocoa Beach, Fla., on Saturday to commemorate the 50th anniversary of Alan Shepards suborbital flight. The event was marked by a parade, with the astronauts riding in a fleet of Chevrolet Corvettes that included examples of the sports cars six design iterations.

title: Unease About Greece Grows as S.&P. Downgrades Its Debt Again
description: ATHENS  Worries about Greeces intractable debt problem deepened on Monday, stoking fears that the country remains on a path to fiscal disaster and that European leaders do not have a convincing plan to prevent a default.

title: JPMorgan Hires Former Barclays M.&A. Banker
description: JPMorgan Chase has hired Drago Rajkovic, a Wall Street veteran who most recently worked for Barclays Capital, to lead the banks technology-related mergers and acquisitions group, according to an internal e-mail obtained by DealBook.

title: The Morning Line: All Eyes on Graham Motion
description: The praise continued Monday for Graham Motion, the trainer of Kentucky Derby winner, Animal Kingdom. Joe Drape in the New York Times writes that Animal Kingdom is trained by an Englishman who has never been cited for violating a medication rule and believes a horse should be allowed to be a horse as much as possible. Drape adds: The trainer came to the United States 30 years ago but adheres to European principles of horsemanship. His base is a European-styled training center in Maryland, where his stock hacks, or gallops, on wooded trails or runs in pastures and is turned out in paddocks. Last year, he was one of two trainers on the top 20 earnings list without a medication violation.

title: Russian President Reaches Out to Nations World War II Allies
description: MOSCOW  President Dmitri A. Medvedev said Monday, at an annual celebration of the defeat of Nazi Germany, that a rising generation of young Russians were working to reinforce bonds of friendship, cooperation and fraternity with the countries that fought alongside Russia.

title: Lightening the Paper Load
description: Conferences and trade shows seem to generate vast amounts of paperwork  booklets, programs, handouts, guides. But as increasing numbers of business travelers carry smartphones and tablets, organizers of these events are responding by developing mobile applications.

title: As Rodriguez Slumps, So Does the Yankees Offense
description: ARLINGTON, Tex.  Kevin Long, the Yankees hitting coach, considers Alex Rodriguez as being more in tune with his mechanics than any other player he has worked with. When Rodriguez is swinging well, he can explain exactly why. And when he is not, he is a master troubleshooter. At least, usually.

title: Local Honey for a Runny Nose
description: Among allergy sufferers, there is a widespread belief that locally produced honey can help build immunity to local allergens. The honey, after all, is made by bees that pollinated local plants.

title: Guerrilla Culinary Brigade Finds a Permanent Home
description: Alan Philips and Jason Apfelbaum, who have been running pop-up dinners in parking lots and similar venues with their company, Guerrilla Culinary Brigade, are settling down. Late next week they plan to open Co-Op Food & Drink in the space that had been Thor in the Hotel on Rivington. This is my first real restaurant, Mr. Philips said, but I havent given up on the pop-up dinners either.

title: Whole Wheat Spaghetti With Green Garlic and Chicory
description: This dish is inspired by a classic oil and garlic pasta. Ive added chicory, a bitter green that is much loved in southern Italy but underused here. Its sold with lettuces in the supermarket, often called escarole or curly endive. Chicory contains a type of soluble fiber called inulin, which some studies suggest may have a positive effect on blood sugar levels.

title: BMW M1, Painted by Frank Stella, Heading to Auction
description: Visitors to the atrium of the IBM Building, at 56th Street and Madison Avenue, encounter a brightly colored BMW M1 painted by the artist Frank Stella in 1979. Many pause and pose for mobile phone photos, and with good reason.

title: Asparagus With Green Garlic
description: When you saut or roast asparagus in hot olive oil, the asparagus will have a much more concentrated flavor than it would if steamed or blanched. Here I add the garlic to the pan once the asparagus is just about done, so that the garlic cooks only long enough to soften and sweeten.

title: 'The Man Who Shot Liberty Valance'
description: A. O. Scott discusses how truth and justice are sacrificed as order is brought to a lawless land in John Ford's 1962 film.

title: Neanderthals and Early Humans May Not Have Mingled Much
description: An improvement in the dating of fossils suggests that the Neanderthals, a heavily muscled, thick-boned human species adapted to living in ice age Europe, perished almost immediately on contact with the modern humans who started to enter Europe from the Near East about 44,000 years ago. Until now bones from several Neanderthal sites have been dated to as young as 29,000 years ago, suggesting there was extensive overlap between the two human species. This raised the question of whether there had been interbreeding between humans and Neanderthals, an issue that is still not resolved.

title: Obama on Bin Laden Mission Lifts 60 Minutes
description: President Obamas interview on 60 Minutes about the mission that killed Osama bin Laden helped lift the program to No. 1 in the ratings on Sunday night as 13.8 million people tuned in to the broadcast, according to Nielsens estimates.

title: A Lighter, Lovelier Garlic
description: I first encountered green garlic one summer in Provence. I was working on a garlic cookbook, so I bought lots of it every time I went to the market. But one day in June I came across an unfamiliar variety. The generous cloves  enrobed in several layers of soft, moist, pinkish skin  were almost juicy, and their flavor was less pungent than that of regular garlic.

title: A Change in Fortune for the West Coast?
description: As I wrote on Friday in the Bay Area edition of The Times, residents of the West Coast have been locally sheltered from the impact of accelerated sea level rise.

title: Boehner Lays Out Path on Debt Limit
description: House Speaker John A. Boehner plans to tell the Economic Club of New York on Monday night that an increase in the federal debt limit should be accompanied by spending cuts that exceed any rise in borrowing power.

title: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Yemen, Afghanistan, Pakistan and Japan.

title: Urban Twisters
description: Q. If big tornadoes hit Manhattan, would the skyscrapers break up the winds, or would some of them be destroyed?

title: Setti Warren to Challenge Scott Brown in 2012
description: Setti Warren, the mayor of Newton, Mass., announced Monday that he would seek the Democratic nomination to challenge Senator Scott Brown next year in what will likely be a crowded primary race.

title: Burson-Marsteller Heads North of Nine
description: A leading public relations agency is carving out a specialty from its global technology practice.

title: Tracking Lineage Through a Bramble
description: Those stars among the hunter-gatherers of fossils related to human origins, Donald C. Johanson and Richard Leakey, returned last week to the American Museum of Natural History in New York, the scene of a bitter televised brawl between the two 30 years ago. They were older, presumably wiser and definitely much more temperate. The title of the program, Human Evolution and Why It Matters: A Conversation with Leakey and Johanson, signaled that this was not to be a re-enactment.

title: Pictures of the Day: Yemen and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Yemen, Afghanistan, Pakistan and Japan.

title: Living on Thin Ice
description: Relentless warming in Antarctica is taking a toll on Adlie and emperor penguins.

title: In a Changing Antarctica, Some Penguins Thrive as Others Suffer
description: ROSS ISLAND, Antarctica  Cape Royds, home to the southernmost colony of penguins in the world, is a rocky promontory overlaid with dirty ice and the stench of pinkish guano. Beyond the croaking din of chicks pestering parents for regurgitated krill lies the Ross Sea, a southern extension of the Pacific Ocean that harbors more than one-third of the worlds Adlie penguin population and a quarter of all emperor penguins, and which may be the last remaining intact marine ecosystem on Earth.

title: Three-Word Parenting Lessons
description: On the Web site of Psychology Today this month, the psychologist Jim Taylor comes clean.

title: French, but Conversant in Many Genres
description: The pipe organ is a mysterious and complex instrument, whose flight deck of keys, knobs, tabs and pedals require the performer to be pianist, pilot and tap dancer simultaneously. Organists often work diligently in the shadows, their consoles hidden from view. But the handsome new Manton Memorial Organ at the Church of the Ascension in Greenwich Village was on full display for its inauguration on Thursday evening, with a concert by Jon Gillock.

title: Waiting and the Deficit (Wonkish)
description: What DC considers a despicable scare tactic: accurately describing a proposal to dismantle Medicare.

title: Where Do You Eat at the Park?
description: Its spring in New York  a time when parks fill up with city dwellers whove been indoors, patiently waiting for the warm sun to show its face. Among the citys great perks are its parks, and with parks come outdoor concerts, Frisbee matches, sunbathing, nature-watching and last but far from least, alfresco dining.

title: Cuban Dancers Complete a 5-Decade Trip to New York
description: HAVANA  At the humid, spare studios of Danza Contempornea de Cuba here last week, two dozen dancers rolled their spines forward, turning their outstretched arms in their sockets as drummers beat a slow, syncopated song dedicated to the Yoruba deity Obatal.

title: Distracted Driving: An Answer Perhaps?
description: There are at least two irrefutable facts about the practice of people communicating by cellphones while driving cars. First, it is a big problem, with studies estimating that more than 500,000 traffic accidents and 2,600 deaths a year are caused by cellphone-distracted drivers. No one has documented the problem as thoroughly as my colleague, Matt Richtel.

title: PBS Revamps Schedule of Friday Night Shows
description: PBS is making changes to its Friday-night schedule this fall, trimming its public affairs programming and adding a nine-week run of arts performances, the public broadcaster announced on Monday. The Friday newsmagazine Need to Know will shrink to a half-hour, beginning Sept. 16, from an hour, and take on a new focus on issues related to the 2012 election. On Oct. 14 the new PBS Arts Fall Festival will start its run of offerings from around the country, including The Little Mermaid From San Francisco Ballet; Women Who Rock, based on an exhibition at the Rock n Roll Hall of Fame in Cleveland; and Give Me the Banjo, narrated by Steve Martin, exploring the roots of American music. Other changes this fall include the addition of a Wednesday broadcast for the Sunday-night staple Nature.

title: Featherweight Relative of the T. Rex Is Found
description: Researchers working in the western Gobi Desert in Mongolia have discovered the almost complete skeleton of a tyrannosaurid dinosaur that was less than 3 years old when it died, younger and smaller than any previously known. The animal, Tarbosaurus bataar, is the closest relative of Tyrannosaurus rex, the predator that lived at the same time in North America.

title: An Eclectic Virtuoso
description: Gary Lucas has a wide-ranging body of work that has channeled musical traditions from Poland, China, Israel, India and elsewhere.

title: Songwriter With a Global Guitar
description: The music business has never quite known what to make of Gary Lucas. Go to a site for streaming or downloading songs, and you may find his music consigned to a vague category called other. Look him up in standard reference works, and hes likely to be referred to as a legendary left-field guitarist whose work is eclectic or just plain eccentric.

title: In Digestion, Leeches Show Sophisticated Side
description: Some leeches like it cool, but some like it hot. It all depends on whether they are hungry.

title: Sports Replay: May 9
description: Whether it be soccer, table tennis or horse racing, a view of the day in sports is firmly focused on the eyes.

title: Helping Jackson Travel His Path
description: Jerry Krause no longer speaks to Phil Jackson, the N.B.A. coaching legend he helped create. Its personal, he said, and it really doesnt much matter anymore, as long as he knows that Jackson is doing the right thing and checking in on the man who will always professionally connect them.

title: Finding High Spirits in Shakespeare
description: To follow his shattering adaptation of Othello, Giuseppe Verdi and his trusted late-career librettist, Arrigo Boito, turned to another Shakespeare play. Not King Lear, which had tantalized Verdi for years. Not The Tempest, whose storm and complex father-daughter relationship must have appealed to him.

title: Staten Islands Secret Oasis
Getty Trusts Pick for President Surprises Art World
description: The J. Paul Getty Trust in Los Angeles, which emerged from years of instability only to lose its leader to a fatal heart attack last summer, surprised the art world on Monday by announcing that James Cuno, the director of the Art Institute of Chicago and a highly respected figure in the museum world, would take over as the trusts president and chief executive in August.

title: Morgan Stanley Lost Money on Just 3 Days in Quarter
description: The highs werent quite as high. And the lows were not quite as low.

title: Japans Nuclear Future in the Balance
description: TOKYO  The accident at the Fukushima Daiichi power plant has done more than spew radiation into the air and sea and force tens of thousands of people to evacuate their homes. It has blown a big hole in Japans energy policy, which had assumed that nuclear power would supply a growing part of the countrys needs.

title: A Lot of Hot Water, but Not Much Is Being Used to Produce Electricity
description: YANAIZU, Japan  As visitors to any of Japans thousands of hot springs know, this country is sitting on a lot of very hot water.

title: Lakers Bitter Exit Evokes 1991 Pistons
description: There was a strange symmetry in how Phil Jacksons 20-season coaching run ended Sunday in Dallas, with his Lakers reprising the role of Coach Chuck Dalys Pistons against Jacksons rising Bulls in 1991.

title: Poker as a Game of Skill
description: Is poker a game of luck or skill? Thats the question the economists Steven D. Levitt (of Freakonomics fame) and Thomas J. Miles explore in a new working paper published with the National Bureau of Economic Research.

title: A Book Publisher Finds Ready Conversation
description: IVE been a business traveler for most of my career, but I started to fly what seems like nonstop about 15 years ago. I like to travel for business because I like meeting people, but Im not a great flier.

title: Fountains of Optimism for Life Way Out There
description: For those who hunt for life on other worlds, water in its liquid form is perhaps the leading indicator. Life as we know it on Earth is based on water and carbon. And if organisms can prosper here in nasty environments  in geysers, in the depths of the sea, in toxic waste, in water that is too hot, too cold, too acidic or too alkaline  why could they not prosper out there?

title: A Green Banner for Puerto Rican Day
description: The National Puerto Rican Day Parade is going green.

title: Calm Demeanor, Assertive Sounds
description: The trumpeter Shane Endsley exudes a calm, steadying demeanor on the bandstand, and his tone, dry and matte, falls a long way from brassy effulgence. Hes an interior and economical soloist, averse not only to empty flash but also to wasted effort. And yet his music doesnt come across as rigid, cold or self-effacing. Quite the opposite, actually.

title: By the Way, Meet Vera Stark
description: Photos of Lynn Nottages new play at Second Stage Theater.

title: Unconscious Lessons of a Jazzman
description: MONTCLAIR, N.J.  Fred Hersch is a jazz pianist who has long since gone beyond jazz, and his irreducible gift or skill is for solo playing. The enormous variety in his touch, and his sophisticated sense of musical narrative through arranging and improvising, render him special. Beyond that, hes a composer in several idioms, a bandleader for groups of many sizes, and a setter of texts to music. A jazz pianist cant do much better.

title: Critics Choice: New CDs
description: THE ANTLERS

title: Music in Review
description: MUSICIANS FROM MARLBORO

title: Tonsils and Weight (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: With Help From NATO, Libyan Rebels Gain Ground
description: QARYAT AZ ZURAYQ, Libya  Rebel fighters made significant gains Monday against forces loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in both the western and eastern areas of the country, in the first faint signs that NATO airstrikes may be starting to strain the government forces.

title: Offering Lost Words (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: All Exposure Counts (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: The New Yorker Begins to Offer iPad Subscriptions
description: David Remnick, the editor of The New Yorker, sat in a conference room on the 11th floor at Cond Nast headquarters with Robert A. Sauerberg Jr., the president of Cond Nast, and Eddy Cue, the vice president for Internet services at Apple. The latest print issue, with an erased image of Osama Bin Laden on the cover, was on the table an inch away from its digital sibling, the new New Yorker app for the iPad, which was made available on Monday for subscription.

title: Wars Legacy (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Bronx Zoo, 9:44 A.M.
description: Enutifa Gamia, 10, and Jordan Gamia, 4, posed with the Bronx Zoos mascot, Jose the beaver, before Enutifa, who is from Togo, took the citizenship oath in a ceremony at the zoo at which 35 children from 14 countries became citizens.

title: Ann Curry to Become a Co-Host of Today
description: Ann Curry will replace Meredith Vieira as co-host of the Today show, NBC announced Monday, confirming much-anticipated changes in the cast of its perennially dominant morning show.

title: An Irresistible Austrian Riesling Beckons
description: LET me immediately declare my bias: I love Austrian rieslings. I say that knowing Im speaking very generally, but dont we always about wine?

title: Wright Has Been Playing in Pain
description: DENVER  Mets Manager Terry Collins said that David Wright had been playing through back pain ever since he and Carlos Lee of the Houston Astros collided at third base on April 19 as Wright went to apply a tag. Collins said Wright had played down the extent of the injury, but Collins believes it has affected Wright at the plate.

title: New Call in Albany to Quit U.S. Immigration Program
description: A group of 38 state lawmakers sent a letter to Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Monday urging him to remove New York from a national program that has been a cornerstone of the Obama administrations immigration enforcement efforts.

title: The Real Cost of Airline Travel Remains a Mystery, for Now
description: The Transportation Department is moving to require airlines to release much more detailed information about all those extra fees theyve been collecting in recent years.

title: LinkedIn and Freescale Join Surge of I.P.O.s
description: As investor appetite for initial public offerings grows, dozens of technology companies from start-ups to stalwarts are prepping for their stock market debuts.

title: Study Links Flammable Gas in Water and Nearby Drilling
description: Researchers from Duke University say they have found a clear link between gas drilling in Pennsylvania and Upstate New York and high levels of flammable methane in drinking water  a situation that became a prominent talking point in the drilling debate after flaming faucets were featured in the documentary Gasland.

title: Bin Laden Aftermath: A Rush of Emotion
description: To the Editor:

title: N.F.L. Continues Effort to Maintain Lockout
description: The N.F.L. asked a federal appeals court Monday to vacate a District Courts preliminary injunction that briefly lifted the two-month lockout and send the case back to the District Court.

title: Census Data Reveals a Shift in Patterns of Childbearing
description: WASHINGTON  College-educated women are waiting longer to have children than those without a college education, according to new data from the Census Bureau.

title: Boehner Outlines Demands on Debt Limit Fight
description: WASHINGTON  Speaker John A. Boehner said Monday that Republicans would insist on trillions of dollars in federal spending cuts in exchange for their support of an increase in the federal debt limit sought by the Obama administration to prevent a government default later this year.

title: Coca-Cola in the Hide-Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Early Child Care
description: To the Editor:

title: A Carbon Fee, Not a Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Risks of Taking Hormones
description: To the Editor:

title: Emergency Alert System Expected for Cellphones
description: WASHINGTON  The emergency broadcast system is coming to cellphones.

title: On Par: A Cure for the Slice?
description: Bill Pennington, golf reporter for The New York Times, gets a few golfers to try out the new Polara golf ball, which claims to straighten out that nasty slice.

title: A Golf Ball That Wont Slice Comes With a Catch: Its Illegal
description: EDGEWATER, N.J.  Ducks quack, dogs bark, cab drivers honk and golfers slice. Among the basic truths of the planet: 80 percent of golfers cannot hit their tee shots where they aim.

title: Social Networks Offer a Way to Narrow the Field of Friends
description: There are times when you just have to tell your friends about something  but not necessarily your Facebook friends.

title: In Reversal, City University Trustees Approve Honorary Degree for Tony Kushner
description: In a hastily convened meeting of their executive committee, City University of New York trustees approved an honorary degree for Tony Kushner on Monday night to try to quell widespread criticism over the boards decision last week to withhold it because of concerns about the playwrights views on Israel.

title: Electric Avenue
description: THE American response to rising gas prices has been depressingly predictable. Were shocked to see prices top $4 a gallon, as if its never happened before. We demand that something be done  not to reduce our dependence on oil, but to cut the cost of a fill-up. Fortunately the White House is standing behind a goal that could genuinely transform the nations automotive fleet: putting one million electric vehicles on the road by 2015.

title: Once Vultures, Unwanted Suitors Like Hertz Now Seen as Strategists
description: When it comes to deals, attitude matters.

title: Physicist Groups Study Raises Doubts on Capturing Carbon Dioxide From Air
description: Over the last few years, some of worlds brightest minds have become fascinated with a seemingly simple idea: easing the threat of climate change by pulling carbon dioxide out of the air.

title: Why Greece Should Reject the Euro
description: Washington

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,555 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It recently confirmed the death of the following American:

title: Rebels Gain Ground in Libya
description: The Free Libya Forces advance against those loyal to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in both the western and eastern areas of the country.

title: Google to Start a Cloud-Based Music Player
description: A month after Amazon angered music labels by starting a cloud-based music player without their cooperation, Google is doing the same thing.

title: Els, With Hope for More, Is Hall of Famer
description: ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla.  A gentle giant from Johannesburg, and a self-proclaimed former mean guy from Manhattan who grew up on Seaman Avenue in Inwood. One of the most recognizable athletes ever produced by Japan, and a former president of the United States. A Scot born in St. Andrews who emigrated to the United States, and an Armenian immigrants son and one of the greatest producers in the history of televised sports.

title: Antipsychotic Drugs Called Hazardous for the Elderly
description: Nearly one in seven elderly nursing home residents, nearly all of them with dementia, are given powerful atypical antipsychotic drugs even though the medicines increase the risks of death and are not approved for such treatments, a government audit found.

title: Bloggingheads: Was He Worth It?
description: Mike Konczal, left, of the Roosevelt Institute and Megan McArdle of The Atlantic reflect on the meaning of Bin Laden's death.

title: Gunter Sachs, Ex-Husband of Brigitte Bardot, Dies at 78
description: Gunter Sachs, a wealthy German-born art collector who was fodder for gossip columns in the 1960s for his playboy antics and his brief marriage to Brigitte Bardot, died on Saturday at his home in the Swiss Alpine resort of Gstaad. He was 78.

title: Pursuing Pardon, Steinbrenner Aided F.B.I.
description: George Steinbrenner, the Yankees principal owner, cooperated with the Federal Bureau of Investigation on national security cases and was willing to let it stage an organized-crime raid at Yankee Stadium, according to documents released Monday by the F.B.I, less than a year after Steinbrenners death.

title: Willard S. Boyle, Father of Digital Eye, Dies at 86
description: Willard S. Boyle, who won the 2009 Nobel Prize in Physics for helping to develop a device that is at the heart of virtually every camcorder, digital camera and telescope in use, died on Saturday in Truro, Nova Scotia. He was 86.

title: Deaths and Injuries Reported in Yemeni Protest March
description: Security forces and government supporters opened fire on protesters in the Yemeni city of Taiz on Monday, witnesses said, while a doctor confirmed that four people were killed and scores wounded after almost a month of stalled negotiations over how and when President Ali Abdullah Saleh would leave office.

title: Gingrich Set to Run, With Wife in Central Role
description: WASHINGTON  Callista Biseks friends from rural Wisconsin were stunned when, well over a decade ago, she confided that she was secretly dating an older, married man: Newt Gingrich.

title: In Peru, Dreaming of American Glory
description: Diego Chvarri is a household name in his own household, which happens to be in Lima, Peru. His English may be spotty, but his soccer is solid. Perhaps most important of all, Chvarri owns a cherished document: a United States passport.

title: Mets Get Bad News on Young and Mejia
description: DENVER  Monday was the kind of day that has become all too familiar for the Mets over the past few years, one in which medical jargon was far more relevant than baseball lingo.

title: U.S. Was Braced for Fight With Pakistanis in Bin Laden Raid
description: This article is by  Eric Schmitt,  Thom Shanker and  David E. Sanger.

title: Dodd-Frank Dissenters Sound Off
description: Jonathan Alcorn/Bloomberg NewsKenneth Griffin, Citadels chief executive, is no fan of the Dodd-Frank Act.

title: The Missing Fifth
description: In 1910, Henry Van Dyke wrote a book called The Spirit of America, which opened with this sentence: The Spirit of America is best known in Europe by one of its qualities  energy.

title: In Rape Trial, Officer Calls Woman the Aggressor and Says They Only Snuggled
description: For the past several weeks, Police Officer Kenneth Moreno has sat silently in a courtroom amid accusations that he raped a drunken woman whom he had been called to help. In her testimony, the woman said she remembered an officer rolling down her tights and then penetrating her as she lay face down and dazed on her bed.

title: Judge Moves Jurors, Not Trial, in Murder Case
description: MIAMI  High-profile murder cases always raise the question: Will jurors be able to weigh the evidence impartially?

title: The Unions Shoddy Aristocracy
description: With the Pentagon budget up two-thirds over the last decade, its no surprise that charges of war profiteering make for regular front-page fodder. But for sheer scale and audacity, nothing beats the corruption that surrounded the Union war effort  and, thanks to the horrendously poor quality of the resulting equipment, did much to undermine it.

title: Doing More Than Praying for Rain
description: In the United States, insurance against extreme weather is seen as so important that Washington subsidizes it highly and requires it for farmers who want other government benefits. If American farmers need weather insurance, African peasant farmers need it even more. But the vast majority of African peasant farmers have no opportunity to insure their crops.

title: Arizona: Governor Will Appeal to Supreme Court
description: Gov. Jan Brewer, a Republican, said on Monday that she would petition the United States Supreme Court to lift an injunction blocking some portions of Arizonas controversial immigration law. The Justice Department sued the state over the law, known as Senate Bill 1070, and persuaded a federal judge to issue an injunction. The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit upheld that decision, ruling in April that immigration is predominantly a federal matter. When faced with injustice, Arizonans will not sit idly by, Ms. Brewer said in a statement.

title: Avoiding Greeces Lehman Moment
California: A Book About 18 Years of Captivity
description: Jaycee Dugard will tell the story of her kidnapping and years as a captive in a book to be published by Simon & Schuster, the publisher said Monday. A Stolen Life is to be released on July 12. Ms. Dugard, 31, wrote the book without the help of a ghostwriter, a spokeswoman for the publisher said. She was kidnapped off a street in South Lake Tahoe, Calif., as an 11-year-old and was held for 18 years. In a California courtroom last month on April 28, Phillip Garrido, a convicted sex offender, pleaded guilty to charges including rape and kidnapping.

title: Cuban Government Outlines Steps Toward a Freer Market
description: MEXICO CITY  For the first time since the Communist revolution 52 years ago, Cubans will be allowed to buy and sell houses and newer automobiles, and they may be able to travel abroad as tourists more freely, under policy changes announced Monday that are intended to shake up the countrys foundering economy.

title: Lottery Numbers
Westchester Towns Take Hit From Rise in Tax Appeals
description: GREENBURGH, N.Y.  Local governments here in well-to-do Westchester County are being overwhelmed by property tax appeals, driven by a growing industry of companies seeking reductions in homeowners bills in exchange for a share of their savings.

title: More Than a Rsum
description: You must remember this: He worked as a community organizer.

title: Mayors World Remade in an Instant
description: TUSCALOOSA, Ala.  In the weeks before the tornadoes demolished one-seventh of his city, Walter Maddox was doing what mayors in small cities do.

title: The Rejected Windfall
description: After Gov. Rick Scott of Florida thoughtlessly rejected $2.4 billion in federal aid for a high-speed rail line, he claimed last month that he was doing a huge favor for the national Treasury, which he expected would give away the money in tax cuts. That was nonsense, of course; Mr. Scott was really doing a favor for train passengers in the Northeast, Midwest and California, which were given $2 billion of his money on Monday for better service.

title: New Attacks on Womens Rights
description: With the help of 16 Democrats, House Republicans passed a bill the other day with the narrow-seeming title of the No Taxpayer Funding for Abortion Act.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: In Burkina Faso, Leader Keeps Cool Under Fire
description: OUAGADOUGOU, Burkina Faso  The riots have ended for now. The main market is bustling again and fleets of motorcycles have returned to the dusty streets. And in his fortresslike palace miles away, the president appears serene in portraits the newspapers publish.

title: 2 Planes Crash in Orange County, Killing Pilots
description: Two small airplanes collided in midair over a hamlet in Orange County, N.Y., on Monday, leaving both pilots dead, the Federal Aviation Administration said. No one else was on the planes.

title: Tuesday: Assists and Steals
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Ill just come right out and say it: I really like themes like this one. At first glance, it may not seem too difficult to come up with an idea like this, but look again.

title: A Black Actress Trying to Rise Above a Maid
description: A biting wind of realism, blowing both hot and cold, sweeps into the second act of By the Way, Meet Vera Stark, the fitful comedy by Lynn Nottage that opened on Monday night at Second Stage Theater. Reality, in this instance, assumes the fantastical form of an aging, teetering woman in a psychedelic-print dress and Technicolor makeup, applied with a trowel. She slurs when she speaks or sings, and you just know that her vision is blurry. But as embodied by Sanaa Lathan, she is so sharply focused she stings.

title: On Jeter, Cashman Broadens His View
description: MONROE TOWNSHIP, N.J.  Brian Cashman, the Yankees general manager, showed up Monday morning in a golf shirt, slacks and shoes to play 18 holes at Forsgate Country Club, 54 miles down the New Jersey Turnpike from Yankee Stadium.

title: Police Department in Newark Is Facing U.S. Inquiry
description: NEWARK  The Justice Department is investigating claims that brutality, baseless searches, intimidation and false arrests are commonplace in the Newark Police Department, officials announced on Monday.

title: They Should Be Condemning Syria
description: Syrians have shown extraordinary courage, defying a bloody government crackdown to demand greater political rights and freedom. Their courage, and their blood, should shame the many governments that are cynically supporting Syrias election later this month to the United Nations Human Rights Council.

title: Indonesia: Tigers Spotted in Forest Where Paper Mill Saws Are Coming
description: Motion-sensing cameras on the island of Sumatra captured video of two families of endangered tigers in a lowland forest scheduled for destruction, the World Wildlife Fund said Monday. Twelve tigers, including two adult females with cubs, passed in front of the cameras over two months between the Bukit Tigapuluh National Park and nearby mountains. Asia Pulp and Paper has plans to clear large areas of the forest.

title: Continuing Questions About Chernobyl
description: It has been 25 years since the worst nuclear power accident in history at the Chernobyl plant in Ukraine, and we still arent certain what health damage it may ultimately cause. That gap needs to be filled by a vigorous research program  both to improve readiness to cope with another bad nuclear accident and to enhance understanding of the long-term effects of low doses of radiation.

title: More Familiar Spider-Man Hopes to Bury the Dark
description: Bathed in green light, Patrick Page took center stage at the Foxwoods Theater on Broadway and hissed his lines with the sinister glee of a villain back from the dead.

title: West Bank: Tax Withholding by Israel Will Delay Paychecks for Palestinians
description: The Palestinian prime minister, Salam Fayyad, left, said Monday that the Palestinian Authority could not pay the salaries of its employees on time this month because of Israels decision to withhold the transfer of tax revenue it collects on behalf of the Palestinians. Israel delayed the transfer of almost $90 million after the reconciliation last week between Fatah, the party that dominates the West Bank-based Palestinian Authority, and Hamas, the Islamic militant group that controls Gaza. Israel said it was suspending all such transfers until there were guarantees that none of the money would end up in the treasury of Hamas, which is sworn to Israels destruction. The Palestinian Authority has had financial difficulties since late last year and is running a monthly deficit of $30 million. The French government provided it with a special grant of $14.3 million on Monday. On Friday, the European Union said it would advance $121.9 million to help it meet its needs.

title: India: Supreme Court Rejects Order That Religious Site Should be Shared
description: Indias Supreme Court on Monday overturned a lower court ruling that called for the countrys most disputed religious site to be divided between Muslims and Hindus. The Mughal emperor Babur built a mosque at the site, in Ayodhya, in the 16th century. Some Hindus believe that the same spot is the birthplace of the god Ram, and that Babur had destroyed a Hindu shrine to build his mosque. In 1992, Hindu activists tore down the mosque, unleashing sectarian violence in which about 2,000 people were killed, mostly Muslims. In October a court ruled that the site should be split between the two religions, but the Supreme Court rejected that solution, calling it strange. The Supreme Court is expected to rule later on the question of how to resolve control of the site.

In a winking style more reminiscent of The Muppet Show than Sesame Street, Kermit is introduced to Pirates stars like Geoffrey Rush, Penlope Cruz and Johnny Depp (who appears baffled by the concept of a talking frog), mingles with stray guests like Steven Tyler and Bruno Tonioli, and steals kisses from Vanessa Hudgens and Kirstie Alley. (Miss Piggy might want to skip those scenes.) Yes, its all a promotion for a coming Disney-produced Muppets movie, and while we would have preferred to see Gonzo introduced to Keith Richards, Kermits brief encounter with that randy Rolling Stone is still worth the price of admission.

title: Major League Soccer: Little Fish, Little Pond
description: Every year, Major League Soccer Players Union releases the salaries of all players under contract in M.L.S. Those figures are just out, and theyre worth a look. (Other peoples salaries always are.) Depending on how you feel about lockouts and LOOGYs who get $8 million for two years, they might make you feel a little bit better about pro sports in America. Yes, there have been some ugly leg-breaking tackles of late. But at least our soccer players arent a lot of spoiled rich guys, you know? By my quick count, only six players make more than the $1.2 million Bobby Bonilla will be getting from the Mets every year for the next 25 years (he retired from baseball in 2001, in case youre wondering why you havent heard that name in a while). And if you pool the salaries of the two biggest names in M.L.S., David Beckham and Thierry Henry, you still wont have enough to cover Eddy Currys $11 million-plus salary this past season.

title: An Epic Game 4 in Memphis

The arena is not much more than a long golf shot from the Mississippi River, which had risen so high Tuesday, people were flocking downtown just to ogle it, perhaps the oddest of all tourist attractions. If some of them filed into the Grizzlies playoff game against Oklahoma City, they found themselves watching another force of nature: a 133-123 triple-overtime victory by the Thunder with 256 points, 206 field goal attempts, 90 free throw attempts and 67 personal fouls.

title: Pearl Vision
description: For her latest collection, the jeweler Monique Pan went in search of sustainable pearls  and wound up working in a lagoon in the South Pacific. Pan says she furthered her commitment to eco-minded jewelry during her CFDA/Vogue Fashion Fund mentorship at Tiffany & Company; she and the companys C.E.O., Michael Kowalski, share what he calls an approach to precious materials that is sustainable and benefits the communities involved. The quest led Pan to the Ahe atoll in French Polynesia, where the Kamoka Pearl Farm uses fish and sponges to clean its oyster shells. The farm harvests without chemicals, feeds its employees (Raw oysters, fried oysters, oyster risotto, a lot of oysters! Pan says) and turns the shells into beads. Pans line uses Kamokas keshi pearls in hues of blue, aubergine and gold for pieces like a ring set with delicate pav-diamond tendrils (conflict-free, of course), which Pan says was inspired by Ahes pollution-free midnight sky reflecting against the waves and the light.

Some of the letters were signed with putatively black names (like DeShawn Jackson) and some were signed with putatively white names (like Jake Mueller). The letters from the putatively black constituents received fewer responses from white legislators and received more responses from minority legislators.

title: The Fighting Mans Beast
description: Luke Mogelson questions the bad apples theory of war crimes but doesnt question the enterprise that makes such crimes possible, perhaps inevitable. Whats the difference between soldiers taking advantage of a dangerous and confusing situation to commit murder and countries using a dangerous and confusing situation as an excuse for war? If the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan had caused the surrender of the militant fundamentalists who seek our destruction, if they had denied these enemies the ability to attack, if the wars hadnt devastated the economies and the innocent citizens of the countries we attacked, they might be justified.JAMIE BALDWIN,Redding, Conn., e-mail

title: Joyce Carol Oates Updates Her Widows Story
description: When Joyce Carol Oatess memoir, A Widows Story, came out in February, some reviewers took her to task for not mentioning that 13 months after the death of her husband, Raymond Smith, in February 2008, she remarried. Writing in The New York Review of Books, Julian Barnes said some readers will feel they have a good case for breach of narrative promise. In a letter in the current issue of The New York Review Ms. Oates defended her choice , writing that the book was meant to be about the immediate experience of widowhood, not her subsequent life. But she also wrote that in retrospect I can see that I should have added something like an appendix, to bring my personal history up to date, and said that she hopes to add such an appendix to later editions.
