description: Pretty much every T we commission for the magazine has a back story. But few go as far backor have as many plot twistsas the story behind this particular T, which was created by the artist Clifford Ross and will appear in the upcoming Summer Travel issue.

title: Newspaper Regrets Erasing Hillary Clinton
description: Updated | 5:06 p.m. A newspaper catering to ultra-Orthodox Jews in New York apologized on Monday for publishing a photograph of the White House Situation Room during the raid on Osama bin Ladens compound that was digitally altered to make it seem as if Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton and another female official had not been present.

title: Two New National Magazine Awards
description: There are two new Alexander Calder stabiles in our possession. Last night, the magazine won two National Magazine Awards, or Ellies (so called for the sculptures resemblance to an elephant). One was for News and Documentary Photography for The Shrine Down the Hall, photographs by Ashley Gilbertson; essay by Dexter Filkins. The photo essay was a portrait of the preserved bedrooms of the young people killed in the wars of Iraq and Afghanistan.

title: Like Magic, Great Sports Nicknames Are Disappearing
description: Todays baseball rosters are filled with names, not nicknames, not like the ones that used to be. The N.B.A. playoffs are equally devoid of onomastic pleasures, just cheap echoes of Magic and the Mailman, Tiny and Tree, Chief and Cornbread. The N.F.L. cannot match the treasured nicknames that evoke folk heroes like Night Train, Hacksaw and the Refrigerator.

title: Bathhouse and Gas Company Building Are Named Landmarks
description: A former public bathhouse in Midtown Manhattan and the former headquarters of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company in Downtown Brooklyn have been designated as landmarks, the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission announced on Tuesday.

title: Apple and Google Executives Testify on Mobile Privacy
description: Saying there has been a fundamental shift for cellphone users in determining who has their information and what theyre doing with it, Senator Al Franken, Democrat of Minnesota, held a hearing Tuesday to question executives from Google and Apple on data location and mobile devices. The hearing was the first for the newly formed Senate Judiciary Subcommittee on Privacy, Technology and the Law, led by Mr. Franken. Read more about the hearing on Media Decoder.

title: Good Citizenship: Assessing Civics Knowledge and Education
description: Overview | Why is civics education important? What are the most effective and engaging ways to engage teenagers in learning civics? In this lesson, students will conduct a research project about civic education and students knowledge at their school. They will then prepare a presentation of their findings and recommendations to a panel of their school;s history faculty and administrators.

title: Dancing to the Top
description: Dancing With the Stars attracted 20.2 million viewers on Monday, lifting ABC far head of its network competitors in the nights ratings, according to Nielsens estimates. ABCs Castle won the 10 p.m. time slot after the two-hour installment of Dancing With the Stars, garnering 12.6 million viewers and outperforming CBSs Hawaii Five-0 (9.2 million) and NBCs Law & Order: LA (5 million) in the hour.

title: Microsoft Acquires Skype
description: Microsoft's $8.5 billion acquisition of Skype is the biggest technology deal so far this year, and the transaction would rank among the 12 biggest high-tech deals since 2000.

title: Skype Deal Gets a Mixed Reaction
description: Is Microsofts acquisition of Skype a smart deal?

title: Simon Russell Beale to Drive London Taxi on New York Stage
description: The British actor Simon Russell Beale will return to the New York stage this summer as a London taxi driver in Atlantic Theater Companys production of Bluebird, a tender drama by Simon Stephens about chance encounters and coming to grips with ones past.

title: Presbyterians Approve Ordination of Gay People
description: After 33 years of debate, the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) has voted to change its constitution and allow openly gay people in same-sex relationships to be ordained as ministers, elders and deacons.

title: Obamas Remarks on Immigration
description: Following is a text of President Obama's remarks on immigration, delivered Tuesday in El Paso, as released by the White House:

title: The National Bar and Dining Rooms
description: FIFTIETH Street and Lexington Avenue is the pulsing heart of no particular neighborhood, a lively intersection near the back door to the Waldorf-Astoria, just south of a DoubleTree. Office workers stream through on the way to the subway stop at the corner. Hotel guests pilot wheelie bags deep into yellow-cab traffic, and bark at one another in French. If you were looking for a neighborhood bistro of the sort where you might linger over dinner for a while, happily talking with friends while picking at fries and finishing a bottle of wine, the corner would rank low on a list of possible locations.

title: Reviewing the National
A Midtown Homecoming for the First Corvette
description: Last Saturday, the worlds first Corvette returned to its birthplace.

title: The Morning Line: Motion Is Still Riding High
description: This is somewhat of slower day for news about the Triple Crown with some of the horses in transit. Animal Kingdom is headed back to his training headquarters at Fair Hill in Maryland. The trainer Graham Motion is still ecstatic about the Kentucky Derby victory. Motion says: I have a lot of confidence in this horse. Hes the whole packageI guess, to use a term thats probably overused. Hes got a tremendous disposition and is just a really brilliant horse.

title: In Search of the Great Nicknames
description: Updated We are no longer accepting comments for this feature. We discuss some of your favorite nicknames at http://tinyurl.com/69dkego

title: Can Skype Make Microsoft Sexy Again?
description: With Microsofts $8.5 billion acquisition of Skype, the software company faces a challenge in integrating the communications service into its offerings.

title: $100 Weekend in Rio de Janeiro
description: Filling your time during a cheap weekend in Rio de Janeiro would seem like a no-brainer: head to Ipanema beach on Saturday, spend a couple of bucks to rent a beach chair and a couple more on tempting snacks from roaming vendors. Rinse (in the on-beach showers) and repeat (on Sunday).

title: Last Call
description: Nothing lasts forever  and that includes these far-flung destinations, which are changing as they balance their own needs with those of ever more curious travelers.

title: Skype, Even for $8.5 Billion, Could Be a Deal
description: Long before Skype became the object of Microsofts desire, the big phone mobile companies like Verizon and AT&T had slowly been increasing the price of Internet data usage on mobile phones, while lowering the cost of talk time.

title: Another Season of House on Fox
description: One of televisions most memorable characters, Dr. Gregory House, will return for at least one more season thanks to the conclusion of a negotiation Tuesday between Fox, the network that has broadcast it, and NBC Universal, the studio that owns it.

title: A Return to Penguin Press for Scott Moyers
description: In one of the more unusual U-turns in the publishing business, Scott Moyers, a top agent at the Wylie Agency, will return to the Penguin Press as its publisher.

title: Zynga Does a Deal With Lady Gaga
description: Attention Farmville players: youll soon have an unconventional virtual farm as your neighbor.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Japan, Uganda and Afghanistan.

title: It Sounds Like Lost, Except With Stranded Whisky
description: When cases of Canadian Club are hidden, they sometimes tend to stay hidden.

title: TimesCast | May 10, 2011
description: President Obama urges Congress to act on immigration reform; Syria's most powerful businessman; and in China, jasmine is seen as a problematic revolutionary symbol.

title: Queens, 10:51 A.M.
description: Bronze casters at the Modern Art Foundry in Astoria prepared to pour bronze into a mold to create Looking Up, a 6.5-foot sculpture by Allston Chapman. The sculpture is one of seven to be unveiled in Riverside Park in June as part of the Model to Monument program, a partnership between the Art Students League of New York and the City Parks Department to create art for public parks.

title: Staying the Course, Post-Fukushima
description: The renaissance that the American nuclear industry has been talking about for almost 20 years looks a bit slow and small at the moment, with two of the four leading reactor candidates chosen for aid by the Department of Energy apparently having fizzled.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Japan, Uganda and Afghanistan.

title: In Japan, a Boat Stranded by Tsunami Is Lifted From Rooftop
description: Photos of compelling cars are nothing new to the Automobiles section. But the shot of a Mitsubishi i-MiEV in a tsunami-struck town in Japan, which ran in Sundays Automobiles section, was arresting because, about one block away from the electric vehicle, a two-story building was topped by a boat.

title: Bill Paying Made Easier, but for a Fee
description: Lots of people like to pay big bills with their credit or debit cards so they can rack up reward points or manage their cash flow when money is tight. But its sometimes hard to do that with certain big bills, like those from your mortgage servicer or your electricity provider. Many of those companies still refuse to accept plastic  or accept only certain brands.

title: Bed and Shrekfast: Gaylord Hotels Meet DreamWorks
description: There are theme parks tied to movie studios and there are theme cruises, and now, the themed hotel stay. The Gaylord hotel company has teamed up with DreamWorks to feature animated characters at its four resorts, in Nashville, Tenn., Kissimme, Fla., on the Potomac in National Harbor, Md., and Grapevine, Tex., Gaylord announced recently.

title: The Book of Tweets
description: Did we always think in search terms and we just didnt know it? Thoughts melded into words, and the words, if you squinted, began to yield Dominant Nouns. The dominant nouns then formed their own relationships. Early Internet searching was an art. The available results were mostly useless, so you had to refine your search  you had to try to think like the algorithm just as the algorithm was trying to think like you. An unexpected partnership. I always thought this was why search took off: you had the vague feeling that you were working with someone else, on the path to refinement.

title: Photo Replay: May 10
description: The day in sports included a golf tournament for disabled players in South Africa and tributes to a fallen Belgian cyclist in Italy.

title: Met Museum Elects Trustee as Chairman
description: Daniel Brodsky, a real estate developer, was elected chairman of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Tuesday in a vote by the museums board. Mr. Brodsky will assume the post on Sept. 13, succeeding James R. Houghton, who has been chairman for the past 13 years and will now become a trustee emeritus.

title: Newborn Abandoned in Trash at a Queens Hospital
description: Updated 6:55 p.m. | A young woman apparently gave birth at a hospital in Queens and then left the baby in the garbage receptacle and walked away, law enforcement officials said.

title: How eBay Fared in Latest Skype Deal
description: The conventional thinking goes that Meg Whitman, eBays former chief executive, blundered by buying Skype six years ago for $2.5 billion.

title: The Lost Art of the Sports Nickname
description: The decline in the use of nicknames is most easily gauged in sports, where they have long played a role in distinguishing athletes.

title: The Question of Salt
Some Powers for Dealing With Failed Financial Firms
description: Having previously dismissed the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporations report on how Lehman Brothers would have been resolved under the new Dodd-Frank orderly liquidation authority as overly optimistic, I thought it would make some sense to consider what else we might do with a large, failed financial institution.

title: Disney Profit Declines 1%, Partly on Movies and Parks
description: LOS ANGELES  The Walt Disney Company took several financial blows in its most recent quarter but largely managed to contain the damage: profit dropped just 1 percent from a year earlier, to $942 million.

title: Fete Accompli | Parsons After Dark
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#850", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: A Cautious Memoirist Who Ends With a Laugh
description: Among Nobel laureates of recent vintage, only Mario Vargas Llosa, who won the prize in literature last year, has delivered as much pure pleasure as the Portuguese novelist Jos Saramago. Saramagos best books read like hallucinatory thrillers. Theyre warm to the touch; they practically palpitate in your hands.

title: On Our Radar: War-Torn Liberia Signs Timber Deal with E.U.
description: Liberia, home to 45 percent of the rain forests in West Africa, signs a deal with the European Union to prevent illegal timber exports and develop a sustainable forestry industry. Illegal logging flourished during the countrys long civil war but led to crippling sanctions against the timber industry. [BBC]

title: Genres and Styles Without Borders, in a Brooklyn Series
description: The border-hopping proclivities of classical composers and performers have become more pronounced in recent years, resulting in a freewheeling blend of genres and styles. Gala NYC, a new series (the name means Global Art, Local Audience) founded by Mike Block, a Juilliard-trained cellist and disciple of Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Project, aims to promote this healthy eclecticism by combining performers from varying disciplines.

title: Deliberative Theater Critics Honor Good People
description: New York theater critics had an awfully hard time on Monday selecting the best play of the year for their annual award. Four rounds of balloting by the New York Drama Critics Circle revealed strong preferences for three Broadway plays that have also been nominated for this years Tony Award for best play  Good People, Jerusalem, and The ____________ with the Hat.

title: For a Sextets Substitutes, a Chemistry Test
description: The effect that substitute players can have on an ensembles character probably varies according to the size of the group in question. Orchestras use subs on a regular basis, sometimes for extended periods, with no great impact on corporate identity. But for full-time chamber groups, consistent chemistry is a key attribute. It would be hard to imagine a prominent string quartet, for instance, soldiering on for more than a few outings with a pinch-hitter.

title: Google Plans to Streamline Android
description: Android phones have been a runaway success for Google  perhaps too runaway. Now Google is trying to add some order to the craziness.

title: One Tenor, Three Voices, in Arias From Handels Era
description: Les Violons du Roy, a Quebec  ensemble led by Bernard Labadie, has a broad repertory that includes Romantic and contemporary works. But the ensemble is best known for its zesty performances of Baroque and Classical music, performed on modern instruments, and it played to its strengths on Sunday evening at Zankel Hall in a program devoted to Handel and his contemporaries.

title: Amid Bostons Gremlins, Heat Finds Its Heart
description: Boston

title: Debating the Bush-Obama Era
description: In response to my column on the Bush-Obama foreign policy convergence, Andrew Sullivan runs down what he sees as the five fundamental discontinuities between the two administrations approaches:

title: Woman for All Seasons, Ballads and Emotions
description: One of the pleasures of cabaret reviewing over the long haul has been to observe the evolution of K T Sullivan from an effervescent musical comedian into the increasingly fearless and complex singing character actor she is today. Her new show, which opened at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel last week, is called Rhyme, Women and Song, but it might just as well be titled The Seven Ages of Woman, for all the musical and emotional territory she covers.

title: A Tale of Nanjing Atrocities That Spares No Brutal Detail
description: Two terrible faces stare out from City of Life and Death, a fictionalized telling of the Rape of Nanjing, a pair of indelible bookends for this anguished film. The first belongs to Lu (Liu Ye), who, with hundreds of other soldiers, has been rounded up by invading Japanese troops amid a frenzy of violence. The close-up of Lus impassive face locked in unspoken emotion floods the screen. Much later, after innumerable deaths and acts of barbarism and heroism, the face of a woman will similarly fill the screen in close-up, her frantic eyes stretched wide, as if they had been permanently shocked open by what they have seen.

title: In Border City Talk, Obama Urges G.O.P. to Help Overhaul Immigration Law
description: EL PASO  President Obama came to this border city on Tuesday to argue that he is doing his part to crack down on illegal immigration, and that Republicans must now join him in overhauling the nations immigration laws for the millions of workers already here illegally.

title: TimesCast | The Immigration Agenda
description: As President Obama urges Congress to take up federal immigration reform, Arizona has been moving ahead on its own immigration initiatives.

title: Times Hires James B. Stewart, Financial Writer
description: James B. Stewart, a Pulitzer prize-winning reporter and author of several best-sellers on the business world, will become a columnist for the Business Day section of The New York Times, the paper announced on Tuesday.

title: U.S. Reaches a Settlement on Decisions About Endangered Species
description: The Interior Department, facing an avalanche of petitions and lawsuits over proposed endangered species designations, said Tuesday that it had negotiated a settlement under which it will make decisions on 251 species over the next six years.

title: In This Neverland, Its Peter Puppet
description: Its easy to feel somewhat dubious about reviewing art made for children, especially when youre not accompanied by a trusty, underage sidekick.

title: Hiss at the Villain, Cheer the Vagabond
description: The name alone conjures greasepaint and gaslights and the Ghosts of Theater Past. Dion Boucicault, the 19th-century Irish playwright and actor, was popular in Britain and America with melodramas like The Colleen Bawn, one of the most successful plays of the time; The Octoroon; and The Shaughraun, now at the Irish Repertory Theater in a lively, loving production.

title: A Family Tragedy in a Neo-Nazi Home
description: A Family Tragedy in a Neo-Nazi Home

title: One Persons Detritus Is Someone Elses Play
description: What turns junk into artifacts? The passing of time, of course. But the new documentary drama Locker No. 4173b suggests, sometimes jokingly, other times not, that that may be too simple an answer.

title: Plans for LinkedIns I.P.O. May Make Few Friends
description: Harry Campbell

title: Fashion With a Twist | Orly Genger at VPL
description: When Victoria Bartlett, the designer behind the Visible Panty Line label, opened her first boutique in New York late last year, she intended it to be more than just a showcase for her clothes  it would also be a gallery, where the artistic collaborations that are a regular feature of her work could be put on display. She put the plan into action for the first time on Monday night, when the Mercer Street shop was the site of an installation by the artist Orly Genger, whos known for knotting thick nylon climbing rope into massive, room-filling shapes and who has collaborated with Bartlett on installations for her runway shows and also on accessories. Squat, as the new piece is called, has an unusual twist: For the duration of the event, it incorporated two live models, both clad in VPL underwear. The idea was to have it look like something had blown through like a tornado and swept up against the window, engulfing the girls, Bartlett explained as she surveyed the scene. Its this enormous muscle of rope thats come crashing through the store.

title: Whimsical Winds Buffet Hearts on a Magical Isle
description: The world is a stage, the island is a world and the stage is an island in Target Margin Theaters delightfully homespun new production of The Tempest.

title: Cocoron
description: THEY come two by two to this lunar stretch of the Lower East Side, where the vibe is more checks-cashed-here than rocker grottoes and adhesive jeans. They wait on the sidewalk, by a battered A.T.M., orderly, resigned.

title: Reviewing Cocoron
She Doesnt Want to Be in Kansas Anymore
description: Empty beer bottles on every surface, a sullen post-adolescent in the corner and not an interpersonal boundary in sight: this is the pungent but predictable setting of Little Black Dress, a Midwestern Gothic by Ronan Noone, presented by the Exchange, that opened on Thursday at the Theater at St. Clements.

title: Obama to Deliver Commencement at Memphis H.S.
description: President Obama will deliver the commencement address at Booker T. Washington High School in Memphis, the White House announced Tuesday.

title: Deal Tempers Rents Owed by Condo Owners in Battery Park
description: Condominium owners at Battery Park City, the 92-acre development in Lower Manhattan built from dredged sand and dirt excavated for the original World Trade Center, will save hundreds of millions of dollars in ground-rent payments under a deal reached Tuesday.

title: Will Pizza Delivery Chains Cry, Curse You, Red Baron?
description: A brand of frozen pizza is getting tough with the people who deliver pizzas to consumers homes.

title: The Spotlight Finds a Basque Shepherds Canteen
description: IVE never hailed a taxi in my life, Linda McCoy said on the phone last week from central California. Im terrified of this whole thing.

title: Video: Noriegas Restaurant
description: From the outside, youd probably never notice it. Step inside, and youll probably never forget it. A look at the food and culture of Noriegas, an award-winning Basque restaurant at a boardinghouse in Bakersfield, Calif.

title: Orly Genger at VPL
description: A film of "Squat," an installation by the artist Orly Genger, at the VPL store on Mercer Street. Directed by Peter Sutherland.

title: Rick Kaplan, Producer for Couric, to Leave CBS
description: Two weeks after Katie Couric confirmed that she was leaving the CBS Evening News, her producer, Rick Kaplan, said Tuesday that he was departing, as well.

description: Although we have been wrong before, we believe there will be no more miracle eyases to celebrate in Violet and Bobbys nest.

description: Thomas Kellers latest is an edition of Bouchon Bakery on a highly trafficked corner of Rockefeller Center. It is to open on Thursday.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Young Farmers

title: Blood Clams: Worth a Second Look
description: Once you get past the off-putting name and appearance, you will find that blood clams have a deliciously crisp succulence, like geoduck, and a flavor that is not as briny as a littleneck or cherrystone clam. The redness that gives these cockles their name is due to a high level of hemoglobin. They are about the size of a lime and have very hard shells, with black, hairy material covering part of the shell.

title: Tortilla Chips of a Different Munchability
description: A trip to Vermont is no longer the only way to obtain Gringo Jacks tortilla chips, which are made at the restaurant by the same name in Manchester. These smallish flour chips can now be ordered online. Their munchability is driven by exceptional flakiness  a similar texture, if not taste, to that of the fried noodles offered in Chinese restaurants. The plain ones are fine; the whole-wheat version has deeper flavor; and the spiced ones, hand-dusted with a ruddy, vibrant mixture, suit creamy dips and make a nice garnish for ceviche, salads and soups.

title: A Tandoor Oven Brings Indias Heat to the Backyard
description: RON LEVY never intended to become a tandoor mogul.

title: A Fruit With a Future
description: IF there is one thing the dragon fruit has mastered, its the art of the Hollywood entrance.

title: A Stage Life
description: Photos of the life and work of Arthur Laurents.

title: Comparing Stage Notes on Laurents
description: Asked by New York Magazine to talk about the pugnacious writer Arthur Laurents in 2009, the composer Mary Rodgers Guettel responded bluntly, Call me back when hes dead. So I did. The answer remained: no comment.

title: More Greek Out
description: An Argentine commenter on my Greece-leaving-the-euro post notes that Argentina, in addition to letting the peso drop, both defaulted on its debt and imposed temporary restrictions on bank withdrawals. Indeed. Something similar would have to happen for a euro exit to take place.

title: Killings and Rumors Unsettle a Libyan City
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  Three weeks ago, a traveler spotted a mans body in the farmland on this citys outskirts, shot twice in the head with his hands and feet bound. He had disappeared earlier that day, after visiting a market.

title: Boston Scientific C.E.O. Steps Down; Stock Falls
description: Investors were none too pleased on Tuesday when they heard the news that Ray Elliott, the president and chief executive of Boston Scientific, the medical device manufacturer, would be stepping down at the end of 2011.

title: And the G.O.P. Candidates Are
description: Gail Collins: David, this is an extremely exciting week. Newt Gingrich is preparing once again to announce the formation of a presidential exploratory committee. I dont think Ive been this excited since last week when a guy came to read our gas meter.

title: Stranded on the Tarmac
description: To the Editor:

title: In Popularity Polls of Governors, Cuomo Is High on the List
description: ALBANY  Gov. Andrew M. Cuomos effort to rally the public to support his agenda is based on a simple political calculation: He is popular, and the Legislature is not.

title: Turn Your Android Phone Into a Remote Control for Your Home
description: Google wants people to use its Android software to operate a lot more than just phones and tablets. And at Google I/O, the companys conference for developers in San Francisco this week, the company showed off a future where someone could use an Android phone to turn on and off the lights, the dishwasher, a lamp or a sprinkler system  or anything else they want to.

title: New Bill Supporting Same-Sex Marriage Is Introduced in Assembly
description: With only weeks to go before the end of the legislative session in June, a senior Democratic lawmaker in the New York State Assembly introduced legislation on Tuesday to legalize same-sex marriages, signaling that Assembly lawmakers were unwilling to wait for efforts by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and gay rights groups to pull together enough votes to move the measure through the Republican-controlled State Senate.

title: Hikers on Trial
description: On May 11, Shane Bauer and Josh Fattal, two of the three American hikers who were detained by Iranian officials after crossing a border between Iraqi Kurdistan and Iran in 2009, will go on trial in Tehran for espionage. They have been held in Evin Prison for almost two years.

title: Hip Makers Told to Study More Data
description: In an unusual move, the Food and Drug Administration has ordered all producers of a popular category of artificial hip to undertake studies of the implants, which have been linked to high early failure rates and severe health effects in some patients.

title: Murky Identities and Ties Hinder NATOs Hunt for Afghan Insurgents, Report Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Two new reports addressing human rights issues in Afghanistan have raised questions about how NATO troops are conducting the war. Both reports center on a question that has vexed international forces since the war began: How can the military be sure it has killed, detained or made deals with the right people?

title: Justice Department Is Investigating Google Advertising
description: The Justice Department is investigating Google advertising, and Google may have to pay $500 million, according to a Google filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Tuesday. As a result, Google said, last quarters net income was 22 percent lower than it originally reported.

title: Gus Johnson Joins Fox Sports
description: Gus Johnson, who left CBS Sports after 16 years, joined Fox Sports on Tuesday to call college football and basketball and N.F.L. games.

description: Nine days after American commandos killed Osama bin Laden, President Obama has added the event to the rundown of administration achievements in his political stump speech. Even so, a supporter beat him to it.

description: The 10 portable classrooms outside Public School 19 in Corona, Queens, were supposed to be temporary.

title: Arum Says Pay-Per-View Buys Were Up for Pacquiao Fight
description: Based on early projections, Bob Arum, the chairman of Top Rank boxing, said he believed the pay-per-view buys from Manny Pacquiaos defense of his welterweight title fight against Shane Mosley last Saturday would match or exceed the roughly 1.2 million buys for Pacquiaos previous fight, against Antonio Margarito.

description: To the Editor:

title: Gus Johnson Joins Fox Sports
description: Gus Johnson, who left CBS Sports after 16 years, joined Fox Sports to call games in college football and basketball and the N.F.L. Johnson is best known for an excitable style that was most in evidence during the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament on CBS, which he will no longer call.

title: Penn Gets $225 Million for Its School of Medicine
description: The University of Pennsylvania has received a $225 million gift, the largest in its history, from Raymond G. Perelman and his wife, Ruth, for its medical school, which will be renamed the Raymond and Ruth Perelman School of Medicine at the University of Pennsylvania.

title: France Arrests Six on Suspicion of Planning to Train With Militants
description: PARIS  Six men suspected of planning to go to Pakistan to train with Islamic militants have been arrested in or near Paris, the French interior minister said Tuesday.

description: To the Editor:

title: Off With Its Head: Wonderland Musical to Close on Sunday
description: A new Broadway musical based on a classic series of childrens books and updated for a modern audience? Should be bigger than Wicked, right? Not on this side of the looking glass, buddy.

title: Town Torn by Tsunami Sees Reopened School as a Therapeutic Step
description: OTSUCHI, Japan  The week before classes resumed, the middle schools gymnasium was still a makeshift morgue. But the bodies were removed and the floor disinfected, so Kirikiri Middle School could welcome back students for the first time since the tsunami swept away much of this port town.

title: We Are the World, and Were Growing
description: To the Editor:

title: New to Teaching, Idealistic, at Risk for Layoff
description: Samantha Sherwood had lofty aspirations when she settled on a family-studies major at the University of Connecticut, like redrawing welfare rules or weaving together a sturdier safety net for people in need. She figured that she could change the world in big, broad strokes, and that she might pick up a fancy title and ample salary along the way.

title: Kuwait Viewed As Syrias Rival For U.N. Council
description: Syrias attempt to join the United Nations main human rights body will very likely be thwarted by Kuwait, which is planning to seek the Asian seat traditionally reserved for an Arab country, Western diplomats said Tuesday.

title: Guatemalan Court Acquits Former President of Embezzling
description: MEXICO CITY  A Guatemalan court has acquitted a former president, Alfonso Portillo, of charges that he embezzled state money.

title: No Pardon for Felon Elected Mayor in Oklahoma
description: PHOENIX  Christopher S. Linder has had many monikers over the years: Big Slim was his gang nickname, 151011 was his inmate number, and he has been mayor-elect since voters in Pawnee, Okla., chose him to lead their small town.

title: The Future of Cafeteria Food
description: If you have gone to school, worked in an office, factory, or other large workplace, youve probably eaten  and hated  your fair share of institutional cooking. I still remember the name of the food service company that ran the cafeteria where I went to college, and I would still revile it, except it deserves partial credit for forcing me to learn how to cook.

title: Iran: Nuclear Reaction Is Begun
description: Iran has started the nuclear reaction at its Bushehr power plant, the Russian company that built the reactor said in a statement on Tuesday that indicated Iran is close to wrapping up work on the site that has dragged on for more than three decades. The German company Siemens abandoned the partly completed plant after the 1979 Islamic revolution in Iran, and more delays followed even after Russia resumed construction in 1994. The United States once opposed the plant. But the International Atomic Energy Agency monitors it, and the United States dropped its objections after Russia provided assurances of controls on the fuel supply and the disposal of spent fuel rods. The Russian state company that builds reactors abroad said that operators at the plant would test safety and control equipment before connecting the reactor to electricity generating turbines, a process that could take about two months.

title: Critics Fear G.O.P.s Proposed Medicaid Changes Could Cut Coverage for the Aged
description: WASHINGTON  As Republicans inch away from their plan to reshape the nations Medicare program, their equally transformative ideas for Medicaid, now largely in the shadows of the budget debate, are moving front and center.

title: A Critique of a Texas Representatives Air Quality Claims
description: In March, the Environmental Protection Agency, acting under court order, proposed the first national standard for emissions of mercury, sulfur dioxide and other pollutants from coal-fired power plants.

title: Yankees Prepare for Younger, More Aggressive Royals
description: The Yankees opened a three-game series Tuesday against the Kansas City Royals, who are quite a bit more challenging than they have been for a while. The youthful Royals love to run, apparently from the moment that their manager, Ned Yost, opened spring training.

title: Horace Freeland Judson, Science Historian, Dies at 80
description: Horace Freeland Judson, a science writer whose 1979 book The Eighth Day of Creation is regarded as the definitive account of the breakthroughs that transformed molecular biology in the mid-20th century, died on Friday at his home in Baltimore. He was 80.

title: Focused on the Swing, Not the Score
description: WINDERMERE, FLA.  When Sean Foley was a college golfer, he sometimes exasperated his coach by giving tips to opposing players. He was precociously interested in swing theory and swing mechanics, more concerned with how many greens he hit in regulation than with his final score. When he was 14, an obsessive reader of golf instruction books, he was offering unsolicited  and possibly incorrect  advice to hapless duffers. At 16, he could imitate Nick Faldo frame by frame on video.

title: The Composers Other Voice
description: I have been a composer for my entire adult life. And for the most part, despite the exhaustion and relative poverty it has entailed, this self-styled job has been a source of satisfaction, even great joy.

title: Saying Farewell to a Gangster of a Bygone Era
description: The man and woman unfolded themselves from a cab at the corner of Ninth Avenue and 42nd Street, then stood blinking in the sunlight for a few seconds, searching for a familiar piece of ground, a bearing. So there: the bus terminal across the street. But their gazes lingered on tall buildings that had risen in the last two decades or so. It was nearly 10:30 on Tuesday morning. They shuffled down the street and melted into a small crowd on the sidewalk outside the Church of the Holy Cross.

title: After Bin Laden, U.S. Reassesses Afghan Strategy
description: WASHINGTON  The killing of Osama bin Laden has set off a reassessment of the war in Afghanistan and the broader effort to combat terrorism, with Congress, the military and the Obama administration weighing the goals, strategies, costs and underlying authority for a conflict that is now almost a decade old.

title: Six From FIFA Are Accused in Bribery Case
description: Soccers world governing body, which has little international oversight and has long faced charges of corruption, found itself embattled again Tuesday when six of its top officials were accused of participating in a bribery scandal related to bids for the 2018 and the 2022 World Cups.

title: For Microsoft, Skype Opens Vast New Market in Telecom
description: Microsoft has peered into the future, and placed a bet that people the world over want to stay in touch with someone anytime and anywhere  preferably at no cost.

title: Google Lobbies Nevada to Allow Self-Driving Cars
description: Google, a pioneer of self-driving cars, is quietly lobbying for legislation that would make Nevada the first state where they could be legally operated on public roads.

title: When the Levee Doesnt Break
description: Conway, Ark.

title: Celtics Taking On the Look of a Champion No Longer
description: BOSTON  For the last 11 days, the shifting fate of the Boston Celtics could be tracked through the twitches in Paul Pierces cheeks. His expression told the story.

title: Chaos at Home Stalls Tuition Aid for Libyan Students in U.S.
description: DENVER  Loqman Mohamed, a 28-year-old Libyan student from Benghazi, has been spending his nights scouring the Web for the latest on the war ripping apart his homeland.

title: Leadership Change at About.com
description: The About.com division of The New York Times Company switched leaders on Tuesday in a shake-up.

title: Bad Bargains
description: So Osama bin Laden was living in a specially built villa in Pakistan. I wonder where he got the money to buy it? Cashed in his Saudi 401(k)? A Pakistani subprime mortgage, perhaps? No. I suspect we will find that it all came from the same place most of Al Qaedas funds come from: some combination of private Saudi donations spent under the watchful eye of the Pakistani Army.

title: Iraqis Share Their Views on U.S. Troop Presence
description: One of the biggest questions hanging over Iraq is whether the government will ask United States forces to remain in the country after the end of the year.

title: Googles Digital Music Service Falls Short of Ambition
description: Google had big plans for its new digital music service. It wanted an online store to compete with iTunes and Amazon, as well as a smart locker storage system in which the company would stream music to its millions of users from a gigantic central jukebox.

title: Pressure Grows for Trustee to Leave Board of CUNY
description: The day after City University of New York trustees approved an honorary degree for the playwright Tony Kushner, pressure continued to mount on Tuesday for the resignation or removal of the trustee who had raised concerns about Mr. Kushners views on Israel.

title: Neo-Nazi Father Is Killed; Son, 10, Steeped in Beliefs, Is Accused
description: RIVERSIDE, Calif.  The day before he allegedly shot his father, the sandy-haired 10-year-old boy showed off a prized possession to a visitor. It was a thin leather belt emblazoned with a silver insignia of the Nazi SS.

title: Should U.S. Stay or Go? Views Define Iraqi Factions
description: BAGHDAD  In the Shiite enclave of Sadr City, young men demand in militant tones that American troops leave immediately. Iraqi Army officers worry that the country will take a violent turn if the troops go. In the north, Kurdish factions that have enjoyed 20 years of American security guarantees fret about their future, and Sunni Muslims worry about Irans rise as a political power. In Parliament, the political leadership has largely stayed silent.

title: Skype Investors Reap Windfall in Deal With Microsoft
description: Daniel Acker/Bloomberg NewsA Skype booth at the 2010 International Consumer Electronics Show.

title: Without Concessions, Connecticut Starts Layoff Process
description: HARTFORD  A week after shepherding into law the largest tax increase in Connecticut history, Gov. Dannel P. Malloy began issuing layoff notices on Tuesday to the first of more than 4,700 state employees facing dismissal, after two months of negotiations with unions failed to reach an agreement on worker concessions and budget cuts.

title: A Family Tragedy in a Neo-Nazi Home
description: Im trying to give human voice to people that most of society sees as monsters, said Julie Platner, a 28-year-old photojournalist and video journalist in Brooklyn.

title: Peace Corps Volunteers Speak Out on Rape
description: WASHINGTON  Jess Smochek arrived in Bangladesh in 2004 as a 23-year-old Peace Corps volunteer with dreams of teaching English and helping the world. She left six weeks later a rape victim after being brutalized in an alley by a knife-wielding gang.

title: TimesCast | Syria's Business Tycoon
description: In Syria, one man is the focal point of the protesters' economic grievances.

title: Lottery Numbers
Old Man With Clicker
description: HOLLYWOOD

title: Top FIFA Officials Are Named in Bribery Investigation
description: Jer Longman writes about the testimony Tuesday in a British parliamentary inquiry into corruption at the highest levels of soccer. A former F.A. president and one-time leader of Englands failed World Cup bid, David Triesman, accused four top FIFA officials of soliciting bribes for their votes in bidding to host the World Cup. Read the article here, and come back to comment.

title: President Obama at the Border
description: President Obama went to the border in El Paso on Tuesday and delivered a speech on immigration reform. He didnt present a bill or issue any executive orders or set deadlines for action. Aides say his goal was to create a pathway and a sense of urgency to move forward. That is a start but not nearly enough.

title: Bringing the Mall of America Magic to New Jersey
description: When the Ghermezian brothers, immigrants from Iran who had settled in western Canada, wanted to build the largest shopping center in the United States a quarter-century ago, they shipped a submarine that had been custom-built for them in Vancouver  and was an offbeat attraction at their mall in Edmonton  to Bloomington, Minn., and parked it in front of City Hall. Their company, Triple Five, won the development rights for what would become the Mall of America.

title: Ticket-Fixing: A New Twist in an Inquiry
description: Ticket-fixing was so prevalent among police officers in the Bronx that even a highway officer whose job was to administer Breathalyzer tests  the very tool used to determine if a driver is drunk  was himself caught on a wiretap trying to fix a ticket for someone, according to a person with knowledge of the contents of the wiretap.

title: Loan Limits' Effect on Counties
description: The National Association of Realtors calculations of how the change in government loan limits will affect various counties. The GSEs, or government-sponsored enterprises, are the government-controlled mortgage holding companies, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac.

title: Governor Presses Lawmakers in Albany to Pass His Agenda
description: ONONDAGA, N.Y.  Denouncing the State Legislature as riddled with conflicts of interest and unable to police itself, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo began a statewide tour on Tuesday intended to shame lawmakers into overhauling ethics rules and passing the rest of his legislative agenda.

title: Federal Retreat on Bigger Loans Rattles Housing
description: MONTEREY, Calif.  By summers end, buyers and sellers in some of the countrys most upscale housing markets are slated to lose one their biggest benefactors: the deep pockets of the federal government. In this seaside community of pricey homes, the dread of yet another housing shock is already spreading.

title: Wednesday: Youll Enjoy This
description: Administrivial NOTEPAD Alert! There is a notepad in the Across Lite version of this puzzle that reads as follows: When this puzzle is done, the 11 circled letters can be connected by a curved line to spell a two-word phrase appropriate to this puzzles theme.

title: Chelsea Piers Expands, Staying Close to Home
Belmont Casino Plan Could Aid Islanders
description: The Nassau County executive, Edward P. Mangano, will announce on Wednesday plans to pursue construction of an Indian casino at Belmont Park as part of a larger deal that may lead to a new arena for the Islanders.

title: G.M. to Spend $2 Billion in Hiring and to Upgrade U.S. Plants
description: TOLEDO, Ohio  General Motors said Tuesday that it would invest $2 billion in its factories in the United States to meet gradually growing demand for its products in the aftermath of its government-sponsored bankruptcy.

title: MoMA to Buy Building Used by Museum of Folk Art
description: The Museum of Modern Art is buying the building of the struggling American Folk Art Museum on West 53rd Street, officials said Tuesday.

title: Prosecution in Rape Trial Assails Story of Officer
description: A prosecutor on Tuesday grilled a police officer accused of rape on numerous minuscule details of the night in question.

title: Ex-Senator Needs Longer Sentence, Prosecutors Say
description: A former New York state senator who offered to serve as a diplomat in the Middle East to avoid a prison term of up to two years for his conviction on corruption charges should instead receive an even harsher sentence because he has failed to accept responsibility for his crimes, federal prosecutors told a judge on Tuesday.

title: From Low Draft Pick to Chance in Rotation
description: DENVER  By the time the 21st round of baseballs amateur draft arrived in 2007, Dillon Gee still had a faint hope of being selected by a major league team. But as he sat through each previous round without his name being called, Gee said he thought more and more about becoming a firefighter, like his father, Kevin Gee.

title: From Low Draft Pick to Chance in Rotation
description: DENVER  By the time the 21st round of baseballs amateur draft arrived in 2007, Dillon Gee still had a faint hope of being selected by a major league team. But as he sat through each previous round without his name being called, Gee said he thought more and more about becoming a firefighter, like his father, Kevin Gee.

title: Voicefeed Tries to Improve Voice Mail
description: It may seem the only way to improve voice mail is to do away with it. But an app called On Voicefeed, which lets you customize messages for different callers, makes voice jail a bit more palatable.

title: Post-Traumatic Childhood
description: Brookline, Mass.

title: Bad Luck and Hard Times on the Menu at a Bus Terminal in West Virginia
description: WEIRTON, W.Va.  The bus terminal in this old mill town used to be for people who were going places. Greyhound would take them to nearby Pittsburgh and Cleveland and other cities where the steel industry was booming.

title: A Social Networking Device for Smokers
description: Companies have started adding the ability to communicate wirelessly to an increasing range of devices, like tablet computers, cars and refrigerators.

title: At a Crucial Moment, Rodriguez Delivers for the Yankees
description: The moment would have been filled with noise and high drama even if Alex Rodriguez were not at the plate. The Yankees had loaded the bases with two out in the fifth inning Tuesday, and the sounds of sirens, explosions and rock music were pumped over the loudspeakers at Yankee Stadium.

title: Haitis Continuing Cholera Outbreak
description: A United Nations report on the cholera outbreak that has sickened 300,000 Haitians since last fall, killing nearly 5,000, finds evidence to suggest that the disease may have originated at a United Nations military camp north of the capital, which spilled raw sewage into a tributary of the Artibonite River. The epidemic was able to spread so far only because of the chronic and horrible deficiencies in Haitis sanitation and health care systems, which long predate the 2010 earthquake.

title: Florida Legislature Votes to Ease Rules on Development
description: MIAMI  Just before the Republican-led Florida Legislature finished up its session for the year, it gave developers a parting gift: It pushed through measures that would reverse 25 years of growth management law by loosening state oversight of builders and making it harder for people to challenge development.

title: Even for Gov. Christie, This Ones a Stretch
description: Gov. Chris Christie of New Jersey prides himself on his bluster and relishes the attention it garners in conservative circles beyond the state. He jumped the shark last month, suggesting he might defy the State Supreme Court if it orders him to make up a $1.6 billion shortfall of education financing that disproportionately punishes poorer districts and their students.

title: Skype Deal Is Unlikely to Pay Off for Microsoft
description: Microsoft has only recently embraced the Internet cloud. But from the perspective of its shareholders, thats certainly where its $8.5 billion deal to buy Skype belongs.

title: Prices of Imported Goods Increase as the Dollar Declines
description: Prices of goods imported into the United States rose 2.2 percent in April, more than forecast, as a slumping dollar and growing economies overseas pushed up the cost of fuel and food.

title: Cake Mixes, Taken Seriously
description: FOR decades, advertising for Duncan Hines cake mix has itself followed a recipe, featuring mothers baking cakes for children, or children encountering a freshly baked cake and mischievously helping themselves to a piece.

title: M.L.S. Salary Figures Released
description: Major League Soccers players union released the 2011 salary figures for the leagues players over the weekend, and the disparity between rich and poor was clear.

title: Republican Demands and the Debt Limit
description: Even before the White House and the Republicans began talks on the debt limit, John Boehner made clear that he was looking for a political fight, not a compromise.

title: Appellate Court Hears Defense of Health Law
description: RICHMOND, Va.  The Obama administration opened its appellate defense of the 2010 health care act on Tuesday before three randomly selected judges who each had been appointed by Democratic presidents, including two named by President Obama himself.

title: Another Bronx Getaway, This Time Without the Scales
description: Has the Bronx Zoo cobra been sharing her getaway secrets?

title: For Schwarzenegger and Shriver, a Transition and a Separation
description: LOS ANGELES  Since the start of the year, one of the big mysteries here has been what the states most famous couple  Arnold Schwarzenegger, the former governor, and Maria Shriver, a former television news correspondent and a daughter of the Kennedy dynasty would do after Mr. Schwarzenegger returned to private life.

title: Utah Immigration Law Is Blocked
description: A federal judge in Utah on Tuesday temporarily barred a state law to curb illegal immigration from taking effect, saying he wanted to give both sides in a lawsuit more time to prepare their arguments.

title: Ohio: Doctor Found Guilty on Drug Counts
description: A doctor who the federal authorities said was one of the largest national dispensers of Oxycodone, a powerful prescription painkiller, was convicted on Tuesday of illegal distribution. As a result of the verdict, in federal court in Cincinnati, Dr. Paul H. Volkman of Chicago could face life in prison for illegal distribution of a controlled substance that resulted in the death of four people in southern Ohio, where he practiced. Such a sentence would be the first of its kind in Ohio, where the authorities are trying to strengthen laws to combat the drug scourge, one of the worst in the nation.

title: California: High-Speed Rail Plan Is Questioned
description: California should rethink its plan to build the first leg of the nations only true high-speed rail project in a stretch of the Central Valley because it would attract too few riders, a report issued Tuesday by the State Legislative Analysts Office said. The report, which warns that the full route from San Francisco to Los Angeles may never be completed and is likely to cost more than the estimated $43 billion, calls for starting construction in a more densely populated area and for giving control of the project to the State Transportation Department. The independent authority currently overseeing the work said it would review the recommendations. The federal government has awarded the project $3.6 billion.

title: Alabama: Another Twist in Corruption Case
description: A federal appeals court has reversed two charges against a former health executive in a closely watched corruption case. The United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit, based in Atlanta, upheld most of the convictions stemming from $500,000 in contributions by Richard M. Scrushy, a former HealthSouth chief executive, to retire the debt of a state lottery campaign backed by former Gov. Don E. Siegelman, and sent both mens cases back to Federal District Court for resentencing. A Department of Justice spokeswoman, Laura Sweeney, said the department was pleased with the courts decision. But Sam Heldman, an attorney for Mr. Siegelman, said the courts definition of bribery was open to interpretation by prosecutors, and many politicians and contributors could run afoul of it. It places everyones liberty at the mercy of mind readers, he said.

title: Not Even Warhol Can Liven a Slow Night at Sothebys
description: A mix of overly optimistic sellers and price-conscious buyers made for a bumpy evening at Sothebys sale of contemporary art on Tuesday night. In an overflowing salesroom filled with big-money collectors like the former Hollywood agent Michael Ovitz, the fashion designer Valentino and the Los Angeles financier Eli Broad, the audience did more watching than shopping, with thin bidding on the most expensive works.

title: Chip Supplier Sees Full Output in Fall
description: The worlds leading supplier of electronic control chips for automobiles, whose main factory was heavily damaged by Japans powerful earthquake, said it hoped to resume full shipments to customers by the end of October.

title: Chinas Efforts to Cut Inflation Fall Short
description: HONG KONG  Consumer prices in April rose faster than the Chinese governments target for the fourth month in a row, as bank lending also climbed faster than expected, economic data released Wednesday morning showed.

title: Rent vs. Buy, a Longer List
description: My column this week revisits the question of whether to buy a home or rent one. In the newspaper, we included a chart showing average rent ratios  the purchase price of a house divided by the annual rent of a similar house  for several metropolitan areas. Here, we include a longer list.

title: Stephen Herrero on Black Bear Attacks
description: Stephen Herrero, a University of Calgary professor emeritus, discusses a new study of fatal black bear attacks in North America.

title: Visa Advances Toward a Digital Wallet
description: Visa is taking another big step in its continuing efforts to create a universal digital wallet.

title: Study of Black Bears Finds Its Not the Mamas That Should Be Feared the Most
description: If you believe Stephen Colbert  and really, who doesnt?  bears are deadly.

title: Fidgeting Your Way to Fitness
description: If work is interfering with your plans for a workout today, perhaps you should drum your fingers against your desktop in frustration. Doing so may help, in some small way, to maintain or augment your fitness, at least according to a study published last month in the journal Medicine & Science in Sports & Exercise.

description: Updated

title: Hospitals Tally the Tolls of Fighting
description: As fighting continues in Libya, the dead and wounded are tended before fighters re-join the front.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Art From Allan Stone Estate Is a Big Draw
description: Sculptures fashioned from mangled bits of old cars, and paintings depicting cakes topped with fluffy frosting, gave a peek at the visual world of Allan Stone, the legendary Manhattan dealer who died in 2006, and whose collection was the subject of a special sale at Sothebys on Monday.

title: Chile: Power Project Approved
description: Officials in Chile have approved a huge hydroelectric project in the heart of Patagonia, setting off protests by environmentalists in several cities. The Environmental Assessment Commission of Coyhaique, a regional government commission in southern Chile, approved on Monday the $3.2 billion project, which involves a series of five dams in the sparsely populated region of Aysn, which is dotted with nature reserves. Government officials say the HidroAysn project is needed to help stave off an energy squeeze in Chile, which imports about 70 percent of its energy. Environmentalists say it will flood thousands of acres of largely undeveloped territory and damage ranching and tourism. The police arrested at least 60 people late Monday in Santiago at a downtown protest that attracted thousands. Hundreds of demonstrators also took to the streets in at least four other Chilean cities. Opponents, including some members of Chiles Congress, said Tuesday that they would appeal in court, while opposition legislators said they would request a congressional investigation into irregularities in the projects approval.

title: Davis Helps Mets Win, but Is Injured in a Collision
description: DENVER  A well-earned victory on a soggy evening at Coors Field was tinged with a measure of concern for the Mets, who suffered a loss despite their 4-3 victory over the Colorado Rockies.

title: News Quiz | May 11, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Test Yourself | Math, May 11, 2011
description: Test your math skills with todays question, created by Patrick Honner at Math for America from the article Uncertainty of Whats Next for Dodgers.

title: F.A. Official Names Names, but Only After Playing Along
description: There was a strong stench of foul play when FIFA awarded the hosting rights of the 2018 and 2022 World Cups to Russia and Qatar six months ago. Several reports of corruption and bribery within the sports world governing body preceded the final voting process, calling into question the integrity of the organization and way in which it operates. And the final decision only served to heighten suspicions.

title: After Quake, Toyotas Profit Plummets 77%
description: Toyota, whose operations have been severely disrupted since the March 11 earthquake and tsunami in Japan, said Wednesday that its quarterly profit fell 77 percent but that it expected production to begin recovering up to two months sooner than previously forecast.

title: HSBC Aiming to Cut $3.5 Billion in Costs
description: 7:49 p.m. | Updated

title: Salvation Pursued Musically
description: Paul Simon assumed the voice of God at the Beacon Theater on Tuesday night. I mean that literally: during an interlude in Love Is Eternal Sacred Light from his new album, So Beautiful or So What, Mr. Simon threw his arms wide, deepened his voice and ventured his best deity. Somehow the Supreme Being, confiding and complaining as if bellied up to the bar, sounded a lot like a guy in a Paul Simon song.

description: WHO have been seriously affected by flooding from the Mississippi River?

description: A new article about the Disney tween star China Anne McClain looks at the pressures in the lives of todays tween and teen stars. Would you want to be famous under the age of 18? Why or why not? Why do you think so many young stars get into trouble?

title: Syria Shells Major City as Crackdown Spreads
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian military intensified a methodical, ferocious march across the countrys most restive locales on Wednesday, shelling the countrys third-largest city from tanks, forcing hundreds to flee and detaining hundreds more in what has emerged as one of the most brutal waves of repression since the Arab Spring began.

title: Kanye West Turns Melodious and Moody at MoMA
description: Moving forward, every Kanye West show should conclude with a rant. In November, at the intimate concert he played at the Bowery Ballroom to celebrate the release of his latest album, My Beautiful Dark Twisted Fantasy, he closed the night with 10 minutes or so of wounded tongue lashings and self-lacerations.

description: Casey B. Mulligan is an economics professor at the University of Chicago.

title: A Drinkers Guide to Mumbais Permit Rooms
description: Considering Mumbais reputation as Indias night-life capital, it is something of an anomaly that the city is still technically under prohibition. Imposed by the state government shortly after India achieved Independence, prohibition has been gradually eased over the years but was never completely lifted. One of the remaining constraints is that anyone attempting to purchase or consume alcohol must obtain a permit declaring that they continue to require foreign liquor and country liquor for preservation and maintenance of my health.

title: The Early Word: The Next Step
description: Todays Times

title: Q&A: Pruning the Mac Address Book
description: Q.

title: The Sweet Spot of Business Growth
description: The growth of business revenue can be steady or sporadic, and it can also reverse itself and go down. Even more complicated is profit, which does not always stay on speaking terms with revenue. Even when sales can go up, profit can go south. The reverse can also happen, which may seem counterintuitive. Let me explain.

title: Old Mutual Investment Group Hires New C.F.O.
description: Old Mutual Asset Management, the asset management and hedge fund arm of the London-based life insurer, named Steve Belgrad as chief financial officer on Wednesday.

title: After 60 Years, an Unfaded Desire to Make It Legal
description: Richard Adrian Dorr first sang for John Mace at the Juilliard School of Music in 1948: a rendition of the show tune All the Things You Are, in which the singer elegantly explains all the wonderful things his lover is to him.

title: Obama and Boehner Face Off on Role of Government
description: The coming clash between President Obama and House Speaker John A. Boehner over the budget, entitlements and the nations debt is being driven by political calculations that will loom large in tense negotiations this spring and into the summer.

title: In the Dark, Maybe, but Not Lost
description: Why are we in this tunnel? my mother asks sharply from the back seat.

title: Trial of American Hikers Charged With Espionage in Iran Is Unexpectedly Delayed
description: PARIS  The trial of three Americans charged with espionage and illegal entry in Iran after their arrest almost two years ago near the border with Iraqi Kurdistan failed to resume in Tehran on Wednesday, and their Iranian lawyer said he had formally protested the delay.

title: Inflation and Economic Hooliganism
description: In a way, I miss the months that followed Lehmans failure. O.K., not really  but if it was a time of terror, it was also a time of clarity. The whole world was going to hell in a handbasket, and policy makers everywhere shared a common goal: stopping the plunge.

title: Gold Mania in the Yukon
description: When I first met Shawn Ryan and Cathy Wood, in 2005, they were living with their two young children in a small cabin outside Dawson City, at the northernmost end of the paved road system in Canadas Yukon Territory. It was a beautiful site in the summertime, with clear water lapping the banks of the Klondike River and the sky still bright at midnight. But the sun hit their roof for the last time each year in early December and didnt show up again for six weeks. Temperatures in the dead of winter could reach 50 below zero. Wood sometimes feared that their children would freeze. Back then Ryan and Wood already knew they had found gold, but they didnt have proof.

title: A.I.G. Outlines Share Sale Plan
Woody Allen Headlines Cannes Guest List
description: PARIS  As the film world and its attendant paparazzi and army of scribes descend upon the 64th Cannes Film Festival that begins today and runs through May 22, the French media has mused less about the plot of the opening film, Woody Allens Midnight in Paris, than over whether one of its cast members, Carla Bruni-Sarkozy, the first lady of France, would be one of those descending.

title: Ex-Mets Employee Charged in Theft
description: The former Mets clubhouse manager Charlie Samuels was charged Wednesday in connection with the theft of nearly $2.3 million worth of team equipment and memorabilia  from hats, bats and balls to a full set of autographed 1986 World Series uniforms.

title: The Duck Starts Here
description: Each of David Changs restaurant is a different animal, it seems. Momofuku Ssam Bar has a whole pork butt, Momofuku Noodle Bar serves a mountain of fried chicken, and M Pche does beef seven ways.

title: Duck and Cover and Check Your Cellphone
description: Those of us old enough to remember I Love Lucy when it was a hot new thing on television are also old enough to remember civil defense drills that had us ducking under our desks at school. Received wisdom back then seemed to be that if the Russians ever dropped the big one, the desks would keep us from being vaporized like soldiers in the original The Day the Earth Stood Still.

title: Quote Unquote | The Will to Power Indeed
description: -Karl Lagerfeld tells WWD about his latest project: publishing the complete writings of Friedrich Nietzsche. Easy is totally a word I would use to describe Nietzsches writing.

title: Venice Reclaimed
description: The common refrain about Venice, besides that its sinking, is that it is no longer a city for Venetians. The native population is declining (as is most of Italys), replaced by some 20 million tourists a year. But several recent restoration projects, both well financed and small-scale, are bringing a sense of localism back to the city.

title: Is Another Housing Crash Coming?
description: Looking at the relative prices of buying and renting homes in Silicon Valley, Manhattan and a few other places is enough to make you wonder whether parts of the housing market are still due for a crash. To consider that question in more detail, I had a conversation with Mark Zandi, the chief economist at Moodys Analytics, which provided much of the data for my column:

title: Wednesday Reading: Antipsychotic Drugs Overused in Nursing Homes
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Merkel Signals Support for Italian to Lead E.C.B.
description: BERLIN  Germany moved Wednesday to reassure financial markets by supporting Mario Draghi as the next president of the European Central Bank, virtually assuring him of the job, but offered no quick end to uncertainty over the continuing Greek and Irish debt crises.

title: Tea Party Express Endorses Nelson Rival in Nebraska
description: The Tea Party Express, whose money and endorsements proved key to the victories of several Senate candidates in 2010, has made its first endorsement for 2012, backing Jon Bruning, a Republican who serves as Nebraskas attorney general, in his bid to unseat Senator Ben Nelson, a Democrat.

title: Confronting the Anthropocene
description: LONDON  Im participating in a one-day meeting at the Geological Society of London exploring the evidence for, and meaning of, the Anthropocene. This is the proposed epoch of Earth history that, proponents say, has begun with the rise of the human species as a globally potent biogeophysical force, capable of leaving a durable imprint in the geological record.

title: Court Backs Veterans Complaints on Mental Health Services
description: In a sweeping decision released Tuesday, the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ruled that unchecked incompetence by the Department of Veterans Affairs had led to poor mental health care and slow processing of disability claims for veterans.

title: Warm Welcome for Animal Kingdom at Fair Hill
description: A crowd of about 30 people gathered to welcome Animal Kingdom, winner of the Kentucky Derby, to Fair Hill on Tuesday. The group was a mix of Fair Hill horsemen, fans and local news media.

title: Americans Abroad, Part 1: The Top of the Class
description: Most of the soccer leagues around the world are winding down this month, which means that it is a good time to assess how United States national team regulars performed for their club teams.

title: A Polling-Based Forecast of the Republican Primary Field
description: This is the finale of a four-part series (Part I, Part II, Part III) evaluating the utility of early presidential primary polls as forecasting instruments. My contention is that these polls have enough predictive power to be a worthwhile starting point for handicapping a field of candidates. In this article, well see what they have to say about the Republican contenders for 2012.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: A.I.G. Lays Out Plan for Share Sale | The American International Group and the Treasury Department will sell roughly 300 million shares, in the insurers latest step toward regaining its independence from the government.

title: Japan Looks to an Uncertain Future
description: The natural and nuclear disasters unleashed on March 11 have exposed the fragility of Japans postwar economic order. Rebuilding will require a national rethinking, many experts say, if this country is to achieve an economic rebirth.

title: Japan Ponders Its New Normal
description: ISHINOMAKI, Japan  Its factory wiped out by the tsunami, a maker of vital parts for smartphones says it will move production overseas.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Jury Reaches Verdict in Rajaratnam Trial
description: The federal jury in Manhattan deciding the fate of Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire chief of the Galleon Group hedge fund, reached a verdict on Wednesday.

title: Pakistani Is Seeking Inquiry on U.S. Raid
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The leader of the main opposition party called on Wednesday for an independent inquiry into why the Pakistani Army had no knowledge of the American raid that killed Osama bin Laden.

title: Bloomberg Given Poor Marks in New Poll
description: Its the schools, stupid.

title: Ristretto | In Philadelphia
description: Philadelphia has plenty going for it: the best four-man rotation in baseball, art worth fighting over, a ruin so elegant and haunting it feels like Berlin. It also has superb coffee. Recently, I went on a coffee crawl that took me to a handful of shops where the baristas arent just tremendously skilled, theyre disarmingly sweet-natured. I found an energetic scene thriving outside the gravitational pull of the hometown giant La Colombe Torrefaction.

title: A Report Card on Transportation Spending
description: A study that examined how states account for billions of dollars spent annually on transportation found that most are not tracking how their investments are performing in six important areas, among them mitigating the effects of transportation on the environment.

title: At 100, Still a Teacher, and Quite a Character
description: When Bel Kaufman sits you down on her sofa and asks, Are you comfortable? the right answer, she reminds you, requires a Yiddish inflection, a shrug and the words, I make a living.

title: Senate Democrats Reintroduce Dream Act
description: On the heels of President Obamas renewed call to overhaul the nations immigration laws in Texas on Tuesday, Senate Democrats are reintroducing a bill that would give legal status to some illegal immigrants who came into the United States as children.

title: Taking Airport, Rebels in Libya Loosen Noose
description: MISURATA, Libya  Rebels in the contested western city of Misurata stormed the citys airport on Wednesday afternoon, swarming over the grounds from the south and east and reclaiming it from the military of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Syria Sent Missing Al Jazeera Journalist to Iran
description: A reporter for Al Jazeeras English-language news channel who disappeared while covering the uprising in Syria almost two weeks ago was sent to Iran within two days of being detained by Syrian authorities, the network confirmed Wednesday.

title: Hedge Fund Billionaire Is Guilty of Insider Trading
description: Raj Rajaratnam, the billionaire investor who once ran one of the worlds largest hedge funds, was found guilty on Wednesday of fraud and conspiracy by a federal jury in Manhattan. He is the most prominent figure convicted in the governments crackdown on insider trading on Wall Street.

title: The Voices of the Galleon Trial
description: In the insider trading trial of Raj Rajaratnam, the government built its case against the billionaire co-founder of the Galleon Group in large part on a series of secretly recorded phone conversations. Prosecutors said these tapes showed how the hedge fund manager obtained illicit information on several stocks and traded on it. Mr. Rajaratnam was found guilty of all the charges against him, and he is the most prominent figure convicted in the governments crackdown on insider trading on Wall Street.

title: Can Hate Be Part of Good Parenting?
description: I was riveted and horrified this morning by my colleague Jesse McKinleys story of the Hall family of Riverside, Calif.

title: Graphic: The Rajaratnam Verdict
description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan accused Raj Rajaratnam, the chief of the Galleon Group hedge fund, of being at the center of a network that traded stocks on illegal tips from 2003 to March 2009.

title: Goslings Defy Prospect Parks Birth Control Effort
description: Updated, 12:10 p.m. | Score four, at least, for the Prospect Park geese.

title: A Fortunetellers Prophecy: Dartmouth vs. Princeton
description: Last year, at a school-sponsored event called After Prom, a fortuneteller predicted that I was going to make a tough choice between two great colleges. Despite my disbelief in such prophecies, I walked off wondering how likely that would be.

title: Imagining the Sound of a Taxi Horn Not Honking
description: Out-of-control horns are one of the biggest complaints about taxis in New York. So thousands of ringing ears perked up last week when the city announced that its high-tech new taxicab, the Nissan NV200, would include a so-called low-annoyance horn, which promised to reduce ear-splitting honks.

title: Rare Works Stolen From Exhibition at Forbidden City in Beijing
description: BEIJING  Rare handicrafts from a private museum in Hong Kong that were on display at the Forbidden City in Beijing were stolen on Sunday, forcing a shutdown of one part of the ancient palace, according to an article on Wednesday in the English-language edition of Global Times, a government-run newspaper in Beijing.

title: Double Faults
description: It hardly qualifies as news these days when another athlete gets in Twitter trouble. But there was something a little deeper going on in the case of the tennis player Donald Young a few weeks ago. Young, upset at how the U.S.T.A. was allotting the wild-card entry it had to the French Open this month (the association used a playoff that Young lost), leveled a tweet at the organization that we cant print. Patrick McEnroe, the head of player of development, blasted back and demanded an apology from Young before his organization would back Young any further. (Young closed out his Twitter account and apologized.) Beneath it all there seemed to simmer tensions over coaching, player development and support and maybe even race.

title: Schrdingers Seat
description: Term for House seats which may or may not exist, depending on how district lines are drawn.Writing for National Journal, Charlie Cook commented:

title: Round Up the Usual C.E.O.s
description: It has been nearly a year since the chief executives of the five biggest multinational oil companies were hauled before a committee of Congress for a ritual flaying. Last June, the heads of Exxon Mobil, Chevron, Shell, BP and ConocoPhillips were called by the House Energy and Commerce Committee to testify on the Deepwater Horizon disaster, which at the time was still pouring 50,000 barrels of oil a day into the Gulf of Mexico.

title: Collecting Sediments on the Ocean Floor
description: Alyson Santoro, a postdoctoral researcher at Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, writes from off the coast of Chile, where she is studying microbes in the nitrogen cycle.

title: Quote Unquote | Artistic License
description: Abbey Lee Kershaw describes the difference between her day job and her night job, poet not being one of them.

title: TimesCast | Revolutionary Jasmine
description: In China, jasmine is seen as a problematic revolutionary symbol.

title: Woman Who Left Newborn in Trash Is Arrested, Police Say
description: A woman who left her newborn girl in a Queens hospital bathroom trash can on Tuesday has been arrested, the police said.

title: 13 Ways to Save on Gas this Summer
description: HEADING for the highway this summer? The great American road trip will cost you more than last year thanks to high fuel prices.

title: Wednesdays Mets-Rockies Game Rained Out
description: DENVER  Wednesdays scheduled game here between the Mets and the Colorado Rockies has been rained out and rescheduled for Thursday at 3:10 p.m., Eastern time. Both teams had a free day Thursday, after which the Mets will fly to Houston for a three-game series with the Houston Astros.

title: Britain Warns of Inflation Risk
description: The Bank of England warned Wednesday that inflation in Britain could hit 5 percent this year, raising the likelihood that the central bank would lift its main interest rate from the record low level at which it has stood since the depths of the financial crisis.

title: A Sinking Feeling in San Jose
description: It appears to be the year of the psychiatrists couch in the N.H.L. playoffs. We found the Vancouver Canucks there in the first round, talking through their franchises childhood issues, that being 40 years of acute stress disorder. Therapy resulted in a cathartic Game 7 victory over the tormenting Blackhawks. Now, its San Joses turn. Driven to near distraction by the Red Wings charge back from a 3-0 deficit to tie their second-round series, the Sharks now need to be saved from their own screaming psyches.
