title: Why Austin, Tex.,  Is a Good Place for Small Businesses
description: Recently, Austin was ranked No. 1 in small-business vitality for the second year in a row in a survey by the American City Business Journals.

title: Engineers Gather, Asking What Makes the City Tick
description: It was the last Tuesday of the month, and, like clockwork, the geeks arrived in droves. Dozens of engineers, computer programmers and physicists  most of them grayed and balding, dressed in what might best be described as retro-nerd  crammed into an upper-floor conference room near Union Square.

title: Hillary Clinton Takes Seat at Arctic Council
description: Officials of the eight Arctic nations are taking their first concrete step to cooperate in an ecologically fragile region where climate change is driving economic competition.

title: Suspects in Terror Case Wanted to Kill Jews, Officials Say
description: The 26-year-old man from Queens had discussed growing a beard and the side curls of a Hasidic Jew, the police commissioner said, a disguise that he apparently hoped would enable him to attack a synagogue in Manhattan and take out the whole entire building.

title: Demjanjuk Convicted for Role in Nazi Death Camp
description: MUNICH  In what may be one of the last major Nazi war crimes trials, a German court sentenced John Demjanjuk, a former autoworker in Ohio, to five years in prison after he was found guilty of taking part in the murder of 28,000 people while working as a guard at the Sobibor concentration camp in Nazi-occupied Poland in 1943.

title: Romney Confronts Health Care Questions
description: Is Mitt Romney, the former Republican governor of Massachusetts, an advocate for a state version of what conservatives derisively call Obamacare?

title: Watching Whales Around the Clock
description: Kate Stafford, an oceanographer at the Applied Physics Laboratory at the University of Washington, writes from Alaska, where she is participating in a visual census of bowhead whales.

title: On Broadway, Old Friends Walking on Air
description: WHATS new? is not, as a general rule, a tactful way to begin a conversation about Broadway. Its sort of like asking an agoraphobic shut-in, And where have you been lately? Still, go ahead. Ask me whats new this season on Broadway, the one thats being celebrated by the presentation of the 65th annual Tony Awards on June 12. For once, I can provide some encouraging answers.

title: Down-and-Outs Are Center Stage Once Again
description: IF youre hungering for entertainment that confronts the bruising realities of the current economic climate, it probably wouldnt occur to you to hail the nearest taxi and request that the driver take you to a Broadway theater  any Broadway theater.

title: After Rebel Success in Misurata, NATO Strikes Tripoli
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Less than 12 hours after rebels reclaimed the airport in the contested western city of Misurata, explosions echoed across Tripoli as NATO warplanes struck a large, heavily guarded compound that serves as a base for Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

title: Wash, Let It Dry, Comb It. Thats Trumps Deal.
description: For many of you, maybe most, this is going to fall squarely under the heading of T.M.I., but the New Yorker who defies parody more than any other admits to using a comb but not a hair dryer. That would be Donald Trump. Before you start groaning, remember: You were told going in that this might qualify as too much information.

title: Thursday Reading: The Mixed Results of Designing Clothes Online
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: This Old Hotel
description: Turning a historic house  whether designed for laborers or lords  into a hotel is never easy. When Fred Krehbiel, a Chicago industrialist, decided to buy Ballyfin, a Georgian manor on 600 acres in Irelands County Laois, the property was being used as a school, he says, and we had to give them six years to build a new building. During that time, Krehbiels team of more than 100 workers began transforming the 1812 mansion into a hotel with 15 rooms, all while working around 500 teenagers. Krehbiel and crew restored ornate plasterwork, bought back some of the previous owners paintings, rebuilt the conservatory (which had to be disassembled and shipped to England for repairs) and even uncovered a Roman sarcophagus bathtub, now installed in one of the guest rooms. (Appropriately, a family motto of Ballyfins original owner, Sir Charles Coote, was cote que cote  cost what it may.)

title: Insights on Stimulus, Thanks to the Mafia
description: It is hard to prove that a burst of public spending can stimulate economic activity. Governments generally try the experiment in response to a downturn, and who is to say how quickly an economy would have recovered?

title: Will Ferrell to Receive Mark Twain Prize for Humor
description: The Mark Twain Prize for American Humor is named for one of historys most distinguished satirists and has, since 1998, been awarded to noteworthy comedians and writers like Whoopi Goldberg, Bob Newhart, Neil Simon and Bill Cosby. But somehow, it just got a little classier: Will Ferrell, the Saturday Night Live alumnus turned star of hit films like Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby and Anchorman: The Legend of Ron Burgundy, will be the 14th recipient of the Mark Twain Prize, the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts said on Thursday morning. Mr. Ferrell said in a statement that he was truly honored to receive this distinction, adding: I will now begin cultivating a Mark Twain-esque mustache in anticipation of the event.

title: American Idol: The Top 4
description: James Durbin > Scotty McCreery > Lauren Alaina > Haley Reinhart

title: Oil Executives, Defending Tax Breaks, Say Theyd Cede Them if Everyone Did
description: WASHINGTON  Executives of five of the largest oil companies on Thursday defended the $2.1 billion they receive each year in tax breaks, but said they would be willing to give them up as part of a comprehensive reform of the tax code.

title: Town Hall Participants Ask Obama for Help
description: What do you do if your mortgage is under water or youve lost your job in the federal government?

title: 2nd G.M. Stock Sale May Come Later Than Expected
description: 7:52 p.m. | Updated

title: Midnight in Cannes and a Surreal Opening Ceremony
description: CANNES, France  Lady Gaga was performing on the beach a few hundred feet away, but youd never have known it at the start of the Cannes Film Festival on Wednesday, where everything was Woody-mania. The French have made no secret of their adoration for Monsieur Allen, whose Midnight in Paris opened the festivities, and drew legions of fans to the Palais des Festivals. We will be on a balcony overlooking it, saying, Woody, Woody!  said one local, who couldnt manage to get in. Around the red carpet, among the throngs of tuxedo-clad men looking for extra tickets to the premiere, was one who held a sign which read simply: Woody  Merci.

title: Americans Abroad, Part II: The Rest of the Class
description: On Wednesday we posted our grades for the top-performing American soccer players competing overseas  the honor roll, if you will.

title: Use Your Words
description: Its notoriously difficult to figure out which top collegiate quarterbacks will succeed in the NFL. Pro teams give prospects an SAT-type test called the Wonderlic test, which doesnt predict all that accurately. A company called Achievement Metrics, on the other hand, studies the words college athletes use in media interviews. Some use words that signal high degrees of confidence, conceptual complexity and team orientation. Others use words that signal self-centeredness and distrust.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Chartjunk
description: The Washington Monthly has a good profile of Edward Tufte, the graphics guru. I read Tufte many years ago, and have tried to take to heart his strictures on how to present data visually. In particular, I took to heart his injunctions against chartjunk, which the article defines as

title: As Commodities Rebound, Major Indexes Close Higher
description: Stock markets in the United States rose while the dollar fell and commodities rebounded from an early slump led by Chinas efforts to curb lending.

title: New For Flip Videos: An Expiration Date
description: Ever since Cisco said it would stop making its popular Flip video cameras, consumers have wondered what will happen to their videos stored on FlipShares Web service. Now the company is telling us. It has announced two important deadlines for Flip video camera owners if they want to keep and share their movies. One is coming up fast, and the other is a little further out.

title: WikiLeaks Confidentiality Agreement Leaked
description: Updated | 7:09 p.m. According to a leaked copy of a confidentiality agreement that WikiLeaks asked members of its staff to sign, people working for the anti-secrecy group were obliged to agree to keep secret not only the contents of documents obtained by the organization, but also any newsworthy information related to the workings of WikiLeaks.

title: Styled to a T | Lapo Elkann
description: The Guy

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links from the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Poetry Pairing | May 12, 2011
description: In our weekly Poetry Pairing series, we collaborate with the Poetry Foundation to feature a work from its American Life in Poetry project alongside content from The Times that somehow echoes, extends or challenges the poems themes. Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

title: An M.L.S. Stat Pack
description: For the stat freaks who often lament the absence of sabermetrics (ad nauseam) in soccer  your time is coming.

title: Theft Reveals Lapses in Chinese Museums Security
description: HONG KONG  A bungled art theft this week at the Palace Museum in the Forbidden City in Beijing may not have been worthy of a master thief, with the police quickly claiming to have found the suspect, but the episode has nonetheless produced questions and criticism about security at Chinese museums.

title: With Help From Shapeways, You Can Print Your Dishes
description: Shapeways, a company that allows people to print 3-D objects, announced on Thursday that it will now let you print things in a ceramic material that is food safe. Until now, 3-D printers have primarily printed in plastics or other materials that you wouldnt want to eat off of.

title: Uniting a Continent Through a Wacky Song Contest
description: DSSELDORF, Germany  When the Armenian singer known as Emmy appeared onstage sitting in an oversize boxing glove on Tuesday night, European viewers knew that at least one performer was upholding the traditions that the Eurovision Song Contest is known for: an over-the-top stage performance and a forgettable tune sung in questionable English.

title: Goldmans Shares Drop Sharply After Downgrade
description: Shares of Goldman Sachs are under pressure following a scathing report from an outspoken industry analyst.

title: Anchors Are Chosen for NPR and PBS News Programs
description: Two public broadcasting anchor chairs are getting new occupants. Audie Cornish, National Public Radios Congressional correspondent, will be the new host of Weekend Edition Sunday, NPR announced Thursday, while Jim Lehrer of PBS said he is stepping down from a regular anchor role on the PBS NewsHour effective June 6.

title: The Mother Behind a Derby-Winning Trainer
description: In a bucket-list moment, Julie June Stewart woke up at 4 a.m. and bought a ticket to the 2008 Belmont. She hasnt stopped going to the races since. That is when she isnt isnt taking on a wildfire, hurricane, volcano or oil spill as the nations leading expert in disaster airspace coordination.

title: Met Museum Sues Man Who Bought a Painting It Wasnt Selling
description: In Chapter 2 of a long story that is growing longer, the Metropolitan Museum of Art filed suit Tuesday in United States District Court in Manhattan seeking possession of a painting now in the hands of Robert Wylde, a British collector. The 1981 painting, The Innocent Eye Test by Mark Tansey, was bought by Mr. Wylde for $2.5 million from the Gagosian Gallery in 2009. Last year, the gallery told Mr. Wylde it had learned that the Met already owned 31 percent of the painting  which depicts a cow gazing at a portrait of other cows  and that the other owner had promised that the museum would eventually own the whole thing. Mr. Wylde filed suit in federal court in Manhattan against the gallery in March of this year, contending it had misled him, and held on to the painting.

title: F-Factor
description: The influence of Friends, Fans and Followers on purchasing decisions.

title: Butchers of the World, Unite!
description: On June 1, people who love meat will have a new way to express their feelings: by joining the Butchers Guild, a new trade organization for butchers. The guild was started last month, complete with a mission statement, a crest (a hand, a heart, a steer, a book) and an oath. The founders, Tia Harrison (a chef and butcher) and Marissa Guggiano (a writer), say the goal is to build an active national community of butchers and meat-centric chefs. Charter members include the nose-to-tail celebrities Chris Cosentino of Boccalone in San Francisco, Guy Arnone of Eataly in Manhattan and the women behind the hip new butcher shop Lindy & Grundy  in Los Angeles, Erika Nakamura and Amelia Posada. (Tattoos are not required for membership, though they are prevalent.)

title: Piecing Together a Supply Chain
description: DETROIT  Two months after Japans devastating earthquake and tsunami, Japanese automakers in the United States continue to struggle with significant supply disruptions.

title: Doing the Flamenco on the Beach at Cannes
description: CANNES, France  Not everything was official pomp and circumstance on the opening day of the Cannes Film Festival; there were also some unofficial stunts. The first red carpet event was around a film thats not even close to being in competition, the animated Puss in Boots, a prequel spinoff from Shrek, starring Antonio Banderas as Puss and Salma Hayek as Kitty Softpaws.

title: A Portrait of Parkinsons Disease
description: Karen Alexander says she is one of the lucky ones. Ten years after learning she has Parkinsons disease, she takes two drugs to control her symptoms and so far has few of them. A tremor on her left side can make it hard to balance a teacup and saucer, but at 74, it doesnt bother me much, she said. Luckily, Ms. Alexander, who lives in a suburb west of Chicago, is right-handed.

title: Crime Wave in Egypt Has People Afraid, Even the Police
description: CAIRO  The neighbors watched helplessly from behind locked gates as an exchange of gunfire rang out at the police station. Then about 80 prisoners burst through the stations doors  some clad only in underwear, many brandishing guns, machetes, even a fire extinguisher  as the police fled.

title: Bogged Down on Big Issues, Iraq Takes Aim at Smoking
description: BAGHDAD  In a country where the power blinks out several times a day, where filling up a gas tank can take hours and motorists stew in seemingly endless traffic jams, smoking is one thing that seems blissfully easy.

title: A Cannes Conversation About Women in Film
description: CANNES, France  There are a record number of female filmmakers competing for the biggest prizes in competition for the Palme dOr at the Cannes Film Festival this year: four. Thats 4 out of 20 (last year, there were zero women in the competition). As lopsided as that 20 percent figure may still be, some of the buzzed-about films around the Croissette this year are directed by women, including Lynne Ramsays We Need to Talk About Kevin and Julia Leighs Sleeping Beauty. An entry far out of the competition, Kung Fu Panda 2, the animated sequel starring Angelina Jolie, Jack Black and Dustin Hoffman, was directed by Jennifer Yuh, who was a story artist on the first film; at a press conference on Thursday, a journalist asked Ms. Jolie if her character was more developed because of Ms. Yuhs involvement. (Ms. Jolie, who plays a tigress, hedged an answer. I do feel if we had a male director, I would have had a bigger part, Mr. Hoffman  red panda  said jokingly.) Other films have notable female performances, like The Beloved, in which Catherine Deneuve stars, and sings, with her daughter, Chiara Mastroianni. It is scheduled to be the festivals closing film.

title: For Chihuahuas, the Race Is Not Always Swift
description: There is no starting gun at a Chihuahua race. The loud noise might unduly alarm the competitors, who are high-strung even when not running for $1,000 in prize money.

title: A Web of Spider-Man Credits
description: Its C.S.I.: Broadway: Whose name is rendered in bigger typeface on the new title page of the Playbill for the musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark, Julie Taymors or Philip William McKinleys?

title: Kelly Is Praised as the Man for the Job Atop the F.B.I.
description: Update, 1:15 p.m. | On Thursday, shortly after this post was published, President Obama asked Congress to extend the 10-year term of Robert S. Mueller III, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, for another two years.

title: More Lobsters on the Streets of Manhattan
description: On Monday, a Lukes Lobster truck came to Midtown. On Thursday, as Grub Street reported, the Red Hook Lobster Pound rolled out its own roving lobstermobile. It says it is testing the waters and will try to be out as many days a week as possible serving hot Connecticut lobster rolls and cold Maine lobster salad rolls ($16).

title: A Glow From Within and on the Surface
description: NEWARK  This vulnerable and volatile city, stuck on the downside of a boom-and-bust cycle for decades, could be one of the most peaceful places on earth for the next few days.

title: Building Wealth Through Renting
description: You have probably heard a version of the idea that renting a house is tantamount to flushing money down the toilet, while buying a home is building equity for your future. Well, its wrong, at least much of the time.

title: Woods Limps Off Course, His Future Uncertain
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  Tiger Woodss sudden, unexpected withdrawal from the Players Championship on Thursday because of nagging pain from his surgically repaired left knee will have ripple effects well beyond this week.

title: Jim Lehrer to Step Down as Anchor of NewsHour
description: Elizabeth Jensen reports on Arts Beat that PBSs Jim Lehrer is stepping down from a regular anchor role on the PBS NewsHour effective June 6. Mr. Lehrer said he would continue to appear on the program many Fridays.

title: Officials in Louisiana Face Dilemma: Bad Flooding, or Worse
description: YAZOO CITY, Miss.  As the crest moves steadily down the Mississippi River, unhurriedly receding in Memphis while sending its backwaters at a rapid clip across the farmland of the Mississippi Delta, officials from the Army Corps of Engineers on Thursday were coming close to making one of the most momentous decisions remaining on their list of flood-fighting options.

title: At 96 M.P.H., Pitcher Gives the Mariners Added Hope
description: BALTIMORE  Ken Griffey Jr. was back in the Seattle Mariners clubhouse on Tuesday, which meant the usual heckling, cackling and general clubhouse mayhem. Spotting Ichiro Suzuki with his back turned, Griffey wrapped him in his arms and tickled him until Suzuki showed proper deference.

title: Protests Overshadow Inauguration in Uganda
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  Ugandans frustrated with their government held large, boisterous celebrations on Thursday to welcome home the nations leading opposition figure, drowning out a lavish and dignitary-studded inauguration ceremony for President Yoweri Museveni.

title: Early H.I.V. Therapy Sharply Curbs Transmission
description: People infected with the virus that causes AIDS are far less likely to infect their sexual partners if they are put on treatment immediately instead of waiting until their immune systems begin to deteriorate, according to preliminary results from a large clinical trial released Thursday.

title: Clinton Toughens Tone Toward Syria
description: NUUK, Greenland  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton moved the United States a step closer to calling for the ouster of President Bashar al-Assad of Syria on Thursday as she denounced his governments intensifying crackdown on protesters.

title: When Sinus Problems Wont Go Away
description: The humble sinuses, those hollow cavities hidden in the bones around the nose, usually draw little appreciation. But nothing makes one yearn for clear sinuses like sinusitis, a condition that can make the head feel as if it were filled with cement and can render every breath a struggle.

title: Yale Opens Its Image Vault Online for Free
description: Yaleis going first. The university, in New Haven, announced that it is opening its entire digital image collection to the public for free  the first Ivy League institution to take this step toward open access. Yale houses millions of images in its archives, museum and libraries, including a sonata written by the hand of Mozart and a watercolor by William Blake. The open access policy allows us to more fully harness the potential of digital and networked technologies in service to scholarship as well as to creative use and reuse of our rich cultural heritage, said Meg Bellinger, director of the Yale Office of Digital Assets and Infrastructure. It frees us to concentrate on our core mission to create, preserve and disseminate knowledge in digital form.

title: Heat Arrives on Cue
description: If we didnt know better  and didnt mind being lumped in with the black helicopter crowd  we would be certain the script for these N.B.A. playoffs was being written in some studio somewhere, perhaps by out-of-work soap opera writers under the watchful eye of the N.B.A. marketing department. The Miami Heats whole season followed the perfect narrative for the leagues new villain franchise: the players stumbled early, really stunk for a while, blamed their clueless coach, bounced back, humbled the mighty Lakers a few times, then overcame the sage elder statesmen of the Celtics in the second round of the playoffs.

title: Yucca Shutdown Was Political, Federal Watchdog Says
description: The nations vast stockpiles of nuclear waste never made it to Yucca Mountain, but the now-defunct $15 billion project is still radioactive  politically, that is.

title: Chinese Christians Rally Around Underground Church
description: BEIJING  More than a dozen Christian leaders in China have thrown their support behind an embattled underground church, calling for the government to end its persecution and for broader religious freedoms as well.

title: What to Ask About Sinusitis
description: Confronting a new diagnosis can be frightening and, because research changes so often, confusing. Here are some questions you may not think to ask your doctor, along with notes on why theyre important.

title: Selected Studies: Sinusitis
description: Government agencies, universities and corporations frequently enroll patients in studies developed to test the effectiveness of new drugs, procedures and medical devices. Participants may benefit by gaining access to experimental therapies, and they make an important contribution to scientific research. For more information, visit ClinicalTrials.gov, a service of the National Institutes of Health.

title: Two Red-Eyes, 36 Sleepless Hours and Still a Choice
description: I think I know where Im going, I say as I walk into the living room, checking my phone for anticlimactic effect.

title: Artifacts | Gillian Wearings True Stories
description: Most of us dont actually wear our hearts on our sleeves. Not unless we are the subjects of Gillian Wearings unnerving photographs and videos, documents that wrest the dark side of being human from a deceptive public image.

title: What You Need to Know About Sinusitis
description: Dr. Richard M. Rosenfeld, an otolaryngologist at SUNY Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn, was chairman of a panel of the American Academy of Otolaryngology  Head and Neck Surgery that wrote clinical practice guidelines on adult sinusitis in 2007. The guidelines clarified how to distinguish when an acute sinus infection is caused by a virus versus by bacteria. Antibiotics dont work against viruses but are nonetheless frequently prescribed for sinusitis. The drugs overuse can foster resistant bacteria.

title: Exploring the Roots of Sinus Trouble
description: Ingfei Chen, health reporter, writes about chronic sinus problems, which affect up to 14 percent of adults, in The Times Health Guide: Sinusitis. Here she interviews Dr. Noam A. Cohen and Dr. James N. Palmer, sinus surgery specialists at the rhinology lab at the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, about the underlying causes of chronic sinus complaints. See, too, Ms. Chens stories, When Sinus Problems Wont Go Away, 5 Things to Know About Sinusitis,  and Questions for Your Doctor.

title: Brad Paisleys Country Underground
description: WHAT is country music? Is it a sound: an acoustic guitar, a pedal steel, a fiddle, a high lonesome croon? Is it regional art  and if so, what region, exactly? (Nashville? Appalachia? Bakersfield, Calif.?) Is it a grand tradition, stretching from the Carter Family and Jimmie Rodgers, to Roy Acuff and Hank Williams, to Johnny Cash and Dolly Parton and George Jones, down to the present day? Is country a way of life? A worldview? The best answer might be that country is music that cant stop defining itself  the genre that cant stop asking What is country music?

title: Chrysler Exports Imported From Detroit to New York
description: After viewing Chryslers two-minute Super Bowl XLV advertisement, during which the rapper Eminem emerged not from the all-new Chrysler 300, but from a 200 sedan, some Monday-morning quarterbacks felt that the brand missed an opportunity to showcase a superior product, one deserving of the spots emotional impact.

title: Obama Seeks to Extend Muellers Term as F.B.I. Director
description: President Obama is asking Congress to pass legislation that would extend the 10-year term of Robert S. Mueller III, the director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, by two years, the White House said in a statement Thursday. Mr. Muellers tenure is scheduled to end on Sept. 4.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Scoops
description: A shop in the Prospect-Lefferts Gardens neighborhood in Brooklyn has gained a large following with its offerings of ital food and vegetarian ice cream.

title: A Haven for Rastafarian Food
description: A YOUNG man stepped in from a wet and howling Friday afternoon, letting the door swing shut behind him. Inside the shop, the air was thick with incense and spice. A European soccer match on a small television set competed with the reggae playing on the stereo and the crackle of mock salmon steaks frying on the stove.

title: Council Votes to Raise Fines for Recalcitrant Cabbies
description: Updated 2:01 p.m. | Taxi drivers are about to face even stiffer fines for refusing to take passengers based on their destinations.

title: Regulators Seek Ways to Determine Which Financial Firms Are Crucial
description: WASHINGTON  One of the central reforms in the Dodd-Frank financial regulation act faces further delay after top regulators told a Senate committee on Thursday that they believed more clarity was needed on what factors determined whether a financial company was systemically important. That label would make a company subject to heightened government regulation.

title: Improve Your Skin by Imbibing: Radical or Fadical?
description: Pick me up. Calm me down. Banish my reserve. Banish some strangers.

title: Facebook Seeks to Downplay Campaign Against Google
description: 3:17 p.m. | Updated Added comment from Burson-Marsteller and public relations experts, and more details on Social Circle.

title: Tracks in the Yukon
description: In this Sundays magazine, I write about Shawn Ryan and Cathy Wood, who are leading a new gold rush in the Yukon. I first met Ryan and Wood while reporting a story for T magazine about a commercial boom in wild morels near Dawson City in 2005. As soon as I had the assignment, I called my friend David Arora and asked if he wanted to go along. Arora is famous among mushroom pickers; nearly all of them own a copy of his giant field guide, Mushrooms Demystified. Arora seems to know everybody, but the two people he recommended as most important to talk to in the Yukon were Ryan and Wood.

title: Curtain Up: Broadway-Set Smash Gets a Spot on NBCs Roster
description: 3:26 p.m. | Updated

title: White Rappers Paying Homage to the Past
description: NOT 30 seconds into Dr. Lecter, the debut full-length album by Action Bronson, and the history lessons begin. It happens quickly, this one  a few bars rapped in the cadence of Broken Language, a minor 1995 hit by Smoothe Da Hustler and Trigger Tha Gambler. Its the sort of reference dropped in as a wink, from connoisseur to connoisseur, insider to insider.

title: Howard Markss Missives, Now for the Masses
description: The writings of Howard Marks, chairman of Oaktree Capital Management, have a cult following on Wall Street.

title: Relief for Noses in Brooklyn and Queens
description: Jamaica Bay should smell better the next time it pours.

title: Energy Agency Sees Slowdown in Oil Demand
description: PARIS  The International Energy Agency on Thursday cut its forecast for crude oil demand next year as a result of the recent surge in petroleum prices and weakening growth prospects for industrialized countries.

title: TimesCast | Post-Mubarak Crime Wave
description: David D. Kirkpatrick Reports from Cairo where police officers stand by as crime takes over the city.

title: Scientists Report Stresses Urgency of Limiting Greenhouse Gas Emissions
description: The nations scientific establishment issued a stark warning to the American public on Thursday: Not only is global warming real, but the effects are already becoming serious and the need has become pressing for a strong national policy to limit emissions of heat-trapping gases.

title: Obama Calls Immigration Reform a Moral Imperative
description: President Obamas political outreach on immigration reform continues: Two days aftera speech in El Paso within sight of the Mexican border, the president on Wednesday urged Latino pastors at a prayer breakfast in Washington to help mobilize a new movement for change to benefit the millions of people here illegally and their children.

title: With Financing in Flux, Saabs First E.V. Program Awaits Its Fate
description: Saabs partnership with the Chinese manufacturer Hawtai Motor Group, announced on May 3, would have brought 120 million euros ($171 million) to the ailing Swedish automaker. The deal, however, fell apart, leaving Saabs future as murky as it was when it first halted vehicle production more than a month ago. Also left in flux is Saabs ePower electric vehicle program.

title: Readers Recall Their Favorite Nicknames
description: The article by John Branch this week about the disappearance of sports nicknames drew quite a response in Bats and from our friends on Facebook.

title: How Lowering the Cap for U.S.-Backed Mortgages Will Affect Home Buyers
description: The approaching end of federal guarantees for very expensive mortgages is worrying potential home buyers  and sellers  in high-cost markets. Will they be able to get financing? How much more will they have to pay for that financing?

title: Which Presidential Video Works Best?
description: The days of live presidential campaign announcements, complete with confetti, are over. Its a YouTube era now.

title: Red Sox Put On Their Rally Caps for Jeter
description: Hours before Derek Jeter would provide powerful evidence that he was not necessarily on his way down in the Yankees batting order or out of the lineup altogether, members of his wide-ranging fan club voiced unwavering support.

title: The Future of Skype
description: Well, you heard the news: Microsoft is going to buy Skype for $8.5 billion. Its the most money Microsoft has ever spent for anything.

title: Deflating That Big, Puffy White Gown
description: Bridesmaids, an unexpectedly funny new comedy about women in love, if not of the Sapphic variety, goes where no typical chick flick does: the gutter. Well, more like the city street that Lillian, a soon-to-be wife played by a wonderful, warm Maya Rudolph, dashes into, dressed in the kind of foamy white gown that royal weddings and the bridal industrial complex are made of. Suddenly realizing in a salon that shes been hit with food poisoning, she flees like a runaway bride, except that it isnt a man whos making her, uh, run, but the giddy, liberating humor of the writers Kristen Wiig and Annie Mumolo.

title: Regulators Defend New Rules on Big Financial Firms
description: The Dodd-Frank financial regulatory overhaul requires regulators to tackle the notion that big banks are too big to fail.

title: The Morning Line: Remembering Michael Baze
description: The lead story on Thursday remains the death of the jockey Michael Baze. Daily Racing Form reports that autopsy on the rider did not reveal an anatomical cause of death, and a toxicology report for Baze will not be available for about three weeks. His former agent Ron Ebanks says in the Pasadena Star-News, I think he went through a separation with his wife and I think that depressed him. Sadness and depression are the worst things in the world for anyone and I think that got a hold of him.

title: Popcast: Brad Paisley Proudly Preaches to the Choir
description: Brad Paisley is openly wooing his old audience with his new album, This Is Country Music, his ninth.

title: Teaching The Crucible With The New York Times
description: Though often considered second best to his Death of a Salesman and opening to lukewarm, if not downright hostile, reviews, Arthur Millers play The Crucible continues to be mounted and taught worldwide because it speaks to universal fears of social isolation and the unknown  fears especially present in a rapidly changing world, not to mention in the topsy-turvy social order of school.

title: Head of French Company Is Killed in Libyan City
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  The president of a French private security company who had scheduled a meeting on Thursday to discuss business opportunities with opponents of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi died in a hospital here on Wednesday, apparently after he was shot in the stomach, the French Foreign Ministry and rebel officials here in Benghazi said.

title: Israel Allows a Glimpse of Its Array of Defenses
description: PALMACHIM AIR FORCE BASE, Israel  The Israeli military allowed foreign reporters rare access to this heavily guarded Mediterranean base south of Tel Aviv on Thursday in what military officials described as an effort to showcase Israels technological advancements in the field of air defense and to underscore the array of threats from rockets and missiles.

title: Cuomo Pushes Back on Ethics Reform
description: As he crisscrosses New York pushing the need to strengthen ethics rules in the State Legislature, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on Thursday rejected the suggestion that ethics rules for the governors office should be bolstered, too.

title: Losing Custody Because She Has Cancer
description: King Solomons choice was easy compared with the one faced by the North Carolina judge Nancy E. Gordon. The custody dispute before her recently was between Alaina Giordano and her ex-husband, Kane Snyder, and the fight was over whether their children  11-year-old Sofia and 5-year-old Bud  should live with their mother, in Durham, or their father, in Chicago.

title: Pogues Posts: The Future of Skype
description: David Pogue writes on his blog that every time some big clumsy corporate behemoth buys a popular consumer-tech product, I cringe. It almost never works out. Read the entire post about his impression of Microsofts acquisition of Skype on Pogues Posts.

title: Guess Where This Is
description: Its time again for our weekly contest: guess the location of the photograph above.

title: With Galleon Wiretaps, a Two-Edged Sword
description: Expectations for the burden of proof in insider trading cases may be heightened by the prosecution of Galleon Group co-founder Raj Rajaratnam, as wiretaps may become the new norm for evidence.

title: Hawks, Grizzlies Demonstrates Value of Depth
description: N.B.A. teams have reached the point in the playoffs when they are hindered by the most basic of human limitations: physical fatigue. Like it or not, basketball players are not conceptual beings nor robots, and as such theyre limited by what their bodies are able to do. Obvious though that may be, its a factor of performance sometimes lost in the one game at a time playoff mentality, an inescapable component of teams failing or succeeding.

title: I.R.S. Moves to Tax Gifts to Groups Active in Politics
description: Big donors like David H. Koch and George Soros could owe taxes on their millions of dollars in contributions to nonprofit advocacy groups that are playing an increasing role in American politics.

title: Report Urges U.S. to Consider Charging Ensign
description: WASHINGTON  Senator John Ensigns top aide warned him in 2008 that his office might be breaking the law by helping a former staff member build up a lobbying business. The senator let out a long groan, then said they should help the former employee anyway, according to a remarkably detailed Senate report that urged the government to consider criminal charges against Mr. Ensign.

title: The Songbook, for a Song
description: The singers Emily Bergl and Colleen McHugh are keeping the American songbook tradition alive and affordable.

title: Buying Influence at Universities
description: Over the years there have been concerns about donors subtle influence at universities. Professors might be reluctant to research gas taxes, for example, if the building they work in is named after Chevron.

title: The Ensign Investigation: Senate Panel's Preliminary Findings and Senator's Response
description: The Senate Ethics Committee on Thursday asked the Justice Department to reopen its investigation of former Senator John Ensign, saying it had found evidence that he had conspired to help his former aide violate a lobbying ban, had broken campaign finance laws and had obstructed an investigation.

title: 36 Hours in San Francisco
description: Much of the city's waterfront has become another of its pleasures.

title: 36 Hours in San Francisco
description: SAN FRANCISCO typically wows visitors with its heights or its sights. The hills sear themselves into memory after a few up-and-down-and-up-again cable car rides or punishing walks. Then there are the vistas: the sweeping views of the city, the postcard-ready Victorians below Alamo Square Park. But surrounding all of that is the waterfront: miles of Pacific Ocean coastline and the expansive natural harbor of San Francisco Bay. Once a working industrial area with pockets of outright blight, much of the citys waterfront has been polished into another of its pleasures. Start exploring in the east, south of the Bay Bridge, and loop your way west to the Golden Gate and then south to Ocean Beach. In one weekend romp, youll join San Franciscans in many of the places they love best  and see what remains of their citys maritime heart.

title: Less Talk, More Action: Improving Science Learning
description: Over the past few years, scientists have been working to transform education from the inside out, by applying findings from learning and memory research where they could do the most good, in the classroom. A study published in the journal Science on Thursday illustrates how promising this work can be  and how treacherous.

title: Children of Hoarders
description: Television shows like TLCs Hoarding: Buried Alive and A&Es Hoarders have raised awareness about the problems of hoarding, in which a person compulsively collects items to the point that a space becomes virtually unlivable.

title: Seeing Things | Getting Upper
description: Tagging and typography come together in Getting Upper: Graphic Designers and Artists Reconsider the Alphabet, an exhibition that opens this weekend at the Pasadena Museum of California Art. While typographers build letters and alphabets, graffiti artists take them apart, reshaping language with their tags.

title: Speaking Up in Class, Silently, Using Social Media
description: Wasnt it just the other day that teachers confiscated cellphones and principals warned about oversharing on MySpace?

title: ABTs Herman Cornejo Injured, Exits Don Quixote
description: Herman Cornejo, a principal dancer with American Ballet Theater, will not perform during the first two weeks of the companys season, Kevin McKenzie, the artistic director, announced on Thursday. Mr. Cornejo, who withdrew due to an injury, was scheduled to perform in Don Quixote on May 19 and in Antony Tudors Shadowplay on May 24 and 25. Rolando Sarabia, a veteran of the National Ballet of Cuba and Miami City Ballet, will replace Mr. Cornejo for the performances of Don Quixote. Craig Salstein, a soloist, will replace Mr. Cornejo in Shadowplay at both performances. The company earlier announced that Ethan Stiefel, another principal, would withdraw from the entire season. This is the first time Mr. Sarabia will appear with the company.

title: Romney Defends Massachusetts Health Plan, but Concedes Flaws
description: ANN ARBOR, Mich.  Former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts came here on Thursday to address the biggest threat to his nascent presidential campaign, defending core elements of the health care law enacted in his home state five years ago even as he tried to reassure conservatives that he would work to roll back the similar national overhaul President Obama signed into law last year.

title: Tough on Bodies, Easy on Wallets
description: This week the Weekend Miser columnist turns her cost-cutting attention to matters athletic.

title: Disaster Plan Problems Found at U.S. Nuclear Plants
description: ROCKVILLE, Md.  Despite repeated assurances that American nuclear plants are better equipped to deal with natural disasters than their counterparts in Japan, regulators said Thursday that recent inspections had found serious problems with some emergency equipment that would have made it unusable in an accident.

title: Mets Davis on D.L.; Fernando Martinez Called Up
description: 3:43 p.m. | Updated

title: With Galleon Wiretaps, a Two-Edged Sword
description: Expectations for the burden of proof in insider trading cases may be heightened by the prosecution of Raj Rajaratnam, the Galleon Groups co-founder. Peter J. Henning, the White Collar Watch columnist, takes a look at how wiretaps may become the new norm for evidence in white-collar investigations.

title: Send In The Cranks
description: Matt Yglesias notes that another GOP senator, in addition to declaring that Peter Diamond, one of the worlds greatest economists, isnt fit to be on the board of the Fed, has joined the ranks of monetary cranks:

title: Cooperation Is Pledged by Nations of the Arctic
description: NUUK, Greenland  The eight Arctic nations pledged Thursday to create international protocols to prevent and clean up offshore oil spills in areas of the region that are becoming increasingly accessible to exploration because of a changing climate.

title: Girl, 12, Killed in NATO Raid on Wrong Afghan Home
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  In the fertile lowlands of eastern Afghanistan it is already summer, and the warm nights send families out of sweltering houses and into their courtyards so that they can sleep in the relative cool of the night breezes.

title: Just One Look | Chanel Resort Collection
description: Karl Lagerfeld staged his Chanel cruise collection this week as a premiere to the Cannes Film Festival, and even produced a short film, The Tale of a Fairy, for the occasion. The clothes he showed on the other hand, like this billowy-sleeved white dress, seemed geared less to the glitz of la croisette than to the refined glamour of the Hotel du Cap, where the show took place, and which Lagerfeld accurately refers to as the other side of paradise.

title: House Tour: Carversville, Pa.
description: A refurbished four-story grist mill from 1799 that sits on a creek has cultivated its owners love of gardening.

title: Qaddafis Visit to Hotel Puzzles Journalists
description: On Thursday in Tripoli, dozens of journalists staying at the Rixos Hotel, where the Libyan government hosts  or confines  the foreign press corps, were left asking themselves the same question: How did Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi manage to hold a meeting at the hotel one night earlier without any of them noticing?

title: A Deeper Look at LinkedIns Structure
description: Jin Lee/Bloomberg News

title: House Tour: Carversville, Pa.
description: WHAT Three-bedroom house on 4.8 acres.

title: The Book of Mormon Tour to Open in Denver
description: The 137,000-plus Mormons who live in Colorado (not to mention the rest of the states population) will be the first people outside New York who get the chance to see The Book of Mormon.

title: Who Could Become the Data Sheriff?
description: In an article I wrote for the Week in Review section last Sunday, I noted that no federal laws existed to punish companies when customers personal information and data were stolen in cyber-attacks, or mishandled by companies. And so punishment in these cases is left up to the states. Yet in many instances, state officials dont have the resources to tackle this problem, and even acknowledge that they dont always understand the technical aspects of breaches.

title: Hammering Nails
description: Last week, our colleague Lia Miller offered a few proposals for a revamped Two and a Half Men. But hold the voting. A judge in California may have struck sitcom/reality-show gold.

title: France Will Drop Charges Against Iranian Dissidents
description: PARIS  The French authorities are dropping a terrorism investigation into 24 members of an Iranian dissident group for lack of evidence, court documents show, nearly eight years after a sensational raid on the organizations headquarters amid charges that the group was planning attacks on targets in Europe.

title: So Scandalous a Prosecutor Took Notice
description: PARIS

title: Consumers Want Fast, Friendly Service
description: More than a third of consumers report having had a bad experience with a service provider, and the vast majority of them took time to complain about it, a recent survey finds.

title: Immokalee, Americas Tomato Capital
description: This morning I left Immokalee, Fla., the source of almost all the winter tomatoes grown in the United States. Its inspiring tomato workers have gone from enduring slavery, beatings, wage theft (and sub-minimum wage pay) and 12-hour days in the blazing heat with no shade, to a victory that, that, while not quite complete, is possibly the most successful labor action in the United States in 20 years, the details of which will have to wait for a column or even a story.

title: A Spooky Reminder to Obey the Speed Limit
description: New York City, it should be noted, has a speed limit: 30 miles per hour unless otherwise noted. The Transportation Department is hoping a pixelated image of a skeleton wont let you forget it.

title: TimesCast | May 12, 2011
description: The potential presidential candidate Mitt Romney confronts health care questions; NATO planes strike Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's compound; and crime sweeps Cairo.

title: Safer Sushi
description: For eco-minded eaters  not to mention radiation alarmists  fish is a quandary these days. Much of the seafood served in American restaurants is imported, caught using methods that endanger other animals or farmed unsustainably. But a few chefs around the country are trying to turn the tide with local, eco-conscious menus.

title: Youre Never Too Old to Learn Shoemaking
description: LEARNING should be a lifelong pursuit. But between the cost of tuition and dark memories of failure at the blackboard, formally committing to edification can be daunting.

title: GILLIAN WEARING: People
description: Tanya Bonakdar Gallery

title: ERIC FISCHL: Early Paintings
description: Skarstedt Gallery

title: CARTER MULL: The Days Specific Dreams
description: Taxter & Spengemann

title: Bloomberg Administration Is Criticized on Wages
description: One by one, City Council members took turns deriding the Bloomberg administration on Thursday for opposing a bill that would raise the minimum wage for some low-income workers by as much as $4.25 per hour.

title: Burn This, Curse That, Wreak Your Havoc
description: The only reason to see Hesher is to cringe before Joseph Gordon-Levitts portrayal of its scary, hot-wired title character, a violent California drifter who barges into the home of a grieving suburban family and is given the run of the house.

title: McConnell Thinking Big on Entitlements
description: The Senate minority leader, Mitch McConnell, said Thursday that the debt-ceiling debate provided Congress with a rare opportunity to make sweeping changes to entitlement programs and spending, and that he would not vote to raise the level without significant budget cuts and revisions to Medicare and Medicaid.

title: MARK GROTJAHN: Nine Faces
description: Anton Kern Gallery

title: IBRAHIM EL-SALAHI: From Time to Time
description: Skoto Gallery

title: Pictures of the Day: Kosovo and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Kosovo, Afghanistan and Libya.

title: The Passions and Demons of Yves Saint Laurent
description: Oh to live the exquisite life! A wistful sigh of longing was my initial reaction to LAmour Fou, Pierre Thorettons tantalizing documentary about Yves Saint Laurent, the French couturier who died in 2008.

title: Nail Down the Seats  The Exorcist Is Coming to the Stage
description: If heads are turning more than usual next summer in Los Angeles, it may be because a stage adaptation of The Exorcist, about a 10-year-old girl possessed by the devil and the Catholic priest who tries to save her, is set to open there at the Geffen Playhouse.

title: Domesticity and Radicalism Clash in a Neo-Nazi Home
description: Jesse McKinley spent two months looking into the activities of the Southern California chapter of the National Socialist Movement, the nations largest neo-Nazi group, and the chapters leader, Jeff Hall. On May 1, midway through his reporting on the project, Mr. McKinley received word that Mr. Halls 10-year-old son had been charged with murdering him with a handgun as he lay on the living room sofa, just a day after Mr. McKinley had spent much of the afternoon at the family home for a meeting of the group. His subsequent article on Mr. Hall and the murder, and the unusual circumstances of the case, have aroused so much reader interest that Mr. McKinley was asked to describe his impressions of Mr. Hall, his family and his world.

title: Wheelies: The Pipeline Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Indian and Afghan Leaders Forge Deeper Ties in Meeting
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Afghanistan and India agreed to move ahead on a strategic partnership framework during a visit to the Afghan capital by Indias prime minister on Thursday, just weeks after a visit from the prime minister of Pakistan, Indias archrival.

title: Primordial Soup, a Musical Brew
description: The brilliant and largely forgotten critic Seymour Krim (1922-1989) grew up, as have so many American readers, worshiping those writers who captured what he called the unofficial seamy side of American life. The excitable Krim put it this way: I dreamed Southern accents, Okies, bourbon-and-branchwater, Gloria Wandrous, jukejoints, Studs Lonigan, big trucks and speeding highways, Bigger Thomas, U.S.A.!, U.S.A.!

title: Torture or Porn? No Need to Choose
description: In spite of its generic title, A Serbian Film, directed by Srdjan Spasojevic, has already provoked scandal on the festival circuit and fascination from devotees of extreme cinema. At first glance  and few are likely to dare a second  it belongs in the high-concept shock-horror tradition whose most recent and notorious specimen is probably The Human Centipede. As is often the case with movies like this, A Serbian Film revels in its sheer inventive awfulness and dares the viewer to find a more serious layer of meaning.

title: Keeping Score: Its the Year of the Pitcher, Part II
description: Sean Forman is the creator of Baseball-Reference.com, an online baseball encyclopedia of players, teams and box scores in the major and minor leagues.

title: Pictures of the Day: Kosovo and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Kosovo, Afghanistan and Libya.

title: Truth, Justice, and the American Way of Oil Subsidies
description: Even a hardened cynic like myself is often amazed at what people think they can get away with. First the Ma-hes-looking-at-me-funny whining from Wall Street, now this:

title: Paris (and Cannes) in the Spring, Through Woody Allens Eyes
description: CANNES, France  Hes taken Manhattan, and once again Woody Allen took Cannes, if not by storm, then with a light flurry of soggy jokes, a soupon of charm and a couple of movie stars in tow. His latest, Midnight in Paris, the opening-night attraction of the 64th Cannes Film Festival here  his 11th movie at this event  isnt a re-return to form, a revitalization along the lines of his 2005 entry, Match Point. But it gave the swarming festivalgoers, locals, journalists and paparazzi a lingering look at a movie legend who waved from high atop the red carpet trod by giants of cinema and the festivals notorious fashion police.

title: Obama Campaign Moves Into Chicago Headquarters
description: CHICAGO  A group of reporters and photographers on Thursday got a glimpse of the new Chicago headquarters for President Obamas re-election effort. An entire floor in 1 Prudential Plaza, which looks out on the citys prized Millennium Park downtown, will be the campaigns home. It is only a few blocks from the 2008 headquarters.

title: A Singers Tribute to Lena Horne, Her Regal and Daunting Role Model
description: When the jazz singer Nnenna Freelon was a little girl, she recalled in her show, Lena: A Lovesome Thing, on Wednesday evening at Feinsteins at Loews Regency, Lena Horne was held up as the standard of beauty and pride.

title: Dancing Octopuses
description: If you have ever felt guilty about eating octopus because of its relatively large brain size, prepare to feel doubly so. As Boing Boing reports: videos of cirrate octopuses filmed swimming in the deep ocean and set to classical ballet music seem well on their way to becoming a YouTube genre. Boing Boing links to a recent Guardian article that describes what has made this glimpse into the balletic life of our favorite cephalopod possible. Thanks to improvements in digital technology  a high-definition underwater video camera that can film at 6,600 feet where less than 1 percent of the suns rays ever penetrate  we can now takea rare look at a mysterious benthopelagic sea animal: Grimpoteuthis bathynectes, one in a group of 14 recognized species that are often referred to as Dumbo octopus because their fins resemble the large ears that the fictional character, Dumbo the elephant, used to fly. (O.K., maybe these arent exactly the ones you eat, but still.) The video below, filmed 200 miles off the Oregon coast, shows you what youve been missing:

title: Those Spirited Strings and Other Things
description: The pianist Alfred Brendel, who retired in 2007 at 77, said he wanted to stop performing while still at his peak. And he did, leaving his fans with recordings and fond memories of concerts as he enjoys a busy life of lectures, coaching and poetry.

title: The Samurai Shopper | Organic? Not So Fast
description: The Samurai Shopper finds herself on the horns of a dilemma, and believe me, its not all that comfy a place to be. The dilemma is this: Should I support organic skin care because its organic  a healthier choice for us and the planet and maybe other planets too? Or should I throw my weight behind skin care that works but may be organically incorrect?

title: For Tomorrows Column
Gloom and Doom, and How to Profit From It
description: Jacob Kepler/Bloomberg NewsThe Bellagio in Las Vegas, the site of the Salt Conference.

title: Answers About the Stanley Cup Playoffs
description: Following are the responses from Jeff Z. Klein, the national hockey writer for The Times, who this week took questions from readers about the Stanley Cup playoffs as they wind down to the conference finals.

title: Rationality Meeting Romanticism
description: At a performance by Marc-Andr Hamelin, you dont have to wonder whether braininess will eclipse finger power, or vice versa. Mr. Hamelin brings both to his work in ample measure, and he plays with heart as well. He also takes an omnivorous approach to the keyboard repertory, and his interpretive imagination is so flexible that he seems completely at home in just about everything he touches.

title: A Love for the Ages, but Which One?
description: IT was early June in Illinois: hot, humid, unbearably sticky. The cicadas droned in the trees, their monotonous buzz somehow adding to the heat.

title: A Picture Window on a Life Turned Inside Out
description: Everything Must Go is the story of a middle-class man hitting bottom, for reasons that are both as obvious as the empty beer cans that pile up around him and as elusive as the never-seen wife who has just walked out of his life. In a single day the man, a midlevel Arizona sales executive named Nick Halsey (Will Ferrell), loses his job and returns home to find that the locks on his house have been changed, his bank account frozen and all his stuff piled in the front yard.

title: A. Eugene Kohn
description: Mr. Kohn is a founder and the chairman of Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates, one of the worlds largest architecture firms, with headquarters in New York. The firms work in the area includes the Hudson Yards master plan on the West Side and condominiums like One Jackson Square and 27 Wooster Street, as well as the expansion and renovation of the Museum of Modern Art.

title: Financing Foreclosed Homes
description: FORECLOSED homes dont show very well  financially strained borrowers may ignore maintenance; lenders turn off the water and power to cut the cost of letting the place sit. A poor appearance can complicate financing, but it doesnt prevent sales.

title: What Good Is Sitting Alone in Your Room? Cabaret Is a Steal
description: Fans of the American Songbook can get their fix of torch songs and 11 oclock numbers on almost any night in New York. This weekend alone brings the husband-and-wife duo of Jason Danieley and Marin Mazzie to the Caf Carlyle; K T Sullivan saluting Dorothy Fields at the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel; and Nnenna Freelon covering songs made popular by Lena Horne at Feinsteins at Loews Regency.

title: NBC News May Start New Prime-Time Broadcast
description: NBC News is in the early stages of developing an hour-long news broadcast for prime time, a participant in the planning said Thursday.

title: Q & A
description: Keep the Pictures on the Fridge, Please

title: Silver That Survived War and Centuries
description: Hungarian gilded-silver vessels and jewelry that narrowly escaped World War II looters will go on display on Friday for the first time in seven decades at a Christies auction preview in New York.

title: The Metropolitan, in All Its Hilarity
description: Funny is a rare adjective for an exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. It just might apply, however, to Infinite Jest: Caricature and Satire From Leonardo to Levine, which opens there on Sept. 13.

title: On Our Radar: Nations Race to Carve Up Arctic
description: A stream of leaked diplomatic cables reveal a race by Arctic nations to carve up the region, as melting ice, driven by climate change, opens up potentially vast natural resource reserves, including billions of barrels of oil. The cables cite warlike language from Russian officials, who have aggressively asserted claims over large swaths of the Arctic seafloor. [BBC]

title: Starry, Starry Cinema (The Breezes Are Free)
description: IN New York this summer the drive-in movie is thriving. Minus the cars.

title: Cano Cleared to Play Thursday Night for Yankees
description: Robinson Cano was cleared by a neurologist to play Thursday night, the day after he was beaned by a 93-mile-per-hour fastball. A CT scan taken Wednesday came back negative, and Yankees Manager Joe Girardi said all other testing, including Impact, a 20-minute computerized evaluation that assesses memory, reaction time and processing speed, came back normal.

title: When Brecht and Weill Danced, Revisited
description: In New York City Ballets new production of The Seven Deadly Sins, the sins seem far from deadly, and not even strikingly sinful. Nothing is irritatingly wrongheaded about Lynne Taylor-Corbetts direction or choreography  cynical ambivalence about these sins is built into this 1933 ballet by Bertolt Brecht and Kurt Weill  but nothing is remotely memorable either. Call it A Few Minor, Dull Peccadillos instead. After its Wednesdays gala premiere, the only feature of the staging that stayed in my head was the mannered enunciation employed by Patti LuPone as Anna 1, as she rhymes An-na with Louisian-na and distorts her prolonged final syllables.

title: Two Meaty Visions of Flesh and Blood
description: In 1952, Francis Bacon posed for photographs with two sides of beef attached, like wings, to his naked torso. The gesture was provocative, as Lady Gagas meat dress would be a half-century later, but it was also deferential, a nod to Chaim Soutine, whose paintings of carcasses dangling in butchers stalls had been haunting the art world since a 1950 retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: The Fully Engaged Lens
description: As a witness to human history, photography has been much questioned over the past three decades. Ever more sophisticated digital techniques of manipulation have only further eroded faith in its trustworthiness as a truth teller. Yet intrepid photojournalists continue to fan out all over the world, uploading images of people, places and events of almost every conceivable kind, from scenes of mundane domesticity in remote locations to recordings of terrifying natural and manmade disaster.

title: Strife of 64, in Somber Tones
description: In September 2008, during the second week of his first season as music director of the Dallas Symphony Orchestra, the Dutch conductor Jaap van Zweden led the premiere of August 4, 1964, a 70-minute oratorio by the American composer Steven Stucky, with text by the librettist Gene Scheer.

title: Bahrains Protesters Were Drugged, Official Claims
description: Adopting what might be called the Qaddafi defense, the head of Bahrains military claimed that the countrys brutal crackdown on dissent was entirely justified because the kingdoms security forces had been confronted by young protesters under the influence of mind-altering drugs.

title: Stars Beneath the Stars
description: A look at some of New York Citys outdoor screening venues.

title: Met Opera Singers Pull Out of Japan Tour
description: Two star singers have backed out of the Metropolitan Operas tour to Japan, the Met said on Thursday. The news is sure to stir dissatisfaction among some members of the company who have expressed worry over safety risks following the nuclear emergency in Japan caused by the March earthquake and resulting tsunami. The Met, citing reassurances from the State Department and experts, has said it was going ahead with the two-week tour in June, and that all company employees  chorus and orchestra members and others  would be required to go.

title: Developers Focus on Moderately Priced Subdivisions
description: Ridge

title: Quilts: Masterworks from the American Folk Art Museum
description: Images from the exhibition.

title: Cautious Blogger Grim Buys a Home
description: BIG news in the virtual neighborhood: Grim bought a house.

title: Town Weighs Affordable Housing Panel
description: Salisbury

title: Major Record Labels Settle Suit With LimeWire
description: 8:15 p.m. | Updated Ending a five-year court battle over music piracy, the major record companies on Thursday settled a copyright infringement lawsuit with LimeWire, a popular file-sharing network, for $105 million, the Recording Industry Association of America announced.

title: Upper West Side Condo Votes to Ban Smoking
description: NEW YORK CITYS smoking ban spreads from bars and restaurants to parks and beaches Monday, and now one condominium on the Upper West Side has taken the step of prohibiting residents from smoking inside their apartments.

title: This Billboard Could Draw Attention
description: A British artist is creating an unusual ad for a Swiss bank to display at an American airport.

title: Huntsmans Positions on Gay Rights Are Within the G.O.P. Mainstream
description: Jon M. Huntsman Jr. has a number of hurdles to overcome if he is to become the Republican nominee for president  including his service in President Obamas administration as ambassador to China and his comparatively liberal positions on several issues.

title: Washington Square Park, 3:54 P.M.
A Hotel With a Luxury: More Sidewalk Elbow Room
description: IT is a favorite game to scout Pennsylvania Station, on the west side of Seventh Avenue from 31st to 33rd Street, for relics of the original 1910 building, demolished in the 1960s. Searchers find old handrails, stairways, columns and other elements.

title: Spare Times for May 13-19
description: Around Town

title: Now Batting for Charity, a Sabermetrician
description: It was a fall game in 1986 between the Boston Red Sox and the Mets. An error by Bill Buckner led to a run and helped open the door for a Mets victory. But it wasnt Game 6 of the 1986 World Series; it was a September exhibition game between the teams to benefit Bostons Jimmy Fund and the New York Amateur Baseball Foundation.

title: Theater Listings: May 13  19
description: Theater

title: Art Among the Wreckage
description: A look at a new exhibit of works by the artist John Chamberlain.

title: Downsizing in a Burst of Glory
description: The American Folk Art Museums radiant quilt exhibition will probably be the last of its kind at its unwelcoming, decade-old building on West 53rd Street. On Tuesday evening, while the shows opening reception was under way, the trustees voted to sell the building to its prominent neighbor, the Museum of Modern Art, for an undisclosed sum.

title: The Non-Parent Trap
description: My wife and I are in our early 30s and have been struggling with infertility for several years. Weve shared our situation with only family and a few close friends and prefer to keep it that way. But were asked about babies constantly. One week, I was asked 28 times when we would be having kids. Each question acts as a painful reminder of our sadness. Any suggestions?Anonymous

title: Spare Times: For Children for May 13-19
description: PETER YARROW AND FRIENDS

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for May 13-19
description: Art

title: Dance Listings for May 13-19
description: Dance

title: Classical Music/Opera Listings for May 13-19
description: Classical

title: First New Identification of 9/11 Victim Since 2009
description: The New York City medical examiners office has made the first DNA identification since December 2009 of a victim of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center, the office said on Thursday.

title: Movie Listings for May 13-19
description: Movies

title: Pop and Rock Listings for May 13-19
description: Pop

title: Jazz Listings for May 13-19
description: Jazz

title: War Machines (With Gymnasts)
description: ON a nondescript street in Long Island City, Queens, is a mysterious gold-painted door with a drawing of a colorful tent and a sign that reads Circus Warehouse. Inside is a cavernous space with a flying trapeze, gymnastic rings and ropes, ballet bars and piles of thick practice mats. It was here on a recent spring morning that about a dozen people were gathered around two pairs of strangely familiar objects: identical models of airline business-class seats, impeccably fashioned in wood. One, an American Airlines design, featured a seat in the upright position, beside it a bed with a meticulously carved imitation of a blanket and pillow.

title: Habitats | West 72nd Street
description: Andrew Chesler and Amanda Robb wanted a bigger apartment, but their self-employed status was a turnoff to co-op boards. Then, Mr. Cheslers mother had an idea: Why not chop her four-bedroom apartment in two?

title: Allora & Calzadilla
description: A look at the work of the two artists chosen to represent the United States at the Venice Biennale.

title: Family Compound on the 35th Floor
description: SEYMOUR SOLOMON was justly famous as a founder of Vanguard Records, the label that starting in the 1950s presented such celebrated performers as the Weavers, Paul Robeson and Joan Baez. Fewer people know that in the late 1960s and early 70s, Mr. Solomon also occupied one of Manhattans more dazzling apartments.

title: Tibetan Collection
description: Images from an exhibition at the Newark Museum.

title: More Protest Video From Syria
description: At about 1 a.m. local time in Syria on Friday morning, an activist who has used YouTube to document protests in the city of Homs uploaded three clips of what he described as a new demonstration there on Thursday night.

title: Simple Quest for Literacy Hits a Wall of Politics
description: The First Grader, directed by Justin Chadwick and written by Ann Peacock, tells the remarkable true story of Kimani Nganga Maruge, an illiterate member of the Kikuyu tribe in Kenya who enrolled in a rural primary school in 2003, when he was 84. The Kenyan government had recently established universal free education, and in claiming his right to it Mr. Maruge became both an inspiration and a lightning rod. He was invited to New York to address the United Nations, but in his own country his embodiment of the concept of lifelong learning was decidedly controversial.

title: Glencore to Emerge From Shadows With I.P.O.
description: LONDON  Tucked away in a small village about 30 minutes from Zurich, Glencore International has grown from a small, secretive trading firm into one of the biggest buyers, sellers and producers of commodities in the last three decades. Behind the scenes, Glencore touches most basic resources, like sugar in coffee and the wires in cellphones.

title: A Taste for Psychedelics and the God Particle
description: Smirking at its own putative cleverness, The Big Bang carries film noir parody into previously unexplored territory  particle physics  to address, if not to solve, the mystery to end all mysteries. Its resident madman, Simon Kestral (Sam Elliott), who with the help of a kinky physicist has built a particle collider under the New Mexico desert, is a multibillionaire with below-the-shoulders silver tresses, a death-rattle voice and a taste for psychedelics.

title: Selig Predicts Sale of Minority Share of Mets Soon
description: Commissioner Bud Selig voiced optimism Thursday that the Mets will have a new minority investor in place shortly but offered no timetable for a resolution of baseballs investigation of the Los Angeles Dodgers.

title: Video: TimesCast | Romneys Health Care Stance
description: Pam Belluck, who covered Mitt Romney as governor of Massachusetts, offers her insight as Mr. Romney discussed the health care overhaul he enacted in Massachusetts.

title: Complaint Box | Gloves That Go Everywhere
description: The New York City health code mandates that all fast food restaurant employees must wear plastic gloves when handling or serving food. I think we can all agree that this is a good rule.

title: Cano Gets O.K. to Play a Day After Beaning
description: Robinson Cano returned from his appointment with a neurologist to find an ultraprotective helmet resting in his locker. He did not know who put it there, or whether he would wear it Thursday night against Kansas City, less than 24 hours after he was beaned by a 93-mile-per-hour fastball.

title: U.S. Inquiry of Google on Drug Ads
description: Federal regulators are investigating Google on suspicion of illegally displaying ads for online pharmacies that are operating outside the law, government officials said Thursday.

title: Boisterous, Big-Voiced and Built to Last
description: You may never have heard of Jools and Lynda Topp, country-singing lesbian twins from New Zealand, but its not because of their retiring personalities. Boisterous, big-voiced and built to last, these musical sisters have carved successful careers by doing what most people only dream of: that is, exactly as they please.

title: Father Sues Elite Washington School, Saying Psychologist Had Affair With His Wife
description: The father of a kindergartner at Sidwell Friends, one of the most prestigious private schools in Washington, filed a lawsuit on Thursday against the school and its former psychologist, claiming that the psychologist had an affair with his wife while treating his daughter.

title: OMeara Turns Back the Clock
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  As Mark OMeara made his way down the aisle to the front of the interview room Thursday, he said, I know youre all shocked.

title: At Scoops in Brooklyn, Ital Food (Even Ice Cream)
description: A young man stepped in from a wet and howling Friday afternoon, letting the door swing shut behind him. In the shop, the air was thick with incense and spice. A European soccer match on a small television set competed with the reggae playing on the stereo and the crackle of mock salmon steaks frying on the stove.

title: Paramedic Challenges Officers Story in Rape Case
description: Testimony in the rape trial of two police officers ended on Thursday with a paramedic contesting one officers emotional account of his futile effort to save a mans life.

title: A Constant in a Changing Neighborhood Is Endangered
description: For 60 years, Claudio Caponigros hole-in-the-wall barbershop on East 116th Street has been an East Harlem landmark, with generations of men taking turns in one of the shops three ancient peppermint-color chairs, receiving his tender ministrations among leather strops and bottles of Jeris hair tonic.

title: 9 Months and 22.24 Seconds Later, Roster Spot Is Won
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  After nine months of training and more than a little tension between teammates and friends, the final spot on the United States swim team came down to a 50-meter freestyle sprint Thursday at Mecklenburg County Aquatic Center. When it was over, Cullen Jones barely held off Josh Schneider to earn the berth for the world championships in July in Shanghai.

title: A Martial Artist in Action
description: In True Legend, his return to feature-film directing after a 15-year hiatus, Yuen Woo Ping soemtimes flashes the skills that made him the worlds favorite action choreographer for hire. (His rsum includes the Matrix and Kill Bill films, as well as Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.)

title: Getting Jobless Men Back to Work
description: To the Editor:

title: A Wall Street Conviction: Will It Change Anything?
description: To the Editor:

title: McConnell Ties Debt Limit to Spending Reductions
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate minority leader, Mitch McConnell, said Thursday that the debt ceiling debate provides Congress with a rare opportunity to make sweeping changes to entitlement programs and spending, and that he would not vote to raise the level without significant budget cuts and revisions to Medicare and Medicaid.

title: The Markets Nose-Dive
description: To the Editor:

title: Federal Money for States
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rise in Asthma
description: To the Editor:

title: Annals of Creative Misreading
description: A pretty amazing comment thread about yours truly on Crooked Timber. No need for me to weigh in.

title: Only a Number
description: At 101 Buster Martin ran the London Marathon. But first, he says in Mark S. Wexlers documentary How to Live Forever, he had a pint and a fag. The cigarette is no big deal; hes been smoking since he was 7. A 94-year-old thoracic surgeon is thinking about retiring, but says he still feels a rush of energy when operating.

title: The Cost of Taking Children to the Theater
description: To the Editor:

title: In Debt, Far From Home and Claiming Servitude
description: HOUSTON  The television advertisements the welder saw in Hanoi were alluring, almost too good to be true. A company partly owned by the government was offering jobs in the United States that paid $15 an hour, plus overtime, far more than the man, Chin Ba Ngo, could make in Vietnam.

title: Millrose Games Expected to Leave Garden for Armory
description: The Millrose Games, the most famous indoor track meet in the world, are expected to leave Madison Square Garden, where they have been held since 1914.

title: Waiting for a Hawk Rescue
description: In the afternoon sun, Colin Jerolmack and Jennifer Schaperow anxiously awaited news of a plan to assist Violet from the state's rescue team.

title: In Chicago, a Peek at Home Base for a Re-Election Bid
description: CHICAGO  A clump of reporters and photographers on Thursday got a glimpse of the new Chicago headquarters for President Obamas re-election effort. An entire floor at 1 Prudential Plaza, which looks out on the citys prized Millennium Park downtown, will be the campaigns home  only a few blocks from the 2008 headquarters.

title: Shooting for the Stars
description: Obsessive fans of the exuberant and enchanting British filmmaking team the Archers  Michael Powell (1905-90), who largely directed, and Emeric Pressburger (1902-88), who largely wrote the screenplays  will not want to miss Cameraman, a documentary about Jack Cardiff, the cinematographer behind some of their most indelible images. A specialist in Technicolor from its early days, Cardiff was best known for the lush, painterly compositions in Archer films like the fantastical Matter of Life and Death, his first feature as cinematographer; Black Narcissus, for which a mountaintop Indian monastery was vividly created at Pinewood Studios, and for which he won an Oscar; and The Red Shoes, widely regarded as the definitive film about ballet.

title: Hawk Cam | Rescue on the Ledge
description: Updated, 8:15 p.m. |  A medical rescue team, which spent Thursday observing Violet, the red-tailed hawk and new mother with an injured leg, decided not to try to take her from her nest high above Washington Square Park in order to treat her.

title: Mickelson Learns All Courses Arent Fair
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  The Players Stadium Course at T.P.C. Sawgrass is as much a test of sanity as it is skill, with golfers often finding themselves penalized for their good shots as well as their bad ones.

title: Gates Puts Cost of Libya Mission at $750 Million
