Theres no sign yet of Seal Team Six  a memoir by a former member of the supersecret unit that brought down Bin Laden, which was rushed into stores a few weeks early following the raid  but stay tuned.

title: Caucus | The YouTube Primary
description: Michael D. Shear gets reader feedback on which candidate has the best Web video so far. Also, Megan Liberman and Jim Rutenberg discuss the Republican field taking shape.

title: Dave Ramseys 12% Solution
description: Thousands of people swear by the philosophy of Dave Ramsey, an up-by-the-bootstraps kind of guy who doles out tough financial advice about getting out of debt and living within your means. His legions of fans call his nationally syndicated radio show to seek his advice, attend his self-help seminars in both big arenas and small church classrooms and buy his best-selling books and DVDs. Hes part entertainer, part financial coach.

title: British Parakeet Boom Is a Mystery, and a Mess
description: STANWELL, England  The evening started peacefully enough at Long Lane Recreation Park in the western suburbs of London, disturbed only by the occasional rumble of a distant jet landing at Heathrow Airport. But just before sunset, five bright green missiles streaked through the air toward a row of poplars at the parks edge.

title: Film Announcements Are Always More Fun Aboard a Yacht
description: CANNES, France Weve traversed the red carpets and the publicity stunts. But there is another side to the film festival here: the maritime side. Were talking, of course, about yachts. Big ones and bigger ones, they crowd the harbor, drawing gawkers and aspirants (and Diddy). Really, no trip to the French Riviera is complete without a yacht party. And though the festival may be the pinnacle of the glamour racket, as Manohla Dargis noted in The New York Times, but that doesnt mean its without its share of left-field come-ons.

title: Denmark Warned Over Border Plans
description: BRUSSELS  Controversy over the future of Europes passport-free travel zone grew Friday when Denmark was warned that its plans to restart checks at its frontiers could be against European Union law.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $13.5 Million
description: Big Ticket is a new feature with the Big Deal column that will list one of the priciest sales of the previous week.

title: Faith, Education and Income
description: In this weekends Times Magazine, I have a column explaining the tight link between education and income for religious groups in this country. The most educated groups, like Hindus and Jews, are the most affluent, while the least educated are the least affluent. The chart with the column has more details.

title: Wisconsin Retirement Adds to Democrats Burden in Senate Races
description: Today, Herb Kohl of Wisconsin will become the sixth Democratic senator to retire rather than seek another term in 2012. Of those six retirement announcements, this is surely among the more problematic for Democrats.

title: Best Sellers Weekly Graphic: Dead First
description: Charlaine Harris is back atop the hardcover fiction list with Dead Reckoning.

title: Wealthy Hesitate to Take a Break on Estate Taxes
description: PRESIDENT OBAMA and the Republican Congress gave the wealthiest Americans an enormous gift at the end of 2010. They increased the exemption on a series of estate-related taxes and lowered the tax rate on any amount over those limits. The catch is it lasts only two years.

title: Andy Reid Talks Horses With Graham Motion
description: Steeplechase Times has been with Animal Kingdom, winner of the Kentucky Derby, at the Fair Hill Training Center in Maryland. Joe Clancy was there when Andy Reid, head coach of the Philadelphia Eagles, and two others  the offensive coordinator Marty Mornhinweg and the scout Brett Veach  talked with Animal Kingdoms trainer, Graham Motion.

title: In Galaxy, Less Hype and Finally Real Action
description: Spore, released in 2008, was the most over-hyped game in recent memory. Through years of prerelease publicitymongering, Spores publisher, Electronic Arts, and its famed designer, Will Wright, managed to convince much of the general public and the gaming world that they had created an everything simulator.

title: Citigroups Symbolic Dividend
description: CNBC looks at how investors are reacting to Citigroup after it resumed paying a dividend. The bank, which required a huge bailout during the financial crisis, cut the payout in 2009.

title: Fox Rides Idol to Another Ratings Victory
description: Fox finished atop the Thursday-night ratings as 21.6 million viewers tuned in for the American Idol elimination episode at 8 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. The Idol finalist James Durbin failed to advance to next weeks round, earning the lowest vote tally of nearly 72 million cast, leaving Lauren Alaina, Scotty McCreery and Haley Reinhart in the running.

title: The Tonys: Stop the Show!
description: Catch Me if You Can might have gotten mixed reviews, but pretty much everyone agrees that Norbert Leo Butzs rendition of Dont Break the Rules in the first act is the kind of showstopper you dont see on Broadway all that often. Except this season, which is notable for numbers that, through the alchemy of song, sound, legs, lights and star power  not to mention tap dancing  build into something more joyful than the sum of their parts.

title: Sunny Delight
description: Arthur Kulkov, the Siberian born, Coney Island raised in-demand model currently towering over Port Authority in an ad over five stories tall, is known around town for his eccentric and super-stylish way. His ease with fashion and sense of humor about his style adds to his appeal as a professional model, certainly. But his eye-catching outfits and lack of self-consciousness are what really sets him apart. I hate to say that this business has influenced my style, but it certainly did. All these years you have no choice but to pick up on things here and there, but obviously with my own spin on things. Ha. While on the set for a campaign shoot in Sarasota, Fla., he caught stares sporting these Day-Glo orange pieces (athletic sandals and shorts by Adidas, hat by American Apparel). He ordered the flip-flops from a soccer magazine, got the shorts at Y-3 and snagged the hat from another shoot. I thought it was brightly cool  I wouldnt rock all together, but I think it looks cool in parts.

title: Antigay Bill in Uganda Is Shelved in Parliament
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  After receiving overwhelming criticism from across the globe, Ugandas Parliament on Friday let the time expire on a contentious anti-homosexuality bill that had threatened this East African countrys international standing.

title: Why 401(k)s Should Offer Index Funds
description: The people who help you with your investments ought to act in your best interest.

title: Lobbying for a Better 401(k) Plan
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I encouraged readers to storm the barricades (but nicely!) to suggest improvements to their 401(k) or other retirement plans. Namely, I suggest that the majority of plans could use more index mutual funds.

title: 22 Miles and a World Away From Los Angeles
description: THE problem with wilderness is that it is, by definition, too darn far from where most people live. Yes, many cities have a few nice day hikes, but its a lucky accident of geography and conservation that creates serious, out there backcountry hiking opportunities close to a major urban area.

title: The Trans-Catalina Trail
description: A 37-mile trail takes hikers on a four-day trek.

title: Regarding the Royal Consummation
description: By now we can assume that Prince William and the new Duchess of Cambridge have consummated their marriage, or anyway we can hope. These things can be problematic. Its said, for example, to have taken seven years for the Dauphin Louis-Auguste of France, later Louis XVI, and the Hapsburg Archduchess Maria Antonia, known as Marie Antoinette, to consummate their union. (They were just teenagers, 15 and 14, at the time of their wedding in 1770, though on the face of it that would hardly explain the delay.) But at least William and Kate can spend time alone. In the old days, servants and witnesses would have been spending the night in the royal bedchamber with them.

title: May 15  21
description: Film

title: Letters: Short-Hop Airlines
description: To the Editor: Regarding Small Airlines for Shorter Hops (Practical Traveler, May 1): As a frequent purchaser of direct air, my only complaint thus far is trying to book a flight when seats are limited and not always available unless one pays full price. Other than that the convenience of going direct far outweighs the limitations. One has to be flexible with an itinerary.

title: New Host Needed: Be Prepared to Fill Big Shoes
description: Wanted: Host for a two-hour live public radio show Saturday nights, from the Fitzgerald Theater in St. Paul. Qualifications: Brilliant writer; eclectic musical tastes with a fondness for traditional Protestant hymns and patriotic songs; knack for poking fun at Midwesterners without offending them. Ability to charm four million listeners unhappy to see the present occupant go a plus.

title: An Explorer of Black Historys Uncharted Terrain
description: FOR some people, filmmaking is a lifelong dream. For Stanley Nelson, it began as more of a situational thing, a response to time and place. The time was the late 1960s and early 70s, the place to be avoided was Vietnam, the refuge was film school at the City University of New York. It was kind of my motive to stay in school no matter what, you know what Im saying?

title: Rock Star Tunes in to the Elders of the Tribe
description: SINCE 2006, when Arctic Monkeys appeared on the British music scene, Alex Turner, the frontman, has been acclaimed as a songwriter wise beyond his years. (He was 20 when the group hit it big, thanks in part to the tendency of the British press to trumpet and acclaim.) Through lineup changes and side projects, and a recent foray in New York with his girlfriend, Alexa Chung, the MTV personality and Madewell designer, Mr. Turner has gravitated toward classic musicians, like Gene Clark of the Byrds, and films like the 1959 western Rio Bravo. His retro sensibility is evident on the bands fourth album, Suck It and See (Domino), to be released June 6. The title seems cheeky but its not, Mr. Turner said. Its an old Britishism, like a bit Dick van Dyke-y, like give it a try almost  itd be a slogan for some candy, he said. Thats not really traveled very well. In a conversation peppered with other Britishisms (nice one, love he said, often, alongside saucier phrases) he recently spoke with Melena Ryzik from Stockholm, where the band members were starting their tour, performing together for the first time in over a year. Im a bit nervous, to be honest with you, Mr. Turner said. I have just opened a beer, actually. Well see if thats going to help it out. I dont want to do too much of that. Im worried I might become forgetful, and theres a lot of words in our songs. Here are excerpts from their conversation.

title: Something Genre Crossing, Something Bold
description: BRET EASTON ELLIS, the author of Less Than Zero and a man who knows a thing or two about the 1980s, recently tweeted, The two key American films of the 1980s: Blue Velvet, Something Wild... The first choice is no surprise, but the second confused some of his followers. When I tweeted it, people responded to Blue Velvet but asked, Whats the other one?, Mr. Ellis said in a telephone interview.

title: Late Preminger, the Un-Swinger
description: TOWARD the middle of Otto Premingers 1967 Hurry Sundown, a land-rich, cash-poor Southern belle, Julie Ann Warren (Jane Fonda), visits Rose Scott (Beah Richards), the black woman who raised her and who, Julie Ann remembers, gave her the only semblance of love she knew in childhood.

title: In Search of Star Power
description: The 2011 Audi A5 and S5 coupes and convertibles are exquisitely styled, but lacking in character.

title: Your Palms Telling Me You Must Let Go. Of $27,000.
description: Can psychics see their own futures? If so, Sylvia Mitchell, 36, peering into her crystal ball on a busy corner of Greenwich Village, might have caught a glimpse of her drivers license photo, blown up and attached to an unpleasant poster saying Wanted and Grand Larceny and $28,000. And so she apparently took off.

title: Citadels Griffin Debates Dodd-Frank
description: 4:37 p.m. | Updated

title: S.E.C. Official Demoted Despite Spotting Stanford
description: In 1997, Julie Preuitt sounded the alarms that the Texas financier R. Allen Stanford was operating a huge Ponzi scheme.

title: Divorce, in Style
description: CHARLES Bronfman and his wife, Bonnie, are inviting 100 of their friends to an elegant evening of cocktails for what they hope will be a once-in-a-lifetime event.

title: Rejection May Hurt More Than Feelings
description: THE GIST Being socially rejected doesnt just feel bad. It hurts.

title: Big Deal | Price Cuts and Foie Gras
description: In the cutthroat world of high-end New York City real estate, there is a simple maxim among brokers: Sell what you have seen.

title: Something About a Witch
description: FOR years, Scott Murdock was haunted by a cinematic image fluttering at the periphery of his memory. It involved a witch. She was serving pancakes. And there were lots of colorful bubbles floating over the screen.

title: Name-Dropping in Designer Audio
description: IN 1982, General Motors began selling three models that for the first time offered high-end designer sound systems, made by Bose, starting a trend in which branded audio systems are now available in almost every vehicle.

title: Homework Follies
description: Many parents dread homework time, and the struggle they will have to go through to get their kids to do it. So, is all this effort worthwhile? Over the years a disturbing amount of evidence has emerged suggesting that it is not. For a forthcoming study in the journal Economics of Education Review, Ozkan Eren and Daniel Henderson measured the effect of homework on math, science, English and history tests for 8th grade students in the United States. They used a method that controlled student and teacher traits. They found that doing additional math homework had large and statistically significant effects on math test scores. They found that additional homework in science, English and history had little or no impact.

title: Romancing the Stars
description: AS Carrie Bradshaw would have recognized, a museums cultivation of a potential patron is a form of courtship, with the same flirtation, grand gestures, ardent hopes for a future together  and then, sometimes, of course, the realization that the person youre wooing is, well, just not that into you.

title: The Continental Battle of the Bands
description: Since 1956, Eurovision has been one of the few cultural institutions that bind citizens of Europe together.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, Jerusalem, China and Spain.

title: Qaddafi Calls From a Place You Cannot Reach
description: Updated | 4:46 p.m. Hours after Italys foreign minister said on Friday that he had heard from the Roman Catholic bishop of Tripoli that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi had been wounded and left the Libyan capital, Libyan state television broadcast a brief audio statement from the countrys leader, who told NATO that he was in a place you cannot reach.

title: Douglas Crase, Frank Polach
description: Douglas Crase and Frank Polach were married Tuesday afternoon at Center Church, the First Church of Christ, in Hartford. The Rev. Paulo G. Frana, a minister of the United Church of Christ, performed the ceremony.

title: Laura DiBetta, Gregory Hopper
description: Laura Lynn DiBetta and Gregory John Hopper were married Thursday on the beach at Magens Bay on St. Thomas in the United States Virgin Islands. The Rev. Jeffrey Neevel, a minister of the Reform Church in America, officiated.

title: Melissa Gronlund, Christian Le Mire
description: Melissa Kai Gronlund and Christian Paul Le Mire were married Saturday in New York. The Rev. Michael L. Lindvall performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church, where he is the senior pastor.

title: Allison Maimona, Stephen DeVito
description: Capt. Allison Anne Maimona and Capt. Stephen Roy DeVito, both of the Air Force, were married Saturday evening at Club Hillbrook, an inn and private club in Chagrin Falls, Ohio. The brides brother, Matthew P. Maimona, who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated.

title: Johanna Vespe, Anthony Aulisa
description: Johanna King Vespe and Anthony Jerome Aulisa were married Saturday at the Regis High School Chapel in Manhattan. The Rev. Philip Judge, a Roman Catholic priest and the schools president, performed the ceremony.

title: Megan Barrick,Harvey Taylor II
description: Megan Frances Barrick and Harvey Parnell Taylor II were married Saturday afternoon at the Cathedral of St. Patrick in Charlotte, N.C. The Rev. Christopher A. Roux, the cathedrals pastor, performed the ceremony.

title: Sophie Balzora, Eric Siddall Jr.
description: Dr. Sophie Myriam Balzora, a daughter of Micheline Balzora and Dr. Jean Daniel Balzora of New City, N.Y., was married Saturday morning to Dr. Eric Clayton Siddall Jr., the son of Mary Jane Collins of Oswego, N.Y., and Mr. Siddall Sr. of Baldwinsville, N.Y. Lulrick Balzora, a cousin of the bride who was ordained as a Baptist minister and was a Navy chaplain, officiated at the Glen Island Harbour Club in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: Kalpana Narayan, Ganesh Shankar
description: Dr. Kalpana Narayan and Dr. Ganesh Mani Shankar were married Thursday morning at the Hyatt hotel in Westlake Village, Calif. Samudrala Krishnamachari, a Hindu priest, officiated.

title: Joseph Carino Jr. and Michael Pace
description: Joseph Carino Jr. and Michael John Pace were married Friday afternoon at Roton Point Beach Club in Rowayton, Conn. Colleen R. Hains, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated.

title: Corinne Poole, Tyler Maulsby
description: Sara Corinne Poole, the daughter of Sarah Weeks Poole and Kenneth H. Poole of Shalimar, Fla., was married Saturday evening to Tyler Emrys Kent Maulsby, the son of Elena L. Barnum of Stamford, Conn., and the late Allen F. Maulsby, who lived in Old Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. Carol Winn Crawford officiated at Rayne Memorial United Methodist Church in New Orleans, where she is the pastor. The Rev. Terence L. Elsberry, an Episcopal priest, took part in the ceremony.

title: Danielle Waring, Paulo Bernardo
description: Danielle Marie Waring and Paulo Antonio Bernardo were married Friday evening at the American Cancer Societys Relay for Life Cancer Walk at Wilton High School in Wilton, Conn. Charles P. Flynn, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated.

title: Dawn Meyer, Christian Keeney
description: Dawn Meyer and Christian Jeffrey Keeney were married Saturday evening at the Philadelphia Country Club in Gladwyne, Pa. David M. Brown, a Universal Life minister, officiated.

title: Patricia DeScenza, Eric Cullen
description: Patricia Rose DeScenza, a daughter of Margaret C. DeScenza and Robert P. DeScenza of New York, was married Saturday to Eric Paul Cullen, a son of Cheri and Gerald Cullen of Severn, Md. The Rev. Kenneth Doyle, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Patricks Cathedral in New York.

title: Marisa Kardos and Michael Garshick
description: Marisa Sydi Kardos and Michael Seth Garshick are to be married Sunday evening in West Orange, N.J. Rabbi Irving Spielman is to officiate at the Pleasantdale Chateau, an event space.

title: Angela Hurdle and AdeRotimi Sijuwade
description: Angela Camille Hurdle and AdeRotimi David Sijuwade were married Saturday evening at St. Luke Community United Methodist Church in Dallas. The Rev. Zan W. Holmes Jr., pastor emeritus of the church, performed the ceremony.

title: Sylvie Erb and David Fenton
description: Sylvie Erb and David Scott Fenton were married Saturday at the couples weekend house in Bedford, N.Y. Barbara Biziou, a minister of the Sanctuary of the Beloved, officiated.

title: Marc Hurel, Steven Perry
description: Marc Hurel and Robert Steven Perry were married Saturday afternoon at the Red Inn in Provincetown, Mass. The Rev. David A. Johnson, a Unitarian Universalist minister, officiated.

title: Carolyn Jones, Todd McCarty
description: Carolyn Louise Jones and Todd Christopher McCarty were married Saturday at St. Michaels-by-the-Sea Episcopal Church in Carlsbad, Calif. The Rev. Doran B. Stambaugh, the churchs priest in charge, performed the ceremony.

title: Kelly Doran and Matthew Santo
description: Dr. Kelly Maureen Doran and Matthew Joseph Santo were married Saturday at the Church of St. Francis Xavier in Manhattan. The Rev. Paul Farin, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Sabrina Gleizer, Jonathan Keehner
description: Sabrina Michele Gleizer and Jonathan Temple Keehner were married Saturday evening at Rasputin Restaurant in Brooklyn. David Andrew Temple, an uncle of the bridegroom who became a Universal Life minister for the event, officiated at a nondenominational ceremony, with Gennady Zeltser, an uncle of the bride, assisting.

title: In a Cube, and Taking Cues From Text Messages
description: A man and a woman wearing suits and flip-flops climbed into a large glass cube in the Winter Garden atrium downtown just before noon on Thursday, as the early lunch crowd from the World Financial Center filtered in.

title: Laura Blinkhorn, Daniel Ryan
description: Laura Marshall Blinkhorn and Daniel Paul Ryan were married Thursday by Judge Rosemary M. Collyer of United States District Court in Washington, who officiated in her chambers.

title: Elizabeth Harris, Kelly Kleinert
description: Elizabeth Allen Harris and Kelly Joanna Kleinert were married Saturday evening in the garden house at the Keeler Tavern Museum in Ridgefield, Conn. Patricia Stephens, a Connecticut justice of the peace, officiated.

title: Brittany Bochow and Matthew Brandwein
description: Brittany Leigh Bochow and Matthew Louis Brandwein are to be married Sunday at the Fox Hill Inn in Brookfield, Conn. Rabbi Roger Ross is to officiate.

title: Kate Nicholson and Michael McGovern
description: Kate Wakefield Nicholson, the daughter of Lori L. Nicholson and Peter G. Nicholson of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married Saturday afternoon to Michael John McGovern, a son of Mary Ann McGovern and Robert F. McGovern of Derry, N.H. The Rev. Joseph M. Palubeski, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Cathedral of St. Theresa in Hamilton, Bermuda.

title: Jill Olich, Matthew Hamilton
description: Jill Mara Olich and Matthew Garver Hamilton were married Saturday at the Fearrington House Inn in Pittsboro, N.C. The Rev. Franklin Golden, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Elizabeth Smith and Richard Cotton
description: Elizabeth Weinberg Smith and Richard Cotton were married Saturday at the brides home in New York. Judge Robert D. Sack, senior judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in New York, officiated.

title: Elizabeth Kim, John Connorton III
description: Elizabeth Jone Kim and John Vincent Connorton III were married Saturday in New York. The Rev. Peter K. Meehan, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Church of Our Lady of the Rosary, where he is pastor.

title: Amy Laschon, Kenneth Wolfe
description: Amy Christine Laschon and Kenneth J. Wolfe were married Saturday at St. Mary, Mother of God Catholic Church in Washington. Msgr. Charles E. Pope performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Daniel J. DAlliessi, also a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Giselle Woo, Daniel Huron
description: Giselle Christina Woo and Daniel Joseph Huron were married Saturday evening at the Hackley School in Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. William Dearman, an Episcopal priest and the brides fifth-grade teacher at the school, performed the ceremony.

title: Sandra Coudert, Todd Graham
description: Sandra Coudert and Todd Newell Graham were married Saturday evening at the Troutbeck Inn in Amenia, N.Y. The Rev. Steven Yagerman, an Episcopal priest, officiated.

title: Susannah Pollack, Benjamin Marsh
description: Susannah Rose Pollack, a daughter of Pam Arnold Pollack and Keith L. Pollack of Brooklyn, was married in Brooklyn Saturday evening to Benjamin King Marsh, a son of Ellie Putnam and John Langdon Marsh of Seattle. Rabbi Barton Shallat officiated at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.

title: Jennie Ripps, Max Brockman
description: Jennie Rebecca Ripps, a daughter of Susan Shapiro Barash of New York and the late Richard Ripps, was married Saturday to Max Brockman, the son of Katinka Matson and John Brockman of New York. Justice Melvyn Tanenbaum, of State Supreme Court in Islip, N.Y., officiated at the Gramercy Park Hotel in New York.

title: Pictures of the Day: Pakistan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Pakistan, Jerusalem, China and Spain.

title: Dolan Reasserts Traditional Definition of Marriage
description: Timothy M. Dolan, the Roman Catholic archbishop of New York, on Friday added his voice to the growing debate over legalization of same-sex marriage in New York, telling readers of his blog that the traditional definition of marriage as the union of one man and one woman is hardwired into our human reason.

title: Desert Prose
description: The Harvard historian Roger Owen is one of the pre-eminent minds on the modern Middle East, but even he was dumbstruck by the civil unrest sweeping the Arab world. The books that will shed light on it all, he says, have yet to be written. In the meantime, one could turn to the classics: The literature you need now is almost Shakespearean. Were dealing with family rule with fatal flaws. Or to the following volumes, selected by Owen, which give some background on this complicated revolutionary moment.

title: The Photo P.&G. Probably Wanted to Retouch
description: The Fortune 500 issue, which hit newsstands this week, has the business magazines annual look of seven of the most photogenic boards in the United States.

title: 21 Months in Prison for Former State Senator
description: WHITE PLAINS  A former state senator was sentenced in federal district court here on Friday to 21 months in prison and three years of supervised release after pleading guilty last year to obstruction of justice and tax evasion.

title: Metropolitan Preview | The Fleas
description: In a city that thrums with opportunity and a veritable buffet of wonderful things to do  theaters! museums! parks!  flea markets have somehow emerged as many peoples first choice of a way to spend the weekend, writes Ashley Parker in this weeks Metropolitan cover article, The Flea Marketing of New York. Over the last few years, the markets, with their vintage clothing, handmade jewelry and profusion of handcrafted foods have proliferated, as have the crowds drawn to them. On Brooklyn Fleas opening weekend, about 25,000 people filed through the Fort Greene and Williamsburg markets, according to the organizers, and SuChin Pak, a founder of the Hester Street Fair, estimated that 11,000 people came to her markets opening day this year. Read Ms. Parkers explanation of how shopping for vintage clothing, old typewriters and artisanal cheese became the hippest way to spend your weekend here.

title: British Parakeets and the Tumbleweed Blues
description: Life on Earth is getting stranger by the minute. Parakeets are flocking in Britain, as described in Elisabeth Rosenthals news story today. But dont forget the monk parrots in Brooklyn, the American bullfrogs in Japan and France, the Burmese pythons in the Everglades, the West Nile virus spanning the Americas. (Oh, and the American squirrels that are also displacing their kin in Britain.) You get the idea.

title: TimesCast | May 13, 2011
description: The Pakistani Army chief balks at American demands to cooperate; evaluating the billions in American aid to Pakistan; and the Op-Ed columnist Nicholas D. Kristof on Pakistans rampant illiteracy.

title: Video: The YouTube Primary
description: Michael D. Shear gets reader feedback on which candidate has the best Web video so far. Also, Megan Liberman and Jim Rutenberg discuss the Republican field taking shape.

title: Hotel Review: Nicks Cove & Cottages in Marshall, Calif.
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Book Review Video: Jane Goodall
description: This weeks Book Review contains a special section on childrens books: more than a dozen reviews of picture books, chapter books and novels for kids and teenagers. Inside is a review of two new picture books about Jane Goodall  Me  Jane by Patrick McDonnell, and The Watcher by Jeanette Winter. Recently, Dr. Goodall and both authors visited The Times for a video interview, embedded above.

title: Vines and Valleys in Oregon
description: OREGON is hiking country. Its also wine country, with vineyards that are increasingly destinations for oenophiles. So perhaps its no surprise that the combination of hiking and wine tasting has a name: wiking.

title: Hiking With a Child (and Tricks) in Tow
description: CHARLIE likes a lot of outdoor things, said my son Gus, then 4 1/2, about a friend who likes nothing more than classifying lichens in the forest. I like indoor things. This was, and still is, true. Gus can spend hours with his cheek on his bedroom rug, building Lego space stations and acting out savage battles upon them. Two years ago, summer break from preschool meant to Gus a happy vacation from being trundled off to parks and beaches with the rest of his class. But I had a different idea.

title: The Birds of Kauai
description: An abundance of species, but many are imperiled.

title: An Eden for Rare Birds in Hawaii
description: THE trade winds were pushing a misty fog across the treetops of the Alakai wilderness  a cloud forest atop the mountain hinterlands of Kauai  when my guide spotted something yellowish flitting among the boughs of an ohia tree.

title: Its a Bears World in Kodiak, Alaska
description: SHE gave a chuff and pulled up short, as surprised to see us as we were to see her. Her dense, fluffy fur was blond. I watched her square, expressive face very closely because this bear  maybe 300 pounds and 10 yards away  would be the one deciding how the encounter played out. An adrenaline-driven voice in my head said, This could go badly. But it was also telling me how incredibly thrilling it was to be so near this animal. Not being on top of the food chain certainly heightens ones awareness.

title: Where the Wild Things Are
description: Bear-watching trip on Kodiak Island in Alaska.

title: Did the School Overreact?
description: Lets play a Friday afternoon game of Did the School Overreact?

title: Powered by an Idea
description: The Paxton steam car did not revolutionize the auto industry, but it remains a benchmark of innovative design.

title: A Directory of Rare Wonders
description: A regional guide of endangered species.

title: A Coast-to-Coast Guide to Endangered Species
description: THE whoosh of a surfacing orca and the glower of a mother grizzly still have the power to raise goose bumps; a soaring California condor can yet astonish. But chances to admire many of our wildlife neighbors are becoming increasingly uncommon. Invasive buffelgrass is crowding out saguaros and other native cactuses throughout the Southwest, while melting sea ice is threatening the Pacific walrus and polar bear in Alaska. Mosquito-borne diseases are threatening Hawaiis songbirds, and white-nose syndrome is wiping out bats in the East.

title: Google Is Said to Have Broken Internal Rules on Drug Ads
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Google allowed rogue online pharmacies to advertise on its site in violation of its own advertising policies, according to one of the companies subpoenaed in the federal investigation of Googles drug ad sales.

title: Good News for Grandpa
description: Death panels notwithstanding, Grandpa gets to live a little longer.

title: Childrens Bookshelf: Wheels
description: Pamela Paul reviews new childrens picture books about bicycles, wagons and cars.

title: Is New York Bringing You Down?
description: New York, I Love You, but Youre Bringing Me Down, is the final track on LCD Soundsystems 2007 album, Sound of Silver.

title: How Sending a Letter Can Help Save Wildlife
description: Looking for little ways to help endangered species?

title: For a Violinist, Success Means a New Low Point
description: SINCE Pythagoras, musicians and scientists have known (or thought they knew) that the lowest pitch a string stretched taut can produce  the fundamental  is the pitch it produces when vibrating freely. Stop the string anywhere between the end points, and the vibrating section sounds at a higher pitch. Theoretically, there is no ceiling. As with dancing, the skys the limit, but the floor is always the floor.

title: Now Opening | Salvor Projects
description: After about seven years of collaborating with various retailers, the men behind Salvor Projects will open their first shop this Saturday. The store is like a lab, the designer Ross Menuez says, having sought a space where he could continue to experiment with his designs as well as bring together everything Salvor has done in the past. Specializing in screen prints, they hope to cater to a range of customers from the Madison Avenue woman interested in a graphic tote bag to your average skateboarder looking for a printed shirt. At the shop, these mostly one-of-a-kind pieces are displayed against an austere, monotone interior that allows the clothes to be the focal point  an architectural decision that should attract many a design enthusiast.Prices range from $140  $300. Salvor Projects, 172 Forsyth Street. Go to www.salvorprojects.com.

title: Pilot Paternalism
description: The dearth of women television writers is well documented. But it reached a sort of negative milestone last year when Neely Swanson, a former development executive and adjunct professor at the U.S.C. School of Cinematic Arts, published her essay Women Cant Create and White Men Cant Jump at the behest of the Deadline Hollywood blogger Nikki Fink, who called 2010 the worst network pilot season for women. Melissa Silverstein, of the blog Women and Hollywood, was one of many to pick up the story. She compared the numbers and showed, for example, that there was an 11 percent decline in comedy pilots by women writers between 2009 and 2010.

title: Gus Van Sant on Young Love and Young Death
description: CANNES, France  For the last decade the director Gus Van Sant, a regular presence at the Cannes Film Festival, has undergone an artistic rebirth with movies about death. In 2003 he won the festivals top prize, the Palme dOr, for Elephant, his minimalist evocation of a Columbine-like school shooting. He returned to the competition here with Last Days (2005), an opaque antibiopic about the final hours of a suicidal rock star modeled on Kurt Cobain, and Paranoid Park (2007), a coming-of-age tale whose teenage hero wrestles with his culpability in a mans gruesome trainyard demise.

title: Appalachian Mountain Club Rolls Out Specials for Children
description: Best known for its backcountry hut-to-hut hiking system in the White Mountains, the Appalachian Mountain Club is seeking to encourage the next generation of trekkers with new youth-oriented program called Kid Spoken Here.

title: Pakistan Loses Another Journalist
description: You better come to your senses. This was the last threat received by the Pakistani journalist Nasrullah Afridi days before he was killed in a car bomb blast in Peshawar on May 10, his friend and colleague Sher Khan said in a telephone interview.

title: On the Lookout for an Amazon Tablet
description: The latest version of the Kindle went on sale over 10 months ago, so its been some time since weve heard a major new hardware product announcement from Amazon.

title: From the Pen of a Giant of Industrial Design
description: THE Brooks Stevens automotive designs of the mid-20th century, including the one-off Paxton Phoenix he created for Robert P. McCulloch, have long been recognized as fresh and distinctive departures from Detroit creations of the era. His singular perspective had many roots, but it grew at least in part from his fertile background as an innovator of a broad range of products.

title: Touchy Ford Telematics
description: FORD telematics systems that have gone haywire and Chryslers and Dodges that cant get out of Park are among the problems covered in the latest technical service bulletins.

title: Dreaming of Steam, but Running on Gas
description: TO Robert Paxton McCulloch, the idea of transplanting London Bridge to an Arizona desert probably seemed no more far-fetched in the 1960s than his dream, nearly two decades earlier, of mass-producing a steam-powered automobile.

title: Slow Recovery Worsens Financial State of Medicare
description: WASHINGTON  The financial outlook for Medicare deteriorated in the last year because of the sluggish economic recovery, and the programs hospital insurance trust fund will be exhausted in 2024, five years earlier than projected last year, the government said Friday.

title: Romneys Rhetoric on Health Care Echoes Obama
description: In a speech in Michigan on Thursday, Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts, sought to explain the past and, at the same time, shift attention to the future.

title: Catching an Indiscreet Overcall for 800
description: When asked for a notable deal, Fred Stewart and Kit Woolsey, winners of the Cavendish Invitational Pairs last Sunday in Henderson, Nev., gave Board 4 from the first session.

title: Connecticut Unions Agree to $1.6 Billion in Givebacks
description: HARTFORD  Threatened with nearly 5,000 layoffs, representatives for 45,000 unionized state employees agreed Friday to $1.6 billion in concessions over two years to help balance a budget that Gov. Dannel P. Malloy says includes pain for everyone: record tax increases, substantial program cuts and worker givebacks in health care, pension benefits and wages.

title: Childrens Bookshelf: Cats & Dogs
description: Pamela Paul reviews new childrens picture books about pets and working animals.

title: Former S.E.C. Official Said to Be Subject of Criminal Inquiry
description: WASHINGTON  A former Securities and Exchange Commission enforcement official who has been accused of repeatedly blocking efforts to investigate R. Allen Stanford, the Houston financier charged with running a $7 billion Ponzi scheme, is the subject of a federal criminal inquiry for having done legal work for Mr. Stanford after leaving the S.E.C., government officials said Friday.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: 13 More City Schools to Restart
description: Thirteen additional struggling schools will be put under limited private management next year, the city said on Friday, meaning a total of 22 schools are now slated to be run day-to-day by a nonprofit organization.

title: Couric Sets Date to Leave CBS Evening News
description: Katie Couric will anchor her final evening newscast for CBS on Thursday, CBS News said Friday.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 13
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Keeping Affluent Kids From Turning Into Brats
description: In this weekends Wealth Matters column, Paul Sullivan looks at the reasons wealthy families are not giving a lot of large gifts to children and grandchildren right now, even though they may miss out on the opportunity to take advantage of generous tax rules that will only last until the end of 2012.

title: Around the Web, a Push for Bridesmaids
description: Does the future of female-driven comedy rest on on how well Bridesmaids fares at the box office? Writers around the Web are standing up for the film, hoping it will lead to more projects and opportunities for funny women in Hollywood. In her review, The Timess Manohla Dargis praises the screenwriters Kristen Wiig and Annie Mumolo, saying they know what female moviegoers want: honest laughs with, and not solely about, women. She added that the film offers irrefutable proof that along with producing and starring in a hit TV series (thank you, Tina Fey), women can go aggressive laugh to aggressive-and-absurd laugh with men. All they need, beyond talent and timing, a decent director and better lines, is a chance.

title: Hitting the Ceiling
description: How bad will it be if we dont manage to raise the debt ceiling? And what should Obamas negotiating strategy be? A few thoughts.

title: Chic in Review | Following Kate Middletons Footsteps
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Choice of Lawsky for Financial Post Is Revealed in E-Mail
description: The Cuomo administrations disciplined approach to announcements, rollouts and other political stagecraft is a fact of life in Albany.

title: In a Hyphenated Program, the Movement Takes and Holds Center Stage
description: Interdisciplinary. Thats the word that crops up in almost every contemporary choreographers biography or mission statement. Just about every dance troupe, it seems, is dedicated to collaboration, democracy, conversation, exchange. And so it is with Catherine Cabeen and Company, which opened at the Joyce SoHo on Thursday night and is described in the program as a forum for investigating both the creative processes and artistic products that result when artists of different mediums collide.

title: A Defiant Qaddafi Says He Survived Attack
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  A day after an underground command center in his central Tripoli compound was blasted by a barrage of bunker-busting bombs, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi issued a defiant message to NATO on Friday, saying that he had survived and was now in a place where you cant get me.

title: On the Street | McQueened
description: The excitement of the exhibition Alexander McQueen: Savage Beauty has spilled out onto the front steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, with visitors dressing to the nines to view it.

title: Fast-Tracking to Kindergarten?
description: ON command, Eze Schupfer reads aloud the numbers on a worksheet in front of her: 42, 43, 12, 13. Then she begins to trace them.

title: HBO Talking to DeNiro for Movie About Madoff
description: 6:21 p.m. | Updated The Bernard Madoff saga will come to HBO as an original movie now that the network has acquired the rights to the book The Wizard of Lies, written by Diana Henriques, a reporter for The New York Times.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 13
description: More Photographs

title: Embracing the Artichoke
description: WHEN it comes to cleaning artichoke hearts, Ive always been a rather dainty cook.

title: Inflation Expectations
description: Just to follow up on something Ive mentioned before: after the commodity correction, plus the fairly tame inflation report, market expectations of future inflation have fallen. Heres the spread between 10-year Treasuries and inflation-protected versions of the same:

title: The Films of Rob Marshall
description: A look back at some of the movies from the director.

title: Footnote
description: The Kitchen, the 40-year-old performance and exhibition space on West 19th Street in New York, said that its board of directors had appointed Tim Griffin as its new executive director and chief curator. Mr. Griffin, a former editor of Artforum magazine, will replace Debra Singer, who has held the job since 2004 and who announced plans in January to resign.

title: American Idol Delivers Yet Again
description: Fox finished atop the Thursday-night ratings as 21.6 million viewers tuned in for the American Idol elimination episode at 8, according to Nielsens estimates. The Idol finalist James Durbin failed to advance to next weeks round, earning fewest votes of the nearly 72 million cast, leaving Lauren Alaina, Scotty McCreery and Haley Reinhart in the finale. Foxs Bones (11 million) trailed slightly behind CBSs CSI (11.5 million) in the 9 p.m. hour. CBS delivered a second-place finish over all, attracting 13.8 million at 10 for The Mentalist and broadcasting the sitcoms The Big Bang Theory (10.5 million) and Rules of Engagement (8 million) at 8 and 8:30. ABC was third with Wipeout (5.5 million), Greys Anatomy (9.4 million) and Private Practice (7.2 million). In a distant fourth place, NBCs comedy lineup struggled, led by The Office at 9 (6.2 million) and back-to-back episodes of Parks and Recreation at 9:30 (4.5 million) and 10 (3.6 million).

title: Denying Links to Militants, Pakistans Spy Chief Denounces U.S. Before Parliament
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  In an unusual, and apparently heated, closed-door session of Parliament, Pakistans spy chief issued a rousing denunciation of the United States on Friday for its raid that killed Osama bin Laden and denied that Pakistan maintained any links with militant groups, according to lawmakers.

title: Rap Duo Heads Back to the Stage, Granting No Compromises (or Smiles)
description: No rap group  maybe no act in any genre  has gotten more mileage from straight talk than Mobb Deep. This Queens duo, Havoc and Prodigy, have specialized in plainspoken menace for almost two decades: almost every song is in the aggressive, threatening second person. Havoc and Prodigy can go long stretches  whole albums, it can feel like  without so much as one metaphor. Metaphors are indirect. Mobb Deep doesnt want to confuse you.

title: A Top SUNY Official Is Accused of Giving a No-Show Job
description: The states ethics commission on Friday charged the president of the research foundation of the State University of New York, John J. OConnor, with giving a no-show job to the daughter of the former Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno.

title: A Christian Avenger
description: Opened on Friday nationwide.

title: Chicago Is Winfreys Town, but There Is Room for the Bulls
description: Oprah Winfrey is powerful, but she did not single-handedly reschedule the Eastern Conference finals. However, she will be borrowing the Chicago Bulls home court for 48 hours next week.

title: Teenage Dreams
description: Nearly every teenager Ive ever known likes to go to bed late and wake up late. So why does high school often start at 8 a.m.? Robert Daniel Vorona and a team of researchers decided to take advantage of a natural experiment. High schools in Virginia Beach, Virginia start 75-80 minutes earlier than high schools in the neighboring town of Chesapeake, which has similar demographics. Vorona and his team investigated whether students in Virginia Beach also had more automobile crashes. They did. Virginia Beach crash rates were significantly higher and their peak crash times were one hour earlier than peak Chesapeake crash times. The study was published in the Journal of Clinical Sleep Medicine.

title: Hip-Hop for Life
description: Opened on Friday nationwide.

title: Video of Protests and Clashes in Syria
description: As my colleague Anthony Shadid reports, despite a brutal crackdown in Syria, protesters took to the streets in at least five neighborhoods in Homs, Syrias third-largest city and a center of the two-month uprising. Activists said protests ranged in numbers from hundreds to thousands, and at least two people were killed when security forces opened fire.

title: To End All Wars
description: Introduction: Clash of Dreams

title: Exploring Themes of War, Both the Existential and the Concrete
description: It is hard to believe that the Oregon Symphony had never performed in Carnegie Hall until Thursday evening, when it played a vivid, often wrenching program, Music for a Time of War, as part of the Spring for Music festival. The orchestra was formed in 1896, and its international reputation has grown since 1987, when it began recording big, opulent works and sonic spectacular CDs for the Delos label. Many of these discs, conducted by James DePreist, the orchestras music director at the time (and now emeritus), remain in print and show the ensemble to be a highly polished precision instrument. Since 2003 it has been directed by Carlos Kalmar, a Uruguayan conductor who has maintained it admirably.

title: Taking the Audience Up Close and Personal, and Beyond Skin Deep
description: RoseAnne Spradlin has a knack for placing dancers and audience members in close quarters. For a while in downtown dance, this sort of intimacy was the new black. Choreographers moved the audience closer to the stage, limited the seating and favored a deadpan display of body parts.

title: Hot Rocks
description: The unofficial sub-theme of our Money Issue is, What now? The worldwide recession is over (fingers crossed), and the developing world has seemingly forgotten that anything untoward ever happened. Meanwhile, in the U.S. and Europe, doubt, confusion and recriminations reign. While the recovery lurches ahead, dangers loom everywhere  the deficit battle in Washington, dissension in the European Union, oil-price shocks. For this years Money Issue, we went out in search of narratives that reflect this mixed-up state of affairs.

title: A Little Offbeat Humor in Cyclical Explorations
description: Attending a concert by the pianist Bruce Levingston can feel a bit like showing up at a party at which you dont know most of your fellow guests. Dont hold it against him. Evidence indicates that Mr. Levingston mingles with ease in an exalted social stratum. Its members presumably help to support his nonprofit organization, Premiere Commission, which has financed the creation of some 40 new works; admirably, they also attend his concerts, greeting his efforts with exuberant response.

title: App Smart Extra: Keeping Track of Great Wines
description: Ive probably collected more than 50 corks from bottles of wine that I tasted at restaurants and wanted to remember later. The corks were invariably chewed up by my dog or tossed in the garbage.

title: The Battle for Libya | May 13
description: Friday Prayers in Benghazi and the continuing conflict in Misurata, Libya.

description: In Sundays Automobiles section, John Pearley Huffman drives the entire Audi A5/S5 family in a quest to find a combination of engine, transmission and body style that best suits the cars handsome lines.

description: LAS VEGAS  Three years ago, the SkyBridge Alternative Conference in Las Vegas was something of a backwater affair.

title: Victory Dance?
description: There was a moment in President Obamas appearance at a fundraiser Tuesday evening in Austin, Tex., that became a topic of much discussion during the week. Peter Nicholas at The Los Angeles Times reported on that moment, at which Osama bin Laden became an applause line in a presidential campaign speech:

title: Mercks Hepatitis C Drug Wins F.D.A. Approval
description: The Food and Drug Administration approved on Friday the first of a new generation of hepatitis C drugs that promises to increase the cure rate while shortening the time required for treatment.

title: J. Lo: The Sequel
description: SHE arrived like a modern-day Cleopatra, smiling and waving down at her adoring masses from the top deck of a trolley, her blown-out tresses fluttering in the wind.

description: To the Editor:

description: Tell your story in your own Vows video. Click here for more information.

title: Upfronts: Networks Order New Shows and Cancel Others
description: As the networks clear up their orders for new series next fall, they are bringing the curtain down on some others.

title: Singing the Praises of Water
description: Spring vegetables are the star of this weeks Eat column on pasta primavera, but water plays a key supporting role, and in fact, the most important step of many pasta recipes is scooping up a cupful of pasta-cooking water right before you drain the pasta. Without that water, youll never be able to bring the pasta and saucein this case, cooked vegetablestogether into a cohesive dish (unless you add tons and tons of olive oil, which has the drawback of weighing down a pasta dish, taste- and texture-wise).

title: Letters
description: To the Editor:

description: LOS ANGELES  Want to see the California Governors Mansion, once home to such political giants as Ronald Reagan and Earl Warren? Youd better hurry.

title: New Series Pits James Against an Old Foe
description: A late-game scoring burst enabled LeBron James to vanquish the Celtics and silence those detractors who had said he couldnt close. Now that he has finally beaten the Big 3  Kevin Garnett, Ray Allen and Paul Pierce  in a playoff series, James will turn his attention to the Chicago Bulls in the Eastern Conference finals.

title: Georgia Gives Police Added Power to Seek Out Illegal Immigrants
description: ATLANTA  Gov. Nathan Deal of Georgia on Friday signed into law one of the nations toughest immigration measures, empowering local police officers to question certain suspects about their immigration status.

description: In this homemade video, Marisa Kardos and Michael Garshick share the story of how they met at medical school and the fun hasn't stopped ever since.

description: If youre lucky enough to cohabitate with kids and an iOS device, here are four things to do to make things work smoothly (assuming youre already adept at removing applesauce from the screen). If theres a fifth, please share below.

description: In this homemade video, Brittany Bochow and Matthew Brandwein tell of their "magic bus" ride.

description: Consciousness. A foggy memory. The lack of physical evidence.

title: Two Straight Athletes Combat Homophobia
description: Ben Cohen is a world-class English rugby star, and Hudson Taylor is a three-time college all-American wrestler. They live on opposite sides of the Atlantic Ocean. They barely know each other.

title: For a Member of the First Black Class, a Second Chance
description: As one of its first black students in 1956, Burlyce Sherell Logan faced so much resistance at her Texas college that she dropped out. But 50 years later, she re-enrolled.

title: F.A. Cup Final: Stoke City Is Ready for Its Close-Up
description: It was only a matter of moments after Kenwyne Jones had put Stoke City ahead against Arsenal on Sunday that the chant began to ring out around the Britannia Stadium. It was immediately obvious what was being said and who it was being aimed at:

title: Friends Help Hold Back the Flood
description: A community of friends helped Russell Petty build a levee around his home in DeValls Bluff, Ark., and saved it from the flooding White River.

title: Neighbors 1, the Elements 0 (for Now)
description: DeVALLS BLUFF, Ark.  Muddy children stood in a human chain, passing sandbags to others who were two, three or four times their age. One volunteer was an exchange student from the Czech Republic. One man was in his 70s. Coolers of food, drinks and ice appeared, and no one knew where they had come from.

title: Taste of China Not as Far East: Egyptian Wing at the Met
description: There was a pagoda in the Egyptian wing of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Thursday night, at least at first glance. The sandstone Temple of Dendur was bathed in red light, as several hundred people  mostly Chinese-Americans  gathered to celebrate connections between China and the United States. At times, the shadows cast on the temples lintel conjured the up-ticked eaves of Asian architecture.

title: Pornography Is Found in Bin Laden Compound Files, U.S. Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  The enormous cache of computer files taken from Osama bin Ladens compound contained a considerable quantity of pornographic videos, American officials said on Friday, adding a discordant note to the public image of the Islamist militant who long denounced the West for its lax sexual mores.

title: Cities Nationwide Heighten Vigilance on Terror
description: MIAMI  In large and midsize cities across the country, police chiefs and domestic security officials say they have drastically increased counterterrorism operations under the assumption that a lone wolf or a small group of terrorists will try to strike on American soil to avenge the killing of Osama bin Laden.

title: Promoting Peace, Nobel Laureates Square Off, Politely
description: NEWARK  Of the many rare scenes provided here on Friday by renowned advocates of enlightenment and nonviolence, the rarest may have been a pair of Nobel Peace Prize winners getting about as close as such people ever get to actual confrontation.

title: Report From a Pashtun Teen: Cricket, Diplomacy and Hope
description: Our Pashtun teenage blogger, Sher Bano, wrote this piece late last month on how the Cricket World Cup semi-final match between India and Pakistan really brought the country together and gave Pakistanis hope and something to cheer for. As we were getting ready to post it, the news broke that Osama bin Laden had been killed in Abbottabad. We decided not to run the piece until things calmed down. In the meantime, Sher emailed us her reactions to the killing, and they perhaps offer a window into the thinking of some young Pakistanis. This is some of what she said:

title: A College Degree, 55 Years and an Era in the Making
description: DENTON, Tex.  As she prepares for her commencement at the University of North Texas here on Saturday, Burlyce Sherrell Logan can still hear the words the institutions president spoke at her freshman welcoming ceremony.

title: A True Finnish Spring
description: Helsinki, Finland

title: An Ailing Killebrew Simply Says Farewell
description: Harmon Killebrews modest farewell on Friday  in which the slugger of 573 home runs said his battle against esophageal cancer had come to an end  evoked the goodbyes made by former President Ronald Reagan as he faced Alzheimers disease and Charlton Heston as he described symptoms consistent with Alzheimers.

title: Areas Will Be Flooded to Protect Louisiana Cities
description: MORGAN CITY, La.  To relieve the pressure bearing down on the levees brought by a Mississippi River that has swollen to epic proportions, the Army Corps of Engineers will open the Morganza spillway, a gated structure north of Baton Rouge that would divert water from the river to protect New Orleans and other areas downriver by flooding a large area in southern Louisiana.

title: May Madness in N.H.L. Playoffs: Collapse and Advance
description: Of the four teams left in these Stanley Cup playoffs, three have survived near-disastrous collapses.

title: Recovery Seen in Rising Use of Credit Cards
description: Ever since the United States emerged from the recession, economists have been watching for signs that Americans are spending again.

title: Volunteers and Victims
description: Houston

title: Facebook, Foe of Anonymity, Is Forced to Explain a Secret
description: Facebook, it seems, doesnt always practice what it preaches.

title: Sabbatini Puts Possible Suspension Aside and Vies for Lead
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  While controversy continued to swirl around him, Rory Sabbatini played himself into contention for a second consecutive week. Sabbatini, who finished third in the Wells Fargo Championship, carded a one-under-par 71 Friday and is four strokes off the lead at the halfway point of the Players Championship.

title: Presidential Primary Book Club
description: Newt! Newt! Newt!

title: With Low Profile, Rays Rise to Top
description: Contrary to the popular belief that the rest of baseball devoutly observes the high, holy occasions when the Yankees play the Red Sox, a full slate of games was scheduled for Friday night. That included one in St. Petersburg, Fla., where the defending American League East division champion and leading Rays were hosting the Orioles.

title: Libyan Immigrants Flock to Italy
description: More than 9,000 people have arrived in Lampedusa, Italy, from Libya since its unrest began.

title: Libyan Immigrants Becoming Italian Immigrants
description: LAMPEDUSA, Italy  The fishing boats from Tripoli began arriving in the clear light of morning and continued well into the day on Friday, unloading more than 1,000 immigrants to this tiny Sicilian island. Most who made the rough crossing were men in their 20s and 30s, but there were also dozens of women, some pregnant, and several babies, whose sharp cries pierced the fresh sea air.

title: Bernard Greenhouse, Acclaimed Cellist, Dies at 95
description: Bernard Greenhouse, an internationally acclaimed cellist and a founding member of the Beaux Arts Trio, died on Friday at his home in Wellfleet, Mass., on Cape Cod. He was 95.

title: Pakistan After Bin Laden
description: Like most Americans, we have long despaired at the cynicism of Pakistans leaders, who accept American counterterrorist aid while also sheltering and enabling some of the worst anti-American extremists. But we never imagined that Osama bin Laden would be found hiding in plain sight, a stones throw from Pakistans leading military academy and an hours drive from Islamabad. Pakistans behavior since then has only added to the outrage.

title: Jeff Gralnick, Power in News at 3 TV Networks, Dies at 72
description: Jeff Gralnick, a blunt, gravel-voiced television news executive who got his start in the days of the 15-minute, black-and-white evening newscast and went on to play leading roles in the news divisions of three major broadcast networks, died on Monday at his home in Weston, Conn. He was 72.

title: Health Insurers Making Record Profits as Many Postpone Care
description: The nations major health insurers are barreling into a third year of record profits, enriched in recent months by a lingering recessionary mind-set among Americans who are postponing orforgoing medical care.

title: Millrose Games Will Move Uptown
description: The Millrose Games will be broken into two sessions and held on a Saturday when the meet moves next year to the Armory Track and Field Center in Upper Manhattan.

title: One Year and Many Billions Later
description: Last Mays $140 billion European bailout was supposed to ease Greeces return to private financial markets. But it demanded too much too soon in the way of growth-killing austerity. And it insisted that Greece keep paying its lenders in full and on time.

title: Reach Sambath, Tribunal Spokesman in Cambodia, Dies at 47
description: Reach Sambath, who survived the Khmer Rouge killing fields as an orphan and rose through journalism and teaching to become the spokesman for a tribunal in Cambodia that is trying the leaders of the Khmer Rouge, died on Wednesday. He was 47.

title: Toms Skips the Pitfalls of T.P.C. Sawgrass and Grabs the Lead
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  It has been awhile since David Toms last won a PGA Tour event, but in the past few weeks he has looked more and more like someone who remembers just how he won a dozen of them before his 40th birthday.

title: The Ensign Investigation, to Be Continued
description: The Senate Ethics Committee acted responsibly in referring the sordid case of former Senator John Ensign to federal authorities for possible criminal violations. Rather than let the matter fade with the Nevada Republicans hurried resignation before his scheduled deposition, the panel stressed that there was substantial credible evidence he violated the law.

title: In Shift, Ads Try to Entice Over-55 Set
description: After 40 years of catering to younger consumers, advertisers and media executives are coming to a different realization: older people arent so bad, after all.

title: U.S. Scrutinized Ensign, but Senate Dug Deeper
description: WASHINGTON  Justice Department officials investigating Senator John Ensign spent many hours last year in a Las Vegas office interviewing his ex-aide, Douglas Hampton, as they scrutinized e-mails, handwritten notes and the aides detailed recollections about payoffs, secret lobbying and hush money over a disastrous affair.

title: From a Footnote in American Baseball to a Record-Breaker in Japan
description: GINOZA, Japan  Few foreigners are likely to learn the word akage no matter how long they play baseball in Japan, but Matt Murton will hear it a lot in just his second season here. Adoring fans use the word to describe the top of his crown  redhead  an unusual sight in Japan.

title: Lawrence Johnson, Who Helped Ease Boats Into Water, Dies at 97
description: Lawrence N. Johnson, the founder of a boat trailer company who designed a trailer that made launching a boat almost as easy as parking a station wagon, died on May 6. He was 97 and lived in Spokane, Wash.

title: Chicago Ordered to Hire 111 Black Firefighters
description: CHICAGO  The City of Chicago must hire 111 black firefighter applicants who were passed over for jobs years ago and pay tens of millions of dollars in damages to about 6,000 other black candidates under a ruling issued on Friday by a federal appeals court.

title: Lottery Numbers
Donors to G.O.P. Are Backing Gay Marriage Push
description: As gay rights advocates intensify their campaign to legalize same-sex marriage in New York, the bulk of their money is coming from an unexpected source: a group of conservative financiers and wealthy donors to the Republican Party, most of whom are known for bankrolling right-leaning candidates and causes.

title: H.I.V. S O S
description: Treatment as prevention.

title: Footnote in Majors, Sensation in Japan
description: GINOZA, Japan  Few foreigners are likely to learn the word akage no matter how long they play baseball in Japan, but Matt Murton will hear it a lot in just his second season here. Adoring fans use the word to describe the top of his crown  redhead  an unusual sight in Japan.

title: Debate Over Intelligent Design Ensnares a Journal
description: According to one cynical view, academic disputes are so vicious only because the stakes are so low. Yet as the editors of Synthese, a leading philosophy journal, can tell you, what they publish matters: in debates over Christianity, the teaching of evolution, and American politics.

title: Saturday: Home to One and a Half Billion People
description: SATURDAYS PUZZLE  Its tough to pinpoint exactly where I crashed and burned on this one, because normally I like to fancy myself on Mike Nothnagels wavelength. His puzzles usually fall fairly readily for me, and I always enjoy them. This one was highly enjoyable once I got a toehold in the puzzle.

title: Family Quarrel Imperils a Labor Heros Legacy
description: KEENE, Calif.  A series of dirt roads in this tiny Central Valley town leads to a warren of homes and offices that has been, for decades, the headquarters of the United Farm Workers union. This is where Cesar Chavez, the labor and civil rights leader, carved out a retreat and raised his family. In a former tuberculosis sanatorium, the Chavez children learned the lessons of the union and listened to endless conversations about the backbreaking work in the nearby fields.

title: Victory Lap for Beltran in Houston
description: HOUSTON  In the mind of the typical Houston Astros fan, it must seem fitting that Carlos Beltran came back to play here a day after having a career game.

title: The Andy
description: Uptown, art lovers were bidding as much as $38.4 million this week for Andy Warhols early paintings. Downtown, where Mr. Warhol reigned for years as a pop artist-provocateur, things were considerably different.

title: For a Gala Concert, 90 Years of Songs
description: MARVIN HAMLISCH has won multiple Grammys, Oscars and Emmys, along with a Tony and many other awards. Despite all those accolades, however, it does not take much to make the 66-year-old composer feel special, he said in a recent phone interview.

title: Captive Soldiers Tell of Discord in Libyan Army
description: MISURATA, Libya  The army and militias of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, who for more than two months have fought rebels seeking to overthrow the Libyan leader, are undermined by self-serving officers, strained logistics and units hastily reinforced with untrained cadets, according to captured soldiers from their ranks.

title: Teacher Reviews Will Put More Focus on State Tests
description: Responding to criticism from Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and others, state education officials on Friday revised their plans for evaluating teachers so that up to 40 percent of their annual reviews could be based on students scores on state standardized tests.

title: Ex-Senator Gets 21-Month Prison Term in Tax Evasion Case
description: WHITE PLAINS  A former state senator was sentenced in federal district court here on Friday to 21 months in prison and three years of supervised release after pleading guilty last year to obstruction of justice and tax evasion.

title: Bloggingheads:  Leave Afghanistan?
description: David Corn, left, of Mother Jones and James Pinkerton of Fox News discuss Bin Laden and the war in Afghanistan.

title: Huge Protests in Yemen as Talks Drag On
description: Tens of thousands of protesters poured into the streets of Yemens capital, Sana, and cities across the country on Friday, keeping alive their efforts to drive President Ali Abdullah Saleh from office, according to activists and news reports from Yemen.

title: The Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Microsofts purchase of Skype, Music Beta from Google, guilty verdict for Raj Rajaratnam, G.M. investments and more.

title: Its Continental, but Not Old-Fashioned
description: EVERYTHING is new at Vitae, which has taken the place of Abel Conklins, a 25-year veteran in an 1841 building in Huntington Village. In addition to the new name, the restaurant, which opened in March, has a new owner, chef and look.

title: Wlffer Wins Merlot Contest
description: Like regional vintnersorganizations nationwide, the Long Island Merlot Alliance seeks evidence that its wines are the peers of better-known ones elsewhere.

title: Vulnerability Shows in a Longtime Rivalry
description: The fan in the right-field seats at Yankee Stadium who caught Boston third baseman Kevin Youkiliss home run ball in the seventh inning Friday night heaved it onto the field, where a ball boy scooped it up and hurriedly took it away, as if the whole thing never happened.

title: Violence Suffocated a Fathers Poetry, but Not His Voice
description: MEXICO CITY

title: Buffet or  la Carte, and Spicy or Not
description: THE many storefront restaurants on Broadway near its intersection with Tarrytowns busy Main Street, with its popular Tarrytown Music Hall, offer a panoply of dining choices for just about any occasion or appetite. The selections are international: Asian, Italian, Portuguese, Greek, new and old American, pizza and hot dogs.

title: Whites That Go With Spring
description: Remember when white wine by the glass came in one flavor, chardonnay? As diners have become more knowledgeable about food, restaurants and wine shops have kept pace, with chardonnay giving ground to albarino and aligot, grner veltliner and gewrztraminer, viognier and verdicchio. Consumers have backed off cheap, over-oaked chardonnays and embraced outlier varietals that offer better quality for the money.

title: Corrections
Germany: Ex-Nazi Guard Released Pending Appeals
description: John Demjanjuk, a former concentration camp guard who was convicted Thursday in what may have been one of the last Nazi war crimes trials, was released from a Munich prison on Friday pending the outcome of his appeals. Mr. Demjanjuk, 91, who is ill and stateless, was not considered a flight risk, but the authorities had trouble finding a nursing home to accept him. He will remain free while he appeals his conviction and five-year sentence for taking part in the killing of 28,000 Jews as a guard at the Sobibor concentration camp in Nazi-occupied Poland. A court spokeswoman said the appeals could take 18 months to two years.

title: Mets Have Another Powerful Night, but This Time Others Contribute
description: HOUSTON  Carlos Beltran had a rather modest night. One day after bashing three home runs, all Beltran could muster Friday was a double. But on a night of breakouts and comebacks, the Mets still got their three home runs anyway.

title: Photo Replay: May 13
description: A look at the day in sports, from the court to the links.

title: China: Credit Cooperative is Firebombed
description: A former worker at a rural credit cooperative in northwest China lighted a bottle full of gasoline and threw it into a meeting of his former colleagues on Friday morning, injuring 49 people, 19 of them seriously, the Chinese government said in a statement. The suspect was identified as Yang Xianwen, who fled after starting the fire about 8:30 a.m., the statement said. He was captured by the police at 5 p.m. Mr. Yang had been fired from the cooperative for embezzling public funds, the statement said, without explaining whether the money had belonged to the cooperative or another public entity. The incident occurred in Wuwei City in Gansu Province.

title: Friday Night Lights Watch: Forging and Breaking Ties
description: Before we get into breaking down the most recent episode of Friday Night Lights, I want to address a question that came up in the comments section last week about what was going on with T.M.U.s back-channel method of aiming to recruit Vince.

title: France Chides Britain for Support of Parliament Move
description: Frances European affairs minister scolded the British government for an unfriendly and aggressive gesture on Friday, after Prime Minister David Cameron and his deputy, Nick Clegg, backed a move to phase out the French city of Strasbourg as the seat of the European Parliament. In March, European legislators approved a bill to reduce time spent by the Parliament at the official chamber in Strasbourg, and allow for more time at the administrative offices in Brussels, where they conduct most of their business. The French minister, Laurent Wauquiez, said he told his British counterpart, David Lidington, that European institutions should reside in a plurality of locations, as doing so reflects the diversity of the European Union. Mr. Wauquiez said that the bill ran contrary to European treaties, and that France would contest it before the European Court of Justice.

title: Uganda: Deadly Ebola Virus Confirmed Near Capital
description: Preliminary tests have identified a case of hemorrhagic fever caused by the rare and deadly Ebola virus in central Uganda, a medical official said Friday. A young girl whodied in a hospital in the town of Bombo, about 25 milesfrom the capital, Kampala, tested positive for the virus, said Dr. Nelson Mugisha, a member of the medical team working on the case.He said the United States Centers for Disease Control and Preventionhad helped the government with the initial diagnosis. The viruscan leadto large outbreaks with high death rates.

title: Rangers Player Is Found Dead in His Home
description: Derek Boogaard, a 28-year-old Ranger regarded as one of the toughest fighters in the N.H.L., was found dead on Friday, the team announced.

title: Two Are Dead After a Fire in Brooklyn
description: Two people were killed on Friday night when a fast-moving fire engulfed the top floor of a building in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn, the authorities said.

title: Japanese Workers Death Not Linked to Radiation
description: TOKYO  A worker at Japans crippled nuclear plant died Saturday of causes that appeared to be unrelated to radiation, the plants operator said.

title: Remembering Ron Springs, the Football Player
description: Andy Barall writes about pro football history for the Fifth Down. Ron Springs, who died Thursday, was known for raising awareness about organ donations. But he was quite a football player as well.

title: Red Bulls Tim Ream Answers Your Questions
description: The second-year defender did his homework during the clubs trip to Montreal for an exhibition game on Wednesday, and here are his answers to questions from readers of the Goal blog:

title: The Weekend Word: Stepping Down
description: Todays Times

title: Obama Shifts to Speed Oil and Gas Drilling in U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, facing voter anger over high gasoline prices and complaints from Republicans and business leaders that his policies are restricting the development of domestic energy resources, announced Saturday that he was taking several steps to speed oil and gas drilling on public lands and waters.

title: Sentence of the Week
description: So many good sentences this week  a springtime burst of phrasal fecundity:

title: Farming Shrimp With the Planet in Mind
description: 7:41 a.m. | Updated Heres a shout-out to the amazing team of Pace University graduate and undergraduate students who, led by professor Maria Luskay (with my assistance), just completedthe short documentary Linda Thornton: Seeking Sustainability, One Shrimp at a Time. I hope youll give it a look and offer your reaction.

title: March of the Hooligans
description: Me on currency wars and all that, in the magazine.

title: Monetarist Pathos
description: I feel David Beckworths pain. Really, I do.

title: Old Man River
description: Whee! Theyre letting the Mississippi spill into the Atchafalaya.

title: Urban Forager | Ramp Season
description: In recent weeks, while traversing the wet, wooded areas of friends backyards in Greenwich, Conn., and Westchester County, I discovered lush carpets of two-leaved plants under the dappled light of deciduous trees. Crouching down low among last years foliage, I found that while the stems of the plants in Greenwich were white and the ones in Westchester were reddish, the air in both areas was filled with the distinctive fragrance of onions. Ramps. I quickly considered the culinary possibilities  savory ramp pie, scrambled eggs with ramps, ramps with morels.

title: Racings Drug Problem: More Complicated Than It Looks
description: Steve Zorn is racing manager of Castle Village Farm thoroughbred partnerships, and a director of the New York Thoroughbred Horsemens Association and the Backstretch Employees Service Team. He writes the Business of Racing blog.

title: Basic Black for U.S. Women
description: The United States womens national team will be wearing its new all black uniforms in Saturdays exhibition match against Japan.

title: Laugh Lines
description: JAY LENO

title: Weekend Plans? World to End
description: The last time he predicted the world would end (on Sept. 6, 1994, to be specific) his research was flawed, Harold Camping acknowledges. Not this time, he says. Mr. Camping, a retired civil engineer and the leader of Family Radio Worldwide, an independent Christian ministry, says he is convinced, based on a close reading of the Bible, that the end will begin on Saturday, heralded by huge earthquakes. His group has erected billboards across the country urging people to repent. Volunteers have traveled the country and the world spreading the same message. One of them, Lincoln Ropp, a medical student in Florida, went to Bulgaria. We definitely see a lot of scoffing and mocking, Mr. Ropp told the South Florida Sun-Sentinel. But really, we take this as expected. Jesus said when you speak the truth, youll be hated.

title: As Baghdad Erupts in Riot of Color, Calls to Tone It Down
description: BAGHDAD  In downtown Baghdad, a police headquarters has been painted two shades of purple: lilac and grape. The central bank, a staid building in many countries, is coated in bright red candy cane stripes.

title: Prime Number
