description: 1: The estimated number of rapes per minute, on average, of women in Congo, which United Nations officials have called the epicenter of sexual assault as a weapon of war.

title: Tensions Rise as Palestinians Mourn Israels Founding
description: JERUSALEM  Tensions were high in East Jerusalem on Saturday as hundreds of Palestinians buried a 17-year-old demonstrator and preparations were under way for rallies on Sunday to mark the founding of Israel 63 years ago, an event that Palestinians call the nakba, Arabic for catastrophe.

title: Back Then: 1955
description: As any fan of Dick Tracy video wristwatches knows, the idea of video calling long predates Skype, the pioneer in Internet phone-calling to be acquired by Microsoft in an $8.5 billion deal announced last week. Here is how The Times covered an early videophone call between the mayors of San Francisco and Palo Alto, Calif., at a public demonstration in 1955: "Spokesmen predicted that the elaborate gadget, combining the telephone in the same panel with a maze of television tubes, would have an important place in American life probably in the 1960s. "

title: Fighting Words
description: Last week, Mitt Romney, the former governor of Massachusetts and would-be Republican presidential candidate, sought to differentiate the health insurance plan he signed from President Obamas.

title: A Mexican Soccer Symbol Adjusts to the U.S.
description: Rafael Marquez does not spend much time in the kitchen, except when he is out sampling the restaurants of New York.

title: Teeing Up a Duffer Debate
description: MIAMI  The tiny red arrow on the irregularly dimpled golf ball offers the slice-prone hacker an irresistible pledge: Point the ball that way and, yes, it will go that way.

title: The Morning Line: Figuring Out Animal Kingdom
description: There is considerable news today in thoroughbred racing, and not all of it concerns the Preakness.

title: Recent Inflation History
description: During the Bush years, I used to get triumphant letters from conservatives saying things like, You say Bushs policies are bad, but the economy added 110,000 jobs last month  as if that was a big number; they had no idea what good job creation looks like.

title: Some Fans in Canada See Vancouver as Foreign
description: If you are American, you might think that the Vancouver Canucks are now Canadas team because they are the last Canada-based club standing among the final four in the Stanley Cup playoffs. Well, think again.

title: For Second Time in 3 Days, NATO Raid Kills Afghan Child
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  For the second time in three days, a night raid in eastern Afghanistan by NATO forces resulted in the death of a child, setting off protests on Saturday that turned violent and ended in the death of a second boy.

title: Bin Ladens Family Tree
description: Bin Laden had six marriages and at least 20 children over the course of 37 years. Heres a look at the family tree of a terrorist.

title: Bin Laden as Patriarch
description: WASHINGTON  When a man stalks the world as a mass killer, it distracts from the ordinary interest we might otherwise take in the mundane details of his life. And so it was with Osama bin Laden.

title: A Call From Within for the N.C.A.A. to Act Decisively Against Cheating
description: RICHMOND, Va.  There are few more optimistic places in college athletics right now than Virginia Commonwealth University. The campus hosted raucous impromptu street parties after its mens basketball team ambushed the Final Four, blitzing brackets and conventional wisdom with its charmed run.

title: Variety: A Headbanging Cryptic
description: SECOND SUNDAY PUZZLE  This has been a fun but tough week for me, puzzlewise. Yesterday I got Nothnageled, the day before that I was Naticked. Today, I am very grateful that I got my business degree in Strategic Guessing*, because thats precisely how I was able to get through this cryptic. That, and walking away from it once in a while.

title: Hawk, Man and Webcam
description: What could be rarer, in this city where the works of man blot out earth and sky alike and what wilderness persists seems compromised and debased, than a chance to bear close witness to a sacred spectacle of nature: a majestic hawk and her mate, hatching and raising a family.

title: Crawford Struggles at Plate and With Boston Spotlight
description: By the time Carl Crawford emerged from the trainers room late Friday, the Boston locker room had all but cleared out. Crawfords Red Sox had defeated the Yankees, 5-4, to take the opener of a three-game series at Yankee Stadium.

title: Norse Fantasy
description: Jake Halpern has an exuberant curiosity about people in their natural habitats; I think of him as a kind of maestro of attentively hanging out (for instance here and here). So when we sent him to Iceland to report on that countrys small steps toward economic recovery, we knew wed get a great tale about people. We did. And we got a bonus. Even before hed even left Iceland, Jake sent an e-mail containing another, more personal tale (see what I mean about exuberant?), this one about scalding rivers running through an icy landscape, a snowstorm and whats best left to the imagination.

title: Mets Closer Is Smiling Through the Pain
description: HOUSTON  Of all the changes that have taken place with the Mets since last years tumultuous season, perhaps the most striking has been the apparent transformation of Francisco Rodriguez.

title: In East, Intrigue in Series With Intersecting Story Lines
description: Nearly three decades ago, the Lakers pitched their training camp tent at the College of the Desert in Palm Desert, a couple of hours east of Los Angeles on Interstate 10. Every once in a while, Pat Riley, on his way to coaching the Lakers to three championships, ran into the colleges mens basketball coach, Gar Forman.

title: Whiff of Scandal Wafts Over 1918 World Series
description: More than any other American sport, baseball has an established historical footprint, and among its significant early events is the fixing of the 1919 World Series by gamblers and the Chicago White Sox, a team forever labeled the Black Sox. It is the only recognized gambling scandal to tarnish a World Series.

title: Assault in Border Town Sends Syrians Into Lebanon
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Hundreds of Syrians fled into Lebanon on Saturday after Syrian Army troops assaulted a border town, killing at least three people and arresting hundreds in the latest phase of a ferocious crackdown on the two-month uprising against the rule of President Bashar al-Assad.

title: Damon Sharpens Focus, With Eye on 3,000 Hits
description: CLEVELAND  Reverse the letters on the back of Johnny Damons jersey, and they spell nomad. That is what Damon has become as he bounces around the American League, from the Yankees in 2009 to the Detroit Tigers last season to the Tampa Bay Rays now.

title: Rich and Sort of Rich
description: How did $250,000 become the magic number?

title: Alaskas Ferries Go Farther North
description: Passengers from the lower 48 traveling to Alaska using its ferry system will be able to go farther north than before with new service that deposits them 60 miles south of Anchorage.

title: Undrafted Are Trapped in Lockout Netherworld
description: On the day the N.F.L. lockout entered its third month, while players and owners argued in a Minneapolis court over billions of dollars in television revenue, Dan DePalma was exerting his sliver of control over football on a high school field in Hoboken, N.J., last week.

title: Louisiana Spillway Opened to Relieve Flooding
description: MORGANZA, La.  After declaring that public safety is our No. 1 priority, officials from the Army Corps of Engineers opened the Morganza spillway, sending water from the engorged Mississippi River rushing into the pastures and cropland here to forestall potentially catastrophic damage farther downstream.

title: Chicago Trial May Unmask Pakistans Links to Militants
description: WASHINGTON  Two years before terrorists struck the Indian port city of Mumbai, a Pakistani-American man named David Coleman Headley began laying the groundwork for the attack, financed, he claims, by $25,000 from an officer in Pakistans powerful intelligence service.

title: Rodman, Heading to Hall of Fame, Is Already Back on A List
description: Dennis Rodman sat in a Midtown hotel lobby Wednesday, a few hours before kicking off a monthlong, multicity celebration of his 50th birthday at a Manhattan strip club. He pointed to each of his five rings.

title: Sex on Wheels? Now Its Room for Groceries, Too
description: MARANELLO, Italy

title: A Coach With a Situation for Almost Any Occasion
description: Phil Jackson ambled away last Sunday with a contented half-grin and a creaky gait, taking his 11 championships, Zen musings, literary references, book-giving habits and beloved triangle offense with him.

title: As Rift Deepens, Kerry Has a Warning for Pakistan
description: WASHINGTON  The United States and Pakistan are veering toward a deeper clash, with Pakistans Parliament demanding a permanent halt to all drone strikes just as the most senior American official since the killing of Osama bin Laden is to arrive with a stern message that the country has only months to show it is committed to rooting out Al Qaeda and associated groups.

title: The Buyers Are Back at Cannes
description: CANNES, France The success of independent films like Black Swan and The Kings Speech appears to have emboldened buyers here at the 2011 edition of the Cannes Film Festival. Theres been a bull market for acquisitions in the early days of the festival, even among American companies, which, battered by the financial downturn and other film industry woes, have largely sat on the sidelines in recent years, as The Hollywood Reporter noted.

title: A Panorama of the World Trade Center Site
description: A view of the south memorial pool at ground zero with 4 World Trade Center rising above newly planted white oak trees and 1 World Trade Center beyond the pool. The temporary wooden barrier is where the names of the victims of 9/11 will be placed. As part of the design, a system is being installed that will keep the temperature of the bronze name panels constant regardless of the weather, according to a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.

title: A Long Time Coming for a Mariners Outfielder
description: When the Seattle Mariners cut the troubled Milton Bradley last week, they opened a spot for a player with a deep appreciation of his chance. Outfielder Mike Wilson, who spent 10 seasons in the teams farm system, earned his first promotion to the majors.

title: Marital Matters and the 2012 Election
description: WASHINGTON  Cheri Daniels, whose aversion to politics appears to be the reason her husband, Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana, is dithering about running for president, had no shortage of stories during her much-hyped speech in Indianapolis last week. There was the one about her driving a dump truck, the one about how she attended a senior citizens prom, about how she took a prize for cow milking at the state fair.

title: Foods With Benefits, or So They Say
description: START in Aisle 2, third shelf from the bottom: here is grape juice for your heart. Over to Aisle 4: there are frozen carrots for your eyes.

title: Comparisons in Chief
description: WASHINGTON  As a candidate in 2008, Barack Obama pointedly noted that he doesnt look like all the presidents on the dollar bills.

title: A Low Bid for Fixing a Big Mess
description: SO the feds finally got one: Raj Rajaratnam, the hedge fund tycoon, is going down for insider trading.

title: Note to Staff: Were a Team, Not a Family
description: This interview with  Linda Lausell Bryant, executive director of Inwood House in New York, was conducted and condensed by  Adam Bryant. Inwood House focuses on teenagers health issues.

title: A Curve Isnt the Cure
description: To the Editor:

title: A Third Factor on the Economy
description: To the Editor:

title: Innovation, Gliding Across the Generations
description: DOES inventiveness run in families? Is there a gene that awakens the entrepreneurial urge? A look at the Smith family offers at least anecdotal evidence that the answer is yes.

title: When It Comes to Inbox Advertising, Less Is Still More
description: WHEN Google introduced Gmail seven years ago, it didnt copy Yahoo Mail or Microsofts Hotmail. Gmail was built for distraction-free speed. The ads were text-only, and so unobtrusive that you could forget they were even there.

title: Why Worry? Its Good for You
description: THE late Amos Tversky, a Stanford psychologist and a founding father of behavioral economics, used to say, My colleagues, they study artificial intelligence; me, I study natural stupidity.

title: Suddenly, Gold Isnt Looking So Solid
description: A RICH man carrying a heavy bag of gold coins set sail on a voyage, but his ship ran into stormy weather. Before it capsized, he attached the bag of gold to his waist and jumped overboard. He sank with his fortune, never to be seen again.

title: Behind the Greening of Wal-Mart
description: GIVEN our daily struggles with information overload, I suppose its inevitable that there will always be major, perhaps global, issues that some of us simply dont follow. Bosnia was like that for me. As serious as I knew the situation was, it went on for so long that I finally just gave up.

title: When Fear Stifles Initiative
description: CALL it trickle-down anxiety. Accustomed to hearing about budget cuts and layoffs from on high, employees at every level are becoming risk-averse. Dedicated, ambitious workers tell me they are so afraid of making a mistake that they feel its safer for their careers to avoid innovation and initiative. Managers need to realize that this paralysis threatens their companies health.

title: Head, Talking
description: From Cvltvre Made Stupid.

title: Belarus Opposition Leader Gets a Five-Year Sentence
description: MOSCOW  Belarus sentenced a leading opponent of the countrys authoritarian president to five years in prison on Saturday for organizing a large antigovernment protest. The sentence is the harshest punishment yet in a far-reaching crackdown that shows little sign of abating.

title: Still Making the Cool Stuff
description: I WAS focused on building things from an early age. When I was about 3, our toilet broke and my mother was ready to call the plumber. I told her I would fix it and asked her to get my Richard Scarry book How Things Work in Busytown. Between the picture ofa toilet, and the text she read to me explaining how the parts worked, I fixed it.

title: Florida Men Accused of Aiding Pakistani Taliban
description: WASHINGTON  The F.B.I. on Saturday arrested three Pakistani-Americans, including father and son imams from South Florida mosques, charging them with providing financing and other material support to the Pakistani Taliban.

title: Tunica Casinos Flooded
description: Rain falls in Tunica's town center, but a levee protects it from river flooding.

title: Tunica Casinos Flooded
description: Kate Thomas, a resident of Tunica, Miss., discusses the impact of flooding in the area.

title: Tunica Casinos Flooded
description: Qwondra Smith, a Tunica casino worker, discusses the impact of flooding there.

title: Tunica Casinos Flooded
description: Mayor Chuck Cariker discusses the impact of flooding in Tunica.

title: Letters to the Editor
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 30 Seconds With Mia Hamm
description: Mia Hamm is soccers leading international scorer in history, man or woman, with 158 goals. She was a leader on the United States team that won the inaugural Womens World Cup in 1991, the 1999 Cup, and Olympic gold medals in 1996 and 2004. Now 39, Hamm, who has 4-year-old twin girls with her husband, the former baseball player Nomar Garciaparra, took part in ESPN the Weekend at Walt Disney World in Florida.

title: Mets Beltran Sits Out Because of Eye Irritation
description: HOUSTON  Carlos Beltran was a late scratch from the lineup today after he woke up with swelling in his right eye. Fernando Martinez, who homered Friday night against the Houston Astros in the Mets 6-4 victory, was placed in right field, batting eighth.

title: Struggling Franchises Plot Their Next Moves in an Uncertain Climate
description: In the midst of one of the most exciting Stanley Cup playoffs in memory, some troubled N.H.L. franchises made news last week.

title: Seeing Beauty in the Rust Belt
description: Amid the decline of the American steel industry, years of disuse have transformed components of the Bethlehem Steel plant in Bethlehem, Pa., in striking ways.

title: News Corp. Will Disclose Its Political Donations
description: Beginning this summer, the News Corporation, the media company controlled by Rupert Murdoch, will announce each year all the political contributions it has made.

title: West Provides Game 7 Drama
description: This N.B.A. postseason has featured the two-time defending champion Los Angeles Lakers being swept away, the verification of the Miami Heat conglomerate in the vanquishing of the Boston Celtics, and an unlikely upstart in the Memphis Grizzlies, who were involved in a triple-overtime game against the Oklahoma City Thunder.

title: TMX Group Gets Takeover Bid
description: OTTAWA  The parent company of the Toronto Stock Exchange said on Saturday that it had received an unsolicited takeover bid from several Canadian banks and pension funds.

title: In Flooded Tunica, the Casinos Are Idle but Concerns Are Nonstop
description: TUNICA, Miss.  Like countless communities up and down the Mississippi River, life these days in this town of 1100, and its surrounding countryside, depends on which side of the levee youre on. The town center, shielded from the river, looks nothing more than a bit bedraggled, while on the other side, flood waters have invaded homes, displaced hundreds and submerged crop fields.

title: Brewery With a British Flavor
description: To an out-of-towner, Oxfords narrow, winding Hurley Road holds a couple of surprises. The first is its proximity to an airport. The second, just off the slightly overgrown country lane in a modern industrial park, is Cavalry Brewing, which began producing beer last July.

title: A Steakhouse With Quite a View
description: THERE will always be a place for a traditional New England-style steakhouse serving plain, sturdy cuisine. Particularly if it sits on an exquisite piece of Connecticut real estate. Brushmill by the Waterfall in Chester is such a destination.

title: Mired in Drought, Garca Tries to Stay Positive
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  A shot facing Sergio Garca last week had a high degree of difficulty. It required timing, finesse, concentration and extreme accuracy, and Garca was hyperfocused on pulling it off.

title: Eating Out Gets Easier for Celiac Patients
description: CLIFTON, N.J.

title: Erasing the Face of History
description: Chapel Hill, N.C.

title: Verlander Nearing Elite Company
description: The Tigers Justin Verlander became the 30th pitcher to throw multiple no-hitters when he blanked the Toronto Blue Jays last Sunday. The first pitcher to throw a no-hitter twice actually threw three gems in a brief career in the 1880s.

title: Corsets, Cleavage, Fishnets
description: HOLLYWOOD

title: Who Benefits If Huckabee Doesnt Run?
description: Im not going to speculate on what decision Mike Huckabee will make when he provides clarity tonight on his Fox News program about whether or not he will run for president.

title: Republicans Optimistic About Retaking Senate
description: WASHINGTON  Just two years after watching Democrats claim a 60th seat in the Senate, Republicans are heading into the 2012 election season well positioned to challenge them for control of the chamber, giving the party reason for optimism even as it worries about the strength of its presidential field.

title: Florida Men Accused of Supporting Pakistani Taliban
description: MIAMI  Six people, including two imams at South Florida mosques, have been indicted on federal charges of providing financial support and encouraging violence by the Pakistani Taliban, the United States attorney here announced Saturday.

title: I Am a Man
description: Watching the Arab uprisings these days leaves me with a smile on my face and a pit in my stomach. The smile comes from witnessing a whole swath of humanity losing its fear and regaining its dignity. The pit comes from a rising worry that the Arab Spring may have been both inevitable and too late. If you are not feeling both these impulses, youre not paying attention.

title: Driver Runs Down Narcotics Officer in the Village
description: A Westchester man turned his vehicle into a weapon on Friday night, steering it onto a sidewalk in Greenwich Village and ramming into a plainclothes police officer who, with his partner, was trying to arrest three drug suspects, the authorities said.

title: Where Water Is an Old Friend, Until It Turns Into a Nemesis
description: BUTTE LA ROSE, La.  You do not really want to ask a Cajun why he lives in a swamp, especially when he is packing everything he owns because the very swamp he loves is about to swallow up his house.

title: Venice Tourist Ships Rattle Windows and Nerves
description: VENICE  When cruise ships and ferries stream their way down the Giudecca Canal to dock at Venices main passenger terminal, the windowpanes on some of the palazzos on the quay have been known to tremble. Sometimes, even the walls shake.

title: What Holbrooke Knew
description: When he was alive, Ambassador Richard Holbrooke was effectively gagged, unable to comment on what he saw as missteps of the Obama administration that he served. But as we face a crisis in Pakistan after the killing of Osama bin Laden, its worth listening to Holbrookes counsel  from beyond the grave.

title: San Mateos Asian and Hispanic Voters Speak Up
description: Like many residents in this corner of San Mateo County, Violeta Ortega can name the exact intersection on Middlefield Road where sun-blanched taqueras and car repair shops fade into leafy oaks and 10-foot-high walls that circle some of the most expensive houses in the United States.

title: A Big Whine From Big Oil
description: With gas at $4 a gallon, oil at $100 a barrel and profits at near-record levels, it is hard to feel sympathy for the oil industry. Yet sympathy is what the C.E.O.s of the five biggest companies asked for when they appeared Thursday before a Senate hearing on a Democratic proposal to eliminate about $2 billion in tax breaks for the Big Five.

title: Big Deal. I Just Said It. I Didnt Say It Was True.
description: Elizabeth Lesly Stevens writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: Oakland Police Force Restructuring Could Hinder Murder Investigations and More
description: The Oakland Police Department, reeling from budget cuts, is planning an organizational overhaul that will push more officers onto the streets, but could undermine its ability to investigate murders and other serious offenses at a time when the homicide rate is soaring.

title: When Doctors Humiliate Nurses
description: To the Editor:

title: A Newly Pastel Capital
description: Artists, city officials and designers in Baghdad are lamenting what they feel is of the ugliest periods in the citys history, as banks and police buildings are outfitted with unconventional color schemes.

title: Red Rock Island
description: Jutting out of the blue near the Richmond-San Rafael Bridge is Red Rock Island, a homely atoll with a colorful history and a sizable price tag. Many have made plans over the years to develop this ideally situated islet with spectacular views, but it is currently uninhabited.

title: Children of War
description: To the Editor:

title: Radiation and Cancer
description: To the Editor:

title: Cardiologists Accuse Hospital of Discrimination
description: VICTORIA  The e-mails and memos written by administrators and doctors at Citizens Medical Center here about three of their colleagues of Indian descent are, at best, derogatory. An operating room chief wrote of trying to force the Indians off the reservation. Others wrote about their Indian troubles, or labeled the hospitals two rival cardiology practices as the Cowboys and the Indians.

title: Electric Cars of the Future
description: To the Editor:

title: Outdoor Smoking Bans
description: To the Editor:

title: Westchester Tax Appeals
description: To the Editor:

title: Do-or-Die Time for Bills Has All Eyes on the Clock
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

title: For Subway Cars, The Final Trip
description: Because new trains have more plastic, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority has suspended the reefing program after 10 years and 2,500 burials.

title: Lawmakers and Others Discuss Changes to Education Programs for Prisoners
description: As state lawmakers combed the budget this year for cuts to close a multibillion-dollar shortfall, some leaders focused on a line item that usually draws little attention: the Windham School District, which received more than $128 million in 2010-11 to provide education to inmates in the states sprawling prison system.

title: In Prison Reform, Money Trumps Civil Rights
description: Columbus, Ohio

title: Pats Pick
description: The best new restaurant in Texas right now.

title: Did the Microsoft Case Change the World?
description: Remember when Microsoft ruled the PC industry? In the 1990s, its Windows operating system became so dominant that government trust-busters took it to court. They spent four years and millions of dollars making the case that Microsoft was unduly using its power to wipe out rivals in the Web browser business and other domains.

title: The Secrecy Tax
description: Who are the fat-cat five? Political money bundlers are wondering now that the Internal Revenue Service has put five unnamed donors on notice that it is looking at the checks they write to nonprofit groups that are increasingly funneling money directly to political campaign troughs.

title: Strolling Coney Island the Hard Way
description: Not since Charles Feltman was credited with inventing the hot dog 140 years ago has Coney Island had to adjust to such radical change as the concrete compromise thats about to alter its signature boardwalk along the Atlantic beachfront.

title: A Mayor Moves on, and a Myth Moves In
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Figure in 2006 City Hall Patronage Case Has a New Career Lobbying City Hall
description: The citys inspector general forced Christopher Kozicki from his high-ranking job in Mayor Richard M. Daleys administration three years ago, citing his involvement in the infamous hiring of an unqualified, but politically connected, teenager as a building inspector. At the time, his lawyer said Mr. Kozicki would move on to pursue other opportunities.

title: The Other Torture Debate
description: IT wasnt long after Osama bin Ladens killing that the arguing began: did the Bush administrations torture policy produce essential intelligence that led the United States to Bin Ladens hideout in Pakistan?

title: Big Business Threatens and New Tax Break Is Readied
description: David Greising writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Bringing the High Line Back to Earth
description: THE second section of the High Line, the park built atop an abandoned elevated rail trestle on the west side of Manhattan, is scheduled to open next month. Like a movie sequel, High Line II will have some things that are the same  more of those neat high-tech concrete planks underfoot and peel-up benches  as well as some things that are different: a woodland flyover of dense vegetation; a lawn; and a dramatic glass cutout exposing traffic on the street below. Food carts and something called a wine porch are promised, as well as a Renzo Piano-designed restaurant.

title: Charles McPhee, Host of Dream Doctor on Radio, Dies at 49
description: Charles McPhee, a nationally syndicated talk radio host who made a career analyzing the stuff of dreams, died last Sunday at his home in Woodland Hills, Calif. He was 49.

title: Cornell Dupree, Guitarist and Sideman to the Stars, Dies at 68
description: Cornell Dupree, a guitarist whose quietly bluesy style made him an in-demand session musician throughout the 1960s and 70s for artists like Aretha Franklin, Paul Simon and Ringo Starr, died May 8 at his home in Fort Worth. He was 68.

title: Montezemolo in the News
description: There have been reports in recent days of Luca di Montezemolo, the chairman of Ferrari, saying that the Formula One teams are now open to the possibility of a breakaway series.

title: Montezemolo in the News
description: There have been reports in recent days of Luca di Montezemolo, the chairman of Ferrari, saying that the Formula One teams are now open to the possibility of a breakaway series.

title: Sunday: Included Herewit
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  Well, thats more like it: A puzzle I can solve without bloodshed.

title: Credit Error? It Pays to Be on V.I.P. List
description: The credit rating bureaus, whose reports influence everything from credit cards to mortgages to job offers, have a two-tiered system for resolving errors  one for the rich, the well-connected, the well-known and the powerful, and the other for everyone else.

title: Playgrounds of the Past
description: New Yorks vibrant flea markets offers patrons a large volume of food, scavenger hunts and nostalgic items from the past.

title: Tackling the Problems of Appalachia, Theatrically
description: CUMBERLAND, Ky.  Robert Gipe, an expert on Appalachia, had grown weary of watching flip-chart presentations about the regions problems. Their remedies were too sweeping, and their language, full of terms like sustainable development, were too lofty.

title: Service Complaint
description: Is it just me, or has Verizon Wireless 3G service along the Northeast Corridor gotten significantly worse over the past few months? There were always gaps, but they seem to have multiplied  no signal much of the way between Baltimore and Washington.

title: The Supreme Court Had Its Say. Now Let Shareholders Decide.
description: Valley Forge, Pa.

title: Broadcast of Die Walkre Performance at the Met Is Delayed
description: The massive set for Wagners Ring being staged at the Metropolitan Opera picked a fine time to misbehave. A technical problem left an estimated 175,000 people sitting in movie theaters around the world (and nearly 4,000 people at the Met itself) twiddling their thumbs while waiting for the start of a live high-definition broadcast of Die Walkre, the cycles second installment. Finally, after about 45 minutes, the performance started.

title: Major Delusions
description: London

title: Dessert, Laid-Back and Legal
description: Remember melatonin? In the 1990s, this over-the-counter dietary supplement was all the rage among frequent fliers, promoted as the miracle cure for jet lag. Now it is back in vogue, this time as a prominent ingredient in at least a half-dozen baked goods that flagrantly mimic the soothing effects of hash brownies  and do so legally. At least for now.

title: Your So-Called Education
description: COMMENCEMENT is a special time on college campuses: an occasion for students, families, faculty and administrators to come together to celebrate a job well done. And perhaps there is reason to be pleased. In recent surveys of college seniors, more than 90 percent report gaining subject-specific knowledge and developing the ability to think critically and analytically. Almost 9 out of 10 report that overall, they were satisfied with their collegiate experiences.

title: Site of Fatal Fire Was a Boarding House, Fire Officials Say
description: A Brooklyn row house where two men died in a fire on Friday night was an improvised boarding house, fire officials said.

title: Readers Comment on my Holbrooke Column
description: My Sunday column offers advice from Ambassador Richard Holbrooke, the late American envoy to Afghanistan and Pakistan, for the crisis we now face in relations with that region. Holbrooke couldnt speak out publicly at the time, but his posthumous views could not be more relevant at a time when we face a crisis in relations with Pakistan.

title: U.S.D.A. May Hire an Ex-Employees Group
description: WASHINGTON  The federal Department of Agriculture may soon issue a contract to a community organization co-founded by Shirley Sherrod, the former department employee who was asked to resign last year after a conservative activist issued an edited videotape that appeared to show her making racially insensitive remarks.

title: Black or White?
description: In February 1861, just weeks after Louisiana seceded from the Union, Randall Lee Gibson enlisted as a private in a state army regiment. The son of a wealthy sugar planter and valedictorian of Yales Class of 1853, Gibson had long supported secession. Conflict was inevitable, he believed, not because of states rights or the propriety or necessity of slavery. Rather, a war would be fought over the inexorable gulf between whites and blacks, or what he called the most enlightened race and the most degraded of all the races of men. Because Northern abolitionists were forcing the South to recognize the political, civil, and social equality of all the races of men, Gibson wrote, the South was compelled to enjoy independence out of the Union. (Read Randall Lee Gibsons article, Our Federal Union.)

title: Struggling Again, Dickey Gives Knuckleball a Day Off
description: HOUSTON  If there is one thing that R. A. Dickey has never been over his 12-month Mets career, it is conventional. An avid reader who yearns to climb mountains and to be a ball boy at the United States Open, Dickey is unique among professional athletes.

title: Posada Sits Rather Than Hit Ninth in the Lineup
description: At 4 p.m. Saturday, Jorge Posada said he understood why Manager Joe Girardi had dropped him to ninth in the Yankees batting order. I put myself in this spot, Posada said. Two hours later, Posada marched into Girardis office and told him that he felt disrespected. Rather than suffer the ignominy of hitting last in a nationally televised game against the Boston Red Sox, Posada pulled himself out of the lineup.

title: Chicago Braces for the Unknown and a New Mayor
description: CHICAGO  With only a few days to go, Richard M. Daley, the longest-serving mayor in Chicagos history, had yet to pack up his City Hall office, which was cluttered with old photographs, trinkets from other towns, even the desk from which his father once governed this city.

title: I.M.F. Chief, Apprehended at Airport, Is Accused of Sexual Attack
description: The managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, was taken off an Air France plane at Kennedy International Airport minutes before it was to depart for Paris on Saturday, in connection with the sexual attack of a maid at a Midtown Manhattan hotel, the authorities said.

title: Daleys Next Task: Adapting to Life Outside City Hall
description: CHICAGO  Yes, there will be the shock of not going to work on the fifth floor of City Hall on Monday, as Mayor Richard M. Daley has for more than two decades. But there are more pressing matters to worry about. Like getting used to carrying a wallet, buying a cellphone, and remembering how to drive a car.

title: Sony Begins Phased Restoration of PlayStation Services
description: Sony said on Saturday that it would begin restoring the PlayStation Network for its 77 million users after hackers infiltrated the service and forced it offline almost a month ago.

title: Stack of Evidence Sealed Galleon Case, Juror Says
description: Andrew Burton/Getty ImagesRaj Rajaratnam leaving federal court after his conviction.

title: Secret Desert Force Set Up by Blackwaters Founder
description: ABU DHABI, United Arab Emirates  Late one night last November, a plane carrying dozens of Colombian men touched down in this glittering seaside capital. Whisked through customs by an Emirati intelligence officer, the group boarded an unmarked bus and drove roughly 20 miles to a windswept military complex in the desert sand.

title: Boogaard Family Authorizes Brain Study
description: In poll after poll of N.H.L. players it was always a landslide: Derek Boogaard was the toughest, most feared fighter in the league.

title: McDowell and Watney Lead, but Storms Leave Much of Two Rounds to Play
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  A four-and-a-half-hour rain delay during Saturdays third round of the Players Championship defanged T.P.C. Sawgrass, and golfers filled with pent-up energy attacked the softened course like a swarm of children at an Easter egg hunt.

title: China Delays Report Suggesting North Korea Violated Sanctions
description: China has tried to suppress a report at the United Nations suggesting that North Korea and Iran have been routinely sharing ballistic missile technology, United Nations diplomats said Saturday, expressing concern that Beijing was again working to shield the North.

title: At a 10-Year Reunion, Old Songs and New Voices
description: As if guided by sense memory, they took their positions from their gospel chorus days, only they were standing on a sidewalk on the Upper West Side.

title: A Visual Narrative of Old England, Rude, Lewd and Colorful
description: Americas baby boomers savored the joyously irreverent cartoons of Mad Magazine and the leeringly carnal comix of R. Crumb. Gilded Age New Yorkers either cheered or fumed at the political savagery in the drawings of Thomas Nast. And Georgian-era Londoners got early versions of all three in the rude, lewd, devilishly funny prints of Thomas Rowlandson.

title: The Bruise Patrol of Central Park
description: THE three men wearing in-line skates stood quietly in the shade in Central Park, studying the passing crowd. Then a nearby skater, Jesse Madigan, 25, slammed into a curb, doubling over, and they pounced.

title: An Operatic, Comic Romance
description: One look at the set for Italian American Reconciliation and you may form an opinion as to just what kind of production this is.

title: A Power Breakfast With a Cozier Touch
description: Breakfast in the main dining room of the Loews Regency Hotel on Park Avenue at 61st Street is still the see-and-be-seen meal for New Yorkers with money and influence, but a younger generation of power brokers is establishing its own beachhead in the Library. It is a quieter, cozier spot off the lobby, with a mounted flat-screen television, a plush couch in the window and enormous reproductions of classic books standing upright. On Wednesday, in the main dining room, called 540 Park, Larry King dined near Jonathan M. Tisch, the chief executive of Loews Hotels, who was with Jane Rosenthal, Robert De Niros producing partner. But in the Library, a nonprofit executive and her frequent consulting partner sat between The Grapes of Wrath, by John Steinbeck, and Bullet Park, by John Cheever, talking baby names and home renovation. DIANE CARDWELL

title: In Southampton, Portraits From a Luxe Life
description: Southampton, N.Y.

title: The Consciousness of a Feminist Expressionist
description: For many painters, prints serve as a place to try out new ideas, experiment in a different medium or circulate their images in a reproducible format, while earning some extra money. Sometimes, however, a print exhibition can feel like a vital key to an artists career. Such is the case with Dancing With the Dark: Joan Snyder Prints 1963-2010 at the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum in New Brunswick.

title: Pick a Car, Then Off to Church
description: A connoisseur of and a cheerleader for all things Staten Island, John C. Gustafsson, president (until June 30) of the Staten Island Historical Society, was born there 49 years ago. Both he and the borough expect a busy summer as the celebration of Staten Islands 350th anniversary hits its peak. Mr. Gustafsson retired in 2006 from a law career that began at Simpson Thacher & Bartlett and concluded at Sheppard Mullin Richter & Hampton, where he was administrative partner in the New York office. He and his wife, Mary Beth, general counsel of First Solar, live in a Stanford White house in West Brighton; Mr. Gustafssons son, Christopher, 13, visits every other weekend.  ROBIN FINN

title: As a Festival Expands, Its Needs Do, Too
description: MEMORIAL DAY weekend will bring the third installment of Bombfest  an acronym for Bring Our Music Back Festival. But instead of bringing the music back to Durham, where the multigenre festival was held last year, the events founders, Frank Bombaci and his son, also named Frank Bombaci, will be delivering headliners like Weezer, Wiz Khalifa and Snoop Dogg to Hartford.

title: You Can Do That on a Sunday?
description: It was Sunday morning, about 11 oclock, and a casual glance might have suggested I was in church. There were a couple of bibles nearby; a depiction of the Garden of Eden was available for examination. But I wasnt in church. I was in the Museum of Sex. New Yorks blue laws, it appears, are not holding up so well.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Unrest Continues as Libya Mourns Dead
description: Protests broke out across the country even as Libyans buried victims.

title: As Libya Buries Victims, Hints of Deception
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  As the nine pinewood coffins were laid on scrubland beside the glistening blue waters of the Mediterranean, uniformed men with Kalashnikov rifles fired volley after volley into an azure sky, and a trumpeter blew the discordant melancholy of a final farewell.

title: After Hinting Otherwise, Huckabee Says He Wont Run for President
description: Former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas said Saturday night that he would not seek the Republican nomination for president next year in an announcement that had been hotly anticipated  in part because of contradicting hints he gave right up to the minute he finally made his intentions known.

title: How Libyan Rebels Have Repelled Qaddafi in the Western Mountains
description: How Libyan rebels have repelled Qaddafi in the western mountain region.

title: Photo Replay: May 14
description: The day in sports was filled with kicks, slides and celebrations.

title: Voices Soar Again, 10 Years Later
description: In 2001, a teacher took her students from P.S. 86 in the Bronx on an unlikely journey: to a small island in Finland, where they would perform their music. They reunited 10 years later.

title: Upsets Are Paving the Way to the World Championship
description: The first round of the World Championship Candidates Matches in Kazan, Russia, produced several surprises.

title: G.O.P. Candidates Line Up to Compliment Huckabee
description: Now comes Huck, Part 2  the effort by other candidates to pick up his supporters with kind statements about the latest noncandidate, former Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas.

title: Running on Moderation in Immoderate Times
description: BRAZIL, Ind.  Senator Richard G. Lugar had already been introduced to the Clay County Republican Club as a leader in reducing the threat of nuclear, chemical and biological weapons, a man of Hoosier common sense and a true statesman for our time.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 15
description: The 2012 presidential race gained momentum this week as potential Republican challengers began announcing their candidacies, making the election a major topic of conversation on the Sunday talk shows.

title: Lottery Numbers
Times Square Pastor Remembered as Charismatic and Charitable
description: While many speakers at the memorial service for the Rev. David Wilkerson on Saturday spoke of how many lives his ministry had touched, one clergyman spoke from very personal experience.

title: Yanks Night Starts Oddly, Then Turns to Disaster
description: The Yankees night began on a curious note, with an announcement shortly before the first pitch that Jorge Posada, penciled into the No. 9 spot in the teams batting order by Manager Joe Girardi, had been scratched from the lineup.

title: When a Batting Order Becomes a Reflection of Disorder
description: Theres nothing like going to the office and being blindsided by the news that you have been demoted.

title: Posadas Mental Health Day
description: Jorge Posadas late scratch from the Yankees lineup shortly before a 6-0 loss to the Boston Red Sox on Saturday at Yankee Stadium led to a night of speculation and disagreement over why he did not play.

title: No. 20 on Your Roster, No. 9 in the Order
description: Jorge Posada and Derek Jeter have been friends for nearly 20 years, since they were teammates at Class A Greensboro in 1992. Their daily interaction is part of the fabric of the Yankees clubhouse. Jeter, holding a cup from Starbucks, grabs a pair of sanitary socks and belts out, Sado!  his nickname for Posada. They have won together  five World Series championships  and they have lost together, and now they are, almost inevitably, declining together, a 36-year-old shortstop and a 39-year-old designated hitter.

title: In Paris, the Striking Strokes of Japanese Calligraphy
description: When Ritsuko Koga met Ayako Wakahara, the president of the Young Japanese Calligraphers collective, she was moved by her ambition and her objective to make the value of Japanese calligraphy known to the world. Ms. Koga, who oversees the gallery space at Espace Japon (12 rue de Nancy; 33-1-47-00-77-47; www.espacejapon.com), then invited the group to display their oeuvre in Paris. All of the artists studied calligraphy at Tokyos University of Taito-bunka, an institution that puts special emphasis on Eastern traditions and culture. By working as a collective, the Young Japanese Calligraphers communal nature fortifies the solitary aspects of this written art.

title: 2010 Texans: What the Film Revealed
description: While we wonder whether there will be a 2011 season, this is part of a series looking back at the 2010 season, with the benefit of film analysis.

title: Q. and A. With the Red Bulls Rafael Marquez
description: Rafael Marquez, the captain of Mexicos national team, is in his second season with the Red Bulls of M.L.S. The veteran, who has played in France and for Barcelona in Spain, is back at his natural center back position and has helped to steady the clubs defense as the Red Bulls prepare for Sundays game against visiting Chivas USA. Marquez, a superstar in Mexico, has often times seemed like that other guy as the club and league promote the exploits of Thierry Henry, who was also his teammate in Spain. Marquez spoke recently with Jack Bell of The Times.

title: Going Dutch
description: For those of us fortunate enough to regularly patronize New York Citys wondrous bodegas, the appearance of cut tulips ($7 a bunch, two for $12) in mid-February is our first inkling that spring is coming. Most of us dont have access to real trees, after all. Besides, those other, more fluorescent flowers, the ones that require a certain level of patience to sift through, dont appear to be tied to a particular season  or to Earth, even  as they sit huddled in green buckets, illuminated by fluorescent lights.

title: With Europe in Crisis, Fragile Time for I.M.F.
description: LONDON  Its hard to imagine a worse time for the International Monetary Fund to be without a forceful European leader.

title: A Morning at Fair Hill
description: On Saturday morning, I met three friends and headed over to Fair Hill to watch Animal Kingdom train. We met at the local deli, formerly named Prizzios, and drove to the clockers stand. There was light chatter among my friends, who had not yet seen the Derby champion.

title: Credit Report Errors: How Have You Handled Them?
description: On todays front page, Tara Siegel Bernard uncovers something youve probably suspected for a long time: Equifax, Experian and TransUnion has one system for solving important peoples credit report errors and another for everybody else.

title: Singers From Azerbaijan Win Eurovision Contest
description: FRANKFURT  A singing duo from Azerbaijan was the surprise winner of the Eurovision Song Contest on Saturday, the first victory for the country  technically located in Asia  since it began competing in the popular event four years ago.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Soul-Searching in France After Officials Arrest Jolts Nation
description: PARIS  The arrest in New York of one of Frances leading global figures and a possible next president, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, on charges of attempted rape produced an earthquake of shock, outrage, disbelief and embarrassment throughout France on Sunday.

title: Muslims and Coptic Christians Clash Again in Egypt
description: CAIRO  Muslims and Coptic Christians clashed with bullets, rocks and Molotov cocktails here for the second time in seven days on Saturday night, sending at least 55 people to the hospital, officials with Egypts Interior Ministry said.

title: Salmon-Eating Sea Lions Sentenced to Die
description: For the crime of snacking on endangered salmon, dozens of sea lions have been sentenced to die.

title: Cannes Q. and A.: Julia Leigh on a Modern-Day Sleeping Beauty
description: CANNES, France The Australian novelist-turned-director Julia Leigh traces the origins of her first feature, Sleeping Beauty, to what she calls a bout of self-exposure. The attention she received for her well-received first novel, The Hunter (1999), led to a recurring nightmare about being watched in her sleep.

title: Israeli Troops Fire as Marchers Breach Borders
description: JERUSALEM  Israels borders erupted in deadly clashes on Sunday as thousands of Palestinians  marching from Syria, Lebanon, Gaza and the West Bank  confronted Israeli troops to mark the anniversary of Israels creation. More than a dozen people were reported killed and scores injured.

title: Seven Tips to Better Landscape Photos
description: The photographer Ansel Adams is reputed to have said Landscape photography is the supreme test of the photographer  and often the supreme disappointment.

title: Landscape, With Flowers
description: This weeks Look features tulips seen from such a height that we see not flowers but a colorful abstraction. That picture above looks more like a worn throw rug from a northern European department store than a planted field. The tulip, of course, is a signature icon of Dutchness, along with windmills, clogs, pointy bonnets, dark Rembrandt portraits/bright Van Gogh craziness, certain Amsterdam liberties and  on my altar, at least  soccer wizards like Johann Cruyff and Dennis Bergkamp. And Cruyff has his own move named after him and is one of the architects behind totaalvoetbal; Bergkamp did this (and this).

title: He Saw Plenty From the Ring, Not So Much in It
description: There was a time, a few decades ago, when pro wrestling thrived in New York City, whether at Madison Square Garden, or in high school gyms.

title: Update on Verizon
description: Well, with regard to this post, Im on Amtrak now, and my connection seems OK. In fact, Im sure that its perfectly reliable; theres no chance whatsoever that I will be cut off in the middle of a

title: The Morning Line: Motion and Fair Hill Are Hot Topics
description: Almost all of the Triple Crown news today involves varying aspects of Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdom.

title: Faye Dunaway Defends Canness Artistic Soul
description: CANNES, France International sex scandals with likely candidates for the French presidency have not disrupted proceedings at the film festival here. On Sunday afternoon, Frdric Mitterrand, the French minister of culture, gave Faye Dunaway a medal and the honor of being an officer in LOrdre des Arts et des Lettres. Ms. Dunaway, whose kohl-eyed, sex-kitten image, photographed by Jerry Schatzberg in 1970, graces program guides and advertisements all over town, and hangs stories high above the Palais des Festivals, seemed to deserve the title, or at least she was ready to defend it. At the opening night dinner following the premiere last Wednesday of Woody Allens Midnight in Paris, she bristled at the notion that Cannes might have a commercial bent. Dont say that, because its wrong, she said. Cannes is not commercial, for Gods sake. Cannes is the only festival in the world, and the only entity in the world, that honors great film, from all over the world.

title: Google Turns On Charm to Win Over Europeans
description: PARIS  Chiseled into the stone facade of the vacant Second Empire building at 8, rue de Londres here is the name of the French national railroad, a former occupant. Most recently, the site housed another conservative pillar of the French corporate establishment, the insurer AXA. The proud new owner is a company with a very different image in France, more bomb-thrower than bourgeois: Google.

title: Upfronts: NBC Bets on Talent Shows and Scripted Series
description: 2:52 p.m. | Updated NBC, hoping to rebound from almost a decade of conspicuous failure, will count heavily on its lineup of talent competitions to set up a new season packed with 12 new scripted series.

title: A Sports Executive Leaves the Safety of His Shadow Life
description: Last month, in a Midtown office adorned with sports memorabilia, two longtime friends met for a private talk. David Stern, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, sipped his morning coffee, expecting to be asked for career advice. Across from him sat Rick Welts, the president and chief executive of the Phoenix Suns, who had come to New York not to discuss careers, but to say, finally, I am gay.

title: The French Reaction to I.M.F. Chiefs Arrest
description: The arrest of the chief of the International Monetary Fund, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, for an alleged sexual attack of a maid at a New York hotel sent tremors through the French media and blogosphere on Sunday, inspiring a mix of contempt, sympathy, expressions of national humiliation and more than a few conspiracy theories that the contender for the French presidency had been set up by his rivals.

title: A Classical Guitarist Making Herself Heard
description: The classical guitar is mostly a solitary instrument, partly because the greatest works written for it are in the solo repertory, but for practical reasons too: It is so soft-spoken that its voice easily gets lost alongside louder orchestral instruments and in the large halls where orchestras tend to play. So even though its concerto repertory has grown prodigiously since the late 1930s and is plentifully available on recordings, opportunities to hear guitarists play concertos in concert remain comparatively rare.

title: Choi Wins in Playoff After 3-Putt by Toms
description: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla.  K. J. Choi was the last man standing at the Players Championship on Sunday, winning on the first hole of sudden death with a short par putt after David Toms  who had made a 17-foot birdie putt at the 72nd hole to tie  missed a putt that was two inches shorter than Chois.

title: I.M.F. Names New Leader
description: Hours after its chief, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, was arrested in connection with the alleged sexual attack of a maid at a Midtown Manhattan hotel, the International Monetary Fund on Sunday named John Lipsky as acting managing director.

title: This Week Panel
description: Basically, what Digby said.

title: Money 1937 (Slightly Wonkish)
description: A followup on my note on monetarist pathos: Ive been rereading Friedman and Schwartz, and its striking just how much the debate in 1936-7 paralleled the debate now.

title: Resistance and Desire, With a Little Mud Wrestling
description: For the choreographer Nai-Ni Chen, her piece Dragons on the Wall (Tianji) doesnt have much to do with mythical, fire-breathing creatures. Shes more focused on what the dragon can symbolize: individual freedom. As she writes in the program notes, a dragon is about power and tremendous energy.

title: E.U. Panel to Propose Tighter Data Protection
description: BERLIN  The European Commissions advisory panel on data protection plans this week to urge governments in the European Union to treat the geographic location of cellphone users as personal data, deserving of the highest level of privacy protection.

title: Gingrich Calls G.O.P.s Medicare Plan Too Radical
description: WASHINGTON  Days after formally announcing his candidacy for the 2012 Republican presidential nomination, Newt Gingrich on Sunday sharply criticized a plan by House Republicans that would drastically overhaul Medicare, the federal health care program for retirees.

title: Hollywoods Box-Office Slump Continues
description: LOS ANGELES Hollywood still couldnt shake its box-office slump, as Thor, the top performer for a second weekend, posted $34.5 million in North American tickets sales for Marvel and Paramount Pictures, down 34 percent from $52 million on the same weekend last year for Iron Man 2, another Marvel-Paramount action fantasy that was also in its second week. Thor, starring Chris Hemsworth, above, has had $119.3 million in domestic ticket sales to date.

title: Ahead of Schedule, Indians Rock Again
description: CLEVELAND  Two flags hang from each lamppost on Ontario Street here, outside the home of the best team in baseball. On one side is a head shot of a smiling Cleveland Indians player. On the other is a photograph of that player shaking hands with a fan.

title: Evolution, and a Definitive Endpoint
description: Titles of concert programs can be misleading. Take The Evolution of the Symphony, as the conductor Kent Nagano called the program he presented with the Montreal Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on Saturday night, the final concert in the first Spring for Music festival. This sounds like the title of a music history course in college. But the actual program, which alternated performances of Bachs keyboard sinfonias, played by the pianist Angela Hewitt, with works by Gabrieli, Webern, Stravinsky and Beethoven, was more subversive than that drab thematic heading suggested.

title: Broadway Union Takes On Priscilla Over Music
description: In a bid to protect jobs, the Broadway musicians union is waging an unusually aggressive, political-style campaign against the new musical Priscilla Queen of the Desert in hopes of undercutting the use of recorded music during live theatrical performances.

title: Foodies vs. Techies
description: Forget James Beard and Julia Child. When it comes to American cookery, Im for their foe: Poppy Cannon, food editor of Ladies Home Journal and House Beautiful and much-mocked author of The Can-Opener Cookbook.

title: The Indians Manny Acta: Follow Me
description: CLEVELAND  The Cleveland Indians finished last in the majors in attendance last season, which is where they are now. But they have tried hard to recruit more fans and create a sense of closeness between the community and the players.

title: An Accomplished Premiere, Served Along With Other Flourishes
description: The generous breadth of taste shown by New York Theater Ballet with its Signatures series is good for New Yorks whole dance scene. This weekend at the Florence Gould Hall it showed pieces by Frederick Ashton, Merce Cunningham and Antony Tudor  three of the 20th centurys supreme choreographers  as well as a world premiere by the British choreographer Richard Alston. Larger than the excellence of any one work here, which is saying much, was the stylistic diversity of the program. Ive been grateful for this company before; Ive never admired it more than on this occasion.

title: Getting a Slice of LimeWires Pie
description: The music industry scored a victory against online piracy last week by winning a $105 million settlement against the file-sharing network LimeWire. But where will that money go? And will any of it end up with the artists whose work was illegally downloaded?

title: Eyes on the Bermuda Bowl
description: The semifinals of the open trial to pick the second United States team for this years Bermuda Bowl world championship were slated to end late on Sunday night in Henderson, Nev.

title: Housewives, Sure, but What Makes Them Real?
description: So many questions with no clear answers. Does a significant chunk of the universe really consist of dark matter, and why cant we detect it? Is free will real or just a carefully orchestrated divine illusion? Who is still watching The Real Housewives of New Jersey, one of the most idiotic shows on television?

title: Renovations That Seek to Put Film Out Front
description: People have long joked about the challenge of how to find the Film Society of Lincoln Center.

title: At Cannes, Synergy but Not Consensus
description: CANNES, France  There may not have been consensus by Day 4 of the Cannes Film Festival  no movie has yet been universally loved, loathed or violently debated  but the critics have staked out their positions and fired up their thumbs. The British are keen on the British film We Need to Talk About Kevin, Lynne Ramsays drama about an American mother and her psycho son, while the French are less impressed. The reviewer at Cahiers du Cinma anointed it with an unsmiley face in a trade magazine, a perfect representation of what sometimes seems to be the default critical attitude here.

title: Monday: Like the Best Straight in Poker
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  Your mileage may vary, but I knew I was going to be having a good puzzle day when this one opened at 1 Across with the word SCRUM. Im not sure why it put me in such a good mood, but its a fun word.

title: Skype-Style Calls Force Wireless Carriers to Adapt
description: Today, long-winded talkers need to worry about running out of minutes on their cellphone plans. But someday there will be no minutes to run out of  just megabytes.

title: Turner, the Second Baseman Come Lately, Breaks Out
description: HOUSTON  Justin Turner, the Mets surging second baseman, is playing well enough that on Sunday, Mets Manager Terry Collins heaped his highest praise on him.

title: Her Folksy Parlor, Crowded With Family and Friends
description: When the Canadian songwriter Kate McGarrigle died on Jan. 18, 2010, she left behind an extended musical family and a quietly magnificent catalog. Both were at the center of A Celebration of Kate McGarrigle, tribute concerts on Thursday and Friday nights at Town Hall.

title: Voices From the Buses on the Road to Civil Rights
description: The filmmaker Stanley Nelson has a stunning accomplishment in Freedom Riders, a documentary that chronicles a crucial, devastating episode of the civil rights movement, an episode whose gruesome visuals impinged on the perception of American liberty around the world. Commemorating the 50th anniversary of the freedom rides, the film (to be shown Monday on PBS) is a story of ennobled youth and noxious hatred, of decided courage and inexplicable brutality. In May 1961 the Congress of Racial Equality sought to challenge the segregation of interstate travel on public transport and sent forth activists, both black and white, and many of them students, on a bus journey through the South, where they were received with violence that law enforcers refused to tame.

title: Comedian Who Raps, or Rapper?
description: Donald Glover was part of a comedy troupe that became famous for making viral videos, which earned him a job as a sitcom writer, which he abandoned before landing a spot as a sitcom star, which hes now leveraged into a side career in music.

title: A Military Posts Secrets: Espionage, Not Aliens
description: At the start of Area 51, Annie Jacobsens cauldron-stirring book about Americas most mysterious military installation, Ms. Jacobsen offers a passing glimpse of a large-headed little gray space alien being interrogated by scientists in white coats. This is both a tease and a distraction. Yes, Ms. Jacobsen will eventually address the U.F.O. issue with which conspiracy theorists eagerly associate Area 51, but her book is not science fiction. Its much more levelheaded. It is an assertive account, revelatory but also mystifying, of the long-hidden United States weaponry and espionage programs to which she says Area 51 is home. (Some say Area 51 is home to nothing, because it does not officially exist.)

title: Web Critics Sum It All Up in a Word
description: The online review, long the default means on the Internet to express support for a local business, has been eclipsed by Facebooks one-click Like button.

title: Footnotes
description: Georgiana Pickett has been named the new executive director of the Baryshnikov Arts Center, the center has announced. Ms. Pickett has been the executive director of 651 ARTS at the Brooklyn Academy of Music since 2004. She replaces Stanford Makishi, a former dancer, who resigned in February. ... The director Darko Tresnjak (The Merchant of Venice) will take over as artistic director of the Hartford Stage theater company in Connecticut in July, Playbill.com reported. He will succeed Michael Wilson, who has served for the past 13 years and is to retire in June.

title: New Victory to Open With The Little Prince
description: The New Victory Theater will open its new season on Oct. 1 with a show starring new creations from an Avenue Q puppet maker. The show, The Little Prince, an adaptation of the French fable by Antoine de Saint-Exupry, written by Rick Cummins and John Scoullar, will feature life-size puppets designed by Michael Schupbach, an alumnus of the Jim Henson Muppet Workshop. The season continues Oct. 13 with the United States premiere of White, a contemporary work from the Catherine Wheels Theater Company, of Scotland, that was a 2010 Edinburgh Festival Fringe award-winner last year; and the Reduced Shakespeare Companys Complete World of Sports (abridged), beginning on Oct. 21. Other highlights will include Untapped!, a dance and rock review from Australia (Nov. 11), and Bai Xi, a circus show from Shanghai (Dec. 2).

title: Durant Seizes Control for Thunder
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  No matter where he spotted up Sunday, Kevin Durant was going to hold the ball and the outcome of Game 7 in his hands. The Oklahoma City Thunder, after all, was built around him when it moved here in 2008 from Seattle, only to settle into its new home with a 3-29 start.

title: How Drudge Has Stayed on Top
description: For most big news Web sites, about 60 percent of the traffic is homegrown, people who come directly to the site by dint of a bookmark or typing in www.latimes.com or www.huffingtonpost.com. The other critical 40 percent comes by referrals, the links that are the source of drive-by traffic, new readers and heat-seekers on a particular story.

title: Alibaba and Yahoo Try to Make Up
description: SHANGHAI  It was an unexpected dispute over two continents that floored technology investors.

title: Lincoln Captured!
description: Despite recent rumors to the contrary, Lincoln displayed no vampiric powers in his early presidency. But it is true that he could appear many places at the same time, thanks to a chemical process that seemed to borrow as much from the dark arts as from science.

title: Obama and Immigration Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Road, but at Home
description: CHICAGO  Dwyane Wade was a Chicago kid and a Bulls fan long before he was a Miami Heat star, but his hometown loyalties stop at the baseline.

title: Options for Bringing Down the Cost of Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: The Shirtless Congressman
description: To the Editor:

title: A Rule Gives as It Takes Away
description: Goldman Sachs is lobbying to weaken limits on proprietary trading imposed by the so-called Volcker Rule that was part of last years financial overhaul. But like most hastily written legislation, the rule has unintended effects that are only now becoming apparent. One may make the business of managing private equity investments even more lucrative for the likes of Goldman.

title: Gay Marriage
description: To the Editor:

title: Tax Stock Transactions
description: To the Editor:

title: Forty Years After a Dream Mile, a Harsh Reality for Track
description: The news that the Millrose Games are leaving Madison Square Garden after 97 years to relocate uptown to the 168th Street armory reminds us of how indifferent we are to track and field. And yet, in a coincidence of timing, we remember, too, that we were not always this way. Fridays announcement came almost exactly 40 years after an event that placed the sport, however briefly, front and center in the consciousness of the American public.

title: New York Theater Ballet
description: Photos from the companys performance at Florence Gould Hall.

title: Dragons on the Wall
description: Photos from the Nai-Ni Chen Dance Companys performance.

title: Doric Wilson, Playwright and Mainstay of Gay Theater, Dies at 72
description: Doric Wilson, a playwright whose satirical, wisecracking works are considered bricks in the foundations of the Off Off Broadway and gay theater movements, died May 7 at his home in Manhattan. He was 72.

title: Homegrown Drones
description: A growing group of hobbyists and engineers are designing and selling do-it-yourself drones of near military caliber.

title: Secrecy Breeds Curiosity Over an ESPN Expos
description: Inside James Andrew Millers black messenger bag was potential sports-world dynamite: the 770-page oral history of ESPN that he has written with Tom Shales.

title: In This Sky, the Planes Fly Alone
description: BOULDER, Colo.  A father of five and a professed geek, Chris Anderson, editor in chief of Wired magazine, is always looking for child-friendly activities that could, he hopes, inculcate his children with techie sensibilities.

title: Former Galleon Employee Is Next Target in Inquiry
description: Among the more intriguing spectators at the trial of Raj Rajaratnam was Zvi Goffer, a former Galleon employee. His interest was more than just curiosity about his former boss.

title: Before It Can Rebuild, Japanese Town Must Survive
description: OTSUCHI, Japan  The crumpled cars have reddened with rust, and spring rains and a warming sun have left the ashes and mud hardened into an earthen plate of armor. But Satoshi Watanabe still comes every day to pick through the charred debris that was once his home, searching for the remains of his 2-month-old infant daughter.

title: Is College Worth It? Answers From Presidents and the Public
description: The Pew Research Center has just released a report incorporating two surveys  one of 2,142 adults 18 or older; the other of 1,055 college presidents  each centered on the question, Is college worth it?

title: TV Networks Expect a Jump in Spending on Commercials
description: Fox is the only television network that broadcasts Glee, but just about every network is gleeful as this week begins.

title: United Arab Emirates Confirms Hiring Blackwater Founders Firm
description: The United Arab Emirates confirmed on Sunday that it had hired a company run by Erik Prince, the billionaire founder of Blackwater Worldwide, to provide operational, planning and training support to its military. But it gave no details of the companys project to build a foreign mercenary battalion for the Emirati government.

title: When New York Was Ready to Rumble
description: A two-minute history of the glory days of pro wrestling in New York City, from the memory and photographs of Al (Samson) Vass, a veteran referee.

title: Despite Restrictions, Microblogs Catch on in China
description: SHANGHAI  Wang Yin, a 24-year-old graduate student at the elite Tsinghua University in Beijing, constantly uses Sina Weibo, Chinas Twitter-like social networking site.

title: Varitek Understands Posadas Distress
description: The many parallels in the two players careers make comparisons inevitable.

title: The Wrong Reasons for Same-Sex Marriage
description: Forest Grove, Ore.

title: Afghanistan May Be Open to New Path, Kerry Says
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Osama bin Ladens death will allow a new phase in the United States relationship with Afghanistan, one that could include reductions in troops and spending, Senator John Kerry said while visiting here on Sunday.

title: Support for Antipiracy Bill
description: The entertainment industry threw its weight behind a proposed law that would give law enforcement officials and others new authority to move against Internet sites that traffic without permission in copyrighted material.

title: Patience, Not Punishment, for Pakistan
description: Islamabad, Pakistan

title: Internet Filters Set Off Protests Around Turkey
description: ISTANBUL  Thousands of people in more than 30 cities around Turkey took to the streets on Sunday to protest a new system of filtering the Internet that opponents consider censorship.

title: Murray Handwerker, 89, Dies; Made Nathans More Famous
description: Murray Handwerker, who transformed his fathers Brooklyn hot dog business, Nathans Famous, into a celebrated national fast-food chain, died Saturday at his home in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. He was 89.

title: Wallace McCain Dies at 81; Fed the World Frozen Fries
description: Wallace McCain, who helped create the worlds largest frozen French fry maker, lost one of Canadas most public family feuds and then built another major food company specializing in cold cuts and sliced bread, died on Friday night in Toronto. He was 81.

title: After Weak Season, Networks Strive for Fresh Ideas
description: Acknowledging that the crop of new television programs last year was almost a complete washout, the networks are spending big this year to promise, if not genuine excitement, at least something different.

title: A Day After a Prideful Outburst, Posada Apologizes
description: Before he could start his workday on Sunday, Jorge Posada took time to reflect on perhaps the worst day of his decorated career, and realized that he needed to apologize to Joe Girardi. In the managers office at Yankee Stadium, they had a conversation with a far friendlier tenor than on Saturday, when Posada removed himself from the lineup an hour before the Yankees game against Boston, feeling slighted that he had been dropped to ninth in the batting order.

title: Eurovision Joy Deflects Cares for a While
description: BAKU, Azerbaijan  For three hours on Sunday morning, as the nightclub around him filled up with dry ice and stiletto heels, 28-year-old Ziya Rahbarli watched the gigantic screen with the gravity of a social scientist.

title: Economic Reports for the Week Ahead
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include housing starts for April and industrial production and capacity utilization for April(Tuesday); and weekly jobless claims, existing home sales for April, the Philadelphia Fed manufacturing index for May, and leading economic indicators for April (Thursday).

title: Senator and Granddaughter on Two Sides, but One Stage, in Debate on Gay Marriage
description: Rubn Daz Sr., the Bronx state senator, Pentecostal minister and steadfast opponent of same-sex marriage, gathered his flock on Sunday for a rally on the steps of the monumental Art Deco courthouse in the Bronx, serenaded by church bands and an ear-piercing soundtrack of Latin song.

title: Space Shuttle Endeavour Is Readied, Once Again, for Its Final Launching
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  NASA made final preparations for the launching of the shuttle Endeavour on a mission to the International Space Station, confident that it had fixed an electrical problem that grounded the spacecraft two weeks earlier.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Mondays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Tuesday.

title: Managing at the Intersection of Then and Now
description: Joe Girardi saw this coming. Not this, specifically, because no one could have imagined the proud Jorge Posada asking out of a game with a bruised ego. But when Girardi became the Yankees manager before the 2008 season, he understood what he would inherit if he stayed long enough.

title: Salute to a Movie Producer
description: LOS ANGELES  Swearsies.

title: British Commander Says Libya Fight Must Expand
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Two months into the NATO bombing campaign against Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis forces, Britains top military commander has said that the Libyan leader could remain clinging to power unless NATO broadened its bombing targets to include the countrys infrastructure.

title: Money Troubles Take Personal Toll in Greece
description: ATHENS  His face contorted with anguish, Anargyros D. recounted how he had lost everything in the aftermath of the Greek economic collapse  the food-processing factory founded by his father 30 years ago, his house, his car, his Rolex, his pride and now, he said, his will to live.

title: Cuts Could Stall Sluggish Courts at Every Turn
description: Extensive budget cutbacks being rolled out in New York States courts are expected to add new delays to practically every facet of the judicial process, from the moment a suspect is brought in to be charged until the case is heard in court, and onward into appeals.

title: America Held Hostage
description: Six months ago President Obama faced a hostage situation. Republicans threatened to block an extension of middle-class tax cuts unless Mr. Obama gave in and extended tax cuts for the rich too. And the president essentially folded, giving the G.O.P. everything it wanted.

title: Mets Travel Home With a Smile
description: HOUSTON  Although the Mets are still tied for last place in the National League East, and still have a losing record (19-21), they were feeling pretty good about themselves as they left Texas on Sunday night.

title: Teeing It Up for Their Clubs, Not Their Feet
description: BIRMINGHAM, Ala.  Golf was going to form a wedge between Al Del Greco and his son Trey. The younger Del Greco was convinced it would as he nervously rehearsed what he planned to say to his father, a former N.F.L. place-kicker.

title: A Requiem for Huckabee
