description: Most candidates for the highest office in the land spend months, if not years, currying favor with the rich and powerful: glad-handing at fund-raising dinners, schmoozing in mansions, pressing the flesh in Aspen and Manhattan and Nob Hill.

title: Going Back on the Deal
description: Last year, Republicans refused to renew unemployment benefits unless the high-end Bush-era tax cuts were preserved. After the White House agreed to keep the tax cuts through 2012, they agreed to extend federal jobless benefits through 2011. Now, they want to renege.

title: Police Seek Evidence From I.M.F. Chief on Sex Attack
description: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the leader of the International Monetary Fund, spent most of Sunday at the Manhattan Special Victims Unit in East Harlem as prosecutors sought additional evidence, including possible DNA evidence on his skin or beneath his fingernails, to bolster allegations that he had sexually assaulted a maid in a $3,000-a-night suite at a Midtown hotel, officials said.

title: Syrian Border Violence May Hold Message for Israel
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  For 37 years the border between Israel and Syria, still technically at war, has proven as quiet as any of the Arab-Israeli frontiers silenced by peace agreements. On Sunday, it was not, and the tumult on the Golan Heights could augur a new phase of the uprising against President Bashar al-Assad and the web of international relations he is navigating.

title: Tunisia Is Uneasy Over Party of Islamists
description: TUNIS  Accused as subversives or terrorists, they bore the repressive brunt of the Tunisian dictators reign  two decades of torture, prison or exile.

title: Despite City Crackdown, Immigrants Still Are Often Cheated by Job Agencies
description: Cristina Rivas, 49, an immigrant from El Salvador, thought her one-year search for steady work had finally come to an end. A Queens employment agency that she had paid $120 said it had found her a job as a waitress at an upscale restaurant. She needed only to show up.

title: Governor Cuomos List
description: Gov. Andrew Cuomo of New York began barnstorming the state last week to rally support for three of his campaign promises: ethics reform, same-sex marriage and, unfortunately, his misguided cap on property taxes. He advised voters upstate to tell their representatives: pass these bills or dont come home.

title: The Rush to Secret Money
description: President Obama should waste no more time and sign an executive order requiring government contractors to disclose any checks they write to the newly legal troughs of secret campaign donations. House Republicans, who in the past loudly supported such transparency, are holding hearings to push the absurd claim that Mr. Obama is aiming to violate donors free speech.

title: Remembering the Freedom Riders
description: Fifty years ago this month, a group of black and white volunteers boarded two public buses in the District of Columbia to travel into the Deep South, where segregated waiting rooms, restrooms, lunch counters and other indignities were a fact of life despite Supreme Court rulings striking down segregation in interstate travel.

title: Commuters Feel Pinch as Christie Tightens
description: As a standard-bearer of fiscal conservatism, Gov. title: Idea Rebounds: Automatic Cuts to Curb Deficits
description: WASHINGTON  Among the highest-profile laws of recent decades was a failed one: the 1985 deficit-reduction statute called Gramm-Rudman-Hollings for its Senate sponsors. Intended to force a balanced budget, it spawned budget gimmicks and did little to cut deficits, provoking one of its authors, Senator Ernest F. Hollings, to say, Im filing for divorce on grounds of infidelity and irreconcilable differences.

title: At School for the Disabled, High Pay Leads to State Pressure and Now Layoffs

Without a doubt, Ms. Cervasio said, the best thing that ever happened to Gina was getting into the Henry Viscardi School, one of 11 state-supported public schools for the severely disabled in New York.

title: Many Eyes on a Fight in Nassau County Over a G.O.P. Proposal for Redistricting
description: MINEOLA, N.Y.  Even by the raucous standards of Nassau County politics, it was a wild day. Almost 200 residents, mostly minorities, trooped into the county office building for 10 hours last Monday to testify, shout, wave placards and threaten to sue over a redistricting plan being rushed through in record speed by the Legislatures Republican majority.

title: The Unreality of Being a Celebrity
description: Someday, someone will write a definitive phenomenological study of what its like now to be famous, although a simple infographic would probably just about cover it. This Is Your Consciousness on Fame would be the heading, just above arrows representing a positive feedback loop and captions reading: Noncelebrities become convinced that celebrity dwells on a different plane of existence ... which increases the magnitude of unreality, solipsism and alienation already being experienced by celebrity; celebrity succumbs to exponentially alienated and surreal view of reality and with behavior to match ... which further increases the fascination exerted on noncelebrities; celebrity builds permanent residence on a different plane of existence, applies for passport.

LED lamps have only been able to emit light equivalent to a 60-watt standard bulb.

title: Credit Where Its Due: A Simpsons Spelling Lesson
description: There wouldnt seem to be many milestones left for The Simpsons to achieve after 22 seasons, but we think we saw a first for the show on Sunday night: Bart Simpson apologizing for a mistake. Though Barts chalkboard gag in the opening credits of the show is usually reserved for a throwaway one-liner or a joke about current events, The Simpsons used the space to make good with the comedian Kristen Schaal, whose name had been misspelled in the closing credits of last weeks episode. (There are many worthy reasons for The Simpsons to stay on good terms with Ms. Schaal, including the fact that its the right thing to do and, as a voice performer on the Fox animated series Bobs Burgers, shes a next-door neighbor of the show.)

title: Geography, Income and Religion
description: In response to my column on religion and income (and my follow-up post on Economix), several readers have asked whether geography plays a big role. As one reader wrote, Jews (and Asians) live primarily on the coasts, where above average incomes are earned (and needed). The implication here is that Jews and Hindus arent the most affluent religions largely because theyre the most educated; according to this view, much of their affluence instead stems from the fact that they tend to live in expensive, high-income metropolitan areas, like New York, San Francisco, Washington and Boston.

title: A Rendezvous With Manet in Paris
description: PARIS  Before I do my Torquemada routine, lets begin on a positive note with an all-time favorite, that gorgeous redhead in the woods. Shes a shocker, even now, stark naked and turned to meet our gaze, at ease beside those two stiff, fully dressed men at a picnic. Something seems to have distracted her outside the pictures frame, our arrival maybe, or something behind us; its hard to tell. Her look has cracked the wall between her and us. Shes in our space.

title: The Morning Line: Whats in a Name?
description: Today, much of the news media plays the Name Game with the horses likely to be entered in the Preakness. The Baltimore Sun explains how horses get their names and asks Shouldnt there be a hall of fame somewhere for thoroughbreds whose accomplishments are few, but whose names are marvelous? Apparently, Yakahickamickadola may be the winner of the oddest  if not greatest  horse name ever.

title: MoMA to Pay $31.2 Million for Folk Art Museum Building
description: The Museum of Modern Art will pay $31.2 million for the American Folk Art Museums building, according to a notice the folk art museum filed to its bondholders. The two museums announced the planned sale last week but had not disclosed the price. The folk art museum took on $32 million of debt to construct the building on West 53rd Street, but attendance never met expectations, and after sustaining investment losses in the financial crisis, the museum defaulted on its debt. The folk art museum had said that the sale would allow it to retire its debt, as well as pay fees to lawyers and consultants. The numbers are close: As of June 30, 2009, the museum owed a principal of $29,945,000 on the bonds.

title: Even James Bond Can Use Help Sometimes
description: BECAUSE of the sensitive nature of my work, I do face-to-face meetings. That makes my flight schedule brutal. Its not uncommon for me to fly from Miami to New York City on Monday, go to Los Angeles on Tuesday, Moscow on Thursday and then back to Miami for my sons lacrosse or football games on Saturday.

title: In Women, Hernias May Be Hidden Agony
description: Laura Sweet was an active, upbeat 42-year-old saleswoman living in Santa Monica, Calif., when the agony first started  debilitating, flaring pains in her pelvis that lasted for days and recurred periodically. The discomfort resulted in many visits to the emergency room, referrals to various specialists, wrong diagnoses and a daily cocktail of painkillers.

title: CBS and Boston Rob Win on Sunday Night
description: CBSs Survivor: Redemption Island topped the ratings on Sunday as 13.1 million viewers tuned in to the reality shows two-hour season finale, according to Nielsens estimates. After three previous tries, Rob Mariano, a k a Boston Rob, was finally victorious, winning this seasons $1 million prize. CBS ranked No. 1 for the night, leading at 7 p.m. with 60 Minutes (12 million) as well as at 10, following the Survivor finale with a reunion special (11.3 million). ABC placed second for the night, garnering 10 million viewers from 9 to 11 for the season finale of Desperate Housewives. NBC was third with Dateline at 7 (5.2 million), Minute to Win It at 8 (3.5 million) and The Celebrity Apprentice from 9 to 11 (6.6 million). Fox and its animated comedy lineup finished fourth.

title: The Logic Behind Nasdaqs Longshot Bid for NYSE
description: There is a technical term in deal-making to describe a bid like the one Nasdaq made for NYSE Euronext. Its called taking a flier.

title: Does Late-Night Eating Cause Weight Gain?
description: THE FACTS

title: The Caucus | A Fight Over the Debt Limit
description: The Times's John Harwood and Jackie Calmes on Timothy F. Geithner's message to Congress about the government reaching the debt limit on Monday.

title: Video: Geithner Warns Congress Over the Debt Limit
description: Timothy F. Geithner told Congress that the government would have reached the debt limit on Monday, but for what he called extraordinary measures. John Harwood and Jackie Calmes discuss.

title: Leeks: Onion Flavor, Without the Onions
description: Recently John Lyons, proprietor of the Woven Garden in Los Angeles and my gardening guru, brought over an armful of leeks that had just been harvested from his vegetable garden, their untrimmed greens streaming like long ribbons.

title: Russian Billionaire Announces Plan for Political Party
description: MOSCOW Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the Russian billionaire and principal owner of the New Jersey Nets basketball team, announced Monday that he would lead a liberal Russian political party with close ties to the Kremlin.

title: Search Allowed if Police Hear Evidence Being Destroyed
description: WASHINGTON  The police do not need a warrant to enter a home if they smell burning marijuana, knock loudly, announce themselves and hear what they think is the sound of evidence being destroyed, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday in an 8-to-1 decision.

title: Vain Glorious | Jemma Kidds Secrets to a Brilliant Body
description: Jemma Kidd has been busy: the 36-year-old former model runs the Jemma Kidd Makeup School in London, looks after two successful cosmetics lines  JK for Target, available at the mass retailer, and her makeup academy, for which she makes the QVC rounds  and last year, had twins with Arthur Wellesley, the Earl of Mornington (when she married him in 2005, it made her an official countess). All of this left her feeling, understandably, sluggish, until she adopted the Metabolic Balance Diet. Its this German diet. They take your blood and they analyze your hormone levels, vitamin levels, whats right for you, your body type, your height, your weight. They analyze everything and give you this big list of what you can and cannot eat, Kidd explained while previewing her summer and fall collections. But the main rules are one type of protein for each meal, youve got to wait five hours between each meal, no snacking, an apple a day. The first thing you eat should be protein  its all about leveling your blood sugar and your hormones. Weight loss is the third thing. Its detox for the first two weeks  youre not allowed any fat. Ive lost 23 pounds since January, 15 of them in the first 10 days. The svelte Kidd was in New York a couple of weeks ago for the Metropolitan Museum of Art Costume Institute Gala (she wore McQueen), where she was privy to some testimonials to one of her Target products, Show Stopper Year-Round Body Glow. Its organically grown into quite a successful little product, she said. I had five people at the Met ball come up to me and say, My makeup artist put it on me. Its fabulous!

title: On Our Radar: A Satellite Tour of a Threatened Rain Forest
description: A computer illustration created by the wildlife activist group WWF-Indonesia using Google Earth provides a tour of Sumatran rain forest areas at risk of destruction by logging companies and palm oil producers. The animation focuses on Bukit Tigapuluh, a hilly region that provides habitat to endangered tigers, elephants, orangutans and other rare species. Camera trap footage from this area released by WWF this month showed a dozen tigers living in a logging concession. [Yale Environment 360]

title: Companys Arenas Leave Cities With Big Problems
description: RIO RANCHO, N.M.  The plan sounded great during the real estate boom: build a midsize arena, stuff it with sports, music acts and monster trucks and create a centerpiece for the new city center being developed on a dusty mesa here, 20 miles north of downtown Albuquerque.

title: Slow Pace of Flooding Might Lower Its Crest
description: ATLANTA  Floodwater that is moving slower than anticipated and a conservative hand on the floodgates is easing some of the concern in a nervous Louisiana.

title: Israel Leader Outlines Points Before U.S. Trip
description: JERUSALEM  Days before Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is to meet with President Obama, he laid out his principles Monday for accepting a Palestinian state, showing greater flexibility on territory but still pursuing a far more hawkish approach than any Palestinian leader is likely to accept.

title: An Online 20th-Century Playlist From the Library of Congress
description: Listen up. Now you can tune into the National Jukebox, the Library of Congress new online collection of popular recorded music, monologues and more from the early decades of the 20th century. At the moment, the Jukebox includes more than 10,000 recordings on 78-r.p.m. discs made by the Victor Talking Machine Company from 1901 to 1925, but the library plans to expand the collection regularly. You can hear the opera star Enrico Caruso, Tin Pan Alley and Irving Berlins Broadway hits. The site enables you to create your own playlist. The collection also include hundreds of offensive, though historically significant, ethnic, religious and racial characterizations that come with a warning label. There is also a detailed explanation of the painstaking process of transferring these old discs into digital recordings.

title: Rahmbo No More: Call Him Mr. Mayor
description: Rahm Emanuel, who served as President Obamas first White House chief of staff, completes his latest political transformation on Monday, taking office as the next mayor of Chicago. Monica Davey, the Times Chicago bureau chief, gives a full rundown. Read more

title: With World Support, an Ambitious Plan Would Vaccinate 90 Percent of Infants
description: Haiti, which did a poor job of vaccinating its children even before the 2010 earthquake, has come up with a plan to immunize 90 percent of its newborns by 2015, the Pan American Health Organization announced last week.

title: Once a Bustling Automobile Row Anchor, Now Empty
description: It was a dignified mainstay of Automobile Row, the line of glittery showrooms and automobile-related offices that stretched up Broadway from the West 50s to somewhere north of Columbus Circle. Its tire-company name lingered when new tenants moved in, among them a studio where stars like Duke Ellington made recordings.

title: Yankees Five-Game Home Slide Was Low Point of 2009
description: For those wondering when the Yankees last lost five consecutive games at home, the answer is: not that long ago.

title: A Car Collection Gets a Rare Showing
description: Malcom Pray was a car dealer in Greenwich, Conn., for about 25 years and started collecting cars in the early 1960s. Now he has more than 50 and keeps most of them in two garages in Banksville, N.Y., just across the border from Greenwich. On Sunday, he opened up those garages for a fund-raiser.

title: Video: Rob Lowe on Writing His Memoir
description: The actor Rob Lowe recently visited The Times to talk about his memoir, Stories I Only Tell My Friends. A video of his conversation with Sam Tanenhaus, the editor of the Book Review, is embedded above. Carina Chocanos review of Mr. Lowes book  and Shirley MacLaines Im Over All That is online today. Also, Janet Maslins review of Stories.

title: Politics on Film: Have Knife, Will Use It
description: In Washington, Chris Lehane, a Democratic consultant, is known  and this is a compliment in that world  as a fervent advocate of the dark arts of politics: the cutthroat, destroy-your-enemies, do-what-it-takes-to win approach to political campaigns. In the last five days, it always comes down to a knife fight in a telephone booth, Mr. Lehane said, commenting on the final days of the 2008 presidential campaign.

title: Lester Lave  An Appreciation
description: David Keith, a University of Calgary researcher focused on carbon, climate and energy technology and policy, sent a note last week alerting me to the death of Lester B. Lave, an environmental economist at Carnegie Mellon University who had been a mentor, colleague and friend of his.

title: Southern Swell
description: Now that Costa Ricas best breaks have been overrun, Nicaragua is luring wave riders with low-key surf camps and undiscovered beaches. Popoyo, on the southern Pacific coast, has the most consistent barrel, along with hotels like the Popoyo Beach Lodge (popoyobeachlodge.com; doubles from $55 ). But two and a half hours north of Managua and just west of the town of Chinandega lies the countrys undeveloped northern Pacific coast  and dozens of breaks so new that many dont have names. This is where the pro surfer and model Holly Beck set up her camp, Suave Dulce (surfwithhollybeck.com) after she stopped competing in 2008. Nicaragua, says Beck, a California native, is the ideal place to help people experience the joy of getting pushed by the ocean. Many of Becks students stay at El Coco Loco (011-505-8999-8662; elcocolocoresort.com; doubles from $100), a rustic resort near the town of Santa Maria del Mar with five palm-thatch cabanas near several surf spots. La Bahia Beach Hodel (011-505-8958-5075; labahiabeachhotel.com; doubles from $150) is a more luxurious option: four stone-and-teak casitas with outdoor showers, private pathways to one of Nicaraguas most beautiful beaches and three breaks in front of the hotel (with more nearby). Both resorts serve seafood delivered daily by local fishermen, and theres also plenty of the local catch at Al Cielo (011-505-8993-4840), a popular open-air palapa run by two French guys, with 360-degree views.

title: Nasdaq Drops N.Y.S.E. Bid
description: Nasdaq OMX Group and IntercontinentalExchange have pulled their hostile bid for the New York Stock Exchange after regulators signaled that a merger would run afoul of anti-trust regulations.

title: Designer for BMW i Subbrand Takes Aim at the Future of Urban Transport
description: It always gets harder to drive, said Benoit Jacob, the head designer of BMWs new i subbrand, at a panel discussion on Sunday night.

title: The Right Plastic for Perks
description: Credit card issuers have begun aggressively marketing to business travelers because they often have many of the attributes the issuers look for, like good jobs and higher incomes.

title: Neighborhood Under Water
description: Poor and low-lying communities, like Kings in Vicksburg, Miss., have been hit especially hard by the flooding Mississippi River.

title: As Bonds Appeals Verdict, Jurors Who Convicted Him Are Watching
description: Barry Bondss perjury trial was nearly eight years in the making before he was convicted last month of obstruction of justice in federal court. Yet his case, which has cost both sides millions of dollars and has dragged on since his initial indictment in 2007, is far from over.

title: Mapping Happiness: Analyzing an Interactive About a Nations Well-Being
description: This month weve been experimenting with a new Multimedia of the Week feature, and today we have a second installment.

title: Beyond the Melting Pot
description: One evening last fall I was walking through Chinatown in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, when, suddenly, in the midst of Cantonese restaurants, shops selling knockoff designer bags and food stalls hawking exotic-looking meats, I came across the wholly unexpected sight of a Hindu temple with a voluptuous gate tower: a riot of gilded idols and precious stones and wafts of thick incense.

title: Britain Set to Announce Ambitious Environmental Steps
description: BRUSSELS  Britain is poised to announce some of the worlds most ambitious goals for reducing greenhouse gas emissions  a striking example of a government committing to big environmental initiatives while also pursuing austerity measures.

title: Bridesmaids Looks at Losing a Business
description: Over the weekend, I saw Bridesmaids. The movie, with its female-driven plot, is a welcome departure from the sappy fare typically marketed to women and the comedies that put them on the sidelines. But its also an exploration of the emotions that follow the failure of a small business.

title: After 22 Years  22 Years!  K.K.R. Is Exiting Primedia
description: 7:12 p.m. | Updated

title: Jump in Revenue Helps Halve California Deficit
description: SACRAMENTO  After months of doomsday scenarios and apocalyptic warnings about cuts to California schools, parks and the police, the news from Gov. Jerry Brown on Monday was nothing short of startling: California is now expected to see $6.6 billion more in revenue over the next two years than had been expected.

title: Bloomberg Wants to Make New York No. 1 Digital City
description: The New York City of the future will offer wireless Internet access in many of its parks, make vast reserves of data available to programmers and host live chats with 311 agents, according to a plan unveiled on Monday by Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

title: Ryan Defends Medicare Proposal
description: With protesters gathered outside, Representative Paul D. Ryan, the House Budget Committee chairman, on Monday defended his Medicare proposal in a speech to the Economic Club of Chicago.

title: New CDs
description: RAPHAEL SAADIQ

title: M.R.I., 1974
description: The technology for measuring the magnetic properties of atomic nuclei goes back to the 1930s. But it took decades for scientists to put it to medical use.

title: Thwarted at Home, Nasdaq May Look Abroad
description: Now that the Nasdaq OMX Group and the IntercontinentalExchange have pulled their hostile bid for NYSE Euronext, after regulators signaled that a merger would run afoul of antitrust regulations, Nasdaq may focus on overseas targets. DealBooks Azam Ahmed speaks with Graham Bowley of The New York Times about what potential deals are next for the exchange industry.

title: 1947 Mystery That Matters Now
description: For video games, the real world is the final frontier.

title: Pursuing Imperfection in Malicks Eden
description: CANNES, France

title: Nate Silver, Guest Ethicist
description: Not long ago, the magazine published an article about how to avoid paying full price for air travel. Several readers wrote in to say the proposed method amounted to lying, and asked what I thought about the ethics of such an approach.

title: Photo Replay: May 16
description: A view of the day in sports, including a supporter for an embattled soccer official.

title: Live Blogging the Upfronts: Fox
description: The 2011-12 television network upfronts continue in New York. Walking into the Beacon Theater this afternoon, where Fox is presenting its new prime-time schedule, attendees passed life-size visages of Simon Cowell. Fox is betting that Mr. Cowells X Factor will improve its performance in the fall just like American Idol has in the winter and spring.

title: Jeter Explains Posada Comments to Yankees Officials
description: Derek Jeter had a conference call with high-ranking Yankees officials Monday afternoon to clarify comments he made Sunday in support of Jorge Posada.

title: Basque Boogie
description: The laid-back Basque town of Biarritz has been Europes surf capital since the 1950s. Yet despite the crowds and the casinos, it has retained its scruffy coolness. The Bay of Biscay provides the town with two main waves: the Plage de la Cte des Basques, a popular and consistent sandbar break; and the Grande Plage, an unpredictable, high-performance beach break up the coast. At least a dozen groups give surfing lessons, among them Jo Moraiz (011-33-6-62-76-17-24; jomoraiz.com), Frances first surf school. Biarritzs plushest beach hotel is the Htel Du Palais (011-33-5-59-41-64-00; hotel-du-palais.com; doubles from about $665), a palace-turned-hotel where Alain Ducasse worked one of his first kitchen jobs. Youre less likely to see surfers there than at one of the campgrounds on Biarritzs outskirts. A happy medium between opulence and outdoors is Htel Le Caritz (011-33-5-59-24-41-84; hotel-lecaritz-biarritz.com; doubles from $210), a handsome inn with a terrace restaurant. For the closest surf proximity, try the basic but comfortable Carlina Lodge (011-33-5-59-24-42-14; carlina.com; doubles from $190), which has direct access to the Cte des Basques. For post-surf refueling, the lovely covered market Les Halles (halles-biarritz.fr) offers outdoor fish and tapas restaurants, palpable reminders of the citys vicinity to Spain. And Le Surfing (011-33-5-59-24-78-72; lesurfingbiarritz.fr), an inviting bar and restaurant where vintage surf memorabilia serves as dcor, might be the only brasserie in town that allows sandy feet.

title: TimesCast | May 16, 2011
description: The I.M.F. chief is denied bail in a sexual assault case; some in France see a setup; French journalists unspoken rule to protect politicians privacy.

title: Vote to Name the Baby Hawk
description: Update, May 17, 4:08 p.m. | Read about the baby hawks newly bestowed name.

title: Wright Has Stress Fracture in Back
description: David Wright pulled on a maroon Virginia Tech T-shirt, jeans and running shoes, then strolled out of the Mets clubhouse at 4:40 p.m. Monday, done for the day and who knows how much longer. A half-hour earlier, the club disclosed that he had a stress fracture in his lower back.

title: Earning Power of Spider-Man Undiminished
description: Returning to Broadway after a brief hiatus to accommodate a creative overhaul, the musical Spider-Man: Turn Off the Dark earned $809,941 for five preview performances last week before mostly full audiences at the Foxwoods Theater, according to the weekly box office data released on Monday by the Broadway League.

title: For Two Hours, a Vintage Car Collector Throws Open His Garage Doors
description: When he was growing up, Malcolm Pray went to the 1939 New York Worlds Fair, where he saw a 1937 Delahaye. He promptly fell in love, and 25 years later, when he found that very car for sale, he bought it. That was the first purchase in a vintage-car collection that today consists of more than 50 vehicles.

title: Obama and Graduates Cheer for Each Other
description: The graduating class of Booker T. Washington High School in Memphis was getting a last-minute pep talk from its principal, Alisha Kiner, on Monday, just before the ceremony began, when an out-of-town visitor dropped by to offer his own words of encouragement.

title: One Death Provides New Life for Many
description: Mirtala Garcia laid a hand on Sebastiao Lourencos chest, then pressed her ear there for a moment.

title: Nate Silver, Guest Ethicist
description: Not everyone was pleased with Nate Silvers Acts of Mild Subversion column about hidden-city ticketing, a trick to save money on airfares. In fact, several readers  who saw the tactic as tantamount to lying  sought out the views of The Timess resident ethicist, Ariel Kaminer. So Ms. Kaminer, over at the The 6th Floor blog, asked Nate to comment on the ethical underpinnings of hidden-city ticketing.

title: Parade of Bodies and Tame Exoticism
description: When a dance companys identity is predicated on its national or ethnic identity, the choreographic traps it can fall into are precipitous and deep. Its a problem that the Danza Contempornea de Cuba, currently at the Joyce Theater, shares with, among others, Ballet Hispanico, Dance Brazil and, to some extent, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater.

title: Tunes to Help Gray Skies Clear Up
description: Ur-show tunes belted by a brassy show-tune voice: that describes Herman on Herman ...With a Touch of Merman, the program of Jerry Herman songs being performed by Peggy Herman (she is not related to the composer) at the Metropolitan Room. The show, which has the distinction of being directed by Tommy Tune (with Peter Glebo), exemplifies a pep-for-peps-sake Broadway musical atavism.

title: P.R. Guru Linda Robinson Joins BlackRock
description: After 25 years with her public relations firm, Robinson Lerer & Montgomery, Linda G. Robinson has left to join BlackRock as a senior managing director and the global head of marketing and communications.

title: With Huckabee Out, Whither Iowa?
description: The decision by Mike Huckabee to forgo another presidential bid means that the former governor of Arkansas wont be seeking back-to-back victories in the the Iowa caucuses, and leaves the first-in-the-nation presidential contest without a clear Republican front-runner.

title: Democrats Take Aim at G.O.P. Freshmen on Medicare
description: Members of the House are back home in their districts this week, and in the case of some Republicans, protesters are along for the ride.

title: Critics' Picks: 'Umbrellas of Cherbourg'
description: A.O. Scott looks back at Jacques Demy's 1964 musical with Catherine Deneuve.

title: Humm and Guidara of Eleven Madison Park Will Run Restaurants in the NoMad Hotel
description: Daniel Humm and Will Guidara, the executive chef and manager of Eleven Madison Park, will be running the lounges and restaurants in the NoMad hotel, which is being developed on Broadway and 28th Street.

title: French Shocked by I.M.F. Chiefs Perp Walk
description: As our colleagues Steven Erlanger and Katrin Bennhold report, The arrest in New York of one of Frances leading global figures and a possible next president, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, on charges of attempted rape produced an earthquake of shock, outrage, disbelief and embarrassment throughout France on Sunday.

title: Senate Posturing Kills Small Business Investment Research Renewal
description: Efforts to renew  and overhaul  the well-regarded Small Business Investment Research and Small Business Technology Transfer programs, which expire at the end of this month, may be in jeopardy now that the Senate appears unlikely to vote on its reauthorization bill anytime soon. And the person behind that bills demise, according to Democrats, at least, happens to be one of its chief architects  Senator Olympia Snowe, the Maine Republican on the Senate Small Business Committee.

title: In Trump Coverage, Catchphrase Becomes Clich
description: It was as common as the lack of surprise that greeted Donald Trumps announcement that he would not run for president.

title: Feets Too Big? No Problem; Everyone Dances Here
description: Once, a special event in jazz meant something warm and secretive and spontaneous: two guys who hadnt seen each other in a while, improvising several choruses together. But lately  since the early 1990s, when jazz became fixed in the world of arts grants and cultural institutions  it has often meant something more structured, official and imposing: heady written music, presented before a theater audience, sometimes elaborated with text or image or drama, program-noted and documented and ready to be reproduced elsewhere.

title: Latino Music, From Tango Back to the 16th Century
description: Since their founding in 1978, the annual Wall to Wall 12-hour marathons at Symphony Space have focused on a single composer; a genre, like opera; or a region, as did last years survey of music from behind the Iron Curtain. On Saturday the Wall to Wall Sonidos program explored Latino culture, with performers and composers from Spain and Central and South America representing myriad styles, including 16th-century vocal polyphony, tango, contemporary string quartets and Latin jazz.

title: DNA Exposed
description: Q. What does a test tube of DNA look like?

title: Arc of Life and Love, Unbent by Treatment
description: Gavin Snows skin cancer was discovered routinely enough: a mole on his back seemed suspicious to a dermatologist, who removed it for biopsy. The diagnosis was less typical. In 2006, Mr. Snow had Stage 3 melanoma, a disease usually found in people three decades older.

title: Love Endures Even Cancer
description: Gavin Snow found out he had stage 3 melanoma two months before meeting Haley Tanner. Together they have endured the ups and downs of living with a tragic disease.

title: Endeavours Final Flight
description: On May 16, the shuttle Endeavour rose slowly on a pillar of fire, picking up speed and eventually disappearing from view as it stabbed through a layer of clouds on its way to orbit.

title: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Israel, Lebanon, Libya and Turkey.

title: Profile in Style | Dick Page
description: As one of the worlds most in-demand makeup artists and the artistic director of Shiseido Makeup, Page traverses the usual New York-Paris-London-Milan-Tokyo circuit. When it comes to his coveted downtime, however, he gets off fashions beaten track, heading for rugged destinations like Iceland and the Arctic. The Long Island country shack he shares with his husband, James Gibbs, serves as the starting point for his favorite way to explore: camping. Our Teardrop trailer is always ready to go, he says. As is his Olympus digital camera: I photograph everything. Naturally, Pages photos dont merely serve as souvenirs  they also become makeup colors. View slide show >>

title: Donating Lives
description: Julio Garcia died unexpectedly in 2010. His widow decided to donate his organs to seven different people. And they recently had the opportunity to thank her in person.

title: A Lizard That Builds With the Family in Mind
description: Many animals build houses for their offspring, but no one thought lizards were among them. Now researchers have found that great desert skinks, lizards that live only in northern Australia, build and maintain elaborate tunneled homes, where they live in cooperative multigenerational family groups.

title: Back to a Time (the 80s) When Digital Was a Mere Dream
description: Much of Radio Play, a formless jumble of dopey humor and loopy music, by Tommy Smith and the alt-comedy darling Reggie Watts, is performed in almost complete darkness. This places a higher premium on what we hear as opposed to on what we see  a shift in focus that, Mr. Wattss considerable musical gifts notwithstanding, doesnt always play to his strengths.

title: At Vox Festival, Future of City Opera Sounds All Too Familiar
description: The board of New York City Opera is to meet on Thursday and consider that beleaguered companys plans for next season. As it happened, the discussion about City Operas uncertain future coincided with Vox, the companys annual festival of contemporary American opera, which was held over the weekend at New York Universitys Skirball Center and at Le Poisson Rouge. Since its start in 1999, Vox has been the centerpiece of City Operas vision of itself as a lab for new work; the festivals tag line has long been Preview the Future of Opera.

title: Group Spent Nearly $5 Million Backing Cuomo Budget
description: ALBANY  A coalition of business leaders supportive of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo spent nearly $5 million in the past two months lobbying in favor of the governors budget and his proposal to limit local property taxes, according to a new filing with the state ethics commission.

title: Malicks Film Adds a Dose of Sincerity to the Festivities
description: CANNES, France  In The Tree of Life, a cosmic head movie of the most ambitious order, Terrence Malick reaches high, his ecstatic camera and thoughts soaring. Shown on Monday morning at a press screening at the 64th Cannes Film Festival, where it was met with pre-emptive, harshly insistent boos and a vigorous rejoinder of equally determined applause, the film directly addresses the larger questions of existence that are woven throughout Mr. Malicks work. It seeks to affirm the beauty of a world in which God is present in all things.

title: Salzburg Must Replace Berlin Philharmonic
description: The Salzburg Easter Festival is scrambling to find a substitute for the Berlin Philharmonic, which said last week that after next year it would move to Baden-Badens Festspielhaus, or festival hall. This has to be a reinvention, a restart of the whole thing, or we have to quit it, Martin Riegler, the festivals spokesman, said on Monday. Officials were trying to find a future for the festival, including a new orchestra, he said. The festival was founded in 1967 by the Philharmonics conductor, Herbert von Karajan, as a place for it to play opera. The decision to move to Baden-Baden follows a financial scandal that led to allegations of fraud against two former officials. In explaining the move, a Philharmonic spokesman, Olaf Maninger, said, We need the kind of long-term security that the Baden-Baden Festspielhaus has to offer, according to Bloomberg News. Mr. Riegler said the orchestra wanted to expand its offerings beyond the two opera performances, six concerts and handful of chamber music performances it has been giving in Salzburg. We dont have the money for it, and Baden-Baden seems to have, he said.

title: Pictures of the Day: Israel and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Israel, Lebanon, Libya and Turkey.

title: Taking Measure of Weight-Loss Plans, and the Studies of Them
description: Consumer Reports, famous for its ratings of appliances and cars, has jumped into the diet wars.

title: Hold On for One More Day: Judd Apatow Talks About the Aftermath of Bridesmaids
description: It looks like moviegoers tossed Kristen Wiig a bigger bouquet than was originally expected this weekend: her new Universal comedy Bridesmaids sold $26.2 million through Sunday, according to box-office numbers released on Monday, up from the $24.4 million in ticket sales estimated on Sunday. Thats good news for Ms. Wiig and her co-screenwriter, Annie Mumolo; the films director, Paul Feig; its prolific producer, Judd Apatow (of Knocked Up and Funny People renown), fans of funny women and anyone who likes to laugh at moving images displayed on a screen, all of whom had pretty much concluded that Bridesmaids was a crucial standard-bearer for studio comedies with female leads.

title: Winklevoss Twins Lose, Again
description: 7:32 p.m. | Updated  Winklevoss team vows to appeal.

title: Spending the Afternoon With a Femme Fatale
description: Over the past year or so Fabio Luisi, the Metropolitan Operas increasingly busy principal guest conductor, has usually been ready to take over whenever James Levine, grappling with back problems, has withdrawn from a scheduled performance at the house.

title: A New Gauge to See Whats Beyond Happiness
description: Is happiness overrated?

title: Backing Up Your Facebook Content
description: As more and more of us put more of our online lives onto Facebook, the worlds biggest social network is moving from a convenient accessory to a necessary utility. People I communicate with for work have begun using Facebook rather than e-mail for important conversations.

title: Libyan Woman Describes Rape by Qaddafi Forces
description: Eman al-Obeidy, a Libyan woman who burst into a Tripoli hotel packed with foreign journalists in March to say that she had been raped by members of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis security forces, described her ordeal in an interview with Britains Channel 4 News conducted in Doha, the capital of Qatar, where she has found refuge.

title: Turning to Biomechanics to Build a Kinder, Gentler Rib Spreader
description: DURHAM, N.C.The sign on the door at the renovated tobacco warehouse reads Physcient. Inside are a few rooms that, depending on where you look, seem like an artists studio, a machine shop or a natural history museum. A lathe stands next to a drill press; along other walls are vises, huge enamel-red C-clamps, microscopes and plywood frames covered in electronics. But there are also reed-woven sculptures of insects called water boatmen hanging on the walls, along with glass-fronted boxes holding preserved flying dragon lizards. Casts of human rib bones are scattered on tables. A huge cast of a fearsome pair of fish jaws rests on a row of books.

title: Party Love at Cirque de Cannes
description: CANNES, France  There were some parties here the other night. Of course there are parties here every night, because who wouldnt want to celebrate being on the French Riviera, for decades a symbol of sun-dappled, Champagne-fueled luxury? Especially during the Cannes Film Festival, the annual pageant of haut aesthetics and a beacon to starlets since the early days of the bikini.

title: One Family, Lots of Watercress Sandwiches
description: THE streets of the Upper East Side were almost deserted on a recent rainy Saturday. But inside William Poll, afood and catering shop at 1051 Lexington Avenue, things were happening.

title: Citizens United Lawyer Creates Super PAC
description: While the comedian Stephen Colberts plan to form a so-called Super PAC to raise money for federal elections attracted some attention last week, another Super PAC formed by a key Republican campaign lawyer filed registration papers with the Federal Election Commission. The Republican Super PAC Inc., formed by James Bopp Jr., an Indiana lawyer, and Roger Villere, chairman of the Louisiana Republican Party, is designed to be a vehicle for unlimited contributions toward independent expenditures in support of Republican candidates at the national and state levels.

title: The Funeral Party Ran Off; Now Go Chase It Down
description: The Israeli playwright Hanoch Levin (1943-99) ticked off many of his countrymen with his blowtorch satires on human venality, often with a political dimension. With Winter Wedding, now in a revival ably directed by David Willinger at Theater for the New City, he pillories the familial calamities of matrimony with cynicism, absurdist flair and relish for whoopee-cushion humor. (The play, translated by the director and Laurel Hessing, has been retitled from its original, Winter Funeral.)

title: Obama Is a Millionaire, Records Show
description: President Obama is a millionaire with assets that could reach as much as $12 million, mostly from proceeds from his two best-selling books, according to financial disclosure forms made public by the White House on Monday.

title: Running Down a Sanity Checklist
description: As Jon Ronson undertakes one of the journalistic escapades that make up The Psychopath Test, he describes renting a car and savoring its smell. This aroma never fails to bring back happy memories of past sleuthing adventures. The particular episode that springs to his mind is trailing the conspiracy theorist David Icke around as he hypothesized his theory that the secret rulers of the world were giant, blood-drinking, child-sacrificing pedophile lizards that had adopted human form.

title: Japanese Officials Ignored or Concealed Dangers

title: Control Desk for the Neural Switchboard
description: Treating anxiety no longer requires years of pills or psychotherapy. At least, not for a certain set of bioengineered mice.

title: Police Officers Lawyer Says Money Motivated Rape Accuser
description: The lawyer for a police officer accused of serving as a lookout while his partner raped a woman argued Monday that no rape had occurred, that the woman was motivated by money and that his client had no motive to help his partner break the law.

description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said on Monday that it would not seek Congressional approval of free trade agreements with Colombia, Panama and South Korea until Republicans agree to expand assistance for American workers who might lose jobs as a result.

description: The federal judge overseeing the Roger Clemens perjury case wants more information from lawyers who investigated the use of performance-enhancing drugs in baseball.

title: Mets Wright Has Stress Fracture in His Back
description: The Mets announced Monday that third baseman David Wright has a stress fracture in his back and could end up on the disabled list for several weeks while it heals, the latest blow to a team used to them this season. The injury could be partly to blame for Wrights .226 batting average, but he took pains on Monday not to use it as an excuse for his slow start. Read the article here, and come back to this post comment.

title: Q&A: Using an iPod With a Linux System
description: Q.

title: N.B.A. Draft Lottery Could Create More Problems Than Solutions
description: The N.B.A. draft lottery, an event that hinges on bouncing Ping-Pong balls, can give a team hope of claiming direction and focus out of years of misfortune.

title: Home Tech: Tankless Water Heaters Explained
description: A few months ago my husband and I moved into a house outfitted with a demand or tankless water heater. Having lived only in rentals that were tapped into giant hot-water tanks, I was intrigued by the devices claims of energy efficiency. But after a few weeks of turning on the faucet as I normally do, I began to wonder if I was using my newfangled appliance the way it was meant to be. I decided to find out exactly how these new warmers work, and how to best to take advantage of their efficiency claims.

title: Lightning Leads With Its Focus, Not With Its Fists
description: BOSTON  Last season, the Tampa Bay Lightning was the most penalized team in the N.H.L. This season, under its first-year coach, Guy Boucher, 21 teams took more penalties.

title: Bing Taps Facebook Data for Fight With Google
description: Microsoft is hoping that its alliance with Facebook will get more people to choose Bing over Google.

title: Japan: U.S. Agency to Stop Monitoring Nuclear Plant
description: The United States Nuclear Regulatory Commission said on Monday that its 24-hour operations center had stopped monitoring the nuclear reactors at the Fukushima Daiichi plant because the situation there had improved. The conditions at the Japanese reactors are slowly stabilizing, said William Borchardt, the agencys chief staff official. As conditions have continued to improve and the Japanese continue to implement their recovery plan, the N.R.C. has determined that it is time to adjust our response, he said. The agency still has a team of engineers in Tokyo, he said. Mr. Borchardt said last week that the condition of the reactors was static but not stable.

title: Amid Tension, Yanks Slump Hits 6
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  A new workweek dawned Monday, and with it came the opportunity for the Yankees to purge themselves of one of the uglier stretches in Joe Girardis tenure. Off the field, a messy dispute engulfed the front office, the manager and two of the clubs iconic players. On it, ragged performances had dropped them out of first place in the American League East, sending them backsliding toward mediocrity.

title: Belarus: Government Critic Sentenced Over Protest
description: A Belarussian court convicted a journalist and critic of the nations authoritarian president on Monday of helping to organize a large antigovernment protest in December. The journalist, Irina Khalip, received a two-year suspended sentence. Her husband, Andrei Sannikov, a former presidential candidate, was sentenced to five years in prison on Saturday for a similar offense, and the authorities had previously threatened to take custody of their young son.

title: China: Rumors of a Private Club in the Forbidden City
description: The Forbidden Citys management group handed out registration forms last month for a luxury private club to be located in the compounds Jianfu Pavilion, which was restored with money from a fund in Hong Kong, according to a report in The Beijing News on Sunday and in the English-language edition of Global Times on Monday. Rumors about the club surfaced last week, when Rui Chenggang, an anchor for China Central Television, said on his microblog that the entry fee was one million renminbi, or about $154,000. Officials sent a statement to Global Times saying there were no plans to open any club.

title: Houston Businessman to Buy Astros
description: Jim Crane, who lost a bid to buy the Texas Rangers last year, announced a deal Monday to acquire the Houston Astros from Drayton McLane for $680 million, which includes the lease on Minute Maid Park.

title: Questions Raised About a Code of Silence
description: PARIS  The ritual follows a clear script: a scandal threatens to destroy the reputation of a powerful figure in France. Politicians say they are shocked. Friends say they are incredulous. Journalists debate whether they should have investigated rumors and revealed secrets. The dust settles. The status quo returns. Private life is protected.

description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Borrowing a page from Saddam Husseins old playbook, officials tied to the government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi on Monday threatened to post human shields at telecommunications sites under threat of NATO bombing.

title: Obama Is a Millionaire, Records Show
description: President Obama is a millionaire with assets that could reach as high as $12 million, mostly from proceeds from his two best sellers, according to financial disclosure forms made public by the White House on Monday. The disclosures only require Mr. Obama and his wife, Michelle, to list the value of their assets in wide ranges. For example, the president lists royalties from Dreams From My Father as between $1 million and $5 million. Mr. Obamas financial disclosures have largely remained the same since he took office in 2009.

title: For Fox and NBC, Let the Singing Begin
description: AS the television upfront week began on Monday, the presentations of the two networks that were first to outline their 2011-12 schedules to advertisers differed drastically. But their basic points were the same: broadcasting is alive and well.

title: Sammy Wanjiru, Marathon Champion, Is Dead at 24
description: Sammy Wanjiru, who set a blistering pace to shatter the 24-year-old Olympic record in the marathon, becoming the youngest winner of the event, died on Sunday in Nyahururu, Kenya. He was 24.

description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration on Monday proposed creating international computer security standards with penalties for countries and organizations that fell short.

title: As Summer Approaches, Odd Behavior Onboard
description: IWAS scanning online headlines last week and this one caught my eye, No Explanation for Outbreak of Insanity on Planes.

title: Sex, the Koch Brothers and Academic Freedom
description: More than a few of the respondents to my column about CUNYs on-again-off-again-on-again awarding of an honorary degree to Tony Kushner say that while I may be correct about the technical definition of academic freedom, I miss the larger point. Thats because there isnt one. A board of trustees with every right to make a decision made it in a way that (a) ran counter to its previous practice (b) permitted a single member (Jeffrey Wiesenfeld) to derail a process that had seemed to be on a familiar track and (c) put CUNY right in the middle of the briar patch called the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. Maladroit, unfortunate and (as I said) dumb. But thats it. It was just the board screwing up with the predictable public-relations disaster as the result. No ones freedom was curtailed, no ones speech was censored, no harm, except to the boards reputation and by extension to CUNYs, was done.Because Wiesenfelds objections were to Kushners views on Israel, the uproar that followed the boards decision to table his nomination quickly escalated into a shouting match between those who said that Israel was engaged in ethnic cleansing and those who replied that people who said that were anti-Semites and/or self-hating Jews. The responses to my column followed the same pattern. No one wanted to hear the topic of academic freedom parsed (a word used in derision by one reader, as if parsing something, trying to get it right, were a crime). MSP Shiloh complained that Dr. Fish misdirects our attention to the arcane and off topic of the academic honorary degree process, when [t]his was, and is, about Israels persecution of Palestinians. Other respondents were just as sure that this was, and is, about a university honoring a selfrighteous hack (mcghostoflectricity) who spews current day Palestinian propaganda (neilrobert). Both sides are wrong, not about Israel  I did not and will not come down on that issue  but about what this is about. Its about institutional ineptness, a relatively small matter that nevertheless can teach us some lessons. The back-and-forth trading of ritual insults is hardly edifying, but a proper understanding of what academic freedom is might be.

title: Uganda: Opposition Leaders Wife Is Briefly Held
description: The Ugandan government briefly detained the wife of the countrys leading opposition figure on Monday. The woman, Winnie Byanyima, the wife of the opposition leader Kizza Besigye and a senior director at the United Nations Development Program in New York, had been on her way to the airport to fly to the United States when her car was stopped by security forces and towed to a police station. She was soon released. Mr. Besigye has staged twice-weekly street demonstrations over the last month and has been arrested repeatedly.

In his starched white shirt and crisp suit, Tom Thibodeau looks more likely to sell James a life insurance policy than he is to thwart his title hopes.

title: Italy: Berlusconi Candidate Trails in Milan Race
description: Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy was dealt a resounding blow on Monday when Mayor Letizia Moratti, left, of Milan failed to avoid a runoff in her bid for re-election. Mr. Berlusconi had staked his reputation in support of Ms. Moratti and had campaigned strenuously for her. But with two-thirds of the votes counted, the center-left candidate Giuliano Pisapia was well out in front, but was short of a majority. The runoff election will be in two weeks.

He does not enter rooms of people so much as plunge into them, hugging and hand-clasping his way from wall to wall. His smile is outsize, and almost as indelible as a campaign poster.

Trump announced on Monday that he would not seek the presidency, a development less important for the Republican field or his national political future  if he ever had one  than for what it said about a media culture that increasingly seems to give the spotlight to the loudest, most outrageous voices.

Now, the creditors have the upper hand as the automaker seeks $6 billion to pay back the Treasury. The creditors are pressing their advantage.

description: Bard College, a small liberal arts institution in the Hudson Valley, has received a $60 million gift from the Open Society Foundations in recognition of its global involvement, which includes programs in New Orleans, Nicaragua and Russia, officials are to announce on Tuesday.

description: The story of evolution, we have been told, is the story of the survival of the fittest. The strong eat the weak. The creatures that adapt to the environment pass on their selfish genes. Those that do not become extinct.

title: A Book in Every Home, and Then Some
description: When we imagine people without books, we think of villagers in places like Afghanistan. But many families in the United States have no childrens books at home. In some of the poorest areas of the country, its hard to find books for sale. A study (pdf) of low-income neighborhoods in Philadelphia, for example, found a ratio of one book for sale for every 300 children. Tens of millions of poor Americans cant afford to buy books at all.

description: The bet was audacious from the beginning, and given the miserable, low-down tenor of contemporary politics, not unfathomable: Could you divide the country between greedy geezers and everyone else as a way to radically alter the social contract?

Not content with the presidents wide-ranging powers to pursue the archcriminals of Sept. 11, 2001, Republicans want to authorize the military to pursue virtually anyone suspected of terrorism, anywhere on earth, from now to the end of time.

description: Every year foreign orchestras with exotic or impressive-sounding names crisscross the country. They follow grueling routes and play in arts centers, small theaters and school auditoriums in places like Pembroke, N.C., and Modesto, Calif.

description: Hewlett-Packard is moving up its second-quarter earnings report to Tuesday rather than Wednesday, the company announced in a statement on Monday without citing a reason.

description: Before you take a drug or undergo a medical procedure, wouldnt you want to be sure it is the most effective and, if possible, the least costly available?

title: Another Misguided Idea From the Gun Lobby
description: The Environmental Protection Agency declined to block the use of lead in hunting and fishing last year. It was the wrong call. To ensure that the agency doesnt come to its senses, the National Rifle Association  assisted, as usual, by Congress  is pushing legislation that would bar the E.P.A. from restricting the sale of lead shot and bullets or lead sinkers.

title: A Washington Flavor as Chicago Swears in a Mayor
description: CHICAGO  As a cast of top Washington figures looked on, Rahm Emanuel was sworn in Monday as mayor of Chicago, offering praise to the longtime mayor he succeeds but mainly promising sweeping change.

title: In Georgia, Court Ruling Could Close Some Charter Schools
description: A ruling by the Georgia Supreme Court on Monday cast doubt on the future of 17 charter schools there, leaving thousands of families uncertain about whether classes will continue through the end of the academic year and how students will continue in the fall.

title: The Gateses as Living Sitters
description: The new portrait of Bill and Melinda Gates commissioned by the National Portrait Gallery in Washington depicts the leaders of the giant foundation bearing their name, and its work, with a respectful familiarity. Sitting on the arm of a chair with his arms crossed, Bill Gates appears supremely self-assured. Sitting slightly in front, Melinda looks confident. Over her shoulder is a video monitor showing two African girls and displaying ALL LIVES HAVE EQUAL VALUE. That is the credo of their foundation that addresses huge problems in American education, global health and other areas.

title: SUNY Official in Bruno Case Takes Leave of Absence
description: ALBANY  A top official at the State University of New York accused of giving a no-show job to the daughter of former Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno agreed on Monday to take a leave of absence until his case is resolved.

title: A Movie Premiere Just Like Hollywood Used to Make Them
description: There was the 3,000-foot red carpet (though in this case it was black) that rolled up Main Street in Disneyland, right to Frontierland. The street was lined with television cameras, correspondents and photographers. Nearly 20,000 fans, many wearing mouse ears, screamed at people they recognized, or thought they recognized. It all led to a full-blown outdoor theater, with a 3-D screen and stadium seating for 2,000 guests, built  for this night only over a lake in the center of Disneyland.

title: New York Investigates Banks Role in Financial Crisis
description: The New York attorney general has requested information and documents in recent weeks from three major Wall Street banks about their mortgage securities operations during the credit boom, indicating the existence of a new investigation into practices that contributed to billions in mortgage losses.

title: Bob Flanigan, Four Freshmen Founder, Dies at 84
description: Bob Flanigan, a founding member of the Four Freshmen, the well-scrubbed tight-harmony group begun more than 60 years ago, when all of its members really were undergraduates, died on Sunday at his home in Las Vegas. He was 84.

title: Pilots Avoid Jail in Brazil Crash
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  A Brazilian federal judge on Monday sentenced two American pilots involved in a fatal air crash over the Amazon rain forest in 2006 to community service.

title: Penguins New Imprint: Blue Rider Press
description: For six months, the new imprint at Penguin Group USA headed by David Rosenthal has remained stubbornly nameless. No longer, Mr. Rosenthal said on Monday: it will be called Blue Rider Press, a name inspired by the group of painters in early 20th-century Germany who bucked convention and promoted individual expression. The Blue Rider name historically represents individuality and quality in the arts, Mr. Rosenthal said in an e-mail. And that same intent will be reflected in the eclectic fiction and nonfiction books Blue Rider Press will publish. Mr. Rosenthals imprint will release its first titles in the fall, including The New New Rules by Bill Maher and a bedtime story parody, Goodnight iPad. It has also acquired books by Valerie Plame Wilson, Delia Ephron and R. A. Dickey. Mr. Rosenthal was offered his own imprint at Penguin after losing his job as publisher of the flagship imprint of Simon & Schuster last summer, and joins other Penguin imprints like Riverhead Books, Portfolio and the Penguin Press.

But Monday night was foggy and glum, and Bays majestic shot only got as far as the warning track. It was caught.

title: White House Stops Post-Speech Photo Ops
description: On Monday morning, May 2, readers of The New York Times  and newspapers around the country  could pick up the latest editions to see the face of President Obama staring back at them from Page 1 with that quiet but steely resolve that had been evident the night before. It seemed a fitting record of his announcement that Osama bin Laden had been killed by American forces.

title: Was Manchester Citys Trophy Worth What It Cost?
description: Manchester City has a shiny new silver trophy, paid for largely with Middle Eastern gold, and a reason to beat its chest in the streets of a city long dominated by its crosstown rival. It will surely take more than an F.A. Cup triumph for Manchester City to close the gap on mighty Manchester United, but after hundreds of millions of dollars spent to build a Premier League contender, its something.

title: How Do You Define Wealthy?
description: To separate the middle class from the wealthy, federal income tax policy sets the dividing line at $250,000 for family income. But some people have disputed that policy, arguing that theres a big difference between earning a quarter of a million dollars a year  especially in a high-cost-of-living area  and earning millions or even billions. What do you think? How do you define wealthy? How much do you think a family needs to earn to be considered wealthy by the government?

title: Bomb Found in Bus in Ireland Hours Before Queen Arrives
description: LONDON  Brushing aside bomb threats, Queen Elizabeth II embarked on the first visit by a reigning British monarch to the Irish Republic on Tuesday  a visit heavy on symbolism after decades of hostility and mistrust, and protected by some of the tightest security Dubliners could recall.

title: Toshiba in Discussions to Buy Landis & Gyr

Go with a guide who knows the ropes, like those at the local-run Keyhole Surf Camp (niaskeyholesurfcamp.com).

title: Critics Picks Video: The Umbrellas of Cherbourg
description: In this weeks Critics Picks, A. O. Scott looks back at Jacques Demys 1964 musical The Umbrellas of Cherbourg. The film stars Catherine Deneuve and Nino Castelnuovo as a couple in love who are separated by war. Mr. Scott calls it one of the most romantic films ever made. With every line of dialogue sung, the film plays more like an opera than a musical. This is singing as conversation, Mr. Scott says, a way for the actors to express their emotions, simply, sincerely and with a minimum of artifice. Yet the film itself uses the artifice of cinema to its advantage, with bright colors and an attractive cast. Have you seen The Umbrellas of Cherbourg? Please share your thoughts in the comments area below.

title: Libyan Oil Minister Said to Defect to Tunisia
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  The oil minister of Libya fled to neighboring Tunisia over the weekend, the Tunisian Interior Ministry said Tuesday, in what appeared to be another high-level defection from the increasingly isolated government of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi. Officials in Tripoli said the oil minister was on official business outside the country.

Oh, come on, the former House speaker huffed. Thats bizarre. All he meant, Mr. Gingrich went on to explain, was that Mr. Obamas policies would turn all of America into Detroit, which probably didnt endear him to Eminem.

title: Citing Safety Concerns, Vocal Group Cancels Visit to Japan

The Collegium Vocale Gent, a highly regarded ensemble that helped open the newly renovated Alice Tully Hall two years ago, has canceled a June tour that was to have included three performances in and near Tokyo because of concerns over nuclear safety brought on by the March quake and tsunami that crippled a nuclear power plant, resulting in releases of radiation.

title: Music Library at Harvard Acquires a Trove of Soltis Scores
description: Like most conductors, Georg Solti marked up his scores, noting tempos, voices to emphasize and the occasional cut. But he was also a prodigious reviser of his interpretations, according to scholars, leading him sometimes to acquire four or five copies of a score to note his ideas freshly each time. That has led to a large collection of scores  some 500  that Harvard University has just received. The family of Solti, who died in 1997, donated the collection to the Loeb Music Library at Harvard, university officials said on Tuesday. They are the most heavily marked-up scores I have ever seen, said Virginia Danielson, the Loebs librarian, and a source of valuable insight into Soltis musical thinking.

title: The Hardest Part of Running a Restaurant
description: Rafael thanked me for offering him a dream job. A fisherman since childhood, a painter of fish by day and a server at night, he had been waiting for a sustainable seafood place in which to work. He was well-spoken and mannerly, a good listener. We talked for an hour, going over his experience, his ambitions, how he stretched his canvases. He wanted to start work immediately. We agreed he would start the next day, at noon, train and taste and get familiar with our steps of service. That was a month ago. We have not heard from Rafael since.

title: Dancing With the Stars Leaves Rivals in the Dust
description: A two-hour installment of semifinal performances on Dancing With the Stars topped the ratings on Monday night as 21.4 million viewers tuned in to the ABC reality show from 8 to 10 p.m., according to Nielsens estimates. No other network came close to matching ABCs ratings, including during the 10 p.m. hour when ABCs Castle (13.2 million) outperformed CBSs Hawaii Five-0 (9.8 million) and NBCs Law & Order: LA (4.3 million).

title: Parties in France Adjust to Changed Landscape
description: PARIS  With its presumptive presidential candidate in a New York jail awaiting resolution of sexual assault charges, including attempted rape, the Socialist Party moved on Tuesday to try to reassure its troops, while President Nicolas Sarkozy was reported to have told his partys legislators that the arrest of Dominique Strauss-Kahn was a disaster for the Socialists, who had lost the moral part of the battle for the presidency.

title: From Land to Sea | Ryan Burch Video
description: The California-based surfer and shaper Ryan Burch is fast gaining recognition for his iconoclastic D.I.Y. board designs and ability to ride almost any shape and size with spontaneity and grace. Here, Burch shapes from scratch a five-foot, two-inch asymmetrical board he calls the Sledgehammer.

title: Gear Gurus
description: From the late 80s through the early 2000s, much of surf culture was marked by homogeneity. The gear companies became behemoths, and the most popular boards (many shaped by computers) looked largely the same. In recent years, though, surfings zeitgeist has begun to celebrate individuality  a shift back to the homespun ethos of the sports early days. A surfer now is more likely to be riding a board he made himself, often a radically new shape. Even high-ranked pros are working collaboratively with their preferred shaper to come up with original, untested designs. Here, from left to right, some of the California-based gear guys who are leading the way.Mitch Abshere The owner of the Captain Fin Company produces surfboard fins and wet suits from Japanese rubber, which is especially soft, allowing for more agility (captainfincompany.com).

title: Iran Says Missing Al Jazeera Reporter Committed Offenses
description: Iran said Tuesday that it was pursuing information about a missing Al Jazeera reporter sent to Tehran by the Syrian government in early May, saying she had committed several offenses, including traveling without a valid passport.

title: Egypt Holds 136 for Israeli Embassy Protest
description: The Egyptian military could bring charges against 136 people arrested during a protest outside the Israeli Embassy in Cairo on Sunday, including two prominent bloggers.

title: His Back Pages, Captured on Film
description: Bob Dylan will turn 70 next Tuesday  unless of course Judgment Day arrives in the meantime, an eventuality that Mr. Dylan might well take in stride. After all, the scope of his historical imagination stretches from before the flood to the end of days, and the man himself can sometimes seem to dwell outside of time altogether. Devotees who use the age of their idol to calculate their own dismaying senescence may be shocked that he is so old, but to many more of us he has always been around. He was never young. Or else he was so much older then, and hes younger than that now.
