description: Photographs from Ireland, Libya, Pakistan and South Africa.

title: A Once-Empty Theater Plays A Leading Role in a Revival
description: WILMINGTON, Del.  A recent Saturday gathering of children eating peanut butter and jelly sandwiches and bouncing to the beat of an African band in a renovated theater was a fitting symbol for the continuing efforts to revive the citys Market Street corridor.

title: Live Blogging the Upfronts: ABC
description: ABC is in rebuilding mode this year, something that was evident when the network ordered 13 new shows earlier this month. Now the network is showing off its schedule to advertisers at Lincoln Center.

title: PBS Special on Half the Sky
description: Today was an exciting day: the formal announcement of a PBS special on Half the Sky (my latest book with my wife, Sheryl WuDunn). The two-night special will air in late fall of 2012, but its also part of a much broader trans-media project intended to raise global womens issues higher on the agenda.

title: Posada to Hit Seventh; Soriano on D.L.
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  Jorge Posada will bat seventh while serving as the designated hitter on Tuesday night as the Yankees seek to end a six-game losing streak.

title: Pictures of the Day: Ireland and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Ireland, Libya, Pakistan and South Africa.

title: What Your Teens Are Reading
description: I had an article in The New York Times Book Review this Sunday. Specifically, it was about two young adult novels (Bitter End by Jennifer Brown and Stay by Deb Caletti) that share the theme of dating violence. More broadly, though, it explored the role of young adult novels in general.

title: TimesCast | May 17, 2011
description: Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi threatens to use 40,000 human shields as NATO broadens its bombing campaign; Wall Street's new sheriff; and a farewell to 'America's Most Wanted.'

title: Whats in Store for The Good Wife Season Finale?
description: 4:18 p.m. |Update: The Alicia-Kalinda Relationship

title: Cond Nast Will Be Anchor of 1 World Trade Center
description: Cond Nast Publications, whose stable of magazines chronicles the American zeitgeist as meticulously as any anthropologist, has reached an agreement to lease one million square feet at 1 World Trade Center, giving ground zero a much-needed corporate anchor with a proven ability to attract other businesses.

title: Scooter Enthusiasts Descend on Times Square
description: The New York Scooter Club held its sixth annual Block Party last weekend, and despite various barbecues and concerts packing the calendar, the unofficial highlight for the club is a nighttime cruise through Times Square.

title: Plan a Week in Italy for the Frugal Traveler: The Rules
description: For my trip around the Mediterranean, Im asking readers to plan a fun-filled, smartly-themed, low-budget five-day trip to somewhere on the Italian coast. Its up to you to come up with a destination and associated theme. A multiday hike through gorgeous countryside and small towns? A lesser-known side of a much-visited tourist destination? Sampling the seafood specialties along a string of coastal villages? Anything goes, as long as you can get me there from Naples (where Ill be the week before) and keep the budget light.

title: The Mediterranean on a Budget: The Voyage Begins
description: On Thursday, I head to Spain to begin what sounds like a foolhardy adventure: high season in the Mediterranean on a budget. For 10 weeks, Ill be just one soul among the gobs of tourists descending on its azure waters from around the world. Why would someone with a schedule as flexible and a wallet as light as mine want to fight the hordes of Italian and British and Norwegian and Chinese and Pennsylvanian vacationers and their affiliated bathing suit styles?

title: A Final Season of House, but Without Dr. Cuddy
description: Whatever final-season plans the creators of the Fox drama House may have had for sending the curmudgeonly and lovelorn title character off into the sunset with his boss, Dr. Lisa Cuddy, were dashed Tuesday when the actress Lisa Edelstein announced she would not return to wrap up the popular series.

title: New York Board of Regents Approves Restrictions on Museum Sales
description: The New York State Board of Regents on Tuesday made permanent a set of emergency regulations regarding the deaccessioning of artworks. In September the Regents approved the expiration of the regulations, which enjoined museums from selling artworks for operating costs and had been in effect since 2008.

title: Exploring Roots of Climate Stasis, and Next Steps
description: David Roberts, the Grist blogger, has written a double-barreled book review for the American Prospect thats well worth reading. It explores The Climate War, Eric Pooleys deconstruction of the long, and ultimately failed, effort to pass a comprehensive climate bill in the United States. But Roberts focuses most on David Victors new book Global Warming Gridlock, which Im way overdue to read. Victor, from the University of California, San Diego, has been a frequent and welcome voice on Dot Earth.

title: U.S. Agencies Plan a Public Forum on Location Services
description: Location-based services, the mobile-phone applications that make use of a persons geographic location, are attracting growing attention in Washington following reports that phone and software companies might have been sharing location information with third parties.

title: Bloomberg Visits Albany to Lobby for Same-Sex Marriage
description: ALBANY  Calling same-sex marriage the single most important issue facing New York State, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Tuesday visited the Capitol and pledged to support the campaign of any Republican senator who votes in favor of allowing gay couples to wed.

title: Fiji for All
description: Tavarua, the small, heart-shaped island in the Fijian archipelago, has two of the worlds most sought-after waves, Cloudbreak and Restaurants. Since 1984, access to them had been controlled by the Tavarua Island Resort (tavarua.com). But last year, Fijis military dictatorship put an end to the hotels exclusive rights, to the delight of local Fijians and international surfers, who have begun boating to the breaks from neighboring islands. Look for other resorts to spring up nearby and take advantage of the new access.

title: Lincoln Center Theater  Entices a Younger Crowd
description: Lincoln Center Theater on Tuesday started a program to provide $30 seats to its performances for people ages 21 to 35, theater officials announced. The program, called LincTix, allows members to buy tickets for productions at the Vivian Beaumont and Mitzi E. Newhouse Theaters at Lincoln Center, as well as to Lincoln Center Theater productions on Broadway. A limited number of LincTix will be available for every performance and available in advance. Once registered online, LincTix members (memberships are available at LincTix.org) can buy tickets for coming productions and to War Horse, now at the Vivian Beaumont Theater (regular tickets cost $75 to $125), and to A Ministers Wife, now at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater (regular tickets are $85). LincTix members will also have a chance to purchase seats together with other LincTix members and will get invitations to free LincTix parties and other special events. Mem Membership includes advance notice of the $20 tickets for all LCT3 productions, which showcase the work of new playwrights, directors and designers.

title: Interesting Rock Talk. No, Really.
description: Promotional band videos  virtually without exception  are joy vacuums. No one wants to see a musician droning on about how this new record is a break with the past/a return to his roots. Rock star, your lack of introspection is compensated by the fact that you can play guitar: no more self-analysis for you! And yet, the electronic press kit persists.

title: The Battle for Libya
description: Battle for Libya | May 17, 2011

title: Killebrew Was Always First With a Hello
description: MINNEAPOLIS  Harmon Killebrews reputation as one of the nicest and most approachable people in baseball was well deserved. He made several trips a year to the Twin Cities, and if he passed you in the hallway at the Metrodome or at Target Field, he would, without fail, say hello first. Thats just how he was.

title: Nehro Will Skip the Preakness
description: Nehro, the runner-up to Animal Kingdom in the Kentucky Derby, will not run in the Preakness Stakes on Saturday and be pointed instead to the Belmont Stakes on June 11.

title: From Land to Sea
description: Ryan Burch creates a surfboard from scratch.

title: On Our Radar: Pesticides a Threat to Childrens I.Q., Studies Find
description: Prenatal exposure to pesticides  common in agricultural areas as well as low-income urban neighborhoods, where the chemicals are used to control cockroaches and other insects  can significantly affect a childs ability to succeed in school, a trio of new studies finds. This is not trivial, a researcher says. [Yale Environment 360]

title: A Librarys Treasures, From Gutenberg to Malcolm X
description: To mark the 100th anniversary of its flagship building on Fifth Avenue, the New York Public Library is putting some of its prize holdings on display.

title: Tropical Punch | Cartagena
description: As this Colombian city becomes a favorite destination for the international jet set, more stylish shops, fancy fusion restaurants and colonial mansions-turned-hotels are dialing up the heat in this Caribbean gem. View Style Map >>

title: An Exploration of the World That Made Bach and That Bach Remade
description: Bach, as the culmination of the German Baroque, effectively eclipsed his ancestors, whether actual family members or simply musical forebears.

title: Strong Sales to Businesses Lift Dells Earnings
description: Strong sales to businesses continued to prop up Dells earnings in the first quarter despite a weak economy and still-sluggish demand from consumers.

title: Muslim World Is Unsure of Obama, Poll Finds
description: A new survey by the Pew Research Center suggests that President Obamas scheduled speech on the Middle East this week will be greeted by skeptical audiences in several predominantly Muslim countries.

title: I.M.F. Chief May Claim Consensual Sex as a Defense
description: As Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, spent his first full day on Rikers Island, the hotel housekeeper who accused him of sexual assault was struggling with what her lawyer said was a life upended by the case.

title: Shire Buys Biotech Firm for $750 Million
description: It was one of the most anticipated initial public stock offerings in a while  at least for the biotechnology industry.

title: Cockroaches May Help Explain Asthma Outbreaks
description: Sometimes, Kafakaesque reactions of dread and disgust toward creatures like cockroaches are scientifically justified.

title: Fewer Emergency Rooms Available as Need Rises
description: Hospital emergency rooms, particularly those serving the urban poor, are closing at an alarming rate even as emergency visits are rising, according to a report published on Tuesday.

title: Europeans Face Up to Chance of 2nd Greek Bailout
description: BRUSSELS  Confronting the looming prospect of a second bailout for Greece, European finance ministers insisted Tuesday on further deficit-cutting efforts from the government in Athens and acknowledged for the first time that the private sector could be included in a restructuring of Greek loans.

title: Berlusconi Fails to Sway Electorate in Milan
description: ROME  For months, Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi has nimbly weathered sex scandals and dissent within his own coalition, but this week he suffered something even rarer in his long career: a political miscalculation.

title: Church Report Cites Social Tumult in Priest Scandals
description: A five-year study commissioned by the nations Roman Catholic bishops to provide a definitive answer to what caused the churchs sexual abuse crisis has concluded that neither the all-male celibate priesthood nor homosexuality were to blame.

title: For Paulson, Gold Still Glitters
description: You cant accuse the hedge fund manager John A. Paulson of lacking loyalty.

title: Congress Asks Sony to Address Unanswered Questions
description: A House subcommittee sent a followup letter to Sony on Tuesday after the company failed to answer a number of questions regarding an attack on its PlayStation Network last month.

title: In Cannes, an Upbeat View of the Film World
description: CANNES, France  As he sat on his balcony overlooking the Mediterranean, Dan Talbot, the celebrated founder of New Yorker Films, could have lighted every screen here with his optimism. Up close, this town can sometimes look a little grubby, the business somewhat desperate, the movies too. But on the fifth floor of the Hotel Splendid on Tuesday, as he sat taking in the bright blues of the sky and sea, the rushing festivalgoers and languidly moving rest, and even said hello to a dove perched on a railing, life looked pretty grand and so did the 64th Cannes Film Festival.

title: Thelewala
description: 112 Macdougal Street (West Third Street), (212)614-9100, thelewalany.com.

title: Coburn Withdraws From Gang of Six
description: The already weak prospects for a bipartisan debt-reduction deal this year dimmed further on Tuesday when a Republican member of the Senates so-called Gang of Six, Senator Tom Coburn of Oklahoma, withdrew after months of private negotiations amid differences over Medicare and Social Security.

title: Inside Thelewala
In Consumer Behavior, Signs of Gas Price Pinch
description: High gasoline prices have not derailed the economic recovery, but thats small comfort to Loraine Greene. A customer relations manager in the Hudson Valley of New York, Ms. Greene spent the weekend packing up to move to a rental house much closer to work.

title: Ally Changes I.P.O. Plans, Offering Some Debt as Well
description: Ally Financial, the former lending arm of General Motors, amended its plans on Tuesday to hold an initial public offering of its stock, tweaking the deal to appeal to a broader range of investors. The move also indicated that the government could shed more of its 73.8 percent stake in the company than previously expected.

title: Souvlaki GR
description: 116 Stanton Street (Essex Street), Lower East Side, (212) 777-0116, souvlakigr.com.

title: A Poem by Nate Marshall
description: The poet Nate Marshall performs "Look," a piece featured in the slam poetry documentary "Louder Than a Bomb."

title: Inside Souvlaki GR
Capturing Beauty, With All Its Flaws
description: IN 2010 there were more than 12 million cosmetic procedures  from breast implants to Botox injections  performed in the United States, according to the American Society of Plastic Surgeons. Meanwhile, there is at least one mother who has injected Botox into her child, a beauty pageant contestant (as seen on Good Morning America last week); a steady stream of models in uneasy relationships with their body weight, and magazine layouts in which skin color and body shapes have been digitally modified.

title: Artichoke Basics
description: Melissa Clark, the author of the Good Appetite column, demonstrates how to prepare artichokes, a spring staple.

title: A Stream of Words, Painting a Picture
description: Gather a bunch of teenagers together in a room, and usually what you sense is an abundance of hormones. But in Louder Than a Bomb, a documentary about a high school poetry slam of that name in Chicago, it is earnestness that is thick in the air as these young writers convene and try to shape their emotions and observations into competition-worthy poetry.

title: Mushrooms, From Dazzling to Deadly
description: How dazzling is the world of mushrooms? The fan-shaped cinnabar oysterling looks like something you would find undersea. The violet webcap is vibrant. These are among the more than 600 fungi described and illustrated in this scholarly and beautiful book. It gives examples of cultivated mushrooms like shiitake, explains why porcini cannot be cultivated (no spores), has an interesting section on truffles and describes dozens of edible wild mushrooms. It also covers hundreds of mushrooms that are inedible or deadly poisonous.

title: Kazakhstan: Suicide Bomber Strikes
description: Authorities in Kazakhstan were trying to determine whether a man who blew himself up on Tuesday inside a government office building in a provincial town had links to Islamic radicals. If so, it would be the first known terrorist suicide bombing in oil-rich Kazakhastan. Governments in the region, including Russia, have expressed concern that violence from the Afghan war is spreading to formerly Soviet Central Asia. The attack wounded two bystanders at a local police headquarters in the city of Aktobe. Kazakh prosecutors said it appeared that the bomber had ties to organized crime but not to radical Islamic groups.

title: With Reactor Damage Thought to Be Worse, Tokyo Utility Sticks to Plan
description: TOKYO  Japan vowed Tuesday to stick to its goal of stabilizing a stricken nuclear power plant in as soon as six months, despite recently acknowledging that damage to the plants reactors might be worse than initially estimated.

title: Can Recipe Search Engines Make You a Better Cook?
description: LETS say you have invited four people for dinner on Saturday. Its now Wednesday morning, and reality is setting in. On the guest list: two pescatarians, a Top Chef fanboy and a gluten avoider. Also, spring is in the air; local asparagus, arriving now. The challenge, as always: how to find dishes that are reliable, delicious and gastronomically correct?

title: Googles Most Wanted Recipes
description: Julia Moskins article on recipe search engines discusses some the major players in that world, including the newest member of that group: Googles Recipe View tool.

title: TimesCast | Wall Street's New Enforcer
description: Gretchen Morgenson discusses the investigation into three major Wall Street banks by the New York attorney general, Eric T. Schneiderman.

title: VPN for the Masses
description: If youve ever worked for a large (or even not so large) company, you may have encountered a virtual private network, or VPN. VPN is a technology that adds a layer of security to outside networks (like the one in your home, the airport, or a hotel room) that may not be as secure as what you have at the office.

title: Gus Johnson Is Eager to Expand His Horizons at Fox
description: Last week, at the exact moment that the broadcaster Gus Johnson learned he would no longer call the N.C.A.A. mens basketball tournament, he was shooting baskets. Johnson found that a remarkable coincidence. In many ways, the tournament defined him, made him famous. His cult following had grown from his work in March.

title: Senate Group on Debt Loses a Key Republican
description: WASHINGTON  The already weak prospects for a bipartisan debt-reduction deal this year dimmed further on Tuesday when a Republican member of the Senates Gang of Six, Senator Tom Coburn of Oklahoma, withdrew after months of private negotiations amid differences over changes to Medicare.

title: In Japan Reactor Failings, Danger Signs for the U.S.
description: TOKYO  Emergency vents that American officials have said would prevent devastating hydrogen explosions at nuclear plants in the United States were put to the test in Japan  and failed to work, according to experts and officials with the company that operates the crippled Fukushima Daiichi plant.

title: How to Protect the iPad in the Kitchen
description: The tablet computer, with those wonderful apps that display recipes and color pictures, is one of the best new kitchen tools. But if you cook like Julia Child did  splashing the bouillabaisse and tossing the flour all over the counter there is no way youd bring it into the kitchen. An iPad, after all, doesnt rinse off like a cutting board. Moisture is its chief enemy.

title: Greece Has Ways to Fix Debt Woes, but All Lead to Misery
description: Harry Campbell

title: Reviewing Gotham Bar and Grill
Gotham Bar and Grill
description: IN a city obsessed with the shiny and novel, Gotham Bar and Grill is an outlier. Open since 1984, it celebrates stability and excellence, perhaps even opulence. Fabric chandeliers billow beneath soaring ceilings. Elaborate flowers are everywhere. People dress for dinner and are escorted past marvelous photographs on the way to their tables. It is all very civilized there.

title: Couples Affair, Business Edition
description: The gowns were elaborate. The Champagne was flowing. The starburst chandeliers in the Metropolitan Opera House lifted magically to the ceiling as the lights dimmed. The curtain rose smoothly, and the conductor raised his baton.

title: New Season Opens for American Ballet Theater
description: American Ballet Theater opened its new season with gala on Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House that featured 12 short performances.

title: South African Vote May Reflect Lessening of A.N.C.s Luster
description: SOSHANGUVE, South Africa  The crowd was black and poor, and the politician was white and well-to-do. She was onstage, gamely singing a song with Xhosa-language lyrics, and when she started to dance a few simple steps, Simon Mahlangu, a 42-year-old man looking on, nodded appreciatively and said, Shes really not as bad youd expect.

title: Treats Without Calories? Imagine That
description: I HAVE a belt of adipose tissue lodged around my middle. Im a bumper car, protected from unwarranted bumping. Need a gently sloping shelf on which to display historical thimbles or wee porcelain Scotties? Call me. The Alford steaks, they are marbled.

title: Farewell to 'America's Most Wanted'?
description: Brian Stelter on Fox's announcement that "America's Most Wanted" will no longer be a weekly show.

title: Considering Next Steps for Wanted
description: Most TV shows have fans. Americas Most Wanted has deputies.

title: Christos Colorado Project May Hinge on Sheep
description: Nearly 20 years after the artist Christo and his wife, Jeanne-Claude, proposed draping a river canyon in southern Colorado in miles of translucent fabric, a federal thumbs up or down on the project may hinge on one factor above all others: the happiness of several hundred bighorn sheep.

title: U.S. to Extend Haitians Post-Quake Immigration Status
description: Haitians who received a special American immigration status after last years earthquake will be allowed an additional year and a half to live and work in the United States while their country struggles to recover, the Obama administration announced on Tuesday.

title: The Mideast Conflict, Past and Present
description: To the Editor:

title: France and the Perp Walk
description: To the Editor:

title: Spare Parts Find a Home: Waffles
description: OFFAL and waffles may not have the appeal of surf and turf, but give it time.

title: Lasagna From Brucie to Bake at Home
description: At her rustic little restaurant, Brucie, Zahra Tangorra gives the home cook a worthy resource. Bring in your 9-by-14-inch baking pan and she will fill it with enough lasagna for 12 people, ready to bake at home, or to take away parbaked or fully cooked. As you put the bubbling pan on the table, let your guests make their assumptions about who deserves credit. Meatless lasagna, with marinara, ricotta and mozzarella, with Ms. Tangorras fresh pasta, was delicious, though there was a little too much sauce and cheese to cut neat portions. Ms. Tangorra, above, suggests letting it sit after baking and then reheating it. Mushroom and goat cheese lasagna, and an eggplant with Swiss chard variety, are also offered.

title: At Nice Matin, a Wine List That Hits All the Marks
description: AS exciting as it feels to pick up a wine list already well known for its great bottles, its even more electrifying to have few expectations and to be knocked back in goggle-eyed surprise.

title: Dining Calendar
description: The Gangs All Here

title: Chemical Suspected in Cancer Is in Baby Products
description: More than 30 years after chemical flame retardants were removed from childrens pajamas because they were suspected of being carcinogens, new research into flame retardants shows that one of the chemicals is prevalent in babys products made with polyurethane foam, including nursing pillows, car seats and highchairs.

title: Off the Menu
description: Opening

title: Gilt Taste Arrives, With Ruth Reichl at the Helm
description: Along with selling high-end clothing and luxury travel online, the Gilt Groupe has started Gilt Taste, offering artisanal hard-to-find foods. Some are exclusive and some have been sold only to chefs. Ruth Reichl, the former editor of Gourmet magazine and former restaurant critic of The New York Times, is its editorial adviser, curating the selections, as well as editing essays, articles and recipes that will be included.

title: British Lesson for the U.S.
description: To the Editor:

title: In Wake of Ruling, Possibility of Progress in N.F.L. Lockout
description: N.F.L. players and owners ended a brief round of negotiations Tuesday against a landscape dramatically altered by an appeals court decision that allowed the league to continue a shutdown that threatens the start of the regular season.

title: California: Honor for Immigrant Activist
description: The University of San Francisco will award an honorary doctorate at graduation ceremonies on Friday to an illegal immigrant, Isabel Castillo, 26, of Harrisonburg, Va., who has been a leading advocate for passage of the Dream Act. The legislation would give legal status to people like her, who were brought to the United States at a young age and went on to attend college. Ms. Castillo came to the United States from Mexico at age 6; she graduated with honors from Eastern Mennonite University. Stephen A. Privett, the president of the University of San Francisco, said he decided to award the degree after reading about Ms. Castillo in the On Education column in The New York Times earlier this year. He said the university wanted to underscore the fundamental unfairness of our denying a path to citizenship to some of the most motivated college students in the country.

title: Venting Failure in the Nuclear Reactors at Fukushima Daiichi
description: The emergency vent system designed to help prevent hydrogen explosions failed to work in at least two of the three reactors in operation. Venting would have reduced the amount of hydrogen gas that accumulated in the buildings.

title: Palestinian Authority Delays Elections
description: The Palestinian Authority said Tuesday that it was delaying local elections scheduled for July until late October in order to organize the voting in Gaza, which is controlled by Hamas. Last month, Hamas and its rival, Fatah, which dominates the Palestinian Authority, announced a surprise unity agreement. Palestinians have not held an election in five years because of a bitter split between the groups. The October poll will indicate how each party is faring as it prepares for legislative and presidential elections within a year, as called for in the unity accord.

title: Sixth Soldier Charged in Afghan Killings
description: SEATTLE  A sixth soldier was charged Tuesday in connection with what Army prosecutors have described as the sport killings of three Afghan civilians last year, officials at Joint Base Lewis-McChord near here said.

title: Abortion and Choice
description: To the Editor:

title: After Legal War, a West Side Landmark May Rise
description: Since its construction in 1933, the Metro Theater on the Upper West Side has had a turbulent history. Among its numerous iterations: a pornography house, an art-house movie theater and home to two national cinema chains.

title: A Tale of Two Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: PC Makers Are Seeing a Slowdown
Imagining Detroit
description: Detroit was once called the Paris of the West, but at this point its more reminiscent of Venice. Like Venice, its demise has been imminent for some time, as crucial businesses and huge chunks of the population flee.

title: Top Hispanic Name Loses Ground, Even as Birthrates Stay High
description: No way, Jose!

title: Canucks Are Falling, Sharks Are Complaining, and One Fight Is Not Happening
description: The Vancouver-San Jose series is only one game old, but the gamesmanship is already in full swing.

title: Buffalos Attractions
description: To the Editor:

title: The War in Libyas Western Mountains
Mayor Presses Republicans In Albany on Gay Marriage
description: ALBANY  Urging lawmakers to put themselves on the right side of history, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg visited the Capitol on Tuesday and vowed to support the re-election campaign of any Republican senator who votes to allow gay couples to wed.

title: Why Be a Tree Stump When You Can Soar?
description: My God. Look at you. Thats what Jon-Jon Goulians grandfather, the political philosopher Sidney Hook, said to him while Mr. Goulian was visiting Hooks house in Vermont during the summer of 1987. The elderly man held a rolled-up copy of Commentary magazine in one hand, as if to smack his 19-year-old grandson like a horsefly.

title: Joseph Wershba, a Journalist Who Helped Take On McCarthy, Dies at 90
description: Joseph Wershba, who as a CBS television reporter working with Edward R. Murrow revealed the story of Lt. Milo Radulovich, whose dismissal from the Air Force because of his relatives leftist leanings became a symbol of the anti-Communist witch hunts of the 1950s, died on Saturday at a hospital near his home in Floral Park on Long Island. He was 90.

title: When Mahler Took Manhattan
description: HERES an often overlooked bit of music history: Gustav Mahler, who died in Vienna a century ago today, was a New Yorker for the last three years of his life and, for that brief time, arguably the most famous musician in town. Its not a trivial point  as a conductor at the Metropolitan Opera and then at the New York Philharmonic, he set musical standards that resonate even today.

title: At Preakness, Not Everybodys Idea of Fun
description: Excessive drinking at the Preakness Stakes, the second jewel of horse racings Triple Crown, reached its nadir in 2007 when videos of young men racing atop portable toilets in the Pimlico Race Course infield as beer cans rained on them went viral. There was safety to consider, and the threat of lawsuits loomed.

title: As Uprisings Transform Mideast, Obama Aims to Reshape the Peace Debate
description: WASHINGTON  Six months after the Arab world erupted in a political firestorm, President Obama has been searching for ways to link the regions historic transformation to the long-stymied peace negotiations between Israel and the Palestinians. It is far from clear how he can do that.

title: Maurice Goldhaber, Atomic Physicist, Is Dead at 100
description: Maurice Goldhaber, a physicist who delved into the intricacies of atoms and headed the Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island for more than a decade, died last Wednesday at his home in East Setauket, N.Y. He was 100.

title: Bibi and Barack
description: Reading the headlines from the Middle East these days  Christians and Muslims clashing in Egypt, Syria attempting to crush its democracy rebellion and Palestinians climbing over fences into Israel  you get the sense of a region where the wheels could really start to come off.

title: Video: Americas Most Wanted Unwanted by Fox
description: Brian Stelter discusses Foxs announcement that Americas Most Wanted, a mainstay on the network for 23 years, will no longer be a weekly show.

title: A Legacy of Insubordination
description: When he took office, Abraham Lincoln faced the greatest strategic challenge of any American president before or since: that of holding the country together as political and moral tensions that had risen steadily over the course of nearly 100 years strained mightily to tear it apart. But he also confronted a standard of civil-military relations that internalized domestic political intrigue and countenanced soldierly insubordination. Epitomized by Gen. George B. McClellan, this organizational problem was a crippling impediment for Lincoln early in the Civil War that required all of his political and psychological acumen to overcome. It was substantially a product of the Mexican War of 1846-48.

title: Day After Contentious Remarks, Soriano Heads to Disabled List
description: The Yankees put reliever Rafael Soriano on the disabled list Tuesday, but, befitting their fortunes recently, they also dealt with a matter unrelated to his ailing right elbow.

title: F.B.I. Agent Is Accused of Lying for Lover
description: An agent with the Federal Bureau of Investigation got too close to a confidential informer in a criminal investigation and is now in trouble with the law, an indictment made clear on Tuesday.

title: President Obama and the Arab Spring
description: It should be no surprise that the ferment in the Arab world has touched the Palestinians, whose promised two-state solution is no closer than ever. On Sunday, the anniversary of Israels creation, thousands marching from Syria, Gaza, Lebanon and the West Bank breached Israels borders and confronted Israeli troops. More than a dozen people were killed; scores were injured.

title: For States, a Glimmer of Hope on Deficits
description: From stronger-than-expected tax collections in deficit-ridden California to projected surpluses in struggling states like Michigan and Pennsylvania, a growing number of recession-weary states are finally announcing a bit of good budget news for the first time since the downturn began.

title: Cond Nast Publications
description: FOUNDED1909 by Cond Montrose Nast

title: Hotel Keycard of I.M.F. Chief May Tell a Tale
description: Under siege by thieves who regularly got their hands on old-fashioned room keys, hotels in New York began using electronic locks on their doors in 1977, led by the fabled, fusty Algonquin. The new keys would be plastic, with a magnetic strip swiped through a card reader on the door.

title: For Buyers of Web Start-Ups, Quest to Corral Young Talent
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Sam Lessin sold his Web start-up to Facebook for millions last year, and Facebook promptly shut it down. All Facebook wanted was Mr. Lessin.

title: Flooding Takes Economic Toll, and Its Hardly Done
description: The swollen Mississippi River, already spilling over into wide areas of the Mississippi Delta, has dealt the South a heavy economic blow that is seeping into every possible corner of the regions commercial and agricultural life.

title: Droit du Dirty Old Men
description: Paris

title: In Heats Buddy Act, Nearly All Interviews Come With an Assist
description: CHICAGO  An unruly swarm of cameras, microphones, recording devices and elbows had engulfed Dwyane Wade when an advisory was issued from outside the tangle of humanity and technology.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,561 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Tuesday:

title: Will the Banks Finally Have to Answer?
description: At long last, there may be a serious investigation into the mortgage mess  the kind that results in clarity as well as big fines and maybe even accountability.

title: Whats Good for Workers ...
description: The refusal by Congressional Republicans to renew assistance for workers who lose their jobs to overseas competition is another instance of their callous determination to slash the budget at the expense of the most vulnerable Americans. It is also bad for American business and other constituents dearer to their hearts.

title: Wagons North!
description: Mayor Michael Bloomberg didnt make many friends when he offered his own idea for saving Detroit, which has lost one-fourth of its population over the last decade.

title: Curtains for Elaines, a Legendary New York Hangout
description: When the restaurateur Elaine Kaufman died last year, the manager who inherited her legendary restaurant on the Upper East Side said, Were going to try to run it as usual.

title: Ryan Says He Will Stay in the House
description: Representative Paul D. Ryan, a Wisconsin Republican and the chairman of the House Budget Committee, made it clear on Tuesday that he would not run for the Senate seat being vacated by Herb Kohl, a Democrat who was first elected in 1988. Instead, Mr. Ryan said he would remain in the House and lead the Republican fight over the budget and the national debt. Our nation is quickly approaching a debt crisis that will do serious damage to Wisconsinites and all Americans if it is not properly addressed, Mr. Ryan said in a statement on his Web site. I believe continuing to serve as chairman of the House Budget Committee allows me to have a greater impact in averting this debt-fueled economic crisis than if I were to run for the United States Senate.

title: Up Front: Tom Carson
description: The critic Tom Carson has written about music, books, television and film for publications as diverse as The Village Voice and GQ.

title: Albert Brooks's First Novel
description: Albert Brooks has written his first novel, 2030. The Book Reviews editor, Sam Tanenhaus, interviews the acclaimed actor, screenwriter and director about the art of writing fiction.

title: Albert Brookss Dark Vision of the Future
description: As a comedian and filmmaker, the very gifted Albert Brooks has specialized for more than 30 years in cooking up quandaries with no ready solution except humiliation. His often ingenious first novel is no exception to that rule. In the future America of 2030, the national debt has long since surpassed the gross national product. Why anyone would want to be president is more and more of a mystery. On the rosy side  well, sort of  a cure for cancer has been found, turning the man who did it, Dr. Sam Mueller, into a billionaire and a guru.

title: Officer in Rape Trial May Have Convinced Himself of Relationship, Prosecutor Says
description: When a police officer had sex with a woman in her East Village apartment, a Manhattan prosecutor said Tuesday, he may actually have felt he was doing nothing wrong.

title: Lottery Numbers
Yale Restricts a Fraternity for Five Years
description: A Yale fraternity whose alumni include both President Bushes has been banned from conducting any activities on campus for five years, including recruiting, as punishment for an episode last October in which members led pledges in chants offensive to women, the university announced on Tuesday.

title: Atop I.M.F., Contradiction and Energy
description: Artful politician that he is, Dominique Strauss-Kahn has a keen sense for not just his strengths but also his potential weaknesses  though few would be quite as blunt in saying so.

title: American Coach Finds Success in Guatemala
description: ANTIGUA, Guatemala  A gem of a town nestled in the central Guatemalan highlands, Antigua attracts plenty of Americans. They come for all sorts of reasons  to see the ruins of this one-time Central American capital, to climb the picturesque volcanoes that surround the city, and to get a taste of a region known as the land of eternal spring.

title: Wednesday: Cubic Rubik
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  The subject of todays puzzle passed away recently, and this is a fine tribute to him by David J. Kahn, as it is chock full of his work.

description: ALBANY  The millionaires tax may be on its way back. Or so Democrats in the State Assembly hope.

title: Cavs Get the No. 1 Pick and a Rebuilding Boost

description: Fox Hispanic Media and Mun2, part of the Telemundo network, showed their upcoming slate of programs for Spanish-language viewers.

title: Wrights Injury Prompts Series of Moves by Mets
description: Two hours before they were scheduled to face the Florida Marlins at Citi Field Tuesday night, the Mets announced the game was canceled because of inclement weather. The news was met with some amusement in the clubhouse, considering there was plenty of sun peeking through the clouds at the time.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Yankees Snap Losing Streak, Quieting Concerns Along Way
description: ST. PETERSBURG, Fla.  In the hours before Tuesdays game, the Yankees were worried enough about their slumping cleanup hitter, Alex Rodriguez, that they wondered whether something was physically wrong with him. The hitting coach Kevin Long said Rodriguez was failing to incorporate the lower half of his body into his swing, that he had lost the explosiveness the Yankees saw from him during spring training and in early April.

title: TV Steps Up Pitch to Hispanic Market
description: AS television executives peddle their coming programs to advertisers this week, before the start of the 2011-12 season, their sales spiels are taking on a decided Spanish accent.

title: With Time Slipping Away, N.B.A. and Players Plan to Meet
description: SECAUCUS, N.J.  The N.B.A. and the players union are meeting with greater frequency as time dwindles for reaching a new labor agreement and avoiding the leagues first lockout since 1998.

title: Goldman No Longer Laps the Field
description: Goldman Sachs has lost its luster. The firm earned a best-in-class reputation for its history of profitability and navigating upheaval. But it seems less assured lately. In fact, Goldman is in danger of looking downright average.

title: Drug Study a Setback for Abbott
description: A study has suggested that an anticholesterol drug, TriLipix, does not protect against heart attacks or strokes better than a generic medicine, according to a report released on Tuesday. As a result, uses of the drug, made by Abbott Laboratories, may be limited in the United States or be subject to more testing.

description: BOSTON  The solution to what was ailing the Boston Bruins was right there in their dressing room all along: the highly regarded but underused 19-year-old rookie center, Tyler Seguin.

description: European antitrust officials raided several of the worlds largest container shipping companies over possible collusion, the European Commission said in a statement on Tuesday.

description: Oaktree Capital Management is planning to list its shares on the New York Stock Exchange, the latest private investment firm to tap the public markets.

title: Video From the Upfronts: Spanish-Language Programming on the Rise
description: As Stuart Elliott and Tanzina Vega reported, the continuing growth of the Spanish-speaking population shown by the 2010 census is not going unnoticed by media and marketers. This years upfront week features presentations from as many Spanish-language programmers as there are from English-language broadcasters. This video takes a look at some of the shows pitched to advertisers. Executives also discuss the goals and spirit of their programs.

title: Senate Refuses to End Tax Breaks for Big Oil
description: WASHINGTON  The Senate on Tuesday blocked a Democratic proposal to strip the five leading oil companies of tax breaks that backers of the measure said were unfairly padding industry profits while consumers were struggling with high gas prices.

title: Diabetic? Ford May Have an App for That
description: While driving recently along the Ventura Freeway in Los Angeles, I watched a driver drift across traffic and settle at the shoulder of the road. Other drivers pulled over, exited their vehicles and began slapping the cars windows in an effort to arouse the motorist, who was slumped over the wheel. I do not know the drivers fate, as I was traveling in the leftmost lane.

title: The Body Weight-Muscle Mismatch
description: Recently scientists at Penn State sewed tiny weighted vests and slipped them around the middles of healthy laboratory rats, hoping to discover how animals muscles respond to changes in body size. The vests increased the animals weight by as much as 36 percent. After five days, the scientists found that the rats muscles contained increased amounts of certain proteins involved in the generation of muscle force. The muscles were redesigning themselves to be stronger.

Tuesday night, they hit virtually every note and rolled the Oklahoma City Thunder, 121-112, to take a 1-0 lead in the Western Conference finals.

title: Dirty Politics: From Halls of Power to Hotel Suites
description: Had the sexual assault charges against Dominique Strauss-Kahn, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, never surfaced, The Good Wife would have invented them. It is easy to imagine that the writers are already mining a story from his ugly circumstances for a forthcoming script. (And then moving on to an episode about Arnold Schwarzenegger.) The details would change  the nationality of the accused might shift from French to Italian; the I.M.F. might become the Fund for Global Monetary Alliance; the New York hotel suite where the police said the attack took place might become a hospital room in Chicago.

They contend that some of Commons lyrics about should make him ineligible for such an honor. What do you think about Commons participation in the White House event?

description: LONDON  On the second day of a visit to the Irish Republic, Queen Elizabeth II on Wednesday visited the site of a massacre more than 90 years ago that still evokes memories of fierce hostilities between Ireland and Britain.

title: In Prague, Celebrating the Richness of Romani
description: The rhythmic, pulsating sounds of brass and rich voices, a film premiere and a wedding reconstruction are all part of the festive week of Khamoro in Prague. Now in its 13th year, the Khamoro Festival, which runs from May 22 to 28, aims to show the richness of Romani culture, and contribute to the integration of Roma into society, while also encouraging the improvement of relations between the Romani community and Czech society.

title: Adaptive Bombshells
description: Tim Harford, a columnist for The Financial Times, has a book out this month, Adapt: Why Success Always Starts With Failure. Its an argument about the virtues  and necessity, really  of trial and error. In his words, there are three essential steps: to try new things, in the expectations that some will fail; to make failure survivable, because it will be common; and to make sure that you know when youve failed. It sort of seems like common sense, but the books wealth of fascinating case studies shows just how uncommon and difficult it often is for people and institutions to follow such a program.

title: H.P. Dodges a Thunderbolt
description: Hewlett-Packard, the worlds largest personal computer manufacturer, announced Tuesday that it would not be installing Intels new Thunderbolt I/O connections on its desktop computers. The company said it would continue fitting USB 3.0 connections to its machines.

description: EAGLE LAKE, Miss.  If you need to get ahold of somebody here, this is how.

title: Are We Cutting Fat or Bone?
description: I have spent many years focusing on how to increase revenue in my custom picture-framing business. Much of what weve done has worked, and the business is now roughly 20 times the size of the average framing shop in America. Lately, however, because of the economy, the housing crisis, and other factors, the framing industry has shrunk, and I now spend quite a bit of time looking for cost reductions.

title: Preakness TV Coverage
description: The NBC Sports Group will not televise the post position draw ahead of the Preakness Stakes as it did for the Kentucky Derby. Instead, HRTV will broadcast the draw from Pimlico Race Course at 5 p.m. Eastern on Wednesday as part of its Pursuit of the Crown show. On Friday, the Animal Kingdom extravaganza will begin in earnest.

title: Raccoon Peekaboo
Can Newt Gingrich Control Newt Gingrich?
description: The problem for Newt Gingrich does not appear to be a lack of self-awareness. But self-awareness is not the same thing as self-control.

title: Even Offstage, Lady Gagas Ready for the Stage
description: EVEN for a rehearsal, Lady Gaga dresses up. She was preparing to headline the annual gala for the Robin Hood Foundation, a gathering of 4,000 of New York Citys richest people to benefit antipoverty programs, in a ballroom at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center on May 9.

title: Brad Pitt Discusses The Tree of Life
description: CANNES, France  At the Cannes Film Festival, the world capital of auteur cinema, The Tree of Life was greeted with the sense of occasion befitting a Terrence Malick movie. But for much of the assembled media at this glamour-hungry event, it was also  and perhaps more to the point  a Brad Pitt movie. In fact, a good number of journalists left the films Monday morning press screening early to get in line for the news conference, where Mr. Pitt was the star attraction. (Mr. Malick, as expected, was not there.)

title: Bloomberg Lobbies for Gay Marriage. Well, It Couldnt Hurt.
description: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg went to Albany to ask that lawmakers make it possible for gay couples to marry in New York State. Naturally, advocates of same-sex marriage applauded him. They might just as easily have said, Uh, oh.

title: Blogging Morgan Stanleys Annual Meeting
description: There was no shortage of good topics on which shareholders can grill Morgan Stanleys chief executive, James P. Gorman, at the firms annual meeting on Wednesday in Purchase, N.Y.

title: Upfronts: CBS Adds Three Dramas, Two Sitcoms for Fall
description: From a position of strength, CBS is adding three dramas and two sitcoms to its prime-time schedule in the fall, and is moving several of its established franchises to new time slots.

title: Follow Their Nose
description: If there is a place that the name Astier de Villatte conjures, it is most definitely Paris. For 15 years, Ivan Pericoli and Benot Astier de Villatte have been creating furniture and wonderfully goopy, overglazed ceramics which they sell from their charming shop on the rue Saint Honor. But when the two set out to create a new collection of candles, they broadened their horizons, following their noses  in their imaginations, at least  to far flung places like Brasilia and Kobe. Of the 20 different destination-oriented scents, created in collaboration with the fragrance company Takasago, some might seem vaguely familiar: Naples, for example, is a bouquet of almond, orange blossom, and Ylang-Ylang, lightened by a refreshing touch of petitgrain and neroli. Alcatraz, on the other hand (Indian blond tobacco, yerba mat with its notes of dried hay, smoked lignum vitae and cinnamon spiced with black pepper) seems to have been conjured not from an actual three-hour tour but a dream. And what is the smell of home? Rue Saint Honor is described as a powdery cloud in which a few delicate green notes and a jasmine rose accord merge deliciously with the amber and leather atmosphere.

title: Youve Got to Start Somewhere: A Climate Prescription
description: Hoping to find a way around the current political impasse on climate change and energy policy, a former top adviser to President Obama has devised a policy proposal to drive down greenhouse gas emissions from the utility industry over the next 20 years.

title: The Hot-Money Cowboys of Baghdad
description: My friend, Iraq is a rich, virgin country! one of its richest men, Namir al-Akabi, told me with a startling enthusiasm when I met him earlier this year at his office in Baghdad. Akabi is the chairman of the Almco Group of Companies, a conglomerate he built from nothing in the wake of the American invasion in 2003. What makes Iraqs economic potential so great, he explained, despite everything, is not just its abundant natural resources  it is the shattered state of Iraq itself: the damage done by the American war, but also the long, steady decay under Saddam Hussein, from the war with Iran that began in 1980 through the invasion of Kuwait a decade later and the crushing international sanctions that followed the first gulf war. The country has been decimated, and therein lies its potential.

title: Barbaro: Getting Ready for the Derby
description: Alex Brown, a regular contributor to The Rail, is author of the newly published Greatness and Goodness: Barbaro and His Legacy. In this excerpt, he describes Barbaros preparations before his dazzling performance in the Kentucky Derby.

description: Two months after an atomic bomb destroyed Hiroshima, President Harry S. Truman commissioned a study of the damage done to the city.

title: Allstate Buys Insurance Businesses for $1 Billion
description: 2:58 p.m. | Updated The Allstate Corporation said on Wednesday that it had agreed to acquire two insurance businesses from the White Mountains Insurance Group for about $1 billion.

title: Huntsman Chooses Orlando for 2012 Headquarters
description: Jon M. Huntsman Jr. is a former governor of Utah. He now lives in Washington. But the site of his presidential campaign  if he jumps into the race next month  will be in Florida.

title: Wednesday Reading: Fewer Emergency Rooms As Need Rises
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

title: Reaction to The Good Wife Finale: Your Questions Answered

title: Philip Roth Wins Man Booker International Prize in Disputed Decision
description: Calling him the most decorated living American writer, a panel named Philip Roth the winner of the Man Booker International Prize on Wednesday, an honor awarded every two years to an author for extraordinary work in fiction.

title: A Handmade Tale
description: I wanted to do something with my hands, says James Roberts, explaining how he became a shoemaker. Together with Thom Grogan, Roberts owns Captains of Industry, a gentlemans outfitter and cafe in Melbourne, Australia. Grogan, who runs the bespoke-suiting side of the business, thinks the Internet Age has inspired a craving for things that arent mass-produced. People are getting pretty sick of being anonymous online and just buying stuff through online stores, he says. They want interaction. Roberts and Grogan dont stop at shoes and jams: they even make their own thread from scratch. Its kind of relaxing, Roberts says, if all goes well. View interactive feature >>

title: Kitchen Coverup
description: On Gadgetwise, Damon Darlin presents a few new ways to keep iPads and other tablet computers clean and neat while youre cooking. His favorite is Chef Sleeve, a clear plastic envelope that costs less than a buck and lets you use the touch screen with greasy fingers. Plus its box doubles as an iPad stand.

title: X-Ray Scan Reveals 513 Migrants in 2 Trucks
description: When police ran X-ray scanners over two cargo trucks at a checkpoint in southeastern Mexico on Tuesday, they made a surprising discovery: Inside the trailer were the ghostly shadows of 513 migrants  some suffering from dehydration  packed together in near-suffocating conditions.

title: Overseer of 9/11 Health Fund Is Chosen
description: WASHINGTON  The Justice Department on Wednesday chose a special master to administer a multibillion-dollar fund created to provide compensation to rescue workers and others sickened from exposure to toxic fumes, dust and smoke from ground zero after the 2001 terrorist attack.

Best Western has even hired Cesar Millan of National Geographic Channels Dog Whisperer to be the chains pet travel expert.

This week, two of his granddaughters stopped by The New York Times. Alexandra and Cline Cousteau, cousins, did not seem to know each others schedule but were on the same wavelength in some other respects.

description: Eventbrite, a ticketing start-up based in San Francisco, got its start by offering to help any event organizer peddle tickets  whether it be for a yoga class or an indie comedy show.

description: The globe-trotting surferati have been quietly colonizing Mexicos Pacific coast for years. Alongside cheap and cheery beach shacks, you now find famous artists hanging out in French bistros. But not all is spoiled; the stretch of coastline from Acapulco to Puerto Vallarta offers a range of surf towns, from established to emerging. Pick your paradise.

title: Bedtime Books for Boys
description: Bedtime stories are charged with the mighty, sometimes seemingly insurmountable task of quieting and perhaps even inducing an audience to slumber. At the very least, theyre meant to compel the intended listener, say, a 4-year old boy, to stop somersaulting off the bunk bed and to please, please sit down. (That this process is often fraught with irritation has recently been showcased by a forthcoming children's-book parody, Go the  to Sleep, by Adam Mansbach and Ricardo Corts, whose appearance online ricocheted among parental Twitterers like the answer key to next weeks S.A.T. exam.)

title: Sex-Assault Case Puts Focus on Police Unit, Not Quite as Seen on TV
description: In some ways, last weekend was not especially remarkable for the New York Police Departments Special Victims Squad. About 30 new cases came in, typical for the citywide unit of 190 specially trained investigators and supervisors.

title: W.T.O. Ruling on Airbus Subsidies Upheld on Appeal

title: In Earth v. Humanity, Nobelists Issue Verdict

title: In His Dreams? Not Quite. David Hyde Pierce Plans His Directing Debut
description: After 11 seasons spent playing the Jungian analyst Niles Crane on Frasier and a parallel career on the stages of Broadway productions including Monty Pythons Spamalot, Curtains and La Bte, David Hyde Pierce, the Emmy and Tony Award-winning actor is ready for a change of scenery. Hell be sitting in the front of the house when he makes his directorial debut with It Shoulda Been You, a musical comedy that will be presented at the George Street Playhouse in New Brunswick, N.J., this fall.

title: Sleep Loggers, Take Two
description: Bryson Voirin, a doctoral student at the Max Planck Institute for Ornithology in Germany and a fellow at the Smithsonian Tropical Research Institute in Panama, writes from Panama, where he is studying sleep in wild frigate birds.
