description: To underscore the priority that Discovery Communications says it is placing on Hispanic viewers, the president and chief executive, David Zaslav, made a herculean effort to attend the Discovery U.S. Hispanic upfront presentation at the Four Seasons restaurant in Midtown Manhattan on Wednesday.

title: A NATO Raid Sets Off a Deadly Afghan Protest
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A normally peaceful northern city erupted in violence on Wednesday, as thousands of protesters clashed with security forces after a NATO night raid that local officials claim killed four civilians. NATO defended the night operation and said the four people who were killed, two of them women, were armed insurgents who fired on its troops.

title: Another Month, Another Home
description: For five years, Jim Casparie pleaded with his parents, Robert and Virginia Casparie, to accept more help. His father, then 91, had Alzheimers disease, and his mother, 84, had diabetes and poor balance, falling frequently. When they finally agreed to move to an independent living apartment in 2008, Mr. Casparie, 61, an investment banker, thought at last he could stop worrying about their safety.

title: Air Force One Lands Safely After Circling
description: Amid poor visibility and a light rain, Air Force One had a missed approach before landing safely at Bradley International Airport near Hartford on Wednesday morning, White House officials said.

title: Widow of Madoff Son to Write Memoir
description: A member of the Madoff family is telling all in a memoir to be released in December, its publisher said on Wednesday. Stephanie Madoff-Mack, the widow of Mark Madoff, the son of Bernard L. Madoff who committed suicide last year, sold her book to Blue Rider Press, an imprint of Penguin Group USA. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Best Wishes Turn Middling
description: FORGETTING a friends birthday used to be uncomplicated. The excuse would be made, the gaffe forgiven. But among the many changes wrought by Facebook, the sites ritual birthday reminders  those jolly alerts on the edge of that blue-and-white screen  have rendered old rules moot.

title: Extending Credit Card Protections to Small Business Users
description: Each month, Americans get more than 10 million business credit card pitches in their home mailboxes. The cards are aimed at small businesses and sole proprietors, but they generally lack the new protections that apply to consumer cards, a new report from the Pew Charitable Trusts says.

title: Improving the View at the Beach
description: OUR guarantee: 10 seconds after putting on a pair of Orlebar Brown swim trunks, you will immediately lose your muffin top, develop a six-pack and instantly bear an uncanny resemblance to the smooth god-beings in the accompanying photograph.

title: Performance Art and Immigrant Rights
description: Tania Bruguera, an artist, works to address issues facing illegal immigrants.

title: An Artists Performance: A Year as a Poor Immigrant
description: Tania Bruguera has eaten dirt, hung a dead lamb from her neck and served trays of cocaine to a gallery audience, all in the name of art. She has shown her work at the Venice Biennale, been feted at the Pompidou Center in Paris and landed a Guggenheim fellowship.

title: Wishful Wedges and the Energy Quest
description: 10:02 p.m. | UpdatedRob Socolow of Princeton University is quoted by National Geographic as saying the popular wedges approach to charting climate progress that he proposed with his colleague Stephen Pacala in 2004 was misused by climate campaigners to overstate the ease with which the world could cut tens of billions of tons of heat-trapping carbon dioxide emissions out of its energy menu.

title: Cannes Q. and A.: Nanni Moretti on Tackling Big Game
description: CANNES, France Outspoken in interviews and in his offscreen role as a political activist, the Italian writer, director and actor Nanni Moretti tends to take a lighter touch in his films. Habemus Papam (We Have a Pope), screening in the official competition at the Cannes Film Festival, concerns a newly elected pope named Melville (the French actor Michel Piccoli), whose existential panic attack prompts the cardinals to call in a psychoanalyst (Mr. Moretti). But while the shrink is sequestered at the Vatican, the pope goes on a walkabout through the streets of Rome, rekindling an old love of acting as he stumbles into a theater production of Chekhovs Seagull.

title: Test Head
description: Test description text.

title: Can Batteries Replace Power Generators?
description: When the Long Island Power Authority said last summer that it was going to need new power capacity in the next few years, most people assumed that meant new generating stations or new transmission cables. But of the 16 companies that submitted proposals, one, AES Energy Storage, took an entirely different tack: it proposed batteries.

title: Fate Hands Cavaliers the No. 1 Overall Pick
description: There is a salty New York flavor to the New Jersey narrative of Kyrie Irving, who made the 20-minute drive from his home in West Orange to the N.B.A. Entertainment studio in Secaucus on Tuesday night and landed with both feet inside a made-for-television draft lottery drama.

title: Maggie Gyllenhaal to Replace Streep in Reading of Play About Marie Curie
description: Citing a scheduling conflict, Meryl Streep has dropped out of a reading of Alan Aldas new play about Marie Curie at the World Science Festival gala at Alice Tully Hall on June 1. Maggie Gyllenhaal, whose most recent appearance on a New York Stage was in Three Sisters, is taking on the role of that pioneering scientist in Radiance: The Passion of Marie Curie at the fund-raising event. Bob Balaban is directing the reading, which will also feature Amy Adams, Bill Camp, Allison Janney, David Morse, Liev Schreiber and Brent Sexton.

title: The Morning Line: Full Field for Preakness, Minus Nehro
description: The lead story on the Triple Crown trail is the decision of the owner Amed Zayat not to enter his horse Nehro in the Preakness. Nehro finished second in the Kentucky Derby. Zayats racing manager said in the New York Post, The main decision came down to Mr. Zayat feeling it was a little much to ask the horse to run four great races in an eight-week time frame. Zayat told the Daily News, I let my horse tell me what the next step is. In the last six weeks hes run a lot. Ive got to be kind to him. Patience rewards you. I dont want to get my ego involved. You do what is right by the horse.

title: Setsuden
description: Japanese term for energy saving, which became a buzzword after the March 11 earthquake and tsunami.

title: Sex and the Politician
description: David Brooks: Gail, can I talk to you about that hoary old intersection between private life and politics?

title: Whats Wrong and Whats Right With These Web Sites?
description: One thing Ive learned over the years is that the quality of a Web site depends as much on the quality of the design and the effectiveness of the messaging as it does on the amount of money invested in technology and features. Thats why there are lots of major companies that have invested millions in their online business but have Web sites that fail miserably.

title: Tiny Treasures | Missbibis Dollhouse Gems
description: At 43 square feet, Missbibi, the recently opened jewelry store in Pariss Palais Royal, is so small, if you blink on your way down the arcade you might miss it. This suits Brigitte Giraudi, 34, who is known as Miss Bibi, just fine. Ive always appreciated small, delicate, beautifully made things, says the jeweler, who turned from stop-motion animation and miniature model construction to sautoirs and broaches. Oddly enough it was Giraudis fascination with dollhouse furniture that spurred her move to jewelry.

title: Chinas Rich Try to Fly Around Red Tape
description: WENZHOU, China  Here in this smoggy coastal metropolis, the nouveau-riche heart of entrepreneurial China, the latest sign that one has really made it is not a Benz, or even a Bentley. It is a helicopter. Perhaps 10 of Wenzhous super-rich have one.

title: Jazz at Noon Is Closing Out a 46-Year Run
description: Leslie Lieber wants to make it clear: His age is not the issue.

title: Lars von Trier Kicks Ups a Cannes Controversy
description: CANNES, France  It wouldnt be a film festival without a little controversy. On Wednesday at the Cannes Film Festival, the director Lars von Trier caused a media firestorm when, at a news conference for his film Melancholia, he seemed to sympathize with Hitler.

title: The Lessons of Gingrich v. Ryan
description: There are two obvious ways to look at the firestorm that greeted Newt Gingrichs criticisms of the Ryan budget, and the humiliating walkback that quickly followed. From one perspective, its a sign that Gingrich is hopelessly out-of-touch with his own partys newfound seriousness about tackling entitlements. Thus Pete Wehner:

title: Cast Adrift in the Milky Way, Billions of Planets, All Alone
description: Is the galaxy full of orphans?

title: Harsh Light on Two Men, but Glare Falls on Women
description: A flotilla of TV news trucks was stationed outside a Bronx apartment building this week, as photographers scrambled to get a shot of the hotel cleaning woman who accused the managing director of the International Monetary Fund of sexually assaulting her. Inside, reporters fired questions at her neighbors: Was she good-looking? Did she pay her rent on time? What was her behavior like?

title: Darby Downstairs
description: THE Darby, a seven-month-old supper club that occupies the former Nells space, quietly opened a subterranean lounge in April, trying to recapture some of the spots old magic. Called the Darby Downstairs, the basement bar (with a separate entrance) is run by Richie Akiva, Ronnie Madra and Scott Sartiano  night-life veterans who operate Butter and 1Oak, which cater to bankers and models.

title: Safety Agency Cracks Down on Novelty Motorcycle Helmets
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has revised its labeling for new motorcycle helmets.

title: Caucus | Obama and the Middle East
description: The Times's Mark Landler in Washington and David Kirkpatrick in Cairo report on President Obama's challenges ahead of a speech tomorrow on the Middle East.

title: Now Remapping His Life
description: A WHITE cockatoo named Koko rested on the shoulder of Florent Morellet, its blood-curdling shrieks punctuating Mr. Morellets raspy French accent. In all his years in New York he never had a pet, until one day last August the cockatoo just flew into his massive, art-filled loft on Lafayette Street in SoHo.

title: No Jail Time for Ex-Political Boss in Pension Case
description: Raymond B. Harding, the former chairman of the New York State Liberal Party, was spared jail time on Wednesday for his role in a pay-to-play scheme involving the states $141 billion pension fund.

title: U.S. Imposes Sanctions on Syrian Leader and 6 Aides
description: WASHINGTON  The United States intensified political and economic pressure on Syria on Wednesday by imposing sanctions on President Bashar al-Assad and six other senior Syrian officials in the wake of a bloody crackdown on political protests in the country.

title: Cash Crops Under Glass and Up on the Roof
description: When Lufa Farms began selling produce to customers in Montreal in late April, it signaled what could be the beginning of a tantalizing new era in the gastronomic fortunes of that Canadian metropolis.

title: Video: President Obama and the Middle East
description: Mark Landler in Washington and David Kirkpatrick in Cairo report on the challenges facing President Obama as he prepares to deliver a major speech on the Middle East on Thursday.

title: Homes for $1.3 Million
description: A condo in a 1920 building in Seattle; a house in Boston built in 1860; and a contemporary in San Diego.

title: What You Get for ... $1.3 Million
description: SEATTLE

title: Beware the Doorman Wielding an iPad
description: ITS 2 a.m. at Lavo, the East 58th Street hot spot, and theres an impenetrable mob radiating from a single point: the doorman. His name is Richard Wheeler, he speaks softly with a British accent, and hes not nearly as intimidating as the two beefy bouncers who flank him.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Africa and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from South Africa, Kuwait and Russia.

title: Spike Jonze Finds Inspiration in a Handbag
description: CANNES, France - The directors here are serious of purpose, creating films that take on love, death, social ills, political turmoil, and, in the case of Terrence Malick in his Tree of Life, even the origin of the universe itself.

title: California Special Election Produces Unexpected Result
description: It was supposed to be a race among Democrats to succeed Representative Jane Harman in one of the most Democratic districts in the county.

title: Teachers Union Sues to Stop School Closings
description: 9:51 p.m. | Updated The United Federation of Teachers filed a lawsuit on Wednesday in an effort to halt two tools the citys Education Department uses to change the school system: closing schools for poor performance and giving charter schools space in buildings occupied by traditional public schools.

title: As Stimulus Nears End, Fed Signals Focus on Rates
description: A majority of Federal Reserve policy makers said at their most recent meeting that the best next step in their program to stimulate the economy would be to reduce the balance sheet and then focus on interest rates, according to minutes of the April meeting released on Wednesday. But they also said that simply discussing interest rates and other options did not mean that any move would necessarily begin soon.

title: Do My High School Jeans Still Fit?
description: IN the early 1990s, when I was in high school, one of my best friends got an after-school job at his local Gap. I could only imagine the glories, which seemed as foreign as Gstaad or Marrakesh: the folding, making those stacks of T-shirts perfectly neat! The chance to listen to the company-issue store soundtracks, filled with hits of the day, over and over! The discounts!

title: Everything Is Illuminated | Rinko Kawauchi at the Herms Gallery
description: The Japanese photographer Rinko Kawauchi is finely tuned to what she likes to call the small voices in our world  those that whisper. Her eyes, she says, naturally focus on small things. And her latest body of work, Illuminance, which provides the content for both an exhibition, opening Friday at the Herms gallery, and a lush book published by Aperture, is resplendent in them. A tiny green frog perches on the palm of a seemingly enormous hand; a lit cigarette, its ash a fiery orange, juts from the fingers of another. A slab of raw tuna is approached in such proximity that it takes on the monumentality of landscape. An image of goldfish packed to the gills in a plastic bag brings to mind the Tokyo subway during rush hour.

title: Consumer Bureau Plans New Mortgage Form
description: The mountains of paperwork are one of the few certainties of home buying.

title: Answers About the N.B.A. Playoffs and More
description: The following are the responses from Jonathan Abrams and Howard Beck, who took questions from readers this week about the N.B.A. playoffs, which head into the conference finals, as well as the Knicks and Nets.

title: Are Talent Acquisitions a Sign of a New Bubble?
description: Theres no question that the bubbly feeling has returned to Silicon Valley. The signs are everywhere. Lavish parties are back and so are the highly valued start-ups. Theres a seeming frenzy over the coming LinkedIn IPO. And now, theres a surge in talent acquisitions, which I wrote about today.

title: Under a Cosmic Magnifying Glass
description: An illustration of the method by which astronomers using a ground-based telescope found evidence for 10 free-floating, Jupiter-mass planets in space.

title: Personal Hardware
description: When I ventured into the world of personal manufacturing for last Sundays magazine article, The Kitchen-Table Industrialists, I found myself itching to make something myself. Like many urban professionals, I spend a lot of time producing things on a screen and very little time making anything tangible  besides lunch. As I describe in my article, I tried, on a trip to Detroit, to make an iPad stand, based on a design I downloaded from the Web. But the 3-D printer  yes, this exists  kept botching it. So I scaled back my ambitions and 3-D printed this lovely hexagonal nut. Its not much, and its not much use without a bolt, but its something.

title: Charles Schwab to Offer Index-Only 401(k) Plans
description: Ron Liebers Your Money column last weekend urged investors to ask their employers for more index-fund choices in their 401(k) retirement plans. Many plans are heavy on actively managed funds, even though index funds offer lower administrative costs and relatively lower risk that benefit investors as they build their nest eggs.

title: In Amsterdam, a Loft on a Canal
description: A two-bedroom loft condominium in a former candy factory overlooking the Looiersgracht canal in Amsterdam is on the market for $1.4 million.

title: House Hunting in ... Amsterdam
description: A LOFT IN A FORMER FACTORY ON A CANAL IN THE NETHERLANDS

title: Crime Pays Again for CBS
description: A Dancing With the Stars elimination episode attracted 17.7 million viewers on Tuesday night, according to Nielsens estimates. The ABC reality show won its 9 p.m. time slot but for the night over all the network finished in second place behind CBSs lineup of crime show finales, including NCIS (18.1 million) and NCIS: Los Angeles (15.4 million).

title: Key Question Is Left Open as Medvedev Faces Media
description: SKOLKOVO, Russia  As the start of President Dmitri A. Medvedevs news conference drew near on Wednesday, 800 journalists were in such a state of anticipation that they burst into spontaneous applause when an aide climbed up to the podium to adjust a teacup set out for the president.

title: Another Long Gallop for Animal Kingdom
description: Steeplechase Times is with Animal Kingdom at the Fair Hill Training Center as he prepares for the Preakness Stakes on Saturday. On Wednesday, Joe Clancy captured the scene:

title: Indias Anti-Poverty Programs Are Big but Troubled
description: NEW DELHI  India spends more on programs for the poor than most developing countries, but it has failed to eradicate poverty because of widespread corruption and faulty government administration, the World Bank said Wednesday.

title: Adele Is at No. 1 for 8th Week, but Lady Gaga Is On Deck
description: Adele still dominates the Billboard charts, but with Lady Gaga on deck her reign probably wont last much longer.

title: At a Time of Needed Financial Overhaul, a Leadership Vacuum
description: After the worst crisis since the Great Depression, President Obama has unleashed an unusual force to regulate the financial system: a bunch of empty seats.

title: Changing of the Guard on Morgan Library & Museum Board
description: When the board of the Morgan Library & Museum meets on Thursday afternoon, a new president will preside for the first time in time 23 years. Lawrence R. Ricciardi, a retired I.B.M. executive, is taking over the post from S. Parker Gilbert, who held it for more than two decades.

title: In Nebraska, Alfresco Automobile Trove Awaits Bidders
description: Car collectors, in their undying quests for the Find, would not let the pending liquidation of a salvage yard full of old and rusting vehicles go unnoticed.

title: A Familiar Face in Peru, and a More Local Recruiting Effort
description: In a sunny auditorium in Trujillo, Peru, the other day, a crowd of political activists waved orange flags and shouted, Rud, Rud, Rud!

title: Endangered Species Ecotourism: Developing Citizen Science Travel Itineraries
description: Overview | What are endangered species? How and where can people observe and encounter endangered species in the world today? In this lesson, students survey endangered species across the country and around the world. They explore the ecosystems where different endangered species live and develop ecotourism itineraries to introduce travelers to endangered species across the globe.

title: Roaming the Streets, Taking Surreal Turns
description: The narrator of Teju Coles odd, sometimes striking, sometimes frustrating first novel is a med student named Julius who likes to wander through the streets of New York City, and the book is filled with arresting, strobe-lit glimpses of Manhattan, this strangest of islands.

title: Jane Pratt, Unbound and Ready for the Web
description: THE model Veronica Webb made charming faces at the camera. Michael Stipe, the lead vocalist for R.E.M., cozied up to a snake. The actor David Arquette designed a T-shirt that read: I love. Therefore I am.

title: Want a Copy of Obamas Birth Certificate?
description: President Obama took the issue of where he was born seriously enough to release his long-form birth certificate last month. But his campaign is not above using it to have a bit of fun.

title: Delta-Northwest Mergers Long and Complex Path
description: ATLANTA  How many chimes should pilots ring to signal the plane is about to land  two or four? Should flight attendants first pour drinks into a cup or just hand over the can?

title: Searching for a Job? Try Looking at Your Hand-Held First
description: If youre consulting a mobile app for advice while youre on the way to a big job interview, you may be a little desperate, a little lazy or maybe just not too bright.

title: Another Day in the Hawkeye State
description: Another day in Iowa, where complete strangers say irony-free things like Jeez! Thanks for stopping by! (Think Frances McDormand in Fargo.)

title: Beyond Bunny Yeagers Lens, a Shy Pinup
description: Bunny Yeager is shunning the cameras, for the moment at least. Strange, since only last week she professed in an interview: I like to pose. I like to be in front of anybodys camera.

title: At This Event, the Drinks Are on Bernie Madoff
description: If people are willing to pay $6,000 for Bernard L. Madoffs velveteen bedroom slippers, what will they pay for the contents of his liquor cabinet?

title: At Least the Outfield Grass Will Be Green
description: Our friends at Above the Fold point out today that Major League Baseball has had more rainouts through this point of the season than ever before.

title: Retired Detective Charged With Holding Up Drugstores for Pain Pills
description: Updated, May 19 | A former police detective was arrested Tuesday in connection with a string of gunpoint robberies of Brooklyn pharmacies in which the holdup man demanded narcotics rather than money, the Brooklyn district attorneys office said.

title: This Is Your Brain on Twitter
description: 5:47 p.m. | Updated  Adding response from Bill Keller at the end.

title: Republican Senators Query I.R.S. on Nonprofit Donations
description: A group of Republican senators wrote to the head of the Internal Revenue Service on Wednesday seeking internal correspondence and other information regarding the agencys heightened scrutiny of donations to some nonprofit advocacy groups that are playing a growing role in political campaigns.

title: Getting Cozy in Public
description: In a global phenomenon, yarn bombers are taking their brightly colored fuzzy work to Europe, Asia and beyond.

title: Chanos Defends Whitneys Call on Munis
description: In an interview with CNBC, James Chanos, president and founder of Kynikos Associates, defends the analyst Meredith Whitneys bearish call on municipal bonds, saying that investors werent being compensated for the risks.

title: At Age 99, Outliving Your Bandmates
description: Les Lieber, 99, has run a weekly lunchtime jam session for nonprofessional musicians since 1945. But interest is waning, and the longtime series may close.

title: Gelfand to Play Grischuk in Candidates Finals
description: The final two players in the World Candidates Matches in Kazan, Russia, were anything but expected when the event began.

title: A Woolly Trend
description: "Charging Bull," near Wall Street, was covered in crochet by Olek, an artist in New York.

title: Graffitis Cozy, Feminine Side
description: THE bronze statue of Rocky near the Philadelphia Museum of Art irked Jessie Hemmons. She found the statue too big, too macho and too touristy, so last month Ms. Hemmons, a 24-year-old artist, bombed him. With pinkish yarn.

title: A Favorite Emerges for Helm of I.M.F.
description: PARIS  The French finance minister, Christine Lagarde, was on a panel at the World Economic Forum in Davos this January when her usual smile turned into a frown. Next to her, Robert E. Diamond Jr., chief executive of Barclays and one of the most powerful bankers in the world, thanked regulators and finance ministers for their role in shaping a better environment after the financial crisis.

title: Upfronts: Turner Brings New Series to TBS and TNT
description: After joking his way (very effectively) through the technical glitches that plagued his companys upfront presentation Wednesday morning, the Turner Entertainment president, Steve Koonin, urged advertisers to stop leaving the event and promised Turners networks, TNT and TBS, would be on all but equal footing with the broadcast networks in the coming year.

title: Where Do You Surf?
description: T asked insiders from the surfing and design worlds to weigh in with their favorite surf spots.

title: How to Merge Two Airlines
description: After Delta and Northwest announced their merger in 2008, they began planning for what turned out to be an 18-month sprint to integrate 1,200 systems across the airlines. Managers built this master guide. Each note represents a project that could involve thousands of tasks.

title: Live Blogging the Upfronts: CBS
description: CBS is bringing advertisers to Carnegie Hall  in the midst of a monster rainstorm in midtown Manhattan  for a preview of its fall 2011 schedule. It is adding five shows in the fall and doing so from a position of strength, since it continues to draw more total viewers than any other broadcaster.

title: Gates Says No Sign That Top Pakistanis Knew of Bin Laden
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said Wednesday that he surmised that somebody in Pakistan had been aware that Osama bin Laden was hiding in a compound in the Pakistani garrison town of Abbottabad, but that there was no evidence so far that anyone in the countrys senior leadership had known.

title: Pictures of the Day: South Africa and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from South Africa, Libya, Kuwait and Russia.

title: Remembering the Gracious Harmon Killebrew
description: BALTIMORE  I never watched Harmon Killebrew play or had the pleasure of meeting him, but I felt a connection with him. One of my favorite things to do when I got home from school was to turn on ESPN and watch reruns of Home Run Derby, which pitted some of baseballs top power hitters against each other in, yes, a home run hitting contest.

title: TimesCast | May 18, 2011
description: The U.S. imposes sanctions on Syria's president and six aides; Roger Cohen on President Obama's Mideast policy speech on Thursday; and "The Good Wife" starts its second season amidst two scandals.

title: Into the Trenches
description: CONSPIRACY theorists, start your search engines. If ever there was a season and a reason to be suspicious, it is now. Did Mother Nature secretly collude with Uncle Fashion to create this springs retail phenomenon: the trench coat?

title: Trading Up: Trench Coats for Men
description: The rainy-day staple returns with a sleek update, ditching heavier cuts for sleek, modern silhouettes.

title: How Many Stars Must a Man Run Down?
description: In a blog post for Diners Journal this morning I said that Gotham Bar and Grill, which I wrote about this week, had been reviewed four times by The New York Times.

title: In England, Four Floors and a Lot of Steps
description: In 2007, Eric Guibert, left and Robin Pembrooke, sold their home to buy a 6,000-square-foot former factory building in Kennington, England.

title: Finding His Inner Sinatra, the Always Charming One
description: Tom Postilio, a suave, witty Frank Sinatra acolyte with a mischievous twinkle in his eye, remembers the epiphanic moment when he first saw his idol in June 1984 at Carnegie Hall. He was 14 years old.

title: In England, a Former Factory to Call Home
description: LONDON  Four years ago, Eric Guibert, an architect, and his fianc, Robin Pembrooke, an online television executive, were growing tired of their two-bedroom home in Waterloo, a bustling South London neighborhood. Mr. Guibert, whose specialty is developing unconventional properties like reclaimed churches and barns, took issue with many of its features.

title: Senate Rejects Republican Bill on Exploration for Oil and Gas
description: WASHINGTON  With Democrats citing last years oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico as a cautionary tale, the Senate on Wednesday decisively rejected a Republican plan to allow more coastal oil and gas exploration and to speed the issuance of drilling permits to oil companies.

title: Turkish Magnate Puts His Passion on Display
description: The textile magnate Oner Kocabeyoglu is exhibiting the work of more than 430 works by 20 modern artists from his country.

title: Shopping Snapshots for May 19
description: The Spanish designer Agatha Ruiz de la Prada opens a store; sample sales from Derek Lam and Steven Alan; other items, sales and events in New York.

title: Scott Brooks and the Task of Stopping Nowitzki
description: Scott Brookss team faces an impossible riddle in defending Dirk Nowitzki, but on a micro level, Brooks has stumbled into an interesting opportunity for redemption. No coach has taken a bigger hit to his reputation over the course of this postseason than Brooks. Phil Jackson was ushered out gracefully, despite his teams being swept by the Dallas Mavericks in the second round. Gregg Popovich did what he could, but succumbed to the fate of an aging roster. Doc Rivers coached admirably in the face of injuries to his team, but a series win against the Heat wasnt in the cards.

title: Finding Family History Online
description: For those on a genealogy quest, large or small, these are exciting times.

title: Newly Released Books
description: This months new books, including translations from French, Spanish and Japanese, as well as one British import, offer glimpses of family life from around the world. Adult siblings, new couples and a family in political danger redefine home. Meanwhile, Will Allison looks at how a snap decision causes one American family to come undone.

title: His Own Best Character
description: OH, Jon-Jon!

title: As Citi Revives, Pandit Wins Big Pay Package
description: 8:58 p.m. | Updated

title: Extinction and its Discontents
description: May 23, 11:52 a.m. | Updated Fairly far along in my career as an environmental journalist, I had to start writing pieces that amounted to obituaries for species. First came Miss Waldrons red colobus (which popped back on the radar, at least for now). Then the Yangtze River dolphin, or baiji (pictured below), then the Chinese paddlefish.

title: The Group-Deals Craze Comes to Private Jets
description: Have you ever wanted to fly on a private jet, but the mere thought is enough to cause your wallet to panic?

title: Protesters Rally in Madrid Despite Ban
description: Thousands of protesters who say they are ignored by Spains political class gathered in a central square in Madrid on Wednesday night to demand reforms, despite an effort by electoral officials to impose a ban on demonstrations as Spain prepares to vote in local elections this weekend.

title: The Notes Behind 'Network'
description: View the letters, notes, screenplay excerpts and ideas that helped Paddy Chayefsky shape Network.

title: Fossil Sheds Light on the Lizard-Snake Divide
description: The origin of snakes is a perplexing matter.

title: The Battle for Libya | May 18, 2011
description: Four foreign journalists held by the Libyan government for six weeks were released Wednesday.

title: Where Neon Was the New Black
description: IN a city of museum titans, what fund-raising tack works for a relative newcomer? For the Museum of Arts and Design, nearing three years in its modern Columbus Circle space, the strategy seems to be young and irreverent.

title: Scene City: Museum of Art and Design Gala
description: Its spring gala tried to build cachet through its younger patrons, like Waris Ahluwalia, Tyson Beckford, Karim Rashid and Mazdack Rassi, the founder of Milk Studios in the meatpacking district.

title: LinkedIn Prices I.P.O. at Top of Forecast at $45 a Share
description: 8:36 p.m. | Updated

title: Exploring Boxwood
description: If you love green, and the deer are eating everything in your garden, boxwood  which comes in a range of shades, shapes and sizes  is a lovely alternative. Unlike English boxwood, which prefers partial shade, most will tolerate sun without turning yellow, but almost all are darker green in the shade.

title: Prestige Cant Halt Downfall of Theater
description: SEATTLE  When Bartlett Sher handpicked Kate Whoriskey to succeed him as artistic director of Intiman Theater here in 2009, he appeared to be giving her a dream job. Under Mr. Sher, Intiman had become one of the countrys most prestigious theaters, nurturing a growing audience while basking in the reflected glow of Mr. Shers increasing fame as a freelance director of operas and musicals, including an acclaimed Broadway revival of South Pacific. For Ms. Whoriskey, then 38 and best known for directing Lynn Nottages Pulitzer Prize-winning play, Ruined, Intiman seemed like the perfect artistic home.

title: Boxwood: Loving What the Deer Dont
description: POTTERSVILLE, N.J.

title: Boxwood Gardens
description: All around Andrea Filippones many gardens are wonderfully different boxwood.

title: Three Twists on Classical Style, in Movement and in Character
description: A dancer extends a leg forward above hip-height, then, keeping that leg outstretched, starts to fall forward in the direction it is pointing. By the time he has brought the raised foot down to the floor, he has transferred much of his weight to it.

title: Footnote
description: Citing a scheduling conflict, Meryl Streep has dropped out of a reading of Alan Aldas new play about Marie Curie at the World Science Festival gala at Alice Tully Hall on June 1. Maggie Gyllenhaal is taking on the role of that pioneering scientist in Radiance: The Passion of Marie Curie at the fund-raising event. Other readers are Amy Adams, Bill Camp, Allison Janney, David Morse, Liev Schreiber and Brent Sexton.

title: City Releases List of 20 Fire Companies Slated to Close
description: The city on Wednesday afternoon released a list of the 20 fire companies it is considering closing to help fill a $600 million budget gap. The city had initially refused to release the list, prompting the City Council to threaten to subpoena it.

title: Disputed Statue Is Back Home in Italy
description: A statue of a cult deity, below left, that was once the subject of litigation between the Italian government and the J. Paul Getty Museum of Los Angeles, was publicly unveiled on Tuesday in its new home in Aidone, Sicily. The Getty bought the seven-foot-tall limestone-and-marble statue in 1988 for $18 million, giving rise to a two-decade legal battle after Italian authorities determined it had been looted from Italy. The museum agreed to return the statue, often identified as Aphrodite, as part of a 2007 accord with the Italian government for the restitution of 40 illegally excavated artifacts. The statue was finally shipped to Rome in March. It has been installed in what is expected to be its permanent home, the archaeological museum in Aidone, a hilltop town near the ruins of the ancient Greek colony of Morgantina, where some experts believe the statue once stood.

title: At the Furniture Fair, Sustainable Furniture Gets Playful
description: THE table lamp is laid-back, and no wonder. Created by Peter Stathis, a San Francisco industrial designer, for Joby, a San Francisco consumer products company, Trapeze has the easygoing affect of a Bay Area windsurfer on a fair-trade coffee break.

title: Designs From the 2011 International Contemporary Furniture Fair
description: The fair showed that objects as banal as fruit crates can have flair.

title: Lawyers Push for Bail to Free Former I.M.F. Leader From Rikers
description: After spending fewer than three days in a cell on Rikers Island, Dominique Strauss-Kahn is making a new appeal to get out on bail.

title: The House of Collection
description: Assembling a 2,000-square-foot cabinet of curiosities.

title: At Home on the Farm and in E-Books
description: PINE PLAINS, N.Y.  Last Friday Susan Orlean was on the verge of some serious animal acquisitions. Her latest herd of 12 Black Angus cattle was scheduled to be dropped off within days. And the local post office could call at any minute to report that four rare and eye-catching Swedish flower hens were ready for pickup, having been shipped overnight from Florida.

title: Another Guilty Plea to Insider Trading Is Disclosed
description: 8:10 p.m. | Updated

title: Demanding Hillary Clintons E-Mail  Now
description: The Canadian company TransCanada is hoping to win State Department approval of construction of the Keystone XL pipeline, which would carry oil sands oil to the Gulf Coast for refining. To this end, it has spent $310,000 this year lobbying in Washington for the cause.

title: In Williamsburg, a Live-In Cabinet of Curiosities
description: PAIGE STEVENSON moved every few years when she was a child in the 1970s, living, among other places, in a tepee on a commune in Mendocino County, Calif.; on a goat farm near the commune; and in a Victorian house in San Francisco with her father, stepmother and a coterie of drag performers. In her adult life, she has chosen something far less nomadic: a loft in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, where she has been since 1989.

title: Shopping for 1960s Design With Wayne Burgess
description: A collector of vintage furnishings, Mr. Burgess has long been enamored of other things from the 1960s as well.

title: Schwarzeneggers Next Film May Have a Familiar Plot
description: LOS ANGELES  If all goes well, Arnold Schwarzenegger will by next year be working out a complicated relationship with an 11-year-old who unexpectedly turned up in his life. Thats the plot of his planned next movie, never mind the rest of it.

title: Paging Rick Perry: How a Southerner Could Sweep to the G.O.P. Nomination
description: Being a Southerner conveys certain advantages upon a Republican presidential candidate.

title: When It Comes to Helping Others: Just Do It
description: Its graduation season, and for the past two months Ive been traveling to campuses in the United States on a book tour to talk about service in the Marines and social entrepreneurship in Africa. One point seems to resonate with students above all of the others. From a commuter college in the plains of Indiana to Stanford and MIT, students have been latching onto one simple sentence: be a doer.

title: 1960s Design
description: IN 1961, Jaguar introduced the E-Type, a low-slung sports car with a long hood and seductively curvaceous lines. Many enthusiasts still consider it one of the most beautiful cars of all time, an opinion shared by the Museum of Modern Art, which acquired one for its permanent collection in 1996.

title: With the Matadors, Capes, Gypsies and Dancing, Who Needs a Plot?
description: Theres not much of Cervantess picaresque tale left in the ballet version of Don Quixote. The plot, taken from Book 2 of the 1615 novel, is barely there, boiled down to the aged dons quest for his dream woman, Dulcinea, and his belief that he has found her in the earthy peasant girl, Kitri. She, however, has her own problems, since her father wants her to marry a rich nobleman rather than her penniless sweetheart, the barber Basilio.

title: An Ancient Victory, Honoring a Later One
description: You would think that because Handels Judas Maccabaeus tells a vague approximation of the story of Hanukkah  or at least it portrays the Maccabees, the storys central characters  it should have become part of the seasonal repertory, as a Jewish alternative to Messiah. But it remains a rarity, and when it is performed at all  as it was on Tuesday evening by the Clarion Choir and Orchestra at Park Avenue Christian Church  it is calendar pages away from the holiday.

title: Made to Order, by Ruby Beets
description: Tiny Ruby Beets, tucked into an old silent-film theater on a side street in Sag Harbor, N.Y., is all of a sudden not so tiny, having doubled in size this month to accommodate a new line of furniture, Ruby Beets Made to Order. Sharone Einhorn and Honey Wolters, the stores owners, have long filled the place with antiquarian goods (like apothecary cabinets, bottom right) and artisanal objects (like Moroccan blankets), as well as clean-lined modern and estate-sale pieces and contemporary artwork (like seascapes by the local photographer Mary Ellen Bartley), all in a muted palette.

title: Ins and Outs of Using Gadgetry
description: Every time a reader asks me a basic question, struggles with a computer or lets a cellphone keep ringing at a performance, I have the same thought: There ought to be a license to use technology.

title: An Eco-Friendly Lamp From Foster & Partners
description: The Dash task light, a collaboration between the London-based architects Foster & Partners and designers at the office furniture company Steelcase, combines sleek styling with a tiny eco-footprint.

title: Turning Photos Into Paint-by-Numbers Art
description: Paintapic, a new service that crosses the low-tech fun of paint-by-numbers with the instant gratification of a Web click, is the brainchild of Keith Gould, a technical director for a design industry Web site and the creator of the photo app Daily Mugshot.

title: At Pop Pub, Deliberate Design for a Fast-Food Menu
description: For 15 years, the restaurateur Roy Liebenthal has been serving fast food in environments that are anything but off-the-cuff. Pop Burger and Pop Pizza, spaces created by the Turkish-born, Manhattan-based architect Ali Tayar, explored the layering of high-tech details with rough surfaces.

title: Dominique Strauss-Kahn Bail Application
description: Dominique Strauss-Kahns bail application and related exhibits.

title: Raising Concerns About Chemicals in Recycled Carpet Padding
description: Every week, it seems, a new study identifies potentially harmful chemicals in the food we eat, the makeup we wear, the toys and bottles used by our children. Next up: the recycled foam padding installed under wall-to-wall carpeting.

title: Sales at Sferra, Pottery Barn and Others
description: During the Sferra sample sale, through Sunday, down comforters and pillows, blankets, sheets, duvet covers, decorative pillows and throws, table linens and towels are up to 70 percent off (Lindsay duvet sets, originally about $620 to $732, are $275 to $325; Chase towels, pictured, regularly $7 to $57, are $2 to $22); Prive Space at Chelsea Market, 75 Ninth Avenue (15th Street), (212) 543-4300. www.ThePrive.com

title: Weighing a Tough Choice With a 5-3 Major Fit
description: The second United States team for this years Bermuda Bowl world championship will be Kevin Bathurst, Daniel Zagorin, Joe Grue, Justin Lall, John Hurd and Joel Wooldridge. Originally seeded ninth, they won the 120-board trial final in Henderson, Nev., on Tuesday against the Rosenblum Cup world champions and top seeds, John Diamond, Brian Platnick, Fred Gitelman, Brad Moss, Eric Greco and Geoff Hampson, by 288 international match points to 257.

title: TimesCast | Timely TV: "The Good Wife"
description: The Times's television critic Ginia Bellafonte on the end of second season of "The Good Wife," against the backdrop of two real-life political scandals.

title: Until the Next Revolution
description: I was 19 years old when I first heard the Kronos Quartets Howl, U.S.A. The album dons as its cover Robert Mapplethorpes stunning portrait of a tattered, weatherworn and ever-so-slightly transparent American flag. The image seemed symbolic of the music  political works by Scott Johnson, Michael Daugherty, Harry Partch (arr. Ben Johnston) and Lee Hyla  which struck me as an honest, direct and sometimes difficult-to-hear assessment of a country in tatters. I was enthralled.

title: Birth Certificate of the Son of Schwarzenegger and Baena
description: Mildred Baena gave birth to Arnold Schwarzeneggers son in 1997.

title: Thorpe Family Split Over Sons Lawsuit
description: The famed athlete Jim Thorpe is scheduled to be honored Saturday morning in the Pennsylvania town that holds his remains and carries his name. But Thorpes two surviving children will be thousands of miles away, both uninvited and uninterested.

title: Power, Status and a Charge of Rape
description: To the Editor:

title: Supporting the Peace Corps
description: To the Editor:

title: For-Profit Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: Republicans and Taxes
description: To the Editor:

title: Dear Diary, I Want to Belong
description: UNION, N.J.  Angelica Bermudez, an underachieving Division III basketball player with discipline problems in her past, was hardly a professional prospect. She started only 10 games as a senior last season, averaging 7 points and 6 rebounds.

title: Round 2: More Reaction to Abbass View of History
Many With New College Degree Find the Job Market Humbling
description: The individual stories are familiar. The chemistry major tending bar. The classics major answering phones. The Italian studies major sweeping aisles at Wal-Mart.

title: Slowed by Injuries, and Weather, the Mets Push Through to Victory
description: Before thousands of empty green seats, with black storm clouds practically tripping over the light stanchions at Citi Field, the Mets left-hander Jon Niese threw his first pitch at 7:11 p.m. Wednesday, even though it might have made more sense to take the night off.

title: James Tempers Expectations for Cavaliers No. 1 Pick
description: CHICAGO  Fate was kind to the Cleveland Cavaliers on Tuesday, but there is only so much healing and hope that can come from the bounce of a Ping-Pong ball, or a No. 1 pick in the draft.

title: TimesCast | U.S. Sanctions Syrian Leader
description: May 18, 2011 - The Times's Beirut Bureau Chief Anthony Shadid on the U.S. sanctions imposed on Syria's leadership.

title: New York Voters Pass 93% of School Budgets in State
description: Voters across New York State approved more than 93 percent of school budgets on Tuesday, as administrators facing sharp reductions in state education aid offered plans to cut staff and programs, tap into reserves and keep tax increases relatively low.

title: Notebook: The Americanization of A.S. Roma
description: 7:16 p.m. | Updated On Friday Landon Donovan dismissed any suggestion that he is interested in a move to Roma.

title: Study Finds Women Slower to Wed, and Divorce Easing
description: WASHINGTON  Nearly half of all women between the ages of 25 and 29 have never been married, up from about a quarter of that age group in 1986, according to a report released on Wednesday by the Census Bureau.

title: The E.P.A.s Secret Agenda
description: Birthers, truthers, Osama-death doubters. These paranoiacs are distracting us from the real menace: one of the governments most powerful agencies is sending sinister messages through its logo.

title: Animal Kingdom Is Morning Line Favorite for Preakness
description: After the field was drawn Wednesday for the Preakness Stakes, the Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdom was made the early 2-1 favorite for Saturdays race. If all the horses reach the gate, the race will have a full, 14-horse field for the first time since 2005.

title: Bloggingheads: Two-State Peace?
description: Daniel Levy, left, of the New America Foundation and Daniel Drezner of Tufts University debate Middle East peace.

title: For Oaktree Capital, a Balancing Act
description: Oaktree Capitals plans to pursue a public stock listing will test one of the main philosophies of its outspoken founder, Howard Marks. Mr. Marks, whose investment missives are widely followed on Wall Street, has often lamented the tradeoff that fund managers make between gathering assets and maintaining performance. Balancing his preference for returns with the demands for growth among public shareholders wont be easy.

title: Second Citys Testing Ground in Cyberspace
description: KUDZU. Asian carp. Greenhouse gases. Sketch comedy.

title: China Reports AIDS Mortality Is Cut by Two-Thirds
description: China has slashed AIDS mortality by nearly two-thirds since it began distributing free antiretroviral drugs in 2002, Chinese government scientists are reporting.

title: As an Insecticide Makes a Comeback, Uganda Must Weigh Its Costs
description: ATEK, Uganda  Bosco Acope was a self-made man.

title: Hybrid Owners Look to Extend Carpool Privilege
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Virtue may be its own reward, but incentives dont hurt. In California in 2004, when the countrys first measure restricting vehicles greenhouse gas emissions became law, 75,000 owners of the gas-stingiest hybrid cars were assured access to carpool lanes.

title: Bias Case May Pose a Problem for Bidder
description: In 2000, the federal agency charged with monitoring workplace discriminationended its investigation of Eagle Global Logistics, a Texas freight company.

title: Restoring Tradition of Quail Hunting
description: PIGGOTT, Ark.  During his periodic stays in this small town in the Arkansas delta, Ernest Hemingway was looked upon by the locals as something of a proto-hippy with his shabby clothes, unshaven face and artistic disposition. He was once mistaken for a hobo. Children taunted him and pelted him with rocks. Obliged to visit his in-laws home in Piggott, Hemingway made the most of it and became a bird-hunting bum.

title: G.O.P. Senators Question I.R.S. Scrutiny of Donors
description: A group of Republican senators wrote to the head of the Internal Revenue Service on Wednesday seeking internal correspondence and other information about the agencys heightened scrutiny of donations to some nonprofit advocacy groups that are playing a growing role in political campaigns.

title: Clinton Aims to Improve Ties With Latin America
description: WASHINGTON  As tumult rages across the Middle East, and relations with Pakistan border on a breakdown, Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton was scheduled Wednesday night to host a private dinner with at least six former Latin American presidents, part of a quiet campaign to repair relations with a region that complains it has been ignored by American policy makers.

title: Rodriguez Will Have Hip Examined When Yanks Return Home
description: BALTIMORE  With Alex Rodriguez under contract through the 2017 season, the Yankees have every reason to protect their investment in him. Even though he said his surgically repaired right hip felt great, tremendous, he will have it checked out during the teams next homestand.

title: Azerbaijan: Court Sentences Activist to Two Years on Draft Evasion Charges
description: A court in Azerbaijan on Wednesday sentenced the political activist Bakhtiyar Hajiyev, who used Facebook to help organize antigovernment demonstrations, to two years in prison on draft evasion charges. Mr. Hajiyev, 29, who studied public policy at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, ran for Parliament last year as an opposition candidate. He was arrested after his name was listed on a Facebook page calling on young people to join protests on March 11. Mr. Hajiyevs arrest follows the sentencing of Jabbar Savalan, 20, to two and a half years on drug possession charges. Mr. Savalan was arrested in February after he announced a protest on his Facebook page, according to Amnesty International. A week ago, the European Parliament passed a resolution condemning Azeri officials for human rights violations, including the violent dispersal of peaceful protests. Azeri officials warned that it could damage relations between Azerbaijan and European governments.

title: A Blood Test Offers Clues to Longevity
description: Want to know how long you will live?

title: Scraping and Cutting to Find $22 Million
description: Troy, Mich., a Detroit suburb where the median family income is more than $90,000, may be one of the more unlikely American cities to find itself in fiscal distress. On paper, it is difficult to understand how this city of 80,000 is struggling: only about 2 percent of its families live below the poverty line; 92 percent of its population has a high school diploma; about half of its adults have at least a bachelors degree; it is one of the safest cities in the country; and the median value of a house is more than $200,000. Still, Troys wealth has proved poor inoculation against the financial problems of cities and states across the country. John Szerlag, Troys city manager, discusses.

title: Gingrichs Rocky Start Not Unusual
description: Can Newt Gingrich recover?

title: Dancer at Heart, and Executive in the Making
description: Nneka Onuorah began taking tap-dancing lessons when she was 4, and by her teenage years, she was proficient in jazz, contemporary and hip-hop moves. She assumed she was destined to be a professional dancer. Instead, after attending LaGuardia Community College, she wound up in a different corner of the entertainment business, as the music specials coordinator at Black Entertainment Television. Ms. Onuorah, 23, lives in Corona, Queens.

title: Sabathia Main Part of Yankees Recipe
description: BALTIMORE

title: Anger Lingers in Iraqi Kurdistan After a Crackdown
description: SULAIMANIYA, Iraq  The protesters are gone from the central square, pushed out by the brutal tactics of the security forces. The jails have been emptied of the young students and journalists who were rounded up for speaking their mind in public. The wounded are home, quietly nursing their injuries.

title: Trading Crown of Jewels for Cap Fit for a Diamond
description: You didnt tell me you were a reporter for The New York Times!

title: In Florida, the Natives Are Restless
description: MIAMI  Joanne and Clift McMahon heard what sounded like a thump-thump at the back door of their bed and breakfast in Port Charlotte, Fla.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,562 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American on Wednesday:

title: Why Animal Kingdom Is a Triple Crown Threat
description: BALTIMORE

title: Bruce Ricker, Who Made Jazz Documentaries, Is Dead at 68
description: Bruce Ricker, a lawyer turned filmmaker who made jazz resoundingly visible in a series of highly regarded documentaries, died on Friday in Cambridge, Mass. He was 68.

title: Texas Catches Fire
description: Even as Texas prepared for war, its fate within the Confederacy sealed, parts of the state still seethed with Union sentiment. And no place was more fervently pro-Union that spring than Bexar County and its largest city, San Antonio, the home of the Alamo, the very cradle of Texas independence.

title: Prosecutors Get Delay in Bonds Hearing
description: A post-trial hearing in San Francisco for Barry Bondss federal perjury case was postponed from Friday to June 17, giving prosecutors more time to decide if they will retry any of the three counts in which the jury deadlocked. The delay also will allow defense lawyers to hone their arguments for the judge to overrule the jury and throw out Bondss lone conviction.

title: Bill Skiles, Frantic Clown to a Straight Man, Dies at 79
description: Bill Skiles, the frenzied, jabbering, sound-effecting clown to the straight man Pete Henderson in the comedy team Skiles and Henderson, died on Monday at his home in St. Cloud, Fla. He was 79.

title: Focus Is on Obama as Tensions Soar Across Mideast
description: WASHINGTON  Few game-changing proposals are emerging to defuse tensions in the Middle East as a busy week of diplomacy unfolds with President Obamas address to the region and his meeting with Israels prime minister.

title: Snooky Young, a Big Band Trumpeter, Is Dead at 92
description: Snooky Young, who led the trumpet sections of some of the worlds most famous big bands  including, for some 30 years, Doc Severinsens Tonight Show orchestra  died on May 11 in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 92.

title: California: Boy Accused in Killing of His Father Says He Was Abused
description: A 10-year-old boy accused of murdering his father  a prominent member of the National Socialist Movement, the nations largest neo-Nazi organization  told the police that his father had physically abused him and his stepmother before the killing, according to documents filed with Superior Court in Riverside County. The boy, whose name is being withheld, said he decided to shoot his father  point blank in the head as he slept on a couch  because he was afraid that his father, Jeff Hall, was having an affair and that the boys living situation would change. The gun was apparently left on a low shelf in the familys home in suburban Riverside, Calif., according to the boys statement to police. It was later found under his bed. The police have issued an arrest warrant for the boys stepmother, Krista F. McCary, with charges including criminal storage of a firearm and child neglect.

title: Nowitzki and the Mavericks Still in Attack Mode Against the Thunder
description: DALLAS  Dirk Nowitzki emerged from the trainers room and bounded down a metal staircase Wednesday, remarkably fresh considering how he had dismantled the Oklahoma City Thunder only 18 hours earlier.

title: The Killing Seas
description: Copenhagen

title: Anticipating Obama's Middle East Speech
description: The Op-Ed columnist Roger Cohen's hopes for President Obama's Middle East peace efforts.

title: Church Abuse Report Authors Defend Findings as Critics Weigh In
description: WASHINGTON  The criminologists hired by the nations Roman Catholic bishops to study the sexual abuse crisis in the church defended their findings on Wednesday at the bishops headquarters  in particular their thesis that the abuse peaked in the 1960s and 1970s and dropped off significantly by the mid-1980s.

title: Lottery Numbers
Private Prisons Found to Offer Little in Savings
description: PHOENIX  The conviction that private prisons save money helped drive more than 30 states to turn to them for housing inmates. But Arizona shows that popular wisdom might be wrong: Data there suggest that privately operated prisons can cost more to operate than state-run prisons  even though they often steer clear of the sickest, costliest inmates.

title: Getting Smart on Aid
description: One cost of the uproar over Greg Mortenson, and the allegations that he fictionalized his school-building story in the best-selling book Three Cups of Tea, is likely to be cynicism about whether aid makes a difference.

title: Yemeni Leader Refuses Deal
description: WASHINGTON  A renewed effort to resolve Yemens political crisis collapsed Wednesday after the Yemeni president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, again backed away from signing an agreement to transfer power, prompting Yemeni officials and analysts to warn that the stalemate could descend into factional violence.

title: The Year of Living Adulterously
description: What is it with Republicans lately?

title: General Says Beijing Wont Challenge American Military
description: WASHINGTON  A top Chinese general said Wednesday that China had no intention of challenging the American military and that it was very strange that questions were raised about his countrys military buildup when the same concerns were not voiced about the United States.

title: Two 9/11 Flight Numbers Retired
description: United Continental Holdings said the company would permanently retire flight numbers 93 and 175, the designations of the United flights hijacked in the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attacks, after they reappeared in a computer reservation system.

title: Justice in Dreamland
description: Police officers following a suspect into an apartment complex in Lexington, Ky., dont know which apartment their man has entered. But wafting through one of the closed apartment doors is the familiar odor of marijuana. The smell provides reason to believe criminal activity is afoot, probable cause for a warrant to search the apartment.

title: U.S. Was Warned on Vents Before Failure at Japans Plant
description: WASHINGTON  Five years before the crucial emergency vents at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant were disabled by an accident they were supposed to help handle, engineers at a reactor in Minnesota warned American regulators about that very problem.

title: Budget Hopes, Further From Reach
description: There was probably never much chance that a self-appointed gang of six senators could produce a comprehensive solution for the nations long-term deficit, given the ruthless political environment. The best hoped was that it could give bipartisan traction to a few useful ideas before they were attacked and destroyed by ideologues.

title: Israel Bares Russia Spy Claim
description: JERUSALEM  Israels military attach in Russia was expelled this week on suspicion of spying, the Israeli Defense Ministry announced on Wednesday, adding that its own investigation into the allegations had found them to be baseless.

title: Upset Over Community Roots Charter Schools Expansion
description: As a parent of a student who started in the inaugural first-grade class at Community Roots Charter School in Brooklyn in 2006, Chris Thompson has watched his son grow up in an elementary school that has transformed itself from an experiment in progressive education to one of District 13s most popular destinations for young families.

title: Georgia: Conflicting Reports Surround Shooting on Border With an Enclave
description: There were conflicting reports on Wednesday about a shooting at the border between Georgia and South Ossetia, a breakaway enclave under Russias military protection. The government of Georgia accused occupation forces of firing on unarmed civilians it said were gathering herbs near the boundary, wounding two, one of them seriously. But South Ossetian officials said that members of the enclaves K.G.B., which patrols the boundary, discovered a group of Georgian youths inside the border. According to Res, an Ossetian news service, a firefight was begun from the Georgian side and Georgian citizens were arrested. South Ossetia gained de facto independence in 2008 after Russia and Georgia fought a short war over it and another rebellious territory.

title: China: Company That Tried to Open Forbidden City Club to Be Investigated
description: A government agency in Beijing has said it will investigate a company that tried to open a luxury private club inside the Forbidden City, according to a report on the Web site of Peoples Daily, the official newspaper of the Chinese Communist Party. The agency, the Beijing Administration of Industry and Commerce, is looking into wrongdoing by the Forbidden City Cultural Development Company, which had been charged by the palaces management office with organizing salons and lectures. Instead, the company began handing out membership sign-up forms without telling the managers, a palace spokesman said. The company reportedly wanted to sign up 500 members at a charge of one million renminbi each, or about $154,000.

title: Thursday: Three Time Tour de France Winner
description: THURSDAYS PUZZLE  Hey there, come on in and have a seat. Make yourself comfortable. May I get you a refreshing beverage? How about a nice, tall cold one? Theres plenty of stuff to cool you down in Paula Gamaches puzzle. Well just chisel some off and put it in our drinks.

title: Produce Your Own Vows
description: Tell your story in your own Vows video. Click here for more information. Here are some of our first and best submissions.

title: The Worlds Best Horse? Shes in Australia
description: Kerry Lonergan has kept his bookmaker driving a Mercedes Benz for years. Hes also had shares in many slow racehorses, and like all owners, remains convinced that the next one he buys will be the next Secretariat. He lives in Brisbane, Australia.

title: Brazil: Government Vows Crackdown on Cattle Ranchers in the Amazon
description: Brazilian government officials said Wednesday that they would crack down on cattle ranchers in the Amazon after new data showed that deforestation there had increased by 26 percent in the nine months that ended in April, compared to with the same period a year before. The data showed to that about 710 square miles had been deforested in that time. Izabella Teixeira, Brazils environment minister, called the jump unacceptable and vowed to seize the cattle of farmers who are practicing deforestation to cultivate new pastureland. Ibama, Brazils environmental protection agency, more than doubled police operations this year intended to deter deforestation. Despite those efforts, Mato Grosso, Brazils leading soybean-producing state, saw a 43 percent increase in deforestation in the nine-month period that ended in April, compared to with the same period last year. Leading environmentalists said some farmers had cut down trees because they expected they would be allowed to do so anyway under a bill being considered in Brazils Congress to ease restrictions on the amount of land that needed to remain forested.

title: Field in Womens 200 Bolstered for Grand Prix
description: Shelly-Ann Fraser-Pryce of Jamaica, the reigning world and Olympic champion in the 100 meters, and Carmelita Jeter of the United States, who was ranked No. 1 in the world in the 100 last year, will compete in the 200 on June 11 at the Adidas Grand Prix on Randalls Island, meet organizers announced. Allyson Felix of the United States and Sherone Simpson of Jamaica had already entered.

title: New Police Unit Will Monitor City Courts for Ticket-Fixing
description: Investigators from the Internal Affairs Bureau will be assigned to monitor the citys traffic courts in an effort to determine whether police officers are intentionally losing cases as favors to colleagues, police officials said Wednesday.

title: Networks Try a Social Media Spin at the Upfronts
description: AT almost every turn this week, television networks are talking about being liked  not only in the ratings, but also on Facebook and Twitter.

title: Status of Libyas Oil Minister Remains Uncertain
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  After the NATO bombing and the rebel forces that have pushed forward at Misurata, only 130 miles from Tripoli, the greatest threat facing the Libyan government may lie in high-level defections that undermine morale and set senior officials to wondering who may be next to abandon Colonel Muammer el-Qaddafis elite.

title: A Victory for Veterans
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit ordered an overhaul of mental health care for veterans, who are killing themselves by the thousands each year because of what the court called the unchecked incompetence of the Department of Veterans Affairs.

title: About That Checking Account
description: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, created by Congress last year as part of financial reform, has broad authority to ban unfair or abusive practices in financial products and services. Protecting checking account holders from unreasonable fees and other costly traps should be one of the agencys first priorities when it opens for business in July.

title: The Vatican Comes Up Short
description: The Vaticans long overdue guidelines for fighting sexual abuse of children are, unfortunately, just that  flimsy guidelines for a global problem that requires an unequivocal mandate for church officials to work with secular authorities in prosecuting rogue priests.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Earthquake and Aftermath Push Japan Into a Recession
description: TOKYO  Japans economy shrank at an annual rate of 3.7 percent in the first quarter, tipping the country into a recession, as the March 11 earthquake and tsunami disrupted production and prompted consumers to cut back on spending.

title: Making the Land of Israel Whole
description: Jerusalem

title: Von Trier Expelled From Cannes Over Nazi Comments
description: Thursday, May 19, 10:34 a.m. | Updated

title: Photo Replay: May 18
description: A look at the day in sports, from soggy Fenway to indoors in Chicago.

title: The Heat Surges Late and Gains a Split in Chicago
description: CHICAGO  The bodies and jersey numbers did not need to change. That much, Erik Spoelstra and the Miami Heat insisted to anyone who would listen. This battle with the Bulls would not come down to personnel, but personality, and the Heat went in search of its own during a tedious two-day gap in the Eastern Conference finals.

title: In Message, Bin Laden Praised Arab Revolt
description: In a message to Muslims made public 16 days after his death, Osama bin Laden praised the pro-democracy uprisings that had swept the Arab world and, in the view of some experts, had called into question the relevance of Al Qaeda, the terrorist network he founded and led for 23 years.

title: Finding the Patient in a Sea of Guidelines
description: Every Friday morning, the patient, a homeless man in his 60s, lumbered into one of our exam rooms, slipped off the running shoes he wore like bedroom slippers and gingerly lifted his swollen legs so we could remove the medicated bandages and examine the raw wounds on his inner ankles.

title: Deconstructing in Cleveland
description: Reclaiming energy and value from old walls, doors and foundations.

title: Material Wonders

title: Word of the Day | suppress

title: Strauss-Kahn Resigns From I.M.F. in Wake of His Arrest
description: Dominique Strauss-Kahn resigned Wednesday as head of the International Monetary Fund after explosive accusations that he had sexually attacked a housekeeper in a Midtown hotel room.

title: For Yankees, Start and Finish Make Up for Whats Between
description: BALTIMORE  Hector Noesi woke up Wednesday as an untested rookie who had spent 16 days with the Yankees without throwing a pitch. He walked off the mound at Camden Yards early Thursday as their savior, the symbol of a brilliant effort by a short-handed bullpen.

title: Phillies Snap Losing Streak With Win Over Rockies
description: A post-trial hearing in San Francisco for Barry Bondss federal perjury case was postponed from Friday to June 17, giving prosecutors more time to decide if they will retry any of the three counts in which the jury deadlocked. The delay also will allow defense lawyers to hone their arguments for the judge to overrule the jury and throw out Bondss lone conviction.

title: Newborn Left in Restroom Trash Can Dies
description: A newborn girl abandoned last week in a hospital trash can in Queens died on Wednesday, officials said.

title: Longing To Perform Opera
description: Young singers audition for the Metropolitan Operas annual contest, a kind of American Idol for serious vocalists.

title: Sing for Your Life
description: Ryan Speedo Green stands almost six-foot-five and weighs 300 pounds and wears size 17 shoes, and on a Sunday afternoon in March he was running in place and doing jumping jacks as he waited in the wings of the Metropolitan Opera for his turn to sing. It was the semifinals of the most important operatic voice competition in America, and Ryan was seized by such anxiety that he felt his massive body vanishing. Seventeen of the 22 singers left in the contest had gone before him; to his ears their performances were spectacular. He was fighting off the feeling that he didnt belong here. Ryan, who is African-American, grew up in low-income housing and a trailer park in southeastern Virginia. When he was 12, he spent time in juvenile detention for threatening his brother and mother. During high school he moved to a street of shacklike homes, with a drug dealers headquarters across from his familys front door and with bullet holes from stray gunfire just above his mothers bedroom window.

title: Scary Moment, Puzzling Ejection
description: BALTIMORE  Of all the bizarre moments in 296 minutes of baseball at Camden Yards on Wednesday, nothing was weirder than the plate umpire, Dan Bellino, ejecting Orioles pitcher Mike Gonzalez in the 15th inning. Gonzalez had just drilled the Yankees Chris Dickerson in the head, cracking his helmet and forcing Dickerson from the game.

title: A Shaken Agency Looks to the Future
description: European officials moved quickly to assert their claim over the leadership of the International Monetary Fund on Thursday, suggesting a serious challenge is being mounted by emerging economic powers like China and India that believe the time has come to break Europes historic grip on the post.

title: J.F.K. Bus Collision Kills One
description: A collision between a Metropolitan Transportation Authority bus anda car at Kennedy International Airport on Wednesday night left one person dead and several people injured, officials said.The crash occurred at 10:25 p.m. on Pan Am Road near parking lot eight. One man in the car was killed, and another was seriously injured.A Port Authority of New York and New Jersey spokesman said that six to seven people on the bus suffered non-life threatening injuries. The crash is still under investigation.

description: The highlights of 2008 included a sporty German coupe, a reborn American icon and a car that relies on hydrogen power.

title: In Ireland, Queen Elizabeth Offers Deep Sympathy For Past
description: LONDON  Queen Elizabeth II neared the end of a visit to the Irish Republic on Thursday after visiting the site of a massacre more than 90 years ago that still evokes memories of fierce hostilities and speaking of her deep sympathy for past suffering.

title: What Are the Best Things Youve Acquired Secondhand?
description: A recent article about flea markets in New York City inspires us to ask about things youve gotten in junk shops, garage sales, flea markets, resale stores, as hand-me-downs, off eBay or Craigslist or via freecycling.
