title: Wordless Grief in a Bosnian Morgue
description: Michel Slomka, 24, graduated from the Universit Paris Ouest Nanterre La Dfense with a degree in anthropology and history, then studied photography for a year. Born and based in Paris, he often works in Bosnia and will return there next month. His conversation with Kerri MacDonald, part of the Turning Point series, has been edited and condensed.

title: Porto Wins Europa League. Can It Get Better Than This?
description: The best team in Portugal won the Europa League on Wednesday when a Colombian named after a Brazilian scored the winning goal in Dublin. Afterward, their coach praised the Englishman who gave him his start. The world game indeed.

title: Deadly Blasts in Kirkuk Hit Iraqi Security Forces
description: BAGHDAD  Three explosions aimed at Iraqi security forces ripped through the divided northern city of Kirkuk on Thursday morning, killing at least 29 people, most of them police officers, and wounding scores more.

title: NIMLOS
description: Not In My Line Of Sight  acronym denoting opposition to plans to construct multi-storey buildings on San Franciscos Treasure Island.

title: Garret FitzGerald, Ex-Irish Premier, Dies at 85
description: LONDON  Garret FitzGerald, who served twice as Irish prime minister, helped set the stage for peace in Northern Ireland and shifted the tone of Irelands relations with Britain, died Thursday in Dublin. He was 85.

title: The Early Word: The Middle East
description: In Todays Times

title: Facebooks New Way to Combat Child Pornography
description: As online photo sharing has exploded so has, tragically, the distribution of child pornography. But while the rise of the Internet and digital cameras have revived a scourge that had nearly been eliminated in the late 1980s, new technology may also help to beat it back again.

title: Festival Brings Dormant Berlin Park to Life
description: A borderline apocalyptic scene awaits when you enter Spreepark, Berlins only theme park, in the Treptow-Kpenick district in the former East Berlin. Life-size replicas of dinosaurs lie toppled on the ground. A pirate ship sits disintegrating in an algae-covered pond. A rusty Ferris wheel stands askew. Spreepark has been dormant since its insolvency in 2002. But from May 26 through 29, the fairground will come alive with the arrival of a multimedia festival called Lunapark Berlin.

title: Does Facebook Help or Hinder Offline Friendships?
description: Two recent articles in the New York Times have raised the question of whether or not the daily interactions on Twitter and Facebook are trivializing our real world friendships by making it easier to do things like wish our friends a happy birthday online and send a tweet instead of picking up the phone, effectively diminishing our desire to have actual, face-to-face conversations.

title: Judge Allows Florida Case Against Trump to Proceed
description: As Donald J. Trump tries to fend off lawsuits from angry home buyers, who claim he misled them about his role in developing luxury towers, his lawyers have repeatedly put forth a simple argument.

title: Should Green Companies Work With Giant Companies?
description: When I started TerraCycle, we quickly came to a defining crossroads: Did we want to sell our made-from-waste products to independent retailers or to big-box retailers? Basically, we were told that if we sold to the big-box chains we would be blackballed by the independents.

title: Remembering Carry Back
description: Leslie Knauf is a writer, editor, marketer and horsewoman in upstate New York who has been attending the races at Saratoga for 50 years. She began riding horses at 9 and owned several thoroughbreds over the years that she rode for pleasure. Shes confident they taught her far more than she ever could teach them.

title: Takeda to Buy Nycomed for $13.7 Billion
description: 5:09 p.m. | Updated

title: Obamas Middle East Speech Has Many American Audiences
description: Thursdays speech by President Obama on the upheaval in the Middle East is aimed at a global audience. But it will also play out in a domestic  and political  context as Mr. Obama seeks a second term in the White House.

title: Rouge Tomate Says It Will Have a Food Cart by Central Park
description: Earlier this week, some cutting-edge Brooklyn restaurateurs said that the parks department has agreed to let them run food stands on the Rockaway Boardwalk. Now, the owners of the more refined Rouge Tomatesay that the department had given them permission to open a food cart at the 64th street entrance to Central Park along Fifth Avenue, starting in mid-June. The carts menu, by the restaurants executive chef, Jeremy Bearman, will use seasonal and local ingredients in sandwiches  like BLTs made with local bacon and lettuce, heirloom tomatoes and whole wheat bread from Amys Bread  soups, snacks, juices and house-made ice cream and sorbets.

title: The Old Ennui and the Lost Generation
description: The definitive poem in English on the subject of cultural nostalgia may be a short verse by Robert Browning called Memorabilia. It begins with a gasp of astonishment  Ah, did you once see Shelley plain?  and ends with a shrug: Well I forget the rest. Isnt that always how it goes? The past seems so much more vivid, more substantial, than the present, and then it evaporates with the cold touch of reality. The good old days are so alluring because we were not around, however much we wish we were.

title: With Hospoda, Czech Food Returns to the Upper East Side
description: Beer is a big part of the vibe at Hospoda, the restaurant set to open on Monday in the landmark Bohemian National Hall on the Upper East Side, once a bastion of Czech food.

title: Toshiba to Acquire Swiss Electronics Maker
description: 5:04 p.m. | Updated

title: Its Been a Sullen Few Days, but the End Is Near
description: If a Staten Island man named Robert Fitzpatrick is right, the world will end on Saturday. Mr. Fitzpatrick has spent a good deal of money putting up hundreds of placards, in the subways and on bus shelters, to warn that May 21 is Judgment Day.

title: Cameron to Re-Release Titanic in 3-D
description: LOS ANGELES  In case you ever doubted, James Cameron is truly the King of the Three-Dimensional World. Or he will be, when his Titanic is re-released by Paramount Pictures and 20th Century Fox on April 6 in 3-D.

title: Thursday Reading: Traveling the Mediterranean on a Budget
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit your wallet.

description: The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, long focused on promoting democracy in Central Europe and the former Soviet Union through loans to business, is likely to extend its mandate to North Africa as part of a push by Europe and the United States to help countries in the region.

description: The weather is officially warm, and its not just a rebellion against a wintry spring that has women leaving their lingerie at home. Examining the spring runways, from Alexander Wang and Haider Ackerman to Jil Sander and Lanvin, there was nary a brassiere in sight.

description: Sue Kenny, the office manager (among other things) at Graham Motions Herringswell Stables since 2002, has been among the hardest hit by Animal Kingdoms victory in the Kentucky Derby.

title: Et Tu, Smoked Herring?
description: Here is a truth a chef might tell you three hours after service and a few drinks into a tear: In matters of cooking, authenticity is a joke. There are recipes, yes. There are traditions, sure. But neither is as important as flavor, as the pure taste of a finished dish.

description: Those readers of The Choice who are still in high school may, at first glance, find little that seems relevant in the front-page article in todays Times under the headline Many With New College Degree Find the Job Market Humbling.

description: William B. Chandler III, who is retiring as chancellor of the Delaware Court of Chancery  the most important court for corporate law in the country  will be joining Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati.

description: On Wednesday I challenged readers to solve a complicated case involving a 50-year-old woman with slurred speech, a toothache and frightening descending paralysis.

Each poem is introduced briefly by Ted Kooser, a former United States poet laureate.

title: Report Faults Mine Owner for Explosion That Killed 29
description: WASHINGTON  In the first comprehensive state report on the 2010 coal mine disaster in West Virginia, an independent team of investigators has put the blame squarely on the owner of the mine, Massey Energy, concluding that it had made life difficult for miners who tried to address safety and built a culture in which wrongdoing became acceptable.

title: Reporter Describes Captivity in Syria
description: Dorothy Parvaz, a reporter for Al Jazeeras English-language Web site who was arrested in Syria last month and then held in Iran until Wednesday, described her detention in a television interview following her release.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: A Military Covenant for America
description: In Britain, two news items dominated the airwaves this past weekend: the Eurovision Song Contest finale and the proposal to make into law the military covenant  the informal pact between the British government and members of the armed forces, promising fair treatment in return for military service. While the value of bringing something like Eurovision to the United States may be debatable, there may be value in exploring the military covenant, especially as a potential framework for bridging what we know as the civilian-military divide.

title: Palin Accuses Gingrich of Caving to the Media
description: Watch the latest video at video.foxnews.com

title: The American Idol of Opera
description: In this weeks magazine, Daniel Bergner writes about the American Idol of opera  the Metropolitan Operas annual National Council Auditions. These tryouts are open to anyone between 20 and 30 and take place at venues across the country. This year more than 1,200 aspiring singers took part. Daniel started reporting last fall when he sat in on some of the early rounds. One enduring memory was his time in Lexington, Ky., where 30-odd singers were auditioning in a small theater at the University of Kentucky. Before the proceedings began, the crowd  voice teachers and coaches, friends, family  stood up and sang a tremendously rousing version of The Star Spangled Banner.'

title: How About a Nice Swedish Punsch?
description: The passion for resurrecting pre-Prohibition cocktails has helped fetch out of historys dustbin several forgotten elixirs, including Crme Yvette, allspice dram, orange bitters and, most famously, absinthe. The latest one to be rehabilitated is Swedish punsch. Beginning this summer, the sweet liqueur will return to liquor stores courtesy of Eric Seed, the owner of Haus Alpenz, a Minnesota-based importing company that specializes in unique and arcane liquors.

title: Patient Voices: Childhood Cancer
description: An unimaginable diagnosis is followed by worry, fear and tough decisions. Six people speak about how childhood cancer changed their lives.

title: The Frick Collection Names a New Director
description: The Frick Collection, a small but sumptuous museum in a limestone mansion on Fifth Avenue, has chosen as its next director Ian Wardropper, chairman of the department of European sculpture and decorative arts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. He will assume the post on Oct. 3, succeeding Anne L. Poulet, who has run the Frick since 2003.

title: Spleen Removal
description: A slide show about spleen removal.

title: Notes of a Screenwriter, Mad as Hell
description: LAMENTING the lack of satirical clarity in the screenplay he was laboring on in the early 1970s, Paddy Chayefsky was mad at himself and American television viewers at large. He was seeing the venomous spirit of the era of Watergate and the Vietnam War infiltrate every program the broadcast networks offered, from their news shows to their sitcoms, and he concluded in a typewritten note to himself that the American people dont want jolly, happy family type shows like Eye Witness News; no, he wrote, the American people are angry and want angry shows. He had set out to write a comedy, but if his film script was funny at all, he said, "the only joke we have going for us is the idea of ANGER."

title: Academies Push For Sanitation and Science Literacy
description: The science academies from the Group of 8 industrialized nations have issued joint statements today in advance of the Group of 8 summit next week in Deauville, France.

title: Stephen Colbert on Network': Great Film or the Greatest Film?
description: An article in Arts & Leisure looks at the notes, drafts and correspondence kept by the screenwriter Paddy Chayefsky during the years he wrote Network, his dark 1976 comedy about the corruption of the news media, the degradation of the truth and the downfall of Howard Beale, a television news anchor with a messiah complex. So whos better qualified to speak about the contemporary relevance of Network than Stephen Colbert, who holds a mocking mirror up to the Howard Beales of the present day while playing one himself on his Comedy Central program, The Colbert Report?

title: Upfronts: The CW Adds Six New Series
description: Following the pattern forged by most of the other broadcast networks this spring, the CW, the part-time network owned by CBS and Warner Brothers, is adding six new series in an effort to increase the total amount of original programming it will offer in the next television season.

title: Tech Talk Podcast: Female Programmers in History
description: Contrary to popular stereotype, computer programmers have not always been caffeine-fueled men in T-shirts coding deep into the night. In fact, some of the earliest programmers were female mathematicians, originally recruited to calculate ballistics trajectories for the Army during World War II. Several of these pioneering women went on to program ENIAC, the worlds first all-electronic computer. In this weeks Tech Talk podcast, Bettina Edelstein speaks with Kathy Kleiman of the ENIAC Programmers Project about their valuable contributions to computing history.

description: Its the challenge faced by every indie band that ventures up to the big leagues: can it stay cool  and independent  once it goes into business with the major record labels?

title: Conservative Party Is Obstacle to Gay Marriage
description: Michael R. Long works out of a cluttered office above a Greek restaurant in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, one block from the liquor store that still bears his familys name, with a replica John Wayne revolver and a photo of Ronald Reagan on the wall. Unlike other political bosses, he fields no phalanx of high-priced lobbyists and consultants. He is virtually unknown to most New Yorkers.

title: Dick Ebersol Resigns From NBC Sports
description: Dick Ebersol, who had defined NBCs formidable Olympic presence since the mid-1990s and who was the last of the high-profile TV sports impresarios, resigned abruptly on Thursday after negotiations on a four-year contract collapsed.

title: A Plan to Cut Mortgage Paperwork
description: Anyone who has applied for a mortgage knows it can involve a daunting amount of paperwork. The new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau is taking a step toward reducing at least some of the pages required by federal law.

title: A Quieter Morning for Animal Kingdom
description: After a series of strong gallops over the past few days, Animal Kingdom enjoyed a more relaxed training program Thursday morning in preparation for the Preakness Stakes on Saturday. We have not had quite as much rain here at Fair Hill as we have had recently, so he returned to the dirt track. This also gave the trainer Graham Motion the opportunity to let Animal Kingdom school a little in the gate.

title: Katie Courics Last Evening News Broadcast
description: When Katie Couric took over as anchor of CBS Evening News in 2006, the move was ballyhooed at the time as a breakthrough for women (she was the first to occupy the seat once held by Walter Cronkite and Dan Rather) and a breath of fresh air for a low-rated broadcast. (Heres video from that initial broadcast, which The Timess Bill Carter called at the time presentable.)

title: Taking a Stand | Igor Dewe
description: No matter what fashion week you attend around the world, part of the fun is checking out the cuckoo creatures who prance around outside in seriously thought-out get-ups. One who flies his freak flag high is Igor Dewe, a 21-year-old Parisian personality and performer, who made headlines in March when he paraded outside the Dior show carrying a placard offering sympathy for John Galliano. Dewe, who said he was shocked by the designers ethnic slurs but felt that his body of work deserved more respect, is best known for his enhanced Louboutins and other pricey footwear which he customizes with the help of his father, a welder. As to how he affords them, he says: You dont need money for clothes when you are fabulous, but for food, that is another story.

Chandler III, the chief judge of the Delaware Chancery Court, announced on Thursday that he would be joining the law firm of Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati as a partner. description: Every year, tens of thousands of icebergs containing billions of gallons of fresh water calve off the glaciers of Greenland and Antarctica into the ocean, where most eventually drift into warmer waters break up and melt.

title: Insurgents Kill at Least 35 in Attack on an Afghan Road Crew
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Insurgents ambushed an Afghan construction crew working on a road project in southeastern Afghanistan early Thursday morning, leaving at least 35 dead security guards, laborers and engineers scattered in the mountainous terrain.

title: Obama Sees 67 Borders as Starting Point for Peace Deal
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama, seeking to capture a moment of epochal change in the Arab world, began a new effort on Thursday to break the stalemate in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, setting out a new starting point for negotiations on the regions most intractable problem.

title: Reporting Live, Outside Rikers
description: At the entrance to Rikers Island on Thursday afternoon, journalists from France seemed to outnumber members of the local press in the hope of catching a glimpse of Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the newly resigned managing director of the International Monetary Fund, accused of sexually assaulting a hotel housekeeper.

title: London Contemporary Art Fair Expanding to New York
description: Frieze, Londons eight-year-old contemporary art fair, is expanding to New York, the fairs organizers announced on Thursday. The first Frieze New York will take place May 3-6 next year on Randalls Island and is expected to include some 170 galleries from around the world. The exhibitions will be housed in a temporary structure designed by the New York architecture and design firm SO-IL.

title: Giffordss Doctors Remain Upbeat After Operation
description: HOUSTON  Representative Gabrielle Giffords was resting in an intensive care unit on Thursday after undergoing surgery to restore a large piece of her cranium with a ceramic prosthesis and install a permanent tube to drain fluid from her skull.

title: A Minority Father at the Playground
description: Which barrier looms larger  racism or sexism? Minority women raise that topic often when discussing how to navigate the workplace, and pundits ask the question periodically when discussing politics, from my informal mental scan of those writings, they are divided on the answer.

title: Zombies Upstage a Routine Public Health Bulletin
description: Pity poor Tom Skinner, a top spokesman for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention who has been valiantly trying to interest reporters in a new study in the agencys Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report trumpeting 10 Great Public Health Achievements. Unfortunately for Mr. Skinner, over at his agencys public health blog, his colleagues were posting something that really got to the beating heart of morbidity and mortality: the first official C.D.C. instructions on coping with a zombie apocalypse.

title: Double-Digit Insurance Rate Increases Get More Scrutiny
description: Federal officials announced new rules on Thursday that require health insurers that decide to raise their rates sharply to provide more justification for the higher premiums.

title: Midtown Hotel Agrees to Silence Bellmens Whistles
description: The ear-piercing whistles of bellmen hailing cabs outside a hotel in Midtown Manhattan will torment neighbors no more.

title: Energy Agency Calls for Rise in World Oil Output
description: PARIS  Expressing serious concern about elevated crude oil prices, the International Energy Agency on Thursday called for an increase in world oil production. It was an unusual move that highlighted consumer countries frustration at the failure of oil-producing nations to lift output in the face of rising demand and tighter supply.

title: Regulator Taken to Task on Trading Limits
description: Bart Chilton is on a mission to rein in speculative commodities trading.

title: Whale Oil Explodes and Buccaneers Bellow
description: It is fitting that what passes for a plot in Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides involves a search for the fountain of youth. This film, the fourth in a series that made its improbable and profitable leap from the theme park to the multiplex eight summers ago, represents an attempt to rejuvenate a flagging franchise.

title: House Tour: Palenville, N.Y.
description: Bob Malkin and Barbara Pokras had a house they loved, but fell in love with another one. Their solution: buy it and rent it out.

title: A Fresh Glow for the New York Public Library
description: When Paul LeClerc, the president of the New York Public Library, was preparing to unveil his Beaux-Arts Fifth Avenue beauty after a $50 million, three-year renovation, he knew that he would need to show it in literally the best light possible. So he went to Paris to consult Franois Jousse, who was then City Halls chief engineer for doctrine, expertise and technical control  something like the lighting director of the City of Light. Mr. Jousse took Mr. LeClerc on tours of Paris by night, showing him lighting canisters, electrical wiring and spotlight colors of the citys monuments, official buildings, bridges and boulevards.

title: Guess Where This Is
description: This week we have an agrarian theme. Your hint: this rice paddy field is outside a major Asian city. Name the city  bonus points for summarizing the news story involving food production in this region.

title: New York Attorney General Is Investigating Trumps For-Profit School
description: The New York State attorney generals office is investigating whether a for-profit school founded by Donald J. Trump, which charges students up to $35,000 a course, has engaged in illegal business practices, according to people briefed on the inquiry.

title: House Tour: Palenville, N.Y.
description: WHAT A two-bedroom, two-bath house.

title: Sad and Haunted Girls Who Couldnt Play Worth a Lick
description: THEY may be the most defensive album liner notes in rock history: The Shaggs love you and love to perform for you, begins one paragraph on the back of the 1969 LP The Shaggs: Philosophy of the World, a cult classic for its guilelessly awful music and otherworldly lyrics. You may love their music or you may not, but whatever you feel, at last you know you can listen to artists who are real. The three members of this young sister act, we read, are happy people and love what they are doing.

title: I Sing the Gadget Electronic
description: ON a rainy April morning in what looked more like a makeshift office than an art studio, Cory Arcangel was deciding what drawings to produce for his survey show Cory Arcangel: Pro Tools, which opens Thursday at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Of two possible contenders, one would present the lyrics of the Miley Cyrus song Party in the U.S.A. in playful, loopy lettering; the other would be an intricately rendered tree. Both images would feature delicate lines laid down by a steady hand, though not Mr. Arcangels: the drawings would in fact be the product of a 1990s pen plotter machine, until recently defunct, which Mr. Arcangel had rerigged and reprogrammed.

title: Bunny Yeager, Shy Beyond the Lens
description: On view this month at the Harold Golen Gallery in Miami is a showcase of Ms. Yeagers self-portraits.

title: The Morning Line: Is the Outside the Right Side for Animal Kingdom?
description: The draw for the Preakness took place Wednesday. A full field of 14 was entered. The Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdom drew the No. 11 post, and was denominated the morning line favorite for the race at odds of 2-1. Second choice in the race is  Dialed In at odds of 9-2. There are differences of opinion on whether Animal Kingdom will be hurt by the outside draw.

title: Sleepless in Seattle Musical to Awaken at Pasadena Playhouse
description: Sleepless in Seattle, the 1993 Tom Hanks-Meg Ryan film that set its climax on the top of the Empire State Building, may yet find its own path to New York as part of the trend of turning hit movies into Broadway musicals. But the stage version of Seattle will start in Southern California: the Pasadena Playhouse announced on Thursday that it would mount the world premiere of Sleepless in Seattle  The Musical beginning June 12, 2012, with performances set to run through July 15.

title: Strauss-Kahn Is Indicted and Will Soon Leave Jail
description: A judge granted bail on Thursday to Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former managing director of the International Monetary Fund, allowing him to be freed from Rikers Island to stay in a Manhattan apartment while his sexual assault case is pending.

title: To Restore Reputation of a Renault Founder, Family Goes to Court
description: PARIS  Nearly 70 years after the pioneering automaker Louis Renault died in a French prison, accused of collaborating with the Nazis, his grandchildren are seeking to restore his reputation  and gain compensation for what they say was the illegal confiscation of his car company by the state.

title: Pogues Posts: 25 Tech Tips and Tricks
description: David Pogue follows up on his Thursday column with a blog post giving readers 25 more basic tips for getting the most out of their consumer electronics.

title: Where And Why
description: Where:

title: F.B.I. Is Looking at Unabomber in 82 Tylenol Case
description: WASHINGTON  The Federal Bureau of Investigation. is examining whether Theodore J. Kaczynski, the Unabomber, was responsible for lacing several bottles of Tylenol with cyanide in 1982, bringing together two of the highest-profile domestic crimes of the late 20th century.

title: JANE FREILICHER: Recent Paintings and Prints
description: Tibor de Nagy

title: JOHN DIVOLA: Trees for the Forest
description: Wallspace

title: ANDY WARHOL: Colored Campbells Soup Cans
description: L&M Arts

title: ETHIOPIAN MAGIC SCROLLS: Talismanic Art of Ethiopia
description: Elizabeth Street Fine Arts

title: LOUISE LAWLER: Fitting at Metro Pictures
description: Metro Pictures

title: Amid Record Prices for Used Cars, eBay Introduces Auction App for iPhone
description: With used-car prices continuing their rise, competition for prime preowned vehicles has turned cutthroat. Into the fray steps eBay Motors with a new app for the Apple iPhone, designed for shoppers intent on hunting deals while theyre on the go.

title: China Gives Pakistan 50 Fighter Jets
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  China has agreed to immediately provide 50 JF-17 fighter jets to Pakistan, a major outcome of a visit by Prime Minister Yousaf Raza Gilani to Beijing this week, Pakistani officials said Thursday.

title: After Hart, a Deluge of Meaner Celebrity TV?
description: LOS ANGELES

title: The Fascist Octopus, Having Sung Its Swan Song, Needs to Retire
description: Orwell wept. His famous examples of careless writing  the fascist octopus has sung its swan song, the jackboot has been thrown into the melting pot  must exit the stage in the face of Newt Gingrichs press secretary:

title: A.N.C. Leading in South African Vote, as Second-Place Party Makes Some Gains
description: JOHANNESBURG  As votes were being counted Thursday in South Africas local elections, the governing African National Congress was once again steamrolling to victory, though not quite at its customary pace.

title: Wedding Etiquette
description: What Exactly Is

title: Trotting Against Traffic
description: On the streets of New York City, horse-drawn carriages are required to travel in the same direction as horseless carriages. But on one Midtown block, the horses may get a chance to trot against the flow this summer.

title: U.S. Manufacturing Trade (Wonkish)
description: Ive been doing some number-crunching on trade issues, and thought Id put something up for those who are interested: a picture of the recent improvement in the US manufacturing trade position.

title: The New Wave
description: Surf culture has long produced its own aesthetic, along with a tradition of surfer-artists. On the visual vanguard at the moment are Alex Kopps and Tin Ojeda. Koppss films, graffiti and collage-like prints (alexkopps.com) give an urban edge to what is usually a beachy domain. The content and events that have influenced my artwork were not discovered at the beach, says Kopps, who lives in the Bay Area and sells some of his T-shirts and posters (right) at Mollusk Surf Shop. His film Displacement, about displacement hull surfboards, uses 1970s Super-8 footage with abstract effects. Ojeda, the Argentinian-born painter and surfer behind the Drug Money Art clothing line (drugmoneyart.com), is bringing the beach to the city. His tees, on which he hand-prints phrases (Beauty Is Boring, says one), first gained a following in his home base of Montauk, N.Y. Now theyre at Barneys and in stores in Tokyo, Berlin and London.

title: Syria Condemns U.S. Sanctions on Assad
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian government condemned on Thursday American sanctions against President Bashar al-Assad and six of his top officials over the ferocious crackdown on antigovernment protesters that human rights activists say has killed at least 850 people.

title: Netanyahu Responds Icily to Obama Remarks
description: JERUSALEM  President Obamas endorsement on Thursday of using the 1967 boundaries as the baseline for a solution to the Israeli-Palestinian dispute  the first by an American president  prompted Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to push back testily and the Palestinian leadership to call an urgent meeting.

title: G.O.P. Blocks Judicial Nominee in a Sign of Battles to Come
description: WASHINGTON  Senate Republicans on Thursday blocked a final vote on President Obamas choice for a federal appeals court opening, marking the first successful Republican filibuster of an Obama administration judicial nominee.

title: Are Young College Grads Too Lazy to Work?
description: Ive received a lot of passionate (and angry) e-mails in response to my article today on the employment fate of recent college graduates. While the messages from young people almost uniformly expressed frustration at the job market theyd been thrust into, some of the e-mails from older readers argued that todays college graduates were having trouble finding jobs because they hadnt worked hard enough. For example, a reader named Norman Berger asks why graduates wonder why they prove worthless to a potential employer when they follow this approach:

title: The Importance of Venting, When a Reactor Threatens to Blow Its Stack
description: As I wrote in Thursdays paper, the Fukushima Daiichi accident is renewing a debate over whether the emergency venting systems that were added to boiling water reactors 20 years ago should be opened only directly by operators or function automatically.

title: Joe Drapes Preakness Picks
description: The Pimlico oddsmaker Frank Carulli set the morning line for Saturdays Preakness Stakes, and Joe Drape has listed the horses in order of preference.

title: Suit Seeks Higher Royalties From Universal Music
description: Two months after Eminems producers won a case against the Universal Music Group over how royalties are computed for digital music, more artists have followed with complaints that they are owed what may amount to millions of dollars in unpaid earnings.

title: Online Treasury Sales Challenge Elderly Investors
description: The federal government has started shifting the purchase of Treasury securities to the Internet to cut costs, which means many elderly investors are facing an unwelcome change.

title: Report on the Upper Big Branch Mine Explosion
description: An independent team investigating 2010 coal mine explosion in West Virginia put the blame squarely on Massey Energy.

title: Perched in Berlin With Hitler Rising
description: One of the malicious nicknames given to William E. Dodd by his fellow American diplomats in the 1930s was Telephone Book Dodd. The joke was that Franklin D. Roosevelt, who appointed Dodd ambassador to Germany in 1933, had supposedly meant to offer the post to a Yale law professor named Walter F. Dodd but made a mistake in looking up the name.

title: Nothing New as No-Hit Bid Again Teases Mets
description: The first batter Mets starter Dillon Gee faced Thursday, Roger Bernadina, fouled off one two-strike pitch after another, eight in all. Twelve pitches into the at-bat, Bernadina still stood in the batters box, as determined as Gee.

title: Theater Talkback: The Skittish Play
description: My patience with Sleep No More, the elaborate haunted house masquerading as theater in Chelsea, began to wear thin at about the time the pointy plastic mask I was wearing started pinching at the bridge of my nose.

title: Reaction in Arab Capitals Is Muted and Mixed
description: CAIRO  President Obama may have hoped that his embrace of the democracy movement sweeping the Arab world might revive the warmth his name evoked after his speech to the Muslim world two years ago. But across the region, many said his soaring words and financial pledges did little to undo their disappointment at his apparent equivocation during the early days of the Arab revolt.

title: For U.S., Matching Moral and Financial Support for Revolts Proves Difficult
description: WASHINGTON  After six months of struggle inside the White House to reconcile American interests in the Arab uprisings with American values, President Obama on Thursday sought to portray the regions revolt in the historical tradition of the American Revolution and the civil rights movement.

title: Photo Replay: May 19
description: The day in sports included preparations for the Preakness Stakes and the French Open, and a crash in practice for the coming Indianapolis 500.

title: Dance Listings for May 20-26
description: Dance

title: Update on Violet: One Good Leg, but Still Hanging On
description: A week after the state decided not to intervene, Violet the red-tailed hawk is neither worse nor better, which offers some relief to those who have been monitoring her condition.

title: Jazz Listings for May 20  26
description: Jazz

title: Republicans Pounce on Obamas Mideast Speech
description: Republicans on Thursday lashed out at President Obama, accusing him of abandoning support for the United States most important ally in the Middle East by calling for a peace deal built around Israels 1967 borders.

title: Spare Times for Children May 20  26
description: THE COMPLETE WORKS

title: An Inventory of Curiosities, Tales Included
description: IT would seem an almost impossible feat to stand out amid the clutter of Archangel Antiques, in the East Village, where tightly packed rails of vintage clothing vie for attention with glass cabinets lined with jewelry and curiosities. Yet the first thing most customers notice after descending to the subterranean entrance is Michael Duggan, who can usually be found sitting toward the back of the musty space, peering out from behind a pair of beige, 1950s tortoiseshell glasses.

title: Spare Times for May 20-26
description: Around Town

title: Classical Music and Opera Listings for May 20  26
description: Classical

title: As School Roofs Crumble, Toronto Finds Solar Solution
description: Like many of its counterparts in the United States, the Toronto District School Board oversees a large number of schools that were built as a result of the baby boom. Now that those schools, like their former pupils, are firmly in late middle age, their roofs have become a major financial problem. The board estimates that it faces a $3 billion backlog in roofing repairs.

title: Movie Listings for May 20-26
description: Movies

title: Bucking Up the British in the Midst of the Fight
description: Most of what happens in Went the Day Well?  an undeservedly forgotten British film showing at Film Forum starting on Friday  is a flashback. In the first scene, a friendly chap in a village churchyard addresses the camera, which is to say the audience, and supposes we want to hear about the big battle that happened in the town a few years before.

title: Posada to Start in Field; Teixeira to D.H.
description: BALTIMORE  Jorge Posada will play in the field Thursday night for the first time this season, but it will not be at catcher.

title: Theater Listings: May 20  26
description: Theater

title: Enjoying the Long Haul
description: I had just shifted the 26-foot Penske Truck Rental rig into Park at the end of a 2,225-mile journey, when it struck me. I had as much fun driving from Ann Arbor to Southern California in this big, dumb, bucking behemoth as I did hustling a Ferrari 458 Italia from Italy to England last summer.

title: Guantnamo Detainee Had Worked as Qaeda Courier
description: The Guantnamo Bay detainee who apparently committed suicide on Wednesday had worked as a courier for senior officials for Al Qaeda in Pakistan, a job similar to those who ultimately were instrumental in leading the United States military to tracking down Osama bin Laden, according to government documents.

title: Museum and Gallery Listings for May 20-26
description: Art

title: The Art of Collecting Collections
description: SHELBURNE, Vt.  There is a mystery about the Shelburne Museum. And you could easily spend a day here, just south of Burlington, walking around its 45 acres, amazed, awed and amused, and still not figure it out.

title: 36 Hours in Milan
description: Italys most cosmopolitan city refuses to coast on its legendary treasures.

title: 36 Hours in Milan
description: For updated suggestions on what to do in Milan, see this more recent 36 Hours column.

title: Calling a Rape a Rape
description: Reading the story in The Times earlier this week about Tristane Banon, a 31-year-old journalist who said that Dominique Strauss-Kahn tried to rape her during an interview in 2002, I was struck by the conversation she had soon after with her mother, who discouraged her from filing charges against a powerful man who was a friend of the family. As Banons mother, Anne Mansouret, a Socialist Party official, recounted the conversation, she told her daughter: Listen, you know, if he had raped you, I wouldnt have any hesitation, but that wasnt the case. He sexually assaulted you, there wasnt any rape per se; so until the end of your life, youre going to have on your rsum, you know, Tristane Banon is the girl who.  Banon ultimately decided not to press charges.

title: Study Sees Way to Win Spam Fight
description: For years, a team of computer scientists at two University of California campuses has been looking deeply into the nature of spam, the billions of unwanted e-mail messages generated by networks of zombie computers controlled by the rogue programs called botnets. They even coined a term, spamalytics, to describe their work.

title: Chinese Characters and Matisse at the Morgan; Hide/Seek Heads to the Brooklyn
description: A floating, iridescent cloud of calligraphy is how the conceptual artist Xu Bing describes The Living Word, his installation of about 400 carved and painted acrylic Chinese characters. This summer, The Living Word 3  the latest version in a series that began in 2001  will rise to the highest point of the Morgan Library & Museums glass atrium.

title: Beatles Photos, Medieval Fashion and Forbess Auctions
description: In the early 1960s the Beatles posed for hours for the German photographer Astrid Kirchherr, even before the roster of four band members was finalized. She met them when they first played in her native Hamburg and encouraged them to imitate her bowl-cut hair and collarless jackets.

title: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Iraq, Israel, Egypt and Afghanistan.

title: City Unemployment Rate Dips to 8.6%
description: Even though New York Citys stalled construction industry has not begun to hire back laid-off workers, the citys unemployment rate dipped again in April to its lowest level in more than two years.

title: Hit the Breakers
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#124", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Empowering People of Spaceship Earth
description: For a generation that came of age in the late 1960s and early 70s, three unusual reference books were catalytic consciousness raisers. The Joy of Sex and Our Bodies, Ourselves are still in print; the third and possibly most influential of all is less familiar to people born after 1980: the Whole Earth Catalog. Brainchild of the visionary techno-hippie artist Steward Brand, this compendium of resources for the New Age is the subject of Access to Tools: Publications From the Whole Earth Catalog, 1968-1974, a modest but stirring time capsule of an exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.

title: TimesCast | May 19, 2011
description: President Obama speaks on sweeping changes in the Mideast and outlines a potential peace deal between Palestinians and Israel; the view from Jerusalem; and reaction from Cairo.

title: In LinkedIn, Some See Potential
description: Whether LinkedIn becomes a worthwhile long-term investment will depend largely on how effectively it can translate its place as "the" go-to social networking site for professionals into revenue.

title: In LinkedIn, Advertisers See Potential
description: LinkedIns potential as a long-term investment will depend largely on how effectively the company can translate its position as the networking site for professionals into revenue. DealBook spoke to several digital advertising executives about the sites status within the social media world.

title: A Grand Tour, With Asterisks
description: A road trip in the new Fiat 500 wouldnt be complete without stops in Naples (Me.), Verona (N.J.), Rome (Ga.) and Venice (Fla.).

title: Stuck at the Border Between the Sexes
description: SOME people assume transgender men are lesbians who couldnt handle being gay. They really think a female would go through all the hassles of transitioning to male just so she could trick other women into sleeping with her.

title: Court Documents Show F.B.I. Is Investigating Unabomber in Tylenol Case
description: An examination by the Federal Bureau of Investigation brings together two of the highest profile domestic crimes of the late 20th century.

title: An Inventory of Curiosities, Tales Included
description: It would seem an almost impossible feat to stand out amid the clutter of Archangel Antiques, in the East Village, where tightly packed rails of vintage clothing vie for attention with glass cabinets lined with jewelry and curiosities. Yet the first thing most customers notice after descending to the subterranean entrance is Michael Duggan, who can usually be found sitting toward the back of the musty space, peering out from behind a pair of beige, 1950s tortoiseshell glasses.

title: Danish Director Barred From Festival After Making Hitler Jokes
description: CANNES, France  The Danish filmmaker Lars von Trier has been a fixture at the Cannes Film Festival throughout his career. All but one of his features have had their premieres here, and he won the top prize, the Palme dOr, in 2000 for Dancer in the Dark. But the longstanding relationship came to an abrupt halt on Thursday when the festivals board of directors declared Mr. von Trier persona non grata a day after he joked at a news conference for his latest film, Melancholia, that he was a Nazi and sympathized with Hitler.

title: Uninterrupted Landscape
description: On the road with Mark Bittman on his Spring Farm and Food Tour.

title: Facebook Page, R.I.P.
description: My sister-in-law died in September. I removed her from my list of Facebook friends, but her Facebook page is still active, and the site keeps asking me if I want to friend her. At what point would it be O.K. to mention to her husband that maybe its time to close her account?

title: Pictures of the Day: Iraq and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Iraq, Israel, Egypt and Afghanistan.

title: A Provocateur Steals Cannes Spotlight
description: CANNES, France  On Thursday the 64th Cannes Film Festival took a surreal turn when the festivals board of directors announced that the Danish filmmaker Lars von Trier had been declared persona non grata, the news erupting shortly before the latest movie from the now imprisoned Iranian director Jafar Panahi was shown.

title: Your Photos: Prom Nights to Remember, and Nightmares
description: New York Times readers around the country (and world) submitted their photos and stories of proms recent and long-past.

title: Close to Eden, Where the Music Is Artisanal
description: The oohs have it  along with that ahs, ohs, and whoas  in songs by Fleet Foxes, a band formed in Seattle that started a two-night stand at the United Palace on Wednesday night. Sooner or later, nearly every Fleet Foxes song gives way to a stretch of wordless vocal harmonies shared by three, four, perhaps five voices, moving together in chords or interweaving in counterpoint. Those harmonies are many things at once: a show of skill and preparation, an offering of sweetness, a utopian communal project and, perhaps most of all, a temporary paradise, a refuge from any kind of discord.

title: From the Classical World of Apollos and Fauns to a Romantic Passion
description: Some things that happened for the first time seem to be happening again. The first three ballets of Wednesdays program at New York City Ballet  George Balanchines Apollo, and Jerome Robbinss Afternoon of a Faun and Antique Epigraphs  all address different aspects of innocence, with the world seeming new; its heartening to see them all in good shape. The fourth, Balanchines Sonnambula, alternately suggests a society both old and sophisticated, death and a dark form of transcendence.

title: From Thornton to Sioux City
description: I spent yesterday with Linus Solberg, a soybean farmer in Cylinder, Iowa, no doubt ruining his day  he was trying to get his beans in the ground  and compressing the rest of mine. But its impossible to leave when someone is friendly, warm and funny.

title: In Polar Bear Territory
description: Kate Stafford, an oceanographer at the Applied Physics Laboratory at the University of Washington, writes from Alaska, where she is participating in a visual census of bowhead whales.

title: She Loved Herself, Yes, but She Also Loved Art
description: Peggy Guggenheim did what she wanted, which was fairly unusual for women born in 1898. A rich New Yorker (although not as rich as some of the other Guggenheims), she married twice and had children but devoted most of her adult life to her modern-art collection and to love affairs, often with men who made art.

title: Q & A
description: Related by Marriage and Co-op Board

title: Leave the Stuff, Keep the Memories
description: JAY GOLDSTEIN and his wife, Carrie, accumulated 15,000 books in the 46 years they livedin the Glen Cove split ranch where they raised their four children. Its sixth bedroom became the second story of a library. All sorts of memorabilia and other hard-to-toss belongings accumulated in the attic and basement. In February, when their home went into contract for $550,000, deciding what to take, what to dispose of and how to lay out their new $8,050-a-month two-bedroom rental apartment at the Atria on Roslyn Harbor, an independent senior community in Roslyn, seemed overwhelming.

title: In House Pricing, Own Up to Flaws
description: BROKERS say conventional wisdom still holds: Price a house right, and do so from the start. But even when a seller is willing to follow that advice, its not always obvious what the right price is. The challenge seems to lie in accurately assessing what factors might make a house less than immediately saleable  and in knowing just how much money those negative factors should chop from the price tag.

title: A 30-Month Short-Sale Saga
description: TEANECK

title: Ronald Dickerman
description: Mr. Dickerman, 47, is the founder and president of Madison International Realty, a real estate private equity firm, which through its investment funds holds ownership stakes in buildings around the world, including several in the New York area, among them the Chrysler East Building and 520 Madison Avenue. The company has also had investments in the Seagram Building over the years.

title: Mr. Disability
description: As weve noted here before, the federal disability program cost about $190 billion last year, in payments to disabled workers and health care for them. Thats the equivalent of roughly $1,500 in taxes for every American household.

title: Riding High
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#750", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Keeping Score: Posada Put Off Decline for Years
description: Neil Paine is an analyst at Baseball-Reference.com, an online baseball encyclopedia of players, teams and box scores in the major and minor leagues.

title: The Caucus Podcast: Obamas Speech and Republican Reaction
description: Tune into The Caucus podcast to hear a discussion of President Obamas Middle East speech and the reaction of some of the Republican presidential candidates.

title: Sculpture in High Relief
description: It has been a while since sculpture could be dismissed as something you bump into when you back up to look at a painting, as Ad Reinhardt, the Abstract Expressionist painter, once said. Even before Reinhardt died, in 1967, the medium was going supernova, expanding and diversifying at an astounding pace. First it began incorporating all manner of found objects and nontraditional materials; then it lifted brilliant color from painting and achieved new levels of abstraction. Since then it has come to include installations, environments, land art, performance and all manner of spectacle.

title: British Police Warn Rwandan Dissidents of Threat
description: KAMPALA, Uganda  The British police have warned two outspoken Rwandan dissidents living in London that their lives are in danger because the Rwandan government may be plotting to kill them, according to British officials and documents.

title: Sasha Mullins and Patrick Lassiter
description: FOR Lisa Sasha Mullins, the best solution to any problem is a road trip on her motorcycle, a Harley Davidson she calls Tigerlily. Riding motorcycles is her wind meditation, she said, as well as her career.

title: A Hike Down Herkimer Street
description: HERKIMER Street, from Bedford to Nostrand Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, is a perfect urban jumble: old frame houses smothered in aluminum siding; apartment buildings jammed in next to tiny brownstones; an empty mansion; a Baptist church in the Islamic style. It requires three or four passes (and a slide show online) to take in even half the details on this complex block.

title: New Brokerage Donates Portion of Fees to Charity
description: A NEW brokerage in New York says it will donate part of its fee from every sale to a group that helps provide safe drinking water in developing countries like Haiti, Liberia and the Central African Republic.

title: Trump Cancels Iowa Dinner
description: The first real casualty of Donald J. Trumps shuttered presidential ambitions has been claimed: the Republican Party of Iowas Lincoln Day Dinner.

title: First Adult Apartment (Must Be a Deal)
description: FOR three years, Shai Benhamou lived with a roommate in a walk-up rental on the Upper East Side. They spent just over $1,600 a month for the two-bedroom apartment, but the bedrooms were only nine feet square. The York Avenue location was far from downtown, where Mr. Benhamou spent most of his nonworking hours.

title: How to Avoid Roommate Regret
description: IF you are a recent college graduate, you may think your roommate days are behind you. But in New York, where real estate is expensive and in short supply, theres a very good chance you will be sharing an apartment well into your professional years.

title: UBS Names Head of Energy Banking
description: UBS said Thursday that it had hired Thomas Langford from Morgan Stanley to be its global head of energy investment banking.

title: China Admits Problems With Three Gorges Dam
description: BEIJING  The Three Gorges Dam, the worlds largest hydroelectric project and a symbol of Chinas confidence in risky technological solutions, is troubled by urgent pollution and geologic problems, a high-level government body acknowledged Thursday.

title: Capitalists Who Fear Free Markets
description: Capitalism is supposed to produce losses on bad investments.

title: Counseling Before Borrowing
description: EVEN though the housing market remains sluggish, Bernell Grier says that her nonprofit agency is hearing from record numbers of people seeking advice on how home-buying works and whether theyre in a position to own now that real estate prices have fallen.

title: Israeli Settlers Reject the Auschwitz Borders of 1967
description: While journalists in the Arab world reported that it was difficult to find any reaction at all to President Obamas speech on the Middle East, his remarks on the future shape of a Palestinian state did prompt a lengthy and pointed reply on one Israeli Facebook page, that of the Israeli prime ministers office.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Archangel Antiques
description: At Archangel Antiques in the West Village, its the curious range of objects  and the colorful store manager  that draw you in.

title: Schwarzeneggers Movie Career Put on Hold
description: Arnold Schwarzenegger is putting his acting career on pause, one of his lawyers said Thursday, amid the news that he fathered a child with a former member of his household staff more than a decade ago.

title: The Shelburne Museum
description: Images from the collections at the Shelburne Museum in Vermont.

title: Florent, the Restaurant and the Man, on Film
description: David Sigals documentary Florent: Queen of the Meat Market isnt just the story of a pioneering restaurateur and his scruffy New York establishment that flourished for 23 years. It is a touching, elegiac tale of the rise (and some would say fall) of a colorful New York neighborhood under the relentless march of gentrification.

title: A Workout, Even for a Runner
description: IM suspicious of workouts that dont give the same kind of cardio buzz that running and plyometrics do, and I often write off these so-called softer exercise routines as unchallenging. The Nalini Method, however, recently put me in my place.

title: Weekend Miser
description: Theater nerds all over the city are beginning to geek out about the 2011 Tony Awards. The ceremony isnt until June 12, but you can feed your theatrical beast at the American Theater Wings free Tony documentary film series at the Times Square Visitor Center on Monday.

title: Conrad to Defer Work on Budget
description: The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, Kent Conrad, announced Thursday that the panel would defer work indefinitely on a budget for the coming fiscal year, and wait to see whether negotiations between the White House and Congressional leaders yield a bipartisan deficit-reduction compromise.

title: A Former Basketball Prodigy, Bereft of All but His Memories
description: LOS ANGELES  When Stephen Turner pulled his silver Mercedes into the Mobil station on a gritty stretch of Hollywood near Vine Street and Santa Monica Boulevard, he did not immediately recognize the gigantic man with Windex who ambled over and offered to wash his windows for a tip.

title: Postgraduate Work in Bergman Madness
description: WHEN Mark Romanek was casting his movie version of the Kazuo Ishiguro novel Never Let Me Go in 2009, the producers gave him one bit of advice, he said: Hire the genius, Mulligan. That would be Carey Mulligan, the almost freakishly talented young British actress, who has embarked on an eight-week run in the Atlantic Theater Companys production of Through a Glass Darkly, Jenny Wortons stage adaptation of the 1961 Ingmar Bergman film.

title: Stage Scenes: Carey Mulligan
description: Photos of some of the actresss work on stage and screen.

title: Sculpture City
description: An interactive look at sculpture exhibitions in New York.

title: Guessing Game Over Prominent Blagojevich Witnesses
description: CHICAGO  Lawyers for Rod R. Blagojevich, the ousted former governor of Illinois, said on Thursday that they planned to call several witnesses of some prominence at his retrial next week, leading to speculation here over who could take the stand. Could it be Rahm Emanuel, the citys new mayor? Or Representative Jesse Jackson Jr.?

title: TimesCast | Reaction From Cairo
description: May 19, 2011 - Journalists at Daily News Egypt, an English-language newspaper in Cairo, react to President Obama's Middle East speech.

title: Spidey Syndrome Invades the Opera
description: QUICK question: Which New York stage production from the season just past was notable for its huge expense, its technical problems and its chilly reception?

title: A City in Peril
description: Electrified by images of gore-drenched interiors and chaotic street massacres, 8 Murders a Day is an impassioned attack on the 2006 decision by Mexican President Felipe Caldern to enact a military campaign against two warring drug cartels in Juarez.

title: The Sensors Are Coming!
description: If you own a smartphone, you probably know just how smart those little gadgets are. They know where youre standing, the direction youre moving in and if youre holding the phone vertically or horizontally.

title: Contrarian Investor Shuns Hot Idea for Bigger Picture
description: As investors clamor for shares of social media darlings, Peter Thiel is avoiding the frenzy.

title: The Residents Go, the Music Stays
description: Lost Bohemia, a new documentary by Josef Astor, is a sad and spirited elegy for the Carnegie Hall Studios, which for more than a century provided working, living and teaching space for all kinds of artists on the floors above the famous concert hall. Mr. Astor, a photographer who moved into the building in 1985, pays tribute to his neighbors and friends who made up the last generation of studio residents. He also acknowledges the famous ghosts who haunt the place, ranging from Isadora Duncan and Enrico Caruso to Marilyn Monroe and Martha Graham.

title: Court Filings Assert Iran Had Link to 9/11 Attacks
description: Two defectors from Irans intelligence service have testified that Iranian officials had foreknowledge of the 9/11 attacks, according to a court filing Thursday in a federal lawsuit in Manhattan that seeks damages for Irans direct support for, and sponsorship of, the most deadly act of terrorism in American history.

title: A Solemn Homecoming
description: Equally awash in blood and sentiment, Cost of a Soul is a remorselessly violent drama populated by weeping women and tormented men.

title: Virtually a Good Time
description: As you might expect from a documentary whose producers include the Oprah Winfrey Network, Life 2.0 is less about the realities of Second Life, the immersive online world, than it is about the offline pathologies of the people who choose to live there.

title: Thrashers Appear Poised to Relocate to Winnipeg
description: The Thrashers stood on the brink of relocation to Winnipeg on Thursday, with the last hope for keeping the team in Atlanta hinging on negotiations with one remaining potential buyer, according to the teams president.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,566 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans this week:

title: Chinese Student Takes Aim, Literally, at Internet Regulator
description: BEIJING  The authorities are seeking a college student who sneaked into a lecture hall at one of Chinas most prestigious universities on Thursday and tossed eggs and shoes at a computer scientist both lionized and reviled as the architect of Chinas strict Internet controls.

title: Upwardly Mobile Nannies Move Into the Brazilian Middle Class
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  In a decade working as a nanny, Andreia Soares finally clambered up the ladder into Brazils middle class.

title: Are We Really Nicer Than Vampire Bats?
description: To the Editor:

title: Annex the West Bank?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Romance Stalked by Hatred
description: A skinny white boy from Nassau falls for a buff black islander in Children of God, a lush Bahamian romance stalked by homophobia and religious hatred.

title: Romney and Health Care
description: To the Editor:

title: China: Censorship Suit Filed Against Web Company
description: Eight Chinese-born pro-democracy advocates filed suit in Federal District Court in Manhattan on Wednesday against one of Chinas largest Internet companies, Baidu, accusing it of colluding with the government in censoring Web search results. The suit charges that there is a conspiracy between Baidu and the government to censor any political speech that is pro-democracy. Jiang Yu, a Foreign Ministry spokeswoman, said Thursday that China guaranteed freedom of speech online and that American courts had no jurisdiction in the country, the news agency Xinhua reported.

title: Belarus: A $3 Billion Bailout? Not So Fast, Says Russia
description: Officials in Belarus said Thursday they had won a $3 billion loan from a Russian-backed fund to alleviate the economic crisis, but Russias finance minister, Aleksei L. Kudrin, said no such decision by the Eurasian Economic Community had been made. Belarus has little hope of winning loans from Western governments, so Russia and other former Soviet states are negotiating a bailout. Twice this week, Belarussian officials have announced a deal, apparently eager to tamp down market panic, only to be contradicted by Mr. Kudrin.

title: Demjanjuk as Metaphor
description: To the Editor:

title: Treating Childhood Trauma
description: To the Editor:

title: Nursing Home Workers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Contemporary Romantic Melodrama
description: Among the steady stream of new Chinese movies opening in America, A Beautiful Life stands out  rather than an overstuffed, jingoistic historical tale or martial-arts blowout, its a contemporary romantic melodrama with a plaintive pop soundtrack that might call to mind Terms of Endearment, The Other Sister or, most strongly, a Nora Ephron comedy minus most of the laughs. (Theres also a bit of Memento thrown in.)

title: Liberty Media Offers to Buy Barnes & Noble
description: 9:23 p.m. | Updated

title: Electrode Experiment Shows Promise as a Paralyzed Man Stands
description: A young man paralyzed by an injury to his spinal cord has regained the ability to stand for short periods, take steps with help and move his legs and feet at will, with the help of an electrical stimulator implanted in his lower back.

title: Libya Revolt Sidelines Women, Who Led It
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  In recent days, after weeks of delays and closed-door meetings, rebel leaders here have announced a slate of new appointments, including a defense chief and a minister for reconstruction and infrastructure. They have added members to a national council, to represent areas in southern, central and western Libya, all in an effort to bolster the revolution, better represent the country as a whole and  in the event that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi bolts  make civil war unlikely, the rebel leaders explained.

title: The Battle for Libya | May 19, 2011
description: Libyans watched a television broadcast of a speech by President Obama on Thursday.

title: Don Barden, a Leading Black Businessman, Dies at 67
description: DETROIT  Don H. Barden, who rose from poverty to build one of the nations largest black-owned businesses through casinos and cable television, died on Thursday in Detroit. He was 67.

title: NASA Installs Device at Space Station in Long-Sought Quest for Antimatter
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  The astronauts aboard the space shuttle Endeavour attached a $2 billion cosmic ray detector to the International Space Station on Thursday, and delighted scientists immediately began detecting thousands and thousands of subatomic particles from deep space.

title: Worth Reading: LinkedIn Traded for $14.50 a Share Last Year
description: Liz Gannes at AllThings D looks at the price of LinkedIn shares when they were traded on SecondMarket.

title: Parents Battle School Districts for Special Support
description: In October, after months of anxiety, Caroline Barwick and her husband, Russell Huerta, celebrated the arrival of their son Sebastians third birthday.

title: Ex-Teammate Says He Saw Armstrong Dope
description: Tyler Hamilton, a former cyclist who was on three of Lance Armstrongs victorious Tour de France teams, told CBS News that he had witnessed Armstrongs use of performance-enhancing drugs.

title: Deal Reached on Extension of Patriot Act
description: WASHINGTON  Congressional leaders on Thursday reached a deal to extend by four years several statutes that expanded the Federal Bureau of Investigations counterterrorism and surveillance powers after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, aides said.

title: The Upfronts at Night
description: The Media Decoder blog visits the CBS and Adult Swim after-parties.

title: From Oakland to the World, Words of Warning: Times Up
description: Scott James writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: Ex-I.M.F. Chief Granted Bail
description: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former chief of the International Monetary Fund, was granted $1 million bail, and will remain under 24-hour surveillance with an ankle monitor.

title: Arizona: 21 Arrested in Smuggling Ring
description: Law enforcement officials announced Thursday the arrest of 21 people who they said used a remote area of the Tohono OOdham Indian reservation to smuggle marijuana and migrants from Mexico into the United States. Working with spotters equipped with night-vision goggles and radios, the smugglers were allied with a Mexican drug trafficking organization, officials said.

title: Mets Looked at Fraud Coverage for Madoff Stakes
description: In 2001, Fred Wilpon and Saul Katz, the owners of the Mets, decided to explore a fairly novel way of protecting the hundreds of millions of dollars they, their families and their businesses had invested with Bernard L. Madoff: they considered buying something called fraud insurance.

title: Refusing to Give In to Eviction
description: On Jan. 19, 63-year-old Tanya Dennis hired a locksmith and broke into her South Berkeley home.

title: California: Schwarzenegger Postpones Return to Film
description: Former Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger is putting his acting career on pause, one of his lawyers said Thursday, amid the news that he had fathered a child with a former member of his household staff more than a decade ago. The lawyer, Patrick Knapp, said in a statement that at Mr. Schwarzeneggers request we asked Creative Artists Agency to inform all his motion picture projects currently under way or being negotiated to stop planning until further notice. Governor Schwarzenegger is focusing on personal matters and is not willing to commit to any production schedules or timelines. The hiatus will include Cry Macho, a movie that was expected to begin production in August. The Terminator franchise and all other projects under consideration are also on hold, Mr. Knapp said, adding: We will resume discussions when Governor Schwarzenegger decides.

title: Armstrong Accused of Drug Use by Ex-Teammate
description: The cyclist Tyler Hamilton, one of Lance Armstrongs former teammates on the United States Postal Service team, said he saw Armstrong inject himself with the banned performance-enhancing drug EPO to win the Tour de France, according to a report on CBSs 60 Minutes that will run Sunday.

title: The Siege of the Freedom Riders
description: Atlanta

title: Losing (but Loving) the Green Card Lottery
description: Cambridge, Mass.

title: Washington: Senate Committee to Defer Budget Talks
description: The chairman of the Senate Budget Committee, Kent Conrad, announced Thursday that the panel would indefinitely defer work on a budget for the coming fiscal year. Mr. Conrad said the size of the projected annual deficits and the divisions between the two parties argued for awaiting the results of the bipartisan talks between Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Congressional leaders of both parties. All 11 Republicans on the Senate Budget Committee issued a statement criticizing the budget delay.

title: A Havana Connection Infuses the Music Scene
description: You wont find many Cuban sandwich shops around San Francisco or Cuban coffee on the menu at many taqueras, but those interested in Latin music and dance cant swing a bat drum without hitting a Cuban salsa class or finding Afro-Cuban-style timba music in clubs.

title: Retailers Fall Short as Shoppers Cut Back
description: Sears Holdings, the department store chain, swung to a first-quarter loss as shoppers cut back on spending.

title: Aiming to Rein In the Anarchy on 2 Wheels
description: Lunchtime on a spring day in 2009, and people in Midtown Manhattan swarmed from their offices, drawing breath on a fine afternoon. Stuart Gruskin, a 51-year-old executive in the financial industry, was on West 43rd Street near Fifth Avenue. He stepped off the curb in front of the Princeton Club.

title: The Death Knell of Slavery
description: When North Carolina finally voted to secede on May 20, 1861, editor William Holden later wrote, the states convention looked like a sea partly in storm, partly calm, the secessionists shouting and throwing up their hats and rejoicing, the Conservatives sitting quietly, calm, and depressed. Even as they voted unanimously to leave the Union, North Carolinas leading politicians could not conceal the conflicts that would divide the state throughout the war.

title: A Conversation About Food, Cooking and Alice B. Toklas
description: Virginia Heffernan talks with Amanda Hesser, a co-founder of food52 and the author of The Essential New York Times Cookbook, about some of the issues raised in a recent column.   The Editors

title: Publishers as Partners in Literacy
description: This week, I reported on the First Book Marketplace, which sells new books at steep discounts to schools and reading programs serving low-income children. Based on sales growth, First Book, which is a nonprofit, anticipates that the marketplace will be financially self-sustaining within a few years. Its hard to find fault with a social-purpose business that makes quality books more affordable for underprivileged children. But, surprisingly, many readers responded to the idea by suggesting that the problem of book access can be adequately addressed through rummage sales, thrift shops, used book outlets and libraries. This reflects a misunderstanding of the problem, which Id like to clarify.

title: Blagojevichs Courtroom, Oprahs Arena
description: James Warren writes a column for the Chicago News Cooperative.

title: Obama and Netanyahu, Distrustful Allies, Meet
description: WASHINGTON  As Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel heads to the White House on Friday for the seventh meeting since President Obama took office, the two men are facing a turning point in a relationship that has never been warm.

title: A Memorable Debut for Hector Noesi
description: Hector Noesis two children had been long asleep by the time their father made his major league debut Wednesday night, pitching four scoreless innings in the Yankees 4-1 victory. But when Yeudri, his 5-year-old son, woke up and heard that Noesi had finally pitched, he had but one question: Did my daddy win the game? Noesi recounted that story Thursday afternoon, when he was still trying to process his good fortune.

title: Making Things in America
description: Some years ago, one of my neighbors, an migr Russian engineer, offered an observation about his adopted country. America seems very rich, he said, but I never see anyone actually making anything.

title: A Rivers Crest Arrives, and Is Set to Linger
description: VICKSBURG, Miss.  Here it was at last  high, fast and in a very bad mood.

title: Judgment Day Followers Await Rapture
description: Thousands of people around the country prepared for Saturday, May 21, also known as Judgment Day, when believers expected to be absorbed into heaven in a process known as Rapture.

title: The Big Society
description: London

title: Heres a Great Place to Cut
description: It seems hard to believe, but the federal farm subsidy program  wasteful, inefficient and virtually indestructible  may at last be headed for serious downsizing.

title: Insurers Told to Justify Rate Increases Over 10 Percent
description: WASHINGTON  Alarmed at soaring premiums and profits in the health insurance industry, the Obama administration demanded on Thursday that insurers justify proposed rate increases of more than 10 percent, starting in September.

title: A Season Interrupted for Barcelonas Abidal
description: BARCELONA, Spain  Surgery in mid-March to have a tumor removed from his liver brought a scary disruption to ric Abidals professional soccer career. His unexpectedly fast return to the sport also brought a reassessment of his life.

title: LinkedIns Surge Sets Stage for More Internet I.P.O.s
description: Its not 1999, but the big Internet I.P.O. is back.

title: Peace and Change
description: We have been waiting for President Obama to lay out his vision of the promises and challenges of the upheaval in the Arab world. His speech on Thursday did not go far enough  there was no game-changing proposal on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict  but he did promise strong support to those yearning for freedom and goaded American allies, including Israel, to take the political risks that are essential for peaceful change and the only way to build a lasting peace.

title: Irans President to Lead Next OPEC Meeting
description: The Iranian president, Mahmoud Ahmadinejad, is expected to lead next months OPEC conference in Vienna as he presses for higher oil prices to aid Irans struggling economy, while also seeking to protect and consolidate his power at home as he confronts a growing split with the nations supreme leader.

title: Zenyattas Trainer Uncovers a Colt That Gives Him Hope
description: BALTIMORE  Zenyattas stall at Hollywood Park remains empty except for a few portraits of her drawn by her fans. She is at Lanes End farm in Kentucky working on becoming a broodmare. Her trainer, John Shirreffs, is here at Pimlico for the 136th running of the Preakness Stakes on Saturday with a pretty good colt named Mr. Commons.

title: Lights on Earth Impede Arizonas Eyes on Space
description: MOUNT HOPKINS, Ariz.  There is no Border Patrol in space. But the very earthly cat-and-mouse game between smugglers and Americas border agents is affecting the exploration of space, lighting up the nighttime sky in southern Arizona and making astronomers strain even harder to figure out the mysteries of the universe.

title: Make My Bed? But You Say the Worlds Ending
description: The Haddad children of Middletown, Md., have a lot on their minds: school projects, SATs, weekend parties. And parents who believe the earth will begin to self-destruct on Saturday.

title: They Need to Be Counted
description: It was a relief to see one politician showing political courage and sense in Albany this week. Of course, that politician was Mayor Michael Bloomberg of New York City and not a state lawmaker. But every bit helps.

title: Way Back Machine | Doomsday, East Patchogue, 1925
description: Almost since the moment the ink dried on the Book of Revelation, seers and scriptural interpreters have been announcing the precise date and time at which the faithful would be whisked off to heaven and those left behind abandoned to immediate and unpleasant annihilation.

title: The Truth About Upper Big Branch
description: An inquiry by the state of West Virginia into the Upper Big Branch Mine explosion that killed 29 workers has found the mines owner, Massey Energy, profoundly reckless in elevating its drive to produce profits above worker safety. Pervasive safety violations  from shoddy ventilation to slapdash control of explosive coal dust  made the mine an accident waiting to happen, according to a panel of experts reporting to the governors office.

title: Randolph Wants Another Chance
description: BALTIMORE

title: Austin Woes Are Capped by Decision to Fire Teachers and a Student Protest
description: After discovering last week that nearly a quarter of their teachers were being dismissed, students at Austin Polytechnical Academy decided to take extreme action. Holding secret planning sessions under the guise of a robotics team meeting, they plotted.

title: Best and Worst Scenes From Upfront Week
description: HERE is a look back at some of the highlights, lowlights and sidelights of the annual television upfront week, which took place around Manhattan from Monday through Thursday as television executives offered advertisers previews of their fare for the 2011-12 season.

title: Ex-Sheriffs Employee Draws Prison for Theft
description: PATERSON, N.J.  The former director of the Passaic County Sheriffs Department motor pool was sentenced on Thursday to four years in prison for stealing $20,000 and a car engine from the department.

title: At CUNY, Concerns That Overhaul of the Curriculum May Erode Academic Gains
description: For as long as anyone can remember, students who have tried to transfer within the City University of New York system  from, say, a community college to a four-year school  have run into delays or denials in getting their course credits accepted. Many have wound up spending additional time and money to secure their degree, while others have simply given up.

title: For James, a Star Turn on Jordans Court
description: CHICAGO

title: Photographer Is Killed in Libya
description: Friday, 12:15 a.m. | Updated

title: Friday: Watchdog in the House
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  There are 500 clues in the Cruciverb.com database that refer to the entry ONO, and the reason that there are only 500 clues listed is because that is the maximum number the database can hold.
