Yoko Ono has become a startlingly popular entry in crossword puzzles because of the alternating vowel-consonant pattern in her name. Ms. Ono has gotten me out of a sticky filling situation on more than one occasion myself.

title: Aldermen, Moving In, Lobby to Get Best Offices
description: Even before the April runoff election determined the membership of the new City Council, veteran aldermen were engaged in another, far less public, campaign: lobbying for premier office space at City Hall.

title: When Boy Meets Girl Plays Second Fiddle
description: Thanks to two central performances that go a long way toward transcending the occasional placeholder melody and clunky double entendre (O.K., the more-than-occasional clunky double entendre), Lucky Guy is more fun than it ought to be.

title: Before the Baby Is Born, Dad Needs to Soothe His Own Inner Child
description: Impending parenthood whips up a familiar tempest of anxieties in the hero of Knickerbocker, a new play by Jonathan Marc Sherman that opened on Thursday night at the Public Theater. Doubts about his readiness to assume the role of responsible caregiver all but ooze from the pores of Jerry (Alexander Chaplin), a 40-year-old book editor whose garden-variety neuroses are inflamed by the knowledge that he will soon have to relinquish gazing at his own navel in favor of cooing over his little boys.

title: Lottery Numbers
Pressure to Improve Water Quality in Chicago River
description: In recent days, the federal government and environmental groups have increased the pressure on Chicagos wastewater treatment agency to stop discharging untreated sewage into the Chicago River during storms and to disinfect the treated sewage that makes up 70 percent of the rivers flow.

title: Budgeters Try to Save Season for the New York City Opera
description: Board members of the New York City Opera hashed through the companys budget and programming options for next season in a grueling daylong meeting on Thursday, a watershed moment for what was once one of the countrys major opera companies. Adding to the pressure, union officials appealed for more mainstream programming and denounced the way the company has been marketing itself.

title: Bloggingheads: Google and Free Speech
description: Ann Althouse, left, of the University of Wisconsin Law School and Matt Welch of Reason debate Google's threat to free speech.

title: Video From the Upfronts: The After-Parties for CBS and Adult Swim
description: On Wednesday, The Timess media reporter Tanzina Vega visited the CBS and Adult Swim upfront after-parties. CBS held its post-presentation festivities in a tent at Lincoln Center with aD.J. and television stars, while Adult Swims affair at the Roseland Ballroom included a performance by Jay-Z.

title: A Cloud Over Turkish Candidates Chances to Lead I.M.F.
description: LONDON  On paper Kemal Dervis would seem to be the perfect candidate to succeed Dominique Strauss-Kahn as leader of the International Monetary Fund.

title: At I.M.F., Men on Prowl and Women on Guard
description: WASHINGTON  It is an international island in the midst of the American capital, a sharp-elbowed place ruled by alpha male economists. The days are long, and employees are regularly pressed together for weeks on end during overseas missions. It is a climate in which romances often flourish  and lines are sometimes crossed.

title: Education Legislation Struggle Breaks Old Alliances, Builds New Ones
description: Just past midnight, at the close of a 14-hour day last week on the floor of the Texas House, Representative Rob Eissler stood joking with reporters.

title: N.F.L. Requests More Time to Respond to Players Lawsuit
description: The N.F.L. asked Thursday for more time to respond to the antitrust lawsuit brought by players in the Brady vs. N.F.L. case. The N.F.L. has asked that the deadline, which is next Monday, be extended until July 6, arguing that the Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit is likely to have decided on the appeal of the now-delayed injunction that would end the lockout. That decision, the N.F.L. said, is likely to inform future actions, including whether to file a motion to dismiss the case. When the N.F.L. asked the players represented in the Brady suit to consent to the extension, they declined. The leagues motion asking for the extension is pending. The Brady plaintiffs would prefer no delays in the lawsuit, which, with its threat of treble damages if the league is found to have violated antitrust law with restrictions on free agency and the draft, may present the best leverage the players have in their contract negotiations.

title: There Is More Than One Way to Land a Catfish
description: Brady Knowlton has scurried up trees to escape elephants. He has been chased by lions. But in years of hunting, he said, no experience compares to plunging his bare hand into murky water and feeling the powerful jaw of a big catfish clamp down on his arm.

title: Saying Hes Not Running Puts Perry in a Good Spot
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor at The Texas Tribune, writes a column for the Tribune.

title: NATO Warplanes Attack Libyan Ships in 3 Ports
description: NAPLES, Italy  NATO warplanes attacked eight Libyan ships on Thursday night in three coastal locations, including the port of Tripoli, expanding the air campaign against what allied officials said was an increasing seaborne threat from Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis forces.

title: Exuberant Days for LinkedIn
description: It looks as if even LinkedIns bankers underestimated the hype. The shares more than doubled on the day of their debut, meaning underwriters left more money on the table than they harvested for LinkedIn and its selling shareholders. But if the hype doesnt wear off soon, the scarcity value of social network investments surely will.

title: GTT
description: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

title: Quiet Departure Is Stark Contrast to Heralded Arrival
description: CBS Evening News bade farewell to its anchor, Katie Couric, on Thursday with a five-minute highlights reel and a rendition of the Beatles ballad In My Life, but there wasnt much sadness on the set. Ms. Couric, brisk and dry-eyed, looked almost relieved as she thanked viewers for, as she put it, coming along with me on this incredible journey.

title: E-Books Outsell Print Books at Amazon
description: In the latest chapter in the unfolding tale of the book evolution from ink to pixels, Amazon.com said Thursday that its customers now buy more e-books than print books.

title: Reviving a Rarity, Right on Time
description: Why certain composers who were popular in their day become marginalized over time is often inexplicable. Somehow this happens especially in opera, perhaps because opera composers so often tailored their works to the specific tastes of the theaters and audiences for which they were writing.

title: FrontPoint to Shut Most Funds After Insider Trading Charges
description: FrontPoint Partners, once a multibillion-dollar hedge fund before it was battered by allegations of insider trading, will shut down most of its funds by the end of the month.

title: Debussy Flows in Ripples and Seductive Warbles
description: Introducing a performance of Debussys Rhapsody for Clarinet and Piano at the Kosciuszko Foundation on East 65th Street in Manhattan on Wednesday night, the distinguished clarinetist David Shifrin mused to the audience that Debussy probably first heard the piece played in a similarly intimate space. While listening to Mr. Shifrins seductive warble and the pianist Gloria Chiens elegant ripples and shadings, your eyes might wander across warm, wood-paneled walls bedecked with old oil paintings; an ornately sculptured ceiling; and vintage tapestries hung over the windows.

title: Schools in Session, but Dont You Dare Take Notes
description: One way jazz can seem from the outside is as a never-ending eulogy. This week in New York there are or have been concerts paying homage to or performing the repertory of: Count Basie, Clifford Jordan, Thelonious Monk, Dizzy Gillespie, Miles Davis and the Modern Jazz Quartet. Its just an average week. Is that O.K.? Is that strange?

title: From Milan to New York in 240 Years
description: Mozarts opera Mitridate, Re di Ponto, had its premiere in Milan on Dec. 26, 1770. A month later, Mozart turned 15.

title: New York Public Library Introduces iPad Apps
description: Here an app, there an app, everywhere an apt app. Now the New York Public Library is creating iPad apps that bring its research collections into the palms of the publics hand, as library officials put it in a statement. Biblion: The Boundless Library is the name for a series of apps available on Apples tablet computer that highlight different elements in the librarys collection. It was developed by the library and the design firm Potion. The first edition showcases the librarys holdings about the 1939-40 New York Worlds Fair, which are among those most consulted by researchers. Users will be able to turn over, zoom in on and roam through hundreds of items. At the end of this week the library is putting out an app that lets the public play Find That Future, from the game designer Jane McGonigal. This summer, look for an app enabling people to reserve books. The first app is available free at Apples iTunes store and nypl.org.

title: Missing Photographer in Libya Is Presumed Dead
description: The family of Anton Hammerl, a South African photojournalist who has been missing in Libya since early last month, said late Thursday that they think he died after being shot on April 5 in the desert.

title: Widow of Bernard Madoffs Son Signs a Deal for a Memoir
description: A member of the Madoff family is telling all in a memoir to be released in December, its publisher said on Wednesday. Stephanie Madoff-Mack, the widow of Mark Madoff, the son of Bernard L. Madoff who committed suicide last year, has sold her book to Blue Rider Press, an imprint of Penguin Group USA. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. David Rosenthal, the publisher of Blue Rider Press, called it the first genuine inside account from a Madoff family member, a memoir that begins with the unraveling of Mr. Madoffs Ponzi scheme. Ms. Madoff-Macks story, he said in a statement, is heartbreaking, compelling and ultimately courageous.

title: American Idol Again, by a Mile
description: The three American Idol finalists still standing (Haley Reinhart, Scotty McCreery and Lauren Alaina, below from left) competed on Wednesday night for a chance to advance to next weeks finale as 23 million viewers tuned in to Foxs two-hour reality show broadcast, according to Nielsens estimates. No other network came close to matching Foxs ratings. CBS placed second, earning its best ratings at 9 p.m. with Criminal Minds (12.5 million) followed by Criminal Minds: Suspect Behavior at 10 (8.4 million). At 8, CBSs rerun of Criminal Minds (6.3 million) lagged behind ABCs sitcom The Middle (7.7 million). ABC finished in third place over all, attracting 10.1 million viewers at 9 for Modern Family but more modest results for Cougar Town at 9:30 (5.4 million) and Happy Endings at 10 (3.8 million) and 10:30 (3.1 million). NBC was fourth, leading the 10 p.m. hour with Law & Order: SVU (8.7 million) but struggling earlier in the night with back-to-back episodes of Minute to Win It at 8 (3.5 million) and at 9 (2.9 million).

title: A 2012 Release Date Is Set for a Titanic in 3-D
description: In case you ever doubted it, James Cameron is truly the king of the three-dimensional world. Or he will be when his Titanic is re-released by Paramount Pictures and 20th Century Fox on April 6 in 3-D. Mr. Cameron, whose 3-D Avatar, with almost $2.8 billion in ticket sales at the worldwide box office, is the highest-grossing film in history, will revise the record books when Titanic, the second-highest-grossing film of all time, with $1.8 billion in worldwide sales, returns to theaters in 3-D. Fox and Paramount joined Mr. Camerons Lightstorm Entertainment in announcing the re-release date on Thursday. The next frontier in 3-D may well involve not fantasies and cartoons but naturalistic dramas like Titanic (starring Leonardo DiCaprio and Kate Winslet, left). Steven Soderbergh, for instance, had planned to shoot his coming Contagion, a disease drama, in 3-D, but backed off when he couldnt quite get the results he needed. Still, 3-D thrillers, love stories and raunchy teen comedies (shudder) clearly are just a matter of time.

title: Pop and Rock Listings
description: Pop

title: Corrections
description: BUSINESS DAY

title: Barbara Stuart, TV Actress, Is Dead at 81
description: Barbara Stuart, an actress with a familiar if not famous face on television for half a century, who appeared on nearly 80 television series that spanned much of the mediums history, died on Sunday in St. George, Utah. She was 81.

title: Posada Provides the Suspense in a One-Sided Game
description: BALTIMORE  The Yankees had not scheduled infield practice, but an hour before Thursday nights game against the Orioles, their fill-in first baseman was out fielding grounders, receiving throws and turning 3-6-3 double plays. Jorge Posada needed the extra work.

title: N.F.L. Requests More Time  to Respond to Players Lawsuit
description: The N.F.L. asked Thursday for more time to respond to the antitrust lawsuit brought by players in the Brady vs. N.F.L. case.

title: Word of the Day | decadence
description: decadence \de-k-dn(t)s also di-ka-\ noun

title: Durant and Depth Slow Down Mavericks
description: DALLAS  The Oklahoma City Thunder should have been rattled, if not by the moment, certainly by the furious counterpunches from the Dallas Mavericks as they fought to hold home-court advantage.

title: Lionel Messi: Portrait of the Artist as a Trainee
description: Jer Longman of The Times traveled to Barcelona recently to research a feature about Lionel Messi for Sundays paper. Not everything he learned will fit in the final version, however, including this glimpse of Messis early days at the club.

title: Risks: Allergic to Peanuts, Even in Transfused Blood
description: Doctors in the Netherlands said that a 6-year-old boy with an allergy to peanuts went into anaphylactic shock after receiving a blood transfusion from donors who had been snacking on them.

title: Prevention: Coffee Lowers Risk of Prostate Cancer, Harvard Study Says
description: If thats java in your cup, drink up. A new study says that men who are heavy coffee drinkers are at lower risk for prostate cancer.

title: We Are All Teenage Werewolves
description: On a Wednesday in March, in a narrow trailer somewhere outside Atlanta, Dr. Funk and Dr. Dre, two special-effects makeup artists, were busy turning two young men, both named Tyler, into werewolves.

title: News Quiz | May 20, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Japan Closer to Giving Rights to Foreign Parents
description: TOKYO  Japan moved closer Friday to joining an international child-custody agreement that would give rights to non-Japanese parents involved in disputes with Japanese citizens.

title: Test Yourself | History, May 20, 2011
description: Test your knowledge of history with todays question about the 1961 Freedom Riders.

title: Daily Lexeme: Mumbudget
description: Todays word, in association with the wonderful Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: The Science of Winter Break
description: With the days shorter and the weekends chillier, whats a family to do? Go to a science museum!

title: Pakistani Dies From Attack on U.S. Vehicles
description: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  A bomb aimed at a two-car convoy carrying American consular officials to work exploded Friday morning, but no Americans were killed or seriously wounded, a United States Embassy spokesman said.

title: South Korean Media Revise Reports on North Korean Trip to China
description: HONG KONG  The South Korean news media changed course on Friday and said that the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-il, was traveling to China, revising earlier reports that his son and heir apparent, Kim Jong-un, had made the journey.

title: Head of Japanese Utility Steps Down After Nuclear Crisis
description: TOKYO  The president of Tokyo Electric Power resigned on Friday, shouldering responsibility for the crisis at the companys Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant as the utility booked a $15 billion annual loss, the largest by a nonfinancial company in Japanese history.

title: Employment Outlook Bleak for College Graduates
description: For WHOM have employment rates fallen sharply in the last two years?

title: Songs About What Went Wrong, but Performed So Right
description: Vengeance is soulful for the English singer and songwriter Adele.

title: Queens Ireland Visit Seen as Significant Advance
description: LONDON  Queen Elizabeth II wrapped up her groundbreaking four-day visit to the Irish Republic on Friday, a trip that ranked among the most politically freighted of her almost 60 years on the throne.

title: Week-Endvy
description: Envy of the social lives of friends  as (mis)described on social networking sites.

title: Prada Is Cleared for Hong Kong I.P.O.
description: 8:19 p.m. | Updated

title: An Early Ad Targets Romney
description: An advertisement scheduled to run in South Carolina during a visit there by Mitt Romney seeks to exploit critiques of his statements on health care.

title: Whats Your Reaction to the Schwarzenegger Scandal?
description: One of the top stories in the news this week is the revelation that Arnold Schwarzenegger, a Hollywood actor who served two terms as governor of California, fathered a child with a member of his households staff approximately 13 years ago, and kept it a secret until now. What are your thoughts about this story, and about the controversy over the related privacy issues?

title: The Early Word: Netanyahu Arrives
description: In Todays Times

title: Food Festival to Feed Prague Gastronauts
description: Long gone are the days when the primary dining options in Prague revolved around meat, dumplings and cabbage. Come the weekend of May 27 to 29, visitors to the Prague Food Festival can see  and taste  exactly how far the capital city has come in embracing cuisines from around the world, not to mention its own.

title: The Rise of the Five-Year Four-Year Degree
description: Judith Scott-Clayton is an assistant professor at Teachers College, Columbia University.

title: Group Unleashes Early Ad Against Romney
description: 8:59 a.m. | Updated The new political group co-founded last month by two former aides to President Obama is unleashing its first television broadside against Republicans Friday, attacking former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts on health care and needling former House Speaker Newt Gingrich in the process.

title: Will Barcelona Be a Different Race?
description: BARCELONA  The talk around the paddock here is about a few points of interest, like Fernando Alonso signing until 2016 with Ferrari and a potential change in date for the Indian Grand Prix to December in order to accommodate a return of Bahrain Grand Prix in October. But in anticipation of the Spanish Grand Prix race on Sunday, the big question is, Will the new rules allow overtaking to happen at this circuit?

title: Will Barcelona Be a Different Race?
description: BARCELONA  The talk around the paddock here is about a few points of interest, like Fernando Alonso signing until 2016 with Ferrari and a potential change in date for the Indian Grand Prix to December in order to accommodate a return of Bahrain Grand Prix in October. But in anticipation of the Spanish Grand Prix race on Sunday, the big question is, Will the new rules allow overtaking to happen at this circuit?

title: Tip of the Week: Logging Out of Facebook Remotely
description: If you forget to log out of your Facebook account before you leave your home, office or other location where the computer might be shared, you do not have to worry about someone else messing around with your profile page. Just log into your account from another computer or device, go to the Account menu in the top right corner of the page and select Account Settings.

title: At Racings Poker Table, Owners and Breeders Are the Marks
description: Billy Walters, one of the worlds most successful professional gamblers, warns that no matter what game you are playing, if you look around the room and cant find the mark, you are it.

title: Patience, Fortitude and a Whole Lot of Legos
description: Nathan Sawaya did Patience first, just as the other guy did. You know, Edward Clark Potter, the sculptor who did the lions in front of the New York Public Library, on Fifth Avenue at 42nd Street.

title: South Africa Assails Libya Over Death of Photographer
description: JOHANNESBURG  South Africa accused Libyan leaders including Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi on Friday of spreading misinformation about the fate of a South African photojournalist by saying he was alive when they knew him to be dead.

title: Embracing the Anthropocene
description: Following up on my coverage of the first scientific conference on the proposition that we have entered a geological epoch of our own making, the Anthropocene, Room for Debate has assembled a great cast of characters to discuss whether this is a good, bad or indifferent thing.

title: Democrats New Tactic: Praising 2012 Republicans
description: At a fund-raiser in Boston this week, President Obama went out of his way to praise Mitt Romney, the former Republican governor of the state, for an assist in passing health care reform.

title: BP Partner Agrees to $1.1 Billion Settlement Related to Gulf Spill
description: LONDON  BP said Friday that Moex Offshore, one of its partners in the oil well that leaked into the Gulf of Mexico last year, had agreed to pay $1.1 billion as part of a settlement for any claims related to the oil spill.

title: Girl Overboard
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#968", 592, 450, true, chameleonData);

title: Moving Murray
description: I spent a recent weekend in southern New Jersey with my father, carefully labeling his entire wardrobe  every sock, pajama top and handkerchief  with a black Sharpie. The continuing care retirement community hes moving to will do his laundry weekly, and it wants his name on each garment.

title: Q. and A. With Lady Gaga on Her Freedom Ride
description: For a profile in Arts & Leisure, Jon Pareles sat down with Lady Gaga as she prepares for the release of Born This Way, her second studio album. The album is as catchy and euphorically overblown as the music that made her a sensation, Mr. Pareles writes about the pop superstar. It also adds an additional dimension to her songs: her cherished relationship with a mass audience  fans who call themselves Little Monsters and dress up with a gender-bending zeal  to whom she is a goddess, a big sister, a mouthpiece, a counselor and a cheerleader.

title: Answers to Readers Baseball Questions, Part 2
description: The following are responses from Tyler Kepner, David Waldstein and Ben Shpigel, the Timess baseball writers, who took questions from readers this week about the Mets, Yankees and the game overall through the first quarter of the 2011 season.

title: Bark Hot Dogs Will Open at Pier 6 in Brooklyn Bridge Park
description: The eating options in Brooklyn Bridge Park will spread south to Pier 6 on May 28 when Bark, the haute dog spot in Park Slope, Brooklyn, opens a stand there serving franks and burgers, along with ice cream from Blue Marble and Uncle Louie Gs, and sandwiches from Milk Truck Grilled Cheese. Later next month it will move to a terrace cafe on the pier with 200 seats and will start serving beers from Sixpoint Craft Ales and wine. The stand will be open Saturdays and Sundays, then the terrace will be open Friday nights, Saturdays and Sundays through Labor Day.

title: A Downgrade by Fitch Leads to a Decline in Greek Bonds
description: Greek bonds led declines among euro area nations on Friday on concern a restructuring of its debt would reignite Europes sovereign debt crisis.

title: As NATO Claims Progress in Libya, a U.S. Deadline Is Put to the Test
description: WASHINGTON  With NATO officials expressing increased confidence on Friday that Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis military position in Libya was weakening, the Obama administration appeared to ignore a statute requiring hostilities to cease after two months if Congress had not authorized them to continue.

title: The Deepest End
description: Wil S. Hyltons article on Air France Flight 447 was informative, fair and moving. I would have never thought that an article on an air disaster would so insightfully touch on so many aspects of the human heart and mind. Hyltons exploration captured in words what the cover photograph so chillingly represented to me: the unfathomable scope of natures capacity to challenge mans quest to advance and the heartbreaking tragedies that will invariably accompany that contest.

title: Unsafe at Any Speed?
description: When my family rents a car, the rental company sends someone to pick us up. The driver they send has sleep apnea (as do I), and he is not getting any treatment. I havent seen him drive dangerously, but drivers with sleep apnea are as much as five times more likely to be involved in car accidents. I doubt I can persuade him to get treatment. I am also uncomfortable tattling on him to his employer. What should I do? A. G., MASSACHUSETTS

title: Germanys Anti-Chaos Crusaders
description: Knuth Kaufmann, a 41-year-old former accountant for the German Air Force and current member of the local Ordnungsbehrde, or Department of Order, eyed a young woman bicycling down the cobblestone lane. As she approached, he ordered her to dismount, and he reached into his pocket. Out came a yellow card with a large red circle around a picture of a bicycle, a reminder that its against the rules to ride in a pedestrian-only shopping zone.

title: My New Kentucky Baby
description: We came to Bowling Green, Ky., home of our good-humored surrogate, Gail, with a court order from California designating me and Richard  my husband in some states, though not in Kentucky  as the future babys legal parents. Id been hoping to avoid Kentucky. Its laws make it seem unwelcoming to gay people and ambivalent about surrogacy. I figured that culturally it would be red-statey too, full of homophobia, guns and fatty foods. The coasts seemed safer, especially for a black man, a Jew and their black-Jewish daughter.

title: Jimmy Lai Animates the News
description: You own magazines and newspapers in Hong Kong and Taiwan and have been called the Rupert Murdoch of Asia  and yet youre best known here for your companys very enjoyable and weird animated re-enactments of news events. The one you did for Tiger Woodss Thanksgiving-weekend car accident got more than five million YouTube views. Why did you get into animation?  I started the animations because print media was going into a sunset business environment. Its obvious that we have arrived at an era of images. I thought that if I could speed up the production of animation, I could make a big business out of recreating the amazing images of the news, because what we get on TV is always the last bit of image. What happened before that image is always missing.

title: An Unspeakable Word Is the Word That Has to Be Spoken
description: What have writers got but words? And what have people got but their own bodies to inhabit?

title: Block Quote: The Case Against Cursing
description: The Times writes unblushingly about sexual behavior, arts censorship, science, health, crime and similar subjects, opening its columns to any newsworthy detail, however disturbing, provided the approach is dignified and the vocabulary clinical rather than coarse. In these situations, the paper rejects evasiveness and euphemism, which would be a disservice to readers who need to understand issues.

title: Fortune Brands Sells Golf Business for $1.23 Billion
description: Fortune Brands said on Friday that it had agreed to sell its golf business to a group led by the owner of the Fila sports brand for $1.23 billion in cash.

title: Warren Buffett: Regional Manager, Scranton, Pa.
description: Is there a new job in Warren E. Buffetts future?

title: Harold Bloom: An Uncommon Reader
description: At the age of 80, with almost 40 books behind him and nearly as many accumulated honors, Harold Bloom has written, in The Anatomy of Influence, a kind of summing-up  or, as he puts it in his distinctive idiom, mixing irony with histrionism, my virtual swan song, born of his urge to say in one place most of what I have learned to think about how influence works in imaginative literature.

title: Growing Up Anxious and Androgynous
description: Jon-Jon Goulians eyes are beady and his head is small, at least in proportion to the rest of him. He went prematurely bald. He has seriously bowed legs and exasperating skin, inasmuch as it long served as the bumpy battleground between him and his acne. But his nose, well, thats quite possibly the worst of him. He has had it surgically altered not once but twice, and a third intervention may well be in order. Its no longer huge but not yet acceptable.

title: Swim Back to Me
description: Walk for Mankind

title: Ann Packers Unhappy Heroines
description: Oh, California, you arent as young as you used to be. Your years of bad decisions and fast living have finally caught up with you. Not to mention the sting of the past decades tumultuous relationships: that nasty breakup with Gray Davis; the fling with the former bodybuilder; and now an 11th-hour reconciliation with an ex, both of you silver at the temples and ready to be done with the drama. Youve seen your share of crises and ruin, but its time to pick up the pieces.

title: Who Was Theodosia Burr?
description: American history brims with stories of mysterious disappearances. We still wonder what happened to Virginia Dare, the first English infant born in this country, in 1587, in the lost Roanoke settlement of what would become North Carolina. Also unknown is the fate of a woman who disappeared in the same region generations later: Theodosia Burr Alston, daughter of Aaron Burr and wife of the governor of South Carolina, whose ship sank off the coast in January 1813.

title: Juniors: In the Quiet of Summer, Start Your Essays
description: Mr. Gelb is the author of Conquering the College Admissions Essay in 10 Steps.

title: Julian Barnes on Not Talking About Love
description: Couples are the beating heart, the systole and diastole, of Pulse, Julian Barness diverting third collection of stories. Author of the best-selling Arthur & George (an odd-couple historical novel in which Arthur is the creator of Sherlock Holmes) and the unclassifiable masterpiece Flauberts Parrot, Barnes is among the most adventurous writers  in style, versatility and narrative structure  of his Amis-McEwan-Hitchens generation. Another of his beguiling novels, Talking It Over, was about a loquacious love triangle, and what the characters mainly talk over in Pulse is what makes couples tick. What do we look for in a partner? the puzzled narrator, who was still unmarried at 30, asks in the title story. Someone who matches us? Perhaps. But is it possible that were sometimes driven towards people with the same faults as we have?

title: Can Social Networking Cure Social Ills?
description: Man, Aristotle said, is by nature a social animal. This is the premise of Tina Rosenbergs new and important book, Join the Club, which examines the idea that human behavior is defined by our relationships with our acquaintances. Peer pressure, she finds, can lead to acts of great courage, or to great harm. But Rosenbergs particular ambition is to unlock the secret of using it to transform the world, in the words of her subtitle. Calling this approach the social cure, she examines how social networks can address some of the worlds most recalcitrant problems  from adolescent cigarette smoking to despotism.

title: A New York Jewish Girl Becomes an Islamist
description: Deborah Baker is a serious biographer who specializes in fairly crazy writers. Her study of the poet Laura Riding, who survived a suicide attempt in 1929, during her 14-year mnage--trois with Robert Graves and his wife, was a Pulitzer finalist. Next came A Blue Hand, her portrait of the Beats in India, few of whom were in robust mental health. Yet even these have nothing on Maryam Jameelah, a New York Jewish convert to Islam, who  as a disciple of Pakistans most world-renowned fundamentalist  made a career out of condemning the West in dozens of books and pamphlets.

title: Von Triers Company Apologizes for Directors Remarks at Cannes
description: The production company that the Danish filmmaker Lars von Trier helped found apologized on Friday for remarks the director made at the Cannes Film Festival on Wednesday in which he said he understood and sympathized with Hitler.

title: The Last Casbah
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#380", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Friday Reading: A New App Helps Used-Car Buyers
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Morning Take-Out
description: TOP STORIES

title: Coming Out: Gay Teenagers, in Their Own Words
description: The suicide of Tyler Clementi, a Rutgers University freshman who jumped from the George Washington Bridge last year after discovering that his roommate had secretly streamed his romantic interlude with another man on the Internet, captured worldwide  attention. In the wake of his death, stories of gay youths being bullied and taking their own lives proliferated.

title: To Win More, Perhaps Woods Should Play Less
description: Until now, most comparisons between Tiger Woods and golfers from other eras have focused on Jack Nicklaus, whose record of 18 major championship victories has been circled on Woodss to-do list since he was a skinny kid living in the Los Angeles suburb of Cypress, Calif.

title: The Muslim Art of Science
description: In the thousand years between the decline of Rome and the springtime of the Renaissance, science and other branches of learning took a holiday throughout Europe. It was a benighted time in the history most of us raced through in school, skipping lightly through Charlemagne and Richard the Lion-Hearted, the Norman Conquest and the Crusades, and arriving none too soon at the time of Leonardo and Michelangelo, Columbus and da Gama, Erasmus and Luther.

title: Who Will Reap the Dividends of Fuel Economy?
description: There are two basic arguments over whether and how the country should respond to climate change and other environmental challenges. One focuses on governments right to regulate industry, and the other on the costs and benefits of such regulation.

title: Consciousness: The Great Illusion?
description: Soul Dust, Nicholas Humphreys new book about consciousness, is seductive  early 1960s, Mad Men seductive. His writing is as elegant, and hypnotic, as that cool jazz stacked on the record player. His argument feels as crystalline and bracing as that double martini going down, though you might find yourself a little woozy afterward. And his tone is as warm and inviting as that big, crackling fire, even if the dim flicker does leave things a bit obscure in the corners. I mean, the man recites Rupert Brooke love poetry at length. Very different from the usual awkward geeks of academic philosophy and psychology.

title: Finding More Founders
description: Historians refer to the trend as Founders Chic: the recent flurry of interest in biographies of the great white men of our nations founding generation. Although George Washington has consistently attracted Americans attention since Parson Weemss biography appeared in 1800, during the last decade published examinations of Washingtons contemporaries have multiplied dramatically. Take John Adams. By my rough count, he alone or in conjunction with other men has been the subject of 19 biographical studies and five documentary collections since 2001. Two more books have examined his marriage to Abigail Smith; she herself has warranted two separate biographies. Remarkably, a recent search in the Cornell library catalog for the phrase founding fathers in titles of books on American history published since 2001 identified 37 volumes.

title: Agency Investigates 170,000 Ford Freestyle Crossovers for Lunging Condition
description: An investigation is under way into the possibility that 170,000 Ford Freestyles have a tendency to accelerate without the drivers foot on the gas pedal.

title: Extra Innings
description: If you wanted to write a novel about the redemptive power of Americas pastime, you would imagine a Midwestern cornfield sculptured into a diamond that brought back the dead and healed generational wounds. Then you would remember that this idea has been taken, and instead you would invent the tale of the longest professional game ever played. You would make it a minor league contest, featuring players with mostly faint hopes of getting to the majors; they would absurdly play into the wee hours with no scouts in sight in Aprils irrelevant cold. Therefore  and heres your grand novelistic gesture  they must be persevering for some purpose larger than themselves. It would take place on Easter, the day the dead are reborn, in a decaying Northeastern mill town peopled by working-class Catholics who believe that unimportant things like wafers, wine and baseball can be made holy through faith. If you wished to be really obvious, the game would last 33 innings  one for each of Jesus years on earth.

title: Pete Hamills Tabloid Thriller
description: Granted, as silver linings go this may be scant consolation, but the decline and demise of newspapers seems to be ushering in a raft of good novels by journalists who miss the old ink and newsprint. Reporters harking back to footloose times are not new (think of Evelyn Waughs When the Going Was Good), but now that end days may actually be upon us, we may be facing a complete subgenre: O sont les news dantan? Weve already had Tom Rachmans book The Imperfectionists. Now comes Pete Hamills Tabloid City, which sets a high bar for those that follow.

title: The Case for Self-Publishing
description: Many thousands of years ago, when I was still a whelpish newspaper reporter in Chicago, I did a short profile of a retired television repairman whod written a memoir entitled The Perilous Life of Boris B. Gursky. As a boy in Ukraine, Gursky said, he was stepped on by a horse; when he was a young man in Mexico, his stepfather had tried to murder him; and when he was a middle-aged man in Chicago, his ex-wife had clawed his face with her fingernails and threatened him with a loaded pistol. Most perilously, Gursky suffered from prostate cancer. He wrote, My body had become so sensitive from staying too long in an environment surrounded with radiation from television sets.

title: Corey Taylor of Slipknot to Speak at Oxford Union
description: After a centuries-long tradition of gussying up its debates with a little pomp and circumstance, one of Britains foremost institutions of oratory apparently has decided that gowns and powdered wigs wont cut it anymore, and has turned to a man known for performing in jumpsuits and fetishistic masks. Corey Taylor, the lead singer of the heavy-metal band Slipknot, will be among the speakers to address the Oxford Union in the coming weeks, according to the schedule published on the unions Web site.

title: D.N.C. Raises More Money Than R.N.C. in April
description: The Democratic National Committee significantly outraised its Republican counterpart in April, powered in part by millions of dollars from successful fund-raisers that featured President Obama, a D.N.C. official said.

title: Editors Choice
description: TO END ALL WARS: A Story of Loyalty and Rebellion, 1914-1918,  by Adam Hochschild (Houghton Mifflin Harcourt, $28.) Hochschilds stirring account concentrates on the appalling losses in the ranks and on the extraordinary courage of the dissenters.

title: Paperback Row
description: THE GOOD MAN JESUS AND THE SCOUNDREL CHRIST,  by Philip Pullman (Canongate, $14.) This provocative retelling of the Gospels, by the author of the fantasy series His Dark Materials, separates the ethical teachings from the miracles and damnations by having the Virgin Mary give birth to twins: Jesus, wise and strong-willed; and the shrewd Christ, who is tempted by a silver-tongued stranger.

title: Journalism on Trial
description: To the Editor:

title: The Definitive F. A. Hayek
description: To the Editor:

title: Music for Silenced Voices
description: To the Editor:

title: The Presidents Middle East Speech
description: The evidence for the Bush-Obama foreign policy convergence continues to pile up: In its broad strokes, yesterdays address was a speech that George W. Bush could have given, from its summary of the neoconservative case against a stability-oriented Middle East policy to its invocation of Iraq as a model for the region to its defense of military interventionism against dictators to its assertion that henceforth, the promotion of democracy would lie at the center of American foreign policy in the Muslim world. Not for nothing are some of the presidents admirers suddenly praising Barack Obama for being a better Bush than Bush himself.

title: Fighting for the Right to Tell Lies
description: DENVER  In 2009, a burly Colorado man named Rick Duncan was a rising star among local veterans groups, advocating on behalf of struggling soldiers and holding forth about his own powerful experiences returning from Iraq as a wounded Marine.

title: Pawlenty to Announce 2012 Run on Monday
description: Tim Pawlenty, the former governor of Minnesota who has been exploring a presidential candidacy for months, will formally announce his intention to join the Republican field on Monday during a visit to Iowa, an adviser said.

title: Harris in Lineup Means Ace on the Mound
description: Willie Harris is not having a good month. He is not having a good season, either, based on his .205 batting average, but perhaps he deserves sympathy for what he has gone through the past four weeks.

title: The 50-Foot Commute
description: AS technology makes it easier for workers to do their jobs from home, buyers and renters in New York are seeking dedicated space where they can install a computer, a comfortable swivel chair and a desk, and block out productivity-sapping distractions.

title: The Last Jam Session
description: IGNORE the splintered banisters leading up the stoop at 106 Rivington Street. Instead, go down the four steps on the right, push through the graffiti-marked metal door into the basement and gird yourself against the rank smell  a perfumed mix of sweat and soaked carpet.

title: South Africa Assails Libya Over Photographers Death
description: The family of Anton Hammerl, a South African photojournalist missing in Libya since early April, said Thursday that they believed he died after being shot on April 5 in the desert.

title: If World Ends, So Does Alternate-Side Parking
description: If the world begins to self-destruct on Saturday, as some religious figures have predicted, there may be a bit of consolation for New Yorkers left behind to perish: alternate-side-of-the-street parking rules would be suspended.

title: The Caucus Click: Jon Huntsman in Hancock, N.H.
Hold the Onions and Cook With Leeks
description: In this weeks Recipes for Health, Martha Rose Shulman asks why leeks are so underused in the United States.

title: Hotels Pitch Savings for Family Vacations
description: With summer approaching, many parents are planning family vacations. And just in time, some hotels are offering specials for travelers with children.

title: On Our Radar: Indonesia Signs Deal to Protect Virgin Forests
description: Indonesias president signs a two-year moratorium on new logging concessions in the island nations still-prolific virgin forests, part of a $1 billion climate change deal with Norway intended to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from deforestation. Under the deal, more than 150 million acres of primary forest are expected to be protected. Indonesia will not return to the past of unsustainable development practices, a top environment adviser says. [The Jakarta Post]

title: Now Open | Nights and Weekends
description: Five Leaves, the Brooklyn cafe and bar known for its ties to the late actor Heath Ledger (he discovered the space while skateboarding), is about to expand its laid-back Aussie vibe with its new spot, Nights and Weekends, located around the corner on Bedford Avenue. Im sort of spellbound by how the restaurant comes alive and becomes part of the street, says Jud Mongell, one of several owners of the popular watering hole. On any given sunny day, hungry patrons pack the pavement in front of the cafe, which is across the street from McCarren Park.

title: Michel Gondry, Reluctant Cannes Judge
description: CANNES, France  By his own admission, Michel Gondry is not really cut out to be a judge. Im against competition, Mr. Gondry, the French-born director of Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind and The Green Hornet, explained recently. This may present a challenge to his role as the president of the short film jury at the Cannes Film Festival here, where he is tasked with, you know, picking a winner.

title: Living In | Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn
description: Sheepshead Bay, a busy area that is home to various ethnicities, retains a tranquillty, in part because of the water.

title: Calm and Clamor, in Equal Measure
description: ON a sunny day, with a cool breeze blowing off the water and people sitting at sidewalk tables sipping tea from small glasses, Emmons Avenue in Sheepshead Bay, Brooklyn, could almost be in Istanbul  or even in the Ukrainian port city of Odessa. Which may explain why so many Turkish and Ukrainian immigrants have made themselves at home among the swirl of ethnicities in this rambling neighborhood at the citys southern edge.

title: Its Footprint Is Small, but Its Chassis Is Classy
description: A FRIEND recently asked me to recommend an economical, not altogether unattractive small car for his fiance, whose Honda Fit was nearing the end of its lease. I have not met the lucky woman, but as her appointed car-geek counsel, I felt compelled to suggest a 1990 Subaru Loyale  roomy and good on gas, but about as pretty as a rust spot.

title: Bronx Childrens Museum Rolls Out, in Bus Form
description: More than a century after the worlds first childrens museum opened in Brooklyn, the Bronx is finally catching up. Sort of.

title: Syrian Protesters Defy Crackdown and Gain Momentum
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Thousands of Syrians took to the streets in virtually every region of the country on Friday in what appeared to be a sign of new momentum and a potentially dangerous turn in the nine-week uprising. Activists said security forces killed at least 26 people and wounded hundreds.

title: Lloyd Webber Pledges Funds From Picasso Sale to British Arts Groups
description: Apparently not content for musicals like Evita, Phantom of the Opera and Starlight Express to be his only gifts to posterity, Andrew Lloyd Webber has decided to make a more easily quantifiable contribution to British culture: he has said he will donate 32 million  nearly $52 million  to arts organizations in his home country, BBC News reported. The announcement comes at a time when the British government has drastically reduced its financial support of cultural institutions as part of a nationwide austerity program.

title: Reflections on Warnings Unheeded
description: FRANKFURT  Jamie Dimon, chief executive of JPMorgan Chase, famously said at Davos in January that he was tired of everybody always picking on banks. Good thing he wasnt at the going-away event for Gertrude Tumpel-Gugerell, outgoing member of the executive board of the European Central Bank.

title: Our Preakness Picks (Dont Sweat, Weve Got This)
description: The Rails contributors welcome this years Preakness Stakes guest picker, Kevin Plank, the founder and chief executive of Under Armour, the Baltimore-based athletic apparel company.

title: Do Tips on Nearby Bargains Outweigh Privacy Concerns?
description: Ever been in an unfamiliar neighborhood, hungry but without much cash in your pocket? Thats where Cheapism would like to come in. The Web site, which helps you find bargains and inexpensive products, is now offering a location-based version.

title: Harold Bloom's Influence
description: Sam Tanenhaus, the Book Review editor, interviewed Harold Bloom, who has achieved an almost unheard-of celebrity for a literary scholar. Bloom's new book is "The Anatomy of Influence."

title: Words We Dont Say
description: In 1997, when I was first hired at New York magazine, Kurt Andersen, now a best-selling novelist and radio-show host, had just been fired as editor. Everybody was grieving about this, though not me, since I wouldnt have had a job there otherwise. And though it wasnt until years later that I even met Kurt, he unwittingly left me a gift: tacked to the bulletin board in the office I took over was a single page titled Words We Dont Say. It contained, as you might surmise, words and phrases that Kurt found annoying and didnt want used in his magazine. Just yesterday, I rescued it from a bunch of old office stuff that I was throwing out, and I have to say, 14 years later, its still a pretty useful list of phony-baloney vocabulary that editors are well-advised to excise from stories.

title: Summer 2011: Tracking Topics in the News
description: Though the school year is winding down, we want to encourage students to continue to watch whats going on in the world.

title: Borg Roots for Nadal to Join Him as New Rival Arises
description: PARIS  What once seemed a foregone conclusion  that Rafael Nadal would match Bjorn Borg by winning his sixth French Open this year  now looks more like a tennis thriller in the making thanks to the rise and prodigious efforts of Novak Djokovic.

title: Touch of Evil
description: The city isnt what it used to be in A DROP OF THE HARD STUFF (Mulholland/Little, Brown, $25.99), as Matt Scudder, the independent (and unlicensed) gumshoe in Lawrence Blocks timeless New York crime novels, sits down late one night to reminisce with Mick Ballou, the proprietor of Grogans Open House, a bar in Hells Kitchen. Gentrification has gussied up that once raffish neighborhood, and a gentler and more refined bunch of patrons has replaced the colorful and largely criminal riffraff that lent character to the old saloon. But instead of forcing Scudder to make his peace with this new world, Block thoughtfully sends him back to the early 1970s, when he was still a working cop and crime was still the leading occupation in the neighborhood.

title: Who Are These People?
description: Can you identify any of these people?

title: Who Are These People?
description: Can you identify any of these people?

title: Huntsman Criticizes Obama on Libya
description: HANCOCK, N.H.  Jon M. Huntsman Jr., who resigned last month as ambassador to China to explore a campaign for the Republican presidential nomination, said Friday that President Obama should not have intervened in Libya and that future military engagements should be weighed carefully based on their financial toll to the United States.

title: Stone Soul Picnic
description: An island can be paradise or prison, Aruba or Alcatraz or both. Or neither. There are tourist islands and desert islands, islands of treasure or target practice, tropical atolls and frozen specks, islands for Gilligan or Godzilla, Dr. Moreau or Dr. No  even metaphorical islands, which no man can be. Each is a petri dish parenthesized by ocean, fermenting its unique varietal of weirdness.

title: Ahead of Villa dEste, Aston Martin Reveals V-12 Zagato Concept
description: Brutal is not a word that design chiefs commonly trot out to describe their creations, but Marek Reichman, the design director of Aston Martin, applied it on Friday in reference to the V-12 Zagato concept, to be shown on Saturday at the Concorso dEleganza at the Villa dEste in Italy.

title: Coney I. Bids Farewell to the Rabbi of the Beach
description: In Coney Island, he was known as the rabbi.

title: Valuing LinkedIn and Social Networking
description: As the fervor for LinkedIn continues, analysts, investors and reporters are asking: Is there another bubble?

title: Why Liberty Media Might Want Barnes & Noble
description: At first glance, Liberty Media and Barnes & Noble make quite the odd couple.

title: For Mazda Designers, Its Out With the Nagare, in With the Kodo
description: THE look of the Mazda 2, widely praised in the four years it has been sold around the world, offers hints of changes to come in the companys designs. It was the work of Ikuo Maeda, who is Mazdas global head of design; his father, Matasaburo Maeda, was also a designer for the company.

title: Hamilton Surrenders Cycling Gold Medal
description: The American cyclist Tyler Hamilton, the 2004 Olympic gold medalist in the time trial, has voluntarily surrendered his gold medal to the United States Anti-Doping Agency after admitting to doping during his cycling career, the International Olympic Committee said Friday.

title: Weekend Competition: Rules for Life
description: This weekend, co-vocabularists are invited to share their rules for life.

title: In Houston, Retooling, Not Rebuilding
description: It has become a rite of spring (at least since 2007) in Major League Soccer: the union that represents the leagues more than 500 players publishes their salaries on its Web site. (It is a useful look, but it would be even more valuable if the union, instead of listing the players alphabetically or by club in the static PDF format, presented the material in an Excel spreadsheet for easy manipulation. But why quibble?)

title: A Day Spent Foraging for Food, and Ideas
description: During the week, the  Leningrad-born author Gary Shteyngart, 38, whose most recent novel is Super Sad True Love Story, writes and teaches at Columbia. (The title of one class: Writing: The Hysterical Male.) On Sundays in spring, he sets out from the apartment near Gramercy Park that he shares with his fiance and wanders the city, often on his own, feeding mind and body.  JOHN SCHWARTZ

title: Adapting to the Reality of Everyday Video Chatting
description: WHEN I was young, people marveled at the idea of making a phone call and actually seeing the person you were talking to.

title: Hawk Cam | My, How They Grow
description: Pip is 2 weeks old today. Happy birthday, Pip.

title: Every Generation Needs Its Howl
description: The magazine has made a number of noteworthy recent additions: new columns, new sections and new writers. Among the new contributing writers is Alex Pappademas, wholl be reporting regularly for us on popular culture (as well, we hope, on an array of other subjects). To experience firsthand Alexs Rumplestiltskinian ability to spin magical gold from apparent cultural dross  and to see just why were so excited to have him here  read his excellent GQ profile of Mike Sorrentino, a k a the Situation, the star of Jersey Shore.

title: Netanyahu to Confront Obama With Reality, Israelis Say
description: Even as he flew to Washington for talks at the White House on Friday, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu continued to signal his anger with President Obamas statement on Thursday that the borders of Israel and Palestine should be based on the 1967 lines with mutually agreed swaps.

title: 2011 Mazda 2
description: The hatchback makes optimal use of a small footprint while returning good mileage.

title: Courts Weigh Efforts to Guard Valor and Speech
description: At what point does a lie become a crime?

title: Big Deal | Haute Couture Pied--Terre
description: During a telephone interview from Paris, the fashion designer Alber Elbaz seemed to find it a little funny that he was being asked about real estate.

title: Strauss-Kahn Is Released From Jail
description: A week ago, Dominique Strauss-Kahn was a man of international stature and influence. By Friday, he had become something of a pariah, turned away from the Upper East Side luxury building he sought to inhabit and stuck on Rikers Island for much of the day as lawyers tried to agree on an appropriate location for his house arrest.

title: On the Economics of Mass Transit and the Value of Common Sense
description: Lets say theres a public transit line near your house. Your commute from home to work on this line will average about 40 minutes, door to door. Are you going to take it, or not?

title: Animal Kingdoms Final Preparations
description: Animal Kingdom completed his final preparations at Fair Hill Training Center Friday morning, ahead of Saturdays Preakness Stakes. With more rain overnight, the main track was sloppy, so he went out to the Tapeta track to train at his usual time, 9 a.m.

title: Opera Singers at Work
description: For this Sundays article about the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions, the acclaimed photographer Lee Friedlander shot 125 singers in New York, Philadelphia and Lexington, Ky. We were able to publish only a fraction of the remarkable images he made, but we can offer a few more of them online.

title: Weekend Fare
description: People who flock to the Brooklyn Flea for the food now have Smorgasburg to check out on Saturdays from 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. along the East River in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, 27 North Sixth Street (Kent Avenue). A mix of about 100 vendors, from Greenmarket farmers to hawkers of handmade food, will gather weekly. Blue Bottle Coffee, Brooklyn Oyster Party, the Meat Hook and Vietnamese food from Bep and Queens Dahn Tu are among the newest participants.

title: A.F.L.-C.I.O. President Denounces Republicans and Warns Democrats
description: In what was advertised as a major policy address, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., Richard Trumka, denounced Republicans on Friday over their efforts to cut Medicare spending and curb collective bargaining while promising  in a warning to Democrats  that organized labor would show greater independence in politics.

title: Harrison Fails to Qualify for French Open
description: PARIS  Ryan Harrison of the United States, who had spurned a chance to earn a U.S.T.A. wild card to the French Open and chose to seek a berth as a qualifier, lost in straight sets in the final round of competition to the energetic Javier Marti of Spain, 6-2, 7-6 (5).

title: Greg Allman Joins the Aging-Rocker Memoir Brigade
description: Another aging rocker, another tell-all memoir. Gregg Allman, one of the founding members of the Allman Brothers Band, will tell his life story in a book to be published by William Morrow, an imprint of HarperCollins. The deal follows one that was made earlier this week in which HarperCollins acquired the English-language rights to an autobiography by Pete Townshend of the Who.

title: The Wading Game
description: Business or pleasure?

title: Yemeni President Again Calls for Early Vote
description: President Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen called for early presidential elections during a speech on Friday before tens of thousands of supporters in the capital, the state news agency reported, as negotiations to usher him out of office dragged into a second month.

title: I Really Should Read The Onion More Regularly
description: Here:

title: Strauss-Kahn Reporter Becomes Part of the Report
description: I stood there in front of the courthouse doing a stand-up for the television unit of The New York Times when suddenly I found myself becoming the story.

title: Video of Protests and Gunfire in Syria
description: As our colleague Anthony Shadid reports, Syrians took to the streets on Friday in Homs and Hama, both in central Syria, as well as in the towns of Baniyas and Latakia along the Mediterranean coast. Government security forces responded with gunfire, killing at least 17 people, human rights activists said.

title: The Caucus | Shifting Republican Field
description: The Times's Megan Liberman and Jim Rutenberg discuss the Republican field as it takes shape.

title: Explaining the Rapture to Kids
description: Lisa McElroy is worrying about the end of the world. Not because she is one of the parents my colleague Ashley Parker wrote about on the front page of the New York Times this morning  the ones who have stopped funding their childrens college accounts because what will money matter after the Rapture  but because she isnt. And in a guest post today she explores what to tell children who have seen the posters and heard the talk about tomorrow being the beginning of the end of the world.

title: The Week in Pictures for May 20
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a peace summit in Newark and a mural at a high school.

title: Whose Failing Grade Is It?
description: SINCE the subject today is schooling, lets start with a quiz:

title: Is It Possible to Legislate Good Parenting?
description: Motherlode makes its debut in the print version of the Sunday paper this weekend. It is the first of what will be a monthly print column in the Sunday Styles section, a chance to expand on the same kinds of topics I cover online every day. (Its one of the first of a number of coming additions and expansions around here, so stay tuned)

title: Europe Frets Over Trade Deficits With China
description: THE European Commission, angered over what it sees as unfair Chinese trade policies, this week imposed what it said were the first ever antisubsidy tariffs against imports from China.

title: Reaching No. 1 With Sunny Attitude and Steely Resolve
description: BRUSSELS

title: A Roman Holiday, Within Easy Reach of the Interstates
description: FOR fans of Italian cars  those with positive recollections, anyway  the high-profile introduction of the Fiat 500 to the United States this year holds the promise of a long-awaited brand renaissance.

title: Simpler Antidote for Heavy Eyelids
description: WITH summer approaching, some drivers will be pushing their endurance behind the wheel to the limit.

title: Triumph Stag: Some Didnt Like It Hot
description: WHAT WAS IT? 1971-73 Triumph Stag.

title: The Hiroshima Exhibit That Almost Wasnt
description: The Little Boy that devastated Hiroshima in 1945 altered the Earths axis, while also (albeit briefly) changing the way war would be waged. It virtually leveled an entire city  the scope of which is only hinted at in these dramatic photographs  and, followed three days later by a second, smaller detonation on Nagasaki, did what determined American military bombing was unable to do: it forced a Japanese surrender.

title: Barnes & Noble Looking Better as It Ages
description: With the growth of e-book sales, Barnes & Noble may now be more valuable to potential buyers than it was when it put itself on the market in August. In an interview with CNBC, David Strasser, an analyst with Janney Capital Markets, weighs in on Liberty Medias $1 billion offer for the giant bookseller.

title: Boogaard Died From Alcohol and Drug Mix
description: Derek Boogaard of the Rangers died from an accidental overdose of the drug oxycodone mixed with alcohol, the office of the medical examiner in Minnesotas Hennepin County announced Friday.

title: A Director of Ideas With Decades of Them
description: FOR me, films are about ideas, said Norman Jewison, looking out over Central Park on a fine New York day not long ago. Every director should ask himself, Why am I making this picture? And if you cant answer that, you shouldnt make it.

title: Inside Hong Kongs Private Kitchens
description: ON little Star Street, a sliver of a lane in Hong Kongs Wan Chai neighborhood, a group of hungry friends and I walked up and down the same block, iPhone maps in hand, a handful of times before pausing before a quiet apartment building. Is this it? I asked, triple-checking the address before pressing the buzzer.

title: Letters: Hello, Tour Operator
description: To the Editor: Regarding the May 8 Practical Traveler column, How to Save on Group Travel: The article provides some useful information, but omits the single easiest solution: using a tour operator.Someone planning a group tour neednt negotiate with the cruise line, the airline, the hotel or the visitor/convention bureau separately. Tour operators have special group departments that make all the arrangements, saving not only money but time, one of todays most precious commodities. Terry Dale New York City

title: Letters: Passing on Upgrades
description: To the Editor: Regarding the May 15 Practical Traveler column, 13 Ways to Save on Gas This Summer: An other important tip when renting cars: think twice before accepting the upgrade offer they often throw at you while at the counter  bigger, fancier or sportier cars often burn more gas. Many rental companies will now tell you what are the most fuel-efficient models available, and many now have hybrids. If you plan on driving your rental far, this kind of thinking can save a small fortune.

title: The Charms of Via del Mar, Along Chiles Coast
description: DANNY DIAZ stared out into the Pacific, scanning the water, ready to dash at the right moment. We are here to catch a sider, Mr. Diaz, 24, said, referring to what he considers the perfect wave, as he stood on the sandy embankment where the inlet Estero Marga Marga meets the ocean in Via del Mar, Chile. He was with a group of friends, all skimboarders, a sport Mr. Diaz described as a mix between skateboarding and surfing.

title: On Virginias Crooked Road, Mountain Music Lights the Way
description: IT starts with a well-worn fiddle, held in equally well-worn hands above a tapping black cowboy boot. Then in comes the banjo, plucked with steel finger picks, followed by the autoharp, the mandolin, the percussive beat of an upright bass. Another banjo grabs the melody, and suddenly the room is bursting with knee-slapping, country-porch music. A man in a crisp checked shirt gets up and starts to dance, bouncing out a complicated bumbumBAM bumbumBAM with his feet, moving as smoothly as a Martha Graham dancer, hitting the floor on the downbeat.

title: Restaurant Report: Little Otik in Berlin
description: American cuisine in Berlin is something of an anomaly. Food in the German capital is about Turkish kebabs, Greek shawarma, Thai green curry and the ubiquitous German trinity of bockwurst, currywurst and schnitzel.

title: Treading Lightly in the Simanjiro Plains of Tanzania
description: WED been hiking for a half-hour when Mark Thornton raised his hand and drew us to a halt. Tracing a circle in the air with his index finger, he whispered, Theyre all around us.

title: 10 Years Later, a Corner of Cincinnati Sees a Brighter Future
description: A decade after it was devastated by race riots, a historic district is seeing a rush of new, independent businesses.

title: Exploring Via del Mar
description: Up and down the coast from Via del Mar, Chile, youll find surfing hot spots, but the region is about more than just waves.

title: Hong Kongs Private Kitchens
description: They have long been places to get relatively inexpensive, delicious and somewhat homespun Sichuan or Cantonese meals in off-the-beaten path settings.

title: Is the Ryan Budget a Litmus Test for 2012 Republicans?
description: Has the Republican budget crafted by Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin become a litmus test for Republican presidential hopefuls?

title: The Crooked Road
description: The Crooked Road in Virginia is a route that takes visitors to places where old-time mountain music was born and still is strummed.

title: Cannes Fashion: Hurry Sundown
description: THE sole purpose of my in-basket this week seems to be to goad me into looking at fashion from the Cannes Film Festival. Everybody from Armani to those Chopard people has been sending e-mails, and, I swear, I dont know why Jude Law needed to borrow a white gold Chopard watch. Didnt he bring his own? And whos going to see it under the cuff of his tux, anyway?

title: Sentence of the Week: Rapture Edition
description: This is our second straight week of superabundant sentence harvesting  which is good, given that it will apparently be our final Sentence of the Week post ever. (Does Twitter still work when the moon has turned to blood?) So lets all really settle in and savor these together, the last good sentences ever tweeted in the Cycle of Human Time:

title: Now Online | Ts Summer Travel Issue
description: The new Summer Travel issue of T sets sail with the model-sailor-adventurer Daria Werbowy, who skippers a sailboat from St. Barts into the spectacularly blue Caribbean Sea. The watery idylls continue on Favignana, a tiny island off Sicily that has lately been discovered by the fashion crowd; in the Cape Cod town of Wellfleet, where a collection of Bauhaus-style bungalows conjures a lost bohemia; and on the banks of the Thames, in which amateur archaeologists called mudlarkers dig for scraps of history. We peel back layers of the past in Kuala Lumpur, one of Asias most cosmopolitan cities, then get lost in time in Tangier, a last redoubt for romantic dropouts. For beach-blanket readers, theres an excerpt from Elaine Sciolinos timely new book, La Seduction, about the role of flirtation and provocation in French society. And for wave-riders weve assembled a guide to cool new surf spots around the globe. Plus: the Selby heads to Melbourne. See all stories from the issue >>

title: The Morning Line: Handicapping the Preakness
description: After a week of articles on Team Animal Kingdom (the horse; the trainer, Graham Motion; Team Valors chief executive, Barry Irwin; and the horses home at Fair Hill)on Friday attention turned to betting the Preakness.

title: Will the I.M.F. Rise Again?
description: Everyone has some fascination with the combination of sex, money and power, but who would have thought they would all point to a career at the International Monetary Fund? Founded in 1945 at the Bretton Woods Conference with a mandate to prevent wild swings in national currency values, the fund, I would have imagined, would set itself against swinging of every kind. That is clearly not the case.According to Alan Beatties interview this morning with I.M.F. semi-renegade Simon Johnson, the fund was firstly aimed at helping struggling postwar economies in Western Europe, and its first loan (in 1947) was to France. For 35 of the funds 64 years, its managing director was French. When Western Europe had recovered, the fund went on to other things and secured for itself, lets say, a mixed reputation. From the 1960s onward, and culminating in the period of strict I.M.F. loan conditionality and rigid programs of structural adjustment, the fund earned a reputation as a corps of technocratic drones pitilessly contented in their air-conditioned hotel rooms as they imposed cookie-cutter solutions on prostrate governments. You would read from time to time of anti-I.M.F. riots in one poor capital or another, and you could guess what it meant, and it wasnt pretty.By the early part of our own century, the fund was entering a period of repentance, not least because some poorer countries were now emerging markets and making a big point of repaying I.M.F. loans and swearing never to take them again. Escaping the I.M.F. became a symbol of freedom. But if the fund wasnt making loans it had no income, and we know what that means: time for reform! Emerging-market players, with a sympathetic United States, pushed for changes in voting power. In essence, the developing world would get more I.M.F. power at the expense (slightly) of the United States and (mainly) of Europe. Several reforms, first undertaken in 2006 and most recently last year, would take the voting share of advanced economies from 60.6 to 55.3, and of emerging market and developing countries from 39.4 to 44.7.

title: Divisions Are Clear as Obama and Netanyahu Discuss Peace
description: WASHINGTON  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel told President Obama on Friday that he shared his vision for a peace between Israelis and Palestinians, and then promptly listed a series of nonnegotiable conditions that have kept the two sides at an impasse for years.

title: Newspaper in Pakistan Publishes WikiLeaks Cables
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  The leading English-language newspaper, Dawn, and its Web site on Friday began publishing a selection of more than 4,000 American diplomatic cables obtained from WikiLeaks that are devoted to Pakistan, opening a window onto the American-Pakistani relationship and domestic politics never before seen here.

title: May 21-22: Top European Matchups
description: The top matchups in European soccer this weekend:

title: The Films of Norman Jewison
description: A look at some of the films being featured in the Film Society of Lincoln Centers retrospective of the director.

title: Grandfather Is Convicted of 2008 Murder of Child in Israel
description: JERUSALEM  The case of a grisly 2008 killing of a 4-year-old girl ended this week with an Israeli court finding the girls paternal grandfather guilty of her murder. The court also convicted the girls mother of soliciting the killing.

title: Chaos of Internet Will Meet French Sense of Order
description: PARIS  The Tuileries Garden in Paris, a celebration of grand geometric vistas and tightly trimmed topiary, will be invaded next week by the denizens of a decidedly more chaotic space: the Internet.

title: Im Not Real, but Neither Are You
description: THERES a scene in the 1988 blaxploitation parody Im Gonna Git You Sucka where, as the hero enters the boudoir of a woman hes just met, he confesses hes not as well endowed as he may have indicated at the bar.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $16.6 Million
description: After almost three years on the market, a sprawling penthouse at One Jackson Square in the West Village with a private swimming pool on its roof terrace sold on Monday for $16.6 million, according to the Corcoran Sunshine Marketing Group, which represented the owners. The penthouse sale was the priciest of the week, according to transactions posted on Streeteasy.com.

title: Eat Her Words
description: Some people put photographs of lithe supermodels on their fridges to help avert caloric mishaps. Now you can reproach yourself in any room of the house, with words from one of the slimmest supes of all. Stitched with Kate Mosss infamous quote, Jonathan Adlers needlepoint pillow is $119 at Kirna Zabte, 96 Greene Street (Spring Street). Or go to kirnazabete.com.

title: Inside the List
description: CITY LIGHTS: Erik Larsons In the Garden of Beasts hits the hardcover nonfiction list at No. 4, without any help from Navy Seals or Steven Tylers hairdresser. Instead, its got Nazis, romance and old-fashioned storytelling chops, not to mention a cover that makes Berlin in 1933 look an awful lot like the Chicago of the 1893 Worlds Fair depicted on the front of Larsons blockbuster The Devil in the White City, which spent a total of 182 weeks on the hardcover and paperback lists starting back in 2003. Like that book, In the Garden of Beasts is shaped around the interlocking stories of two characters, the American ambassador William Dodd, who views Hitlers Berlin with growing alarm, and his daughter, Martha, who finds herself rather enchanted by all the glamorous men in uniform. (Think Carrie Bradshaw in Berlin, as USA Todays reviewer, Deirdre Donahue, put it.) In an interview with The Huffington Post Chicago, Larson, inset, explained his decision to give so much space to Martha, a former assistant literary editor at The Chicago Tribune who left her husband behind to gallivant with French diplomats, Russian agents and the head of the Gestapo: If Id hung the entire book on Dodd, it might have been interesting, but it would have lapsed into a diplomatic history. I find diplomatic histories the dullest of histories.

title: Talking, and Listening, in the Oval Office
description: When President Obama met with Benjamin Netanyahu, the prime minister of Israel, in the Oval Office on Friday, this photo caught our eye. The two men have had a sometimes rocky relationship, (see todays story by Helene Cooper) but they exchanged cordial words on Friday. This picture was snapped as Mr. Obama listened, almost frozen, during long remarks by Mr. Netanyahu, in which the Israeli leader pushed back against the framework for a peace deal that Mr. Obama outlined in a speech Thursday at the State Department. It made us wonder: What is Mr. Obama thinking?

title: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from the West Bank, Japan, Spain and Bulgaria.

title: Not Without His Jewelry
description: Nur Khan, 44, was a trader on Wall Street for six years before joining the night life industry. The man behind Wax, Sway, Rose Bar and the recently closed Don Hills, hes now often found at Kenmare, his first restaurant venture.  BEE-SHYUAN CHANG

title: Where Have the Big Men Gone in the Playoffs?
description: Ever since the N.B.A.s new hand-check rules went into effect before the 2004-5 season, faster players who can penetrate have become more and more valuable. Meanwhile, big men who rely on post scoring to be effective have become scarcer and scarcer.

title: Three Men to Watch in the French Open
description: Richard Gasquet

title: Three Women to Watch in the French Open
description: Bethanie Mattek-Sands

title: Book Review Podcast: Harold Bloom and Albert Brooks
description: This week, a conversation with Harold Bloom about his life and work; the comedian Albert Brooks discusses his first novel, 2030: The Real Story of What Happens to America; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: Renault and Porsche Dominate Alternative-Powertrain Rally in Berlin
description: The Renault Fluence Z.E. electric car was among the victors in the Michelin Challenge Bibendum, a 186-mile, sustainable mobility-themed rally held in and around Berlin this week.

title: Reviewing the Mazda 2
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, Jonathan Schultz drives the Mazda 2, a spry subcompact that has been available outside of the United States since 2007, but that only arrived at American dealerships late last year.

title: For Richer, for Poorer, in Floodwaters or on Dry Land
description: VICKSBURG, Miss.

title: Explosion at Foxconn Factory That Makes iPads
description: 4:38 p.m. | Updated Adding response from Apple.

title: Ren & Charles
description: In this homemade video, Ren Lumley-Hall says that after finding a teddy bear and flowers in her travel bag, she realized that her relationship with Charles Patrick wasn't going to be short term.
