description: Theater

title: Pictures of the Day: West Bank and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from the West Bank, Japan, Spain and Bulgaria.

title: For James Levine, the Twilight of a Conductor
description: DESPITE the frustration he has endured from lingering back problems, James Levine should be feeling some contentment right now.

title: Singers Embrace the TV Road to Stardom
description: BETWEEN 2003 and 2006 Javier released two albums and a live EP on Capitol Records, a fair shot by any music industry standard. He was an amiable and warm singer, precise and flexible, with a crisp pop voice and smooth R&B inflections. And yet that voice, perhaps too clean and pretty, made for unremarkable records that left little impact. Soon after his second album Javier and Capitol parted ways, another quiet casualty of the record business.

title: Vampires, Bachata, Norteo and a Country Coalition-Builder
description: Los Tigres del Norte

title: Private Offerings Come With Many Caveats
description: Paul Sullivans Wealth Matters column this week makes the point that some investors are not any more aware of the risks involved in private equity and debt offerings than they were nearly three years ago, in the depths of the recession. The biggest risk is that they will lose all their money. That is probably not as big a deal for the wealthy as it is for those who aspire to be rich.

title: Timely | Jules Marquis  Art in America
description: Whether by filming an ode to NBC in a field or by having small-town Little Leaguers pace around a New York gallery and mutter good game to one another, Colin Snapp (left) and Daniel Turner frequently take aspects of globalized culture and consumerism and trickle them down to a rural level. The two New York-based artists, who recently began exhibiting collaborative work under the name Jules Marquis, share a Greenpoint studio but regularly shuttle to southeast Virginia, where theyve created a nonprofit art space on a corner of the Turner family farm. Named Jericho Ditch, after a local logging canal, it serves as a venue and creative getaway for fellow artists. It also embodies the Jules Marquis ethos: from the outside, its a shed in a field; inside, its a big-city-gallery-style white box lighted by symmetrical fluorescent tubes. Snapp and Turner have two shows opening in June: at Jericho Ditch and at Martos Gallery in New York.

title: TimesCast | May 20, 2011
description: Obama and Netanyahu meet at the White House; Palestinians in the West Bank remain skeptical of progress toward peace; and a preview of TV's fall lineup.

title: Mayor Is Criticized for Comments on Parents at Poor Schools
description: Responding to a lawsuit filed on Wednesday seeking to prevent the city from closing 22 poor-performing schools, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg made a comment that has sparked outrage among some community leaders.

title: Ren Lumley-Hall and Charles Patrick
description: Ren N. Lumley-Hall and Charles Patrick III were married Saturday evening at the Princeton PrincetonClub in New York. Pastor Charles Patrick II, the bridegrooms father and an associate pastor at Greater Heights Mission Bible Church in Los Angeles, officiated.

title: Graphic Book Best Sellers: Star-Crossed Romance
description: The first volume of Ai Ore-Love Me! hits the manga list at No. 10 this week. The book is about what happens when Mizuki, the lead guitarist at an all-girl school, is approached by Akira, a student at an all-boys school, who wants to join her band. Seems like a reasonable enough premise, but things get more confusing, according to the description on the web site of VIZ Media, which publishes the book: Love may be on his mind, but romance is difficult when everyone keeps mistaking Mizuki for a boy and Akira for a girl!

title: Can Scientists Arouse and Fulfill?
description: Heres a Dot Earth Postcard from Randy Olson, the marine biologist turned filmmaker and science-communication evangelist, who recently attended a conference on neglected diseases, complex systems, learning and more organized by Larry Gold, a biotechnology entrepreneur and microbiologist at the University of Colorado:

title: Goldikova, Racings Grande Dame, Returns on Sunday
description: She was around when Curlin won the Preakness in 2007. She saw Big Brown come and go in 2008, too. She had already staked her turf in the history books when Rachel Alexandra won her Preakness in 2009, and she saw Lookin at Luckys short burst of fame last year, too. All those champions flowered and faded in the blink of an eye next to her glittering career, which is still far from over. Goldikova, the grande dame of worldwide thoroughbred racing, is set to make her seasonal reappearance on Sunday in the Group 1 Prix dIspahan at Longchamp.

title: The Women Who Would Be President. Will They Run?
description: The women who would be president in 2012 are still sitting on the sidelines. But that could change soon.

Angell and Dr. Charles S. Angell of Baltimore. The Rev. Patrick Wenrick, a minister affiliated with CITI Ministries, officiated at the Plantation Golf and Country Club in Fort Myers, Fla.

description: Ehi Ivie Ifeyinwa Oviasu, the daughter of Thelma N. Oviasu and Dr. Felix I. Oviasu of Old Westbury, N.Y., is to be married Sunday evening to Daniel Aaron Kahn, the son of Joyce Kahn of Montpelier, Vt., and David Kahn of Calais, Vt. Rabbi Samuel Weintraub is to officiate at the Gould-Guggenheim Estate in Sands Point, N.Y.

title: Lisa Hankin, Kevin McNeil
description: Lisa Jill Hankin and Kevin Phillip McNeil were married Saturday evening at Temple Beth Torah in Melville, N.Y. Rabbi Susie Heneson Moskowitz performed the ceremony.

title: Elaine McQuillan and Hugh Barry
description: Elaine Marie McQuillan and Hugh John Barry were married Friday at the Columbus Citizens Foundation, a private club, in Manhattan. Justice Edward J. McLaughlin of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: Los Angeles, City of Artists
description: Theres no such thing as L.A., says the curator Benjamin Godsill. Theres multiple, sometimes overlapping bits of community, ideologies and neighborhoods. Organizing a group show around the theme of a major metropolis poses risks. Hyperbole, dime store anthropology and overlooked artists often crowd the presentation. But the best of these endeavors dont seek to galvanize a scene, per se, but provide the most basic of contexts: place. In this way, the mercurial nature of Los Angeles provides a valid starting point for an investigation of its artists. This summer, two separate curatorial teams (both based in New York, funnily enough) will tackle the behemoth subject of art in Los Angeles with group shows staged far from home. Greater LA, on view until June 10 in SoHo, looks at the citys contemporary artists, whereas Venice in Venice, which opens on June 4 at the Venice Biennial, revisits the citys rebel artists from the 1960s and 70s.

title: Remembering the Tunes That Broke Boundaries
description: Songs by African-American jazz musicians that became standards; racially conscious protest songs written by Tin Pan Alley titans and made famous by black performers: the back-and-forth crossover process that accelerated with the birth of rock n roll was the theme of More Than a Song: The Music That Integrated America, a sturdy, thoughtful revue that had performances at the Allen Room on Tuesday and Wednesday evenings.

title: Silk Production Takes a Walk on the Wild Side
description: Most commercial silk today comes from the cocoons of domesticated silkworms, bred over thousands of years to produce cocoons that are easy to unravel into silk that is easy to dye. The use of silkworms is thought to have originated in China nearly 6,000 years ago. There are many species of wild silkworms as well, but their cocoons are more difficult to unravel.

title: Aggressive Bid Leads to a Slam
description: The advance of the young guard. That would be a fair headline for the final of the open trial in Henderson, Nev., this week. The average age of the winning team of Kevin Bathurst, Daniel Zagorin, Joe Grue, Justin Lall, John Hurd and Joel Wooldridge was 31, the youngest being Lall, at 24.

title: Comedy With a Side of Disgust
description: THE few times I have seen the talk show Chelsea Lately, a premonition of a world flattened by small talk and Kim Kardashians rear, my sense of its outspoken and attractive host, Chelsea Handler, has been that she is not so much giving quarter to her guests as holding them at bay with her intelligence.

title: Sleep No More Is a Feast for Style Fanatics
description: Talk about cravings. At one point in the eerily staged production of Sleep No More at a mock hotel in Chelsea, a showily pregnant Lady Macduff hikes up her blue velvet evening dress, hops on to a bar and laps milk from a saucer. At another moment in this crazily meandering interpretation of Macbeth by Punchdrunk, the British experimental theater company, her dress is laid out on a bed, leaving masked spectators free to pore over its capacious folds and seams.

title: Brnnhilde Meets Broadway at Benefit for Collegiate Chorale
description: No question: the musical forces on the stage of Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening were mighty. Take the 180-voice Collegiate Chorale, add a real-life Brnnhilde in the person of the great dramatic soprano Deborah Voigt, and you should expect nothing less than thunder and lightning. But it was not to be. A distant rumble, a flicker on the horizon, a spritz of rain, yes. But except for a rip-roaring Oklahoma! when everything suddenly converged, there was only a hint of a storm.

title: Saying Farewell to School, With Some Help From Brahms
description: The music surrounding graduation festivities at most colleges begins and ends with a weak version of Elgars famous Pomp and Circumstance March. At the Juilliard School, as you might imagine, things are a bit different.

title: More Employers Equalize Health Benefits for Gay Workers
description: This weeks Your Money column looks at the growing number of companies that have decided to equalize the cost of health benefits for their gay employees.

title: For Gay Employees, an Equalizer
description: The battle to legalize same-sex marriage may be dominating the headlines, but that issue could take years to resolve. More immediately, a growing number of companies have taken it upon themselves to make life a little more equal for their gay employees.

title: Israel Cannot Go Back to the 1967 Lines, Netanyahu Tells Obama
description: As my colleague Steven Lee Myers reports from Washington, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel told President Obama on Friday that he shared his vision for a peace between Israelis and Palestinians and then promptly listed a series of nonnegotiable conditions that have kept the two sides at an impasse for years.

title: Look of the Moment | Zoe Saldana
description: The Look: Miracle Grow  with a nod to the natural this floor-length bat-sleeve number blooms with flowers and a striped, color-blocked belt.

title: An Investment Asks, How Much Can You Afford to Lose?
description: INVESTOR interest in private equity and debt offerings continues to increase a mere three years after these illiquid investments caused a lot of anxiety, if not substantial financial losses. The problem is there is little sign that investors are any more aware now of the risks involved in these deals than they were then.

title: Recycled Films and Bitsy Screens
description: A. O. Scott and Manohla Dargis, the co-chief film critics of The New York Times, answer your questions in a monthly column that appears in print and online. This month readers asked about remakes (pro and con), big-screen films on small-screen devices, and more. You can write Ms. Dargis and Mr. Scott at askthefilmcritics@nytimes.com.

title: Ruth Gruber, From Exodus to Ethiopia
description: Ruth Gruber is a pioneering correspondent and humanitarian who recorded the expansion of the Soviet gulag system and the unending trials of Jewish refugees from Nazi Germany. Her own life is chronicled in the 2007 memoir, Witness: One of the Great Correspondents of the 20th Century Tells Her Story (Random House, 2007).

title: The Week in Pictures for May 20
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include the case of a psychic who is accused of having persuaded a client to hand over thousands of dollars to cure herself of an unhealthy attachment to money, the Newark Peace Education Summit, a Brooklyn fire that killed two people and former Gov. James E. McGreevey of New Jersey, who hopes to be accepted as a candidate for the priesthood in the Episcopal Church.

title: Obama Applauds C.I.A. for Bin Laden Raid
description: Praising them for what he called one of the greatest intelligence successes in American history, President Obama told a jubilant crowd at the Central Intelligence Agency on Friday that the tracking and killing of Osama bin Laden was a crucial milestone in the larger American war to defeat al Qaeda.

title: Palestinian Sees Prospects of Deal Receding
description: JERUSALEM  After President Obamas high-profile speech on Thursday in which he laid out broad principles for reaching an Israeli-Palestinian deal, the Palestinian president, Mahmoud Abbas, called an emergency meeting at his headquarters in Ramallah in the West Bank. He advised his associates not to comment on the speech, according to a senior Palestinian official who attended the meeting, but to wait instead for Mr. Obamas meeting with the prime minister of Israel in the White House and see if there are any positive signs.

title: Nameless forest
description: Photos of the new piece by the choreographer Dean Moss.

title: The Upside of Rhubarb
description: TO cook the rhubarb or not to cook the rhubarb: that was the question I had when contemplating an upside-down cake.

title: The Fracking Debate, to a Funk Beat
description: If you prefer your environmental journalism rapped to a funk beat, then you cant miss with My Waters on Fire Tonight, a music video out of Studio 20, the media innovation lab at New York Universitys graduate school of journalism.

title: City Dwellers With Time to Kill
description: LITTLE about Alex DerHohannesian suggests video game champion. A virile 30-year-old television producer, he lives on the Upper West Side, starred on the club hockey team at the University of Kentucky and bears a strong resemblance to Ryan Gosling.

title: No Disrespect
description: Did you hear?

title: Nimrods in Manhattan
description: Big Buck Hunter brings bar patrons together for beer and hunting.

title: New York at the Touch of a Finger
description: Its easy to spot the tourists in New York; theyre the ones with the fanny packs and the guide books.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 20
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: Chic in Review | Riccardo Tiscis New Look?
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: Start Your High-Def Engines
description: Grand Prix

title: The Week In Culture Pictures, May 20
description: More Photographs

title: The Age of Purification
description: SULTALO!

title: Madison Square Park, 12:08 P.M.
This Weeks Magazine: A Picture Show
description: Though there is great stuff to read this week (I promise!), I am going to focus on photography. Just last week, we won a National Magazine Award for a photo essay by Ashley Gilbertson on the bedrooms of dead U.S. soldiers. But as rewarding as the big events like that are, its the week-to-week excellence of our photo director, Kathy Ryan, and her staff that impresses me even more. They dont pursue a particular style or idea about pictures. Their interests are gloriously catholic. They pull stuff out of archives. They come up with stunning ideas that enliven subjects that have been photographed a million times before. They scour the earth for new talent. And they are always receptive to ideas that photographers bring to them, a more important skill than you might think.

title: Idol, Down to Two, Makes Fox No. 1
description: Haley Reinhart, above, received the fewest votes on Thursday nights elimination episode of American Idol, as 21.2 million viewers tuned in to the Fox reality show, according to Nielsens estimates. Lauren Alaina and Scotty McCreery advanced to next weeks final round. Fox led the night as the top-rated network, garnering 10 million viewers at 9 for Bones, the crime dramas highest ratings for a season finale in three years. But CBSs Mentalist led the time slot with the first half of its two-hour finale, which averaged 13.8 million viewers from 9 to 11. CBS was second, drawing 11.1 million at 8 for The Big Bang Theory and 8.8 million at 8:30 for Rules of Engagement. ABC finished third with finales of Wipeout (5.6 million), Greys Anatomy (9.6 million) and Private Practice (7.5 million). NBC was fourth, averaging 7.1 million viewers for its hourlong season finale of The Office at 9 but had lower ratings for Parks and Recreation at 10 (4.2 million) and 10:30 (3.7 million).

title: Footnote
description: The PEN American Center will administer the PEN/Bellwether Prize for Socially Engaged Fiction, an award that was originally founded by Barbara Kingsolver in 2000 as the Bellwether Prize, the organization said on Friday. Beginning in 2012 it will award the prize to the author of a new novel that exemplifies the prizes founding principles. Algonquin Books has agreed to give a publishing contract to at least the next two winners. Going forward, the prize will be awarded every other year.

title: This Weeks Business News in Pictures
description: Scandal at the International Monetary Fund, the fiscal crisis in Greece, rising gas prices and continuing problems at the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear complex in Japan.

title: Where an Audience Becomes the Star
description: Perhaps nothing is more controversial in experimental dance today than performance style. Most of Nameless forest, a new piece by the choreographer Dean Moss that opened at the Kitchen on Thursday night, was unimpeachable. Trying to create a world of human behavior in a three-dimensional set, it involved a number of theater games for its six dancers and for 12 members of the audience, who, invited to sit onstage, at times became involved in both the choreography and some interviews. But it was tediously performed. At Thursday nights show some of the participating innocent bystanders proved more stageworthy than any of the performers.

title: Toronto Exchange Rejects Rival Bid by Canadian Banks
description: The TMX Group, the parent company of the Toronto Stock Exchange, said late on Friday that it had rejected a unsolicited takeover bid from a consortium of Canadian banks and pension funds, saying the offer was inadequate and not superior to its merger agreement with the London Stock Exchange.

title: Experiencing Art With Eyes Peeled, Ears Trained and Hands On
description: The wonderfully eclectic Look & Listen Festival opened on Thursday evening with a program that prized vigor and muscularity over intricacy and nuance: a victory lap, of sorts, in celebration of the festivals 10th anniversary. The point of Look & Listen, as its title suggests, is to bring together music and visual arts, and this year the concerts are in the large, resonant gallery of the Chelsea Art Museum, where an exhibition of colorful abstracts by the painter Jean Miotte surrounds the musicians and audience.

title: New Territory, With Hues of Nature
description: The Trinity Choir, the superb resident ensemble of Trinity Church in Lower Manhattan, is rightly renowned for its polished, spirited renditions of major works from the classical choral repertory. Its activities in contemporary music, though distinguished, have been emphasized less. That changed on Thursday night, when Julian Wachner, Trinitys director of music and the arts, conducted the first formal concert by Novus NY, the churchs newly formed new-music ensemble.

title: Obama Thanks the C.I.A. for Hunting Down Bin Laden
description: WASHINGTON -- Praising them for what he called one of the greatest intelligence successes in American history, President Obama told a jubilant crowd at the Central Intelligence Agency on Friday that the tracking and killing of Osama bin Laden was a crucial milestone in the larger American war to defeat al Qaeda.

title: Young, Aimless and Primed for a Revolution
description: The bubble-headed terrorists of Zack Russells satiric comedy Just Cause at the Flea Theater have no cause, just or otherwise, and no ideology. Thats Mr. Russells point. About the only thing they respond to is a slogan as lazy as they are: Freedom comes to those who love it.

title: 2 Networks Pin Their Hopes on One Comedian
description: On Monday NBC unveiled its hottest prospect for a new hit sitcom, a show called Whitney, created, produced by and starring Whitney Cummings.

title: Derailed Director Cites Urge to Entertain
description: MOUGINS, France  The Danish filmmaker Lars von Trier showed up at this years Cannes Film Festival with Melancholia, a disaster movie about a planet crashing into Earth. He leaves having blazed his own destructive trail through the event, which since Wednesday has been dominated by talk of his rambling comments about Nazism at a news conference and his subsequent expulsion from the festival.

title: Temptations Found in Gardens of Islamic Delight
description: The smell I remember. It was sensuous and sweet in the early summer morning but also airy, light, with an almost spicy edge. And it shifted character as I walked past the murmuring fountains and groomed myrtle bushes. But I didnt pay much attention. Eight years ago there were other impressions to attend to, made by the honeycombed ceilings and ornamented stucco, the interweaving geometries on tiles and stone, the views of tall cypresses and corrugated rooftops. The place, in uniting opposites, seemed to insist on a mythical significance as fortress and pleasure garden, a seat of power and a meditative retreat: the Alhambra.

title: U.S. Finish at Worlds Does Not Reflect Overall Program
description: Although the N.H.L. playoffs are continuing at breakneck speed, the international hockey season officially ended last week with the gold medal game of the 75th world championship.

title: Once Again: Is College Worth It?
description: The dismal job prospects for new college graduates have revived debates about whether college is worth it. The PayPal founder Peter Thiel is among the major skeptics, but there are plenty of others. Check out the comments on yesterdays article about employment rates for recent grads to see what I mean.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,567 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American this week:

title: A Restoration on the Hudson
description: Bannermans Island Arsenal, a Scottish castle on the Hudson River, has been deteriorating for decades. But stabilization work has started on a nearby summer residence.

title: Spanish Paradise
description: A look at the Gardens of the Alhambra exhibition at the New York Botanical Garden.

title: App Smart Extra: A Weather App That Works
description: In a February column on weather apps, I complained about the substandard quality of most in the category.

title: President Obamas Letter About Efforts in Libya
description: Following is a letter President Obama sent to the Senate and House leaders John A. Boehner, Nancy Pelosi, Harry Reid, and Mitch McConnell to update them on the United States military actions.

title: Enter Laughing, From the Liberal Wing
description: Perhaps you, like City Critic, thought that liberals had been eradicated through some kind of spraying program or mass inoculation. No elected official has admitted to being one since the Carter administration, and the very word liberal ranks right up there with care to respond to the rumors about your love child? as guaranteed to make Sunday morning talk-show guests change the subject.

title: Video of the Nakba Day Protest in Lebanon
description: On Friday, a senior official who traveled to Washington with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel told Yediot Aharonot, an Israeli newspaper, that it was important for the White House to understand the seriousness of last Sundays protests along Israels frontiers with Lebanon and Syria. People are waging war along the fences, the official said, and its not an exaggeration.

title: A Bad Year for Car Bargains
description: DETROIT  The average price for a new car in the United States is edging toward $30,000, as automakers remain stingy with discounts and there just are not enough of the most popular vehicles available.

title: The Battle for Libya | May 20, 2011
description: NATO warplanes attacked eight Libyan ships on Thursday night in three coastal locations, including the port of Tripoli.

title: Through Rowing, New Confidence
description: IM bored, announced Shlomo Orenstein, 14, a seventh grader from Brooklyn, as he lay on a floating dock on the Harlem River on Thursday, picking splinters out of the wooden planks with his idle hands.

title: Health in Doubt, Mugabe, 87, Vows to Stay in Power
description: JOHANNESBURG  Some of his fellow autocrats may be struggling  with Hosni Mubarak detained in Egypt and Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi hiding from NATO air bombardments in Libya  but Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, another of Africas longest-serving leaders, declared in an interview published Friday that he intended to run for president this year at the age of 87, and live to be 100.

title: Answers to Questions About New York
New York City Opera to Leave Lincoln Center
description: Just two years after a $107 million renovation at its Lincoln Center home, the troubled New York City Opera plans to move out and perform in various places around New York, officials of the company said on Friday.

title: J.F.K. High School Makes an Unlikely Tennis Powerhouse
description: A few years back, few people would have pegged John F. Kennedy High School in the Bronx as a tennis school.

title: I.M.F. Seeks New Chief by June 30
description: The executive board of the International Monetary Fund said Friday it intends to select a new managing director by the end of June.

title: Sexual Affronts Are a Known Hotel Hazard
description: A lot of people were shocked by the charges that the head of the International Monetary Fund sexually assaulted a hotel housekeeper in New York last weekend.

title: The Defense Cant Afford to Rest
description: WHEN clients call Ivan Vogels cellphone, they are treated to an unintentional, 13-second economic truth. This, the recorded message says, is the law office of Ivan A. Vogel. Leave your name and number. Ill get back to you as soon as I can.

title: At an Adult Swim Party, the Sharks Are Corporate
description: As if the two 12-foot-tall, fog-shrouded golden owls that stood sentry over the crowd at a party for the Adult Swim cable television channel on Wednesday night werent imposing enough, they also shot lasers out of their eyes.

title: A Case That Put a System on Trial
description: THE epigraph of a new book about the Central Park jogger case in 1989 establishes its premise: I think that everybody here  and maybe across the nation  will look at this case to see how the criminal justice system works, Mayor Edward I. Koch said at the time. This is, I think, putting the criminal justice system on trial.

title: At Apocalypse Central, Preparing for What Happens, or Doesnt
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  If Harold Camping and his followers are correct, Gertrude Steins famous comment about Oakland  that there is no there there  may finally be true. If not, some local churchgoers say they will set up encampments outside the headquarters of Mr. Camping, the self-proclaimed biblical soothsayer who has prophesied the end of the world on Saturday, with an eye toward consoling the disappointed.

title: Obamas Speech on the Middle East
description: To the Editor:

title: Beckham-a-Go-Go
description: Somewhere in Los Angeles, in a corner of his house perhaps near where he stows his golf clubs, Galaxy Coach Bruce Arena must be sticking pins in his David Beckham doll and hoping for a quick end to the Beckham experiment, which has turned into a frantic dance as Becks juggles his social calendar among his myriad interests, and the Galaxy, too.

title: Small, Poor, Successful School Waits for Obama, in Vain
description: BRIDGEPORT, Wash.  President Obama stood near the Mexican border last week and challenged Republicans to join him in reforming federal immigration policy. Among the people he said were unfairly at risk under current laws: bright, eager students.

title: Opposing Views of Courts Ruling on Class Actions
description: To the Editor:

title: Mid-Atlantic Dreads Bad Summer of Foul, Hungry Stink Bugs
description: The voice on the answering machine at SBS Pest Control in Pittsburgh offers an unusual valediction.

title: TimesCast | Distrustful Allies
description: May 20, 2011- President Obama meets with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel.

title: An Italian Newcomer That Sticks to the Script
description: I HAVE never seen a wait staff burn more calories than I did on a recent night at Massa, a vigorous new Italian restaurant in Scarsdale (Massa is short for masseria, a fortified southern Italian farmhouse). Seated at the base of a broad staircase leading from the main dining room up to a spacious bar and ancillary dining area, where a private party for 30 was in full swing, my guests and I had the equivalent of front-row seats as we watched waiters dash from the kitchen and sprint up the stairs, then trot back down again, taking two steps at a time.

title: Not Sausage, but Soysage
description: Many restaurants offer vegetarian dishes these days, but diners who want to avoid any kind of animal products, including fish and dairy, will find the pickings slim  unless they visit Jolos Kitchen in New Rochelle.

title: Insider Information Could Hurt Armstrong
description: For the second year in a row, to the day, the buzz at the Tour of California on Friday was about something other than the race. All the talk was again about Lance Armstrong and the former teammates who have publicly accused him of doping to win the Tour de France.

title: Report Finds Data Lacking on Exposure to Defoliant
description: An independent panel of experts has concluded that there is not enough data available to determine whether sailors who served on deep-water ships during the Vietnam War were exposed to Agent Orange, the defoliant that has been linked to cancer and other serious diseases.

title: End-of-the-World Refund?
description: To the Editor:

title: Slender Lies the Crust
description: Real pizza, real thin is how Joseph Vetrano, 40, of Roslyn Heights, describes what he sells at SkinnyPizza, which opened there in March.

title: Evoking Old Madrid, Down to the Dcor
description: ESPAA is the real thing, as authentic a tapas bar and Spanish restaurant as one will find on Long Island. Diners at this two-month-old St. James spot may feel as if they are in Madrid; indeed, the dapper host, Julio Caro, is from there.

title: Use of Military Force: Ways of Interpreting a Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Jack Wolf, Who Did the Math Behind Computers, Dies at 76
description: Jack Keil Wolf, an engineer and computer theorist whose mathematical reasoning about how best to transmit and store information helped shape the digital innards of computers and other devices that power modern society, died on May 12 at his home in the La Jolla section of San Diego. He was 76.

title: Corned Beef and Cannoli
description: When Rosario Minnocci opened Avventura in 1990, it was an all-purpose neighborhood grocery, much like any across the state. A decade later, the store is a first-rate delicatessen and pastry shop  a result of Mr. Minnoccis decision to concentrate on house-made foods and pastries.

title: Fatal Blast and Fire Halt Work at Chinese Plant That Makes iPads
description: An explosion and fire at a plant that makes Apple and Dell products in China killed two people and injured 16 and brought production to a halt, a spokesman for the plant said.

title: At a New Steakhouse, Big Portions and Tabs
description: LODGED in a handsome, free-standing building just off U.S. 1., Gabrieles Italian Steakhouse is a world unto itself, with a dark, circular dining room, several alcoves well suited to foursomes, a lively bar and a large, genial staff.

title: A Response From a Former Nuclear Regulator
description: To the Editor:

title: On the Street | Nightcaps
description: As the marathon Mad May benefit party season draws to a close, it is both startling and delightful to see whimsical headdresses and hats worn with long evening dresses.

title: A Certifiably Green Cafe
description: As its name suggests, Fresh, a sprightly little place in the Hills strip mall in Basking Ridge, uses local and organic ingredients whenever possible. Its owners serve made-from-scratch soups and salads, sandwiches like roasted pork on a brioche bun ($8.95) and blue-plate specials, including barbecued ribs and steak frites, that change daily.

title: Japanese Flavors, Traditional and Modern
Disparate Musicians With a Shared Sensibility
description: THE trumpeter Marvin Stamm and the saxophonist Jason Rigby might seem unlikely band mates. While both are members of the Westchester Jazz Orchestra, they are of different generations (Mr. Stamm is 71, Mr. Rigby, 36) and arguably of contrasting musical temperament, with Mr. Rigbys small-group projects offering a decidedly freer brand of jazz than Mr. Stamms.

title: Im Just Another Guy Who Thinks Hes Smarter Than He Is
description: AFTER Colin Quinn Long Story Short, the comedians 75-minute solo show, had run on Broadway for two months, an extension was announced, and shortly thereafter, another extension.

title: The Menacing Passion of West Side Story
description: The mean streets of 1950s New York dont really look that frightening in the opening scene of West Side Story at the Gateway Playhouse.

title: Years After Two of Fire Dept.s Saddest Days, a Third
description: TAPPAN, N.Y.  In August 2007, two firefighters died of smoke inhalation battling a fire at the former Deutsche Bank building at the World Trade Center site.

title: Illegal Immigrants Children Suffer, Study Finds
description: Eulogia was scared and adrift. At 25, she was poor, pregnant and an illegal immigrant. She worried about how she would pay for medical care and raise her baby, and even whether a trip to the hospital might prompt her deportation to Mexico.

title: Show for Black Artists (Even Those Disliking Label)
description: Some of the knottiest issues in Embodied: Black Identities in American Art From the Yale University Art Gallery dont reveal themselves at the entrance to the show. Instead, they appear later, like in the Viewers Note on the wall next to Adrian Pipers photographs from the 1971 series Food for the Spirit.

title: Players Focus on Antitrust Suit
description: N.F.L. players indicated in a court filing Friday that they plan to proceed with their antitrust lawsuit no matter how an appeals court rules on an injunction that would stop the leagues lockout.

title: Starting a New Season With Youthful Energy
description: THE show that will raise the curtain on the 62nd season of the financially troubled Surflight Theater on May 28 is Rent, by Jonathan Larson, starring the onetime American Idol contestant Justin Guarini.

title: Its All Perfectly Polite. Then the Savaging Begins.
description: Veronica, Michael, Alan and Annette are terribly civilized. Thats the point.

title: Helping Catholic Students Remain Catholic in a Setting of Nietzsche and Beer Pong
description: NEW HAVEN  When she graduated four years ago as the valedictorian of a Catholic high school in Chicago, Marysa Leya received a present from her biology teacher. It was a hand-painted crucifix, intended for her college dorm room, with a note from him on the back urging her: Be sure to stay as grounded and awesome as you are now.

title: Events in Connecticut
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events in Westchester
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around the Hudson Valley. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com, or by mail to Westchester Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Events on Long Island
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Nassau and Suffolk Counties this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com, or by mail to Long Island Calendar, Metropolitan, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405.

title: Podcast: I.M.F., the Mortgage Crisis and the Dollar
description: Since it was founded in 1945, the International Monetary Fund has often played an important role in global finance. But it has rarely received as much news coverage as it has recently.

title: Finally, a Fighting Force
description: IN the last two weeks, an Afghan police officer killed two American Marines in Helmand Province, and another killed a British soldier after a dispute over a soccer match. Last month, an Afghan military pilot killed nine American military trainers after an argument at a meeting in Kabul.

title: Advice for Young Journalists in the Digital Age
description: This Tuesday, I was fortunate enough to be invited to deliver the Henry Pringle Lecture to the very bright group of rising graduates at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.As someone who frequently warns about the perils of small sample sizes, Ive long been reluctant to make too much of my personal path within the media industry. Too often, the advice that one professional gives to another is based too much on idiosyncratic personal experience and boils down to The way I do things is exactly right, and everyone else is wrong.

title: Events in New Jersey
description: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on around the state this week. Items may be submitted by mail to New Jersey Calendar, Metropolitan, The New York Times, 620 Eighth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10018-1405; or by e-mail to njtowns@nytimes.com.

title: The First Shall Be Last  Or, Anyway, Second
description: Whoops. Ive misinformed you.

title: Fortune Brands Sells Its Golf Line for $1.2 Billion
description: Fortune Brands said on Friday that it had agreed to sell its golf business to a group led by the owner of the Fila sports brand for $1.23 billion. The sale of the business, which includes the Titleist and FootJoy brands, is the first big step toward a planned breakup of Fortune Brands, long an unusual conglomerate with a big spirits portfolio and home and hardware business, in addition to golf products. The buyers are led by Fila Korea and Mirae Asset Private Equity, the largest private equity firm in South Korea. Fortune Brands said it expected to net $1.1 billion after taxes and expenses. The golf business accounted for nearly a fifth of the total revenue of Fortune Brands. Nearly half of the $1.2 billion in net sales for the companys golf products came in markets outside the United States. The business had operating income of $89 million in 2010. After the split, Fortune Brands will be a liquor company, with brands like Jim Beam, Canadian Club, Courvoisier, Makers Mark and Laphroaig. Fortune said it expected to complete the breakup in the fourth quarter.

title: Backing for Multiple Sclerosis Drug Lifts Stock
description: Acorda Therapeutics, a biotechnology company, won the backing of European Union regulators for a drug it makes with Biogen Idec to improve walking in multiple sclerosis patients, setting off a 14 percent gain in its share price. The regulators, at the European Medicines Agencys Committee for Medicinal Products for Human Use, recommended conditional marketing authorization for the drug, Fampyra, and asked for further study of the treatment. The drug was approved in the United States in January 2010 and generated $133.1 million last year for Acorda. Biogen markets the medicine outside the United States and pays Acorda royalties. Shares of Acorda, which is based in Hawthorne, N.Y., rose $3.67, or 13.7 percent, to $30.38.

title: A Burglar Led Into Temptation by Catholics and Tattoos
description: While politics is usually the matchmaker in these things, this time it had nothing to do with the strange bedfellows found at The Beach.

title: Spontaneity Again Causes Mayor Trouble
description: Responding to a lawsuit seeking to prevent New York City from closing 22 poorly performing schools, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg made a comment on Friday about parents of children in those schools that immediately prompted outrage.

title: Huntsman Takes His Potential Campaign for Test Drive in New Hampshire
description: HANCOCK, N.H.  Jon M. Huntsman Jr. knows how to speak Mandarin Chinese. He knows how to ride a motorcycle. He knows how to play keyboard in a rock band. He is trying to pick up one more skill: how to run for president.

title: Georgia Says Russia Committed Genocide in 19th Century
description: TBILISI, Georgia  The Georgian Parliament voted Friday to recognize the 19th-century killings and deportations of ethnic Circassians by czarist Russia as genocide, a move that is likely to inflame tensions between the two countries.

title: Evicted From 106 Rivington
description: Voices of those being shut out of a Lower East Side basement space that has served local musicians for more than twenty years.

title: Regulators Find Design Flaws in New Reactors
description: WASHINGTON  In a setback for the only model of nuclear reactor for which ground has been broken in the United States, government regulators have found additional problems with the design of its shield building, a crucial component, the chairman of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission said on Friday.

title: For Trainers, the Preakness Legitimizes a Horse
description: BALTIMORE  When it comes to myth-making, the Preakness Stakes has had trouble competing with the Kentucky Derby and its reputation as the Greatest Two Minutes in Sports and the Belmont Stakes, known as the Test of the Champion. Instead, it is merely the second jewel in horse racings Triple Crown.

title: States Seeking New Registries for Criminals
description: Lawmakers around the country are pushing for online registries, like those used for sex offenders, to track the whereabouts of people convicted of a wide variety of crimes, from arson and drunken driving to methamphetamine manufacturing and animal abuse.

title: Katie Couric Moves On
description: And as the sun sinks in the west, we bid adieu to Katie Couric, First Woman Anchor.

title: Environmentalists Criticize Indonesias Plan to Save Forests
description: JAKARTA, Indonesia  Indonesia on Friday released the details of a $1 billion program to curb forest destruction and reduce greenhouse gas emissions, but environmentalists said the plan gave industry too much leeway to continue clearing vital ecosystems.

title: Apple Is Called Poised to Offer Cloud Music
description: For tens of millions of iTunes users, listening to music may soon get a lot easier.

title: Racing Should Care for Its Own
description: I covered my last Triple Crown race, the Kentucky Derby, three years ago. Eight Belles, only the 39th filly to run the race, nearly beat the heavily favored Big Brown. Shortly after crossing the finish line, Eight Belles collapsed and was euthanized, marking one of the saddest days in Triple Crown history.

title: Job Description of Managing Mets Adds an Unlikely Word: Fun
description: Terry Collins doesnt kid himself, or anyone else within 60 feet 6 inches of him. He would rather have a healthy team than the Mets M*A*S*H unit. He would prefer to be working with a Steinbrenner payroll as opposed to an organization burdened with Wilpon legal expenditures.

title: AIDS Funds Frozen for China in Grant Dispute
description: BEIJING  The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria has frozen payments on hundreds of millions of dollars worth of disease-fighting grants to China, one of the charitys biggest recipients, in a dispute over Chinas management of the grants and its hostility toward involving grass-roots organizations in public health issues.

title: A Summer to Simmer
description: Wow. What a week.

title: TimesCast | Reaction from the West Bank
description: May 20, 2011 - Palestinians remain skeptical of progress towards peace.

title: Former Foes Join Forces for Education Reform
description: Michelle A. Rhee butted heads frequently during her three-year tenure as schools chancellor of Washington with the president of the local teachers union, George Parker, and eventually a voter backlash over the citys school reform wars cost both of them their jobs.

title: A Lost Chance at Redemption for Ebersol
description: Eight years ago, hours before the International Olympic Committee was to award the rights to the 2010 and 2012 Olympics to NBC, Dick Ebersol stood outside the I.O.C.s headquarters and lighted a cigar.

title: Was LinkedIn Scammed?
description: If theres one thing weve all learned in the aftermath of the financial crisis, its that stiffing your client is not a crime. Not if youre an investment bank.

title: On Tysons Face, Its Art. On Film, a Legal Issue.
description: Hollywood is accustomed to lawsuits over salaries, movie credits, even half-baked concepts that become movies. And now a studio may be going to court over a tattoo  or at least over the original concept of the tattoo.

title: Health Reform in Massachusetts
description: Mitt Romneys defense of the Massachusetts health care reforms was politically self-serving. It was also true.

title: In Park Slope, Portrait Project Draws Block Together
description: In the gloaming of yet another rain-drenched day, the faces on the stoops of the Bergen Street brownstones peered like misty apparitions to neighbors and startled dog-walkers alike.

title: Keep the Briefs Brief, Literary Justices Advise
description: WASHINGTON  Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, whose writing is clear but dry, said her style owed something to Vladimir Nabokov, the author of Lolita.

title: Saturday: One of Three Belgian Kings
description: Administrivial Alert-From-the-Future! There will be a Notepad on Sundays puzzle that says The New York Public Library turns 100 on May 23.

title: In an Unlovely, Old Market, Bonds Run Deep
description: Several things to note about the Essex Street Market on the Lower East Side. Unlike its glamorous uptown peers, the factory-chic Chelsea Market and the glossy food palace that is Eataly, it is more Plain Jane than beauty, with utilitarian flooring and generic signs that announce each vendor while screaming municipal ownership.

title: Randy Savage, Pro Wrestlings Macho Man, Dies at 58
description: Randy Savage, who with his trademark sunglasses, bandannas and raspy voice was one of the most recognizable professional wrestlers of the 1980s and 90s as the character Macho Man, died on Friday in a one-car accident in Pinellas County, Fla. He was 58.

title: Capuano Has No Peer in Keeping Watch on First
description: Chris Capuano, the Mets scheduled starter for Saturday nights game against the Yankees, was sitting on the bench May 1 during a game in Philadelphia when he saw something that grabbed his attention. Mets reliever Pedro Beato was doing an exceptional job of keeping runners tied to first base during his three shutout innings.

title: Replacement Mets Outshine Yankees Stars
description: The Subway Series has become an annual event that for six days each season captures the attention of baseball fans in the New York area. But on Friday it seemed as if the subway extended all the way to Buffalo.

title: Bold Move by Thunder Rattles the Mavericks
description: DALLAS  Russell Westbrooks bottom line testified to his undeniable contribution. He had 18 points and 4 assists, and he needed only three quarters to post those numbers.

title: Bill Summers, Car Builder Who Set a Speed Record, Dies at 75
description: Bill and Bob Summers were hot-rodding high school students when they began souping up clunkers in their Southern California town in the 1950s and heading out to race them across dry lake beds.

title: Fall TV Season Preview
description: The Times's media reporters Brian Stelter and Tanzina Vega discuss the networks' focus on comedies and big dramas as upfront week comes to a close.

title: Randall L. Wreghitt, Producer, Dies at 55
description: Randall L. Wreghitt, who used skills from a successful marketing career to produce Broadway and Off Broadway shows, died on Wednesday in Hoboken, N.J. He was 55 and lived in Union City, N.J.

title: Who Should Run the I.M.F.?
description: The arrest of Dominique Strauss-Kahn has turned the International Monetary Fund into front-page news and cast a harsh light on its dysfunctional workplace culture. Whoever is chosen to succeed Mr. Strauss-Kahn must be prepared to address both the European debt crisis and the institutions own problems.

title: Afghanistan: German Troops Fired on Protesters
description: The German Defense Ministry acknowledged Friday that its troops had fired on demonstrators during a violent protest in the northern Afghan city of Taliqan this week, wounding several civilians and possibly killing some. The demonstrations erupted Wednesday after a joint American and Afghan night raid at a family compound just outside the city that left four people dead, two of them women. NATO said the four were insurgents who tried to fire at its troops, but local officials insisted they were civilians. When the protesters tried to attack a small German-run NATO base on the outskirts of the city, the ministry said, German troops fired warning shots in the air before shooting at the legs of the attackers. Some protesters were hit in the torso and at least one was hit in the neck and head region, the statement said. At least 12 people were killed in the two days of protests. German authorities said they were investigating the shootings.

title: Haitis President Martelly
description: The peaceful inauguration this month of Haitis new president, Michel Martelly, should give Haitians cause for pride and cautious hope that their country can move beyond mere survival and start rebuilding.

title: France: Chirac Corruption Trial to Go Forward
description: The corruption trial of former President Jacques Chirac, suspended in March, can go ahead, Frances highest appeals court ruled Friday. Mr. Chirac, 78, the first former French president to go on trial since Marshal Philippe Ptain after World War II, is accused of embezzling public funds as Paris mayor to pay people working for his party. He has denied knowledge of any illegal payments. Co-defendants had argued in vain that some charges were unconstitutional under the statute of limitations.

title: China: Dissident Artist Is Accused of Tax Evasion
description: A company controlled by the dissident artist Ai Weiwei evaded a huge amount of taxes and intentionally destroyed financial documents, Xinhua, the governments official news agency, reported Friday. Xinhua, quoting the police, said that the authorities were focusing on Beijing Fake Cultural Development Ltd. The artists sister, Gao Ge, told Reuters that Mr. Ai is neither the companys legal representative nor its chief executive. So even if the company is accused of these crimes, Ai Weiwei should not be detained, she said. Mr. Ai has been detained at an undisclosed location since April 3.

title: Gas Prices and Political Pandering
description: The closer one looks at what passes for serious debate in Washington over energy, the more depressing it gets. The Republicans have nothing to offer but drill, baby, drill. The Democrats are rightly trying to end industrys cushy tax breaks, but thats not an energy strategy.

title: Iran: Panel Rules President Overreached, Report Says
description: The Guardian Council, Irans top legal panel, has ruled that President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad overstepped his authority by assuming control of the Oil Ministry when he fired the oil minister a week ago, the state-run Fars news agency reported Friday. The report casts doubt on whether Mr. Ahmadinejad will be able to lead the OPEC meeting in Vienna next month, and suggests a further deterioration of his relationship with Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, the countrys supreme leader. The Guardian Council is partly appointed by the ayatollah. The council has not confirmed the report, which said that the presidents appointment of himself as acting oil minister was unconstitutional. Last month, Mr. Ahmadinejad tried to dismiss the intelligence chief, but was reversed by Ayatollah Khamenei.

title: A Mets Site About Nothing
description: Dirk Lammers was in Paris on Thursday when the Twitter message arrived: Dillon Gee took it 5 and 2/3rds innings before Livan Hernandez singled to center to make it 7,849 Mets games with no no-hitter.

title: Sudan: Fighting Reported in Disputed Region
description: New fighting has broken out in the contested region of Abyei in central Sudan, the United Nations said Friday. Two bombs were dropped by aircraft on a bridge outside the town of Abyei on Friday evening, a United Nations official said. Hua Jiang, a United Nations spokeswoman in Sudan, said the world body had also been alerted to possible artillery fire in villages surrounding Abyei, which had not been independently confirmed. There were no casualties reported. On Thursday a United Nations convoy carrying 200 northern Sudanese soldiers was attacked in a southern-controlled part of the region.

title: South Africa: Rail Collision in Soweto Investigated
description: Inspectors from the Railway Safety Regulator were investigating Friday a commuter rail collision that occurred in Soweto during rush hour on Thursday. A packed train full of people returning home from work to the township of Soweto crashed into a stationary train, injuring 857 people, but only three seriously, said Douglas Chauke, acting provincial manager for Metrorail, the public commuter line. Four coaches were damaged, but the rail line reopened Friday in time for the morning rush hour, Mr. Chauke said.

title: A Commute That Mixes Exercise and Politics
description: He took on Barack Obama, tangled with the Washington press corps and elbowed out opponents in a rough-and-tumble New York City mayors race.

title: Lottery Numbers
Upfronts Video: Fall TV Season Preview
description: The Timess media reporters Brian Stelter and Tanzina Vega discuss the networks focus on comedies and big dramas as upfront week comes to a close.

title: Newt's Big Ideas
description: Mark Schmitt, left, of the Roosevelt Institute and James Pinkerton of Fox News debate the ideas of Newt Gingrich.

title: Antitrust Focus for Union
description: N.F.L. players indicated in a court filing Friday that they planned to proceed with their antitrust lawsuit no matter how an appeals court rules on an injunction that would stop the leagues lockout.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Inside Out Project
description: In Park Slope, Brooklyn, posters of neighborhood faces are being pasted on stoops as part of an art project.

title: Backing Her Man With Impressive Resources
description: PARIS  She was much more famous than her husband, and much wealthier, too.

title: Obamas Peace Tack Contrasts With Key Aide, Friend of Israel
description: WASHINGTON  Five days ago, during a closed-door meeting with a group of Middle East experts, administration officials, and journalists, King Abdullah II of Jordan gave his assessment of how Arabs view the debate within the Obama administration over how far to push Israel on concessions for peace with the Palestinians.

title: Photo Replay: May 20
description: The day in sports included preparations for Sundays Formula One race, as well as several close calls in the days baseball games.

title: Boogaard Is Remembered by His Billet Mom
description: As family and friends gathered for the funeral of Derek Boogaard in Regina, Saskatchewan, on Saturday, Boogaard was remembered in the context of a different kind of family  his last billet mom, in Medicine Hat, Alberta.

title: Suicide Bomber Attacks Kabul Military Hospital
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A powerful midday blast on the grounds of the heavily guarded national military hospital here killed at least 6 people and injured more than 20 others, government officials said.

title: Cannes Q. and A.: Gerardo Naranjo and Mexicos State of Fear
description: CANNES, France In his new film Miss Bala, the director Gerardo Naranjo, tackles a topical issue  drug violence in Mexico  though an unlikely protagonist: an aspiring Tijuana beauty queen (Stephanie Sigman) who gets caught up with the local kingpins. Instead of delving into the social or political aspects of the problem, docudrama-style, Mr. Naranjo fashions a tense mood piece steeped in confusion and anxiety. He sticks to the captive heroines frequently befogged point of view while ruthless cartel operatives and corrupt cops remain on the periphery or outside the frame, their actions often unseen and their motivations murky.

title: At French Open, This Plot Looks Familiar
description: Being the third wheel, almost an afterthought, going into Slam tournaments cant be easy if youre a player who has gone into such events as a favorite for nearly a decade. I mean, imagine if you started winning Slam titles when you were 21. At one point you were No. 1 on the computer for so many consecutive weeks that people had a hard time remembering who held the spot before you did.

title: The Weekend Word: Nonnegotiable
description: Todays Times

title: Oil Truck Explosion Kills at Least 15 in Pakistan
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  At least 15 people were killed when a damaged oil tanker carrying fuel for NATO forces in Afghanistan exploded Saturday in the northwestern tribal region, government officials said.

title: Friday Night Lights Watch: Turns of Fortune
description: The episode up for discussion is called Swerve, alluding both to Julies self-imposed car accident and various other instances of changes of heart and turns of fortune. Unable to muster the stamina to return to college after her run-in with Dereks wife last, week Julie decides that the way to bide more time at home is to ram her car into a mailbox near her parents house. Maybe Id be a really weak and bad parent to a teenager, but I dont think I would have tried to force Julie to go back to Burleson, which is after all, a fictitious college and one at a significant psychic remove from her dreams of a Northeastern educational experience. Coach Taylor being Coach Taylor, he wanted Julie to man up and face the mess. The whole point of the affair now seems to have been to stack the deck so in favor of Julies return home that the show could easily situate her back in Dillon. Perhaps it was too implausible that Julie would just go to Dillon Tech in the first place, so the writers dispatched her to a place where she implausibly made no friends and experienced not a seconds worth of intellectual fulfillment or genuine freshman pleasure.It was interesting to see Coach having the correct perception of Julies motives rather than Tami. It is coach who realizes that Julie must have crashed on purpose. Tami is a disbeliever. It was interesting to see the show cast Coachs impotence  he cant get Julie in the car and back to school because she refuses with every fiber of her being to go  against Vinces fathers assertion of paternal authority. Vince is in trouble with his thug lender, and his father steps in and solves problems by beating the daylights out of the guy, hoping to make sure the guy never gets within a yard of Vince again. Will this work? It sure felt as if it would. Id hate to see this come back to haunt Vinces father, or worse, for Vince to take the moral high ground against his dad in response.

title: Cannes Q. and A.: The Loneliness of the Banned Filmmaker

But the most meaningful act of all may be the Cannes Film Festivals decision  announced just days before screenings got under way  to show new films that Mr. Panahi and his countryman Mohammed Rasoulof had made in defiance of their bans. (Like Mr. Panahi, Mr. Rasoulof, whose new film, Goodbye, is about an Iranian woman trying to leave the country, has been convicted for collusion against the regime  both were given six-year prison sentences, which are being appealed.)

And this moment is precisely when the child gets started: the repeat trip to the bathroom, the urgent request for water, the sudden fear of the radiator, the artfully misplaced lovey.

The trips back to the cinematic well (or chum bucket, as the case may be) include Kung Fu Panda 2, Paranormal Activity 3, Scream 4, Fast Five, and the eighth Harry Potter movie, Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows (Part Two). You might call the latter a sequel of a sequel of a sequel of a sequel of a sequel of a sequel of a sequel.

title: Reader Comments on my Religion Quiz
description: The back story behind my Sunday column is a measure of irritation that the Bible is so often cited as a basis for what seem to me to be archaic or backward positions on social issues  such as support for slavery in the 19th century, or opposition to gay marriage today. In particular, theres a widespread sense that religion is deeply conservative on social and sexual issues, when in fact its pretty much all over the map and is much more focused on questions of social justice. So thats why I wrote this 2011 religion quiz as my Sunday column.

title: Back Then: 1911
description: A minor bomb scare aside, Queen Elizabeth IIs visit to Ireland last week seemed less tense than the last visit by a reigning British monarch, a century ago, before the creation of the Irish Free State in 1922. The New York Times reported from Dublin on July 8, 1911, that  amid tight security in the poorest and roughest district  a sergeants arm was broken in a scuffle before King George Vs entourage arrived, at which time men and women who had been jeering the police and soldiers broke into hearty cheers. Elsewhere, the report said, popular sentiment was well expressed by a banner stretched outside a City Council hall at Pembroke, a suburb of the capital, which refused to address the King, declaring, Welcome. We Want Home Rule.

title: Sunday: Fabulous Writer?
description: SUNDAYS PUZZLE  As someone who grew up in New York City, one of my fondest memories was of childhood trips to the main branch of the New York Public Library (now known as the Stephen A. Schwartzman Building). I consider myself lucky to have walked among the majestic columns, up the stairs past the solemn, stone lions that still guard the entrance and through the great halls into the reading rooms. In a quasi-Proustian way, I can still remember the smell of the books and the card catalogs, a sense memory that I wonder if todays children will ever have. Can you really dredge up the memory of how an e-book smelled?
