title: Not Going to the Chapel
description: I PICKED up my jangling cellphone one recent Saturday to hear the elated voice of Zachary, my longtime buddy and college classmate. I just proposed to Caroline, Zach announced, inviting me to the wedding and angling to plot logistics. So when are you flying in?

title: Old Soviet Nuclear Site in Asia Has Unlikely Sentinel: The U.S.
description: KURCHATOV, Kazakhstan  Twenty years after the Soviet Union collapsed and tens of thousands of soldiers abandoned their posts at this remote site in northeastern Kazakhstan, the footprints of another great power  the United States  are increasingly visible.

title: Need Therapy? A Good Man Is Hard to Find
description: Between unresolved family conflicts, relationship struggles and his mixed-race identity, James Puckett had enough on his mind in college that he sought professional help. But after bouncing from one therapist to another, he still felt stuck.

title: Feeding the Gossip Machine
description: An appetite for the latest celebrity gossip fuels a growing, round-the-clock industry.

title: Sweating at the Start, Shackleford Finishes the Right Way
description: BALTIMORE  Shackleford is a little colt, and as he skittered into the starting gate for the 136th running of the Preakness Stakes he seemed to be shrinking before everyones eyes. He had foam on his neck and sweat pouring down his sides and looked like a horse who had left his race in the paddock.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Freshman Democrats in the House Bond Over Policy and Egg Rolls
description: WASHINGTON  When you are a freshman Democrat in the House surrounded by scores of people whose views are antithetical to yours and who regularly pass laws you hate, you need coping strategies.

title: Behind Grass-Roots School Advocacy, Bill Gates
description: INDIANAPOLIS  A handful of outspoken teachers helped persuade state lawmakers this spring to eliminate seniority-based layoff policies. They testified before the legislature, wrote briefing papers and published an op-ed article in The Indianapolis Star.

title: When Grandmasters Fail to Live Up to the Title
description: There are drawn games among top players that are even more exciting than decisive victories, especially when they are riddled with errors and attacks.

title: Annotated Excerpts of the Gates Foundation 990 Form 2009
description: Annotated excerpts of a tax form highlight how the Gates Foundation has increased its attention to education advocacy.

title: Sunday Breakfast Menu
description: From Medicare to the debt ceiling, budgets deals and proposals are the main topic of conversation on the Sunday talk shows.

title: Preakness Replay, May 21
description: A look back at Shacklefords victory at the 136th Preakness Stakes.

title: Leonard Kastle, Composer and Filmmaker, Dies at 82
description: Leonard Kastle, an opera composer who unexpectedly found a niche in film history as the writer and director of the low-budget 1969 crime-thriller film The Honeymoon Killers, died on Wednesday at his home in Westerlo, N.Y. He was 82.

title: Yanks Feast on Mets Pitching, Belting 4 Homers Off Capuano
description: Their ballparks, 10 miles and a borough apart, were constructed at the same time, opening two years ago to breathless anticipation. For $800 million, the Mets erected a pitchers haven. For $1.5 billion, the Yankees built a bandbox, and it suits their team just fine.

title: Before Turners Hot Start, a Few Had Faith in Him
description: Justin Turner knocked in a run Saturday for the seventh game in a row to establish a team record for rookies in the Mets 7-3 loss to the Yankees.

title: The Economics of Education
description: Parents, students and teachers confront a budget shortfall that threatens to reverse hard-won gains in schools that once performed poorly.

title: Mavericks Almost Blow a 22-Point Lead
description: OKLAHOMA CITY  The Dallas Mavericks breathed an epic sigh of relief Saturday night, which for these aging veterans has become increasingly difficult in a Western Conference finals series filled with wild emotional swings.

title: Daniels Decides Against Republican Presidential Bid
description: Updated | 1:42 p.m.

title: Warnings of All-Out War in Fight Over Sudan Town
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The Sudanese Army invaded the flashpoint town of Abyei over the weekend, alarming Western and United Nations diplomats who warned Sunday that it was a provocative act that risked all-out war with the southern Sudanese.

title: Charlatans and Cranks
description: Politico writes that

title: Lottery Numbers
Baghdad Is Rocked by Blasts That Kill 20, Including 2 American Soldiers
description: BAGHDAD  A series of explosions, including one that struck a United States military patrol, shook Baghdad on Sunday, killing 20 people, including 2 American soldiers and 8 Iraqi policemen, according to an Iraqi security official.

title: Iceland Volcano Closes Airports
description: PARIS  Icelands four international airports were closed to most flights on Sunday as the island nations most active volcano erupted for a second day, sending billows of ash 12 miles into the atmosphere, aviation and meteorological officials said.

title: Another View of Killebrew
description: Harmon Killebrews death earlier this week no doubt had legions of boomers digging for a nostalgic look at the longtime Twins slugger on old baseball cards, magazines covers and photographs. One of the most appealing examples of the latter that Ive seen is a mid-1960s image of Killebrew by the photographer Ozzie Sweet.

title: Festival in Paris Spotlights Indie Music, Old and New
description: Normally a spot for picnickers and sunbathers, the Parc de la Villette in Paris will be getting an infusion of sound. The Villette Sonique music festival, running from May 27 to June 1, is a weeklong event in Pariss 19th Arrondissement, spreading various musical acts  including some free shows  between the Cit de la Musique, the Gode and the green fields of the park.

title: Uniform-Wearing Militants Kill 6 at Afghan Police Station
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Insurgents wearing police uniforms and vests laced with explosives stormed a police compound in eastern Afghanistan early Sunday morning, engaging in a firefight that lasted several hours before Afghan and NATO forces regained control of the complex, government officials said.

title: Europeans Focus on Retaining Leadership of I.M.F.
description: PARIS  As the International Monetary Fund prepared to accept nominations Monday to replace Dominique Strauss-Kahn at its helm, European officials rallied over the weekend around Christine Lagarde, Frances finance minister, as their top choice for the post, despite fresh warnings from leaders of emerging markets and other countries that simply handing the job to another European could undermine the funds legitimacy.

title: The Rails Scoreboard
description: How The Rails contributors are doing with their predictions through the first two legs of the Triple Crown (using a 3-2-1 point breakdown for win-place-show). Our guest pickers, Rick Pitino and Kevin Plank, have failed to score.

title: Spains Governing Party Suffers Heavy Losses
description: MADRID  The governing Socialist Party suffered heavy losses on Sunday in regional and municipal elections, even as tens of thousands of Spaniards calling themselves the indignant said they would pursue their protests to force an overhaul of the countrys political system.

title: Obama Presses Israel to Make Hard Choices
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama struck back at Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in a speech to a pro-Israel lobbying group on Sunday, defending his stance that talks over a Palestinian state should be focused on Israels pre-1967 borders, along with negotiated land swaps, and challenging Israel to make the hard choices necessary to bring about a stable peace.

title: Vettel Controls Race in Spain to Win Fourth Prix in Five
description: BARCELONA  Before the race on Sunday, Formula One had high expectations that thanks to new technical rules, the Spanish Grand Prix would not be the same procession it usually is on a track where it is so difficult to overtake.

title: Vettel Controls Race in Spain to Win Fourth Prix in Five
description: BARCELONA  Before the race on Sunday, Formula One had high expectations that thanks to new technical rules, the Spanish Grand Prix would not be the same procession it usually is on a track where it is so difficult to overtake.

title: Schott Op-Chart: All the Worlds a World Stage
description: The purpose of foreign policy, argued John F. Kennedy, is not to provide an outlet for our own sentiments of hope or indignation; it is to shape real events in a real world. And the real world is populated by other leaders, each with their own competing hopes and indignations.Click here for the actors who, since Jimmy Carter, have strutted and fretted their hour upon the world stage.

title: Cannes Q. and A.: Driving in a Noir L.A.
description: CANNES, France Genre movies are typically relegated to the sidelines at the worlds major film festivals, but Cannes this year has done its part to shift the balance. Alongside auteurs like the Dardenne brothers and Aki Kaurismaki, the main competition also features a few surprising Cannes first-timers, like Japans Takashi Miike, whose samurai drama Hara-kiri is the first 3-D movie to screen in competition, and Denmarks Nicolas Winding Refn, best known for the violent Pusher trilogy and the stylized thug portrait Bronson, who is here with his Los Angeles-set noir Drive. (On Sunday, Mr. Refn won the festivals best director prize.)

title: Djokovic Hones a Masterful Winning Streak
description: PARIS  Novak Djokovics 39-match winning streak coming into this French Open sounds lengthy indeed, until you start thinking long-term.

title: In City That Lost Its Team, Every Win Is a Point of Pride
description: With due deference to the millionaire superstars whose soccer skills are followed across the world, the story of English soccers final weekend was the rise of A.F.C. Wimbledon.

title: Other Peoples Politics
description: Update: Robins suggestion to the Italians is, find some way to get Berlusconi into a New York hotel.

title: Rhone Steps Down as Head of Universal Motown
description: The management shake-up at Universal Music Group continues as Sylvia Rhone, a lieutenant of the companys former chairman and one of the most prominent women in the music business, steps down as president of Universal Motown, one of the groups labels.

title: A Move by City Opera Has Potential, as Well as Possible Pitfalls
description: After talking, fantasizing and plotting about it for years, New York City Opera is moving out of Lincoln Center. Immediately! Or so the company said on Friday in a stunning, if very sketchy, announcement from George Steel, the general manager and artistic director.

title: Mideast Questions Likely to Surface in Obamas Trip to Europe
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama left behind a week filled with the strident passions of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict to fly to Europe on Sunday, where his first stop on a six-day tour is Ireland, another country once consumed by sectarian violence.

title: Now Running for President: Mitch Danielss Ghost
description: Mitch Danielss decision to not run for president stands somewhat in contrast to Mike Huckabees, simply because Mr. Daniels had yet to gain significant popular support in the polls. But it also stands in contrast to Haley Barbours, in that Mr. Daniels had a more plausible route to the nomination, most likely by performing well enough in Iowa to gain significant momentum heading into New Hampshire, a state that caters to a number of his strengths.

title: Jimmy Choo Sold to Labelux for About $800 Million
description: Labelux, a privately held luxury group, said Sunday that it had agreed to acquire the high-end shoe and accessories company Jimmy Choo from TowerBrook Capital Partners, a private equity company, and minority shareholders.

title: Worthy Online Resource, but Global Cultural Treasure?
description: BERLIN  In its 10 years of existence, Wikipedia, the global online encyclopedia, has amassed an archive of 18 million entries in 279 languages. It is one of the 10 most popular Web sites on the Internet.

title: Yemeni Leaders Allies Blockade Embassy as He Refuses Peace Deal
description: WASHINGTON  Yemens political crisis deepened on Sunday as President Ali Abdullah Saleh once again and at the last minute scuttled an agreement that he step down, and hundreds of his armed supporters blockaded an embassy, trapping American, European and Arab diplomats for hours.

title: Few Upsets on French Opens First Day
description: PARIS  Samantha Stosur of Australia, last years runner-up, returned to the French Open on Sunday with a convincing 6-2, 6-3 victory over Iveta Benesova of the Czech Republic.

title: Hollywood Presses Its Global Agenda
description: SINGAPORE  When Thor, the Marvel superhero action film directed by Kenneth Branagh, opened in theaters in North America on May 6, the $150 million 3-D film had already made more than $130 million at the international box office.

title: Asia Society Appoints Two Leaders
description: The balance of power between the United States and Asia has shifted dramatically since 1956, when John D. Rockefeller III founded the Asia Society to promote greater understanding of Asia in the United States. In response, the Asia Society is shifting its center of gravity from New York to its outposts in Hong Kong, Mumbai, Manila and elsewhere.

title: The Morning Line: Assessing the Preakness
description: Theres no rapture and no chance of a Triple Crown this year as the 12-1 shot Shackleford defeated the Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdom by a half-length to win the Preakness.

title: Oscar Winner Facing Sex Charges an Apparent Suicide
description: An Academy Award-winning songwriter who was awaiting trial on charges of sexually assaulting about a dozen women was believed to have killed himself in an apartment on the Upper East Side, the police said.

title: Protesters Call for the Resignation of Georgias President
description: MOSCOW  The police clashed with antigovernment protesters in Georgia on Sunday, at one point firing tear gas and rubber bullets, as hundreds of demonstrators gathered in the capital of the former Soviet republic to demand the ouster of President Mikheil Saakashvili.

title: The Magic of a Courtside Seat
description: PARIS  With a relatively uneventful opening day unfolding at Roland Garros, it seemed the best way to spend part of a sunny, breezy afternoon was in my favorite press seat in sports.

title: Pirates Plunders the Global Box Office
description: International audiences carried Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides, the fourth film in this series from Walt Disney Studios, to $346.4 million in worldwide ticket sales since the movie opened abroad on Wednesday.

title: Elite South Korean University Rattled by Suicides
description: DAEJEON, South Korea  It has been a sad and gruesome semester at South Koreas most prestigious university, and with final exams beginning Monday the school is still reeling from the recent suicides of four students and a popular professor.

title: Talk Show Ends, and Oprah Moves On
description: Oprah Winfrey has taped more than 5,000 episodes of her daytime talk show, transforming television and trying to teach millions of viewers how to live life with purpose along the way. She has one more to go. She says she feels relieved.

title: Union Ponders Labor Charges
description: The American Guild of Musical Artists said it would consider filing unfair labor practice charges with the National Labor Relations Boardagainst New York City Opera after that companys board voted on Friday to cut staffing and move from its Lincoln Center home. Alan Gordon, the unions national executive director, said the group might also seek an injunction to keep the company from using the name New York City Opera. George Steel, the operas general manager and artistic director, said on Friday that the move, the layoffs and the cuts to the production schedule were required to keep the company running and to ensure a foundation for sustainable growth. RACHEL LEE HARRIS

title: Media Decoder: Oprah's Final Show
description: After 25 years, the final episode of "The Oprah Winfrey Show" will air on May 25.

title: Gates Warns Against Big Cuts in Military Spending
description: WASHINGTON  In a grim warning about financial priorities during a time of fiscal crisis, the defense secretary, Robert M. Gates, said Sunday that budget pressures must not limit Pentagon spending such that the military is unable to defend American interests in an unpredictable world.

title: Cannes Gives Top Prize to The Tree of Life
description: CANNES, France  In a strong year that was nearly eclipsed by off-screen scandals, the top prize for the 64th Cannes Film Festival was given to The Tree of Life, the long-awaited film from the American director and writer Terrence Malick. A story about transcendence that divided critics, who were alternately transported and turned off by its religious themes and elliptical storytelling, it is the first film from Mr. Malick since The New World (2005). The famously shy Mr. Malick did not appear to accept his award, which was introduced by Jane Fonda, who spoke in emphatic French before saying, And maintenant, now, lets cut to the chase. The competition jury president, Robert De Niro, hurriedly announced the winner.

title: Oprahs Final Shows: What to Expect
On Strength of One Inning, Yankees Thwart the Mets
description: The Mets were nine outs away Sunday from evening their record at .500, from capturing a series against the Yankees, from reigning supreme in New York. Their nominal ace, Mike Pelfrey, was cruising. The bottom of the Yankees order was due up.

title: Obama Addresses AIPAC
description: President Obama repeated his call for Palestinian statehood based on Israel's pre-1967 borders in a speech to the American Israel Public Affairs Committee. (Video: MSNBC)

title: Insects Flee, and Kitty Seeks Revenge
description: Over the weekend at the West End Theater, back-to-back programs showcased new dances by a pair of diametrically opposed artists: Rebecca Stenn and Maura Nguyen Donohue. They were part of the Soaking Wet series created by Jeffrey Kazin and David Parker, who included a program note explaining that the two choreographers show an underlying unity of purpose in their creation of eloquent work. If thats a little ambiguous, this isnt: One had more purpose and eloquence than the other.

title: Meeting, Marriage and Then Trouble
description: When you consider that opera and art song tend to reach their most unforgettable heights and depths at moments of vulnerability and tragedy, it is no surprise that the final part of the soprano Kate Royals concert at Weill Recital Hall on Friday was the strongest.

title: Economic Crisis Unfurls in Hushed Suspense
description: It cant be easy to create a financial thriller. Theres no blood, there are (usually) no bodies. How do you create excitement when most of the action consists of middle-aged white men in conservative suits talking on the phone, and the closest thing to a car chase is a stately procession of big black Town Cars? How often can you show people peering at spreadsheets and recoiling in alarm? What do you do when the scandal itself might as well be labeled Too Complicated to Understand? The HBO film Too Big to Fail, based on the book of the same name by the reporter Andrew Ross Sorkin of The New York Times, about the financial crisis of 2008, uses every cinematic trick in the book, but ultimately succeeds because we know that the danger was real.

title: Rock and Classical Collide With Bowie and a Score by Radiohead Star
description: Wordless Music, the concert series run by Ronen Givony when he is not overseeing the classical and new-music programming at Le Poisson Rouge, is devoted to showing fans of indie rock and contemporary classical music that the two genres have a common appeal. That argument no longer requires special pleading, partly because Mr. Givonys thoughtful juxtapositions have made the point so persuasively but also because so many young composers (and some of their elders) draw freely on both their classical and pop antecedents.

title: In TV Pilots, Paranormal Is the New Normal
description: IT was not so long ago that commercials were filled with fantastical characters like green giants, flying maids and white knights. For the 2011-12 television season, it will be the shows, not the ads, that feature creatures out of fairy tales and ghost stories.

title: Confederate General Buried Far From the Battlefield
description: Robert Selden Garnett, the first general killed in the Civil War, was buried in Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn, but his family did not want visitors to the cemetery to know it.

title: Making a Hashtag of It
description: If youve been watching media debaters flip the pro-con coin about the Internet lately, you know by now that Twitter is either a noble catalyst of the Arab Spring or an atomizer of noxious moronism whose users might as well be huffing computer duster.

title: Mystical Morocco Bursting With Tribal Rhythm
description: West African slaves, transported far from home, held on to rituals that praise saints and spirits with songs, dances, galvanizing rhythms and trance possession. Thats the story of voodoo and Santera in the Americas, and its also the story of Gnawa music in Morocco, made by descendants of slaves brought north from what is now Mali. As part of its World Nomads Morocco Festival, the French Institute Alliance Franaise brought Master Gnaoua Musicians to Florence Gould Hall on Saturday night.

title: The Flight of Curiosity
description: Must one be endowed with curiosity in order to become a philosopher?

title: With Subtlety and Power, Observing Mahlers Moment
description: NEWARK  One hundred years ago last Wednesday, Gustav Mahler died of a heart infection. He was living in Vienna, but three months earlier he had conducted the New York Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall in his final appearance on a podium. That February concert ended a three-year period in which he reigned in New York, first as a conductor at the Metropolitan Opera and then as the Philharmonics music director.

title: Pop Stars Lift SNL Ratings
description: Maybe it was the Gaga effect, or maybe it was J. T., or most likely a bit of both: with Lady Gaga performing and Justin Timberlake, together below, hosting over the weekend, Saturday Night Live recorded its highest ratings for a season finale in seven years. Nielsen reported that the show averaged a 7.0 rating in major local markets  meaning about 7 percent of homes with televisions watched the episode  up from a 5.8 rating for the same episode last season. NBC said that rating was high enough to match the season finale in 2004, when the Olsen twins, Mary-Kate and Ashley, were the hosts and J-Kwon was the performer. Apart from a night in January when the show was preceded by a major football game, Saturdays episode also received a season-high rating. The episode was particularly well-received online for its revival of several past Timberlake sketches and for Lady Gagas appearances in several of the sketches.

title: Nonfiction Writer Finishes Crichton Novel
description: HarperCollins plans to publish a new novel by Michael Crichton, the best-selling author of Jurassic Park and The Andromeda Strain, who died of cancer in November 2008. The book is to be released in November with assistance from the noted nonfiction author Richard Preston, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Crichton wrote about one-third of Micro, a technological thriller, before his death. Mr. Preston, best known for his book The Hot Zone, about the Ebola virus, used Mr. Crichtons personal reference material, outline and notes to finish the novel. When I first read Michael Crichtons unfinished manuscript, I could practically feel his excitement filling the pages, Mr. Preston said in a news release from the publisher. Michael was writing at the top of his game, with a grand sense of adventure, into an eerie world that seems almost beyond imagining. He added that he sought to honor the work and imagination of one of our times most visionary and creative authors. In 2009 HarperCollins also published Pirate Latitudes, which Mr. Crichton had finished.

title: Festival for Puppets
description: St. Anns Warehouse in Dumbo, Brooklyn, will host Labapalooza!, an annual minifestival celebrating new puppet and object theater. Guided by the directors Matthew Acheson and Tom Lee, St. Anns Puppet Lab artists will present a range of works including Interference and Collapse, a look at the death of the R&B singer Sam Cooke, and Senseless! A Brick Foley Adventure, a hard-boiled tale investigating a series of murders at the Helen Keller School of Music, the theater announced. Financed by the Jim Henson Foundation, the New York City Department of Cultural Affairs and the New York State Council on the Arts, Labapalooza!, in its 13th year, will be presented in two programs running from June 2 to 5.

title: Burdened by PBS Dues, Stations Consider Withdrawing
description: ORLANDO, Fla.  Television executives who gathered here last week for PBSs annual meeting enthusiastically embraced projects such as the five-part Women, War and Peace and heard the actress Anna Deavere Smith speak so passionately of PBSs role in bringing the arts to Americans that Paula Kerger, PBSs president and chief executive, teared up.

title: The Parisian Experience of American Pioneers
description: The Greater Journey is an important-looking book by the august historian David McCullough, who has twice won the Pulitzer Prize (for Truman and John Adams) and is a regular source of Fathers Day gifts for distinction-loving dads. His latest lavishly produced volume has a handsome collection of color photographs, a stellar cast of historically important American characters and a long, impressive bibliography. What it does not have is a unifying premise.

title: At the Games Highest Level, Communication Is Everything
description: The higher the level of the game, the more important bidding has become. And for getting to the correct games and, especially, slams, describing openers hand type as quickly as possible is a big plus. So with a balanced hand, utter the phrase no-trump as quickly as possible. With an unbalanced hand, show the long suits.

title: TV Justice Thrives on Fear
description: This week, it was announced that Americas Most Wanted, hosted by John Walsh, the longest running perp walk in television history, would no longer be regularly broadcast on Fox. With the future of Mr. Walshs hunt for bad guys uncertain, who will speak for the victims of crime?

title: Monday: 20 Questions Category
description: MONDAYS PUZZLE  When I am at the American Crossword Puzzle Tournament, it is always interesting to see what kind of talismanic items people bring with them to help them speed up their solving. Ive seen everything from lucky pencils to Troll dolls. Some people wear costumes. Still others, oddly enough, practice solving.

title: Female Magazine Fans Flock to Nook Color
description: Even as the iPad remains the favorite son of the magazine business, publishers are discovering that the Barnes & Noble Nook Color is a very promising younger daughter.

title: Follies
description: Photos from the revival at the Kennedy Center in Washington.

title: Analysts Wary of LinkedIns Stock Surge
description: What are shares of LinkedIn really worth?

title: Mourning the Loss of Yet Another Alley
description: Its all over with, Marilyn Onorato said, casting a final gaze over the 32 lanes at Fairway Bowling. Boo hoo.

title: Yahoos Emphasis Is Better, Not New
description: SUNNYVALE, Calif.  In listing his biggest accomplishments as Yahoos product chief, Blake Irving gave an answer that speaks to the companys painful legacy of layoffs, aimlessness and stalled growth.

title: Cronocaos
description: A new exhibition challenges the rush to preserve sites deemed historic.

title: Militants Attack Pakistani Naval Base in Karachi
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A team of heavily armed insurgents stormed a major Pakistani naval base in the southern city of Karachi late Sunday night, setting off a prolonged gun battle with Pakistani security forces and, by some accounts, destroying an American-made aircraft at the base.

title: The Most Northern of Southern Cities
description: Like many Mid-Atlantic cities, Philadelphia was split between Unionist and pro-Southern sentiments. In early 1861 crowds cheered at a rally to support the seceding states, while the citys political leaders offered Independence Hall as the site for a special convention to conciliate the secession crisis.

title: Armstrong Teammate Describes Doping System
description: For top riders on the United States Postal Service squad, the powerhouse American cycling team led by Lance Armstrong, duplicity was simply a part of the game, one of Armstrongs former teammates said.

title: Lightning Fans Send a Message: We Exist
description: Assumptions about Southern fans interest in hockey are made at ones own peril. The Boston Bruins promotions department made one about fans of the Tampa Bay Lightning, and on Sunday those fans provided a very visible rebuttal.

title: I.M.F. Candidates, by the Numbers
description: The race to succeed Dominique Strauss-Kahn as managing director of the International Monetary Fund is under way. Picking the funds next chief will depend on personalities and politics. But what if the decision were based on the economic performance of the I.M.F.s 187 member states? In that case, none of the current favorites would look particularly good.

title: No Recognition Yet, but European Union Opens an Office in the Libyan Rebels Stronghold
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  Catherine Ashton, the European Unions foreign policy chief, visited Benghazi on Sunday, providing support and a burst of confidence to Col. Muammar el-Qaddafis opponents, who said the high-profile trip was evidence of growing international recognition for their cause.

title: Fine Print Blurs Whos in Control of Online Photos
description: If you post a photo on the Web, it still belongs to you, right? Well, be sure to read the fine print.

title: The Self-Rationing of Medical Care
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Objects to New Law on Clinics in Indiana
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is raising serious objections to a new Indiana law that cuts off state and federal money for Planned Parenthood clinics providing health care to low-income women on Medicaid.

title: Somali and African Union Forces Advance in Mogadishu
description: MOGADISHU, Somalia  Government forces and African Union peacekeepers advanced Sunday against rebels in several Mogadishu neighborhoods, gaining ground in their campaign to take control of the Bakara market, officials and witnesses said.

title: Ex-Leader of Honduras Signs Accord Clearing Path for Return
description: MEXICO CITY  The former president of Honduras, Manuel Zelaya, who was ousted and expelled in a 2009 coup, signed an agreement with the current president on Sunday that clears the way for him to return home after two years in exile, Honduran officials said.

title: CNBC Takes a Hollywood Turn
description: Every few minutes in Too Big to Fail, the film about the darkest days of the financial crisis in 2008 that will have its premiere Monday on HBO, something happens that once seemed unbelievable. Banks collapse. Balance sheets crumble. Government officials plot extraordinary interventions to curb the free fall.

title: Accord With Comptroller Will Help Attorney General Pursue Corruption Cases
description: Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman and Thomas P. DiNapoli, the state comptroller, have entered into an agreement that will grant Mr. Schneiderman powers to criminally prosecute corruption involving taxpayer money, significantly expanding the attorney generals authority to pursue public integrity cases.

title: Arizonas Immigration Law: A View From the A.C.L.U.
description: To the Editor:

title: Tale of the City: Quieting the Cab Honking
description: To the Editor:

title: As Lenders Hold Homes in Foreclosure, Sales Are Hurt
description: EL MIRAGE, Ariz.  The nations biggest banks and mortgage lenders have steadily amassed real estate empires, acquiring a glut of foreclosed homes that threatens to deepen the housing slump and create a further drag on the economic recovery.

title: Daniels Is Out, in Another Jolt to G.O.P. Field
description: WASHINGTON  The announcement Sunday by Gov. Mitch Daniels of Indiana that he would not run for the Republican presidential nomination ended one major chapter of uncertainty in the race but ignited new debate over whether the current field contains a candidate capable of beating President Obama next year.

title: With Triple Crown Hopes Dashed, Enthusiasm Grows for a Belmont Rivalry
description: BALTIMORE

title: Rose Denies Comments on Performance-Enhancing Drugs
description: MIAMI  Derrick Rose denied quotations attributed to him by ESPN The Magazine on the impact of performance-enhancing drugs in the N.B.A. Rose was among a number of athletes polled by the magazine when it asked them to assess the influence of the drugs in their sport from 1 as the lowest to 10 at the highest.

title: Dont Tread on Golfers Right to Hit Ball Poorly
description: Nearly two weeks ago, I wrote an article about the Polara golf ball, a newly redesigned ball that is said to correct slices and hooks off the tee by as much as 75 percent. I tried to slice and hook the ball without much success. Then I went to a driving range, where I approached other golfers and told them I had a ball that wouldnt slice.

title: In Egypt, Police Officer Is Sentenced to Death
description: CAIRO  A Cairo court sentenced a rank-and-file police officer to death after trying him in absentia for the killings of unarmed protesters during the Egyptian revolution, the harshest sentence given to date as the military-led interim government grapples with calls for retribution against members of the former government.

title: One View of the News World
description: When Xinhua, the official government news agency of China, wanted to upgrade from its old office in Queens, it sought out a space that matched its ambitions. So it leased the top floor of a skyscraper in Midtown Manhattan, one with commanding views of the headquarters for Thomson Reuters, the News Corporation, The New York Times and other leading news organizations that have offices nearby.

title: Small Ball Produces Big Inning for Yankees
description: Yankees catcher Francisco Cervelli took a big assignment with him to the batters box in the bottom of the seventh inning Sunday with his team trailing by two runs: drop a bunt that could move two base runners closer to home. The next thing Cervelli knew, Mike Pelfreys 100th pitch was headed straight for his face.

title: The Strauss-Kahn Case: What the Housekeeper Told Police

title: Pawlenty Announces Candidacy a Day Early

title: Nathaniel Davis, Diplomat, Is Dead at 86
description: Nathaniel Davis, a seasoned diplomat who shepherded American interests through upheavals like the Chilean coup of 1973 and the breakout of civil war in Angola in 1975, died on May 16 in Claremont, Calif. He was 86.

description: DEPENDING on traffic, its usually no more than a one-hour car ride from the Sofitel Hotel in Midtown Manhattan to Rikers Island, each of which Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former chief of the International Monetary Fund, checked into for a time last week. But the accommodations provided are worlds apart.

title: Free Speech on Twitter Faces Test

title: Sealift Extends Lifeline to a Rebel City in Libya

title: Police Seek New Ways to Defuse Tension
description: LOS ANGELES  When the police arrived, she was barricaded inside her apartment with her former girlfriend, threatening suicide, a gun in her hand.

description: In drawing new legislative districts for state lawmakers last week, Democrats in Springfield said they abided by voting-rights laws and citizens concerns.

title: When a Bad Golf Course Edges Into Goodness
description: There is no such thing as a really terrible golf course. If youre playing golf on it, how awful can it be? But if some courses are indisputably better than others, then inevitably, some are worse. Quite a bit worse, in my experience. So bad that theyre worth a detour  if only because they make you grateful for the other better kind.

title: Seeking to Disrupt Protesters, Syria Cracks Down on Social Media
description: The Syrian government is cracking down on protesters use of social media and the Internet to promote their rebellion just three months after allowing citizens to have open access to Facebook and YouTube, according to Syrian activists and digital privacy experts.

title: Who Will Play Strauss-Kahn?

title: Tired, Testy, Even Rumpled: French Reporters on the Big Story
description: Theyre weary and disheveled, overworked, underrested and above all cranky  some say they havent had a drop of red wine for days.

description: Hundreds of thousands of high school girls put on cheerleading uniforms each year and thousands more continue on to college, taking their place in a thriving American tradition that has been around for nearly as long as football.

title: When the Internet Thinks It Knows You
description: ONCE upon a time, the story goes, we lived in a broadcast society. In that dusty pre-Internet age, the tools for sharing information werent widely available. If you wanted to share your thoughts with the masses, you had to own a printing press or a chunk of the airwaves, or have access to someone who did. Controlling the flow of information was an elite class of editors, producers and media moguls who decided what people would see and hear about the world. They were the Gatekeepers.

title: Suit Claims Cisco Helped China Pursue Falun Gong

title: Breaking Faith
description: I will not vote to deny a vote to a Democratic presidents judicial nominee just because the nominee may have views more liberal than mine.

Before the fighting was over, the attackers had killed at least 10 Pakistani security officers in a gun battle that lasted for hours and raised new questions about the competence of the countrys armed forces.

Mr. Obama called his proposal the best chance Israel has to avoid growing isolation amid rising political upheaval near its borders.

Its release coincides with that of Heavy Rocks (not to be confused with the 2002 album of the same name) and two Japanese-only titles: another collaboration with noise master Merzbow called Klatter, as well as New Album, which frustratingly mixes tracks from Attention Please and the new Heavy Rocks with other material.

title: Ballerinas, Meet Bally-Rina
description: Who better to judge Ballys new Bally-Rina collection than the real ballerinas of the New York City Ballet? The differences between the Swiss luxury-houses flats and your run-of-the-mill ballet ones are vast according to the companys senior corps de ballet dancers, Gretchen Smith and Marika Anderson. The women work in nude leather Bloch dance shoes both in the classroom and throughout rehearsals. And when theyre not dancing they still prefer to slip into flats. Im really picky when it comes to flats because I wear them to the bone, says Anderson, who previously wore Cole Haan because of the Nike-Air instep. We really like the Bally-Rinas in blue, says Smith pointing out the shoes ultra low vamp. Smith also likes that the sole of the shoe is comfortable and how the inside looks like an actual pointe shoe. This summer, the company heads for a slew of performances in Saratoga and both women see themselves wearing Bally-Rina flats, Smith with a flowy high-waisted skirt; Anderson with fitted jeans and a T-shirt. Theyll pair them with matching Bally-Rina bags stuffed with the tools of the trade: several pairs of pointe shoes, flat shoes, tape, scissors, glue, needles and thread, water and vitamin B. The cute but functional special Bally-Rina collection comes in shades of navy, grass green and yellow  that should be more than enough to keep more than New York City ballerinas dancing.

title: Where Should New York City Opera Go?

The organization did indicate some parameters: three of the operas will be suitable for a larger house, and two for smaller spaces. Already, reader e-mail to The New York Times has raised the Brooklyn Academy of Music as a fine potential home. What do you think of the decision to leave Lincoln Center? Where should City Opera go?

title: Pawlenty Officially Declares Candidacy for President
description: DES MOINES  Former Gov. Tim Pawlenty of Minnesota formally opened his bid for the Republican presidential nomination on Monday with a sharp critique of President Obamas policies, leadership and character, presenting himself as a candidate who could unify his fractious party and win back the White House.

title: Who Writes Your Thank-You Notes?
description: Who writes the thank-you notes in your family?

title: Gold is Not an Investment
description: Carl Richards is a certified financial planner in Park City, Utah. His sketches are archived here on the Bucks blog and on his personal Web site, BehaviorGap.com.

title: Real Estate as Backdrop for the Latest Reality TV
description: The party, in a triplex loft floating high above the East River, was just getting started a little after 6 p.m. on Wednesday. The models, leggy young women dressed in Nina Ricci, Proenza Schouler and Calvin Klein, had started to circulate as waiters came through with trays of canaps like smoked salmon topped with glistening orange roe. A jazz quartet kept up a steady rhythm from under the stairs as guests milled about, exclaiming over the panoramic views through four enormous, synchronized glass clocks set in the tower walls.

title: At the CN Tower in Toronto, Leaning Over a 116-Story Deck
description: A landmark of the Toronto skyline is providing travelers with a dose of extreme adventure starting this summer. The CN Tower is home to a new attraction called EdgeWalk, which will allow visitors to walk around the observation deck, 1,168 feet, or 116 stories, above ground. Guided groups of six to eight walkers (who must be 13 or older) will be attached by harness to an overhead safety rail that encircles the deck, absent of any hand rails.

title: Fox News Executives Dispute Quote About Palin
description: Fox News Channel executives are disputing a quotation made by an unnamed Republican in the latest issue of New York magazine saying that the networks chairman, Roger Ailes, thinks former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska is an idiot.

title: Childbirth: Home Births Are Uncommon but on the Rise
description: The number of home births nationwide rose 20 percent from 2004 through 2008, a new study shows.

title: Accounts and People of Note in the Ad Industry
description: Robert Ames joined the New York office of Here Media as chief performance officer, a post created in the reorganization of the sales and marketing department. He had most recently been chief performance officer at the Jumpstart Automotive Group, New York, part of Hachette Filipacchi Media U.S., which is a unit of the Lagardre Active division of Lagardre.

title: Commemorative Indy 500 Stamp Available at Post Offices

title: Kucinich, Losing District, Looks Very Far Afield
description: SEATTLE  Representative Dennis J. Kucinich, the liberal Democrat from Cleveland, was a long way from home  2,000 miles give or take. But he found plenty of political admirers in this stronghold of progressive political thought.

title: The Morning Line: Its All How You Look at It
description: In the aftermath of the Preakness, there are basically two types of Triple Crown stories. They correspond to the glass half empty or the glass half full view of the Triple Crown. The story lines are: (1) What do we do now without a Triple Crown winner for another year and (2) maybe we can have a rivalry between the Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdom and the Preakness winner Shackleford that will be settled in the Belmont Stakes.

title: Justices, 5-4, Tell California to Cut Prisoner Population
description: WASHINGTON  Conditions in Californias overcrowded prisons are so bad that they violate the Eighth Amendments ban on cruel and unusual punishment, the Supreme Court ruled on Monday, ordering the state to reduce its prison population by more than 30,000 inmates.

title: Where Dissidents Are the Prey, and Horror Is a Weapon
description: An authoritarian government willing to use the most brutal means to hold on to power; a dictator whose thugs have murdered, tortured, imprisoned or intimidated tens of thousands of civilians; and individuals who have risked their lives simply to exercise their most fundamental rights  this is the state of affairs not only in Libya today, but also in Zimbabwe, which has suffered the ravages of more than 30 years under the autocratic rule of President Robert Mugabe.

title: Just One Look | Oscar de la Renta Resort
description: Oscar de la Renta is no stranger to Spain, which is exactly where he went with the Resort collection he showed last week. The clothes were at their most Modern (with a capital M), when the designer sidestepped ruffles and other Flamenco finery in favor of graphic cubist motifs inspired by the work of Picasso and Gris.

title: How Much Do Your Children Sleep?
description: In this weeks Personal Health column, Jane Brody writes about the sleep needs of children and teenagers, finding that many young people are not getting nearly enough sleep.

title: Four Ways to Make Your Battery Last Longer
description: A good friend of mine had been complaining that her iPhone 3GS battery was holding less and less of a charge. When we got together at 5 p.m. one recent day, it was at 5 percent full  and it had been fully charged that morning. She had barely used it all day. The phone was apparently running itself dry simply by being turned on.

title: Ghost Stories

His first museum show, at theNew Museum on the Bowery, opened on May 20.Weerasethakul is known for making superslow movies, usually set in the Thai countryside, that blend Thai folk tales and contemporary life (with an occasional reference to Godard).

title: Exhumation of Allende of Chile Aims to Settle Mystery
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Isabel Allende long ago accepted that her father, former President Salvador Allende, took his own life with an assault rifle just minutes before troops stormed the presidential palace in a coup on Sept. 11, 1973.

description: BRUSSELS  Five days after the United States imposed sanctions on Syrias president, Bashar al-Assad, the European Union followed suit on Monday, overcoming internal divisions on whether to single out the Syrian leader over the bloody crackdown against protesters in his country.

description: MEXICO CITY  After President Jacobo Arbenz was overthrown in a C.I.A.-backed coup in 1954, the Guatemalan government reversed his policies and branded him a Communist, all but erasing his brief presidency from history.

description: A new report shows that home births, while still uncommon, have risen dramatically in recent years. The number of home births  nationwide rose to 28,357 in 2008, up 20 percent from 2004.

description: Ive been thinking a lot lately about how best to use quinoa, in part because of some misguided dishes Ive recently had in restaurants.

title: Showtime Cancels United States of Tara and Renews Nurse Jackie
description: With one fell swoop, Showtime has eliminated several female personalities from its lineup of original programming. On Monday it announced the cancellation of The United States of Tara, the comedy-drama starring Toni Collette as a housewife with dissociative identity disorder (commonly known as multiple personality disorder); the current season will be its last. Tara, which made its debut in 2009, came with an impressive pedigree, which included its creator, Diablo Cody, the Academy Award-winning screenwriter of Juno, and the executive producer Steven Spielberg. And Ms. Collette was widely praised for her performance in the title role, winning an Emmy Award in 2009 and a Golden Globe in 2010. But ratings for the series have diminished, from 816,000 viewers for the premiere of Season 2 to 411,000 viewers for the debut of Season 3 in March, The Hollywood Reporter reported. By comparison, the season finale of Showtimes historical drama The Borgias was watched by 810,000 viewers at 10 p.m. on Sunday, the network said.

title: Brooklyn Concert Series Finds New Home in Coney Island
description: A free concert series in Brooklyn promoted by Marty Markowitz, the borough president, will move to a new performance space in Coney Island after a dispute with neighbors around the park where the concerts took place for 20 summers.

title: Electronic Voting Comes to The Oscars (Finally)

On Thursday, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, which presents the Oscars, sent a letter advising its 6,000 or so voting members that an electronic system for Oscar voting will be implemented as early as this year, and will certainly be in effect by next year.

Around him were trees, their high canopies muting the light from the tropical sun, the occasional woody vine, or liana, climbing up their thick trunks.

title: By the Billions: Creating and Comparing Population Growth Projections
description: Overview | How fast are populations growing around the world? How can governments, institutions and individuals use that knowledge to appropriately plan for the future? In this lesson, students create population profiles of countries and use simple mathematical tools to create population projections that can be compared and analyzed. They also delve into related questions about resources and supplies with respect to projected population growth.

description: CBSs latest installment of its Jesse Stone series of made-for-TV movies featuring Tom Selleck attracted the largest audience in prime time on Sunday. According to Nielsens estimates, 13.7 million viewers tuned in to Jesse Stone: Innocents Lost from 9 to 11 p.m., outperforming NBCs finale of The Celebrity Apprentice in the same time period, which drew a modest 8.4 million viewers.

title: The Culturialist | Robert Irwins Garden Path
description: At this time of year the Central Garden at the Getty Center in Los Angeles is particularly sublime. The unorthodox collection of more than 500 plants, shrubs and trees was brought together and landscaped by the artist Robert Irwin. London plane trees line a path that traverses a stream and descends into a plaza where purple bougainvillea draped over specially constructed metal arbors form a shaded canopy. And the lower bowl is a riot of herbs, vegetables and other plants in constant rotation. Work on the garden started many years before the museum opened in 1997. And despite the fact that, in garden years, 15 is relatively young, it feels very sure of itself.

title: When Doctors Are Called to the Rescue in Midflight
description: Dr. Matthew Rhoa is still haunted by one of his lowest moments as a physician. Several years ago, on the first leg of an international flight, he was just settling in for a nap when a flight attendant came on the public address system to ask, Is there a doctor on the plane?

title: The Youngest Casualties of Cancer
description: For all the advances that have been made against childhood cancer, it remains the leading cause of disease-related death among children younger than 15, with 1,500 fatalities a year. And while the five-year survival rate has improved in recent decades  to 80 percent, up from less than half 40 years ago  the number of cases is rising, too; it now stands at 10,000, up from 8,000 in 1975.

title: Fish Tales
description: Frank Crescitelli, chairman of the Fishermens Conservation Association, is a garrulous Staten Islander with a booming voice and a sure hand on the wheel of his enormous fishing boat, which on Friday was bobbing peacefully on an ebb tide off the Breezy Point jetty, Midtown Manhattan rising in front of him in the mist. It was late morning, a few rainy hours into the Manhattan Cup, a catch-and-release fishing tournament that has been an annual competition in New York Harbor since at least 1999.

title: Heeding an Oil-Spill Lesson, 2 Agencies Team Up
description: One of the lessons painfully learned from the Deepwater Horizon blowout and spill was that the federal officials responsible for regulating offshore drilling lacked adequate input from government agencies with expertise in shorelines, ocean science and toxic spills. One of the key recommendations of the presidential commission that studied the disaster was that federal agencies talk to each other about potential environmental hazards before granting permits to drill offshore.

title: Numberplay: Tinkering with Ladders
description: Last weeks Numberplay puzzle, presented by Gary Antonick and suggested and masterfully moderated by Joshua Zucker, had all the hallmarks of a classic. This puzzle, known as the Ducci game or 4-number game, is easy to state and understand, uses a procedure a child can carry out, and yet it unlocks the door to fabulous mathematical riches. For those who missed it I would urge you to go back and take a look at it. Here is a brief restatement, given a slightly different visual model from last week. Given any four arbitrary positive integers a, b, c and d, representing the top rung of a ladder, you construct another step below it, consisting of the positive differences between them taken cyclically: |a-b|, |b-c|, |c-d| and |d-a|. An example 2-step ladder is:1 2 5 91 3 4 8It turns out that all such ladders eventually end as all the numbers become zeroes. One challenge was to find what initial numbers gave rise to the longest ladders, and it turned out that the champion quartets had a fascinating mathematical property.

title: 2 Studies in Conflict on Growth of Bone
description: Three years ago, researchers at Columbia came to an astonishing conclusion. The amount of bone people make  and their risk of osteoporosis  seems to depend on levels of serotonin, a chemical known mainly for its effects on the brain.

description: The Austrian violinist Thomas Zehetmair has always been a deeply thoughtful player, and if he was sometimes an erratic interpreter in his early days, his highly personalized readings now sound philosophical rather than wayward.

title: A Fairy Tale, Updated Without Ambien
description: PRINCETON, N.J.  Chronic insomniacs may well view the heroine of Sleeping Beauty Wakes, a new musical at the McCarter Theater Center here, with a ravenous envy. Shes been dozing peacefully for almost a millennium, without so much as a milligram of pharmaceutical assistance. As in the original fairy tale, tweaked in this modern update, when she emerges from that long slumber she finds herself staring into the eyes of a love-struck swain, not groping for coffee to dispel the dim haze of an Ambien hangover.

title: Barclays Capital Hires Former Fed Official
description: Brian F. Madigan, a former top official at the Federal Reserve who played a leading role in the emergency lending programs during the financial crisis, has joined Barclays Capital as a senior policy adviser.

title: Notes from the Underground | Gal Rakotondrabe
description: Best known as the pianist for the sister act CocoRosie, Gal Rakotondrabe is also a renowned musician in his own right. And deservedly so. Rakondtrabe and Yasmine Hamdan performed recently at an intimate, invitational salon at the Brooklyn loft of Bianca Casady (one half of CocoRosie), in an evening entitled So Long Sorrow. Hamdan, dressed in strategically ripped acid wash jeans, and yellow wedge espadrilles, sang powerfully in Arabic, accompanied by Rakotondrabes remarkable keystrokes. The lights of the Manhattan skyline illuminated them from behind as Sierra Casady crouched on the floor beside the stage area, nodding her head in unison with the performers.

What fascinates me, and I suspect other viewers, is the vicarious experience of watching the crews working for long stretches in unimaginable conditions.

Our DVD Elmos Travel Songs and Games was inspired by our trips to several American cities, including some good will trips to New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina and Greensburg, Kan., after the tornado, as well as some overseas trips to Australia, Ireland, South Africa and China.

title: Revisiting Notes From a Roommate Search Begun on 9/10/01

title: A Season Brings New Faces and Insights to Classic Roles
description: If there were a Harry Potter ballet, youd cast Janie Taylor as Luna Lovegood, that most ethereal of young wizards. Pale with a cascade of blond hair reaching her waist, she seems naturally to be in communion with other worlds. Though she well may be the weakest technician among New York City Ballets female principals, she brings spiritual intensity to everything she does. On Friday night she made her debut as the Sleepwalker, the title role in La Sonnambula, George Balanchines ballet. The luminous, eerie, compulsive quality she brought to the role refreshed the whole drama.

title: Union Effort Turns Its Focus to Target
description: In the world of big-box discounters, Target enjoys a reputation as a model corporate citizen that sells the latest in cheap chic. title: Prison Ruling Raises Stakes in California Fiscal Crisis

But during those same hostilities, Israeli officials say, they scored a military success they are eager for the world to see: the countrys Iron Dome antirocket missile defense system for the first time intercepted  in seconds  short-range rockets fired from Gaza, according to the officials.

title: Joseph Brooks, a Maker of Jingles, Songs and Films, Dies at 73

title: Edward H. Harte, Texas Newspaper Executive, Dies at 88
description: Edward H. Harte, a prominent Texas newspaper executive and an ardent conservationist who played an important role in preserving vast tracts of open space and stretches of seashore in his state, died on May 18 at a retirement home in Scarborough, Me. He was 88 and also lived in Corpus Christi, Tex.

title: Saudis Arrest Woman Leading Right-to-Drive Campaign
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  The government of Saudi Arabia moved swiftly to extinguish a budding protest movement of women claiming the right to drive, a campaign inspired by uprisings across the Arab world demanding new freedoms but at risk Monday of foundering.

title: Russia: Harsh Words for Georgia
description: The Foreign Ministry rebuked authorities in Georgia on Monday for violating their citizens rights to the freedom of assembly and expression of opinions because the police dispersed an opposition protest over the weekend. The statement left out any comparison to Russias own treatment of opposition protesters, who are routinely arrested, but did note the police action in Georgia could be interpreted as violating a European human rights convention.

title: Whats Up With the Jews?
description: Its been an interesting week or two for Jews. Mel Gibsons new film, The Beaver, opens nationwide in theaters and Jews must decide whether to pay good money to see a movie starring someone whose father is a Holocaust denier, and who has himself vilified Jews in public. In Cannes, the Danish movie director Lars von Trier rambles on at a press conference about sympathizing with Hitler, being annoyed with Israel and admiring Hitlers architect, Albert Speer. Next day he recants, but its too late; hes declared persona non grata at the film festival.

title: Home for the N.F.L. Lockout

title: In Food Deserts, Oases of Nutrition
description: Poor urban neighborhoods in America are often food deserts  places where it is difficult to find fresh food. There are few grocery stores; people may do all their shopping at bodegas, where the only available produce and meat are canned peaches and Spam. If they want fruits and vegetables and chicken and fish, they have to take a bus to a grocery store. The lack of fresh food creates a vicious cycle; children grow up never seeing it or acquiring a taste for it.It is one reason that the poor are likelier to be obese than the rich.

title: A Slice of Afghanistan Well Secured by Afghans
description: SHINKAY, Afghanistan  Zabul Province, one of Afghanistans poorest, is mainly known for being a transit route for Taliban insurgents and NATO supply convoys.

title: Visions of the Past Propel a Man Forward
description: NEWARK  Bernadine Smith raised eight children here, five boys and three girls, 13 years separating the oldest from the youngest. Her boys were inseparable, and she tried to keep them together, keep them home, with board games and cooking lessons and movie nights. If I could have kept my kids in a bubble, she said, I would have.

title: Russian Justice
description: By the time you read this column, you may already know the fate of Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky and Platon L. Lebedev. Moscow, after all, is eight hours ahead of New York, and lets be honest here: Its not going to take the Moscow City Court very long to conclude that the two men deserve another seven years in prison  on top of the eight theyve already served  on laughably trumped-up charges. Chances are, the three-judge panel knew going in how it planned to rule. Thats the way it works in Russia when somebody crosses the countrys ruling plutocrats. They get sent to Siberia on phony charges.

Born in Paris to Iranian exiles, she studied at the prestigious cole Normale Suprieure before teaching literary seminars at Harvard. Now she lives in New York and is something of a fixture at book parties and publishing events. (She was just on the cover of Thursday Styles, giving Jon-Jon Goulian, another of the seasons publishing darlings, a protracted peck.) She speaks six languages, sings opera and is quite beautiful, although even her sultry glamour is tempered a bit by a childlike innocence.

title: Everybody Plays
description: By the way, Daniel Klein conducted an experiment for a George Mason University working paper that illustrates our hunger for cooperation. He asked groups of people in a room to sing a song together. But one person in the room was instructed not to sing unless the other people paid him some money. The question was: Do people desire complete group cohesion so much they are willing to pay to avoid having an outlier/dissident in their group. The groups decided to pay money to achieve what Klein calls encompassment 47.4 percent of the time.
