description: A 46-year-old man who swung a pit-bull puppy by its leash against an elevator wall and also kicked the animal was charged with aggravated animal cruelty on Monday, the police said.

title: C.E.O. of the U.S.A.
description: The job of the president is technically that of the chief executive of the United States. But Im still fascinated by the extent to which business acumen is being emphasized by the early presidential contenders.

title: Explaining War to Our Children
description: Explaining war to kids is always hard, but when youre part of a military family, the task is even more difficult because its so personal. When my sons were little, their father was in the Navy Reserve as an intelligence officer with the Seabees, the Navys construction division. The boys understood what the military was in a very hazy It must involve a ship, Daddy going away, and a large yellow bee kind of way. But because their father wasnt directly in harms way, I was able to gloss over hard questions about war and just concentrate on the fun parts of having a dad in the military from a toddlers perspective  serving the country and wearing really cool hats.

title: Critics Picks Video: Withnail and I
description: This week, A. O. Scott looks back at Bruce Robinsons 1987 British comedy Withnail and I. The film revolves around the relationship between its two central characters (Richard E. Grant and Paul McGann), two out of work actors who spend most of their time drinking, fighting and getting very little accomplished. Mr. Scott calls the movie charming, hilarious and ultimately heartbreaking. Have you seen Withnail and I? Please share your thoughts in the comments area below.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: Michelle Obama Meets the New Duchess
description: From the sidelines, London fashion writers pondered whether the first lady, Michelle Obama, would favor a British designer during her and President Obamas state visit. Meanwhile, an Irish journalist observed that all the stylists in the world couldnt save the incredibly chic Michelle Obama from a battle of a bad hair day in windy Dublin, where Mrs. Obama wore a dotted Marc Jacobs dress and a lightweight coat. Even the length of her eyelashes was closely observed.

title: Chiengora
description: Yarn weaved from dog hair.  (Chien [Dog] + Angora.)

title: A 'Spiritual Connection' With Lady Day
description: A Harlem singer who takes the name Billie Holiday Jr. tries to summon the spirit of Lady Day in the hope of being "the child she always dreamed of."

title: Survey Hints at a Census Undercount in New York City
description: We demand a recount, declared Assemblyman Rory I. Lancman, a Democrat from Queens.

title: As Bank Woes Ease, the F.D.I.C.s Fund Is Building Up
description: 7:23 p.m. | Updated

title: Gold Getter
description: I am not quite sure what to make of this magazine cover. On one hand, it is gold on the cover of a mainstream magazine. But its less convincing as a magazine-cover contrary indicator. Compare it to the housing-peak covers in Fortune (May 2005) or Time (June 2005). The focus here is not on the investment aspect, but rather is a profile on a gold surveyor and on gold as the worlds most primitive form of wealth. Hardly the gushing endorsements we typically like to see as contrary indicators.

title: Egypt Is Moving to Try Mubarak in Fatal Protests
description: CAIRO  Former President Hosni Mubarak will be put on trial for conspiring to kill unarmed protesters, Egypts top prosecutor announced Tuesday, yielding to public demands for accountability and setting an example that could rattle autocrats around the region.

title: Top Down
description: David Leonhardts presentation of the Pew data on religious affiliation and income in the United States (Is Your Religion Your Financial Destiny?) neglects the way that religious groups are distributed geographically. The groups with the highest average household incomes tend disproportionately to live where costs of living and therefore salaries are highest.

title: The Big Thaw
description: As the first-generation daughter of an Icelandic immigrant to the United States, I was never able to tap into the psyche of my fathers native land until I read Jake Halperns article. The dry humor, honesty and independent spirit of the Icelanders, born from living on a rock in the middle of the north seas, were captured brilliantly. Halpern helped me understand what seemed like cavalier financial behavior and heal my embarrassment over their decisions. Thank you for helping me understand my people.

title: Riff
description: Its a clever line by Sam Anderson  if novels are mirrors held up to nature, memoirs are mirrors held up to mirrors. But most fiction actually takes the form either of biography (third-person narrative) or autobiography (first person). The relationship between these sibling genres has been complicated and competitive for at least 200 years.

title: Talk
description: In Andrew Goldmans interview of Larry Summers, my colleague Joseph Stiglitz is cited for saying Summers ignores arguments that he doesnt like. I have disagreed with Summers on several issues, but I have always found him ready to debate my views, even at Columbia, when, on the celebration of my 75th birthday, he took on me, Paul Krugman and others. He shies away from shoddy arguments that are simply populist, not from debating serious differences with critics his own size. By contrast, I have never succeeded in getting a debate, on or off campus, between Stiglitz and myself.

title: Yandex Shares Soar 55% in Market Debut
description: 4:17 p.m. | Updated

title: British Banks Paid Bonuses Using Government Aid
description: LONDON  Some bonuses to British bankers were partly paid using government aid supplied to the beleaguered industry, John Vickers, chairman of a government-backed banking commission, said on Tuesday.

title: Tony-Nominated Plays Reap Box-Office Benefits, and Spider-Man Returns With a Bang
description: Do Tony Award nominees for best play sell unusually well during the weeks between the nominations (this year, May 3) and the awards ceremony (June 12)? Not always. This time last year, for instance, two of the four best-play nominees (In the Next Room, or the Vibrator Play and Time Stands Still) had already closed, while Next Fall earned $150,982 and Red earned $463,639 for performances between May 17-23.

title: Candidates in Western New York House Race Make Final Push
description: Voters in western New York States 26th Congressional district went to the polls on Tuesday in the full glare of the national political spotlight, while the leading candidates crisscrossed the Buffalo area making final appeals to voters.

title: Company Believes 3 Reactors Melted Down in Japan
description: TOKYO  In a belated acknowledgment of the severity of Japans nuclear disaster, the Tokyo Electric Power Company said Tuesday that three of the stricken Fukushima Daiichi plants reactors most likely suffered fuel meltdowns in the early days of the crisis.

title: Watchlist: A Self-Conscious Web Experiment From CBS News
description: The live Web show Whats Trending at cbsnews.com, an attempt to build a news-and-chat program driven by social networking  sort of a digital Today  is a self-consciously experimental project. That self-consciousness registers throughout the half-hour show; it rang through clearly in the premiere episode last Tuesday, when the host, the blogger and online reporter Shira Lazar, announced: We are all about the trending topics and stories the world is sharing. Its what you need to know to be in the now.

title: Decision on New Jersey Schools Abbott Financing
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruling ordered that financing to Abbott districts must be made. Issued May 5, 2011.

title: Wheelies: The Volunteer State Edition
description: In which we bring you motoring news from around the Web:

title: Fighting Intensifies in Yemen as the Government Battles Tribal Groups
description: WASHINGTON  Hopes for a peaceful settlement of Yemens political crisis receded further on Tuesday as street battles intensified between government security forces and opposition tribesmen, leaving at least two dozen people dead and turning part of the Yemeni capital, Sana, into a war zone.

title: Saudi Womans Driving Video Preserved Online
description: As my colleague Neil MacFarquhar reports from Saudi Arabia, the Saudi government has moved swiftly to extinguish a budding protest movement of women claiming the right to drive, in recent days.

title: Court Orders New Jersey to Increase Aid to Schools
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday that a major piece of Gov. Chris Christies cost-cutting was unconstitutional and ordered lawmakers to raise spending for poor, urban schools by $500 million next year, despite a state budget shortfall estimated at $10 billion.

title: New Scrutiny for S.E.C. and Trades at SAC Capital
description: 6:40 p.m. | Updated

title: Gym Class: Samurai Sword Fighting
description: Want to be a samurai? You can get a taste of what its like to be a warrior, as well as the toned arms that go with it, by attending a Forza class.

title: A Murderous Malkovich in Lineup for BAMs 2011 Next Wave Festival
description: John Malkovichs latest turn as a psychopath, new productions of The Threepenny Opera and Krapps Last Tape, a stage adaptation of Ingmar Bergmans Cries and Whispers and the last planned appearance by the Merce Cunningham Dance Company at the Brooklyn Academy of Music are among the eclectic events planned for BAMs 2011 Next Wave Festival, organizers announced on Tuesday. The series, during which BAM will begin a 16-month celebration of its 150th anniversary, starts on Sept. 21 with the New York premiere of Awakening: A Musical Meditation on the Anniversary of 9/11, a work that will be performed by the Kronos Quartet, featuring the Brooklyn Youth Chorus.

title: Hawk Cam | Pip Goes for a Walk
description: Updated, 4:59 p.m. |  Pip the hawk hatchling reached another milestone this morning: Sometime shortly before 10 a.m., the little one hopped out of the nest  and out of the frame of the Hawk Cam. Suddenly the camera just showed Violets lower body and the two inert leftover eggs in the nest.

title: Stuff We Like That Maybe You Wont
description: This list of recommendations was generated with a twist. Staff members were asked to identify things that differentiated their taste from that of their friends and colleagues: What do we like that others in our lives either dont like or dont know about? What is idiosyncratically ours? Some, youll see, took this occasion to reveal their particular guilty pleasures. Others showed us a side of themselves we didnt know existed  is there really among us someone who enjoys Alf? And who watches shark videos? While we figure out what to do with these outliers, read the list and please add your own off-kilter picks in the comments.

title: A Block in Brooklyn: Exodus or Undercount?
description: Census undercounts a Brooklyn block.

title: Netanyahu Gives No Ground in Congress Speech
description: WASHINGTON  Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel, broadly laying out the Israeli response to President Obamas peace proposals, called on the Palestinian Authority president, Mahmoud Abbas, on Tuesday to accept what Mr. Netanyahu framed as a tenet: that Palestinians will not get a right of return to Israel. In so doing, he made clear that he was giving no ground on the major stumbling blocks to a peace agreement.

title: Fill-In | Alligators Everywhere
French Connection | HI Matic
description: Social media, eco-lodging and a D.I.Y. ethic intersect at HI Matic, a new B&B-hostel hybrid in the hip Paris neighborhood of EsBas (East Bastille). The hotel takes a plugged-in approach to hospitality, eschewing full-service concierge and staff for a digitally customizable experience. Not only can guests tailor nearly every detail of their stay on touch-screens throughout the building, but they can also share information with the room next door  or, if they want, with all 42 rooms at once. The organic breakfast is served through futuristic vending machines, which also offer books, aromatherapy diffusers and other goodies. Each visitor receives a personalized list of exhibitions and shows recommended by local experts, and two electronic music stations  one mellow, one groovier  are available on every floor, courtesy of the German record label Kompakt. Matali Crasset, a Philippe Starck protge who has opened three other hotels with the HI group (two in Nice and one in Nefta, Tunisia), created Ryokan-inspired rooms with modular furniture and floor mattresses. She chose the area for its authenticity and charm. There are lots of bars and its fun, but the neighborhood is not touristy, she says. It has kept its local flavor, with mom-and-pop shops and cafs. Among her favorite spots is Septime (80 rue de Charonne), a new foodie hotspot directly across the street from the hotel where the star chef Bertrand Grbaut concocts simple but sophisticated dishes that le tout Paris is raving about.

title: Q&A: Hiking and Dining on Oahu
description: Q.

title: No. 1 Nadal, Stretched to Five Sets by Isner, Bends but Never Buckles
description: PARIS  Rafael Nadal has made a habit of making victory look easy at Roland Garros. He arrived this time as a five-time champion with a 38-1 record. And in all those wins since 2005, the Spaniard with the steely nerve and bending shots never needed a fifth and final set.

title: China Admits Its Technicians Were Held in Pakistan Base Attack
description: BEIJING  A day after denying that any of its citizens had been involved, China confirmed Tuesday that Chinese technicians were taken hostage during a militant attack on a Pakistani naval base.

title: Music Executive Giving $5 Million to N.Y.U. to Expand Music Business Program
description: The music executive Clive Davis is giving an additional $5 million gift to the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University, allowing the expansion of the Clive Davis Department of Recorded Music into the Clive Davis Institute of Recorded Music, school officials announced Tuesday. The gift will make it possible for the school to recruit additional working professionals as faculty members, establish a generous scholarship fund, facilitate the recruitment of young talent from around the world and increase the number of students, university officials said in a statement. Two new programs will be created to bring in talented high school students. Future Music Moguls will be a free program for students in the New York City area, and the Summer High School Programs in Recorded Music will be open to students everywhere.

title: Calculating the Potential Return on Your Major
description: As the cost of college climbs ever higher each year, amid a national economic forecast that remains cloudy, questions about the value of a four-year degree are being raised with increased urgency.

title: Chinas Utilities Cut Energy Production, Defying Beijing
description: YIYANG, China  It is a power struggle that is causing a power shortage  one that has begun to slow Chinas mighty economic growth engine.

title: Sensational or Just Bad? On 2010 Pavie, Two Critics Disagree
description: One wine. One vintage. Two critics. Two reviews that couldnt possibly be more different.

title: At MoMA, Volkswagen Formula XL1 Makes U.S. Debut
description: Martin Winterkorn, the Volkswagen Group chief executive, showed off the latest XL1 Formula prototype, as well as the actress Lucy Liu, on Monday night in Manhattan. Volkswagen claims that the 1.0-liter diesel hybrid can achieve 261 m.p.g.

title: Nowitzkis Grand Stand
description: For a Western Conference finals without the melodrama-a-minute Lakers and formerly age-defying Spurs, the Thunder and the Mavericks are filling in the dramatic narrative nicely. It was hard to ask for much more than Dallas erasing a 15-point deficit in the final five minutes in Monday nights latest N.B.A. epic overtime victory. Yes, this is roughly the same cast of Dallas characters that made an art form of face-planting in the playoffs over the years and yes, the hero was the same Dirk Nowitzki who habitually seems to shrink about half a foot this time of year.

title: Pink Pork Safe to Eat, Government Says
description: Pink is back. Reversing the food safety dictates of decades, the United States Department of Agriculture has announced it is no longer necessary to cook meat (except ground meat) to an internal temperature of 160 degrees. The new magic number for pork chops and other cuts is a much juicier 145 degrees, plus a three minute resting time. This allows the internal temperature to rise slightly, but also has the culinary benefit of thickening the juices so they dont run out when the meat is cut.

title: Subpoena Issued to Writer in C.I.A.-Iran Leak Case
description: WASHINGTON  With the approval of Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr., federal prosecutors are trying to force the author of a book on the C.I.A. to testify at a criminal trial about who leaked information to him about the agencys effort to sabotage the Iranian nuclear program at the end of the Clinton administration.

title: Finding the Nerve to Take an Advertising Risk
description: One of the hardest things to do in business is to take a risk with your advertising. Ive made ad campaign presentations to fiercely competitive, Type A owners and heres what happens:

title: Cuomo Backs Assembly Plan to Cap Property Taxes
description: ALBANY  The odds of a mandatory ceiling on property-tax increases improved significantly after the Assembly unveiled legislation Tuesday morning that was endorsed in short order by Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.

title: Medicare Is on Voters Minds in Congressional Election
description: The special election in western New York States 26th Congressional District has focused on Medicare for weeks now, and as voters emerged from polling places on Tuesday, it remained the dominant topic of conversation.

title: Chandlers Gold Cup Absence Raises Concerns
description: No one has sought Timmy Chandlers long-form birth certificate (yet). Nrnbergs swift young defender, the son of an American serviceman and a German woman, has spent his entire life and professional soccer career in Germany. In March, he pulled on the jersey of the United States national team for matches against Argentina and Paraguay. He was nothing short of impressive, the apparent heir apparent to right back Steve Cherundolo.

title: What Would You Take With You in a Disaster?
Exit Daniels
description: The world may not have ended on Saturday, but for conservatives pinning their hopes for 2012 on a Mitch Daniels presidential campaign, the weekend felt a little bit like the opening of the sixth seal in the Book of Revelation. As with any apocalyptic development, commentary is a bit superfluous: 48 hours later, theres not much to say about Daniels family-driven bow-out except that its a big disappointment to anyone who cares about American conservatism, and that what I said about the 2012 campaign in this column still applies:

title: Subpoena of James Risen
description: Federal prosecutors are trying to force a New York Times reporter and author to testify at a criminal trial about who leaked information to him about a C.I.A. effort to sabotage the Iranian nuclear program at the end of the Clinton administration.

title: Chrysler Pays Back Rescue Loan
description: DETROIT  Chrysler paid back on Tuesday $7.6 billion in loans from the American and Canadian governments, paving the way for its Italian partner, Fiat, to increase its control over the Detroit carmaker.

title: New York City Ballet Announces 2011-12 Season
description: New York City Ballets spring season is in full swing but theres already much to anticipate in the months to come. The world premiere of Oceans Kingdom, a collaboration between Paul McCartney and Peter Martins, is among the highlights of the companys 2011-12 programming. The previously announced work, which will feature costumes by Stella McCartney, will be performed at the companys gala on Sept. 22.

title: Googles G Slate Tablet Has 3D Video
description: Except for screen size, the first tablets on the market pretty much look alike: glass-faced slabs without much to set them apart.

title: The Morning Line: Looking for a Rematch
description: There is a limited amount of Triple Crown news on Tuesday, and much of it involves the hoped-for matchup of the Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdom and the Preakness winner Shackleford.

title: Vocabulinks
description: An occasional assemblage of notable vocabulary and linguistic debate from around the Web.

title: Barnes & Noble Unveils Newest Nook
description: Barnes & Noble introduced its third e-reader in less than two years on Tuesday, a slimmer, lighter black-and-white touch-screen model that the retailer said would help propel its growth in the e-book market.

title: Oprah Calls and Reflects on 25 Years
description: Hi, its Oprah.

title: Wrestling to Make Education Council Polling Work
description: Every two years, the New York City Department of Education gears up for a great exercise in participatory democracy, giving hundreds of thousands of parents a chance to have a say in who will represent them on community education councils citywide.

title: Barnes & Noble Unveils Its Newest Nook
description: From our colleagues at Media Decoder, a look at Barnes & Nobles latest e-reader, the Nook  now with a touch-screen e-ink display.

title: Russian Court Upholds Convictions of Imprisoned Oil Executives
description: MOSCOW  Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, a former billionaire whose prosecution by the Russian government has come to symbolize the countrys legal failings, lost an appeal on Tuesday to overturn a second conviction.

title: Media Decoder: A New Nook
description: From our colleagues at Media Decoder, a look at Barnes & Nobles latest e-reader, the Nook  now with a touchscreen e-ink display.

title: Early Reports of Pilot Error in Air France Crash Are Condemned
description: The main pilots union at Air France and relatives of the 228 people who died in the Atlantic crash of Air France Flight 447 two years ago strongly condemned reports Tuesday suggesting that crucial errors by the jets crew might have led to the disaster.

title: Ex-Automotive Executives Start Incubator for Greentech Start-Ups
description: Three San Francisco entrepreneurs with backgrounds in automotive advertising want to help green technology ventures get off the ground.

title: As Wealth and Literacy Rise in India, Report Says, So Do Sex-Selective Abortions
description: NEW DELHI  Indias increasing wealth and improving literacy are apparently contributing to a national crisis of missing girls, with the number of sex-selective abortions up sharply among more affluent, educated families during the past two decades, according to a new study.

title: Share Your Oprah Memories
description: In 1986 Oprah Winfrey launched her local talk show into national syndication with an episode that aimed to teach viewers how to find the spouse of their dreams.

title: Sudan Official Resigns Post Over Assault at Border Town
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  A top Sudanese minister resigned in protest on Tuesday over the northern Sudanese military assault on the border town of Abyei, as worrisome signs emerged that the area was descending into chaos.

title: LOOK
description: Look

title: U.S. Suit Sees Manipulation of Oil Trades
description: After oil prices surged past $100 a barrel in 2008, suspicions that traders had manipulated the market led to Congressional hearings and regulatory investigations. But they produced no solid cases in the record run-up in gasoline prices.

title: Jack of All Trades | Organic by John Patrick
description: Ive been creating China ink paintings pretty steadily for the eight past years, says John Patrick, the designer of Organic by John Patrick. But they were done only as gifts, not as a way of making money. All of that changed when Alicia Lubowski-Jahn of Fair Folks & a Goat, the artsy specialty store, contacted Patrick to sign him up for an art show to promote sustainable and socially responsible designs. There were two problems. Lubowski-Jahn, who organized the show, Leaf // Cloud: Nature Tangible and Transcendent, loves color, but Patricks paintings are black and white. Also, Patrick, who is an environmentalist, did not previously use organic paint.

title: Dell Tries Again With a Thin Laptop
description: Dells mixed results selling consumer products has not stopped it from trying yet again.

title: Fiano Enjoys a Renaissance
description: FOR one of the more dramatic examples of how the world of wine has changed in the last 25 years, consider the white wines of Italy.

title: Off the Menu
description: HOSPODA  The dramatically decorated dining room, with soaring ceilings and backlighted images of beer, food and people engraved in dark wood, is the final element of a 10-year restoration of the historic Bohemian National Hall, owned by the Czech Republic. Oldrich Sahajdak, the executive chef, who also works at the parent companys restaurants in Prague and elsewhere, has overseen a menu of lightened dishes rooted in tradition, like butter-poached Prague ham with horseradish foam, and flatiron steak with dill sauce and barley dumplings. To the concise menu of beer snacks and smallish plates, a tasting menu will be added this summer. Marek Sada is chef de cuisine. The beer is Pilsner Urquell but is dispensed in four styles led by draught master Lukas Svoboda: 321 East 73rd Street, (212) 861-1038.

title: Avoiding Gluten? Theres a Whole Shop for You
description: Gluten-free products have come so far in the last few years that Lynn Shuter decided she could open a whole shop devoted to them. At G-Free NYC, she sells breads, granolas, cookies and cakes as well as more commonplace snacks that people who are gluten-intolerant can enjoy, like kale chips and popcorn. Fresh baked goods from a number of sources are set out on a display table, some offered for tasting. The shelves and freezers are filled with other foods, including biscotti, pastas and frozen pita breads and boxes of small pizza crusts. Many of the products are dairy-free and some are vegan.

title: Sixpoint Brews Are Now in Cans
description: After six years of brewing ales in more than 200 styles for bars and restaurants to sell on draught, Sixpoint Craft Ales in Red Hook, Brooklyn, is selling beer in cans. Shane Welch, the founder and brewmaster, said aluminum cans keep beer fresher than bottles: they block out light and have no air space on top. They are also lighter to ship.

title: Satisfy That Hankering for Mixed-Vegetable Ice Cream
description: Brian Smith, the owner of Ample Hills Creamery, right, a bright shop that just opened in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, is scooping salted caramel, maple-bacon, chocolate stout with pretzels, all-natural bubble gum tinted with beet juice and 19 other flavors, including chocolate and vanilla. He custom blends his bases (some with eggs, some not), so by law he needs to pasteurize his mixtures of milk and cream from local dairies on site. Homemade cones, and cakes with ice cream and blondies or brownies are also on the menu.

title: Is This Baby a Boy or Girl?
description: When we discussed the trend toward gender neutral parenting on Motherlode earlier this month,we used the term to mean things like not finding out the sex of the baby before birth, allowing children to choose clothes from either department at the store, and not limiting choice of play in any way.

title: Woods Expects to Play U.S. Open
description: Tiger Woods said Tuesday that he spent the last week wearing a protective boot on his left leg to immobilize his sore left Achilles tendon, and hobbled around on crutches to protect the strained medial collateral ligament in his knee and prevent further pain to his sore back. He also said he expected to be ready for the United States Open from June 16-19 at Congressional Country Club in Bethesda, Md.

title: Watchlist: A Second Look at Whats Trending
description: Earlier today, Mike Hale reviewed the premiere episode of Whats Trending, the new Web series from CBS News. He took in the second episode this afternoon:

title: Turning to Labor Board, N.B.A. Union Fires First
description: The legal maneuvering in the N.B.A.s labor battle began in earnest Tuesday, when the players union filed a complaint with the National Labor Relations Board, accusing league officials of failing to negotiate in good faith.

title: Parenting, Tornadoes and Surgical Boots
description: I was on the Today show on Monday discussing my Sunday column about legislating parenting. It was an interesting day to be in the studio, with news from Joplin, Mo., breaking all around. The everyday struggles of parenting get put in their place when you know there are parents out there who have lost everything.

title: A Rumor From the Roundabout
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  Theres an old saying here that goes awaza sar-e chowk, a rumor from the roundabout. If a bit of news seems hard to believe, you might hear it. Kabul residents found themselves saying it plenty on Monday when Afghan media reported the news that Mullah Muhammad Omar, the Talibans reclusive, one-eyed leader, was dead. The news sprang from the National Directorate of Security, the countrys main intelligence agency. Yes, it came from unnamed sources inside the agency, which publicly would say only that Mullah Omar was missing, but it carried enough currency that Western officials, though skeptical, would not come right out and say it was wrong.

title: Exploring Megafauna Fossil Beds
description: Patrick Widmann measuring the knee joint of a fossil, and then exposing more of the bone; he appears to be quite surprised by what he uncovers.

title: Warren and Republicans Spar Over Bureaus Power
description: Republican lawmakers contend the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau will be able to exert too much power over Wall Street.

title: Ivan Vasiliev to Appear With American Ballet Theater
description: American Ballet Theater has announced a replacement for the injured principal dancer Herman Cornejo. Ivan Vasiliev, a principal dancer with the Bolshoi Ballet, will appear with Ballet Theater as a guest artist for three performances during the companys spring season, said Kevin McKenzie, the artistic director. Mr. Vasiliev will replace Mr. Cornejo, who withdrew from scheduled performances in The Bright Stream for the June 11 matinee and the evening of June 14. He will also replace Mr. Cornejo in the leading role of Franz in Copplia on June 16.

title: On Coming Out: Exploring the Stories of Gay Teenagers
description: This month were experimenting with a new format in which we feature a multimedia project on NYTimes.com and provide questions and activity ideas for teaching and learning with it. Today, our third such experiment, uses an audio slide show feature. Please also check out the other two, on an interactive map and a photo slide show.

title: An Italian Painting in Kentucky, Headed Home
description: Small museums dont often find themselves at the center of international investigations, but last year the Speed Art Museum in Louisville, Ky., did, when agents from the Department of Homeland Security tracked an altarpiece stolen in Italy in 1971 to the Speeds store rooms. The piece, a triptych featuring a Madonna and child that may date from as long ago as the 14th century, was stolen from a villa in Goito, southwest of Verona; two years later, the museum bought it from Newhouse Galleries in New York for $38,000. Under a settlement negotiated by the United States Attorney for the Eastern District of New York and announced on Monday, the Speed will soon turn over the work to Homeland Security, which will transfer it to Italian cultural authorities. (The collector who had owned it in 1971 has since died, and the authorities will be responsible for determining who is now entitled to the work.)

title: With a Final Taping, a Daytime Talk Era Ends
description: Before a hand-picked audience of boisterous fans, Oprah Winfrey taped the final hour of The Oprah Winfrey Show in Chicago on Tuesday afternoon, effectively lowering the curtain on the nations most popular daytime talk program.

title: President Obama in Britain
description: The presidents two-day state visit includes some ceremony, and some serious business.

title: Rapping About Tamales and Deportation
description: LOS ANGELES

title: What Microsofts Mango Says About Its Phone Strategy
description: Microsoft showed off the next version of its smartphone operating system, code-named Mango, at an event in downtown Manhattan on Tuesday morning.

title: 2010 Chteau Pavie, a St.-milion Wine, Gets a Good and a Bad Review
description: From a posting by Eric Asimov on Diners Journal at nytimes.com/dining.

title: Grieving Razzano Plays, Fulfilling Fiancs Wish
description: PARIS  Virginie Razzano could have excused herself from this French Open: maintained her distance, kept her thoughts and her pain to herself. But that was not what her fianc, Stephane Vidal, wished for her as they spent their final days together.

title: Where Have All The Mensches Gone?
description: I asked this question five years ago, with regard to members of the Bush administration, who seemed pathologically incapable of taking responsibility for their actions. But its as relevant as ever. Newt Gingrich declaring that anyone who quoted him accurately was lying; and now Tim Pawlenty, who, aside from saying a whole lot of false things while declaring himself a truthteller, pulled a Gingrich when Rush Limabaugh correctly pointed out that he wasnt a true Tea Partier a few years ago.

title: Sears Holdings Changes Agency Roster
description: The Sears Holdings Corporation, which has been struggling to woo shoppers to its Sears and Kmart stores, is enlisting help in the form of two additional advertising agencies.

title: Harrison Loses to Soderling, But Confidence Never Wavers
description: PARIS - Ryan Harrison wants to be the next great American male tennis player, but he was stuck on the outside of the French Open for two days. The 19-year-old lost in the final of last weeks qualifying tournament. He punctuated his disappointment with a toss of his racket over a fence and into a tree.

title: Britains Budget Gap Widens
description: LONDON  A pullback in pay in the financial sector and the end of a bonus tax led to a bigger budget shortfall in Britain in April, according to official data released Tuesday.

title: Democrat Wins Western New York Congressional Race
description: 10:07 p.m. | Updated Democrats scored an upset in one of New Yorks most conservative congressional districts on Tuesday, dealing a blow to the national Republican Party in a race that largely turned on the partys plan to overhaul Medicare.

title: What Are Your Thoughts on Tests to Grade Teachers?
description: Officials at the New York City Department of Education provided some more information on Tuesday about the potential cost of the up to 16 new tests they are developing to grade teachers.

title: Dining Calendar
description: Eating to Win

title: Artifacts | Greenbacks at the Guggenheim
description: The next time someone tells you to show him the money, head straight for the Guggenheim Museum. There, in a second-floor gallery, $100,000 in used one-dollar bills is on plain (and magnificent) view.

title: Spains Mediterranean Beaches Offer a Different Kind of Paradise
description: According to the Caribbean Resort Theory of Paradise, the perfect beach is an endless stretch of powdery white sand lined with coconut palms, staffed by mojito-toting waiters and lapped by turquoise water warm enough to feel like a big salty bathtub.

title: TimesCast | May 24, 2011
description: The Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, reiterates conditions for peace; a look back at his 1996 address to Congress; and West Bank settlers refuse to compromise for a Palestinian state.

title: Graydon Carter: Childrens Book Author
description: Some editors just edit. Others own restaurants, produce movies, write books and paint.

title: Citing Public Interest, Judge Rules for Hangover II
description: 6:00 p.m. | Updated

title: Risk From Spent Nuclear Reactor Fuel Is Greater in U.S. Than in Japan, Study Says
description: WASHINGTON  The threat of a catastrophic release of radioactive materials from a spent fuel pool at Japans Fukushima Daiichi plant is dwarfed by the risk posed by such pools in the United States, which are typically filled with far more radioactive material, according to a study released on Tuesday by a nonprofit institute.

title: Diageo Is Said to Be in Talks to Buy Jos Cuervo
description: Susana Gonzalez/Bloomberg NewsDiageo has its eye on the Jos Cuervo brand of tequila.

title: El Bulli Is the Greatest Restaurant in the World
description: True story: The other night I was teleported to Ferran Adrias El Bulli with my exceedingly close friend, the actress Reese Witherspoon. One minute Reese and I were walking along the beach in Malibu with my rescue-dog Chase, and the next we were nestled into a pillow-covered king-size bed in an apartment no one knows about on top of the restaurants dining room, where there are eunuchs who will fetch you anything you desire. (I desired a Mountain Dew. No problem!)

title: Huguette Clark, Reclusive Heiress, Dies at 104
description: She was almost certainly the last link to New Yorks Gilded Age, reared in Beaux-Arts splendor in a 121-room Fifth Avenue mansion awash in Rembrandt, Donatello, Rubens and Degas. Her father, a copper baron who once bought himself a United States Senate seat as casually as another man might buy a pair of shoes, had been born before the Mexican War. Her six siblings died long before her, one in the 19th century.

title: Where Do You Fall on the Income Curve?
description: The Tax Policy Center has updated its figures on the income distribution in America, which wed previously written about in a post about why most rich people dont feel very rich. They have now crunched income levels for every single percentile, and the numbers refer to 2011 rather than 2010. So Ive updated my chart on this subject.

title: There are Americans in Paris, Still Playing, Too
description: PARIS  For the American contingent, it was sure to be a little different at the French Open without Andy Roddick, and Serena and Venus Williams, all not playing because of with injuries.

title: Pictures of the Day: England and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from England, Washington, Missouri and Afghanistan.

title: Keeping Score: Wilpons Scapegoats vs. Steinbrenners
description: As once-heralded New York baseball trios go, Carlos Beltran, Jose Reyes and David Wright were not the first to invoke their owners ire for their teams failures.

title: Case of Romanian Realism: Regular Guy, With Wife and Girlfriend
description: Around 40, with a soft gut, rounded shoulders and graying hair, Paul (Mimi Branescu), the middle-class Romanian who appears in virtually every frame of Radu Munteans Tuesday, After Christmas, is probably 10 years past the peak of his handsomeness. But he still has some attractive qualities, among them a low-key sense of humor, a decent work ethic and an obliging, if sometimes brusque, demeanor.

title: President Obama in Britain
description: The presidents two-day state visit includes some ceremony, and some serious business.

title: An Iraqi Christian Stands Firm With His Muslim Neighbors
description: BAGHDAD  Over the past several months, Iraqs dwindling Christian population has gotten even smaller.

title: Can a Picasso Cure You?
description: The Russian-born artist Alexander Melamid is by nature an ironist, so adept at serving as his own straight man that its hard to tell how seriously he means to be taken. He may not know himself.

title: Orlando Beats N.Y.C. to 50 Million Visitors, Officials Say
description: Just as the stage appeared set for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg to take bows for the achievement of one of his more audacious goals, he was upstaged on Tuesday by the mayor of the city that Mickey Mouse built.

title: Whitney Breaks Ground for New Building
Mike Mills on Beginners
description: The director Mike Mills is considered a jack-of-all-trades in the indie world (hes directed music videos and designed album covers for bands like Sonic Youth, Air and the Beastie Boys). So its no surprise that his soon-to-be-released dramedy, Beginners, about a young man who learns that his father is gay and has terminal cancer, is more than just a film. I seem to need to make a lot of stuff, he jokingly says. Collateral material includes a book of sketches, aptly titled Mike Mills: Drawings From the Film Beginners,  and some animated shorts to accompany them. T caught up with Mills to talk about Beginners and its never-ending possibilities.

title: Pictures of the Day: England and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from England, Missouri, Afghanistan and Yemen.

title: Decorum Breaks Down at House Hearing
description: WASHINGTON  A House committee hearing on Tuesday about the new Consumer Financial Protection Bureau disintegrated into heated accusations of lying, with the panels chairman accusing Elizabeth Warren of giving misleading testimony at a hearing in March and of making up facts about her agreement to testify this week.

title: Barnes & Noble Caught in a Wall St. Whirlwind
description: Harry Campbell

title: Celebrating Electronics And Energy
description: New music is hardly scarce during the main part of the New York concert season, and spaces like Issue Project Room, Galapagos and the Tank specialize in it year round. But spring and summer are a virtually nonstop parade of festivals celebrating the experimental. Recent weeks have featured the MATA, Look & Listen and Keys to the Future festivals in rapid succession, and on Monday evening the Tribeca New Music Festival opened its 10th season with a tightly packed program performed by Ethel, the string quartet, and devoted almost entirely to premieres.

title: Holding Out Hope in Missouri
description: In Joplin, Mo., rescue workers searched for survivors and victims in buildings leveled by the United States deadliest tornado in more than 60 years.

title: Visitors Lift Up Their Voices to Bach and More
description: Not every musicians Carnegie Hall debut takes place during a concert produced by Carnegie Hall. The institutions in-house artistic administration is responsible for only a fraction of the events that take place there, admittedly including most of its starriest affairs. Still, an artistically successful debut not produced by Carnegie is no less remarkable or noteworthy an achievement  a point made by the Ottawa Bach Choir at Weill Recital Hall on Monday night.

title: Fashioning Artistry on Wheels
description: ALWAYS crazy here, Ernie Wong was saying. Its not just the constant ring-ring of the land lines. Theres the smash-bash of stainless steel resisting ball-peen hammers. The wheeeen of the polishers smoothing steel burrs. The shoooosss of the welding sparks. Not to mention Mr. Wongs mother, Sylvia, schmoozing on the cellphone in Shanghainese while his father, Jimmy, issues production orders in Mandarin.

title: Recently Reviewed
description: CHEFS TABLE AT BROOKLYN FARE

title: Tom Colicchio to Open the Lot on Tap, and Curate High Line Food Trucks
description: Its a pop-up plaza in a vacant parking lot. Its a food truck food court. Its an al fresco taproom. Its an art installation. Its a community event space. And oh, yes  its a destination for hordes of future visitors to the High Line whose strolls northward on the elevated public promenade would otherwise have deposited them pretty much nowhere.

title: Another Spin of the Musical Wheel
description: Elvis Costello came on as all jovial show business  carny barker, M.C. and musical attraction  on Monday at the Beacon Theater. It was part of a three-night stand there for his Spectacular Spinning Songbook tour with his longtime band, the Imposters.

title: A Graphic Memoir That Earns the Designation
description: Book titles are a touchy subject for writers. Its not rare to hear an author complain in private about one of his or hers, and ache to reach back in time to swap it for something else. A different title for a fizzled book might have meant a different life for it.

title: Holding Out Hope in Missouri
description: In Joplin, Mo., rescue workers searched for survivors and victims in buildings leveled by the United States deadliest tornado in more than 60 years.

title: Wrestling With Health Insurance Costs
description: Starting Sept. 1, double-digit increases in health insurance premiums for individuals and small businesses will be subject to a review and possible rejection by state and federal officials. The change is part of the new Affordable Care Act, and is meant to make sure that premium increases are justified.

title: Egypts Literary Revolutionary
description: As protesters filled Tahrir Square in Cairo this spring, one of them turned to Alaa Al Aswany and asked him to write a novel about the revolution. Moments later the protester was dead, killed by a sniper. This would be enough to throw any writer into the spotlight, except that Al Aswany didnt need any help getting there. What made him a household name in Egypt was his first novel, The Yacoubian Building. It portrayed Egypt as a corrupt society, whose public mores were belied by private sins. Considered somewhat scandalous, it nonetheless became a bestseller in the Arab world andwas even made into a feature film.

title: Obama Campaign Cultivates Clinton Donors
description: President Obamas campaign manager, Jim Messina, met privately on Monday night with donors close to his erstwhile rival, Hillary Rodham Clinton, as the campaign sought to knit together and mobilize the Democratic fund-raising elite in advance of the 2012 election.

title: Real Prize for Idol: Rebound in Ratings
description: As the highest-rated season of Foxs American Idol in several years comes to a close this week, one thing is already certain: the competitions winner will be a country music singer.

title: G.O.P. Lawmakers Vote to Delay Derivatives Rules
description: A House panel approved a plan on Tuesday to delay several rules for the $600 trillion derivatives market, a leading player in the financial crisis.

title: Ballets Home Away From Home for International Stars in New York
description: What does American Ballet Theater do better than other companies? Does it have the worlds best selection of male principal dancers? Does it have in Alexei Ratmansky the worlds best full-time ballet choreographer of the day? About these points we can argue. But when it comes to a choice of global guest stars, all dispute fades: Ballet Theater is in a class of its own.

title: Over the Queensboro Bridge
description: Long Island City and Astoria have become magnets for chefs and restaurateurs in search of low rents, backyard space and food-aware customers.

title: Over the Queensboro, to Nosh
description: ALEX SCHINDLER sports a beard and a tattoo, cooks with local ingredients and wears ironic 1970s T-shirts. And yet Mr. Schindlers restaurant, LIC Market, is not to be found in the East Village or in the hip reaches of Brooklyn.

title: World War II and Coconut Cream Pie
description: Theres enough corn to feed an army in The Human Comedy, a severely dated yet wonderfully staged musical by the Astoria Performing Arts Center. The production, with 25 actors and 6 musicians, is an ambitious undertaking, met with an impressive level of skill. But time has turned this overly sincere tale into a gob of sticky sweetness.

title: On Frederick Seidel, Radiohead, the End of the World, Pink Floyd and Weeping Sugar
description: In researching my contribution to our list of Stuff We Like That Maybe You Wont, Id originally intended to recommend the poetry of Frederick Seidel, which I turn to habitually for a rush of dread and pleasure, until I realized its quite possible you will like it, or that you already do. Which is not to say Seidel is impossible to not-love: He has been called crass, disturbing, a name-dropping, upmarket sinner; he has also been called Americas greatest living poet. In fact, he was called both in the same article (specifically, the display text to the article), when Wyatt Mason profiled him for the Times magazine back in 2009.

title: Ahmadinejad Backs Out of Key Role at OPEC
description: President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad of Iran will not preside over  or even attend  next months OPEC meeting in Vienna as previously planned, Irans Foreign Ministry said Tuesday. The change in plan, reported late Monday in Irans state-run press, appeared to signify a retreat by the president in his power struggle with the nations supreme leader.

title: Cooking Temperature for Pork Is Lowered
description: THE other pink meat?

title: TimesCast | Benjamin Netanyahu's Speech
description: May 24, 2011 - The Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, reiterates conditions for peace, and a look back at his 1996 address to Congress.

title: TimesCast | Settlers Stand Firm
description: May 24, 2011 - West Bank settlements are a hindrance to any peace deal based on Israel's pre-1967 borders as proposed by President Obama.

title: Treasury Gets Small Profit From Sale of A.I.G. Stock
description: 9:32 p.m. | Updated

title: A Return to 'The Normal Heart'
description: Joe Mantello talks about returning to the stage in Larry Kramers play.

title: On Our Radar: Brazilian Forest Advocate and Wife Slain
description: Jos Cludio Ribeiro da Silva, a Brazilian rain forest activist, and his wife areshot dead near their home in Para State, in the Amazon. In a speech last year, Mr. da Silva acknowledged that his work battling illegal loggers put him in grave danger. I will protect the forest at all costs. That is why I could get a bullet in my head at any moment  because I denounce the loggers and charcoal producers, he said. [The Guardian]

title: Stage Scenes: Bobby Cannavale
description: Photos of some of the actors past performances in New York.

title: Clijsters Is Back on Clay, Not Yet in Form
description: PARIS  It was hardly vintage Kim Clijsters on Tuesday, but then it is difficult to remember vintage Kim Clijsters at the French Open.

title: New Restaurants in London
description: Sam Sifton takes measure of a few new restaurants from established names in the British dining scene.

title: In London, Stalking the New
description: LONDON

title: A Return to Acting Thats From the Heart
description: JOE MANTELLO was a 22-year-old actor, trained in the classics and fresh to New York, when he set out for the Public Theater one snowy night in 1985 to see The Normal Heart, Larry Kramers play about the first years of AIDS. Watching the protagonist Ned Weeks  a blunt, opinionated gay man not unlike himself  Mr. Mantello understood his need to take action in the face of death and denial, he recalled recently. If others found The Normal Heart a statistics-laden screed, Mr. Mantello felt a visceral recognition that Molire and Sophocles had never triggered.

title: Yankees Shut Down Soriano
description: In the latest of a series of disappointments in his first season with the Yankees, Rafael Soriano has been shut down after a throwing session in which he felt soreness in his arm.

title: N.F.L. Will Fine Teams Whose Players Are Punished Repeatedly for Improper Hits
description: INDIANAPOLIS  The N.F.L. will begin fining teams if their players are repeatedly disciplined by the league for improper hits.

title: Top Colleges, Largely for the Elite
description: The last four presidents of the United States each attended a highly selective college. All nine Supreme Court justices did, too, as did the chief executives of General Electric (Dartmouth), Goldman Sachs (Harvard), Wal-Mart (Georgia Tech), Exxon Mobil (Texas) and Google (Michigan).

title: Behind the Rise in Pell Grants
description: My column this week looks at Amherst Colleges impressive recent track record of recruiting low- and middle-income students. Amherst now has a much higher share of Pell Grant recipients  who tend to come from the lower-half of the income distribution  than most other elite colleges.

title: Mrs. Obamas American-British Day
description: Michelle Obama seems to be pleasing both sides of the Atlantic with her fashion choices during the state visit to England. She arrived in the country on Tuesday morning dressed in a royal blue outfit by Preen, a British label. Later, at Buckingham Palace, she wore a dress by the American Barbara Tfank. She then changed into a purple dress by the London designer Roksanda Ilincic for a visit to 10 Downing Street. For a white-tie dinner at the palace on Tuesday night, the first lady chose a ruched ivory georgette gown by Tom Ford, an American who has his design offices in London, where he lives part of the year. The Ford number looks super on her  flattering neckline, perfect fit, just right for all the pomp.

title: Gates Sees Iran as a Consideration for U.S. Troops in Iraq
description: WASHINGTON  Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates said on Tuesday that if some American troops remained in Iraq beyond the scheduled withdrawal of all United States forces by the end of the year, it would be reassuring to Persian Gulf countries, but not to Iran. And thats a good thing, Mr. Gates said.

title: Wilpon Says He Is Sorry for Remarks
description: CHICAGO  With his public-relations campaign backfiring, Fred Wilpon, the Mets principal owner, apologized to Jose Reyes and Carlos Beltran via speaker phone in a cramped office in the clubhouse at Wrigley Field on Tuesday.

title: Syrian Beaten on Camera Appears on State Television
description: Among the hundreds of video clips posted online by Syrian activists in recent weeks, documenting protests and a brutal security crackdown, few are as arresting as this 75 seconds, apparently filmed last month in the village of Bayda, while members of the security forces hit and kicked a group of prisoners forced to lie face down on the pavement:

title: Hoax Site Distressing for Victims of Shooting
description: TUCSON  Television images of the chaotic scene after the Jan. 8 shootings here do not convince them. Neither do the funerals for the deceased, the scars of the wounded or the federal prosecution of the man accused of being the gunman.

title: A God Is Dead, but Its Business That May Suffer Most
description: PUTTAPARTHI, India  His face adorns the yellow motorized rickshaws zipping down the streets. Billboards bear his simple motto, Love All, Serve All. His portrait hangs in almost every shop: a tiny man with a gravity-defying crown of curly hair regarded by millions of worldwide devotees as a god.

title: Joe Steffy, Blocker for Stars at West Point, Dies at 85
description: Joe Steffy, a star guard who opened the way for the Heisman Trophy winners Doc Blanchard and Glenn Davis to burst through opposing lines for Armys undefeated national football champions of the mid-1940s, died Saturday in Newburgh, N.Y. He was 85.

title: Refighting the Auto Industry Bailout Battle
Deal Reached in Albany to Cap Property Taxes
description: ALBANY  Pledging to provide relief to highly taxed suburban homeowners, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo and legislative leaders said Tuesday that they had agreed to place a 2 percent limit on property tax increases in a plan that rivals the toughest such measures in the nation.

title: Pakistan: Chinese Held in Attack
description: A day after denying that any of its citizens had been involved, China confirmed Tuesday that Chinese technicians were taken hostage during a militant attack on a Pakistani naval base. China has been walking a careful line with Pakistan. It does not want to antagonize India, but it is eager to present itself to Pakistan as a more reliable ally than the United States.

title: Economic Aid to Egypt and Tunisia
description: The World Bank said Tuesday that it was willing to provide up to $6 billion to support political and economic change in Egypt and Tunisia to help them weather declines in tourism and other economic activity. The money is intended to seed a broader package of international support and allow Egyptians and Tunisians to seize the opportunities of historic change to modernize their economies and build more open and inclusive societies, said Robert B. Zoellick, the World Bank president. Both Egypt and Tunisia have been under economic strain since the revolutions in those countries, but the bank said political reforms often produce rebounds in economic activity. Egypt and Tunisia will seek additional help this week from the Group of 8 nations.

title: Gay Marriage: Ethics and Economics
description: To the Editor:

title: Ending Farm Subsidies
description: To the Editor:

title: Punishing a Yale Fraternity
description: To the Editor:

title: Venezuela: Oil Company Sanctions
description: The United States imposed sanctions on Venezuelas national oil company, Petrleos de Venezuela, for its deliveries of two shipments of fuel valued at $50 million to Iran. The sanctions do not directly affect the operations of Citgo, the companys American subsidiary, or prohibit Venezuelan oil exports to the United States. But they prevent Petrleos de Venezuela from competing for United States government contracts, obtaining export licenses or receiving financing from the Export-Import Bank. The State Department also imposed sanctions on six smaller oil and shipping companies, based in the United Arab Emirates, Singapore, Israel, Britain and Monaco, for dealings with Iran.

title: After a Silent Spring, NASA Gives Up on Spirit
description: The Spirit is dead.

title: The Case for Gossip
description: To the Editor:

title: Adult Attention Disorder
description: To the Editor:

title: S.E.C. Leased Unneeded Space, Report Says
description: WASHINGTON  The Securities and Exchange Commission leased $556 million worth of office space last year based on a deeply flawed and unsound analysis of its needs, without competitive bids and using backdated approval forms to justify its rushed attempt to rent the offices, according a report by the agencys inspector general released Tuesday.

title: During the Postseason, Wade Burns the Midnight Oil
description: MIAMI  Dwyane Wade is not necessarily struggling offensively in the Eastern Conference finals, but he has been sneaking out of the house and going to the gym to hoist shots  not out of frustration, but to build confidence.

title: Drugs and Profits
description: Fredericksburg, Va.

title: Demand for Office Condos Grows in Manhattan
description: When the Progressive Credit Union began negotiations to renew the lease for its 9,800-square-foot office near Penn Station in Manhattan, the landlord offered terms that would have more than doubled the rent, to $40 per square foot.

title: Execution Is Sought for Mobster in Death Plot
description: As the death penalty phase began on Tuesday in the trial of a convicted murderer and former mob boss, even the prosecutor acknowledged that capital punishment was not appropriate in most cases.

title: Cartwright Out of Contention to Lead Joint Chiefs
description: WASHINGTON  Gen. James E. Cartwright, long considered the leading candidate to be the next chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, is out of the running for the militarys top job, government officials said on Tuesday.

title: Infusion From China for Toledo, Ohio
description: TOLEDO, Ohio  Before it became known as the Marina District, the 128 acres of tall grass and dirt piles on the Maumee River here was home to one of the citys most prominent eyesores, the Acme coal-fired power plant, which was decommissioned in 1994.

title: Revolutionary Cuba Now Lays Sand Traps for the Bourgeoisie
description: MEXICO CITY  One of Fidel Castros first acts upon taking power was to get rid of Cubas golf courses, seeking to stamp out a sport he and other socialist revolutionaries saw as the epitome of bourgeois excess.

title: Hapless but Not Hopeless, Blue Jays Reyes Carries On
description: Jo-Jo Reyes did everything he could. For seven innings last Sunday in Toronto, he shut out the Houston Astros and gave a 2-0 lead to the Blue Jays bullpen. At that point, the outcome was out of his control, and he could live with the result: a blown lead and another winless day.

title: Taking in Some London Sights, the Obamas Display Skill at Official Travel
description: LONDON  They were shown around their rooms at Buckingham Palace by their hostess, Queen Elizabeth herself. They got to meet and have an actual conversation with one of the few couples in the world even more famous than they are: Prince William and his wife, the Duchess of Cambridge (formerly known as Kate Middleton).

title: Chernobyl Behind Him, Student Takes on Cancer
description: STONY BROOK, N.Y.  Yan Leyfman was born in Belarus in 1989, three years after the Chernobyl nuclear disaster. His family lived only about 75 miles from the nuclear plant, and as a toddler, Mr. Leyfman had a constellation of mysterious symptoms: cysts that covered his entire body, fingernails that fell out, limbs that were swollen and skin that itched torturously.

title: Consider Profits When Judging Initial Offerings
description: The big first-day stock market pops by Yandex, the Russian Internet search company, and LinkedIn, the online business network, show how hungry investors are for technology-related growth possibilities. Thats good news for other businesses that hope to go public. But judging them by revenue potential is risky. Profits are what matter.

title: Hopes Rise in South as Waters Do Not
description: NEW ORLEANS  When the Morganza spillway was opened on May 14, diverting an enormous volume of Mississippi River water to reduce pressure on levees downstream, the thousands of people living in the Atchafalaya River Basin were bracing for the worst.

title: Standing Up to Unwarranted Police Power
description: Whats wrong with the police kicking in the door of an apartment after they smell marijuana drifting from it, if they knock hard, announce who they are and then hear what sounds like evidence being destroyed?

title: Smoking Leisurely, and Illegally, in the Park
description: Leaving time for killjoys to complain, a cigarette was lingeringly smoked.

title: Lagarde Is Said to Seek I.M.F. Job
description: PARIS  Europes top candidate to lead the International Monetary Fund, Finance Minister Christine Lagarde of France, is expected to formally announce her bid for the post at a news conference scheduled in Paris on Wednesday.

title: Protecting High-Risk Students in New Jersey
description: The New Jersey Supreme Court stood up for the states children and strongly rebuked Gov. Chris Christie when it ruled on Tuesday that his draconian school budget cuts violated the State Constitution by depriving impoverished children of an effective education.

title: Army Seeks Recruits in Social Media
description: WHEN ads for the Army used the theme Todays Army wants to join you, a joker rewrote it this way: Todays Army wants to join you. At your place. These days, the Army is getting social  if not quite that sociable  as potential recruits increasingly spend time with social media like Facebook, Flickr, Twitter and YouTube.

title: A Legacy for a Son Whose Character, After 9/11, Was Misjudged
description: If memory serves, the police captain met me over coffee on a Wednesday night in October 2001, when the world was dizzy with menace. He passed along word of a fresh worry. A young Muslim chemist, who worked in an advanced biochemistry laboratory in Midtown, had vanished on the morning of Sept. 11. Because he had once been a member of a police cadet program, he had an ID card that gave him access to police facilities. His name was Mohammad Salman Hamdani, and the captain had just been faxed a flier about him.

title: The G-8s Self-Serving Math
description: The final communiqus havent been written. But the word on the street is that when leaders of the Group of 8 industrialized countries meet in France this week, they will claim that wealthy countries have come close to fulfilling their 2005 promise to boost annual development aid by $50 billion by 2010. They are not even in the ballpark.

title: After a Fire, a Tension Between Two Schools
description: Metal fencing wrapped around the charred monkey bars and partly melted plastic slides of a jungle gym in a police-barricaded corner of the Public School 29 playground in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn.

title: After Comeback Win, Mavericks Focus on Ending Series
description: DALLAS  Kevin Durant held his shooting pose for an extra second, convinced he had just delivered the decisive blow in Game 4 of the Western Conference finals. As his 3-point shot swished and the Oklahoma City Thunder surged to a 15-point lead Monday night, Durant turned and mimicked pulling an imaginary championship belt across his waist.

title: Spy Planes Help Set Targets in NATO Air Campaign Over Libya
description: The air campaign in Libya relies heavily on 24 hour rotating air reconnaissance missions.

title: Daunting Task for NATO in Libya as Strikes Intensify
description: OVER THE MEDITERRANEAN SEA  Just after midnight on Sunday, an allied Mirage 2000 fighter jet prowling the Libyan coastline attacked a Libyan missile patrol boat that military officials said threatened NATO and humanitarian aid vessels in nearby waters.

title: As Housing Goes, So Goes the Economy
description: The Great Recession began with the bursting of the housing bubble. Today, nearly two years after the recession officially ended, the housing market is still in trouble.

title: American Idol Season 10 Finale
description: 9:15 p.m. |Which Finalists Performance Was Idol-Worthy?

title: San Francisco Tech Companies Get a Tax Break
description: A campaign by San Franciscos start-ups to get a tax break from the city paid off on Tuesday.

title: Romney and Democrats Spar Over Auto Bailout
description: WASHINGTON  The recovery of the American auto industry, which repaid a significant part of its debt to the federal government on Tuesday, has sparked a political battle over who deserves credit and who deserves blame.

title: Yandexs Surge on Debut Stirs More Talk of Tech Bubble
description: Shares of Yandex, a Russian search engine barely known in the United States, surged by more than 55 percent on Tuesday, signifying the latest multibillion-dollar technology offering and stoking the debate about whether this market has the makings of a bubble.

title: Lottery Numbers
Watchdog Finds Evidence That Iran Worked on Nuclear Triggers
description: The worlds global nuclear inspection agency, frustrated by Irans refusal to answer questions, revealed for the first time on Tuesday that it possesses evidence that Tehran has conducted work on a highly sophisticated nuclear triggering technology that experts said could be used for only one purpose: setting off a nuclear weapon.

title: Volkswagen Bets on Passat Built in Tennessee
description: CHATTANOOGA, Tenn.  Volkswagen hopes that more seat padding and larger cup holders will help it to become competitive in the United States again and to achieve a lofty goal of becoming the worlds largest carmaker this decade.

title: Lt. Knox Carries on His Friends Legacy
description: Waves of sorrow and indignation rippled across the Northern states in the wake of the fatal shooting of Elmer Ellsworth, a charismatic young colonel who had built a national following in the early days of the war only to be shot dead by an Alexandria, Va., innkeeper on May 24. But few felt the loss as keenly as his trusted lieutenant and friend Edward Knox.

title: Lessons From Tahrir Sq.
description: Cairo

title: Christopher Meloni to Leave Law & Order: SVU
description: Another favorite television character will be disappearing next fall with the departure of Elliot Stabler, the detective played by the actor Christopher Meloni in the long-running NBC series Law & Order: SVU.

title: Report Finds Schools Official Misused Time
description: The former chief financial officer of the New York City school system and several consultants he had recommended used their time and the Department of Educations e-mail system inappropriately to plot the officers exit into a private financial firm, according to a report released Tuesday.

title: Treasury Official Says Profit Wasnt Aim of A.I.G. Sale
description: The American International Groups long-anticipated stock sale raised at least $8.7 billion on Tuesday, with most of the proceeds going to taxpayers.

title: Near the High Line, a Parking Lot With High Ambition
description: It is a pop-up plaza in a vacant parking lot. It is an art installation. It is a food truck food court. It is an alfresco tap room. It is a community event space.

title: Recession Slows Migration, Census Finds
description: WASHINGTON  Domestic migration last year reached its lowest level since the government began tracking it in the 1940s, the Census Bureau said, as the lingering effects of the recession continued to curb Americans mobility.

title: Wednesday: How Its Done
description: WEDNESDAYS PUZZLE  Well, you learn something new every day. At first, I was afraid this was going to be a grid where the circles all spell out the same Swedish pop group, over and over again, until Dancing Queen is stuck in permanent, shrieking rotation in my head. Fortunately, that was not the case.

title: Anna Kournikova Joins The Biggest Loser Amid Overhaul
description: NBC announced during the Tuesday night finale of The Biggest Loser that professional tennis player Anna Kournikova will be the new celebrity trainer on the reality show, replacing Jillian Michaels.

title: States Collect More Taxes, but Troubles Remain
description: States had strong growth in tax collections during the first quarter of the year, but still collected less money than they did before the recession began, according to preliminary data released Tuesday by the Nelson A. Rockefeller Institute of Government.

title: Dont Be a Stranger
description: DUBLIN

title: The Battle for Libya | May 24, 2011
description: Rebels continued to train after NATO forces bombed Tripoli with its heaviest attack yet.

title: Google Expected to Introduce a Wireless Payment System
description: Google is expected to introduce on Thursday a mobile payment system that will let shoppers wave their phones to pay instead of pulling out a credit card, according to people briefed on the announcement.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Sabathia Throws Complete Game, and Yankees Rally in Ninth for Win
description: On the day the Yankees found out that their prized off-season acquisition, Rafael Soriano, was going to be shut down indefinitely, C. C. Sabathia did exactly what they needed, giving the bullpen a day off by pitching a complete game.

title: Bloggingheads: Wanted: G.O.P. Superman
description: Ben Smith, left, of Politico and Byron York of The Washington Examiner debate whether any new Republican presidential candidates will emerge.

title: Democrat Wins G.O.P. Seat; Rebuke Seen to Medicare Plan
description: Democrats scored an upset in one of New Yorks most conservative Congressional districts on Tuesday, dealing a blow to the national Republican Party in a race that largely turned on the partys plan to overhaul Medicare.

title: Twisters Strike Oklahoma, and at Least 5 People Are Killed
description: A series of tornadoes struck central Oklahoma on Tuesday, wiping out homes and businesses and killing at least five people. Officials said the number could rise as search and rescue teams started to fan out across a state already battered by storms over the weekend.

title: Panel Told of Plan to Reduce F-35 Costs
description: CRYSTAL CITY, Va.  A new estimate that 2,400 F-35 fighter jets could cost $1 trillion to operate over 50 years has created more pressure to cut costs in the Pentagons largest program.

title: Start-Ups Vie for Attention at the Venture Capital Table
description: The recent initial public offerings by Internet companies including LinkedIn and Yandex are grabbing the attention of investors and making headlines, but small technology start-ups are expecting more than just scraps from the venture capital table.

title: All That Glitters May Redefine Run by Gingrich
description: WASHINGTON  To the long list of rich-guy foibles that turned into defining campaign moments  John Edwardss $400 haircut, John Kerrys kite-surfing, John McCains inability to remember how many homes he owns  let us now add Newt Gingrichs $500,000 revolving line of credit at the luxury jeweler Tiffany & Company.

title: Where Startups Compete for Attention
description: The recent public offerings by LinkedIn and Yandex have grabbed the attention of investors, but small technology startups are expecting more than just scraps from the venture capital table.

title: Stephen De Staebler, Sculptor of Bronze and Clay, Dies at 78
description: Stephen De Staebler, a sculptor whose fractured, dislocated human figures gave a modern voice and a sense of mystery to traditional realist forms, died on May 13 at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 78.

title: Vote on Debt Is Planned but Criticized as a Stunt
description: WASHINGTON  House Republicans said Tuesday that they would allow a vote next week on an increase in the federal debt ceiling with no strings attached, in order to see it defeated and show Democrats that no increase in federal borrowing authority can be enacted without significant spending cuts.

title: World Bank Offers Aid to Egypt and Tunisia
description: WASHINGTON  The World Bank said Tuesday it was willing to provide up to $6 billion to support political and economic change in Egypt and Tunisia and to help them weather declines in tourism and other industries.

title: Dick Wimmer, Whose Persistence Got Him Published, Dies at 74
description: Zounds, lad, no need to kill yourself now! a phantom from the 19th century tells the central character in Dick Wimmers first novel, Irish Wine, reassuring the struggling artist that someday his paintings will hang in the Tate Gallery in London.

title: In a California Prison, Bunk Beds Replace Pickup Games
description: CHINO, Calif.  The basketball hoops jimmied up to the ceiling prove that this dingy space was a gym once upon a time. But for years now, the windowless space has served as a de facto cell for dozens of prisoners at the California Institution for Men.

title: Photo Replay: May 24
description: A look at the day in sports from a marathon match on the French Open clay courts of Roland Garros to an N.B.A. showdown on the hard court in Miami.

title: The Mets Rocky Finances
description: The prospective buyer of 49 percent of the Mets, whomever it is, will inherit a team in serious financial straits. The Mets are seeking $200 million for the minority stake.

title: Mets Live Up to Owners Criticisms
description: CHICAGO  Whether distracted by recent events or just playing an ill-timed sloppy game, the Mets took the field Tuesday for the first time in the wake of Fred Wilpons remarks criticizing the team, and proved him right.

title: Want Success in Silicon Valley? Drop Out of School
description: Parents, do you hope that your children have the chance to become like Peter Thiel, the PayPal co-founder, Facebook investor and hedge fund manager? If so, Mr. Thiel suggests that you encourage them to drop out of school. In fact, he will help by paying them to do it.

title: A Memory Tonic for the Aging Brain
description: Why, as we grow older, do we forget where we parked the car, and could exercise sharpen our recall? Those questions, of considerable interest to any of us who possess a brain as well as those with cars, is motivating a series of remarkable new experiments by researchers at Johns Hopkins University and the Center for the Neurobiology of Learning and Memory at the University of California, Irvine, during which young and older volunteers watch pictures flash onto a screen, while the scientists watch their brains.

title: New Study Links Spine Product From Medtronic to Risk of Sterility in Men
description: A surgeon at Stanford University, in a study released Wednesday, suggests that one of Medtronics best-selling spinal products poses a risk of male sterility. That finding is in stark contrast to earlier research by doctors paid by Medtronic, who found no connection between the product, Infuse, and a condition that causes sterility.

description: grandeur \gran-jr, -jur, -d(y)ur, -d(y)r\ noun
