title: The Wrongful Conviction as Way of Life
description: Judge Learned Hand called the ghost of the innocent man convicted an unreal dream. But in Convicting the Innocent, Brandon L. Garrett shows that it can be a nightmarish reality. Since the late 1980s, DNA testing has exonerated more than 250 wrongly convicted people, who spent an average of 13 years in prison for crimes they didnt commit. (There is every reason to think that more people have been wrongly convicted since then, but only these 250 have been definitively exonerated by postconviction DNA tests.) Seventeen of the 250 were sentenced to die, and 80 to spend the rest of their lives in prison. By poring over trial transcripts and interviewing lawyers, prosecutors and court reporters, Garrett, a law professor at the University of Virginia School of Law, seeks to explore who these 250 innocent people are, and why they were wrongly convicted. His alarming conclusion: the wrongful convictions were not idiosyncratic but resulted from a series of flawed practices that the courts rely on every day, namely, false and coerced confessions, questionable eyewitness procedures, invalid forensic testimony and corrupt statements by jailhouse informers. Garretts book is a gripping contribution to the literature of injustice, along with a galvanizing call for reform.

title: German Finance Minister Cites Risks in Greek Default
description: FRANKFURT  Amid growing expectations that Greece will have to restructure its debt, the German finance minister, Wolfgang Schuble, warned Thursday that a default could have grave and unpredictable consequences.

description: Update | June 11, 2011: View all 10 favorites here.

title: Merrill and Credit Suisse Fined for Subprime Deals
description: Merrill Lynch and Credit Suisse have agreed to pay fines to settle complaints about the subprime mortgage securities that they sold in the lead-up to the financial crisis, Wall Streets self-regulator announced on Thursday.

description: The Nielsen Company has acquired the rest of a company, NeuroFocus, that specializes in the nascent realm of researching whether neuroscience can be applied to advertising.

title: A Conversation With Bing Gordon

title: Here Comes the Sun
description: Practicing safe sun just got a whole lot sexier. Thanks to the young designers Anne Botica and Monique Moore, whose recently launched clothing line, Mott 50, contains brightly colored basics with UPF (ultraviolet protection factor) 50  which is 10 times the protection of a typical white tee. It really started because we noticed a shift in trends amongst our friends, says Moore, 28, who quit her day job at Cond Nast Digital a few short months after starting the line in the pink-walled apartment she shares with Botica (fittingly located on Manhattans Mott Street). Girls were finally starting to cover up with hats, sun block and tunics rather than trying to get as tan  and burned to a crisp  as possible. For the 27-year-old Botica, fashion is really a family affair. Theres a history of skin cancer in my family, she says. (An olive-green cotton poplin shirtdress with gold accents is named after Boticas younger sibling, Faith, $125.) Our clothes block both UVB, which causes burning and tanning, and UVA rays, which cause aging, wrinkles, sunspots, and skin cancer. This summer, a portion of Mott 50s proceeds will go towards cancer research. Go to mott50.com.

description: The political maneuvering behind the capture of Ratko Mladic; the history of his war crimes; and the Op-Ed columnist Roger Cohen describes meeting Mr. Mladic.

title: Republicans Climate Solution: Clear-Cut the Rain Forest
description: Representative Dana Rohrabacher, Republican of California, needs to hit the science books, forestry experts suggest.

title: Neighborhood Joint | Claudios Clam Bar
description: Claudios Clam Bar, eight miles from the tip of Long Islands North Fork, is a low-brow place with high-brow views.

title: Dickey Leaves Game With Foot Injury
description: CHICAGO  R.A. Dickey, the Mets knuckleball pitcher, left Thursdays game against the Chicago Cubs in the third inning with an injury to his right heel and foot.

title: Einhorn May Join a Small Clubhouse for Financiers
description: If David Einhorn secures a minority stake in the New York Mets for $200 million, the hedge fund manager will join a relatively small club: big-time financial moguls who own a piece of a prominent sports team.

title: Ex-Insurgent Shot to Death in Baghdad
description: BAGHDAD  Marching in lockstep as they shouted No, no, America, tens of thousands of Iraqis loyal to the anti-American Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr poured into the streets on Thursday to warn Iraqs government against extending the United States military presence here.

title: A Conversation With Bing Gordon
description: Bing Gordon has years of experience bridging the world of technology start-ups and venture capital. In addition to having been an executive at Electronic Arts, he is a board member of Amazon and Zynga, among other firms. Now, he is a partner with the venture capital firm Kleiner Perkins Caufield & Byers.

title: First Strokes to Becoming Aquaman
description: SWIMMING and I have never had much need for each other: I grew up in Manhattan with a fire-hydrant sprinkler as my respite from the heat. Out of my parents, four older sisters and myself, only Dad can swim. It was not a skill we put much thought into acquiring; we were a poor immigrant family that spent little time around large bodies of water. There was a trip to Lake George in 1980, however, when the family was lounging by a pool. My legs were dangling in the cool water when my brother-in-law shoved me in. (He became my ex-brother-in-law years later, but my eternal trauma was probably not a factor.)

title: And Now, Fresh Clams and Salty Air
description: HAMPTONS-BOUND traffic in the summer is a sweaty, hectic, BMW-infested mess. But thats not your problem. As you soar down the Long Island Expressway, past the long line of frustrated New Yorkers waiting to disembark at Exit 70, grin and wave, because youre not going to the Hamptons, pal. Youre headed for the North Fork  and straight to Claudios Clam Bar.

title: An Island of Culture in the Harbor
description: IT is not Manhattan, this New York City island that features a miniature golf course designed by artists, a beer garden, trapeze performances, sunbathing on a sandy beach, snoozing on bright red Adirondack chairs, a fort restored just in time for its bicentennial this year, polo, big-name concerts, an organic farm and the largest outdoor presentation of Mark di Suveros monumental sculptures in the city in four decades. This is Governors Island, and its only 800 yards from the Battery.

title: As Goal Shifts in Libya, Time Constrains NATO
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama has subtly shifted Washingtons public explanation of its goals in Libya, declaring now that he wants to assure the Libyan people are finally free of 40 years of tyranny at the hands of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, after first stating he wanted to protect civilians from massacres.

title: New York City Opera Union Files Labor Complaint
description: One of New York City Operas key unions on Thursday charged the company with unfair labor practices and sought a court order blocking its proposed move out of Lincoln Center. The salvo from the American Guild of Musical Artists comes nearly a week after City Opera said it could no longer afford to stay at the arts complex. Opera officials have so far remained silent on what they will present next season or where. The Guild, which represents singers, chorus members, dancers, stage managers and directors, said City Opera was using the move to break its contractual obligations and had refused to negotiate or provide any information about it.

title: Pictures of the Day: Libya and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Libya, Iraq, Spain, and Egypt.

description: Though Gary Graham, Thom Browne and Steven Alan have all set up shop in TriBeCa, the neighborhood has never really gelled as a fashion destination. But the recent opening of Al Abayans Patron of the New may just change that.

title: Mark Zuckerberg Says Hes Only Eating Meat He Kills
description: Mark Zuckerberg has certainly been called cutthroat before, but nobody meant it literally. Yet Mr. Zuckerberg, the founder of Facebook, has told Fortune that he is only eating meat he kills himself. This news apparently came to light when he told his Facebook friends on May 4, I just killed a pig and a goat.

title: Wanted: City Soundtrack Suggestions
description: Walk around Times Square, and it can sometimes seem oppressively dirty, crowded, loud, saturated in exhaust fumes. But walk around listening to the Bee Gees More Than a Woman on your headphones, and its a whole different story.

title: The Last Great Joke-Stuffed Comedy in America
description: When you see a review of a madcap comedy that ends with the words terrorist strikes in the heart of America, you know you probably have a problem and thats exactly how Elvis Mitchells review of Zoolander, which ran in The Times on Sept. 28, 2001, concluded. Mitchell fretted that elements of the film might be a reminder of the atmosphere in this country after the terrorist strikes into the heart of America.

title: Legal Wrangle May Keep 38 Works From Russia Out of Los Angeles Show
description: The Los Angeles County Museum of Art is in danger of becoming the latest victim of an international diplomatic battle that has led Russian museums to hold off making loans of state-owned art to the United States, after a federal judge in the District of Columbia ordered Russia to turn over a trove of religious books and manuscripts to members of Chabad-Lubavitch, the Hasidic group based in Brooklyn.

title: Q. and A. With Caroline Wozniacki
description: Caroline Wozniacki, the 20-year-old Danish player ranked No. 1 in the world, is in the third round of the French Open and still looking for her first Grand Slam singles title. The daughter of Polish immigrants to Denmark, she is now based in Monaco. She spoke with Christopher Clarey of The International Herald Tribune and The New York Times last week before the French Open. The first of two excerpts from that interview:

title: Among Lonelyhearts, a Meeting of Minds
description: Hello Lonesome, Adam Reids smart, poignant trilogy of interwoven vignettes, manages the considerable feat of creating six fully human characters who are quirky enough to transcend the stereotypes found in a typical indie film. Except for a young couple who rush headlong into a relationship after connecting on the Internet, the rest dwell in the uncomfortable limbo of the lonely unattached.

title: Cocktails With a Beer Buzz
description: Those of us who write with any frequency about food and drink usually present ourselves as equal-opportunity hedonists, our hunger no less sharp for one ethnic cuisine than for any other, our thirst all-encompassing. Like parents of diversely gifted children, were supposed to divine beauty and brilliance in each and not play favorites, or at least not cop to them.

title: Keeping Score: Among Phillies Four Aces, a Surprising Big Two
description: When the Philadelphia Phillies added Cliff Lee to a formidable group of starters that included Roy Halladay, Roy Oswalt and Cole Hamels, pundits wasted no time predicting greatness for the teams 2011 rotation.

title: The Economy Is Wavering. Does Washington Notice?
description: The latest economic numbers have not been good. Jobless claims rose last week, the Labor Department said on Thursday. Another report showed that economic growth at the start of the year was no faster than the Commerce Department initially reported  a real surprise, said Ian Shepherdson of High Frequency Economics.

title: Building Apps for Mike Tyson and Other Big Names
description: John and Sam Shahidi, two brothers from California, were working in the satellite television business when they came up with the idea for RunPee, an iPhone application that helps moviegoers figure out the optimal time to go the bathroom in the middle of a movie.

title: Ballet Meets Broadway Choreographers and Composers
description: Ballet companies, like individual dancers, love to demonstrate how diverse they can be. So New York City Ballet, which began its six-week spring season with eight performances of high modernism (black-and-white costuming, no scenery, most of the music by Webern, Stravinsky and Hindemith), is now giving us a tribute to Broadway, with music by Richard Rodgers, Duke Ellington and Leonard Bernstein.

title: Songs of the Poets, in Chamber Settings
description: Unlike most chamber music enterprises, the Mirror Visions Ensemble is run by singers rather than instrumentalists, and its programs are shaped with an ear to the poetry of song texts rather than to overarching notions of musical style. The group, directed by Tob Malawista, a soprano, includes Scott Murphree, tenor; Jesse Blumberg, baritone; and Vira Slywotzky, soprano; with Margaret Kampmeier, the pianist, as its superb accompanist.

title: Solving Puzzles to Help With the Riddle of Midlife
description: Mara Onetto, the wonderful Argentine actress who dominates Natalia Smirnoffs debut feature film, Puzzle, has the dignified bearing and mysterious expression of a middle-aged Mona Lisa. The faint flicker of a smile lingering on her lips evokes a woman with secrets she is much too discreet to reveal.

title: Pawlenty (Sort Of) Endorses Ryan Plan
description: Tim Pawlenty, the former governor of Minnesota, said on Thursday that if elected president, he would sign the Medicare plan put forth by Representative Paul D. Ryan of Wisconsin into law  if he had no other choice.

description: URUAU, Brazil  When the Chinese came looking for more soybeans here last year, they inquired about buying land  lots of it.

title: Tests Reveal Mislabeling of Fish
description: Scientists aiming their gene sequencers at commercial seafood are discovering rampant labeling fraud in supermarket coolers and restaurant tables: cheap fish is often substituted for expensive fillets, and overfished species are passed off as fish whose numbers are plentiful.

title: Brassy and Bawdy, With Fingers Snapping
description: A little bit of Las Vegas in the 1960s has splashed down Off Broadway. The Best Is Yet to Come: The Music of Cy Coleman, a finger-snapping, hard-charging, small-scale but still shiny-looking revue, has taken up residence at the 59E59 Theaters, becoming the latest cultural artifact seemingly spawned by the influential Mad Men television series. A Broadway composer whose glory years began in the heyday of the Rat Pack, Coleman can be seen on the cover of the program in a sleek suit, posing coolly like an honorary member of that informal fraternity.

title: Obama Approval Ratings Up in Two States
description: Two state polls out Thursday offer some good news for President Obama, showing significant improvements in his approval rating.

title: Circular Firing Squad, Run by Young Radicals
description: Theres a darkly comic moment in Olivier Assayass film Carlos, about Carlos the Jackal, involving three Japanese left-wing extremists. The militants, members of the Japanese Red Army, have decided to attack the French embassy at The Hague in an attempt to liberate a comrade imprisoned elsewhere. On their way to the embassy, though, they get lost (you see them studying a map), an absurd turn of events that suggests theres something fundamentally pathetic about them. That this is a terrorist gang that cant shoot (steer) straight, literally doesnt know where its going, finds further fuel in another movie, United Red Army.

title: Space, Light, Bragging Rights
description: THE real estate ad promised a space renovated by a well-known architect, or words to that effect. But Mindy Fox, a food writer who was apartment hunting with her husband, Steve Hoffman, was dubious. If hes so well known, Ms. Fox muttered to Mr. Hoffman as they headed up to Washington Heights back in 2005 to check out the place, how come they dont say who he is?

title: Oprah Finale Generates Best Ratings Since 1994
description: The finale of The Oprah Winfrey Show evidently brought back some fans who had not watched for quite some time. It was the highest-rated episode in almost 18 years. The show recorded a 13.3 household rating in major cities on Wednesday, meaning that 13.3 percent of all households with television sets tuned in. Thats more than twice the normal household rating for her show this season, and its highest since 1994, when its ratings were generally higher and there were fewer competing shows on the air. The ratings are subject to change when the Nielsen Company releases total viewer ratings later, according to CBS Television Distribution, which syndicates the show. Expecting high ratings, CBS charged a premium for advertisers who wanted to be a part of the finale.

title: The Movements Between the Notes
description: Complexions Contemporary Ballet is one of the great mysteries of the dance world. Formed in 1994 by the artistic directors Dwight Rhoden and Desmond Richardson, the troupe continues on despite its dire level of choreography, which used to be soulless but is now sappy too.

title: Looking Behind Curtains on a Gripping Journey
description: During an onstage interview midway through a concert by the Talea Ensemble at the Bohemian National Hall on the Upper East Side on Tuesday night, the Austrian composer Olga Neuwirth fielded a query about her sideline as an experimental filmmaker. I want to look behind the curtains, she said of that activity. I want to go beyond the boundaries.

description: ANY out-of-towner able to handle the shock of New York City real estate prices must prepare to absorb another anomaly: especially in Manhattan, that money buys a different type of home than it does anywhere else in the country, and that will affect financing.

title: The Piet Behind the Couch
description: IN 1885, when the Metropolitan Museum of Art was young and New York was home to much new wealth but only a few old masters, the museum showcased a painting on loan from Europe that created a minor stir.

title: Streetscapes | Central Park
description: Christopher Gray takes a walk through the shadow park within Central Park. Observant visitors can find a buried reservoir, an Indian cave, and an ancient spring, among other things.

title: More Saudi Women Record Driving Videos
description: Manal al-Sharif, a Saudi activist who was arrested this week for encouraging women to defy Saudi Arabias ban on women drivers, will be detained for at least 10 more days, her lawyer told The Associated Press on Thursday.

description: Handel, an inveterate recycler, knew a good tune when he had written one. Or, for that matter, when anyone else had.

title: Q & A
description: When a Co-op Files for Bankruptcy

title: Plenty of Buckets, No Water Needed
description: Neta Pulvermachers 2280 Pints! isnt the first dance to use a bucket, and it probably wont be the last. In this work, which incorporates 57 white five-gallon containers, Ms. Pulvermacher uses buckets to create a mostly whimsical world dedicated to the spirit of imagination and joy.

title: Hudson River Park Trust Picks a New Leader
description: Updated, 6:33 p.m. | Madelyn Wils is trading the Coney Island boardwalk and the body shops of Willets Point, Queens, for the green patches and esplanades that line the Hudson River waterfront in Manhattan.

title: David Barry
description: Mr. Barry, 46, is the president of the Ironstate Development Company in Hoboken, which owns and manages over 6,000 apartments and over 500,000 square feet of commercial space in New Jersey. Its projects include the W Hoboken hotel, 225 Grand in Jersey City and the Pier Village in Long Branch.

title: When Virtues Collide: Quiet vs. Tidy
description: GREENWICH, CONN.

title: Edward Lycett, Designer for Faience Company, Brooklyn
description: Little evidence remains of the Faience Manufacturing Company in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. This pottery company failed in the 1890s, and its former headquarters, on Greenpoint Avenue near the waterfront, has served over the years as a pencil factory and an S-and-M club and now contains a sports bar.

title: Higher-Priced Developments Providing Parking
description: MOTORISTS might be forgiven for thinking that New York has been snubbing them. Times Square has been covered with tables and chairs. Broad strips of streets have been painted green and handed over to cyclists. Builders continue to snap up parking lots for development.

title: Zuckerberg Says Hes Only Eating Meat He Kills
description: Mark Zuckerberg has certainly been called cutthroat before, but nobody meant it literally. Yet Mr. Zuckerberg, the founder of Facebook, has told Fortune that he is only eating meat he kills himself. This news apparently came to light when he told his Facebook friends on May 4, I just killed a pig and a goat.

title: Ecstatic Democrats and Shifting Winds In the Medicare Debate
description: New York Times editors and reporters discuss how Democrats in Washington celebrated a surprising victory in a heavily Republican congressional district in Upstate New York.

title: Books to Bury Yourself In
description: The beach book has undergone a makeover for 2011. As the seasons traditional big names and story lines run out of gas, new variations on old formulas have emerged. Want a story of power, greed and conspicuous consumption? Forget Hollywood; think hedge fund. Want a killer mystery? Forget that corpse in the opening chapter; think about the heroine who wakes up with amnesia and cant trust anyone around her. Want a topical family drama about teenage lovers? Think Romeo and Juliet with sexting thrown in.

title: Back to New Wave, Older and Somewhat Wiser
description: Reunited bands face a choice. Plan A is to ignore the missing years and pick up where they left off; Plan B, to acknowledge the gap and try to update the sound. The Cars lean toward Plan A. When the band played Roseland on Wednesday night, the big difference between their oldies and songs from their new album, Move Like This (Hear Music), was familiarity.

title: Medieval Style Files: Tailored Artistry
description: Can you judge a hunter by his houpeland, or a prince by his pouleines? You certainly can in Illuminating Fashion: Dress in the Art of Medieval France and the Netherlands at the Morgan Library & Museum. This lively show will teach you to scrutinize centuries-old manuscripts as you would a style magazine. (For the uninitiated: a houpeland is a high-waisted, drapey gown; pouleines are shoes with long, pointy toes.)

title: Whats Race Got to Do With It?
description: I am an Asian-American woman living in a mostly white town. Every day, I am asked bluntly: What are you? I get it from colleagues at work and people who have known me for less than five minutes. I find it so intrusive that sometimes I respond rudely. But even then, people will say, You sure dont look it. First, how should I respond to this question? And can you tell me why it upsets me so much?

title: Meeting Ratko Mladic
description: The Op-Ed columnist Roger Cohen recalls meeting Ratko Mladic in Belgrade in 1992.

title: A Tribute to Broadway
description: Images of New York City Ballets program set to music by Richard Rodgers, Leonard Bernstein and Duke Ellington.

title: The Case for Laugh Lines
description: THANK goodness it was drilled into me to greet people with the words, How do you do? Because these days, the question that springs more frequently to mind is, Who are you? Not because my memory is going, but because many of my acquaintances are erasing the traces of identity, if not life, from their faces.

title: 10 Tunes in One, Peeking From a Multitude of Stylistic Niches
description: The alto saxophonist Tim Berne, who often acts as if hes making a joke out of a disappointment, stood at the back of Korzo, a Hungarian restaurant in Brooklyn between the Prospect Expressway and Greenwood Cemetery. He announced that his trio would perform 13 new songs for the very first time  and that the last 10 would be joined together in one piece. Didnt you come up with a name for it? he asked his pianist, Matt Mitchell.

title: Spare Times for Memorial Day Observances
description: In the Area

title: Sophisticates Sketchbooks
description: Drawing is not hard. Children do it all the time. But there are degrees of difficulty, and to see it performed at the highest, most challenging level is a thrill. Even then, though, how do we distinguish different kinds and levels of achievement at the upper end?

title: A Marble Persephone From the Marquess
description: Here are two things auction house experts live for: making a discovery and selling it.

title: Scenes From a Wild Youth
description: CENTRAL PARK, for its size, is one of the most familiar patches of New York. Some people know it better than their own neighborhoods. But there is also a shadow park  a buried reservoir, an Indian cave, an ancient spring, among other things  that peeks out from time to time, but is essentially invisible to most visitors.

title: If Twitpics New Deal Troubles You, Here Are Some Options
description: Word got out this week that Twitpic, the most popular service used by Twitter users to upload and post photos, had struck an exclusive partnership with World Entertainment News Network, a news and photo agency that specializes in celebrity stories and pictures.

description: The doors of Theater for the New City will be bursting open with Lower East Side artists this weekend. The 16th annual Lower East Side Festival of the Arts runs Friday, Saturday and Sunday, with a packed lineup of theater, music, dance, comedy, film, exhibitions, performance art, kids entertainment and an all-day block party.

title: Best of the Worst: Readers Bad Course Recommendations
description: Charles McGraths essay for On Par earlier this week extolling the beauty of bad golf courses elicited a long list of tributes to the ugly ducklings of the game, settings that include 90-degree doglegs, abandoned cars, barbed wire and stubborn kangaroos.

title: Iraqi Shiite Militias Again Pose a Threat as U.S. Forces Leave
description: BAGHDAD  On a United States outpost in southern Iraq, rocket attacks by Shiite militants have grown so fierce that Americans there had to hunker down in a concrete bunker for several hours one recent night. Soldiers have curtailed missions to train Iraqi security forces, and American officials have even debated whether to close the outpost ahead of schedule.

description: A love triangle with fangs but no bite, the German import We Are the Night is mostly infatuated with its own stylish excesses.

title: Just Dozens Rally for Mladic in Belgrade
description: Srecko Sekeljic, a Serbian blogger who contributes to the Web site of B92, a Serbian broadcaster, reports that just 30 supporters of Ratko Mladic, the former commander of the Bosnian Serb Army, gathered in central Belgrade to protest his arrest on Thursday.

description: TOKYO  In Sonys 1993 comedy Groundhog Day, Bill Murray finds himself reliving the same dreary course of events, day after day.

description: This mornings Gallup poll  the first of Republican primary voters since Mitch Daniels and Mike Huckabee announced they wouldnt run for president  is getting a lot of attention for the seemingly strong standing of Sarah Palin, who polls at 15 percent amid signals that she may enter the race.

title: Making the Budget Work With Sleights of Hand
description: Ross Ramsey, the managing editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for the Tribune.

title: Life on the Fringe
description: The heroine (and title character) of J. B. Ghuman Jr.s debut feature, Spork, is part of a long line of teenage outcasts stretching from James Dean to Napoleon Dynamite. She has several of the classic markers of outsider status, including a trailer park address and comically bad hair. Oh, and shes a hermaphrodite.

title: What Makes a Man (or Woman) in a Marriage License? In Texas, Its Unclear
description: In a state that bans same-sex marriage, it would seem to be easy to know who can legally marry. Texas county clerks will tell you it is not.

description: Ludwig Mies van der Rohes modernist federal courthouse in Chicago is now hosting a glass-and- steel-encased buffet of old-fashioned misdeeds, admitted and alleged, featuring two very different protagonists.

title: The Round Goby, an Uninvited Resident of the Great Lakes, Is Doing Some Good
description: When John Janssen, a professor at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, found a round goby in Calumet Harbor in 1994, he feared the worst. The round goby, a small fish with an almost endearing wide-eyed stare, reproduces prolifically and eats voraciously. Mr. Janssen and other scientists expected it to gobble up eggs of prized sport fish and hog the mussels and snails that other fish would normally eat.

title: Devastating Injury for Giants Posey
description: Buster Posey ended last season by catching the final pitch of the World Series. He seems to have ended this season in a gruesome home-plate collision with Scott Cousins of Florida Marlins on Wednesday night.

title: Queen Bee of the Confederacy
description: When I first encountered Mary Chesnut as a starting point for exploring the American Civil War while an undergraduate at Harvard, I could not have been more fortunate. She provided a riveting antidote to the fiddle-dee-dee school of southern womanhood on which I had been weaned as a teenager in the 1960s. Although Scarlett OHara was a beguiling screen heroine, Mary Boykin Chesnut was a flesh and blood Rebel, whose wartime scribbling brought to life intimate and important aspects of southern culture. Since its publication in 1905, Chesnuts diary has become compelling reading. For example here, in an entry about Uncle Toms Cabin:

title: Badmintons New Dress Code Is Being Criticized as Sexist
description: In an attempt to revive flagging interest in womens badminton as the 2012 London Olympics approach, officials governing the sport have decided that its female athletes need to appear more, how to put it, womanly.

title: What Proof Does a Woman Have to Have?
description: Just over Heather Millstones shoulder, next to the cash register at her bar, a black-and-white TV monitor showed the flow of life along a few square yards of 13th Street between Avenues A and B in the East Village.

title: Aware of Its Dependence, Napa Takes Care of Migrant Workers
description: Scott James writes a column for The Bay Citizen.

title: The Path From Charity to Profit
description: On Tuesday I wrote about Kedai Balitaku, a for-profit company started last year by the development group Mercy Corps in Indonesia. Mercy Corps took this unusual step because it realized that its programs to educate mothers about nutrition were not changing what mothers fed their children. Healthy food is expensive, and the crowded conditions in the Jakarta slums mean that many families have no place to cook or eat. So they buy their children the cheapest street food, which is usually either sweet or deep fried. Kedai Balitaku, which usually goes by the name KeBal, aims to become a chain of street carts selling low-priced healthy food to children.

title: Could Japans Debt Lead to a Crisis?
description: Who would save Japan in a sovereign debt crisis? Ideally, it wont have one. But given the countrys terrifying challenges, some senior Japanese financial executives and government bureaucrats are quietly considering a doomsday situation. In a theoretical credit collapse, even China could come to the rescue.

title: Witchy Towns Worry: Do Too Many Psychics Spoil the Brew?
description: SALEM, Mass.  Like any good psychic, Barbara Szafranski claims she foresaw the problems coming.

title: The Teammate Dynamic at Monaco
description: MONACO  One of the things I have always loved about the Monaco Grand Prix is that I find here more than anywhere else that I can watch every single practice session and the qualifying session with almost the same amount of interest as the race.

title: Planning Effort Is Enlivened by Tea Party
description: The words flash onto a black screen: The New World Order is here. Dramatic music swells as the message continues: One Global Vision, Designed by the United Nations, To Strip you of Your Freedom.

title: Weight, Islanders Captain, Retires
description: UNIONDALE, N.Y.  Doug Weight, the Islanders captain, announced his retirement Thursday, ending a 19-year N.H.L. playing career that included 1,033 goals and assists, a Stanley Cup, an Olympic silver medal and a World Cup gold as part of the most decorated generation of American players.

title: Kraft Aims Kool-Aid Ads at a Growing Hispanic Market
description: IN a 2010 report by the Association of Hispanic Advertising Agencies that rated the top 500 American advertisers, Kraft Foods earned the rating of follower. Had Kraft, which had spent 3.8 percent of its ad budget on Hispanic media in 2009, spent just 3.6 percent, it would have been rated a laggard.

title: Shows Shed New Light on Life of Gertrude Stein
description: Gertrude Stein and her family and friends are the focus of two major San Francisco art exhibitions: Seeing Gertrude Stein: Five Stories at the Contemporary Jewish Museum and The Steins Collect: Matisse, Picasso, and the Parisian Avant-Garde at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art.

title: Pakistan and China: Two Friends Hit a Bump
description: BEIJING  This is officially the Year of Pakistan-China Friendship, and in a four-day visit to Beijing last week  the third in just 17 months  Pakistans prime minister, Yousaf Raza Gilani, proclaimed that the two best friends are like one nation and two countries. Chinese officials were reported to have presented Mr. Gilani with 50 fighter jets as a welcome gift.

title: The Audacity of Chinese Frauds
description: To pull off a fraud that humiliates the cream of the global financial elite, you need to have some friends. And where better to have them than at the local bank?

title: U.S. Announces Sanctions Against Israeli Company
description: JERUSALEM  Even as Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was praising the United States in a speech on Tuesday for imposing tougher sanctions on Iran for its nuclear activities, the State Department announced that it was imposing sanctions on a leading Israeli company, Ofer Brothers Group, for activities supporting Irans energy sector.

title: Senators Say Patriot Act Is Being Misinterpreted
description: WASHINGTON  Two senators claimed on Thursday that the Justice Department had secretly interpreted the so-called Patriot Act in a twisted way, enabling domestic surveillance activities that many members of Congress do not understand.

title: Abandoned in Toronto
description: The expansion Vancouver Whitecaps seemed to be headed for a berth in the preliminary round of next seasons Concacaf Champions League when Mother Nature intervened in Toronto on Wednesday night.

title: The Catalan Way to Grow Players on Home Soil
description: BARCELONA, Spain  The stone farmhouse, built in the 18th century as a country estate, is now surrounded by modern stadiums, high-rise buildings and hotels in a leafy and upscale neighborhood here, but it continues to produce a bountiful harvest.

title: In New Tack, Syrians Protest at Night to Elude Forces
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  In a shift in strategy, protesters across Syria have moved their daily demonstrations against the government of President Bashar al-Assad to the evening, in the expectation that security forces will be more reluctant to shoot at them and have a more difficult time identifying them for arrest, activists and organizers said.

title: Medicare and Mediscares
description: Yes, Paul Ryan, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, is a sore loser. Why do you ask?

title: Twisters Tale
description: In that swath of the American flatland that has been so brutalized of late, a 93-year-old woman gave me a warning. She had lost her house as a little girl, a homestead property of timber-sheltered memories that shattered in a twisters strike and took to the Oklahoma sky.

title: Veteran Mavericks Keep Focus on a Ring
description: DALLAS  The Dallas Mavericks yearned for this moment for five years, and a euphoric sense of a mission accomplished filled American Airlines Center as the owner Mark Cuban held aloft the Western Conference championship trophy and fans chanted: Beat the Heat! Beat the Heat!

title: Signs That Bin Laden Weighed Seeking Pakistani Protection
description: WASHINGTON  Documents seized at the compound where Osama bin Laden was killed show that he and his aides discussed making a deal with Pakistan in which Al Qaeda would refrain from attacking the country in exchange for protection inside Pakistan, American officials said Thursday.

title: Armstrong Strengthens Legal Team for Inquiry
description: To combat what his supporters call information leaks that have compromised the criminal investigation into his cycling career, Lance Armstrong this week hired two prominent lawyers who have had success against the government in a case relating to doping.

title: The Mideast Peace Process: No Plan for Talks
description: This is the time for bold ideas to salvage Israeli-Palestinian peace efforts. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel did not seize it. In his address to Congress, he showed  once again  that he has no serious appetite for the kind of compromises that are the only way to forge a two-state solution and guarantee both Palestinians their long-denied state and Israels long-term security.

title: Mysterious Illness Slows Up-and-Coming Driver
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  From mastery to mystery, no Nascar driver has taken more dramatic turns this season than Trevor Bayne.

title: Facebook Is Developing Ways to Share Media
description: Facebook is developing features that will make the sharing of users favorite music, television shows and other media as much a part of its site as playing games or posting vacation photos.

title: AT&Ts Plan to Buy T-Mobile May Reduce Competition, Legislators Warn
description: Members of Congress expressed concern Thursday that AT&Ts planned purchase of T-Mobile USA might thwart competition and raise prices for wireless users.

title: State of Uncertainty for Romney Camp as It Looks to Iowa
description: URBANDALE, Iowa  At this point four years ago, Mitt Romneys television commercials had been running here for 13 weeks. His campaign headquarters, bustling with activity, provided one of the best jobs around for Republican operatives. He fought hard to win the Iowa Straw Poll, an early test of organizing, and he did.

title: Heated Frenzy for Tech I.P.O.s Fails to Ignite Freescale
description: For the last several weeks, the market for initial public offerings looked red hot, thanks almost entirely to the eye-popping debut of the professional social network LinkedIn.

title: In Sadr City, a Rally for American Military Withdrawal
description: Supporters of the anti-American cleric Moktada al-Sadr staged a large rally in Baghdad on Thursday to demand that American forces leave.

title: A Hedge Fund Managers Latest Bet: The Mets
description: David Einhorn made his name on Wall Street by selling short. Famously, he bet against Lehman Brothers stock several months before the famed brokerage collapsed.

title: Conservative Group Wins Nonprofit Status From I.R.S.
description: The Internal Revenue Service has granted nonprofit status to the group that brought down two senior executives at NPR and dealt a death blow to the community organizing group Acorn with videos of its employees giving tax advice to people claiming to be a pimp and prostitute.

title: The Mideast Peace Process: Washington Makes Things Worse
description: Only a few minutes after President Obama finished his carefully balanced speech on the Middle East last week, Republican presidential candidates and lawmakers began twisting his words to suggest that he was calling for an epochal abandonment of Israel.

title: Christie Pulls New Jersey From 10-State Climate Initiative
description: Gov. Chris Christie said Thursday that New Jersey would become the first state to withdraw from a 10-state trading system, the Regional Greenhouse Gas Initiative, declaring it an ineffective way to reduce carbon dioxide emissions.

title: How the Other Half Lives, Still
description: At the Lower East Side Tenement Museum in Manhattan, visitors can view meticulously recreated moments in the lives of the immigrant families who lived there, like the Moores of Ireland. Their dark, stifling apartment sits ready for the wake of a baby girl, dead of malnutrition. This was in the 1870s, when Americas newcomers struggled mightily against poverty and isolation.

title: Lottery Numbers
Despite Its Great Case, Jurors Say, Prosecution Couldnt Prove Claim of Sexual Assault
description: To spectators in the Manhattan courtroom, it was a mundane moment: a court stenographer reading in a monotone voice the testimony of a woman who said she was raped by a police officer.

title: End of the Line
description: In 1995, some 8,000 Bosnian Muslim men and boys were massacred in the town of Srebrenica. It was the worst ethnically motivated mass murder in Europe since World War II. Now, finally, Ratko Mladic, the Bosnian Serb general who masterminded that butchery, is where he should be  in custody, facing prosecution before the International Criminal Court and, we hope, a lifetime in prison.

title: Study Questions Treatment Used in Heart Disease
description: WASHINGTON  Lowering bad cholesterol levels reduces heart attack risks, and researchers have long hoped that raising good cholesterol would help, too. Surprising results from a large government study announced on Thursday suggest that this hope may be misplaced.

title: Jury in Bronx Drunken Driving Case Hears About Routine Ticket-Fixing
description: Ticket-fixing dominated a Bronx drunken driving trial on Thursday, as a police officer who gave a Breathalyzer test to the defendant testified that he had sought help from a top police union official to get two tickets fixed for family members, and, as a favor to the official, had tried to help get a ticket disposed of for another officers nephew.

title: Andretti Wants to Win, for Grandpa
description: INDIANAPOLIS  Marco Andretti made sure to stick a pair of sunglasses in his shirt Thursday afternoon, even though rain drenched the Indianapolis Motor Speedway again. He learned a while ago how quickly the weather changes at this place.

title: Medicare Survival Guide
description: Sometime this summer, the Democrats and the Republicans will go toe-to-toe over whether to raise the debt ceiling. At the height of the confrontation, President Obama may well address the country and say that even though he has offered the Republicans more than $1 trillion in spending cuts (unspecified), the Republicans have not been willing to compromise on a deal. He will then announce that, even without an agreement, the U.S. will still have enough money to continue payments to its creditors.

title: Mortgage Companies Settle Suits on Military Foreclosures
description: Two mortgage servicing companies have agreed to settle federal complaints that they wrongfully foreclosed on the homes of at least 178 military service members and to set aside a minimum of $22 million to compensate those victims.

title: In Game 7, the Bruins Are Counting on Thomas to Be Extraordinary
description: Tim Thomass importance to the Boston Bruins cannot be understated. It has been proved time and again that if he is not standing on his head in the nets, the Bruins will probably lose.

title: Observing a Lacrosse Pioneer, McPhee Style
description: When Bill Tierney coached Princeton to six national championships, he was under the surveillance of the Academic-Athletic Fellow of Mens Lacrosse.

title: When Childrens Scribbles Hide a Prison Drug
description: WINDHAM, Me.  Mike Barrett, a corrections officer, ripped open an envelope in the mail room at the Maine Correctional Center here and eyed something suspicious: a Fathers Day card, sent a month early. He carefully felt the card and slit it open, looking for a substance that has made mail call here a different experience of late.

title: Public Services for Memorial Day Holiday
description: NEW YORK

title: Friday: Drama Halls
description: FRIDAYS PUZZLE  Friday puzzles bring out the weird side of me as a solver.

title: Inside Meghan McCains Bachelorette Pad
description: The famous daughter of the famous senator shows off her 1,100-square-foot bachelorette home in West Hollywood.

title: Contador Appeal Is Postponed
description: Alberto Contador, the three-time Tour de France winner and current leader of the Giro dItalia, may be clear to race in this summers Tour after the appeal regarding his doping case was postponed Thursday from early June to a yet-to-be-set date. That appeal, in which the Court of Arbitration for Sport would decide Contadors fate after he tested positive for the banned drug clenbuterol last July, was supposed to be resolved before the Tour began July 2. If he were to lose the appeal, he could receive up to a two-year ban from the sport. His Tour title could also be stripped. In February, the Spanish cycling federation cleared Contador of any wrongdoing, but the International Cycling Union and the World Anti-Doping Agency appealed. The appeal was postponed because both sides needed more time to prepare for the hearing, the court said on its Web site.

title: A Cure for the Radio Industry?
description: DAR, a new internet service, is essentially "Tivo for the radio." It may be just what the doctor ordered.

title: Ex-Newark Mayor Is Accused of Misusing Campaign Funds
description: NEWARK  Sharpe James got out of prison last year, but he cannot seem to stay out of court.

title: Neighborly Advice to the Palins: In Arizona, the Sun Burns
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.  Alaska may have a midnight sun, but Arizonas burns a little hotter. So the first advice that Sarah Palins new neighbors have for her is: wear sunscreen.

title: Belarus: Ex-Presidential Candidates Are Sentenced
description: Belarus sentenced two former presidential candidates to lengthy prison terms on Thursday for organizing a large protest against elections held in December that independent observers said were tainted by widespread fraud. The former Soviet republics authoritarian president won the election. The two former candidates, Nikolai Statkevich and Dmitri Uss, received six and five-and-a-half year sentences, respectively. The convictions came a day after President Aleksandr G. Lukashenko suggested that he might free his political opponents, remarks broadly interpreted as a signal to the West that he might be willing to negotiate to secure a badly needed loan. But the convictions seemed to indicate the presidents hard line would not soon soften.

title: Setback for Top Prosecutor as Another Big Test Looms
description: In the final days of the trial against two police officers charged with rape, the Manhattan district attorney, Cyrus R. Vance Jr., made a move that his legendary predecessor, Robert M. Morgenthau, would not have contemplated:

title: Qaddafi Flees to Hospitals to Dodge Bombs, Reports Say
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi has responded to intensified NATO bombing of the Libyan capital by seeking sanctuary at night in hospitals he knows will not be bombed, according to a British official accompanying Prime Minister David Cameron to a summit meeting in Deauville, France.

title: Blagojevich Chokes Up as He Defends Himself
description: CHICAGO  I used to be your governor, and Im here today to tell you the truth, former Gov. Rod R. Blagojevich of Illinois said in his federal corruption retrial Thursday.

title: The Medicare Election
description: To the Editor:

title: John Delaney, Founder of Intrade, Dies at 42
description: John Delaney, an Irish businessman who founded Intrade, an online prediction market that allows customers to bet on world political, entertainment and financial events, died on Saturday after coming within 50 yards of the summit of Mount Everest. He was 42.

title: Questions Follow Leader of For-Profit Colleges
description: In 2004, when Todd S. Nelson was chief executive of the University of Phoenix, the nations largest for-profit college, he signed a $9.8 million settlement with the Department of Education, which found that Phoenix had systematically and intentionally broken the federal rules against paying recruiters for students.

title: A Fraud Played Out on Family and Friends
description: IDAHO FALLS  Never mind that he was a multimillionaire. Daren Palmer was quick to carry furniture when someone in his congregation was moving. He volunteered at the church farm. He got down on his knees to clean the sanctuary.

title: The Battle for Libya | May 26, 2011
description: Libyan rebel soldiers mourned a comrade and took positions at the front line near Misurata.

title: U.S. Seeks to Withhold Secret Data From Judge
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration sought Thursday to prevent a lawyer for a former C.I.A. officer convicted in Italy in the kidnapping of a radical Muslim cleric from privately sharing classified information about the case with a Federal District Court judge.

title: Sanchez Leads Way as Marlins Sweep
description: MARLINS 1, GIANTS 0 Anibal Sanchez threw a five-hitter as Florida completed a three-game sweep in San Francisco. Sanchez (4-1) struck out eight and walked two for his fifth career complete game. (AP)

title: South Carolina: Stance on School Aid Is Criticized
description: South Carolinas education superintendent, Mick Zais, faced criticism on Thursday, the day after announcing that the state would not compete for federal money in the Obama administrations Race to the Top school improvement competition. The chairman of the Charleston Education Network, a nonprofit advocacy group, told The Charleston Post and Courier that children would pay the price. Mr. Zais, a Republican, said this years $200 million grant competition amounted to pieces of silver in exchange for strings attached to Washington.

title: Vermont: Governor Signs Health Care Law
description: Gov. Peter Shumlin signed a bill on Thursday that sets Vermont on a path to creating the nations first publicly financed health care system. The law calls for something close to a single-payer system, with doctors and hospitals billing one entity, the state government, for their services. All 620,000 of the states residents would be eligible for coverage under the system, which proponents say would be cheaper than the current patchwork of insurers. A board appointed by the governor will determine payment rates for doctors, benefits and other details.

title: Leonora Carrington Is Dead at 94; Artist and Author of Surrealist Work
description: Leonora Carrington, a British-born Surrealist and onetime romantic partner of Max Ernst whose paintings depicted women and half-human beasts floating in a dreamscape of images drawn from myth, folklore, religious ritual and the occult, died on Wednesday in Mexico City, where she lived. She was 94.

title: Florida: Generals Deportation Hearing Ends
description: After three days of testimony in immigration court in Orlando, a hearing ended in the deportation trial of Eugenio Vides Casanova, a retired general from El Salvador accused of participating in torture there during the civil war in the 1980s. General Vides, who as defense minister was a close American ally, testified on Thursday. Judge James Grim said he would decide whether to order General Vides deported in January.

title: Too Much Fun to Feel Sad at the Farewell to Elaines
description: Alec Baldwin ate dinner in a packed corner, one table over from the actress Linda Fiorentino, a few steps from the author Gay Talese and dozens of bent elbows away from producers, journalists and others lucky enough to get inside.

title: Brookdale Hospital Workers Protest Loss of Health Care
description: About 3,400 workers at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn have lost their health care coverage, because the hospital has fallen behind in payments to its benefits fund, the union that represents many of the hospitals workers said Thursday.

title: Tough Task Awaits Yanks in Seattle
description: The best pitcher in the American League last season, Felix Hernandez is not even the best pitcher on his team this year.

title: Heat Gains Finals as Stars Rally Late
description: CHICAGO  There are perhaps a thousand ways to seize a conference title, but none more emphatic, more authoritative or more vehement than the method LeBron James chose Thursday night to send the Miami Heat to the N.B.A. finals.

title: Corrections
description: FRONT PAGE

title: Azerbaijan: Pardon for Political Prisoner
description: The president of Azerbaijan on Thursday pardoned one of the countrys most prominent political prisoners, a journalist who was convicted of defamation and terrorism after writing articles critical of the authorities, Azeri news agencies reported. Human rights organizations hailed the decision, with the Committee to Protect Journalists calling it a victory against injustice. The case of the journalist, Eynulla Fatullayev, was the subject of a 2010 ruling by the European Court of Human Rights, which demanded his immediate release. The state did not release him and began a new prosecution, on charges of drug possession, eventually sentencing him to an additional two and a half years. Mr. Fatullayev told Amnesty International he was at home with his family Thursday, and thanked those who campaigned for his release. In my opinion, you saved me, he said.

title: Word of the Day | anomaly
description: anomaly \-n-m-le\ noun

title: Scottsdale, in Facts and Figures
description: Some things the Palins may not know about Scottsdale:

title: Arthur Goldreich, a Leader of the Armed Fight to End Apartheid, Dies at 82
description: Arthur Goldreich, who helped lead the armed struggle against apartheid in South Africa and once posed as the operator of a farm where Nelson Mandela, masquerading as his houseboy, plotted revolt, died on Tuesday in Tel Aviv . He was 82.

title: In Tense Post-Bin Laden Trip to Pakistan, Clinton Seeks Firm Action on Extremists
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Secretary of State Hillary Rodham Clinton warned Friday that relations between the United States and Pakistan had reached a turning point, and called on Pakistans leaders to take urgent measures against Islamic extremists in the wake of the killing of Osama bin Laden.

title: Marriage in Egypt
description: In Egypt and across the Middle East, many young people are being forced to put off marriage, the gateway to independence, sexual activity and societal respect.

title: News Quiz | May 27, 2011
description: See what you know about the news below. To prepare, you might scan the articles or summaries on todays paper.

title: Inflation Notes
description: Three short items:

title: No Ideas
description: Ezra Klein points us to the House GOPs rather pitiful jobs manifesto. Ezra describes it as now more than ever: the GOPs response to the employment crisis is to demand exactly the same things it demands when the economy is doing well.

title: Daily Lexeme: Torpefy
description: Todays word, in association with the venerated Oxford English Dictionary, is

title: In Hong Kong, MGM I.P.O. Prices at High End
description: A joint venture between MGM Resorts International and the daughter of a Hong Kong casino mogul raised $1.5 billion on Friday in its initial public offering, highlighting the strong appetite for stocks that have a large exposure to China.

title: Test Yourself | History, May 27, 2011
description: Test your knowledge of history with todays question about former President Bill Clinton.

title: No Trial for Arizona Shooting Suspect
description: WHO is Jared L. Loughner?

title: Outside Elaines, Another Closing
description: Of all the folks who will be disappointed at the closing of Elaines, one must include Warren Cofield, 49, who has been as much a regular as anyone at the famous Second Avenue bote, mingling among the swells.

title: Are You Popular, Quirky or Conformist?
description: A writer named Alexandra Robbins  who was, she says, a dork in high school  believes that often the quirky people with offbeat or unpopular interests who are rejected and ridiculed in high school go on to become interesting, creative, successful adults. Why do you think offbeat teens are often social outsiders? Why do teenagers tend to embrace conformity instead of individuality?

title: Controversy and Fabric at Emin Show in London
description: In the world of British art, only Damien Hirst has raised as much controversy as the 48-year-old artist Tracey Emin, who became an overnight sensation with her work Everyone I Have Ever Slept With 19631995. The tent, appliqud with names and decorated with graphic mementos from her love life, was shown at the Charles Saatchi exhibition at the Royal Academy in London in 1997.

title: The Case for Higher Taxes
description: Uwe E. Reinhardt is an economics professor at Princeton.

title: The Early Word: Setting a Precedent
description: Todays Times

title: Ex-Chrysler Executive Plugs In for Second Act
description: Once upon a time, when auto executives retired, they actually retired. These days, those who arent advising niche sports-car manufacturers are joining up with electric-vehicle companies.

title: Tip of the Week: Netflix Streaming in Other Languages
description: Netflix continues to make progress on its project to add subtitles to its streaming video library. The company recently announced an update to its iOS app that brings subtitles to selected movies and TV shows on the iPad, iPod Touch and iPhone. If subtitles are available for the video that is playing, a caption icon appears on screen. Tap the caption icon to see the list of available subtitle languages.

title: Aid Pledge by Group of 8 Seeks to Bolster Arab Democracy
description: DEAUVILLE, France  Leaders of the Group of 8 wealthiest industrialized nations pledged on Friday to send billions of dollars in aid to Egypt and Tunisia, hoping to reduce the threat that economic stagnation could undermine the transition to democracy.

title: Saudi Arabia Scrambles to Limit Regions Upheaval
description: RIYADH, Saudi Arabia  Saudi Arabia is flexing its financial and diplomatic might across the Middle East in a wide-ranging bid to contain the tide of change, shield other monarchies from popular discontent and avert the overthrow of any more leaders struggling to calm turbulent nations.

title: North Korea Frees American Held Since November, Reports Say
description: BEIJING  An American who had been detained for six months in North Korea arrived in Beijing on Saturday following his release a day earlier, a U.S. Embassy spokesman said.

title: Airstrikes Reported East of Yemen Capital
description: SANA, Yemen  More than 100 tribal fighters overran a military checkpoint northeast of the Yemeni capital on Friday, killing several soldiers and taking control of a strategic gateway to the city, according to tribesmen and witnesses. Five tribesmen were also killed, they said.

title: JetBlue vs. Continental: Battle of the Airline Web Sites
description: Last week in my post, Whats Wrong and Whats Right with These Web Sites, I asked you to compare two sites, Continental.com and JetBlue.com.

title: And Now, Fresh Clams and Salty Air
description: Hamptons-bound traffic in the summer is a sweaty, hectic, BMW-infested mess. But thats not your problem. As you soar down the Long Island Expressway, past the long line of frustrated New Yorkers waiting to debark at Exit 70, grin and wave, because youre not going to the Hamptons, pal. Youre headed for the North Fork  and straight to Claudios Clam Bar.

title: Security Forces Restrained as Syrian Protests Spread
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  Thousands of Syrians took to the streets again on Friday in virtually every region of the country, but in some locales, Syrian security forces showed restraint in not firing on the demonstrations in a possible bid to keep down a death toll that has brought growing international pressure and strained relations with Syrias few allies.

title: A Bright Side to the Bulb Changeover
description: As I noted in an article in Thursdays Home section, some interior designers whose results depend on precisely the right lighting are hoarding incandescent light bulbs before they are phased out under congressional legislation. But not all decorators are wedded to the incandescent.

title: Setting Browser Tabs to Open at Start-Up
description: Do you find yourself hitting the same group of Web sites every time you sit down at your computer? For me, its Facebook, The Times, Instapundit, Techmeme, my bank, and my Google Docs spreadsheet of freelance assignments. In fact, I open three separate Facebook tabs - one for my messages, and two for groups in which Im active. Most people have a similar set of pages they open over and over, several times a day.

title: Elderly Drivers Fail a Test
description: True or false? Most older drivers drive as safely as anyone else. Its just that a few bad apples, particularly those behind the wheel despite poor vision or dementia, make mistakes and produce the statistics showing that per mile driven, drivers over age 75 are almost as dangerous as teenagers.

title: The Reincarnation of Pro-Life
description: Ever since Republicans took control of half the countrys statehouses this year, the anti-abortion movement has won one victory after another. At least 64 new anti-abortion laws have passed, with more than 30 of them in April alone. The campaign is the largest in history and also the most creative. Virginia started regulating abortion clinics as if they were hospitals. Utah, Nebraska and several other states have stopped private health insurers from covering abortions, with rare exceptions. South Dakota will soon tell women that before they go to an abortion clinic, they must first visit a crisis pregnancy center whose mission is to talk them out of it.

title: David Mamet Explains His Shift to the Right
description: While reading your new book, The Secret Knowledge, I thought, My God, in crucifying liberals, this guy is going to infuriate a huge chunk of the people who pay money to see plays. Are you concerned that youre alienating your public?  Ive been alienating my public since I was 20 years old. When American Buffalo came out on Broadway, people would storm out and say, How dare he use that kind of language! Of course Im alienating the public! Thats what they pay me for.

title: Vital Information?
description: I am an H.I.V.-positive man who, thanks to antiretroviral therapy, has had an undetectable viral load for the past three years. I have no sexually transmitted infections. Though I always practice safe sex, I feel an obligation to disclose my status to any potential partner well before engaging in any sexual contact. My doctors disagree, citing evidence that people in my condition are sexually noninfectious. Others make a buyer-beware type of argument. Am I right, or are they? NAME WITHHELD, ENGLEWOOD CLIFFS, N.J.

title: Bonus Feature: The Enthusiast
description: This weeks enthusiast: Jason McBride, senior editor at www.torontostandard.com

title: Egypts Next Crisis
description: On a recent Wednesday morning, Zakaria Mohyeldin steered his fathers black Skoda sedan through a thick belt of Cairo traffic and drove northward into the sleepy farmland of the Nile Delta. Mohyeldin, a tall, broad-shouldered 27-year-old with a jutting chin and a thicket of jet-black hair, had just quit his job as a stockbroker trainee. The revolution was almost three months old, and the hard work was just beginning, he told me. Mohyeldin had seen his life transformed during those amazing 18 days: battling police in clouds of tear gas, ferrying food to the protesters in Tahrir Square and cheering in awe as Hosni Mubarak, Egypts modern-day pharaoh, was cast out in a youth-led revolt. Now he wanted to see what he could do to spread the revolutions high ideals in Egypts agricultural heartland. And he was vaguely contemplating a political career, starting in the village of Kafr Shukr, where his grandfather, a former prime minister, was born.

title: Underground in Vietnam
description: As tourists in Vietnam, my friend Vince and I ate coconut candy and rode bicycles around the Mekong Delta. We lunched on a fish that looked like Harry Dean Stanton and joked uneasily about Agent Orange. Now, as part of the same package tour, our no-name bus took us to the Cu Chi Tunnels, the infamous Viet Cong network that snakes below the jungle northwest of Ho Chi Minh City. We were going to slot our bodies into a hole in the ground and try not to entomb ourselves.

title: Report Details Last Minutes of Doomed Air France Jet
description: PARIS  The captain of the Air France jet that crashed in the Atlantic two years ago was in the cockpit, though not at the controls, as the crew struggled to recover from a high-altitude stall, according to an initial chronology of the flights final moments published Friday by French investigators.

title: Greek Leaders Fail to Reach Consensus on Austerity
description: ATHENS  At an emergency meeting on Friday, the countrys political leaders failed to agree on new austerity measures proposed by the government, but Prime Minister George Papandreou said there was still hope that an agreement would be reached.

title: World Leaders Optimism On Economy Lifts Shares
description: Stocks rose Friday as comments from the Group of 8 industrial nations about the global economys strength offset a slump in home sales in the United States.

title: Schiavone Advances After Peng Retires
description: PARIS  Pushing her opponent from sideline to sideline paid off for Francesca Schiavone of Italy, the defending French Open champion, who reached the fourth round Friday when her opponent, Shuai Peng of China, was forced to withdraw with a leg injury.

title: With Chinese Cash, Saab Starts Rolling Again
description: Cars at the Saab plant in Trollhattan started rolling off the assembly line again Friday as the head of the companys prospective Chinese partner, Pang Da Automobiles chief executive, Pang Qinghua, paid a visit to the factory.

title: Bachmann Plans Iowa Announcement
description: DES MOINES  Representative Michele Bachmann of Minnesota said Thursday evening that she intended to announce her decision on whether to join the Republican presidential race in June during a visit to her hometown of Waterloo, Iowa.

title: Stosur Is Surprised by Dulko in French Open
description: PARIS  The day started poorly for Samantha Stosur of Australia. Her first forehand sailed far over the baseline at the start of her match with Gisela Dulko of Argentina.

title: Is Sarah Palin Pulling a Donald Trump?
description: Is Sarah Palin pulling a Donald Trump on the political universe?

title: Lawyer Seeks Medical Evaluation of Mladic, War Crimes Suspect
description: BELGRADE, Serbia  Life on the run has not been kind to Ratko Mladic, a fugitive in his own land from war crimes charges. His mouth droops sideways and his skin is bluish and mottled red, the pallor of poor hygiene, bad nutrition and self-imposed prison, according to his longtime friend and defense lawyer, Milos Saljic.

title: London Underground | An Old Mills Second Wind
description: Flour milling is not the first thing that comes to mind when you think of Brixton, a neighborhood in South London that is better known for jerk chicken and live music. Owned by the Lambeth Council, the Brixton Windmill has just reopened this month after a 580,000 (about $937,000) renovation. The effort was initiated by a local residents group, the Friends of Windmill Gardens, which was established in 2003 to restore the landmarked but derelict windmill and transform its surrounding park. The restoration and landscaping, which were overseen by Dannatt Johnson Architects, took seven months to complete, and the building now looks unpretentious yet elegant, with a tasteful color scheme.

title: Champions League Final Open Thread: Who Will Make the Difference?
description: A day before Barcelona and Manchester United will meet the Champions League final in London, the preparations have all been made. But fate has a funny way of spoiling the best-laid plans.

title: Federer Cruises Past Tipsarevic
description: PARIS  In the 65th minute of their third-round match, Janko Tipsarevic of Serbia raced to the net to reach a drop shot by Roger Federer of Switzerland.

title: Popcast: Idol Post-Mortem
description: Did Scotty McCreerys bulging eyes win him the American Idol title?

title: Morning Take-Out
description: Former Nasdaq Executive Pleads Guilty to Insider Trading | For years, Donald L. Johnson was a gatekeeper at the Nasdaq OMX Group, whose role at the exchanges market intelligence unit helped him counsel companies on stock-moving strategy.

title: How Paris Created America
description: David McCullough has stressed Frances pre-eminent role in American history for years. We would not, he has argued, have a country without the French, who have permanently and profoundly shaped us. If anyone could get away with suggesting that room be made on Mount Rushmore for Astrix it is McCullough. He seems to have had something else in mind, however. With The Greater Journey: Americans in Paris, he explores the intellectual legacy that France settled on its 19th-century visitors. The result is an epic of ideas, as well as an exhilarating book of spells.

title: Downtown and Underground, an Outpost of Noise
description: Beneath the incense burners and chanting celebrating the 2,555th anniversary of Buddhas birth at a Chinese temple upstairs, an unearthly din rose from the basement of 13 Monroe Street in Chinatown the other Sunday to observe a more recent anniversary. The extended 20th birthday party of the Downtown Music Gallery, purveyors of progressive music of all stripes since 1991, was in full, lurching swing, and more than a dozen brave souls huddled around a makeshift stage for another weekly ritual, a free performance series that gives literal meaning to the term underground music.

title: Japan Tries to Ease Fury of Parents Near Plant
description: TOKYO  Responding to fury among parents in Fukushima, Japans education minister said Friday that the country would set a lower radiation exposure limit for schoolchildren in areas around a stricken nuclear plant and pay for schools to remove contaminated topsoil from fields and playgrounds.

title: Student Crossword | The Industrial Revolution
description: Play our crossword (PDF) to see what you know about the Industrial Revolution. You can find the answers here.

title: Friday Reading: Raising Good Cholesterol May Not Help Fight Heart Attacks
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: The Secret Life of Cairos Jews
description: About 120 years ago, a cache of manuscripts, mostly fragments, was discovered in the storeroom of an old Cairo synagogue. Its members had deposited them there over many centuries. This collection of documents managed to be both heterogeneous and comprehensive at the same time.

title: A Novel of Surreal America, with Rabid Dog
description: Bob, the first-name-only protagonist of Toward You, Jim Krusoes unsettling fourth novel, is a man much obsessed with death. A reupholsterer of antiques by trade and a congenital loser by nature, Bob spends his free hours in the (amazingly named) fictional town of St. Nils tinkering with a device he calls the Communicator, whose purpose is to breach the wall separating the living and the dead. Bobs vanity and his avarice  both seemingly small-time  drive him to this work, and faint dreams of wealth, fame and sexual satisfaction pervade his quotidian existence.

title: Adultery in the U. K.
description: The people in Tessa Hadleys latest novel, The London Train, seem to be managing the trials of adulthood reasonably well, right up until the moment their lives jump the tracks. Their problems are the familiar and expected ones  grief at the death of a parent, career disappointments, marital friction  although that makes them no less difficult or wrenching. No one is more surprised than Hadleys characters when they act on irrational impulse. She sets out to make these blinkered lives plausible, and then to subvert our natural sympathy into something more resembling judgment.

title: Rebirth of a Poet
description: Arvind Krishna Mehrotra's new translation of Kabir brings the poetry of the great 15th-century Indian poet and holy man to life in English for the first time. Not that others havent tried: Pound, Robert Bly and, most notably, Rabindranath Tagore in 1915, with a version consisting of thees, thous and thines, delivered in a sandalwood-scented prayer-book-ese that would not have been out of place atop a teak sidetable at one of Mme. Blavatskys legendary seances. But it is Mehrotra who has succeeded in capturing the ferocity and improvisational energy of Kabirs poetry.

title: Roddy Doyles Dubliners
description: Four Irishmen walk into a pub and start talking international affairs. Poor oul Benazir. What a place. Mad. Would you have given her one? Oh, yeah. Absolutely. But youve heard this one before: were in a story by Roddy Doyle  the title story, in fact, of his new collection, Bullfighting. Old friends. Pints of Guinness. The running patter of filthy jokes. We could almost be back in Barrytown, the fictional Dublin suburb whose inhabitants Doyle brought to such boisterous, profanity-fueled life back in the late 1980s and early 90s.

title: Why Life is So Boring
description: In the 13th canto of Byrons Don Juan, our usually adventurous hero finds himself becalmed in English society, which, Byron reports,  . . . is now one polishd horde, / Formd of two mighty tribes, the Bores and Bored.

title: Noah Webster, Founding Father
description: Even if he had never written his famous dictionary, Noah Webster (1758-1843) would be regarded as one of the most interesting and influential figures of the early days of the American republic. His phenomenally popular American Spelling Book, first published in 1783, outsold every book in the 19th century except the Bible. His relentless book promotion pioneered now common techniques like the author tour, the fabricated blurb and the aggressive stoking of manufactured controversy. His efforts to protect his work from piracy contributed to the development of American copyright laws. In 1793 he founded American Minerva, the first daily newspaper in New York City, eight years before Alexander Hamilton started The New York Post. He helped to establish Amherst College.

title: How to Care for Your Mother
description: Combining personal narrative with practical advice, as Jane Gross does in A Bittersweet Season, is a tricky business. A reader swept up in a story is apt to resent the intrusion of brass tacks. And a reader looking for how-tos will have little use for the details of an authors own tale. Particularly perilous are the transitions between the instructional and the essayistic  passages reminiscent of the fraught moments in Broadway musicals when ordinary speech must lift into song. There is the actor, speaking his lines; suddenly he leans on his pitchfork, squints into the distance and breaks into a soaring rendition of Oh, What a Beautiful Morning.

title: In Shift, Russia Agrees to Try to Talk Qaddafi Into Leaving
description: MOSCOW  President Dmitri A. Medvedev on Friday offered to leverage Russias relationships in Libya to try to persuade Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi to leave power, an act of long-shot diplomacy that for the first time casts Russia as a central player in events unfolding in North Africa.

title: Is World War II Still the Good War?
description: In February, the last surviving American veteran of the First World War died. It is hard to imagine the day when we say goodbye to the last survivor of the Second World War, so large do the good war and the greatest generation still loom in the national imagination. But the calendar and the census do not lie. Some 16 million Americans served in the military during World War II. On the 60th anniversary of the attack on Pearl Harbor in 2001, about 5.5 million were still living. This year, as we prepare to mark the 70th anniversary, the number is closer to 1.5 million, and it drops by almost a thousand a day.

title: What Did Qaddafis Green Book Really Say?
description: If Libyas ragtag coalition of rebels manages to dislodge Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi from power it will mean not only the fall of the longest reigning dictator in the Arab world but also the end of the ambitious ideological system that he dreamed would supersede all rivals. While much of the world sees him as an eccentric and brutal demagogue, Qaddafi has tried for decades to portray himself as a statesman-philosopher. Its an aspiration best embodied in the Green Book, his notorious three-part meditation on politics, economics and everything from the evils of mechanized poultry farming to the importance of owning ones car. In Libya, the text is omnipresent: several generations of students grew up studying it, and the government even constructed sculptures in its image.

title: Up Front
description: It shouldnt be surprising that a writer whose work includes a story collection called Throw Like a Girl and a novel called The Woman Driver should have strong opinions on the pigeonholing of writers by gender. Jean Thompson, whose latest novel, The Year We Left Home, has just been published, is a longtime practitioner of what she described in a recent e-mail as the sturdy realistic tradition that she shares with the British writer Tessa Hadley, whose novel The London Train she reviews on Page 13. Hadley, Thompson noted, is a first-rate psychologist who immerses the reader in her characters using a particularly intimate form of third-person narrator. And Hadley has presented half of her novel  which delves into some of the familiar problems of modern life also found in the womens novels one of the characters reads  from the perspective of a man. When I taught writing, Thompson recalled, inevitably students loved to worry this point, how you could identify male or female writing. So I brought in some blind samples: women writing about sea voyages, men writing about intense emotional experiences. When I asked them to guess the authors gender, they fell right into that famous trap. The Editors

title: Editors Choice
description: THE ANATOMY OF INFLUENCE: Literature as a Way of Life,  by Harold Bloom (Yale University, $32.50.) Bloom, now 80, offers a kind of summing-up of ideas from his sterling career in criticism, and reaffirms his vows of fidelity to Shakespeare.

title: Paperback Row
description: WHAT IS LEFT THE DAUGHTER,  by Howard Norman (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $13.95.) In this epistolary novel, set in Nova Scotia during World War II, Wyatt Hillyer reaches out to a 21-year-old daughter he hasnt seen or spoken to since 1948, when she was 2.
