Beginning with the day his mother and father commit suicide within hours of each other, Wyatts layered tale encompasses unrequited love, murder and German U-boats prowling Canadas eastern shore.

title: N.Y.U. Lands Top Economist for Cities Project
description: New York University has landed a star economist: Paul Romer, a leading expert on economic growth, who has been at Stanford for the last 15 years. Mr. Romer has been a visiting professor at N.Y.U. this year.

title: Chalaque
description: The British police code name for President Obamas state visit to the United Kingdom.

title: Landmines in a Good Bank/Bad Bank Split
description: A recent bankruptcy case reminds us how hard it would have been for Lehman Brothers to implement its good bank/bad bank plan to avoid Chapter 11. And why corporations cant really expect to ditch their troubles by the side of the road, despite what some conspiracy theorists might think.

title: What Were Reading
description: A collection of links by the reporters and editors of the Dining section.

title: To End All Wars
description: To the Editor:

title: Among The Truthers
description: To the Editor:

title: The Balance of Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington and Wall Street: The Revolving Door
description: Its hardly news that the near meltdown of Americas financial system enriched a few at the expense of the rest of us. Whos responsible? The recent report of the Financial Crisis Inquiry Commission blamed all the usual suspects  Wall Street banks, financial regulators, the mortgage giants Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, and subprime lenders  which is tantamount to blaming no one. Reckless Endangerment concentrates on particular individuals who played key roles.

title: Consultant on Payroll Project Is Arrested
description: A former consulting company executive was charged on Friday with receiving at least $5 million in illegal kickbacks in connection with his work as a project manager on the CityTime automated payroll project, people briefed on the matter said.

title: Inside the List
description: LETS GO CRAZY: Celebrities may rule the best-seller list, but psychopaths still rule the world. At least thats the hypothesis floated by Jon Ronson in The Psychopath Test, new at No. 11 on the hardcover nonfiction list. In the book, Ronson (inset) consorts with psychologists, corporate titans, madmen, Scientologists and a cabal of giant, blood-drinking, child-sacrificing pedophile lizardsoh, sorry, those guys were actually from Ronsons earlier book Them  in an effort to prove that those afflicted with mad striving for unlimited success and excessive admiration profoundly shape society and, more important, can be identified with the help of a simple 20-item checklist. Alas, Ronson finds only one high-profile potential psychopath willing to take the test: Albert (Chainsaw Al) Dunlap, the corporate cost-cutting king. (You know how I said in my e-mail that your amygdala might not shoot the requisite signals of fear to your central nervous system and thats perhaps why youve been so successful? Ronson asks gingerly.) Not that Ronson presents himself as the picture of mental health. After consulting the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual IV, he concludes that he may suffer from no fewer than 12 mental ailments, including general anxiety disorder, arithmetic learning disorder, caffeine induced disorder, and malingering.

title: Beer Gardens Everywhere
description: THERE are some who thought, prematurely, that 2010 was New Yorks summer of the beer garden, what with the World Cup and the opening of a half-dozen outdoor, German-style drinking establishments. But not unlike some genetically altered superweed, these ale-and-oompah joints have continued even this year to crop up everywhere you look. They have grown so thick, so fast, that certain neighborhoods (Astoria in Queens and Williamsburg in Brooklyn come to mind) could, with the proper vantage and the help of several pilsners, be mistaken for Bavaria.

title: Why I.P.O.s Get Underpriced
description: The debate over the pricing of initial public offerings has been vigorous.

title: 225,000 Jeep Wranglers Investigated for Potential Air-Bag Failure
description: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration has opened investigations into drivers side air bags that may not deploy on Jeep Wranglers.

title: Pop Shop
description: As if there werent enough reasons for fashionistas to prowl Londons tony Mount Street, Nicholas Kirkwoods graphic new shop features the shoe designers entire collection, including highly coveted collaborations with Rodarte, Erdem and Peter Pilotto, and a clutch of wildly creative cartoon-like confections inspired by the pop artist Keith Haring. 5 Mount Street; 011 44 207 499 5781; nicholaskirkwood.com.

title: Jon Hamm to Direct Mad Men Season Premiere
description: As if Don Draper didnt have enough on his plate already, with a new marriage, a daughter whos too grown up for her age, a son whos constantly being replaced by new actors, a struggling ad agency whose future all but rests on his shoulders and all that smoking and drinking he has to do, another responsibility has been added to his plate for the coming season of Mad Men. Jon Hamm, the actor who plays Draper on that hit AMC period drama, will direct the first episode of the shows new season, the Web site tvline.com reported.

title: Four-Spice Salmon
description: Mark Bittman makes pan-seared, spice-rubbed salmon, a recipe from the Minimalist archives.

title: Hantuchova Upsets Top-Seeded Wozniacki
description: PARIS - Caroline Wozniacki of Denmark, the worlds top-ranked womens player, was ousted from the French Open in convincing fashion, 6-1, 6-3, by Daniela Hantuchova of Slovakia on Friday.

title: Ginger Cucumber Salad With Scallops
description: Mark Bittman makes this recipe from the Minimalist Vault, a salad of crunchy pickled cucumbers and tender scallops.

title: The Minimalist: Ginger Cucumber Salad With Scallops
description: Good news for fans of The Minimalist: Its back, in video form.

title: A Little Less Subway, Please
description: KAREN OSTERGREN had heard about the real estate triad of location, price and space  how, as she said, you can have two at any given time but you cant have all three. For her, location and price were important; space wasnt.

title: Caucus | The Palin Equation
description: Matt Bai assessed what a presidential bid by former Gov. Sarah Palin of Alaska might mean for other 2012 Republican hopefuls.

title: For Those With Diabetes, Older Drugs Are Often Best
description: WHEN it comes to prescription drugs, newer is not necessarily better. And thats especially true when treating diabetes.

title: 2-Bedrooms Are Back
description: AS the real estate market in New York City shuffles toward recovery, two-bedroom apartments have been the last to rejoin the party.

title: Saab Resumes Production With Push From Chinese Partner
description: The struggling Swedish automaker Saab restarted production on Friday at its main plant in Trollhattan, more than a month after a cash squeeze led its suppliers to withhold essential parts.

title: Schnitzels and Suds
description: With more that 50 beer gardens, New York City is becoming a bottomless beer stein.

title: Video: Palins Potential Impact
description: Matt Bai, a political writer for The New York Times Magazine, offered his assessment of the influence of Sarah Palin, the former Alaska governor, on the 2012 presidential race if she does indeed choose to enter the Republican primary.

title: David McCullough's New Book; the Wall Street Implosion; Best Seller News
description: This week, historian David McCullough talks about his new book, "The Greater Journey: Americans in Paris"; The Times's business reporter Gretchen Morgenson, co-author of "Reckless Endangerment", describes the causes of the Wall Street implosion; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host.

title: Guilty Plea Expected in Hedge Fund Case
description: 11:46 a.m. | Updated Samir Barai, a former Citigroup executive who ran Barai Capital Management, is expected to plead guilty on Friday afternoon to insider trading before a magistrate at the Federal District Court in Manhattan, a person briefed on the matter told DealBook.

title: Mo Mamet, Mo Mamet
description: The absolute worst part of my new job doing the weekly Q & A in the magazine is editing the hour-long conversations down to the paltry 700 words allotted for my interview. So many darlings. So many grisly deaths. This was especially true of my conversation with Pulitzer-winning playwright and nouveau-grumpy right-winger David Mamet, who spent the first 10 minutes of our conversation outlining in detail the entire plot of his unproduced screenplay for The Diary of Anne Frank. (In a particularly wonderful bit of Hollywood absurdity, he says that Disney, who commissioned the script, deemed Mamets take too dark before putting it in turnaround.)

title: Lawmaker Explores Climate Solution in Clearing Rain Forests
description: John Collins Rudolf of the Green blog got some reaction from experts on tropical forests to an unorthodox climate solution proposed at a Wednesday House hearing by Representative Dana Rohrabacher, Republican of California. Heres an excerpt, starting with Rohrabacher outlining his thinking for a witness, Todd Stern, the Obama administrations climate envoy:

title: Small Town, in Fact and Feeling
description: PETER ROBIDEAU remembers the day 13 years ago when he and his partner, Ken Lesser, moved into their $260,000 split-level in Malverne. He was searing a pot roast when the smoke detector went off. Seconds later, the doorbell rang.

title: Biodiversity in the Arctic Sky
description: Kate Stafford, an oceanographer at the Applied Physics Laboratory at the University of Washington, writes from Alaska, where she is participating in a visual census of bowhead whales.

title: Obama Uses Autopen to Sign Patriot Act Extension
description: Where in the world is President Obama? Turns out it doesnt matter.

title: John McCain Looks for Mr. Puddles
description: John McCains daughter, Meghan, appears in the Domains column in this Sundays magazine. It reminded me of my favorite meta-moment from the 2008 campaign: Jon Stewarts take on one of the Obama-McCain debates when McCain seemed to be wandering aimlessly on stage. The good stuff starts at 7:30 when The Daily Show provides a soundtrack for McCains thoughts as he looks for his dog, Mr. Puddles.

title: From Racer in First Indy 500, a Roadster That Saved a City
description: COPLEY, Ohio

title: Who Really Won? Its Not So Simple
description: STEERING his Lozier racecar into the final miles of the International Sweepstakes 500-Mile Race on May 30, 1911, Ralph K. Mulford believed he had a clear lead over everyone else, he wrote in Automobile Quarterly in 1969.

title: The Week in Pictures for May 27
description: A slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region.

title: Tornadoes and Warming, from the Archives
description: 7:11 p.m. | Updated Anthony Watts has posteda Wattsupwiththat.com item wrongly asserting that my concerns about statements implying a link between recent tornado outbreaks and human-driven climate change are new.

title: Police Clash With Protesters in Barcelona
description: Updated | 6:37 p.m. BARCELONA, Spain  After nearly two weeks of largely peaceful protests across Spain, police officers in riot gear used force to clear hundreds of protesters from a central square in the Catalan capital on Friday morning.

title: A Storybook Ascent for One Actress
description: Meeting Nina Arianda in person for the first time is very different from meeting her onstage. Instead of the high-pitched WHA-A-A-A-T? with which she announces her entrance as Billie Dawn, the classic dumb blonde she plays in the revival of Born Yesterday at the Cort Theater, Ms. Arianda offers a low-key, low-throated pleased-to-meet-you. Her honking version of hello  which Charles Isherwood described in The New York Times as a cross between Jean Harlow and Cyndi Lauper  has helped to turn Ms. Arianda, 26, into Broadways newest darling and won her a Tony nomination for best actress.

title: Now Booking | St. Pancras Renaissance, London
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#161", 592, 420, true, chameleonData);

title: A Stirring Trip to the Finals
description: You may consider this headquarters for Miami Heat ennui. The headquarters for hating the Heat is elsewhere (hint: try Cleveland). Here, we give the necessary nod to the Heat for an inspired run to the N.B.A. finals, for its particularly inspired comeback from a 12-point deficit in the final three minutes against the Bulls on Thursday night, for its ability to jam all of those egos onto a team bus.

title: Blinded by Brights
description: The other day, Frank Doroff, the vice chairman of Bloomingdales, called to say he had a winner. Mr. Doroff, an affable, quick-talking executive who answers his own telephone, loves when an item is selling. Well, naturally, every retailer does, but for Mr. Doroff the fact that something is moving  flying out the door, as they say  offers proof that desires and needs are being met, however mysterious the process actually is.

title: Pharaohs of Europe
description: Even fewer posts for a while, because Im busy meeting with a bunch of men and woman in suits  and yes, I mean woman, namely Laura Tyson  on matters economic.

title: Remembering Mark
description: Memorial Day remembrances dont change with time. Every year, its the same stories, the same fallen friends, the same whys and what-ifs. We change, at first slowly and barely discernible and then all in a rush, but they? They stay the same.

title: Bombing Attack on Peacekeepers in Lebanon Adds Another Jolt to a Region in Upheaval
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  A roadside bomb struck a United Nations convoy near a southern Lebanese port on Friday, wounding six Italian peacekeepers and a Lebanese passer-by in the first attack on the force in more than three years, Lebanese and Italian officials said.

title: Tussling With New Technology
description: SHOULD the driver adapt to the car or should the car adapt to the driver?

title: No. 1 Wozniacki, Still Seeking First Major, Is Ousted
description: PARIS  Mob rule continued in the womens tournament at the French Open as Caroline Wozniacki, the worlds No. 1 player, was upset in the third round, 6-1, 6-3, by Daniela Hantuchova.

title: Mooseferatu
description: John Cole has been collecting suggested titles for the Sarah Palin movie. Other entries:

title: Too Young for Kindergarten? Tide Turning Against 4-Year-Olds
description: Erin Ferrantino rarely has to consult the birthday chart in her kindergarten classroom to pick out the Octobers, Novembers and Decembers. This year, there was the girl who broke down in tears after an hours work, and the boy who held a pencil with his fist rather than his fingers.

title: Edwards Has Lunch With Banking Heiress
description: John Edwards had lunch Thursday with Rachel Mellon, the reclusive banking heiress known as Bunny who is a potentially major witness in his pending legal case, according to ABC News.

title: Thyroid Drug Shortage Presents Tough Choices for Cancer Patients
description: Lisa Meidls thyroid cancer should be easily treatable with surgery and medication. But for her and as many as 30,000 other patients, the final steps to a cure are painfully out of reach.

title: To Redshirt or Not
description: So begins an article by my colleague Winnie Hu about the process of redshirting  holding a child back a year so that he or she is the oldest, rather than the youngest, in kindergarten. It is a question faced by many parents whose children have fall birthdays, and Hus article explores the ramifications  and the proposed changes to existing rules. She writes:

title: A New Food Frontier
description: THE ASTOR ROOM 34-12 36th Street (35th Avenue), Astoria, Queens, (718) 255-1947, astorroom.com.

title: Israel Waits and Worries Before Gaza Border Opening
description: JERUSALEM  As Egypt prepared to open its border with Gaza on Saturday, Israeli officials said they were worried about weapons and militants flowing into the Hamas-controlled strip and about what the move indicated for Egypts future policies. The government did not issue a statement, saying it was in contact with the Egyptian authorities and wanted to see how the change played out in practice before reacting. Others did not wait.

title: Many New York Hotels Are Opening Beyond Manhattan
description: The number of hotel rooms in New York City has increased by almost 24 percent in the last three years, a growth that has been driven in part by hotels in boroughs beyond Manhattan, according to NYC & Company, the official marketing, tourism and partnership organization for New York City. This year the trend continues, with about 40 percent of the new hotels in New York opening in the Bronx, Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island.

title: Weekend Competition: Bring the Funny
description: Its been a tough week; tell us a joke

title: Music Pick of the Day
description: Dylan turned 70 this week, but hes not the only one whos aging. Chris Hockenhull, a British Dylan enthusiast, tracked down the waifs who surrounded the singer in this iconic photograph which was shot by Barry Feinstein during a British tour in 1966.

title: Summer 2011 on The Learning Network
description: As we did last year, well suspend daily lessons this summer from Memorial Day through Labor Day. But dont worry: there will still be plenty to do.

title: Beverly Hills: Still Elite, but ...
description: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif.

title: Indy 500 and Monaco G.P. Lead Marquee Weekend for Open-Wheel Racing
description: In the lead-up to the 100th anniversary Indianapolis 500, race fans have been promised everything from a parade of vintage Indy racecars to commemorative postage stamps. A reality-television star was even tapped to drive the pace car. While not every promise can be fulfilled, there is always the race itself on Sunday to assuage any sore feelings.

title: Graphic Book Best Sellers: A Treatise on Sex Workers
description: Paying for It, a memoir about prostitution by the cartoonist Chester Brown, lands at No. 2 on our hardcover list. The book, published by Drawn & Quarterly, has received a number of reviews: Brown believes that prostitution is a logical and healthy choice for him, and the women he engages, to make, reads the write-up on the Monkey See blog on npr.org. His friends disagree, for a host of reasons. Paying for It is, at its cool, affectless heart, an argument for a deeply unpopular position, and as such it seems destined to become one of the most controversial memoirs of the year, graphic or otherwise.

title: Old-Time Stuff Is Not Forgotten
description: THE big names  Fort Sumter, Gettysburg, Lee, Grant  are getting much of the focus during televisions Civil War spring and summer, as they always do when this pivotal conflict comes up. But to mark the 150th anniversary of the start of the war, the programming that resumes with a burst this weekend and continues over the next several months also has much smaller things on its mind: a childs doll, an aging tintype, a faded letter. And it is those things, 19th-century artifacts elevated to new prominence by a 21st-century television trend, that provide some of the clearest reminders of what the war was really about and how it remains with us today.

title: Civil War TV
description: An array of upcoming specials tied to the 150th anniversary of the Civil War explore both the big themes of the conflict and smaller artifacts.

title: Big Deal | Storied Sloane Mansion on the Auction Block
description: Word of a scandal began to fly through New York society circles in 1898 when Henry T. Sloane, a wealthy carpet manufacturer who was furnishing the new mansions, hotels and clubs of the city, deeded a mansion on the Upper East Side to his wife.

title: Fiat to Buy Full U.S. Stake in Chrysler
description: Andrew Harrer/Bloomberg NewsChrysler 300 at this years Detroit auto show.

title: Blazers, Roy Ponder Options
description: Imagine being 26 years old, in your first job after college, making good money.

title: What Is Carved in Stone
description: THREE years ago, when I was a sophomore at Northeastern, I typed a text to my then-girlfriend, Sarah, telling her I was leaving college for a year. The thought entered my brain and, as usual, I let her know immediately. Im not sure I had even fully made up my mind, but I had made it up long enough to hit send, and so it became real. She sent back several sad but supportive texts, woven together with ellipses.

title: Shadow Banking Makes a Comeback
description: The shadow banking industry is back  and it could become bigger than ever, according to a new report by Standard & Poors.

title: Weekend Warriors
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#981", 592, 490, true, chameleonData);

title: When Life Throws Those Curveballs
description: IN the wake of his frankly autobiographical new film, "Beginners," the writer and director Mike Mills has found himself frequently encountering the kindness  and the curiosity  of strangers. Its a very sweet and often problematic situation where people feel like they know me and theyre concerned for me, he said by phone from Los Angeles recently. It creates these strange little intimate moments.

title: You Meet the Nicest Sportbikes in the 250cc Neighborhood
description: NOBODY should be surprised to learn that Honda has the know-how to build a smooth, light, easy-to-manage motorcycle that is ideal for novice riders.

title: In Pilsen, Beers Not the Only Thing on Tap
description: ON a recent, unseasonably hot spring day in Pilsen, Czech Republic, the shadowy emptiness of the citys Great Synagogue offered a welcome cool and quiet respite from the blinding, scorching sun. Inside, a handful of tourists wandered the halls, climbing the steps to the upper level, trying to capture the spirit of the vast space of the synagogue  said to be the third largest in the world  in snapshots.

title: Venturing Out in Pilsen, Czech Republic
description: Pilsen has cleaned itself up and opened several wonderful new attractions. The result is a worthwhile destination for visitors.

title: McConnell Downplays Politics of Medicare
description: Senator Mitch McConnell knows one of the golden rules of politics: when your friends are down, do some punching on their behalf.

title: Weekend Fare
description: Governors Island turns into one big picnic on Sunday and Monday from noon to 5 p.m. (V.I.P. entrance is at 11 a.m.) for the Brewers Pic-NYC event, part of this years Meatopia festivities. There will be street food  including vendors like Fette Sau, Lukes Lobster and Asia Dog  and beer sold at Colonels Row. Plates of food will be $2 to $10 and beer is $6. Tickets are $15 and proceeds will benefit Added Value farms.

title: The Many Shades of Wayne
description: AS Fathers Day draws nigh, the studios traditionally shake out their libraries for films presumed to have paternal appeal  pipe-and-slippers movies, suitable for showing on big-screen TVs in wood-paneled dens.

title: Champions League Final  Graphically Speaking
description: Saturday brings the dream final in what some people like to call a massive game, perhaps the two best teams in the world  Manchester United and Barcelona  on the verdant grass of Wembley Stadium in London.

title: No Crumbs or Icing, Just Grapes
description: WHEN Sex and the City ended its run in 2004 as one of HBOs most successful series, seemingly every network tried to recapture the shows lighthearted, feminine formula.

title: May 29  June 4
description: Art

title: Sussing Out the Other Matchups of the N.B.A. Finals
description: On the biggest stage of the N.B.A. playoffs, the spotlight will shine bright on the finals most riveting, star-studded matchups. How the Dallas Mavericks contend with LeBron James and Dwyane Wade, and how the Miami Heat defend against Dirk Nowitzki will go under the microscope; the highly competitive games to come will lead to an insane amount of dissection and analysis, and the magnitude of talent focused in the stars of both teams will naturally draw all attention to them.

title: At a Protest In Cairo, One Group Is Missing
description: CAIRO  Tens of thousands of mostly liberal protesters again filled Tahrir Square on Friday to press for an assortment of demands in a demonstration billed as The Revolution Part II,  but perhaps most notable for the absence of the Muslim Brotherhood.

title: Book Review Podcast:  David McCullough and Gretchen Morgenson
description: This week the historian David McCullough talks about his new book, The Greater Journey: Americans in Paris; the business reporter Gretchen Morgenson, co-author of Reckless Endangerment, describes the causes of the Wall Street implosion; Julie Bosman has notes from the field; and Jennifer Schuessler has best-seller news. Sam Tanenhaus is the host. (Podcast Archive) //

title: Robin Rusch and Thomas Heberer
description: WHETHER bartending, dishwashing or working at a foreign record label to support her world travels, Robin Dolph Rusch had a habit of making it up as she went along. So it wasnt surprising that she fell for someone who makes a business of improvisation.

title: Easing Out the Gray-Haired. Or Not.
description: As the managing partner of a top Los Angeles law firm, Norman H. Levine is no stranger to what might be called the Posada problem.

title: Its Not the Pictures That Got Small
description: Sports Illustrated featured this striking picture across two pages last week. Its quite winning in a couple of senses. Not only does it capture the strike, ball in midflight, that would win Manchester City its first championship (Englands F.A. Cup) in more than three decades, it is also rather charming. This tends to happen when a photographer uses a tilt-shift lens. It does funky things to a pictures focus and turns its subjects into miniature versions of themselves  into toy figurines, really.

title: Wawrinka Comes Back to Beat Tsonga
description: PARIS  Stanislas Wawrinka of Switzerland hit two aces to reach two match points but Jo-Wilfried Tsonga of France refused to fold until Wawrinka slashed an inside-out forehand into a corner for a comeback five-set victory, 4-6, 6-7 (3), 7-6 (5), 6-2, 6-3, on Friday at the French Open.

title: Investment Advice for Small Fry
description: Most of us have no business managing our own investments.

title: The Right Model for Lower Cost Investment Management
description: In this weekends Your Money column, I take a look at Betterment and Flat Fee Portfolios. These are the latest efforts to bring investment management to the merely six-figured  the people who many fancier wealth managers no longer want to help.

title: Band of Outsiders
description: If indeed diamonds are forever, youll want to make sure you dont get stuck with a boring one. The Lucifer Vir Honestus collection of one-of-a-kind engagement rings is a subtly sparkling antidote to all those sterile solitaires. The rings are around $9,000 at Barneys New York.

title: Perceiving the Anthropocene
description: The excellent science writer Oliver Morton has written a captivating feature for the Economist exploring the hypothesis that Earth has entered a new geological epoch of our making, the Anthropocene. It has a gem of a closing kicker:

title: Accustomed to Bad News, Joplin Chaplain Takes It Personally This Time
description: JOPLIN, Mo.  In Bob Heaths 20 years as a police chaplain, he has stood on the doorsteps of hundreds of families to deliver the worst possible news: that their loved one has died. He has tended to the frayed psyches of victims of natural disasters like the one in Gulfport, Miss., after Hurricane Katrina. He has led training seminars around the country in the delicate art of death notification.

title: One Case as Big as It Gets, and One Now in Its Shadow
description: The comment tickled a reporter standing nearby. In the lobby of the Manhattan Criminal Courts building, a few hours before a bail hearing for Dominique Strauss-Kahn last week, a television reporter told David Bookstaver, the spokesman for the Office of Court Administration, that everyone says good things about him.

title: Key to a Successful Fraud Defense: A Red Hanky
description: Raymond Craig Brubaker can thank his lawyers red hanky, and some aggressive questioning, for his freedom.

title: Foxs Fresh Fare a Winner as Rerun Season Begins
description: As summer repeats arrived on Thursday night for much of network television, the lone exception led the evening as 9.1 million viewers tuned in to Foxs eighth-season premiere of So You Think You Can Dance, according to Nielsens estimates. Although technically tied with CBSs rerun of The Mentalist at 10, and excluding cable ratings for TNTs coverage of the N.B.A. playoffs, the two-hour premiere lifted Fox to No. 1 on the night among the four main television networks while attracting the series largest audience for the start of a season in four years.

title: Animal Kingdom Will Run in the Belmont
description: Horse racing is halfway to a Triple Crown rubber match after the trainer of Animal Kingdom said Friday that the Kentucky Derby winner Animal Kingdom would come to New York for the Belmont Stakes.

title: Battle For Libya | May 27, 2011
description: NATO on Friday accused forces loyal to the Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, of placing landmines around the rebel-held city of Misrata to prevent the population from moving.

title: A Fugitive in Their Midst? Ridiculous, Villagers Say
description: LAZAREVO, Serbia  This village near the Romanian border is Everytown, an indistinguishable collection of tidy lawns and trimmed trees, where the local people have been rocked by the news that Ratko Mladic, one of the worlds most wanted war crimes suspects, had been found hiding out among them.

title: Hotel Review: The nhow in Berlin
description: THE UPSHOT

title: Restaurant Report: Wise Sons Jewish Delicatessen, in San Francisco
description: A real-deal Jewish deli in San Francisco has always been as tough to come by as a California-style burrito in Manhattan. There have been a few fleeting attempts, but none have stuck. Leo Beckerman and Evan Bloom aim to change that with Wise Sons Jewish Delicatessen. The pop-up restaurant, which made its debut in January, is open only on Saturdays, when they take over the Beast and the Hare restaurant.

title: Lake Geneva as Shelley and Byron Knew It
description: SWITZERLAND is rarely thought of as a wild artistic center. Most of us recall the harsh verdict of Harry Lime, the character played by Orson Welles in The Third Man, who declared that the countrys most creative achievement was the cuckoo clock.

title: Collecting Wellfleet Oysters With the Best
description: IT would be understandable if one confused a slimy, barnacle-covered rock with an unopened oyster. At least, thats what I told myself. For the last half-hour, my husband and I had been ranging over the seabed looking for oysters on Burton Baker Beach, a quiet stretch of bay nestled in the calm of Wellfleet Harbor. But so far I had found more oyster-esque rocks than actual oysters.

title: In Former Soviet Georgia, Two Families and the Art of Hospitality
description: FIRST the roasted eggplant arrived, topped with walnut paste and pomegranate seeds, followed by seared red peppers glistening with oil, and a salad of cucumbers and tomatoes, scattered with herbs. Then bread from a nearby kiln, a soul mate for the homemade cheese, which was akin to mozzarella with a sour kick. The two women of the house soon shuttled in with carafes of red and white wine, squeezed from grapes tended on the surrounding land and coaxed to life in cisterns out back. It was a fine finale  or so we thought  for our first lunch at a small farmstead in Georgia, the fertile backyard of the former Soviet Union.

title: Marking the 50th Anniversary of the Berlin Wall
description: NO one has the intention to build a wall, Walter Ulbricht, the leader of East Germanys ruling Socialist Unity Party, declared on June 15, 1961. Later that summer, just past midnight on Aug. 13, the Berlin Wall began to go up  so stealthily that historians still cannot agree where the first brick was laid. Twenty-nine years later, Germany reunified and the wall became a symbol lost to history.

title: Shopping in Amsterdams Jordaan Section
description: In Amsterdam, the Jordaan neighborhood offers ambitious goods in small spaces.

title: Why We Travel: Readers Share Their Stories
description: ON April 3, inspired by the essay by Paul Theroux titled Why We Travel, we asked readers to submit essays of their own to answer this question. Several hundred responded, relating stories that took us from the mountains of Peru to the halls of Rome. On May 1 we published three. Here are four more that illustrate the vast range of our readers experiences.

title: Letters: Saving on Gas
description: To the Editor: Regarding 13 Ways to Save on Gas This Summer (Practical Traveler, May 15): Save money overall by not buying a huge SUV that you use in everyday life to drive a few people a mile here or there, because you really want to make sure you have that huge SUV for your family road trip. Rent one for the road trip if it is necessary instead, and youll save on gas the rest of the year. I also recommend keeping track of traffic patterns. I just drove through the night 800 miles one way and, during the day, back home (another 800 miles). The night trip was much, much faster because of the lack of traffic and fewer stops for gas.

title: Home Cooking in Georgia (Not That One)
description: In Kakheti, booming agritourism ventures offer a chance to see how private farming has revived since the end of Communism.

title: Shores of Romance and Scandal
description: Finding the poetry and pleasures of Lake Geneva.

title: On the Farm, After the Fall
description: A trip to the post-Soviet republic of Georgia where agritourism draws visitors eager to help out with the farm chores and reap the bounty at the dinner table.

title: Tempting Fate and Tolkien Purists, Peter Jackson Adds Orlando Bloom to The Hobbit
description: Would you cast someone to play Anna Karenina in a film version of War and Peace? Bring in Tom Joad to spruce up your Of Mice and Men movie? Or add Jack Pumpkinhead to the roster of The Wizard of Oz? Probably not if you know whats good for you, but that hasnt discouraged Peter Jackson from risking the wrath of the literary-adaptation gods by announcing that he has added his Lord of the Rings star Orlando Bloom to the cast of his Hobbit movies, even though Mr. Blooms character, the elf Legolas, doesnt appear in J. R. R. Tolkiens original Hobbit novel.

title: A Stronger Aer Lingus Says It Is Ready to Fly Solo
description: DUBLIN  Christoph Mueller, the chief executive of Aer Lingus, accompanied the Irish prime minister, Enda Kenny, and other officials on Friday on a flight aboard a restored 1936 De Havilland Dragon to observe the 75th anniversary of the airlines first scheduled service.

title: Rockaway Boardwalk Buffet Confirmed
description: The cornucopia of new food offerings at Rockaway Beach is finally confirmed. Mostly.

title: Conjoined Twins: Brain Imaging
description: Several commenters responding to Susan Dominuss story about Krista and Tatiana Hogan said that they would be interested in seeing images of the girls unusual neural anatomy. Here is a brain image provided to The Times by the twins neurosurgeon, Douglas Cochrane of British Columbia Childrens Hospital. The attenuated line stretching between the two organs is what he refers to as the thalamic bridge that may allow them to share sensory perception.

title: Summer Sandal: Espadrille
description: NYTD.fullScreenSlideShowFactory.createSlideshow("#96", 592, 400, true, chameleonData);

title: Answers About Pip and Violet, Part 3
description: This week, Dr. Elizabeth Bunting, a wildlife veterinarian at the Animal Health Diagnostic Center at Cornell College of Veterinary Medicine, and other experts have been responding to readers questions about Pip, the red-tailed hawk hatchling, or eyas, who emerged from the egg on May 6 in a nest on a 12th-floor ledge at New York University  and about Pips mother, Violet, about whose injured leg many of you have expressed concern.

title: Decisions, Decisions
description: The 2011 Ford Edge Sport poses a question to drivers: When it comes to technology, is there such a thing as too many options?

title: David LaChapelle: An Unexpected Life
description: HE was hired by Andy Warhol. He fired Madonna. He photographed Pamela Anderson and Lady Gaga and also Hillary Clinton, and made a star of the transgender apparition Amanda Lepore.

title: If Youre Keen on Quinoa
description: If you enjoy cooking with quinoa (pronounced keen-wah), then youll be interested to learn how to use it best. This week Martha Rose Shulman explores the proper uses of this popular grain.

title: Officials: No Need to Protect Bluefin Tuna Under Species Act
description: The Atlantic bluefin tuna, while under pressure from intensive fishing, does not need protection under the Endangered Species Act, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administrationhas concluded.

title: Big Ticket | Sold for $15,150,000
description: It was a horse race for this weeks biggest sale, with the Mexican billionaire Carlos Slim Hel paying $15.5 million for a town house in Midtown and the prominent philanthropist Laurie M. Tisch closing on the sale of her co-op at the Brentmore on Central Park West for $15.15 million.

title: Ferguson Upbeat for Much-Anticipated Champions League Matchup
description: LONDON  Even Sir Alex Ferguson, the Scottish coaching legend with the stellar record and droll disposition, seemed eager to see what hundreds of millions are expected to watch.

title: Lipsky Talks Debt and I.M.F. Leadership
description: John Lipsky, the acting managing director of the International Monetary Fund, talks about how the organization is working with Greek authorities on handling that countrys debt situation, as well as the I.M.F.s plans for picking a new head, in an interview with CNBC.

title: Palin Releases Video Ahead of Bus Tour
description: Sarah Palin, the former governor of Alaska, released this video on the Web site of her political action committee on Friday, two days ahead of the beginning of a bus tour through the country.

title: Fiat Plans to Buy Treasurys Stake in Chrysler
description: From our colleagues at DealBook:

title: Officials in Germany Support Closing 7 Nuclear Plants
description: FRANKFURT  Seven nuclear power plants in Germany that were shut down after the Fukushima disaster in Japan are likely to be closed permanently after a decision Friday by state environment ministers.

title: For Those About to Rock (and Race), Brian Johnson Salutes You
description: RIDGEWOOD, N.J.,  One thousand fans waited outside the small venue on a muggy May night, anticipating the arrival of Brian Johnson, the lead singer of AC/DC. On this night, though, Mr. Johnson would work without the scorching guitar accompaniment from the brothers Angus and Malcolm Young, or the throttling rhythm from bassist Cliff Williams and drummer Phil Rudd.

title: Its Meat for Beer  or Beer for Meat
description: A brewer and a butcher are teaming up as part of efforts by the beer maker to encourage consumers to think about its lager as an alternative to wine when eating beef.

title: Death Stills Laughter of the Seaports Jolly Old Elf
description: Santa Claus has died.

title: TimesCast | May 27, 2011
description: Palestinians look forward to Saturday, when Egypt plans to open its border with Gaza; and Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi avoids continuous NATO bombings.

title: Amazon Has Forecasters Rethinking Lady Gaga
description: The sales estimates for Lady Gagas new album keep going up and up. The latest projection: 1.15 million, according to the data-crunchers at Billboard magazine, which would make it the fastest-selling album in at least six years.

title: Look of the Moment | Jessica Chastain
description: The Look: Ray of Light  muted green tones are enriched with a burst of neon chartreuse providing a bold, but balanced contrast.The Girl: Jessica Chastain, one of the stars of The Tree of Life, which won this years Cannes Film Festivals Palme dOr award, at the films premiere at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.

title: Jeff Conaway, Actor In Taxi, Is Dead at 60
description: Jeff Conaway, the personable actor who won television fame on the sitcom Taxi and movie success in the musical Grease three decades ago and who later publicly struggled with drug and alcohol abuse, died on Friday in Los Angeles. He was 60.

title: The Morning Line: Waiting on Shackleford
description: The Triple Crown news focuses on the fact that Shackleford, the winner of the Preakness, seems more likely than not to run in the Belmont Stakes on Saturday June 11. Shackleford is headed for the Big Apple with the Blood-Horse writing Shackleford is expected to ship to New York in the next couple of days and will have a workout over the Belmont track before a final decision is made about running in the June 11 Belmont Stakes.

title: Anatomy of a Scene: 'Submarine'
description: Richard Ayoade, the director of "Submarine," discusses a scene from his film about an awkward teenager and his first love.

title: This Sunday: Our Thing for Twins
description: I dont always highlight the magazines cover stories because, well, theyre on the cover. Of course, we think theyre brilliant and worth every minute of your Sunday morning (or whenever). But this weeks cover story, about conjoined twins Tatiana and Krista Hogan, deserves every extra little bit of attention I can bring to it. I expect that the cover picture will make some people squeamish. But I urge those of you who feel that way to get past it and read Susan Dominuss powerful story. It wont make you feel bad, I promise. Its a story about the richness and complexity of human life. There really is something miraculous about these girls, and though the challenges they face are daunting, this is the life they have to live, and it is not without joy and love.

title: Analysis: Federer Goes On the Attack
description: Roger Federer defeated Janko Tipsarevic in straight sets, mauling the feisty Serb with pinpoint serving and aggressive all-court tennis. Tipsarevic has a penchant for scoring upsets in Grand Slams, but Federer broke serve early in the first and played with great variety and imagination to run away with an easy victory.

title: A Tangle of Details Emerge in an Insider Trading Case
description: 6:40 p.m. | Updated

title: Israelis Differ on Defensible Borders
description: The ongoing dispute about whether or not it is permissible for supporters of Israel to even refer to the countrys 1967 borders as one element in future negotiations with the Palestinians obscures the fact that some Israelis disagree strongly with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahus view that a country with those frontiers would be indefensible.

title: The Long Goodbye
description: LOS ANGELES

title: A Wrenching Documentary
description: Farrah Fawcetts documentary about her struggle with cancer was received as a seminal moment in television history when it was broadcast in May 2009.

title: Pictures of the Day: Sudan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Sudan, Spain, Somalia and Libya.

title: Denver Crosses Lacrosses Great Divide
description: Denver lacrosse fans gathered on campus and at local restaurants last weekend to watch the Pioneers defeat Johns Hopkins in an N.C.A.A. tournament quarterfinal in Hempstead, N.Y. But the most emotional viewing party took place on the teams bus ride to the airport after clinching its first berth in the semifinals.

title: This Weeks Business News in Photos
description: Law firms second-tier workers, Sonys struggles, Chinese utilities government defiance, the pursuit of the I.M.F.s top job and more.

title: Growing Funnier Each Serious Minute
description: SEVERAL years ago Harvey Weinstein came across an obscure British television comedy called Garth Marenghis Darkplace  an absurdist series that ran for just six episodes in 2004 before it was canceled. The show, set in the 1980s, was a parodic combination of gory sci-fi horror and medical soap opera, and Mr. Weinstein, who was then co-chairman of Miramax, dreamed of bringing the title to America. I thought it was the funniest, coolest thing, he recalled recently, on the phone from the Cannes Film Festival. I went over to London to try and buy the show and convince the guys to do a movie of it.

title: Chic in Review | A Royal Coup for Tom Ford
description: All the fashion news of the week thats fit to reprint.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 27
description: A slide show of photographs of cultural events from this week.

title: A Classmate Feels the Pressure
description: THE 250cc sportbike class is a small group, but the Honda CBR250R is not its only admirable member. The Kawasaki Ninja 250R has been around since 1986, and with regular updates through the years it has long been a favorite of smaller riders, women and students in Motorcycle Safety Foundation RiderCourses.

title: The Week in Culture Pictures, May 27
description: More Photographs

title: Avoiding Legal Problems When Managing a Household Staff
description: HOUSEKEEPERS have been in the news lately. Look no further than former Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger of California, who recently admitted that he had a child more than 10 years ago with his former housekeeper.

title: Pictures of the Day: Sudan and Elsewhere
description: Photographs from Sudan, Spain, Somalia and Libya.

title: On Our Radar: Habitat Loss and Climate Change Imperil Koala
description: Habitat loss, climate change and disease are taking a toll on Australias koalas, prompting a call by wildlife experts to declare the species endangered. A parliamentary committee is assessing scientific evidence on the species, which is difficult to count in the wild. This species is supposed to be common, yet its slipping to extinction under our noses, a conservationist says. [The Independent]

title: A Reminder on How to Treat the Household Staff
description: Paul Sullivan, in his Wealth Matters column this week, discusses the mistakes made by people who employ household help  anyone from housekeepers and nannies to chefs, butlers and estate managers. Nor is this an issue just for the wealthy anymore, Paul writes, because many two-income couples rely on an array of workers to keep their households going.

title: On the Street | Snow Days
description: While fashion has evolved from its rigid dictates, its as true today as it ever was: after Memorial Day, white rules.

title: TimesCast | Egypt-Gaza Border to Open
description: May 27, 2011 - Palestinians look forward to Saturday, when Egypt plans to open its border with Gaza.

title: The Youngest Kindergartners
description: Kindergarten cutoff dates in 2010 and 1975 in the United States.

title: TimesCast | Qaddafi Remains Elusive
description: May 27, 2011 - Three days after NATO's heaviest bombing of Tripoli, Libya, Col. Muammar Qaddafi remains elusive.

title: U.S. Declines to Protect the Overfished Bluefin Tuna
description: The Obama administration said on Friday that it had declined to grant Endangered Species Act protections to the Atlantic bluefin tuna, whose numbers have declined precipitously because of overfishing on both sides of the ocean.

title: A Tribute to the Past, Visions of the Future
description: When a school is a training ground for a company, its performances offer an interesting opportunity to see the way technique and performance styles are forged. On Wednesday night the Alvin Ailey School presented its Spring Celebration Concert at the Ailey Citigroup Theater, and the senior students who took pride of place were remarkable for the ardent sincerity of their demeanor as well as the excellence of their dancing.

title: New Kids: One Behaved, One, Eh
description: You can dress unruly children in Sunday clothes for church, but that doesnt mean they wont fidget throughout the service. Or does it? On Thursday night at Merkin Concert Hall, the Tribeca New Music Festival presented two fascinating chamber ensembles built around the electric guitar: a relative newcomer to the concert-music sphere, still reluctant to curb its exuberance or disguise its roots in popular idioms. One behaved; the other, not so much.

title: In Iowa, Romney Hears Applause, and Alarms
description: 10:06 p.m. | Updated  DES MOINES  Mitt Romneys first Iowa campaign visit of the year was not foiled by controversial subjects on Friday afternoon, but by a bag of burned microwave popcorn.

title: David Leonhardt on Signs of Economic Weakness; the Rise of Groupon; the Docile Bond Market
description: This week: Jeff Sommer with David Leonhardt on signs of economic weakness, Phyllis Korkki and David Streitfeld on the rise of Groupon, Tyler Cowen on prospects for driverless cars. Also, the docile bond market.

title: Puttanesca Sauce Dressed for Spring
description: PUTTANESCA is a sauce that plies its trade all year round, heedless of the season. The ingredients  pantry staples including canned tomatoes, capers, anchovies, garlic, red pepper flakes and olives  are at the ready whenever the desire strikes.

title: Jewelers Who Faked a Robbery Are Given Prison Time
description: The diamond dealers convicted in March of a Hollywood-worthy insurance scam in which they hired men to dress up as Hasidic Jews and stage a robbery of their store were given a prison sentence on Friday of one and two-thirds years to five years.

title: American Arrested for Insulting Thai King
description: BANGKOK  An American citizen has been arrested in Thailand and accused of insulting the countrys monarchy in the latest in a string of cases highlighting the strict and controversial laws protecting the ailing king.

title: Dickey May Not Miss a Start Despite Foot Injury
description: Pitcher R. A. Dickey partly tore the plantar fascia on his right foot when he ran off the mound to cover first base on Thursday, the Mets said. But Dickey, who was walking without a protective boot or crutch, said Friday that he still hoped to make his next start on Tuesday and avoid an assignment to the disabled list.

title: A Candidate Fights a Contested Legacy in Peru
description: Keiko Fujimori, daughter of currently incarcerated former President Alberto K. Fujimori, is in a tight race for the Peruvian presidency.

title: Rubber City Classic
description: A 1917 roadster built by Ralph Mulford, whose testimony in a patent lawsuit helped save the tire industry in Akron, has become the passion of one Ohio man.

title: A Second Fujimori Contends for Perus Presidency
description: LIMA, Peru

title: A Towering Perspective on Libya
description: The first thing people tend to notice about Bryan Denton is that he is tall  very tall. Theres a reason for mentioning this, and well get back to it before long. First, lets talk about about Bryan and his work, and the year he is having.

title: Paying Respects, in Palace and Ghetto
description: WARSAW  For every foreign leader, a visit to Poland involves paying respects at the memorials to the countrys tragic past. It was no different for President Obama, who landed here on Friday and made his way immediately to the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.

title: Metropolitan Preview: Summer 2011
description: Memorial Day already?

title: Hungarian Tradition, African Lilt
description: The recital that the Moroccan pianist Marouan Benabdallah gave at Zankel Hall on Thursday night, his American debut, was naturally a personal milestone for this 29-year-old artist. From the demanding program he played, with nearly two hours of virtuoso works from the late 19th and early 20th centuries, he seemed determined to make a strong impression.

title: Behind the Scenes, Action and Angst
description: For decades Hollywoods sick soul has provided cannon fodder for novelists and screenwriters. With Cut, a Horse Trade Theater Group and Management Theater Company production at Under St. Marks, the playwright Crystal Skillman presents a modest Hurlyburly for our time, taking aim at reality television, as deserving a target  with as Orwellian a name  as show business currently offers.

title: The Art of the Videogame
description: The artwork that goes into todays videogames can be museum-worthy. Many game scenes look completely photorealistic, created with crisp high-end graphics; others are highly stylized cartoon-like visuals. Some games even contain scenes that are beautifully painted by hand.

title: A Dandy Defensive Coup That Few Players Would Find
description: When a tennis player is at the top of his game, he is said to be in the zone. Expert bridge players experience that also, just knowing where all of the cards are lying. Richie Coren (East) of Delray Beach, Fla., found the zonal play in the diagramed deal from a game in Florida this month.

title: Waiting for the New Mobile Payments Frontier
description: The mobile phone will eventually take over your wallet, replacing your credit cards, cash and coupons. But it could be some time before this new type of transaction becomes an everyday reality.

title: Reviewing the Ford Edge Sport
description: In Sundays Automobiles section, John R. Quain reviews the Ford Edge Sport. For 2011, the popular crossover received a revised front fascia, more robust brakes and the stout V-6 from the base-level Mustang. Ford, however, also wants to train attention on the latest version of MyFord Touch, one of the most advanced in-car computer control systems on the market.

title: Notes From a Young American in Congo: Orphans on the Edge
description: I flew to Kinshasa in order to help a man help a boy. Scott Sherman and his family had recently adopted a four-year-old boy from an orphanage in the capital city of the Democratic Republic of Congo. When Scotts son arrived in the States, he was severely underweight, suffering from a variety of illnesses, and indicated that he had been sexually abused at the orphanage where hed lived. Scotts son told his new parents that one other boy, Moise, had tried to protect him from the abuse. Scott and his family asked me if I could try and help find a better situation for Moise.

title: French Press
description: There were a lot of shockers this week.

title: The Week in Pictures for May 27
description: Here is a slide show of photographs from the past week in New York City and the region. Subjects include a quaint antiques shop in the East Village, a dilapidated castle on the Hudson River, and a special Congressional election in upstate New York.

title: Hawk Cam | What Is Pip Saying?
A Narrative Has Many Blanks
description: IF eons of nature and decades of culture have made anything clear, it is that all creation is more or less a collage. You know, recombinant DNA. XX times XY. Boy meets girl. Annie meets Aliens.

title: Romanticism, Tone Paintings and Modern Takes on Folk Tunes
description: The New Amsterdam Singers have explored music ranging from 15th-century sacred works to modern secular pieces in the 40 years since Clara Longstreth founded the group, and the choirs performances have always been spirited and finely polished. The groups real charm, though, is its passion for contemporary American music. Having built relationships with choral composers around the country, Ms. Longstreth has made a point of building smart thematic programs around their work.

title: Violinists, Plugged in, Bow, Pluck and Twang
description: For the final two weeks of May the programming at the Stone has been in the hands of Philip Blackburn, the director of the enterprising, polyglot record label Innova. Mr. Blackburns idea was to present 24 one-hour concerts by musicians who record for Innova, and on Wednesday evening he offered, as hours 13 and 14, what he called the fiddlers hoedown from hell: back-to-back recitals by Ana Milosavljevic and Todd Reynolds, violinists for whom amplification and sound processing are integral to music-making.

title: Decoding Woody Allens Midnight in Paris
description: Many a writer or artist has longed to travel back in time to the sizzling Paris of the 1920s, to sip absinthe with Hemingway at Les Deux Magots or dine on choucroute garnie with Picasso at La Rotonde. Imagine the conversation! What has beguiled audiences about the new Woody Allen movie, Midnight in Paris, is that the protagonist, Gil, a disenchanted Hollywood screenwriter played by Owen Wilson, gets to live exactly that fantasy.

title: Youth, With Hopes and Bliss Intact
description: All over the world, teenage boys and young men are a problem. With their irrepressible energies and strengths, they are always ripe for industrial, military and other kinds of services. But when they are uneducated, unemployed and unsupervised, many of them get into trouble. They join feral gangs and terrorist groups or become freelance criminals, dissipated addicts, deadbeat fathers, suicides.

title: Podcast: Signs of Economic Weakness, Groupons Rise and Driverless Cars
description: Drawing an accurate picture of an entity as complex and changeable as the modern economy is no simple matter.

title: Sadaf & Dan
description: In this reader-submitted video, Daniel Sheffield recalls not knowing whether the business card Sadaf Jaffer gave him after dinner one night was an invitation for a date.

title: Sadaf Jaffer and Daniel Sheffield
description: Sadaf Fatemah Jaffer and Daniel Jensen Sheffield were married Tuesday at the Harvard Faculty Club in Cambridge, Mass. Rizwan Rizvi, an imam, officiated.

title: Movie Watching Is a Scavenger Hunt
description: Did you hear about the jeweler who opened up a shop but wouldnt accept cash, checks or credit cards?

title: Analysis: Who Will Fill the Void in the Womens Game?
description: What does the ousting of the two top seeds in the womens draw say about the state of the womens game as we head into the second week of Roland Garros? Does the desultory showing of both Kim Clijsters and Caroline Wozniacki mean that the tour is foundering? Is the tour rudderless, adrift in a sea of mediocrity, or is this a time of exciting new players on the cusp of stardom?

title: In the Hip-Hop World, Blogs Mean Business
description: Rick Ross has old friends, and Rick Ross has new friends.

title: Recently Fresh Fruit, Given a Chance to Ripen
description: The best part about Keys to the Future, an unassuming but wide-ranging festival of contemporary solo piano music, isnt hearing things for the first time. Its hearing them again.

title: The PT Boat Is Real, but Sham the Torpedoes
description: ABOARD PT-728, off Lower Manhattan  Capt. Tom Whyte issued only one order all morning, and there were very good reasons why that one order was not damn the torpedoes or lower the depth charge, but Timmy, cover your ears.

title: Once Again, U.S. Finds China Isnt Manipulating Its Currency
description: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration said Friday afternoon that China was not manipulating the value of its currency, choosing once again to avoid any escalation in the long-running trade dispute between the two countries.

title: Ball Marks, Not Instant Replays, Are Final Word
description: PARIS  It happens in almost every match, and sometimes several times. A ball hits the court. A line judge makes a call. A player disagrees.

title: Judge Voids Ban on Campaign Donations by Business
description: A federal judge in Virginia has declared unconstitutional a century-old law banning political contributions from corporations, a ruling that, if upheld, could have major implications for the rules governing campaign fund-raising and spending.

title: Winner of Derby Will Run in Belmont
description: Horse racing is halfway to a Triple Crown rubber match after the trainer of Animal Kingdom, the Kentucky Derby winner, said that the colt would come to New York for the Belmont Stakes.

title: The World This Week
description: A look at Barack Obama's European tour thus far.

title: When Medicare Spending Is Wasteful
description: To the Editor:

title: The Mideast Conflict: What Should the U.S. Do?
description: To the Editor:

title: App Smart Extra: Woodstock on a App
description: Live music fans can use their mobile devices to scout out new artists locally or search for the next Woodstock, as this weeks App Smart column points out.

title: The Arrest of Mladic
description: To the Editor:

title: Nigeria: 70 Suspected Militants Kill Six People in Multiple Attacks
description: About 70 gunmen suspected of being Islamic militants attacked two police stations and a bank in the northeastern city of Maiduguri on Friday, killing six people, the police said. The attackers were armed with explosives and automatic rifles, which they used to attack multiple targets in the Damboa district, said Mohammed Abubakar, the police commissioner in charge of the region. Four police officers and two civilians were killed in the attack, he said. The authorities in Nigerias north have blamed Boko Haram, a radical Islamic sect that draws inspiration from Afghanistans Taliban movement, for a spate of bomb attacks and killings aimed at government officials and the security forces since last year.

title: Gay Marriage Studies, and Coverage of Gay Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: For Some Eighth Graders, Belated Good News
description: This time when Radcliffe Saddler got his envelope at school on Friday afternoon, it was thin and feather-light, and he sensed it was good news. It also meant the end of a painful process that weighed on his family and occupied nearly his entire eighth-grade year.

title: A Day Off at the Monaco Grand Prix
description: MONACO  Friday is the down day in Monaco, with no track action and an almost empty paddock. Well, not quite. Today it has turned into a kind of Cannes festival Part II. Cannes ended last week, but I heard today that Leonardo DiCaprio is somewhere around here in Monaco. Kim Kardashian, the socialite and actress, and the New Jersey Nets forward Kris Humphries have also been around, and today we also had the Spanish model Esther Canadas completely sucking up the attention of all the TV cameras and photographers outside of the McLaren Mercedes motor home on the arm of Jenson Button.

title: A Day Off at the Monaco Grand Prix
description: MONACO  Friday is the down day in Monaco, with no track action and an almost empty paddock. Well, not quite. Today it has turned into a kind of Cannes festival Part II. Cannes ended last week, but I heard today that Leonardo DiCaprio is somewhere around here in Monaco. Kim Kardashian, the socialite and actress, and the New Jersey Nets forward Kris Humphries have also been around, and today we also had the Spanish model Esther Canadas completely sucking up the attention of all the TV cameras and photographers outside of the McLaren Mercedes motor home on the arm of Jenson Button.

title: This Time, Wade Knows How Hard It Is to Win a Title
description: In June 2006, Dwyane Wade was a buoyant, boyish 24-year-old with an armful of shiny trophies and a perfectly nave vision of the future. The Miami Heat had just claimed the N.B.A. championship, with Wade as the most valuable player. And Wade was certain  absolutely certain  that he was on the precipice of something great and enduring.

title: The Church of Oprah Winfrey and a Theology of Suffering
description: The Oprah Winfrey Show ended Wednesday, bringing despair to booksellers who relied on her book club, television programmers who needed her ratings, and religion scholars who for a decade have tried explaining how this child of poverty became the leader of a worldwide cult. They have worked just as hard to define that cult, which is at once Christian and pantheistic, African-American in origin but global in reach.

title: Texas Governor Hints at G.O.P. Run for White House
description: HOUSTON  The ritual of reporters asking Gov. Rick Perry if he is running for president and getting a firm no has become so entrenched in Texas that jaws dropped Friday afternoon when Mr. Perry abruptly changed his tune  slightly  and hinted that he might run after all.

title: Barack vs. Bibi
description: Robert Wright, left, of Bloggingheads.tv and Gershom Gorenberg of The American Prospect debate the Obama-Netanyahu relationship.

title: Ignoring Homes, Thieves Make Off With Just the Gates Guarding Them
description: Hers was the hand of a little girl, smooth and quick, when she first learned to open that little iron gate. That was half a century ago, and while the hand aged  deeper wrinkles, better nails  the gate remained constant, its creak sounding the arrival of visitors like a doorbell and as much a part of the home on Vanderbilt Avenue as the brownstone walls themselves.

title: Reacting to Police Rape Case With Anger, but Little Surprise
description: It was a trial that bared some anxieties that run just below the citys surface: the weakness of a drunken memory; the vulnerability of ordinary residents to abuse from the powerful, especially in a police uniform. For nearly two months, New Yorkers followed a courtroom drama that held all the fascination of a television crime series, with intimate sexual detail and a haunting void at its center into which they could project their own fears or anger.

title: For First Time, Unicef Reveals Differences in Prices It Pays Drug Companies for Vaccines
description: The United Nations Childrens Fund on Friday publicly listed for the first time the price it pays for vaccines.

title: Goodbye Food Pyramid, Hello Dinner Plate
description: Whatever you do, dont call it a pie chart.

title: Giving to Charity by Managing Your E-Mail
description: Send an e-mail, make a charitable donation. Delete an e-mail, make a charitable donation.

title: The Coyote Candidate
description: Today, we are going to discuss Gov. Rick Perry of Texas.

title: Sotomayor Got $1.175 Million for Memoir, Forms Reveal
description: WASHINGTON  Justice Sonia Sotomayor received a $1.175 million advance last year to write a memoir, according to financial disclosure forms released on Friday for the nine Supreme Court justices.

title: F.D.A. Approves Drug to Treat Hospital Scourge
description: As a young infectious disease researcher in 1971, Dr. Sherwood L. Gorbach received an urgent call for help from a drug company. Some patients treated with the companys antibiotic in New Zealand had developed severe cases of diarrhea and bowel inflammation, and some had died.

title: Senate Gadfly Who Isnt Shy About Buzzing
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky did not come to this town to be quiet.

title: Endangered Ryan-os
description: Its hard to overstate just how profoundly Republicans underestimated the publics distaste for their draconian Medicare proposal.

title: Lasting Choice in a Sport of Split-Second Decisions
description: INDIANAPOLIS  A week after her racecar broke during a practice run, hit a wall and flipped, catching fire and dousing her with fuel, Simona de Silvestro still had her burned hands swathed in white gauze. She smiled when she called them her Mickey Mouse hands.

title: Dont Scorn Paul Ryan
description: I hadnt realized until I met him on Tuesday that Paul Ryan had been a protg of Jack Kemp. But the minute I heard him talking about his late mentor, everything suddenly made sense.

title: Fracking Raises Hope for an Onshore Oil Rush
description: Advocates of extracting oil from tightly packed rock say it could increase the nations oil output by 25 percent.

title: Adding Thrills When Flying Upside Down Just Isnt Enough
description: Air show pilots have a tough assignment. They must pull off extraordinary feats of aeronautical airmanship, sure, but the bigger challenge is keeping the attention of an audience that already receives regular doses of adrenaline from various forms of entertainment.

title: Wilpons Sudden Silence Speaks Volumes About His Style
description: Fred Wilpon has called his team lousy and snakebitten. He has mocked Carlos Beltran, dismissed Jose Reyess earning power and said that his most marketable player, David Wright, is not a superstar. He has acknowledged that his Mets are bleeding cash. Yet his dreary portrait of the product was not enough to deter David Einhorn from giving Wilpon $200 million for a piece of it.

title: Arrest Follows Serbias Uneven Path to Break With Its Past
description: BELGRADE, Serbia  The tall building that served as the headquarters for the late Slobodan Milosevics political party, bombed by an American cruise missile in the 1999 Kosovo war, has been privatized and rebuilt, covered now in blue-green glass. Before 1990, it was home to the Communist Party Central Committee; now it houses offices, including Western banks, and a modish shopping center.

title: A New Flood, Some Old Truths
description: The thousands of people forced to abandon their homes in recent weeks to floodwaters are victims not just of nature but of human error as well. Years of mismanagement of the vast Mississippi River ecosystem  the relentless and often inadvisable construction of levees and navigation channels, the paving over of wetlands, the commercial development of flood plains  have made the damage worse than it might otherwise have been.

title: The Not-So-Simple Case for Taking Herman Cain Seriously
description: Ive been taking some heat for yesterdays article, The Simple Case for Taking Herman Cain Seriously.

title: Shale Boom in Texas Could Increase U.S. Oil Output
description: CATARINA, Tex.  Until last year, the 17-mile stretch of road between this forsaken South Texas village and the county seat of Carrizo Springs was a patchwork of derelict gasoline stations and rusting warehouses.

title: Another War in Sudan?
description: The world breathed a sigh of relief in January when southern Sudanese voted overwhelming to secede and the government in northern Sudan accepted the results. But with the July 9 independence date approaching, north and south Sudan are on the brink of war over the oil-rich border region of Abyei. The United States, the United Nations and the African Union will have to press hard to get the two sides to back down.

title: Data Breach at Security Firm Linked to Attack on Lockheed
description: Lockheed Martin, the nations largest military contractor, has battled disruptions in its computer networks this week that might be tied to a hacking attack on a vendor that supplies coded security tokens to millions of users, security officials said on Friday.

title: Margo Dydek, Towering Womens Basketball Center, Dies at 37
description: Margo Dydek, the 7-foot-2 Polish center who was the W.N.B.A.s No. 1 draft pick in 1998 and went on to become its leading career shot blocker, died on Friday in Brisbane, Australia. She was 37.

title: At Fragrance Awards, Sniffing Celebrity Wrists
description: We caught a whiff of Halle Berry, a sniff of Paz de la Huerta and a deep breath of Padma Lakshmi. At the Fragrance Foundations FiFi Awards, billed as the Oscars of the perfume industry, our correspondent came face to face with a sea of celebrity wrists on Wednesday night. All around us, scented arms, flung into the faces of others, were sniffed with the solemnity of a sommelier.

title: Tom West Dies at 71; Was the Computer Engineer Incarnate
description: Tom West, a shy computer engineer who became an unlikely symbol ofhigh techtomultitudesof general-interest readers as leader of the engineering team portrayed in Tracy Kidders book The Soul of a New Machine, died on May 19 at his home in Westport, Mass. He was 71.

title: Steve Rutt, an Inventor Behind Early Video Animation, Dies at 66
description: Steve Rutt, an engineer, inventor and artist whose early video animation system made images expand and contract and leap and dance, and in so doing helped propel the video-art revolution of the 1970s, died on May 20 in Manhattan. He was 66.

title: CVS Wins $3 Billion Pharmacy Contract
description: The CVS Caremark Corporation won a $3 billion contract to provide pharmacy benefits to federal employees, easing concern that the company is losing business to rivals. Medco Health Solutions, which had held the contract, disclosed Friday that Blue Cross Blue Shield Association planned to switch to another provider by 2012. CVS said the new agreement, which starts Jan. 1, will run through 2014. Stock in CVS, which is based in Woonsocket, R.I., rose 65 cents, or 1.7 percent, to $38.80 a share. Stock in Medco, which is based in Franklin Lakes, N.J., fell $5.78, or 9 percent, to $58.66 a share.

title: Dodd-Frank in Limbo
description: Congressional Republicans could not be clearer about their intent to undermine the Dodd-Frank financial reform law. Theyre not helping consumers, so we have to assume that their goal is to protect the bankers.

title: Albany Needs Ethics Reform  Now
description: The first item on Gov. Andrew Cuomos post-inauguration to-do list was ethics reform. Hes been in office five months, and were still waiting for the bill.

title: Oprah, I Hardly Knew You
description: Belgrade Lakes, Me.

title: Lottery Numbers
2010 Was Big-Spending Year Even by Mayors Standards, Documents Suggest
description: He gave away a Jeep Grand Cherokee that retailed for $26,000. He forgave a personal loan worth at least $500,000. He poured at least half a million dollars into a trust fund for his ex-wife. And he cast off a set of unwanted cabinets valued at more than $40,000.

title: Public Services for Memorial Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Studying Housing Through Distorted Indexes
description: THE American housing market seems to be getting worse as time passes.

title: Minority-Stake Sale Could Stabilize Mets Finances Through Next Year
description: When the Mets said Thursday that they were in exclusive negotiations to sell the hedge fund mogul David Einhorn a minority stake in the team for $200 million, they moved one step closer to securing a much-needed financial lifeline.

title: For the Women of the Service, a Tamer Type of Fleet Week
description: When the U.S.S. Iwo Jima docked on Manhattans West Side this week, a gaggle of sailors of a different sort stood ready to greet the ship.

title: Saturday: Advancement Aid
description: Administrivial Alert-From-the-Future! There will be a Notepad on Sundays puzzle that says The grid represents a maze. Enter the room at the upper left and exit at the lower right, following a path that will become apparent as you solve the crossword. When the puzzle is done, read the circled letters in the order in which the rooms are visited to spell a quote by 153 Across.

title: With Arrest, Criticism for Payroll Project Grows
description: As federal investigators arrested another central figure in their widening inquiry into the citys troubled automated payroll project, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg on Friday leveled his harshest criticism yet against the projects main contractor, suggesting there was widespread fraud and gross negligence in the company.

title: Newark Officer Is Killed in a Drive-By Shooting
description: NEWARK  The night before he was to give his younger daughter a birthday party, Police Officer William C. Johnson went out for pizza and never came home. He died early Friday, apparently a random victim of a drive-by shooting.

title: Swishers Batting Average Is Still Far Below His Spirits
description: SEATTLE  On the first day of the Yankees last visit here, Nick Swisher was overjoyed to learn that fans had voted him onto the 2010 American League All-Star team, his reward for a splendid three months. When Swisher returned to Safeco Field on Friday, he was merely trying to maintain his regular spot in the lineup. It has been a disappointing season for Swisher, the teams lone everyday player yet to embark on a hot streak.

title: Carter Brain Tumor Appears Malignant
description: A tumor on Gary Carters brain is most likely malignant, according to preliminary results from a biopsy that was performed Friday morning. A statement from Carters physicians said that once the final pathology report became available in several days, treatment options would be discussed with Carter and his family.

title: Corrections
description: NATIONAL

title: Wright Is Magnanimous; Bullpen Is Too Generous
description: The sting of hearing that his teams owner does not think of him as a superstar was soothed for David Wright by that most reliable and ever-faithful of sources.

title: Mets Partner Was Critical of Carelessness on Madoff
description: In January 2009, roughly a month after Bernard L. Madoffs arrest, David Einhorn wrote an opinion article with Michael Lewis, the author who was then working on a book about the financial collapse of Wall Street. It was headlined The End of the Financial World as We Know It.

title: F.D.I.C. Closes 44th Bank This Year
description: WASHINGTON (AP)  Regulators on Friday shut a bank in Washington State, pushing to 44 the number of United States bank failures this year.

title: Panoramas of Joplin Before and After the Tornado
description: Interactive panoramas of devastation in two locations in Joplin, Mo., compared to images of the same locations before the storm.

title: Africa to Pittsburgh, Slave Ship to 1904
description: You have to start somewhere, and you have to end somewhere. August Wilsons wondrous cycle of 10 dramas depicting the black experience in 20th-century America starts with Gem of the Ocean; but the production now at Hartford Stage also serves as the final offering of Michael Wilsons tenure as artistic director. As it turns out, this conjunction of Wilsons has a certain aptness: With its many comings and goings, the Pittsburgh parlor of the plays mystical Aunt Ester provides both an essential destination and an ideal point of departure.

title: Broadway Rhythm Reappears in My One and Only
description: What could possibly bring together a hick aviator from Texas, a comely swimmer from England, an entrepreneurial prince from Russia and an all-knowing barber from Harlem?

title: You Call This a Golden Age? 1950s TV, via Neil Simon
description: Theres something about New York City in the 1950s. It was a horrible time in crucial ways (sexism, racism, the Communist witch hunts). But on the surface, it was lovely. Americans dressed up for the office, took three-hour lunches and seemed to smoke and drink blithely with little thought of the consequences. All that postwar confidence!

title: Im an Angel, and Im Here to Help
description: We couldnt actually see theater without them, but lighting designers are rarely on our minds as we watch plays. Its a little different with Tom Dudzicks 1990 comedy Greetings! Hes made the lights a crucial part of his story. And Martin E. Vreeland, the designer of the lighting effects in the production at Penguin Rep Theater in Stony Point, in Rockland County, has gotten them all just right.

title: A Republican Stays Connected in Democratic Massachusetts
description: BOSTON  When Scott P. Brown won an upset victory in last years special election for the late Senator Edward M. Kennedys seat, it seemed his tenure could be brief. Massachusetts is a left-leaning state, after all, where larger-than-life Democrats have run for president or become Washington power players.

title: Year One of Festival: 65 Films in 5 Days
