description: In a bid to broaden its theater program and to bring additional polished, diverse theater uptown, City College of New York is lending critical support to an effort to open a new professional theater in residence uptown at Aaron Davis Hall.

title: A Striking, Gentle Portrait of a Shaker Community
description: It must be nice when I passed the meeting house without saying a prayer is the worst sin you can recall committing.

title: Two Top Giselles, Back to Back
description: Behind the story of Giselle lie the still dismaying, well-attested historical accounts of dance mania that caused deaths in the Rhineland in the late medieval and early Renaissance eras. Onstage love, death and dance all come together in an engrossingly beautiful vortex. Other ballets have greater music and greater choreography, yet this one still takes us deep into the classically Romantic heart of what ballet itself is all about.

title: CBS Radio Reminds D.J.s to Identify Songs: When You Play It, Say It
description: It would seem one of the basic tasks of any disk jockey: tell listeners the name of the song they just heard. But last week the head of a major radio company felt compelled to instruct its programmers to start identifying more of the songs played on the air, by title and artist name.

title: Modern Dance Has an iPhone App
description: Modern dance now has a new performance space, the iPhone, with a free app called Dances for an iPhone, created by the choreographer and videographer Richard Daniels. It features six short films with performances by the dancers Carmen de Lavallade, Deborah Jowitt, Regina Larkin, Christine Redpath and Megan Williams, with biographical information for each performer. Mr. Daniels said this was the first installment in a planned series meant to bring the world of dance to a digital audience. Mr. Daniels is an artist in residence at the Baryshnikov Arts Center in New York, where an update for the app, featuring seven new performances, is in production.

title: Jewish Prize for Brooklyn Author
description: Austin Ratner has won the Sami Rohr Prize for Jewish Literature, the Jewish Book Council has announced. Mr. Ratner, who lives in Brooklyn, will receive the $100,000 award, presented each year to an emerging Jewish writer, for his novel, The Jump Artist (Bellevue Literary Press, 2009). Joseph Skibell, the second-place winner, will receive the Jewish Literature Choice Award of $25,000, for his novel A Curable Romantic (Algonquin Books, 2010). Both awards will be presented on Tuesday at the Center for Jewish History in New York.

title: Selections for Next Link Project
description: The New York Musical Theater Festival has selected musicals for its 2011 Next Link Project, a program that provides visibility, financial support, training and networking for rising talent with previously unproduced work. Twelve of the festivals fully staged slots will go to Next Link Project productions, including The Brain That Wouldnt Die! In 3-D!!!, with book and lyrics by T. Sivak and E. Gelman, and Jack Perry Is Alive (and Dating), with book and lyrics by Harrison David Rivers and Daniella Shoshan and music by Julia Meinwald. Selections were chosen by a jury of industry professionals. The festival will run from Sept. 26 to Oct. 16.

title: At I.M.F., a Strict Ethics Code Doesnt Apply to Top Officials
description: At the International Monetary Fund, there is one set of ethics guidelines for the rank-and-file staff and another for the 24 elite executive directors who oversee the powerful organization.

title: Debbie Reynolds Auctions Costume Collection
description: Ever wanted to dress up as Judy Garland in The Wizard of Oz or as Marilyn Monroe in The Seven Year Itch? Profiles in History, a California auction house, is offering enthusiasts an opportunity actually to do so when it puts the famous dresses from those movies and other famous costume pieces worn by classic film stars up for auction on June 18 in Beverly Hills, Reuters reported. The 3,500-piece collection, which is owned by Debbie Reynolds, will include a bowler worn by Charlie Chaplin, the gold velvet gown worn by Barbra Streisand in Hello, Dolly!, right, the Ascot dress worn by Audrey Hepburn in My Fair Lady, left, and several costumes for Julie Andrews in The Sound of Music. Ms. Reynolds said that she was sad to break up the collection but that recent attempts to open a museum to showcase the items had fallen through. Ive reached such a difficult time with the economic situation, Ms. Reynolds told Reuters. To keep them stored another 50 years didnt make sense. I hope in the end they all find happy homes, that they will be shown, and that they might even land in museums.

title: Pop Goes the BB Gun, in Tune
description: A Christmas Story, the holiday film classic about a boy and his Red Ryder BB gun, will find new life on the stage as A Christmas Story, the Musical!, the producers announced. The production features a score by the composer-lyricist team Benj Pasek and Justin Paul (Roald Dahls James and the Giant Peach ) and a book by Joseph Robinette (Charlottes Web) based on the writings of the radio humorist Jean Shepherd and the 1983 Christmas Story film. The prime mover behind the project is Warren Carlyle, choreographer of the Kennedy Centers current production of Follies in Washington. A Christmas Story, the Musical! will begin a five-city tour on Nov. 8 in Hershey, Pa.; it ends with a three-week run at the Chicago Theater.Peter Billingsley, who starred in the film, above, as the boy who was warned about the perils of playing with the gun, has signed on as a producer.

title: Giselle
description: Diana Vishneva and Alina Cojocaru danced for American Ballet Theater.

title: Curtain Down, Heads Up: Parenthood Plays
description: Two male playwrights consider the perks and perils of parenthood in new shows that recently opened in New York. Daniel Goldfarbs Cradle and All, from the Manhattan Theater Club, is about two couples living in Brooklyn Heights, one considering having a baby and the other wondering whether or not to let their baby cry herself to sleep. In Jonathan Marc Shermans Knickerbocker, which closed on Sunday at the Public Theater, a 40-year-old man comes to terms with being a father for the first time.

title: Japan Appears Dispensable as a Supplier
description: Maybe Japan is not as crucial to the global supply chain as those first weeks after the earthquake made it seem.

title: Palin at Rolling Thunder
description: Sarah Palin and her family participated in a motorcycle ride honoring veterans.

title: Palins Path May Be Unclear, but Her Ride Is Revved Up
description: WASHINGTON  For sheer mastery of celebrity theater, Sarah Palin cannot be beat.

title: FIFA Clears Blatter and Suspends Two Others
description: A FIFA ethics panel on Sunday suspended two of the organizations most powerful figures, Mohamed bin Hammam of Qatar and Jack Warner of Trinidad and Tobago, after they were accused of corruption. But the panel found no wrongdoing by the FIFA president, Sepp Blatter, clearing him to run unopposed for a fourth term as president. The vote is scheduled for Wednesday. Read Jer Longmans article here, and a news analysis by Rob Hughes on what the ruling says about Blatter, then come back to comment.

title: Bill Gates and the School Reform Debate
description: To the Editor:

title: Bullpen Rests as Sabathia Helps Yankees Avoid a Sweep
description: SEATTLE  If nothing about their first two games at Safeco Field qualified as relaxing for the Yankees, then Sunday allowed Manager Joe Girardi to sit in his figurative Adirondack chair, sip a tall glass of iced tea and just watch and enjoy.

title: How to Explain the Decrease in Major Crime?
description: To the Editor:

title: An Outsider Making Waves in Hollywood
description: Los Angeles

title: Rookie Loses Indy 500 With Crash on Last Turn
description: INDIANAPOLIS  J. R. Hildebrand, a 23-year-old rookie, had much more on his mind around midafternoon Sunday than just completing one smooth turn that would have won the Indianapolis 500. He was low on fuel. He was swooping in on lapped traffic. And Dan Wheldon was closing fast.

title: Fearing Alzheimers
description: To the Editor:

title: As PC Markets Slow, Nvidia Aims at Tablets
description: Jen-Hsun Huang has rallied his engineers and developers before around his grand plans for Nvidia, the computer chipmaker he helped found nearly 20 years ago.

title: Mugabe Ally Escalates Push to Control Anglican Church
description: HARARE, Zimbabwe  Religion, like politics, is often a dangerous business in this country.

title: Forgetting Why We Remember
description: MOST Americans know that Memorial Day is about honoring the nations war dead. It is also a holiday devoted to department store sales, half-marathons, picnics, baseball and auto racing. But where did it begin, who created it, and why?

title: Teacher of the Hour, 14 Times Daily
description: Calling Allan Renz a golf teacher with a lot of students is like calling Manhattan an island with a lot of buildings.

title: YouTube's Next Stars
description: The winners of YouTubes talent search contest spent a week in video training boot camp at Googles headquarters in New York to elevate their production skills. Here are the contestants entries and pitches in their own words.

title: French Official Resigns Amid Harassment Suits
description: PARIS  A junior government minister resigned Sunday after two women filed sexual harassment suits against him last week, becoming the first clear political casualty here of the fallout from the arrest of the French economist Dominique Strauss-Kahn.

title: At YouTube Boot Camp, Future Stars Polish Their Acts
description: Vanessa Wilson was back in class last week for the first time since law school. Only this time, she said, she wasnt bored.

title: Last Man Standing (Barely) Will Face Djokovic, if He Can Recover
description: PARIS  Shallow on star power but deep on compelling plot, the fourth-round marathon between Fabio Fognini and Alberto Montas was one of the wilder rides in memory at Roland Garros.

title: Retailers Offer Apps With a Catalog Feel
description: Mia Sara, 43, a Manhattan transplant in Los Angeles, misses window shopping in New York, but has found a replacement  shopping on her iPad.

title: Some Faint Praise for Mr. Ballmer
description: Microsoft has missed too many opportunities under Steve Ballmers stewardship. Its a fair criticism reignited last week by the hedge fund boss, David Einhorn, who called for the software giants chief executive to step down. But that doesnt necessarily mean Mr. Ballmer will go. Based on total return to shareholders, other long-time company bosses, including Jeff Immelt at General Electric, have fared worse.

title: Against Learned Helplessness
description: Unemployment is a terrible scourge across much of the Western world. Almost 14 million Americans are jobless, and millions more are stuck with part-time work or jobs that fail to use their skills. Some European countries have it even worse: 21 percent of Spanish workers are unemployed.

title: For French, Arrest Forces Some Questions of Identity
description: Anne Cottavoz is of two minds about the Dominique Strauss-Kahn affair, her American mind and her French mind, though she concedes that after living in the United States for 27 years, there may be some blurring of the two.

title: Riding the Rails to the Circus Ring
description: P.T. Barnum first took to the rails with his self-proclaimed greatest show on earth in 1872, and trains still keep the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey circus on the move.

title: Florida Governor Vetoes PBS Funding
description: Just as a deal came together late last week to keep PBS programming on the air in Orlando, Floridas public broadcasters suffered a financial blow when Gov. Rick Scott vetoed the states nearly $4.8 million appropriation for public broadcasting.

title: Northwestern Wins 6th Title in 7 Years
description: STONY BROOK, N.Y.  Since losing in last years national championship game, the Northwestern lacrosse players Brianne LoManto and Shannon Smith had been contemplating the day they might return to this stage. That this years final would be played on Long Island  minutes from where LoManto, the Wildcats goalkeeper, and Smith, an attacker, grew up  made the opportunity that much more special.

title: Honors for War Service, Long Unacknowledged
description: It was a family mystery. Everyone knew that Milton Rein had served in the United States Army during World War II. Everyone suspected that he had seen combat.

title: Skull Found in Backyard of Old Home in Brooklyn
description: Bright sun and heat beckoned many New Yorkers who had remained in the city over the Memorial Day weekend into their backyards.

title: Trust but E-Verify
description: The Arizona immigration law was controversial from the beginning. Critics said it was ripe for abuse, implicitly discriminatory and probably unconstitutional as well. Business groups and liberal activists joined forces to oppose it.

title: Horton Is Bruins Finishing Touch
description: BOSTON  For a seven-year N.H.L. veteran who had never played in the Stanley Cup playoffs, Nathan Horton certainly knows what to do there.

title: Among Bodies Discarded on a Beach, One That Doesnt Fit
description: The little girl had lived, at most, 730 days or so. Someone had hidden her body in the thicket of branches and poison ivy off Ocean Parkway on the South Shore of Long Island. By the time the police discovered her on April 4, the remains had turned skeletal.

title: Man and Woman Killed at Brooklyn Housing Project
description: A man and a woman were killed and another man was wounded in a shooting early Sunday morning in a courtyard of a Brooklyn housing project, the police said.

title: Inching Closer to States Rights
description: Chief Justice John Roberts is one vote short of moving the Supreme Court to a position so conservative on states rights that it would be to the right of the Tea Partys idea of limited government. That chilling possibility was evident in the courts recent ruling in the case of Virginia v. Stewart.

title: Lottery Numbers
The Kindnesses of New Yorkers
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Rep. Ryans Dubious Sales Pitch
description: Representative Paul Ryan is rebutting critics of his plan to turn Medicare into a premium support program, pointing to two existing programs that he says prove his approach would be better for beneficiaries. Dont believe it.

title: Detroits Rebound Is Built on Smaller Cars
description: DETROIT  After years of being outgunned by Japanese rivals, the American auto industry has made small cars a central part of its strategy, seeking to capitalize on a fundamental shift in the preferences of consumers in an era of fast-rising gas prices.

title: Hudson Power Cable Still Has Critics in 2 States
description: New York City officials are not completely sold on it, some state lawmakers are dead-set against it and now regulators in New Jersey are trying to stop it. But New Yorks governor, Andrew M. Cuomo, wants it, so a cable that would carry electricity from New Jersey to Manhattan appears to be about to make its way across the Hudson River.

title: Her Inheritance: An Eagerness to Serve
description: A few months before Kathy Hochul was born, her family was living in a 31-by-8-foot trailer not far from the hulking Bethlehem Steel plant near Buffalo. When things got a little better, they moved to the second-floor flat of a home in working-class Woodlawn.

title: Millions Need Not Apply
description: Millions of Americans who lost their jobs to the recession and fell behind in payments to creditors are being penalized again, this time by companies that use credit records to screen job applicants. Five states have limited the use of credit histories by potential employers and about 20 are considering similar measures that deserve to become law.

title: Among the Graves This Memorial Day
description: Today, there are families knotted in mourning for a soldier recently lost in Iraq or Afghanistan. There are families for which mourning has become an absence more persistently felt than they could ever have imagined.

title: Corrections
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Shouts of Pull Him Back! Then Rescuers Do Just That.
description: A man who was dangling from the Brooklyn Bridge was pulled to safety by police officers Sunday afternoon as scores of people watched from the pedestrian walkway, from the street below and from cars on the bridge that had been halted during the rescue.

title: Of Monsters, Men  And Topic Modeling
description: The blood of the first Martyr has flowed, the Richmond Daily Dispatch announced on May 27, 1861. Three days earlier Confederate partisan James Jackson had been killed in Alexandria, Va., by a Union soldier after Jackson shot and killed Union Col. Elmer Ellsworth, who had charged into Jacksons inn to remove a Confederate flag atop the building. Arguably the first casualties of the war, Jackson and Ellsworth became celebrated martyrs for the respective Confederate and Union causes.

title: Public Services for Memorial Day
description: NEW YORK

title: Lockheed Strengthens Network Security After Hacker Attack
description: Lockheed Martin said on Sunday that it had stepped up its investigation into a sophisticated hacking attack on its computer networks and bolstered security measures for gaining remote access to its systems.

title: An Ark Built for Today
description: A man in Dordrecht, the Netherlands built an ark to teach others about the bible.

title: A Biblical Blueprint Meets the Fire Code and the Neighbors
description: DORDRECHT, the Netherlands  If Noah had run into the modern nanny state, or nimby, or a few of the other obstacles that Johan Huibers has been facing, the animal kingdom might look a lot different today.

title: Economic Reports This Week
description: ECONOMIC REPORTS Data will include the S.& P./Case-Shiller housing price index for March, the Chicago purchasing managers index for May and consumer confidence for May (Tuesday); the ADP employment report and the Institute for Supply Management manufacturing index for May, construction spending for April and North American auto sales for May (Wednesday); same-store sales for May, revised first-quarter productivity and factory orders for April (Thursday); and unemployment and the I.S.M. service index for May (Friday).

title: Harvard Business Review Reinvention Is Paying Off
description: Shortly after editors at the Harvard Business Review tore up their magazine in 2009, adding pictures to the cover, reader comments to their signature case studies and colorful illustrations  the horror!  cranky reader comments started coming in.

title: Treasury Auctions Set for This Week
description: The Treasurys schedule of financing this week includes Tuesdays regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and an auction of four-week bills on Wednesday.

title: Stories of Bad Golf Courses, Landfills and Kangaroos
description: Charles McGraths On Par essay last week extolling the beauty of bad golf courses elicited a long list of reader tributes to the ugly ducklings of the game, including courses with abandoned cars, moose droppings and kangaroos.

title: Serb Fugitive Slowly Starved of Friends and Cash
description: BELGRADE, Serbia  The arrest of war crimes fugitive Ratko Mladic, found hiding inside a darkened house in a Serbian village last week, came from methodically pressuring his waning network of supporters and draining his financial lifeline so thoroughly that his most bitter complaint when captured was a demand for his frozen military pension of 140 euros a month, according to investigators in Serbia.

title: For Ex-Officers Wife, Anger at His Accuser and Tears at an Upended Life
description: Kenneth Moreno, the former police officer acquitted of rape last week, gazed toward the pavement, choosing his words carefully, thinking of a measured way to describe his feelings about the woman who had accused him.

title: Young and Bored, Behind the Wheel
description: BENGHAZI, Libya  The battered white sedan plunged forward, its engine whining and tires screaming, across the long, tiled plaza in a practiced routine of skids and slides. With a quick yank of the wheel, the driver narrowly missed other snaking cars, and with a tug of the hand brake jerked to a halt inches shy of a crowd of cheering spectators.

title: The Battle for Libya | May 29, 2011
description: Rebel recruits graduate and frontline fire gets heavier.

title: Outbreak of Infections Kills 10 in Germany
description: BERLIN  With 10 people dead of infection and 400 cases reported, the European Center for Disease Prevention and Control said Sunday that a bacterial outbreak in northern Germany was one of the largest of its kind ever reported worldwide.

title: Looking Like His Old Self, Watson Adds Another Major Title
description: Great players dont forget how to do great things. When a defining moment comes, and a golfer like Tom Watson has an opportunity to win a major championship as he did on Sunday its just a matter of whether the body will do what the old head tells it to do.

title: Syrian Forces Struck Northern Villages, Activists Say
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon  The Syrian government deployed the military and security forces to four villages and towns on Sunday, killing at least eight people and wounding many others, in the latest attempt to crush a two-month-old uprising against the leadership of President Bashar al-Assad, human rights groups and activists said.

title: Nepal Averts Crisis Over Constitution Deadline
description: KATMANDU, Nepal  Nepals political parties averted a crisis on Sunday by reaching a last-minute deal that extended the deadline for a new constitution. Prime Minister Jhalanath Khanal agreed to step down as part of the deal.

title: Feud in Kazakh Presidents Family Spills Into U.S.
description: WASHINGTON  Four years ago, Kazakhstans foreign minister summoned the United States ambassador to a meeting in Astana, the capital of his oil-rich nation, to warn that a family squabble between the countrys president and his son-in-law  two of the countrys most powerful men  had boiled over.

title: A Crackdown on Employing Illegal Workers
description: TUCSON  Obama administration officials are sharpening their crackdown on the hiring of illegal immigrants by focusing increasingly tough criminal charges on employers while moving away from criminal arrests of the workers themselves.

title: Changes in Oregon Law Put Faith-Healing Parents on Trial
description: OREGON CITY, Ore.  At the Clackamas County courthouse here, Timothy and Rebecca Wyland sat next to each other  ramrod straight, their shoulders barely touching  as they watched images of their daughter flash on the screen.

title: Seeing the Advantage in Delaying a Solution
description: WASHINGTON  Soon enough, Democrats will have to identify new Medicare cuts they can support.

title: An Unclear Course on Emissions Policy
description: SAN FRANCISCO  Opposition to cap and trade, a regulatory tool for curbing greenhouse gas emissions, normally comes from the right end of the political spectrum, where it is derided as cap and tax.

title: Missouri, Baylor and Cal Advance to World Series
description: Missouri, Baylor and California won super-regional finals to complete the field for the Womens College World Series. The eight-team tournament begins Thursday in Oklahoma City.

title: Congressman Says Hacker Sent Lewd Photo Using His Name
description: Representative Anthony D. Weiner, one of the most prolific users of social media among politicians, said his Twitter account was hacked this weekend when someone sent out a lewd photograph under his name to a young woman in Seattle.

title: Finding Voice in the Pain of a Family and Its Fall
description: GREENVILLE, S.C.  When Victoria Ford was a little girl growing up in Memphis, her family was so widely known, strangers would see her at the grocery store, notice a resemblance and ask, Are you a Ford?

title: The Landscape in the Backyard Is Hydroelectric
description: Ron and Melodie Koe were cruising sunny Eastern Washington in search of a retirement home three years ago when they happened down Columbia Avenue here. The houses, cottages built in the 1930s, were adorable. Old maples lined the sidewalks. Everything was immaculate.

title: Utah Law Makes Coins Worth Their Weight in Gold (or Silver)
description: FARR WEST, Utah  Most people who amass the pure gold and silver coins produced by the United States Mint do so for collections or investments, not to buy Slurpees at 7-Eleven.

title: Earnhardt Out of Fuel; Harvick Wins
description: CHARLOTTE, N.C.  Only a driver as beloved as Dale Earnhardt Jr. could deliver such exquisite agony to his long suffering fans.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,581 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the deaths of the following Americans recently:

title: NYT: Front Page for 05/30/2011
description: NYT: Front Page for 05/30/2011

title: Chinese Try to Appease Mongolians
description: HOHHOT, Inner Mongolia  Chinese authorities publicly acknowledged for the first time on Sunday the depth of anger among ethnic Mongolians over the hit-and-run killing of a herder by a Han Chinese truck driver nearly three weeks ago, which became a catalyst for days of street protests and led to fears among officials here of an outbreak in anti-Han violence.

title: Paul J. Wiedorfer, Hero of the Battle of the Bulge, Dies at 90
description: Paul J. Wiedorfer, who earned the Medal of Honor for charging across an icy field in Belgium in 1944 and eliminating two German machine-gun nests that had pinned down his platoon, died on Wednesday in Baltimore. He was 90.

title: Sergei Bagapsh, Abkhazias Leader, Dies at 62
description: MOSCOW  Sergei V. Bagapsh, who led the Black Sea enclave of Abkhazia through a tumultuous effort to gain independence from Georgia without being absorbed by Russia, died Sunday in Moscow. He was 62.

title: Photo Replay: May 29
description: A view of the day in sports, from the courts of Paris to the crashes in Indianapolis.

title: To a Restless Little Brother Calling for Mama in His Sleep
description: You may not understand this now, but she isnt coming back. Not tonight. Not tomorrow. Day after that. And no, she hasnt left anything behind  a sticky note on the refrigerator door or a quick message for the answering machine, her voice a distant echo calling your name and mine. Nothing. Im sorry because I know you get scared when the wind blows hard like this at night, when the shadows on your ceiling shuffle as if theyve been alive all this time. But Im right here. And the sun will not rise for another few hours and the birds outside are still sleeping remember Johnjohn, your favorite cardinals nestled in the Sweet Gum tree down by the mailbox? The babies wrapped in small, ruby feathers. Thats how you should be right now. Dreaming and resting and not worrying.

title: As Physicians Jobs Change, So Do Their Politics
description: AUGUSTA, Me.  With Republicans in complete control of Maines state government for the first time since 1962, State Senator Lois A. Snowe-Mello offered a bill in February to limit doctors liability that she was sure the powerful doctors lobby would cheer. Instead, it asked her to shelve the measure.

title: Hackers Disrupt PBS Web Site and Post a Fake Report About a Rap Artist
description: The PBS Web site briefly carried a fake article claiming that the famed rapper Tupac Shakur was alive and living in New Zealand after a group of hackers took over the organizations computer systems on Saturday night.

title: Germany, in Reversal, Will Close Nuclear Plants by 2022
description: BERLIN  The German government on Monday announced plans to shut all of the nations nuclear power plants within the next 11 years, a sharp reversal for Chancellor Angela Merkel after the Japanese disaster at Fukushima caused an electoral backlash by voters opposed to reliance on nuclear energy.

title: Latino Artists on Display at London Fair
description: Latin American exuberance will pervade the Pinta Latin American Art Fair, from June 7 to 9 at the Earls Court Exhibition Center. Featuring both established and emerging artists, the exhibition (Brompton Hall, Warwick Road, Earls Court; www.eco.co.uk) will bring together works from 50 American and European galleries all in one inviting setting.

title: The Case for Ken Andersons Place in the Hall of Fame
description: Kerry J. Byrne of the Cold, Hard Football Facts has been making the case for Ken Andersons enshrinement into the Hall of Fame, based on three sets of qualifications:

title: Shared Capitalism
description: Nancy Folbre is an economics professor at the University of Massachusetts Amherst.

title: The Early Word: Commemorations
description: Todays Times

title: Chasing Win Record, Djokovic Faces Tough Finale
description: PARIS  Fabio Fognini, citing a muscle tear in his leg, pulled out of the French Open on Monday, altering the arc of Novak Djokovics winning streak.

title: Air India Faces Hurdles in Joining Alliance
description: NEW DELHI  Air India, the troubled state-owned airline, risks being rejected by the Star Alliance network of airlines because of delays in fulfilling membership conditions, an executive from Star Alliance said Monday, putting in jeopardy a key element of its turnaround plan.

title: Suspended in Space, 103 Stories Over Chicago
description: CHICAGO  The view looking down through the glass floor toward South Wacker Drive is just what youd expect if you were balanced on top of 6,960 boxes of this citys deep-dish pizza  or, as the exhibition at the Willis Tower also tells us, standing atop 313 Oprah Winfreys or 283 Barack Obamas.

title: Complaint Box | Pre-Ponderance
description: Every day, it seems, I am preapproved, prequalified or precertified for yet another credit card or home equity loan that I dont want. I already have enough credit cards, thank you, so that I can prepay my daughters college tuition, allowing her to preregister for courses (pre-med? pre-law?). I can use those cards to pile up air miles so that I can preboard a plane at the airport (after pre-check-in, of course). I can even preorder items during the annual presale event at a major department store.

title: Tempted to Speed? Consider Your Auto Insurance
description: Steep prices at the gasoline pump arent the only thing drivers need to worry about this summer travel season. Speeding tickets and other moving violations can increase your automobile insurance rates by double digits, a recent analysis shows.

title: Yemeni Military Battles Opponents on Two Fronts
description: SANA, Yemen  The government pounded a major coastal city on Monday with airstrikes to dislodge Islamic militants and, to the west, smashed the countrys largest antigovernment demonstration in overnight clashes that killed at least 20 protesters, according to witnesses reached by phone.

title: Heading the IMF
description: I suspect that an endorsement from me may be the kiss of death  but anyway, Stan Fischer really would be the best choice.

title: Godwins Law, Monetary Edition
description: Any mention of the advantages of a higher inflation target will evoke, almost immediately, claims that youre trying to turn America into the Weimar Republic and/or Zimbabwe.

title: The Unkillable Yield Curve Fallacy (Wonkish)
description: Bad ideas in economics never die; they just wait a few months, then resurface, once again touted as wisdom.

title: Qaddafi and Zuma Meet but Reach No Agreement
description: TRIPOLI, Libya  Talks between President Jacob Zuma of South Africa and Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi ended Monday with no sign of the breakthrough Libyan officials had said they hoped for ahead of the visit. The outcome appeared to leave the Tripoli government and its rebel foes still mired in the stalemate that has settled over the conflict, and NATO with the prospect of an extended campaign of airstrikes in its bid to topple the Libyan leader.

title: Taliban Attack in Herat, Far From Their Usual Areas
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The Taliban launched an unusual attack on targets in the western Afghan city of Herat on Monday, including a NATO base, and the police said at least 4 people had been killed and 38 wounded.

title: Monday Reading: Bargain Trips in the Mountains or the Desert
description: A variety of consumer-focused articles appears daily in The New York Times and online in our blogs. Each weekday morning, we gather them together here so you can quickly scan the news that could hit you in your wallet.

title: Carnegies Ousted Residents Agree: Film Has Sad Ending
description: It was not billed as a three-hankie movie  it was a documentary, after all. But Editta Sherman started sobbing a few minutes after the lights went down, and not because of the way she looked on the screen.

title: Palin Family Tours Washington Incognito
description: Sarah Palin and her family sneaked out in Washington on Sunday night for what she called an incognito tour of the national monuments, having successfully created a media frenzy and then ditched the press.

title: Li Fires Husband as Coach, Advances to Quarterfinals
description: PARIS  At the Australian Open earlier this year, the surging Li Na reached her first Grand Slam final. She gave credit to her husband and coach, Jiang Shan, saying she would love her husband even if he were fat and ugly.

title: Capturing Moments of Naval History in New York
New Data on High Unemployment Among Recent Veterans
description: Much has been said about the high unemployment rate among veterans from the post-9/11 wars, but a new Congressional study offers some fresh insights into the nature of the problem, which does not appear to be going away anytime soon.

title: Djokovic-Gasquet: the Mental Mismatch
description: Most matches are decided before the players take the court. Each player, according to this theory, knows who will win, and the loser spends a lot of energy playing just well enough to have a respectable showing, but without truly believing victory is possible.

title: In a Flash, Bryans Advance in Doubles
description: PARIS - Workmanlike is the word that describes Bob and Mike Bryan of the United States, the worlds top-ranked team, as they move through the mens doubles draw at the French Open.

title: The Facts Have A Liberal Bias, Again
description: Steve Benen watches an entire panel on Meet the Press condemn Democrats for accurately describing the Ryan plan:

title: Tressel Quits as N.C.A.A. Investigates Ohio State
description: Jim Tressel resigned as the football coach at Ohio State on Monday, an abrupt move in a long but escalating scandal that has ensnared the university in an N.C.A.A. investigation and sullied Tressels reputation.

title: Animal Kingdom Sharp in First Gallop Since Preakness
description: On a day when the Kentucky Derby runner-up, Nehro, put in a smashing work at Churchill Downs (6 furlongs in 1:12.2), Animal Kingdom put in his first gallop since his second-place finish in the Preakness Stakes.

title: Fortis to Buy Vermont Utility for $470.3 Million
description: Fortis Incorporated, a Canadian power company, said on Monday that it would expand its presence in the United States by buying Central Vermont Public Service for $470.3 million in cash. It will also assume the companys $230 million in debt.

title: Copenhagen Interpretation Finance
Nadal Cruises Past Ljubicic into Quarters
description: PARIS  Ivan Ljubicic wore a worried expression on his tanned face. It was only 1-1 in the first set against Rafael Nadal, the French Opens top seed, but Ljubicic was already struggling with his serve.

title: The Changing Politics of Doctors
description: Doctors were once overwhelmingly male and conservative. But today the politics of the medical profession are changing, as more doctors abandon independent practice for salaried jobs and more women are graduating from medical school, reports Gardiner Harris in the latest installment of his Doctors, Inc. series.

title: Numberplay: A Triplet of Time Puzzles
description: Neil Bickford recently calculated the first 458 million terms for the continued fraction of pi. Thats a record. He cranked out the giant calculation several months ago to celebrate his 13th birthday. Holy cats! you might say: 458 million terms! Its true. Heres Mr. Bickfords account of the adventure, including a link to a complete list of the terms.

title: Dempsey Appointed as Chairman of Joint Chiefs
description: WASHINGTON  President Obama on Monday nominated Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the Army chief, to help steer the American armed forces through the three present conflicts in Muslim countries as the next chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

title: Monfils Delights Crowd With Five-Set Victory Over Ferrer
description: PARIS - If Gael Monfils, the flamboyant French dynamo, picked a favorite shot from his 6-4, 2-6, 7-5, 1-6, 8-6 victory over David Ferrer of Spain, it might be an inside-out forehand that split Court Suzanne Lenghlen into two sharp angles and bounded onward for a winner. It was seven games into the fifth set and it put Monfils ahead, 5-2.

title: Blatter Defiant During News Conference
description: 1:10 p.m. | Updated  Sepp Blatters news conference in Zurich, which was scheduled to begin at 12 p.m., Eastern, did not start until 12:35 p.m. What follows is a transcript of the news conference that was streamed live at FIFA.com.

title: Anger Over Protesters Deaths Leads to Intensified Demonstrations by Mongolians
description: HOHHOT, China  Ethnic Mongolians seething over the killings of two Mongolians by Han Chinese drivers took their anger to the streets of this capital of Inner Mongolia on Monday in a rare expression of antigovernment sentiment here.

title: Justice Stevens Is Off the Bench but Not Out of Opinions
description: WASHINGTON

title: Palins Continue Roll Through Washington
description: Day 2 of the Sarah Palin bus tour started Monday morning with a visit to the National Archives in Washington, where she and her family took a private moment to look at the Constitution.

title: Rollins, Fearless Forecaster, Makes Call on N.B.A. Finals, Too
description: When it comes to baseball, Jimmy Rollins has been exceptionally accurate in the forecasting business. He predicted that the Phillies would win 100 games in 2008; they won 103 and captured the World Series. In 2009, he predicted that the Phillies would meet the Yankees in the World Series; they did. (He also said that Philadelphia would win; well, cant win em all.)

title: 30 Years In, We Are Still Learning From AIDS
description: At first it seemed an oddity: a scattering of reports in the spring and early summer of 1981 that young gay men in New York and California were ill with forms of pneumonia and cancer usually seen only in people with severely weakened immune systems.

title: At City Ballet, the Big Boss Plays the Big Boss
description: A mild tremor of excitement ran through the New York City Ballet audience on Sunday afternoon as the cast of George Balanchines Slaughter on Tenth Avenue took a bow. The dark-suited and hatted dancer who had played the Big Boss in the delightful tale of murder and mayhem at the ballet, had just popped out of the wings, performed a quick, modest salute, and popped back in. It took a moment to realize that the Big Boss was in fact the Big Boss. Peter Martins, the ballet master in chief of the company, had stepped in for an injured Ask la Cour the previous night, and reappeared at the matinee with no fanfare or announcement of the change in cast.

title: Exercise and Olives
description: Im spending a lot of time alone this summer, and though Im a pretty good companion for myself (I think that all my jokes are hilarious), theres always room for more ways to stay entertained.

title: Two New York Hotels Allow You to Sleep Under the Stars
description: In years past, hotel rooms offering outdoor showers in Manhattan were all the rage. This year, the latest in urban en plein air living is the outdoor bedroom.

title: Chinas Economy Slows, but Inflation Still Looms
description: CHANGSHA, China  Chinas economy is starting to slow, after two years of torrid growth achieved following the global downturn.

title: Soderling Squashes Simons French Dream
description: PARIS - For the crowd at Roland Garros, the prize would have been two Frenchmen stepping into the final eight of their countrys international championship, the French Open. First, Gael Monfils made half of that prize come true. Then, Gilles Simon had a chance to join him.

title: Surprise Victory in New York Invigorates Democrats Looking to 2012
description: WASHINGTON  Sal Pace, the Democratic leader of the State House in Colorado, was already preparing to run for Congress in a district captured by Republicans last year, but his partys special election victory last week in a conservative district in upstate New York made the decision all the easier.

title: Police Investigator Is Cleared in Death of Russian Awaiting Trial
description: MOSCOW  Russias Investigative Committee said Monday that prosecutors had cleared a police investigator of any wrongdoing in the case of Sergei L. Magnitsky, whose death in pre-trial detention is viewed as a test of countrys law enforcement and judicial systems.

title: Does Money Grow on Art Market Trees? Not for Everyone
description: As all the talk of record prices demonstrates, contemporary art has soared in value over the last 10 years, outperforming stocks as an investment and drawing attention to possible bonanzas to be found in the market.

title: Seeds of Promise
description: A few years ago, we began to hear a lot about flaxseeds. Rich in omega-3 fatty acids, these seeds also are loaded with vitamin E, B vitamins and certain important minerals (manganese, potassium, calcium, iron, magnesium, zinc and selenium). Impressed, Id buy flaxseeds from time to time and add them to breads, muffins or granola. But to be honest, I never much liked the taste.

title: Mladic Appeals Extradition on Health Grounds
description: BELGRADE, Serbia  The lawyer for the war crimes suspect Ratko Mladic mailed an appeal of his extradition order on health grounds Monday, a tactic likely to result in a short delay in the ex-generals departure from Serbia for trial before the special tribunal for the former Yugoslavia in The Hague.

title: The Difference-Maker: Monfilss Backhand
description: Gael Monfils won the first set over David Ferrer with remarkably consistent play off the backhand side. It was clear from the outset that Ferrer was going to work over the Monfils backhand, trying to break down the shot with a relentless assault. Monfils was ready, however, and played patiently with a high shot tolerance to thwart the Spaniards opening tactics.

title: Box Office Welcomes Another Hangover
description: The Hangover Part II has sold about $137.4 million in tickets since opening in North American theaters on Thursday, according to results compiled by Hollywood.com. That performance  the biggest debut for a live-action comedy and the strongest opening for an R-rated comedy  helped drive robust business for the Memorial Day weekend.Audiences for the top 12 films over the four-day weekend spent about $272.8 million on tickets, up 48 percent from the same period last year. (The figures were not adjusted for inflation or to account for 3-D and Imax ticket prices.)

title: Blatter Sidesteps Tough Questions
description: Sepp Blatter, the embattled president of FIFA, endured more than 30 minutes of questions, many of which he deflected, during an often contentious news conference Monday in Zurich.

title: Charges for Opposition Protest in Georgia
description: MOSCOW  Authorities in Georgia on Monday charged the husband of a prominent opposition leader with organizing attacks on police, using paramilitary groups during violent anti-government protests last week.

title: More Blows to Berlusconi Coalition
description: ROME  Italys ruling center-right coalition was resoundingly beaten in runoff administrative elections on Monday, a defeat that further weakened Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi, who has been besieged by growing dissent within his razor-thin majority and faces criminal charges in court.

title: The Morning Line: As Horses Arrive at Belmont, Alternation Is Out
description: Alternation, the winner of the Peter Pan Stakes at Belmont Park on May 12, will not race in the Belmont. According to the Daily Racing Form, Alternation will concentrate on major stakes events over the summer. Alternations trainer Donnie Van Hemel said, We looked things over and decided to take a breather.  The horse is fine. We just decided to point for races like the Jim Dandy and the Travers. Hes had four or five races early in the year.We want to give him a little breather now, then make some noise later.

title: The Squeaky Joint
description: Q. Is there research on whether fish oil supplements help ease joint pain?

title: Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, 11:55 a.m.
Childbirth: Every Week in Utero Counts, Study Says
description: Pregnancies lasting at least 37 weeks are regarded as safely full-term, but new research finds that babies born in the 37th or 38th week of pregnancy have a higher risk of dying before their first birthdays than those born after 39 weeks of gestation.

title: Patterns: Seniors Fare Better Where Doctors Are
description: Older adults who live in areas with high concentrations of primary care doctors are less likely than those in areas with fewer such doctors to be hospitalized for illnesses that can be managed outside a hospital, like asthma and diabetes, a new study has found.

title: Risks: Hypertension Lurking in Young Adults
description: A new study finds that nearly one in five young adults has high blood pressure, a startling estimate much higher than any previously reported.

title: A Resolute Sharapova Holds Off Radwanska
description: PARIS  Agnieszka Radwanska of Poland, her left leg heavily bandaged, managed to jump ahead of Maria Sharapova of Russia, 3-0, in a fourth-round match Monday at the French Open. For awhile, she didnt dare look back.

title: A Good Nights Sleep Isnt a Luxury; Its a Necessity
description: In my younger years, I regarded sleep as a necessary evil, natures way of thwarting my desire to cram as many activities into a 24-hour day as possible. I frequently flew the red-eye from California, for instance, sailing (or so I thought) through the next day on less than four hours of uncomfortable sleep.

title: Drug Trade Flourishes in Spanish Port Town
description: BARBATE, SPAIN  In the police station of Barbate, a port town in the southern region of Andalusia, officers have pinned a poster to the wall that reads they owe us April, referring to the late payment of their salaries.

title: The Claim: A Diet High in Protein Is Bad for Your Kidneys
description: THE FACTS

title: Dissident Plans a More Active Role in Myanmar
description: HONG KONG  Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the most high-profile dissident in Myanmar, signaled on Monday that she would be seeking to broaden her audience in her country since being released from house arrest.

title: Dispatching the Worn Narrative of the 2006 Finals
description: When the Dallas Mavericks and Miami Heat crystallized their date to meet in the N.B.A. Finals, media dreams of rehashed narratives came true. Dirk Nowitzki will finally be given his shot at revenge and redemption, or so say the series taglines. Yet depicting these N.B.A. Finals as a rematch or even a re-imagining doesnt do the matchup justice; these teams arent two shadows of their 2006 counterparts, but unique and successful basketball machines. Sport doesnt pack the same punch without the underlying story, but is it really necessary to dig up ancient history?

title: Young Russians in Brooklyn Find Love, the Wonder Wheel and Then Life
description: There comes a point in almost every relationship when you discuss the future. Where is this heading? Do you want to get married? Do you want to get married? Vaclav and Lena have had this talk. It has gone well. Vaclav and Lena are 10.

title: Gaining Perspective, Small and Large, With Dolls
description: In the movie Honey, I Shrunk the Kids, an inventor accidently miniaturizes his children, making the world appear enormous to them. Now, scientists have simulated the sensation of feeling tiny using cameras and a doll.

title: Housing Index Is Expected to Show a New Low in Prices
description: SAN FRANCISCO  The desire to own your own home, long a bedrock of the American Dream, is fast becoming a casualty of the worst housing downturn since the Great Depression.

title: In I.P.O. Price Debate, an Investment Giant Weighs In
description: You might recall that about a week ago, my colleague Joe Nocera wrote an intriguing column about LinkedIns initial public offering, in which he said that the bankers who underwrote the deal scammed the social network company by pricing it too low, lining the pockets of its investor clients.

title: The Bilingual Advantage
description: A cognitive neuroscientist, Ellen Bialystok has spent almost 40 years learning about how bilingualism sharpens the mind. Her good news: Among other benefits, the regular use of two languages appears to delay the onset of Alzheimer’s disease symptoms. Dr. Bialystok, 62, a distinguished research professor of psychology at York University in Toronto, was awarded a $100,000 Killam Prize last year for her contributions to social science. We spoke for two hours in a Washington hotel room in February and again, more recently, by telephone. An edited version of the two conversations follows.

title: Darkness Delays Fifth Set of Murray-Troicki
description: PARIS - Victor Troicki of Serbia jumped out to a 5-0 lead in the first set of his match with Andy Murray of Britain at the French Open Monday.

title: Pharmaceutical Giant to Give $5.7 Million Toward Health Programs in Poor Countries
description: Fulfilling a promise made several years ago, the pharmaceutical giant GlaxoSmithKline, based in London, will use 20 percent of the profits it made in the worlds poorest countries to finance health care initiatives, the company announced last week.

title: Shoulda Coulda Woulda
description: Jared Bernstein has a thoughtful response to todays column; oh, and by the way, people should be reading his blog.

title: Bali: Art, Ritual Performance
description: Images from the exhibition in San Francisco.

title: A Storied Paradise, Tempered by Reality
description: SAN FRANCISCO  On a recent nothing-special weekday afternoon, I walked into the Asian Art Museum here and found a Balinese gamelan concert in progress: clanging gongs, pulsing drums, jazzy flutes, the whole real heavenly thing, with musicians settled cross-legged on a fabric-draped platform and a rapt crowd of museumgoers, many quite young, on benches, folding chairs and the floor.

title: New Evidence on Irans Nuclear Aspirations
description: In a report by the International Atomic Energy Agency, seven categories of technology are cited as possible evidence that Tehrans nuclear program aims to build an implosion nuclear device.

title: Wal-Mart Is Being Pressed to Disclose How Global Suppliers Treat Workers
description: Wal-Mart is facing new pressure to monitor and disclose how its international suppliers treat their workers.

title: Bubble-debt Denialism
description: For a project Im working on, I went back to the famous 2004 speech in which Alan Greenspan not only denied that there was a national housing bubble, but denied that it was even possible to have a national housing bubble.

title: Inspectors Pierce Irans Cloak of Nuclear Secrecy
description: The International Atomic Energy Agency last week presented a report to its board that laid out new information on what it calls possible military dimensions of Irans nuclear program, clarifying the central issue in the long clash between Tehran and the West over nuclear technology.

title: Shes Married to a Gunman and Willing to Sing About It
description: Theres a lot of pretty good in the first act of I Married Wyatt Earp, a musical at 59E59 Theaters. The story? Pretty good. Songs? Pretty good. Acting, singing, jokes? Same, same, same. Yet as it wanders into an aimless second act, that pretty goodness wanes, and you long for the show to race toward a bigger finish or to stop and explore a smaller moment.

title: Groundwater Depletion Is Detected From Space
description: IRVINE, Calif.  Scientists have been using small variations in the Earths gravity to identify trouble spots around the globe where people are making unsustainable demands on groundwater, one of the planets main sources of fresh water.

title: The Not-as-Hot Art Market for Formerly Hot Artists
description: The contemporary art market has boomed in the last 10 years, characterized by the steep ascent of artists like Gerhard Richter. But the work of some contemporary artists has not appreciated at the same rate.

title: Timescast | Protest in Inner Mongolia
description: May 30, 2011 - The Chinese police disbursed demonstrators in Hohhot, China, who were protesting the deaths five days ago of two ethnic Mongolians, caused by Han Chinese drivers.

title: On the Road, More or Less, With Palin
description: Heres an update for those of you following the whereabouts of Sarah Palin, the former governor of Alaska.

title: Brooding Now Laced With Hope
description: DEATH CAB FOR CUTIE

title: Summerworks Plays Are Announced
description: Clubbed Thumb, the Obie Award-winning New York theater company that commissions, develops and produces provocative plays, has announced titles for the 16th annual Summerworks festival, from Sunday through June 25, at Here Arts Center in Manhattan. The festival, which highlights original works by American playwrights, will feature three new plays, according to  Maria Striar, Clubbed Thumbs producing artistic director. They are  Tanya Sarachos Enfrascada, directed by  Jerry Ruiz, from Thursday through June 11;  Kristin Newbom and  W. David Hancocks Our Lot, directed by  May Adrales, from June 12 through 18; and  Jason Grotes Civilization (All You Can Eat), directed by  Seth Bockley, from June 19 through 25.

title: Sean Kingston Remains in Hospital After Crash
description: The pop star Sean Kingston who was hospitalized in Miami after an accident involving a personal watercraft on Sunday, was listed in stable condition on Monday, Billboard.com reported. The publicist Joseph Carozza issued a statement saying that Mr. Kingston, 21, had been moved to intensive care from the trauma unit. Seans family thanks everyone for their prayers and support during this time, Mr. Carozza said. Mr. Kingston, whose real name is Kisean Anderson, was taken to Jackson Memorial Hospital after he and a female passenger aboard his watercraft crashed into a bridge around 6 p.m. A boater rescued them from the water, and crews took them to the hospital. No details regarding the injuries have been released. Since breaking out with his debut single, Beautiful Girls, in 2007, Mr. Kingston has scored hits like Take You There, Fire Burning and Eenie Meenie with Justin Bieber, whom he joined on tour last year. Mr. Kingston received an outpouring of support by his fans and his peers on Twitter, including Mr. Bieber, Rihanna, Nicki Minaj and Chris Brown.

title: Artists Remember Gil Scott-Heron
description: Tributes have been pouring in from around the world from musicians and friends of the poet and music pioneer Gil Scott-Heron, who died on Friday at 62. Eminem,  Talib Kweli and Snoop Dogg were among the rappers who acknowledged Mr. Scott-Herons early influence on hip-hop and black protest culture after hearing the news, according to BBC News. The cause of death was not immediately known, though The Associated Press reported that Mr. Scott-Heron had become ill after returning from a trip to Europe. Chuck D of Public Enemy posted on Twitter, We do what we do and how we do because of you. Wu-Tang Clans Ghostface Killah wrote: Salute Gil Scott-Heron for his wisdom and poetry! May he rest in paradise. Eminem wrote on Twitter: RIP Gil Scott-Heron. He influenced all of hip-hop. Cee Lo Green recognized the god Gil Scott, while Talib Kweli said he completely influenced me as an artist. The politically outspoken rapper Michael Franti said Mr. Scott-Herons talent was his ability to make us think about the world in a different way.  Richard Russell, who produced and released Mr. Scott-Herons final album, Im New Here in 2010, described him as a master lyricist, singer, orator and keyboard player.  Lemn Sissay, a friend of Mr. Scott-Herons who produced a documentary on his work, told the BBC that he was a polymath who spoke crucially of the issues of his people.

title: Royal Love Story Heads to Hallmark
description: You saw the wedding. You followed the postnuptials gossip. Now a film about the romance of Prince William and Kate Middleton is expected to be released in August on the Hallmark Channel, The Associated Press reported. William & Kate: A Royal Love Story is a mixture of fact and fiction, according to the director, Linda Yellen, who took some time out from filming at MediaPro Studios in Romania to talk with The A.P. about her project. Ms. Yellen was the producer of CBSs film The Royal Romance of Charles and Diana (1982), which drew a huge audience. William & Kate is more than a romance; its also a psychological story of the memory of the mother, in this case Princess Diana, and her legacy, Ms. Yellen said. The film shows how William has to choose to live his life with her memory and with the decisions he has to make, including the decision of whom to marry. The couple were married on April 29 in a lavish ceremony at Westminster Abbey. Filming for the movie, which imagines some scenes from the couples romance, began in early May. Ms. Yellen, who met Princess Diana, described the project as a very personal story. She added, In a way, its my tribute to her as well as a tribute to the young couple.

title: Morning Feast on the Bolshoi (Popcorn, Too)
description: On Sunday morning, in a live transmission of the Bolshoi Ballets production of the three-act Copplia, the extraordinary ballerina Natalia Osipova bounded with her characteristic lan onto a New York cinema screen. The camera  though only employing close-ups for acting passages  often followed her full-frame, so that we had only a blurry sense of the space around her: disorienting but exciting. In the intimate cinema, people kept starting to applaud.

title: Despite Advances, Tornado Forecasts Show Limits
description: It was a warm, damp day in central Nebraska, heavy and still. The tornado arrived at the Madsen farm just before 3 p.m. Mads Madsen, 63, his wife Minnie, 59, three of their children and five of their grandchildren were in the parlor eating Sunday dinner. Twenty minutes later all 10 of them were dead.

title: From Elegiac Appalachian Hollers to New Terrain
description: Making Romulus Linneys Tennessee the centerpiece of Series A of the Ensemble Studio Theaters 33rd annual festival of one-acts was a fine idea.

title: Viral Outbreaks in Dogs Yield Clues on Origins of Hepatitis C
description: Hepatitis C is, in some ways, a high-profile disease. Worldwide, an estimated 200 million people are infected with the virus. Some of them will suffer cirrhosis, liver cancer and even death. Celebrities like Steven Tyler of Aerosmith and American Idol have spoken publicly of their infections.

title: To Rest Easy, Forget the Sheep
description: Scientists know that many people inadvertently undermine their ability to fall asleep and stay asleep for a full night. Here are some frequent suggestions:

title: Tracking Economy, CO2 Emissions Hit New High
description: The International Energy Agency has reported that global emissions of carbon dioxide from energy use, tracking the recovering world economy,  hit a new high of 30.6 billion metric tons of the gas last year. (Emissions from deforestation and activities like cement manufacturing are not included.) Thats 5 percent above the previous peak, measured in 2008.

title: With Their Fingers Crossed, Fans in Boston Embrace the Bruins
description: BOSTON  It has been a long time since so many Bostonians cared so much about the Bruins.

title: Broad Brushstrokes Obscure a View of Brain Trauma
description: On a fall afternoon in 1988, Jon Sarkin, a 35-year-old Massachusetts chiropractor, was happily playing the eighth hole on a local golf course when he felt something twist in his brain. Three days later he began to hear a high-pitched screech, a siren that only grew louder with the passing weeks. Doctors shrugged; a brain scan suggested a vague abnormality near a nerve at the base of the brain that controls hearing and balance.

title: Reyes Placed on Bereavement List
description: Jose Reyes left the Mets on Monday after the death of his grandmother and may be gone as long as a week on bereavement leave. That means a team already battered by injuries will now be without its best everyday player this season.

title: PBS Plans Promotional Breaks Within Programs
description: FOR decades, the uninterrupted programming on PBS has been one of its most distinctive selling points to audiences and philanthropic and corporate supporters alike.

title: A Source of Strength to Help Conquer Addiction
description: First off, the counselor began, her lips pursed in disdain, its important you understand that I dont have a nickel in the dime  an addiction therapists way of saying this was my fight, not hers.

title: Translation Matters in Choices on Data
description: If your doctor tells you that highly reliable studies have shown that taking a certain pill will cut your risk of getting a serious disease in half, would you take it?

title: In Japan, a Culture That Promotes Nuclear Dependency
description: KASHIMA, Japan  When the Shimane nuclear plant was first proposed here more than 40 years ago, this rural port town put up such fierce resistance that the plants would-be operator, Chugoku Electric, almost scrapped the project. Angry fishermen vowed to defend areas where they had fished and harvested seaweed for generations.

title: The Hotel Push for In-Room Movies
description: AT a dinner party in Tucson over the weekend, the subject of movies came up. The five friends there were all business travelers, all movie buffs.

title: Tuning In to Patients Cries for Help
description: Tom Kerr of Pittsburgh will never forget the long-distance call from his elderly mother, who was in a hospital in the Cleveland area with a broken leg.

title: Flying the Sickly Skies (2 Letters)
description: To the Editor:

title: Diagnosis by Remote (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Nadal Keeps Laboring, but He Keeps Winning
description: PARIS  It has often looked like work this year for Rafael Nadal at his favorite playground. He needed five sets in the first round of the French Open to disarm the unconventional weapons of the towering John Isner, and although Nadal has yet to lose another set on his well-worn path to the quarterfinals, there has been grinding and grumbling in unusual quantities.

title: The Final Frontier (1 Letter)
description: To the Editor:

title: Former Pakistani Navy Commando Arrested in Sweep for Attack Suspects
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A former Pakistan Navy commando has been arrested in a sweep by Pakistani intelligence agents in connection with the audacious attack last week on the naval base in the southern port city of Karachi that apparently was planned with inside information about the facility, security officials said Monday.

title: Union Man
description: On May 31, 1861, Joseph Holt spoke out on behalf of the Union. The man who had been Secretary of War in early 1861 (and who has a role played by Danny Huston in Robert Redfords current film, The Conspirator) saw that his native state of Kentucky dangled precariously in the balance. Its leading men had just resolved upon strict neutrality between the Federal government and the Confederacy. Holt would have none of it. Neutrality, he insisted, was a delusion. He would as soon think of being neutral in a contest between an officer of justice and an incendiary arrested in an attempt to fire the dwelling over my head.

title: With Shutout, Colon Continues to Be a Surprise
description: OAKLAND, Calif.  Since Bartolo Colon last pitched here in September 2007  a time before elbow surgery, before retirement was considered, before a rejuvenating medical treatment  the stadium has changed names twice, but its features have remained the same. The roomy dimensions and acres of foul territory reward pitchers unafraid of contact, encouraging them to throw strikes. And one thing Colon can do, has done, is throw strikes.

title: Sudans Peaceful Partition, at Risk
description: Oxford, England

title: Keeping Score: Which Team Has the Right Stuff to Win the Cup?
description: After analyzing the championship games or series of the N.F.L., N.B.A., Major League Baseball and N.H.L., and the major finals in golf and tennis, we identified 50 championship characteristics in our book, Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological and Mathematical Method. Based on similar research, we focused on several championship characteristics that might predict the winner of the Stanley Cup finals, which start Wednesday in Vancouver. Focusing on concepts of sports psychology, we looked at factors such as big-game experience, leadership on the ice and consistency. So important are these concepts to winning championships that they have proven to be common themes across all sports we have studied.

title: Breaches Lead to Push to Protect Medical Data
description: Federal health officials call it the Wall of Shame. Its a government Web page that lists nearly 300 hospitals, doctors and insurance companies that have reported significant breaches of medical privacy in the last couple of years.

title: Testing Students, to Evaluate Teachers
description: To the Editor:

title: A Supreme Court Ruling on Prison Crowding
description: To the Editor:

title: The Art of the Floor Plan: Capturing a Home, Line by Line
description: In the fiercely competitive game of marketing homes, brokers go to great lengths to cast a property in its most flattering light, sanding down rough edges, cleaning out clutter, loading in new furniture and hiring professional photographers to make the glossy images that lure salivating buyers to weekend open houses.

title: Einhorn Says Deal With Mets Is a Win-Win
description: David Einhorn spoke formally in public for the first time since it was announced last Thursday that he is in talks to buy a minority stake in the team. The hedge fund mogul, who met reporters during batting practice before the Mets played the Pittsburgh Pirates at Citi Field on Monday, said that the deal being negotiating with the Wilpon family was a win-win agreement that he hopes will be completed by the end of June.

title: Treatment for H.I.V.
description: To the Editor:

title: Obama Wraps Up Reshaping of National Security Team
description: WASHINGTON  In announcing Monday that he would nominate Gen. Martin E. Dempsey to be chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, President Obama concluded a broad reshuffling of his national security team just as the administration is heading into a new debate over bringing American troops home from Afghanistan.

title: Waiting on Butler
description: Miami received an emotional boost this month as Udonis Haslem returned from a leg injury that stole most of his season. More important, the Heat got an on-court boost from Haslems play in the Eastern Conference finals against Chicago.

title: For Mavericks, What Could Have Been
description: MIAMI  Mark Cuban did not possess oodles of salary-cap space, like LeBron Jamess other suitors last summer, and his Dallas Mavericks were not one of the handful of teams granted Jamess audience and attention during his free-agent deliberations.

title: Sudan Border Strategy May Bring in Ethiopian Peacekeepers
description: JUBA, Sudan  Western diplomats and African leaders are pressing for a new strategy to defuse Sudans bitterly contested Abyei area: bringing in Ethiopian peacekeepers as a buffer between opposing forces.

title: Afghan Central Bank Defends Itself After Critical Report
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  The governor of Afghanistans Central Bank angrily responded Monday to a presidential panels criticism of his agency in connection with a scandal at the nations largest private bank.

title: For Prostitutes, the Discovery of Bodies on Long Island Is Stoking Fear
description: A chill has swept through the regions underground sex trade.

title: Canada Is in No Hurry to Sell Its Chrysler Shares to Fiat
description: OTTAWA  Fiat wants to buy the Canadian governments shares in Chrysler, but Canadas finance minister said on Monday that he was in no hurry to sell.

title: The Right Way to Shrink Prisons
description: Provo, Utah

title: Buckeyes Trials With Tressel Are Test for N.C.A.A.
description: If there is a sure sign that an athletic department is in trouble and a football program is begging for N.C.A.A. mercy, it is the prepared video statement.

title: A Post-9/11 Registration Effort Ends, but Not Its Effects
description: In the jittery months after the 9/11 attacks, the federal government created a program that required thousands of Arab and Muslim men to register with the authorities, in an effort to uncover terror links and immigration violations.

title: Bronx Woman Fatally Shot, Still Clutching Her 2-Year-Old
description: A Bronx woman was fatally shot in the head as she clutched her 2-year-old son, the police said Monday.

title: Money Blows in to a Patch of Oregon Known for Its Unrelenting Winds
description: MORO, Ore.  It pays to live in Sherman County: $590 a year.

title: Instead of Student Loans, Investing in Futures
description: As the global economy has become more knowledge-based, the importance of a university education has risen dramatically. However, only 7 percent of the worlds population currently has a college degree. There are many reasons why people fail to reach college, including, of course, lack of access to quality primary and secondary schooling. But for millions of students who could succeed in college, the limiting factor is money.

title: 2 Americans Are Indicted in Iraq Contract Bribery
description: BAGHDAD  Two American businessmen have been charged with giving Army officers airline tickets, spa vacations and more than $1 million in bribes to secure multimillion-dollar contracts to supply the American military and help rebuild Iraq, according to court documents.

title: Analysis: How Murray Rallied to Tie Troicki
description: Viktor Troicki started fast in Mondays match against Andy Murray, serving bombs and testing Murrays injured right ankle as he swept to a two-set lead. When he broke Murrays serve at 1-1 in the third set, the Scotsman looked dispirited. But he broke right back and began to find rhythm with his footwork and movement.

title: The Good Banker
description: Not long ago, as I was leaving a business lunch, my luncheon companion handed me a thin manila envelope. He didnt tell me what was in it or why he had given it to me, but as soon as I opened it up, I immediately understood.

title: While Virginia Celebrates Another Title, Relief Combines With Elation
description: BALTIMORE  At the end of his strangest season in 29 years of coaching lacrosse, Virginias Dom Starsia looked exhausted, weary, worn. He entered his news conference Monday night drenched in sweat, absent a smile or any outward signs of celebration, yet with his fourth and most unlikely national title already secured.

title: Trees Felled By Joplin Tornado Leaves Broken Landscape
description: Stripped bare by the swirling wind  as if ravaged by wildfire  the skeletons of oak, elm, and hickory stand sentinel over a wasteland.

title: Once-Stately Trees Tell a Tale of Destruction in Joplin
description: JOPLIN, Mo.  The tornados destruction two Sundays ago was so absolute in some areas of this city that the sweep of the landscape is now broken only by the thick skeletons of oak, elm and hickory.

title: Its Not About You
description: Over the past few weeks, Americas colleges have sent another class of graduates off into the world. These graduates possess something of inestimable value. Nearly every sensible middle-aged person would give away all their money to be able to go back to age 22 and begin adulthood anew.

title: Accusations Are Replaced by Anger at FIFA
description: The American official who blew the whistle on the latest charges of corruption in FIFA, soccers world governing body, said Monday that he had not seen concrete evidence of vote-buying in his two decades as a high-ranking executive in the regional confederation in which the United States plays.

title: Abdias do Nascimento, Rights Voice, Dies at 97
description: Abdias do Nascimento, a Brazilian writer, painter, politician and scholar who was an outspoken civil rights leader on behalf of black Brazilians, has died in Rio de Janeiro. He was 97.

title: Keeping an Eye on the Ball
description: Lots of questions have been asked about David Einhorns purchase of a minority stake in the Mets: Will his investment shore up the Mets finances? (Maybe.) Does the deal allow him to take majority control of the Mets? (Yes.) And will he eventually take over the team? (Probably.)

title: Crossing the Church-State Divide by Ark
description: The American landscape is dotted with tourist attractions created with the help of government subsidies bestowed in the name of economic development. Think of the cheese museum in Rome, N.Y. A project just approved in Kentucky pushes the constitutional envelope.

title: Nowitzki and James Took Divergent Paths to Same Goal
description: MIAMI  The N.B.A. finals open Tuesday night, and they are being served up as a delicious contrast: convenience versus commitment, with LeBron Jamess Miami Heat representing professional basketballs version of a precooked meal and Dirk Nowitzkis Dallas Mavericks a team that was lovingly made from scratch.

title: Making Data Roam
description: Verizon Wireless, which provides wireless broadband access across the country, has sued to block a federal rule requiring wireless broadband providers to offer data roaming on commercially reasonable terms. Verizon is entitled to its day in court, but this suit must not prevail.

title: Madoff Victim Seeks Divorce Do-Over
description: After 33 years of marriage, Steven Simkin and Laura Blank divorced in 2006. They agreed to split their considerable wealth equally. She got the apartment on the Upper East Side; he got the house in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: A Wealth Gap in Equatorial Guinea
description: While American companies have invested billions of dollars in this small nations oil infrastructure, World Bank statistics point to widespread poverty among much of the population.

title: Palin Family Hits Road, if Not 2012 Trail
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa.  Sarah Palin dropped a fresh hint Monday about her presidential ambitions, telling reporters that her One Nation bus tour might at some point go to Iowa, where the 2012 voting begins.

title: A Marine Focuses on the Mission
description: From the deck of an aircraft carrier turned tourist attraction on a sunny, humid Memorial Day morning, Sandy Alderson stepped forward to share in the dropping of a ceremonial wreath into the water below in memory of those who had served aboard the decommissioned ship.

title: Raised by a Pastor, and Now Leading a Synagogue
description: Before Heidi Hoover became a rabbi in Brooklyn, she was a pastors daughter in Pennsylvania.

title: A Flying Eye Hospital Raises Security Eyebrows
description: I NEVER thought that Id be traveling as much as I do. But Im flying almost constantly. Its an exhausting, yet rewarding lifestyle.

title: Tizway Wins Fast Met Mile
description: Tizway was an older horse who had a chance to distinguish himself. H. James Bond is a seasoned horseman who had a chance to return to the spotlight. It took horse and trainer only 1 minute 32.9 seconds to blitz through the second-fastest Metropolitan Mile in the races 118-year history on Monday and accomplish both missions.

title: The Numbers Are Grim
description: A month ago, when an initial gauge of first-quarter economic growth came in surprisingly weak, many policy makers and economists expected the bad news to prove fleeting. But when revised data were released last week, the growth estimate remained stuck at an annual rate of 1.8 percent, compared with 3.1 percent at the end of last year.

title: U.S. Engages With an Iron Leader in Equatorial Guinea
description: MALABO, Equatorial Guinea  While the United States has turned its back on some authoritarian rulers in North Africa and the Middle East, its attitude toward strategically placed autocrats in less restive corners of Africa is more ambiguous, and perhaps nowhere more so than in this oil-rich speck of a nation in the Gulf of Guinea.

title: Putting a Crimp in the Hookah
description: Kevin Shapiro, a 20-year-old math and physics major at the University of Pennsylvania, first tried a hookah at a campus party. He liked the exotic water pipe so much that he chipped in to buy one for his fraternity house, where he says it makes a useful social lubricant at parties.

title: Not a Flashy Investor, Just Successful
description: The money manager Martin D. Sass loves a good bargain.

title: Gov. Christie Abandons a Good Idea
description: Running for governor in 2009, Chris Christie vowed to become New Jerseys No. 1 clean-energy advocate. That was a hollow promise. As governor, Mr. Christie proceeded to cut all the money for the Office of Climate and Energy. He raided $158 million from the clean energy fund, meant for alternative energy investments, and spent it on general programs. He withdrew the state from an important lawsuit against electric utilities to reduce emissions.

title: Palin Talks to the Media, for Three Minutes
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa.  Sarah Palin promised reporters on Monday night that if she runs for president, she will break from the usual approaches taken by presidential hopefuls.

title: Bill Clements Dies at 94; Set Texas on G.O.P. Path
description: HOUSTON  Bill Clements, a brash oilman who founded an international drilling company before going into politics and breaking the Democrats stranglehold on the Texas governors office in 1978, died Sunday at a Dallas-area hospital. He was 94.

title: Video of Tortured Boys Corpse Deepens Anger in Syria
description: CAIRO  Hamza Ali al-Khateeb, a round-faced 13-year-old boy, was arrested at a protest in Jiza, a southern Syrian village near Daraa, on April 29. Nothing was known of him for a month before his mutilated corpse was returned to his family on the condition, according to activists, that they never speak of his brutal end.

title: Corrections
description: The Times welcomes comments and suggestions, or complaints about errors that warrant correction. Messages on news coverage can be e-mailed to nytnews@nytimes.com or left toll-free at 1-888-NYT-NEWS (1-888-698-6397). Comments on editorials may be e-mailed to letters@nytimes.com or faxed to (212) 556-3622.

title: Medicare Plan for Payments Irks Hospitals
