description: WASHINGTON  For the first time in its history, Medicare will soon track spending on millions of individual beneficiaries, reward hospitals that hold down costs and penalize those whose patients prove most expensive.

title: Euro Weakens as Greece Struggles With Austerity
description: The euro weakened for the first time in three days versus the dollar, while oil and copper fell in New York on concern that European governments would struggle to resolve the regions debt crisis amid a slowing global recovery.

title: A FrontPoint Founder Tries Again With a New Firm
description: When FrontPoint Partners began in 2000, its founders envisioned the firm as a one-stop shop for multiple hedge funds, a distinctive strategy in an industry dominated at the time by single star managers.

title: Under an Arizona Plan, Smokers and the Obese Would Pay Medicaid Fee
description: Arizona, like many other states, says it is no longer able to finance its Medicaid program adequately. As part of a plan to cut costs, the state has proposed imposing a $50 fee on childless adults on Medicaid who are either obese or who smoke. In Arizona, almost half of all Medicaid recipients smoke; while the number of obese people is unclear, about one in four Arizonans is overweight, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. The states plan must ultimately be approved by the federal government. Monica Coury, spokeswoman for Arizonas Medicaid program, discusses.

title: Where Free Costs a Lot
description: Travelers who signed up for a British Airways Visa card issued by JP Morgan Chase got a sweet deal in a recent promotion: 100,000 frequent flier miles after spending $2,000 with the card  theoretically, enough for two free round-trip tickets between New York and London.

title: Police Say 85-Year-Old Was Sexually Assaulted
description: A man believed to be in his 20s sexually assaulted and robbed an 85-year-old woman on the Upper East Side early Monday, the police said.

title: Names of the Dead
description: The Department of Defense has identified 1,582 American service members who have died as a part of the Afghan war and related operations. It confirmed the death of the following American recently:

title: Bankruptcy Pays, for the Advisers
A Labor of Wonder: Mapping 19,993 Trees in Central Park
description: Every year about 37 million people go to Central Park, and, finding themselves surrounded by 23,000 trees, most do not know their sassafras from their euonymus.

title: From Spain, Charges Against 20 in the Killing of 6 Priests in El Salvador in 1989
description: MEXICO CITY  A Spanish judge issued arrest warrants on Monday for some of the top military leaders of El Salvadors civil war, accusing them of meticulously planning and carrying out the killings of six Jesuit priests in 1989.

title: Congressman, Sharp Voice on Twitter, Finds It Can Cut 2 Ways
description: For nine months, Representative Anthony D. Weiner has been tweaking others via Twitter, poking fun at Sarah Palin, John A. Boehner and especially Michele Bachmann as he offers his 46,000-plus followers an unusually candid window into the thoughts, activities and edgy humor of a politically ambitious congressman.

title: Egypts Christians Fear Violence as Changes Embolden Islamists
description: CAIRO  The headline screamed from a venerable liberal newspaper: Coptic Christians had abducted a young Muslim and tattooed her with a cross. Copts kidnap Raghada!

title: Belgian Church Will Pay Victims of Sexual Abuse
description: After a tumultuous year following the resignation of a Roman Catholic bishop who admitted sexually abusing children, the church in Belgium bowed to pressure on Monday and agreed in principle to compensate some of the hundreds who claim that they were also victims of clerics.

title: Photo Replay: May 30
description: A look back at the day in sports, from tennis in France to cricket in Wales.

title: Memorial Day Observed
description: Memorial Day events around New York included parades in Brooklyn and Staten Island and ceremonies at the Intrepid Sea, Air and Space Museum.

title: E. Coli Death Toll Grows in Europe
description: The authorities in Europe stepped up efforts on Monday to halt a deadly E. coli outbreak, and Spain and Germany argued over the source of the bacteria. Officials in Germany said the death toll had climbed to 13 in one of the largest outbreaks ever reported. Hundreds of Europeans have suffered from diarrhea, cramps and other symptoms, and vegetables have been pulled from shelves in a number of countries. Germany said Spanish cucumbers could be a source, an announcement that Spain called an irresponsibility and an atrocity. A crucial question was whether the disease could have developed on delivery routes between Spain and Germany, or in storage areas.

title: Reyes Goes on Leave, and Mets Slug 15 Hits
description: In a season riddled with injuries, underwhelming play and off-field distractions, Jose Reyes has been a consistent bright spot on the Mets. He is leading the National League in doubles, triples and hits, and playing with the abandon that is sure to make him much sought-after if he becomes a free agent after this season.

title: Governing, but Not Taking Any Questions
description: Utica, N.Y.

title: Lottery Numbers
An Arboreal Census of Central Park
description: A tour of the trees in Central Park with Ken Chaya and Edward Sibley Barnard.

title: Battle for Libya | May 30, 2011
description: As President Jacob Zuma of South Africa met with Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi in Tripoli, rebels in Misurata took up positions against government forces.

title: NYT: Front Page for 05/31/2011
description: NYT: Front Page for 05/31/2011

title: Assault Charges for Hotel Guest
description: A guest at the Pierre hotel in Midtown Manhattan was arrested on Monday on charges of sexually assaulting a housekeeper the night before, the police said Monday night.

title: Moodys Warns That It Might Downgrade Japans Debt
description: Moodys warned Tuesday that it might downgrade its sovereign debt rating for Japan, joining other rating agencies in taking a more pessimistic view of the Japanese economy after the March 11 earthquake and tsunami.

title: The Forces That Can Change FIFA
description: There are press conferences and there are press conferences. Those that take place in the real world generally take the form of question-and-answer sessions, and if the subject in the glare of the cameras has the necessary media skills then he or she will often enter into some light banter with the gathered scribes. Theres the option to refer to the questioners on first name terms as if greeting old friends. Everyone smiles, everyone goes home happy.

title: Tutus on a Deadline
description: The holidays are anything but calm at the New York City Ballet costume shop, where last-minute fittings coincide with preparation for the new season.

title: Word of the Day | killjoy

title: Test Yourself | English, May 31, 2011

title: Met Stars Back Out of Tour to Japan

They joined Jonas Kaufmann, another tenor who pulled out over concerns after the March earthquake, tsunami and nuclear disaster.

title: Do You Speak a Second, or Third, Language?
description: Cognitive neuroscientist Ellen Bialystok has been studying how being able to speak two languages sharpens the mind. In her conversation with Claudia Dreifus, she states that kids who are bilingual have a way of thinking that helps them better distinguish important information from the less important. Are you or someone you are close to able to speak two (or more) languages fluently? Have you noticed any advantages other than being able to communicate with more people?

title: PAI Partners to Sell Engineering Firm for $3 Billion
description: PAI Partners, the French buyout firm, said on Tuesday that it had entered into a period of exclusivity with an investment group led by Clayton, Dubilier & Rice and AXA Private Equity to sell its stake in the engineering company SPIE.

title: European Court Partially Backs Kremlin in Khodorkovskys Prosecution
description: MOSCOW  Mikhail B. Khodorkovsky, the former Russian oil tycoon who has been jailed since 2003, failed to prove that his prosecution was politically motivated, the European Court of Human Rights ruled Tuesday, while agreeing that the government had violated his rights.

title: Fantasy Focus: Moving the Needle
description: Its hard for a first-round pick to move up significantly, but aside from Jose Bautista, Ryan Braun is probably the top hitter in fantasy baseball this year. While Brauns 12 home runs and .588 slugging percentage through Sunday are improvements over last years rates, the number that jumps out most is his 13 steals in 14 attempts. Milwaukees new manager, Ron Roenicke, is more aggressive on the basepaths than his predecessor, Ken Macha: the Brewers are 14th in the majors in stolen bases this year, as opposed to 21st last year, and Braun in particular is getting the green light. At this pace, a 35-35 season is within reach, and with Braun, youre virtually assured a good batting average. Only Carlos Gonzalez and maybe Matt Kemp offer the same speed-power-average upside, and Gonzalez is struggling this year.Jacoby Ellsburys 2010 was a lost season because of rib injuries, but as he is 27, his value has never been higher. The 19 stolen bases through Sunday put him on pace for close to 60 steals, and thats not accounting for chilly early-season conditions that often slow the running game. Ellsbury also has 6 home runs and 16 doubles and is posting a .298/.368/.462 line in 208 at-bats while hitting leadoff in one of the leagues best lineups. In short, hes what the Red Sox hoped Carl Crawford would be when they gave him $142 million. Crawford was a late first-round pick in most leagues, and Ellsbury must be considered similarly at this point.

title: Kapoors Leviathan Fills Grand Palais in Paris
description: Invited for the fourth edition of the Grand Palaiss annual Monumenta exhibition, the artist Anish Kapoor chose to take the title of the event literally. His creation, titled Leviathan, fills the large-scale venue with a giant sculpture  measuring about 775,000 square feet  that seems to push the walls of the building and, within its interior, drenches the viewer with a blood-red hue.

title: Tuesday: So Old Its New Again
description: TUESDAYS PUZZLE  Weve all heard the somewhat pessimistic saying There are no new ideas, but the quote by the poet Audre Lorde in its entirety is actually There are no new ideas, just new ways of making them felt. Therein lies the challenge behind any creative endeavor.

title: Keeping Score: Championship Characteristics in the N.B.A. Finals
description: After analyzing the championship games or series of the N.F.L., N.B.A., Major League Baseball and N.H.L., and the major finals in golf and tennis, we identified 50 championships characteristics in our book, Who Will Win the Big Game? A Psychological and Mathematical Method. Based on this research, we focused on several championship characteristics that might help predict the winner of the N.B.A. finals, which start Tuesday night in Miami. Last years analysis highlighted leadership factors and correctly predicted that the Lakers would win the championship.

title: Karzai Gives Last Warning to NATO on Airstrikes

title: China: Tiananmen Payment Discussed, Activists Say
description: A group of mothers demanding justice for the victims of the Tiananmen Square massacre of June 4, 1989, said Tuesday that police officials in Beijing had contacted one family in April to discuss giving compensation for the death in that family. It was a rare instance in which officials had mentioned compensation in relation to the killings. However, the group said in a letter circulated on the Internet that the police officials did not talk about revealing the truth of the killings, legal redress or the possibility of addressing each case. Instead, they simply raised the issue of how much money should be given and stressed that this is for individuals, not the group as a whole, said the letter, which had 127 signatures. The group said: The bottom line is this: the souls of those killed during June 4 shall not be defiled; their families shall not be dishonored.

title: Palin Ditches Press and Tours Battlefield
description: GETTYSBURG, Pa.  Sarah Palin took a brief tour of the Gettysburg battlefield and cemetery Tuesday morning as she and her family continued their One Nation tour of historical sites.

title: Using Public Relations to Drive Demand
description: Jill Cartwright hatched the idea for Go GaGa, an online retailer of bags used to tote everything from baby gear to camera equipment, while earning her M.B.A. at Babson. She graduated and started the company in 2007. That fall, she attended trade shows ABC Kids Expo, ENK Childrens Club, and New York International Gift Fair. She emerged with pre-orders and began producing her products, which she says are differentiated by an ergonomically safe strap, in January, 2008.

title: Expressive Attraction
description: Every day Kevin Lewis, who covers the social sciences for National Affairs and the Boston Globe, blasts out an email of wonky goodnessa collection of 10 to 20 study abstracts. Last Saturdays was particularly rich. He sent out the abstract of a study by Jessica Tracy and Alex Beall from a forthcoming issue of Emotion.

title: Iraq: Arrest in Killing of Anti-Baathist Politician
description: A former member of Saddam Husseins intelligence service was arrested in the assassination of Ali Faisal al-Lami, left, a politician who oversaw efforts to purge scores of candidates from national ballots because of ties to the former government, the Iraqi police announced Tuesday. They said the suspect was arrested in the Taji area north of Baghdad but did not release his name or provide any evidence tying him to the killing. Mr. Lami, a Shiite Muslim, was gunned down Thursday night as he drove through Baghdad, becoming one of the most prominent victims of an assassination campaign aimed at security forces and government officials. As the head of Iraqs Accountability and Justice Commission, Mr. Lami played a central role in last years politically divisive attempt to bar a number of candidates, many of them Sunnis, from parliamentary elections.

title: Should Medical School Be Free?
description: Can free medical school help fix the American health care system? In this weekends opinion section, two physicians, Dr. Peter B. Bach and Dr. Robert Kocher, propose that it can.

title: Schiavone Recovers and Outlasts Pavlyuchenkova

title: Makeshift Effort Rising to Oppose Cuts

There were gatherings at subway stations organized by the citys public advocate, Bill de Blasio, at which hundreds of parents recorded messages and signed petitions against cuts to their childrens schools.

title: The End-of-School-Year Scramble
description: In the conversation on Motherlode last week about how some parenting norms differ by neighborhood, many of you mentioned relationships with teachers. In some school districts, it is expected that parents will be present for all school activities; at others a parent who shows up too often is seen as pushy. In some places showering the teacher with end of year gifts is expected; elsewhere, is it frowned upon.

title: A New York Dog Makes Its Hollywood Debut
description: HOLLYWOOD  It is tucked in a storefront a block from the Walk of Fame, walking distance from the annual Academy Awards ceremonies, and steps from the hubbub of tourists, hucksters and celebrity hunters that is Hollywood: a Papaya King hot dog stand, in all its garish yellow and orange glory, selling hot dogs imported straight from the Bronx.

title: Suspect Held in 06 Killing of Journalist in Moscow
description: MOSCOW  The Russian authorities on Tuesday arrested the man they suspect of shooting the journalist Anna Politkovskaya, whose apparent contract killing in 2006 sent a chilling message about the hazards of challenging the powerful in contemporary Russia.

title: Kamoinge Photographers Convey Black Experience
description: Kamoinge, a group of mostly New York photographers who strive to capture the black experience, are creating an archive of their work. The group first assembled in 1963 and now has 24 members, with some focusing on documentary work, others on fine art. They are all driven by a similar passion: honest portrayal. What were documenting isnt just black history, said Russell Frederick, one of Kamoinges newer members. Its American history; its global history. Its something that everybody needs to see. Read and see more on the Lens blog.

title: Trichet to Leave a Difficult Legacy at Central Bank
description: FRANKFURT  Since Europes debt crisis became acute last year, the European Central Bank has gone beyond its role as arbiter of monetary policy to become in effect the adult supervision for quarreling heads of government.

title: In Twist, Federer Can Play Spoiler Against Djokovic
description: PARIS  Now it is Roger Federers turn to be the spoiler, and there is much to spoil.

title: Zumas Office Says Qaddafi Intent on Staying in Libya
description: JOHANNESBURG  In talks with South Africa President Jacob Zuma, the Libya leader Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi emphasized that he will not leave Libya despite air attacks and international pressure, according to a statement released Tuesday by Mr. Zumas office.

title: The Morning Line: Shackleford Settles In at Belmont
description: Shackleford, the winner of the Preakness, arrived at Belmont Park Monday morning. He arrived after an overnight 15-hour van ride from Churchill Downs. The New York Daily News reported that the 3-year-old colt is expected to gallop over Belmonts main oval Wednesday, before having an official workout over the strip Saturday. The Associated Press said that the trainer Dale Romans wants to make sure the 3-year-old colt is in top condition before committing to the Belmont.

title: The Twins Connection: Other Theories
description: As I wrote in Sundays cover story, 4-year-old conjoined twins Tatiana and Krista Hogan seem  based on casual observation and (as yet unpublished) scientific research  to share some sensory perception. Their neurosurgeon, Douglas Cochrane of British Columbia Childrens Hospital, believes that a neural bridge that links the thalamus of one girl to that of the other could explain why, for example, Tatiana would be able to see the stuffed animal Krista is holding, even when Tatianas eyes are closed.

title: Hospital call buttons, 30 years on the AIDS watch and the World Science Festival.

title: In Novel by Mayors Daughter, Hints of Family Life
description: Those who inhabit the rarefied world of Michael R. Bloomberg, with all its perquisites and payouts, have long adhered to a strict code of silence about his personal life: jaunts to Bermuda are cloaked in secrecy, tax returns are heavily redacted and even his golf handicap is off limits.

title: Headed Back to Court, N.F.L. May Gain Clarity
description: At the N.F.L. owners meeting last week, John Mara, the president of the Giants, was asked if the Super Bowl, scheduled for February in Indianapolis, would be played. Yes, he told a reporter, he was confident Indianapolis would have its Super Bowl.

title: As Chinas Workers Get a Raise, Companies Fret
description: HONG KONG  Wages are surging this year in China and among its main low-wage Asian rivals, benefiting workers across the region. But the increases confront trading companies and Western retailers with cost increases and are making higher prices likely for American and European consumers.

title: Crises at FIFA and Ohio State
description: Memorial Day is normally a placid day in sports that allows us to remember what were supposed to be remembering, and no, not just how long to grill the burgers. But on Monday the whole metaphorical barbecue flared so badly that all our eyebrows got singed: Ohio State Coach Jim Tressel felt the flames lapping at his sweater vest and quit amid a deepening N.C.A.A. scandal, and Sepp Blatter, the president of FIFA, called a nonsensical news conference to proclaim there is no scandal in his organization because he says so and because he is FIFAs president, You cannot question me. Feel free to imagine him shaking a spatula at you.

title: A Saudi Activist, in Her Own Words
description: As Arab News reported, a Saudi woman who was detained for more than a week for defying Saudi Arabias ban on female drivers was released on Monday.

title: Standing When the First Lady Pays a Call
description: On Memorial Day, Michelle Obama made an unannounced trip to visit the wounded at Walter Reed Army Medical Center. Joao Silva of The New York Times was among those on whom she paid a call. She came across as a kind and attentive person, Mr. Silva said. She asked about the progress of his recovery and gave yo-yos, Frisbees and White House candies to his children, Isabel, 6, and Gabriel, 5.

title: Why Did Apple Pre-Announce Its Announcement?
description: New product announcements by Apple usually take place with the secrecy of a clandestine military operation.

title: The Vogue Intern | Katie Ermilio
description: Its a well-known fact that Vogue assistants often move on to become designers: Irini Arakas of Prova, Aimee Cho of Gryphon and Eviana Hartman of Bodkin. But who knew that Vogue interns also graduate from the 12th floor right into their own fashion labels? In fairness, Katie Ermilio, who interned at Vogue, had a stint at Teen Vogue before leaving to devote herself full time to making clothes. I grew up in the business, says Ermilio, whose dad owns Ermilio Clothiers, a bespoke mens-wear shop in Philadelphia. But I always thought I was going to be a fashion editor  I had no interest in becoming a designer at all.

title: Historical Society Snags a Founding Fathers Notebooks
description: The New-York Historical Society, already the repository of several sets of original notes by delegates to the Constitutional Convention of 1787, received yet another last week: the notebooks of John Lansing Jr. of New York, who recorded many of the conventions debates.

title: Eamon Dolan to Leave Penguin Press
description: Eamon Dolan, a prominent editor at the Penguin Press who lost one of his titles in a recent shake-up at the publisher, will leave to run his own imprint for a competitor, Houghton Mifflin Harcourt.

title: Nokia Lowers Second-Quarter Forecast and Abandons 2011 Profit Goals
description: Nokia, the cellphone giant battling to maintain its position in the face of competition from the iPhone and Android, said Tuesday that it was abandoning its 2011 profit targets after an unexpectedly poor second-quarter showing.

title: What Hobbit Curse? Jacksons Movies Get Star-Crossed Release Dates
description: As if to prove that there are no supernatural forces working against Peter Jacksons Hobbit movies, for which that director has already contended with a labor dispute, the occasional explosion and emergency ulcer surgery, the studios have settled on some interesting release dates for the two-part fantasy epic. New Line Cinema, Warner Brothers and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer said in a joint statement reported by The Associated Press that the first Hobbit movie would open on Dec. 14, 2012, when some scholars say is the 509th anniversary of the birth of Nostradamus, the French astrologer and soothsayer. (Historical spoilsports say he was born on Dec. 21.) And the concluding Hobbit film will be released on Dec. 13, 2013, a date that not only has two 13s but is also, wouldnt you know it, Friday the 13th.

title: Pakistani Journalist Who Covered Security and Terrorism Is Found Dead
description: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  A well-known Pakistani journalist has been found dead after being abducted over the weekend in an upscale neighborhood here and receiving repeated threats from Pakistans premier intelligence agency.

description: SANTIAGO, Chile  A newly disclosed military legal file has cast fresh doubt on whether former President Salvador Allende, who died during the September 11, 1973 military coup, committed suicide, as the official version and his own family have always claimed.

title: Bartoli Bounds Past Kuznetsova Into Semifinals
description: PARIS  Marion Bartoli of France likes to bounce up and down as she stands at the baseline preparing to serve. There was extra bounce in the 23rd minute of her quarterfinal match Tuesday at the French Open.

description: Ad Store, New York, is opening a satellite office, in Kabul, Afghanistan, to be led by Massoud Etemadi, an Afghan native who is the creative director of the Ad Store Washington office. Mr. Etemadi will be president of Ad Store Kabul, which will operate under the direction of Ad Store D.C.

title: Reaction to Dempsey Appointment
description: Our colleagues Helene Cooper and Thom Shanker report on President Obamas nomination of Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the Army chief, to succeed Adm. Mike Mullen as chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. In a brief Rose Garden announcement in the midst of Memorial Day observances, Mr. Obama highlighted the dual roles that General Dempsey, who, as chairman, will be the countrys highest-ranking military officer, must fill as the United States brings its troops home from Iraq, begins withdrawing from Afghanistan and takes part in the NATO operation in Libya. General Dempsey, the president said, understands that military gains and political progress must go hand in hand.

title: Strange Creatures Promote Montreals Festivals
description: Theres a scene in the musical Bells Are Ringing in which a character gets so excited about meeting a fabulous creature that he joyously breaks into song. Imagine what he would have done if he had come across a new campaign with a menagerie of marvelous beasts.

title: Peace Without Partners
description: It seems like months ago, rather than a week, that President Obama tried to move the Mideast ball down the field a bit, and Israels prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, came to Washington. The applause in Congress for Netanyahus speech last Tuesday  the adjective universally used was rapturous  found an odd counterpoint in the negative reaction among most commentators. Fareed Zakaria simply ruled Netanyahu out of history.

title: Monfilss Magic Evaporates as Federer Advances
description: PARIS  Frances newest favorite tennis son, Gael Monfils, broke Roger Federers serve early in the first set, took 2-1 lead in their quarterfinal match on Tuesday at the French Open and made it look like it wasnt much of an obstacle.

title: India and Pakistan Fail to Resolve Glacier Dispute at Talks
description: NEW DELHI  The slow, uncertain efforts to normalize relations between India and Pakistan apparently made little progress on Tuesday, after defense secretaries from both countries failed to deliver a breakthrough on demilitarizing a Himalayan glacier considered the worlds highest battlefield.

title: Atlanta Loses Thrashers as N.H.L. Returns to Winnipeg
description: After 15 years, the N.H.L. is returning to Winnipeg.

title: The Moons Tide
description: A study by Jeffry Rudski, Lauren Bernstein and Joy Mitchell in the Archives of Sexual Behavior studied the link between the menstrual cycle and perception. Female research subjects were asked to react to various Georgia OKeeffe paintings. Nearly a third of the women in the first half of their monthly cycle discerned sexual themes in her paintings, while only 6 percent of the women in the second half of their cycle did. Women who were taking oral contraceptives saw the paintings the same way throughout the month.

title: North and South Sudan Tentatively Agree to Demilitarize Disputed Border
description: JUBA, Sudan  Northern and southern Sudanese officials have agreed to a preliminary arrangement on demilitarizing the border between them, the African Union said Tuesday, though some officials from both sides immediately expressed skepticism of the deal, particularly its ability to resolve the dispute over the contested Abyei area.

title: Race and Dating
description: Internet dating is fertile territory for people who study social patterns. Belinda Robnett and Cynthia Feliciano studied racial exclusion patterns in the Journal Social Forces. They looked at over 6000 internet dating profiles and found that whites are least open to dating outside their group, with Asians and Latinos close behind. Asian males and black females are more highly excluded than their opposite sex counterparts.

title: New Rescue Package for Greece Takes Shape
description: LONDON  A new rescue package for Greece is taking shape, one that would offer billions of euros in new loans in return for accelerated privatization and tougher tax collection measures on the part of the beleaguered Greek government, European officials said on Tuesday.

title: To Much Skepticism, Syria Issues Amnesty
description: As nationwide protests in Syria entered their 12th week, President Bashar al-Assad issued a general amnesty on Tuesday, Syrian state media reported.

title: How Ashland Won International Specialty
description: For Ashland, the roots of its second-largest acquisition, International Specialty Products, lie in its biggest deal.

title: Andy Robustelli, Giants Hall of Fame Defensive End, Dies at 85
description: Andy Robustelli, the Giants Hall of Fame defensive end in their glory years of the late 1950s and early 60s, when shouts of DEE-fense rang from the stands at Yankee Stadium, died on Tuesday in Stamford, Conn., his hometown. He was 85.

description: Has standing in line for tickets to The Book of Mormon become too much of a mission? A new app could make getting tickets to Broadway shows as easy as a tap of the finger.

title: Fast Cars, Medieval Villages
description: 9:51 a.m. | Updated Ear plugs in, my friend Tom and I watched in awe from our seats three rows above the Monaco Grand Prix course as famous Formula One pilots Id never heard of lurched around the sharp turn in front of us, their engines turning at up to 18,000 r.p.m.s, making the noise of 18 million high-speed hornets. Just across the track, Champagne-sippers watched from their yachts in the bay.

title: Former Buckeye Nicklaus Weighs In on Tressels Resignation
description: DUBLIN, Ohio - Like anyone with any connection to Ohio State University athletics in this central-Ohio suburb of Columbus, Jack Nicklaus had opinions about the resignation of the Buckeyes highly successful football coach Jim Tressel this week.

title: Year-End Roundup | Social Studies, History, Geography and Civics
description: The school year is drawing to a close, and our lesson plans have already gone on summer vacation. So this week were looking back at the 2010-11 school year and collecting the years teaching materials by subject matter, starting today with social studies, American history and civics, global history, economics and geography.

title: A Day in the Unelectrified Life, by Renault
description: Carlos Tavares, the former Nissan Americas head, recently was named the new chief operating officer at Renault. Along with Renault-Nissan chairman Carlos Ghosn, Mr. Tavares has been an outspoken proponent of electric vehicles, appearing at various conferences to tout the Nissan Leaf E.V. and sound the trumpet for strengthening private and public outlays for E.V. infrastructure.

title: The Fatty Crew Comes to the Battery
description: After some delay, the first kiosk of Fatty at the Battery, as Zakary Pelaccios Fatty Crew company is calling their new stands in Battery Park near Castle Clinton, will open Wednesday Thursday (they had to delay it a day) from noon to 7 p.m., selling hot dogs, hamburgers and sandwiches. (After that it will be open 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. daily.) Called Fatty Cue, its to the left of a planted area called the Battery Bosque, in what had been Will Goldfarbs Picnick stands. Fatty Snack, with pastries and ice cream will follow in about a week, once the ice cream machine is installed, and it will be farther the castle. There is some seating around the kiosks. For Kevin Pomplun, one of the chefs, its a reprise: he worked at Picnick.

description: NBC, perhaps confirming its conviction that The Voice represents its best shot at a breakout hit in many years, announced Tuesday that it would offer a special edition of the singing competition on one of the best platforms in television  the hour after the conclusion of next seasons Super Bowl.

title: At Ballet Theater, Popping the Question After the Pli
description: Perhaps its the influence of all those story ballets, where love mostly triumphs (at least when no-one is dying young and becoming a Wili). American Ballet Theater seems to be experiencing an unusual rush of real romance, with three engagements over the last two weeks. On the opening night of the season, Ethan Stiefel proposed to his longtime girlfriend Gillian Murphy on the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House, moments after she and her partner David Hallberg had taken their curtain calls for the Tchaikovsky Pas de Deux. A few days later, the about-to-retire Cuban star Jose Manuel Carreo and corps de ballet dancer Melanie Hamrick announced their engagement. And on Friday, which happened to be the 30th birthday of the Royal Ballet guest artist Alina Cojocaru, her longtime on-and-offstage partner Johan Kobborg (who had arrived unexpectedly to fill in for the injured Maxim Beloserkovsky at the Saturday matinee of Giselle) popped the question. Perhaps Alexei Ratmansky will choreograph a wedding dance.

title: Republicans May Need Exit Strategy From Medicare Plan
description: Is Representative Paul Ryans budget plan unpopular?

title: Analysis: Schiavones Comeback
description: As I watched Francesca Schiavone claw her way back into the second set against Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova, I remembered a story Id heard about Allen Fox, the legendary coach and tennis guru who helped develop Brad Gilbert at Pepperdine. Fox would tell his players to persevere when they were struggling in a match, and to believe that if they just kept battling, their level of play would almost certainly rise.

title: A Date for the Prom: Carrie Sets Key Casting and First Performance Off Broadway
description: After a year of work, MCC Theaters stab at salvaging the musical Carrie from the Broadway flop hall of shame is far enough along that the company announced on Tuesday that it will produce the show next season, with preview performances set to begin Off Broadway on Jan. 31, 2012.

description: An audit by the New York City comptrollers office has found deficiencies in the citys window-guard enforcement program, which prevents children from falling through open windows.

title: Enhancing the Image of Feminist Art
description: Can you name three female artists? The people asked that question outside the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art and the Whitney Museum of American Art cant get much beyond Frida You-Know-Who-I-Mean. Thats old, sad news to Lynn Hershman Leeson, the director of !Women Art Revolution  !W.A.R.  a documentary history of the feminist art movement.

description: The Intact Financial Corporation, the big Toronto-based insurer, said Tuesday that it had agreed to buy the Canadian insurance operation of the AXA Group of Paris for 2.6 billion Canadian dollars in cash ($2.68 billion).

title: Met Museum to Add Hours, Charge $50 to Accommodate McQueen Show Crowds
description: High fashion and money have always gone together, and for the next few weeks, they will do so in the museum world as well as on the racks. The Metropolitan Museum of Art said Tuesday that its Alexander McQueen show, which it recently extended by a week to accommodate the overflow crowds, will be opened during special viewing hours on Mondays, when the Met is usually closed, for patrons willing to buy $50 tickets.

description: The woman who accused two New York City police officers of rape released a statement on Tuesday expressing her disappointment in the jurys verdict. What follows is the statement from the woman, who requested that her name not be used:

title: Daviss Return From Injury Delayed
description: First baseman Ike Davis had a setback in his recovery from a bone bruise in his left ankle when a foot specialist told him Tuesday to wear a protective boot for another three weeks, meaning his return to the Mets is at least a month away.

title: How to Succeed in (Show) Business: Broadway Season Box Office Up Nearly 6 Percent
description: Broadway had another billion-dollar season between late May 2010 and Sunday, with shows grossing $1.08 billion  5.9 percent more than the total for the 2009-10 season  and playing to more than 12.5 million people, according to the Broadway League, the trade group for theater owners and producers. That 2010-11 season attendance figure also reflects an increase of 5.4 percent over the previous season.

title: Lunar Expedition
description: We first met in Toronto, friends of friends, met on the scene, you know? says the designer Jeremy Laing, referring to the artist Scott Treleaven. Laing is no stranger to the artist collaboration  in past seasons he worked with Karen Azoulay and also the band Grizzly Bear. For his fall collection (hitting stores this month), he and Trevleavan generated two different prints  a flaming hand and a moon  that will come in the form of silk jersey T-shirt and a slinky silk crepe dress. Jeremy was in a mood of luminance and transformation, which coincided perfectly, says Treleaven. We were both seeing these circle patterns and lunar imagery. The rest of the collection is a more subtle riff on the theme with crater-etched sweaters, voluminous wide-leg trousers and a black velvet sheath dress  albeit in the same pagan, slightly macabre spirit. I really appreciate the collaborative process; its a great way to keep engaged and grasp onto someone elses creativity, Laing says.

title: In a Bentley, Trying to Catch the Spotlight Again

title: Tenpenny
description: YOU may hardly believe it, walking in through the narrow, undistinguished lobby of the Gotham Hotel on East 46th Street to enter Tenpenny at the end of the hall. It looks like a half-finished Bennigans in there, all brick face and wood and half-filled bookshelves, with room on the walls for flair. A skylight in the rear of the dining room offers a view up the backsides of surrounding skyscrapers: it is the view from the bottom of a well.

title: New Hampshire Is Not Unique
description: I imagine that I may hear from a few people in New Hampshire and Iowa, in response to my column arguing for a different primary schedule. Someone may point out, accurately, that New Hampshire had the highest primary-voter turnout of any state in 2008  53.6 percent, according to the United States Elections Project at George Mason University. (Iowa, a caucus state, had a turnout of only 16.1 percent.)

title: A Bit of Hollywood, Minus the Tinsel
description: People who take things into their own hands and try to operate outside the institutional grid deserve our gratitude. So hats off to the organizers of Greater LA, a sprawling survey of recent art from Los Angeles arrayed in an immense, unrepentantly raw SoHo loft. It represents a tremendous effort on the part of three temporarily allied art professionals: Benjamin Godsill, a curator moonlighting from the New Museum; Joel Mesler, a partner in Untitled, an art gallery on the Lower East Side who began his art-dealing career in Los Angeles; and Eleanor Cayre, a New York collector and consultant who organized The Station, a large group show in Miami during the Basel Miami art fair in 2008.

title: A Chef Has a Way With French Pastry
description: The name of Olivier Dessyns new pastry shop in Greenwich Village, Mille-feuille, is a term for what Americans call a napoleon. The ones he makes, with cream and praline fillings, are first-rate indulgences. So are his beautifully burnished croissants (modest in size but flaky and practically oozing butter), his pains au chocolat and his almond croissants. Another specialty of this French pastry chef are fine macarons in many flavors. And no wonder: he worked in Paris with the chef Pierre Herm, who probably did more for the macaron than Proust did for the madeleine. Brownies (some with praline filling), cookies, madeleines and loaf cakes are also turned out by the busy bakers in the open kitchen. Soon, Mr. Dessyn promises summer fruit tartlets, clairs and other classics, as well as some sandwiches and salads to enjoy at the cafe tables that are coming for sidewalk snacks.

title: At Long Last, Tacos in Paris
description: PARIS

title: Seafood: Read All About It, and How to Cook It
description: Seafood: How to Buy, Prepare and Cook the Best Sustainable Fish and Seafood From Around the World has lavish color photography on each of its 400 pages. And even if you dont try any of the 300 recipes that take up more than half the book, there is plenty to read and to learn. And there is a wealth of good dishes to try. Sesame prawn toasts (call them shrimp toast), smoked fish mousses, crostini and lots of breaded and fried little seafood balls for hors doeuvres are suitable for summer cocktails. These are followed by soups, salads, pastas, one-pot stews, fish pies and tarts, an intriguing collections of curry recipes from various Asian sources, and dishes grouped by technique: frying, baking, roasting, poaching, broiling and grilling.

title: Pink and Green and Just to Cut Watermelon
description: You do not need a special knife for watermelon, but this one, with a watermelon-pink blade and a green handle, is as functional as it is fun. The blade is long (11 inches) and serrated to cut through the rind and the fruit. The little perforations that look like seeds and the blades bright silicone coating make slicing effortless. The knife comes in a matching sheath.

title: Clock Ticks for a Key Homeless Program
description: With New York Citys shelter population near all-time highs, the Bloomberg administration is on the verge of ending its signature housing program for homeless families, saying the programs generosity might have contributed to the problem.

title: The Manly Art of Cooking Has Its Bards
description: Not so long ago, most food-world workers  brewers, fishmongers, butchers  had jobs youd describe as blue collar. This is changing. These days the guy downtown who makes pickles and collects artisanal tattoos on his forearms probably went to Brown and has a failed novella on his laptop. We need a new term for these humans. Bleu collar?

title: Frozen Conflict Between Azerbaijan and Armenia Begins to Boil
description: BAKU, Azerbaijan  In a mostly empty Soviet-era building here on a recent morning, a 29-year-old woman pressed her eye against the scope of a sniper rifle, brown hair spilling over her shoulder, and took aim at virtual commandos darting between virtual trees.
